The debut release for the collaboration between Freddie Gibbs and Madlib features guest appearances from such artists as Ab-Soul, BJ the Chicago Kid, Danny Brown, Domo Genesis, Mac Miller, Raekwon, Scarface, and Earl Sweatshirt.

Although Lucinda Williams' recording career began in 1979, this is just her sixth full-length release, following 1998's well-received 'Car Wheels on a Gravel Road.' 'Essence' features 11 new trackes penned by Williams and co-produced by Charlie Sexton and Bo Ramsey.
This is the debut album for the quartet of Columbia University alumni.
The second full-length release for the New York-based artist was self-produced.

recordname: This (Is What I Wanted to Tell You)
description: The latest full-length release for the alt-country band led by Kurt Wagner was produced by Matthew McCaughan (who also co-wrote several tracks with Wagner).
The debut full-length release for the Jamaican reggae artist Koffee features production with JAE5 and Frank Dukes.
The debut full-length collaboration between Canadian duo Kacy & Clayton and New Zealand singer-songwriter Marlon Williams was recorded in 2019 in Saskatoon, Canada.

The debut full-length studio release for the rapper from Buffalo features guest appearances from Lloyd Banks, Benny The Butcher, Armani Caesar, DeJ Loaf, Elcamino, Flee Lord, Freddie Gibbs, Havoc, Method Man, and Westside Gunn.
The 15th full-length solo release for the British singer-songwriter was produced with Jan "Stan" Kybert.

recordauthor: A Winged Victory for the Sullen
description: The fifth-full length release for the ambient duo of Dustin O'Halloran and Adam Wiltzie was recorded at eight different European locations.
The second full-length release for the London-based Electronic producer is a sequel to his 2013 EP, Love Songs, Pt. 1.
The second full-length release from the duo of Cretan lute player George Xylouris and Dirty Three drummer Jim White was produced by Guy Picciotto.
This is the second full-length studio release for the British electronic band.
The compilation album for the experimental electronic band features remixes by Acid Girls, CFCF, Pink Skull, Narctrax, and Crystal Castles.
The fourth album for the indie rock band features Pulp's Richard Hawley on one track.
The first new studio album in 14 years for the country trio formerly known as the Dixie Chicks was produced with Jack Antonoff.
This is the full-length debut for French techno artist and DJ Pascal Arbez-Nicolas, best known for his 2001 single "La Rock 01" (which is included here).
The seventh full-length for the Korean pop band features guest appearances from Halsey and Sia.
The fifth full-length studio release for the pop band led by Hayley Williams was produced by Justin Meldal-Johnsen and band guitarist, Taylor York.
The the sixth full-length solo release for the guitarist features some original songs and was mixed by Chuck Johnson.
The second full-length solo release for the New Zealand singer-songwriter features a guest appearance from Aldous Harding and was produced by Noah Georgeson.
The Portland-based indie band releases its third album.
The third studio album under the Atlas Sound name was produced by Bradford Cox himself and Nicholas Vernhes.

The ninth full-length release for the indie rock band was produced by Danny Reisch and features contributions from such artists as Howard Draper, Jesca Hoop, Lucas Oswald, Brian Reitzell, Abram Shook, Cully Symington, and Wye Oak's Jenn Wasner.
The first new solo studio release for the British folk singer since 1978 was recorded in her home and was produced by Ian Kearey.
Produced with Biggi Veira, the synth-pop second release for the former Czars singer includes guest vocals from Sinead OConnor.
The fourth album from Brooklyn indie band led by Pete Silberman was influenced by the Eastern philosophy books Silberman was reading.
The sixth full-length release for the Philadelphia pop-punk band was produced by Joe Chiccarelli.
The latest release for the Australian artist features contributions from Chris Abrahams, Tony Buck, Mats Gustafsson, Thor Harris, Heinz Riegler, and Norman Westberg.
The first release in over six years for the Swedish dream pop band was influenced by the frustrations at the direction they felt Sweden is heading toward.
The first new release in 22 years for the British rock band was mixed by Chris Coady.
The latest full-length release for the singer-songwriter from Seattle was self-produced.
The latest full-length release for the Australian psych rock band is the third album in its "Explorations into Microtonal Tuning" volumes.

recordname: A Beautiful Thing: Idles Live at Le Bataclan
description: The first live release for the British post-punk band features the live recording from its 3 December 2018 set at the Le Bataclan in Paris.
The 15th full-length studio release for the pop singer features guest appearances from Blood Orange, Gunna, Slick Rick, and Ty Dolla Sign.
The latest full-length release from the Atlanta-based indie folk artist features a guest appearance from Mei Ehara.
The debut full-length release for the project formed by Palehound's Ellen Kempner and Jay Som's Melina Duterte was written and recorded over two weeks in Jan 2020.
Before the release of this debut solo album, Chris Porterfield was a member of DeYarmond Edison with Justin Vernon (aka Bon Iver) and Megafaun (Brad Cook, Phil Cook, and Joe Westerlund).
The fourth full-length release from the youngest son of Fela Kuti features a guest appearances from Carlos Santana and was produced by Robert Glasper.
The 10th full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter was produced by Mitchell Froom and is his first album of original songs in eight years.
The fourth full-length release from the Pennsylvania noise rock band was produced by Alex Newport.
The Brooklyn-based singer is minimalist in her music, using piano, drums, and her voice to make haunting songs--often drawing comparisons to Enya.

The fourth full-length solo studio release for former Smiths guitarist Johnny Marr was recorded during the COVID-19 lockdown with half of the tracks released on two EPs (Fever Dreams Pt. 1 and 2) in 2021.

The second full-length release for the Montreal artist features guest appearancesa from Durand Bernarr, Eight9fly, Estelle, GoldLink, Mick Jenkins, Masego, Teedra Moses, Iman Omari, Ari PenSmith, SiR, Tinashe, Kali Uchis, VanJess, Pharrell Williams, and Charlotte Day Wilson.
The fifth full-length release for the British alternative rock duo features guest appearances from Clarence Clarity, Ed Harcourt, and The Wytches.
The full-length debut release for Lorely Rodriguez was largely recorded in Mexico and self-produced.

Released exclusively on Apple Music/iTunes, the third full-length studio album for the rapper features guest appearances from such artists as Marsha Ambrosius, BJ the Chicago Kid, Eminem, The Game, Ice Cube, Justus, Kendrick Lamar, Craig Owens, Jill Scott, Snoop Dogg, and Xzibit.

recordname: Africa Express Presents...Terry Riley's In C Mali
description: Co-produced and mixed by Mouse on Mars' Andi Toma, Africa Express reinterprets Terry Riley's In C Mali.
The youngest son of Fela Kuti teams up with his father's band, Egypt 80, on this album produced by Brian Eno and John Reynolds.
The ninth album from the British progressive-rock band.

The Los Angeles band celebrates 30 years in the music business with this 12th studio recording, the first the band has self-produced. Guests include Café Tacuba, Dave Alvin, Tom Waits, Ruben Blades and Elvis Costello.

Yet another experimental indie band to arise out of the Chicago scene, the Fruit Bats are the brainchild of multi-instrumentalist and songwriter Eric Johnson, who has played with Ugly Casanova, I Rowboat, and Califone. On this second Fruit Bats LP, he is joined by Gillian Lisee and producer Brian Deck.

A former member of the San Luis Obispo, Calif. trio Rodriguez, singer-songwriter M. Ward gained a bit of a following while supporting Bright Eyes on tour in 2002, and has drawn comparisons to Giant Sand, Tom Waits, and Grandaddy. This is his third solo release.
San Francisco's Beulah, part of the Elephant 6 collective of indie-pop bands, returns with a follow-up to their well-received 1999 effort 'When Your Heartstrings Break.'

Philly's psychedelic Bardo Pond offer up a 72-minute, ten-track disc. This is their fifth official release, and like its predecessors, it continues the tradition of using a drug reference in the title.
The fifth full-length release for the Brooklyn rock quartet was produced by the band's singer/guitarist Austin Brown.
The third solo release for the ex-The Czars frontman was produced by John Congleton.
The latest release for the artist features contributions from BJ Cole. Sarah Smout, Bridget St John and was produced by Steve Gunn.
This third album from the Stockholm, Sweden indie-rock trio has attracted critical buzz on both sides of the Atlantic. Victoria Bergsman of the Concretes guests.
This is the second full-length studio release for the British indie rock duo of Rachel Zeffira and Faris Badwan.
The latest full-length release for the singer-songwriter features one original written by Steve Earle and 10 songs written by his late son, Justin Townes Earle, who passed away in August 2020.
The third album for the Pennsylvania hard rock band was produced by Alex Newport.
The third full-length release for Lorely Rodriguez as Empress Of was written over two months between tours.
The first full-length release in six year for the Chicago instrumental post-metal band in six years was produced by Sanford Parker.
The sixth full-length release for the Seattle-based singer-songwriter was self-produced.
Gunn Truscinski and Justin Tripp join the New York guitarist, who previously worked with Meg Baird, the Magik Markers, and Kurt Vile, on his fourth solo release.
The second full-length album for the California-born singer E. Nathaniel Dawkins goes for retro R&B and soul style.
This is the debut full-length release for Berlin-based electronic producer James Whipple.
Tony Berg and Eric Valentine produced this follow-up to 2002's Grammy-winning "This Side."
This is the third full-length solo release for the London-based experimental electronic artist.
Jason Molina releases four albums from four recordings sessions in a box set that includes a DVD, postcards, and a medallion.
The Philadelphia-based group releases a second album of Americana roots-rock.
The third full-length release for the doom metal band was mixed by Joe Barresi.
Steve Earle covers songs by the late Townes Van Zandt for his latest album.
The second full-length release for the singer-songwriter was produced by Eric Littman and was recorded at her childhood home in upstate New York.
The California producer/artist releases a seven-track EP four months after Cosmogramma, his third full-length album.
The second full-length release for the British artist features guest appearances from Nile Rodgers and Wretch 32.
The second full-length release for the British post-punk band was produced by James Ford.
The eighth full-length release is the first under the expanded name for the Philadelphia-based artist previously known as Alex G.
This multiculti London four-piece (making their full-length debut with 'Silent Alarm') has been heralded in seemingly every music magazine in the world as 2005's answer to Franz Ferdinand.

recordname: Epic Jammers and Fortunate Little Ditties
description: This is the debut full-length release for the collaboration between Bonnie "Prince" Billy and Bitchin Bajas.
The fourth full-length release for the noise rock trio from Kentucky was produced by Kevin Ratterman.
The third full-length release for the British electronic duo of Dominic Maker and Kai Campos features guest appearances from Andrea Balency, James Blake, King Krule, and Micachu.
The debut full-length collaboration between Marisa Anderson and William Tyler was recorded in Portland, Oregon.

The latest full-length release for the singer-songwriter and his band features songs used in the Jessica Blank and Erik Jensen play Coal Country, about the deadly West Virginia mine disaster in 2010 that killed 29 people.
The second full-length release for the post-punk quartet was produced by Johnny Hostile.
The Blue Nile frontman's debut solo album is his first record in eight years.
The fifth full-length release for the Brooklyn indie rock quartet was produced by the band member, Chris Taylor.
Arab Strap's Aidan Moffat and composer Bill Wells collaborated for more than eight years before releasing their debut album.
'Love Songs' is the first new studio album in ten years for a reunited Mark Eitzel & co.
The distinguished British musician returns with another solo effort showcasing his ability to reimagine classic jazz standards as well as revitalize a few from his own catalogue.
The latest full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter with his band was produced by Dave Cobb and features contributions from Rival Sons' Jay Buchanan and David Crosby.
The debut full-length studio release for the British electronic producer features contributions from Sam Beste, Finn Peters and a ten-piece string section arranged by Amy Langley.
The sixth full-length release for the Los Angeles-based electronic artist is a concept album about the four stages of life.
This 43-song, 4-disc set is composed of all new recordings in roughly four different styles (one per disc): rock, country, acoustic bluegrass, and ballads.
'De-Loused' is the heavily anticipated debut LP from the group formed by former At The Drive-In members Cedric Bixler and Omar Rodriguez.
This is the fourth full-length release for the Australian indie band formed by siblings and a friend in Brisbane.

After a six-year break and the departure of Rostam Batmanglij, the New York indie-rock band is finally back with a fourth studio album, produced by Ariel Rechtshaid and frontman Ezra Koenig. Guests include Dave Longstreth (Dirty Projectors), Steve Lacy (The Internet), Danielle Haim, and Jenny Lewis.

recordname: One Day I'm Going To Soar
description: Dexys Midnight Runners returns with the shortened name Dexys for its first studio album in 27 years.
The Los Angeles punk band returns with its first album in 35 years featuring the original lineup of D. J. Bonebrake, Exenne Cervenka, John Doe, and Billy Zoom.

The fourth full-length studio release for the Southern California artist features guest appearances from André 3000, Brandy, Nate Dogg, Sonyae Elise, Lalah Hathaway, Smokey Robinson, and Jazmine Sullivan.
The second full-length release for the Virginia singer-songwriter was produced with Mathew E. White.
The fifth full-length release for the indie-folk husband-and-wife duo of Michael Trent and Cary Ann Hearst was recorded at their home studio in South Carolina.
The seventh full-length release fore the British singer-songwriter was produced by Flood.
This is the third full-length album for the Canadian punk rock band.
The latest album on the Temporary Residence label for the Oregon quartet.
The Vancouver, Canada indie supergroup attempts to duplicate the success of 2000's 'Mass Romantic' with this sophomore release. Neko Case returns to handle vocal duties.

This is the second international release for Japanese producer/remixer/artist/recording star Cornelius (Keigo Oyamada), following his 1998 breakthrough debut for Matador, 'Fantasma.' A bit less cut-and-paste than its predecessor, 'Point' still showcases a range of musical styles in its 11 tracks.

You take the good, you take the bad, you take them both and then you have... the second album from the UK outfit featuring members of the Auteurs and Jesus and Mary Chain. The title track was a Top 20 hit in the UK.
The fourth studio album from the Austin, Texas-based band mixes it up with the help of Jim Eno of Spoon.
The 13th solo release for the Hüsker Dü and Sugar frontman was inspired in part by his recent move to Berlin.
The double album release from Phil Elverum as Mount Eerie includes a ten-minute song.
The eighth full-length release for the Japanese experimental rock band is its first with new drummer, Mishina.
The debut full-length release for the all-female British post-punk quartet was produced by Johnny Hostile and Rodaidh McDonald.
The second release for the British electronic artist includes a track produced by Brian Eno and another track with RZA as a guest performer.
The artist combines the sounds of Americana and Asia for her first album on the Rounder label.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Massachusetts alt-metal band is its final album with bassist Caleb Scofield, who died in a car accident in 2018.
This is the first album in over 12 years for the Sacramento rock band who is cited as an influence by such bands as Thursday and Blink 182.
Quirky, flamboyant, and young, English multi-instrumentalist Wolf makes his major-label debut with this third album of electro-folk-glam-rock. Marianne Faithfull guests.
The latest full-length release for the San Francisco garage rock band led by John Dwyer was recorded and mixed by bandmember Chris Woodhouse.
Erika M. Anderson of Gowns returns with her debut solo full-length album.

recordname: We Shall Overcome: The Seeger Sessions
description: The Boss' first all-covers album contains 13 tracks associated with folkie Pete Seeger.
The latest full-length solo studio release for the Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter was written while staying in Wales.
The third full-length release for the British duo Let's Eat Grandma was produced with David Wrench.

recordname: Where You Go I Go Too
description: The Norwegian producer's album has only three tracks, but one is nearly 29 minutes long.
Named after a suburb of his native Sheffield, England, 'Lowedges' is the third solo release for the Pulp guitarist.
The debut full-length release for Alabama-based singer-songwriter Ethel Cain was self-produced.
This is the third LP for the Brooklyn five-piece fronted by deep-voiced Matt Berninger.
The eighth full-length release for the Atlanta indie rock band was co-produced with Ben H. Allen, Cate Le Bon, and Ben Etter.
The fifth full-length release for the Detroit post-punk band was produced by David Tolomei.
The debut full-length release for the Canadian artist was co-produced by Tim Gowdy.
This is the final album for the rock trio who decided to end the band after the death of drummer Charles Gocher in 2007.
Antony Hegarty and his band recorded live in Denmark with the Danish National Chamber Orchestra some of the songs from the group's four previous releases with new arrangements.

The fifth and final album from The Delgados (released on the band's own Chemikal Underground label) was co-produced with Tony Doogan. It ditches the strings of its orchestral predecessor, 'Hate,' to take a much poppier approach.
UGK's Bun B sophomore solo album's featured guests include Sean Kingston, Pimp C, Lupe Fiasco, Lil Wayne, Mya, Chamillionaire, and Juvenile.
The fourth full-length release for the Philadelphia noise-rock trio of Mike Polizze, Jason Killinger and Ben Leaphart was recorded in 2014.

recordname: Rap Or Go To The League
description: The fifth full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from Marsha Ambrosius, Chance the Rapper, E-40, Ariana Grande, Kodak Black, Kendrick Lamar, Lil Wayne, Travis Scott, Ty Dolla Sign, and Young Thug.
The latest full-length release for the Ukrainian pianist/composer features contributions from David Allred, Anne Müller, and Hatis Noit.
The sixth full-length release for the British folktronica collective feature the original line-up.
The debut full-length solo release for the Slow Club/The Surfing Magazines member was self-produced.
The eighth full-length release for German pianist/composer Volker Bertelmann under the name Hauschka features player pianos (also known as pianolas).

recordname: A Cosmic Rhythm with Each Stroke
description: The debut full-length release for the duet between Vijay Iyer and Wadada Leo Smith was produced by Manfred Eicher.
The latest release for the Italian experimental jazz-metal band is its first with new drummer Gabe Serbian.
The second album under his real name combines the sounds of electronic, folk and rock music.
The album features 21 tracks never before released by the late singer/songwriter Arthur Russell.
The experimental indie-rockers led by Jamie Stewart return with album number four.
The two-disc collection of the punk rock band's singles plus five unreleased tracks (demos, outakes, and session versions).
The fourth full-length release for the alt-country singer-songwriter was produced by Joe Viers.
The fifth release for the Philadelphia singer-guitarist was produced by John Agnello.
The third full-length release for the St. Louis indie rock band was produced by Matt Bayles.
The fourth full-length release for the Michigan post-hardcore band was produced with Will Yip.
The ninth full-length release for indie rock band was co-produced with Dave Fridmann.
The seventh full-length solo release for the Australian singer-songwriter was produced by Victor Van Vugt.

The British folk singer-songwriter worked with Steve Gunn, who also produced the album features guest vocals from Bridget St John and a band that includes Nathan Bowles, James Elkington, and Jimy SeiTang.
The tenth studio release for the Afrobeat drummer was recorded in France with the Jazzbastards.
His age? 58. And "At My Age" marks the first studio recording for the English singer-songwriter in six years.

The fourth full-length from the Philadelphian songwriter showcases his ability to weave stories and strings together with his lyrical craftsmanship  comparable to Tom Petty and Bob Seger  and guitar-playing skills.
The 20th studio release for the multiple Grammy-winning blues singer-songwriter was self-produced.
The second album for Los Angeles producer Henry Laufer is the first to feature his vocals.
The moody alt-country band led by David Eugene Edwards returns with its darkest set of songs yet.

Now into their third decade of recording, Sonic Youth offer up a return to form that has more in common with their output of the 80s than with anything they have released in recent years. Multi-instrumentalist Jim O'Rourke, who worked with the band on their previous effort 'NYC Ghosts & Flowers,' is now a full-fledged member of the group.

Often compared to Doves and Radiohead, Manchester-based Elbow is yet another new alternative band to emerge from the British music press hype machine. This debut album was shortlisted for 2001's Mercury Music Prize.

recordname: Discovery of a World Inside the Moone

description: The third full-length release for the New York-based Canadian pop artist was again produced with Junior Boys' Jeremy Greenspan.
The third album for the son of Ali Farka Toure integrates different musical styles with his Malian music and includes such guest stars as Dave Matthews, Derek Trucks, and John Scofield.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles singer-songwriter was produced with Ty Segall and features contributions from Mikal Cronin, Nick Murray and Segall.
This is the sixth studio release for the instrumental British post-rock band.
This is the second solo release for the former Supergrass lead singer.
The fourth full-length release for the dream pop group led by Ben Daniels was produced by band member, Jeff Ziegler.

The third full-length release for the electronic artist was created with the help of an A.I. program co-created by Herndon and Mat Dryhurst called Spawn and features guest appearances from Annie Garlid, Lily Anna Haynes, Evelyn Saylor, Spawn, Jenna Sutela, and Martine Syms.
The debut full-length release for the rock band who met at BRIT School was recorded by producer Dan Carey.
The second full-length release for the Virginia-based indie singer-songwriter was produced by Collin Pastore and mixed by John Congleton.

recordname: By The Time I Get To Phoenix
description: The latest full-length release from the Arizona alternative rap group is its last with Stepa J. Groggs, who passed away in June 2020 and features a guest appearance from Zelooperz.
The latest full-length release for singer-songwriter Natalie Mering was co-produced with Chris Cohen.

recordname: An Empty Bliss Beyond This World
description: British producer/experimental artist Jim Kirby releases his latest album under The Caretaker name.
The Philadelphia-born R&B singer/songwriter who has written songs for such artists as Christina Milian, Monica, and Jennifer Hudson, releases her second solo album.
Classical-minimalist composer Ben Frost makes eerie, ambient-electronic noise in By the Throat.
The second album for the son of Steve Earle was produced by RS Field and Steve Poulton.
This self-produced 20th album finds the New York band back down to a four-piece, with Jim O'Rourke dropping out after two albums.
The latest full-length release for the British artist previously known under the name East India Youth was completed from cassette recordings after a hard-drive failure.

The two-disc set includes a reworking of the incomplete "reversion" of Nico's Desertshore album with guest vocalists taking over lead vocals from Genesis P-Orridge, who left Throbbing Gristle in 2007. The Final Report contains songs by Chris Carter, Peter Christopherson, and Cosey Fanni Tutti before Christopherson passed away in 2010.

recordname: True Love Cast Out All Evil
description: The 13th Floor Elevators founder returns with his first album of new music in more than 10 years, and Okkervil River joins him as his backing band.
The third album for the New York band was produced by Nick Launay and Dave Sitek.

recordauthor: The Ghost of a Saber Tooth Tiger
description: The latest release from the duo of Sean Lennon and Charlotte Kemp Muhl was self-produced (except for one Mark Ronson-produced track) and mixed by Dave Fridmann.
The fourth full-length solo studio release for the singer-songwriter features guest appearances by Jack DeJohnette, Blake Mills, Rob Moose, Justin Vernon, and yMusic.
The second full-length release for the Indiana R&B/soul band sees drummer Aaron Frazer taking the lead on six songs.
The Swedish pop singer worked with producer Kieran Hebden and RocketNumber Nine on her first solo release in over 18 years.
The latest full-length solo release for the singer-songwriter features guest appearances from Chris Cohen, Carolyn Pennypacker-Riggs and Joan Shelley.
This is the debut full-length release for the indie pop trio from Brisbane, Australia.
The fifth studio release for the the country singer was recorded in Nashville and is her first album of original material since 2005s Humming By The Flowered Vine.
The second release since the reformation of the rock and R&B band (with new drummer Andy Jody and saxophonist Tom Quartulli) in 2010, is its first on the Bloodshot label.
Named after a character in Jurassic Park, the British trio releases their debut album, with band member Ayu Okakita's voice as a looped instrument.
The fifth album from Kieran Hebden is his first full-length release in five years.
The second full-release for the Los Angeles-based artist was self-produced and mixed.
The fourth full-length release for the R&B/soul singer and his band was recorded live with producer Gabriel Roth.
The latest full-length release for the solo project for Meghan Remy was recorded live in Montreal with 20 session musicians.
The sixth full-length release for the California singer-songwriter was recorded by Ben Chisholm.
The latest album for the duo of Daniel Auerbach and Patrick Carney features two tracks produced with Danger Mouse.

The second full-length release for the Toronto punk band was recorded despite a diagnosis of a possible end of Stefan Babcock's singing career due to a hemorrhaging cyst on his vocal cords if he continued.
Pulp frontman Jarvis Cocker makes his solo debut with this 14-song disc (which includes recent single "Running The World" as a secret bonus track).
This is the debut full-length album for the indie-rock duo from Vancouver, Canada.
The fourth full-length studio release for the experimental California singer-songwriter was produced with Ben Chisholm.
The third and final release of the trilogy of albums from the California-based alternative hip hop group.
The second full-length release for the group based in Niger was recorded by Jamie Carter.
The seventh release for the indie experimental rock band led by Tim Rutili was recorded in Arizona, California, and Texas.
The latest full-length release for Perfume Genius began as a soundtrack to Mike Hadreas and Kate Wallich's dance project, The Sun Still Burns Here.
The seventh full-length release for the country singer-songwriter features a guest appearance from Maren Morris and was produced by Jay Joyce.
This is the debut full-length release for the British electronic producer.
The first full-length release in seven years for the indie-rock band led by Spencer Krug and Dan Boeckner was produced by John Goodmanson.
The second album for the British rock band was produced by Portishead's Geoff Barrow.
The Good Life is a side project for Cursive's Tim Kasher, and this third full-length release (following the 'Lovers Need Lawyers' EP) finds him joined by Stefanie Drootin, Ryan Fox and Roger Lewis.
Vienna's Christian Fennesz, who creates ambient electronica based on processed guitar sounds, returns with his first solo studio effort in four years. David Sylvian guests on one track.
This is just the second full-length recording for the Birmingham, England experimental pop outfit founded in 1995. Included here is the track "Pendulum" from the recent EP of the same name.
This is the sophomore disc for the Norwich, England rock band (led by excitable vocalist Nikki Colk) who at times recall a harder-rocking Electrelane or a UK version of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs.
The third release from the trip-hop/indie/rock/electronic/jazz/pop band named after the first dog in outer space.
This is the 14th full-length studio release for the British electronic duo of of Sean Booth and Rob Brown.
The latest full-length studio release for the Atlanta indie rock band was produced with Ethan Gruska and Catherine Marks.
The pianist's follow-up to last year's Historicity, where he worked as part of a trio, is a solo album of originals and covers.
The latest full-length solo release for the indie singer-songwriter was recorded in Los Angeles with producer Rob Schnapf.
The first new studio release in 11 years for the Detroit rock band features a cover of Donovan's "Hey Gyp (Dig the Slow)" and was self-produced with Joshua V. Smith.
The debut full-length release for the Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter and cellist features production from Jamie xx, Rodaidh McDonald, Skrillex, and Adrian Younge.
The singer-songwriter worked with Rhys Edwards on her second full-length release sung entirely in the Cornish-language.
The fourth release for the British metalcore band was produced by Terry Date and is its first with Worship's Jordan Fish.
The fourth full-length release for the Nashville singer-songwriter was produced by Gabe Wax and mixed by Lars Stalfors.
The folk singer-songwriter's divorce from Tom Bevitori was an influence on the John Askew-produced fourth full-length release.
The debut full-length solo studio release for The Internet guitarist features guest appearances from Daisy and Amandla Stenberg.
This is the eighth full-length studio release for Matthew Cooper under the name Eluvium.
The tenth full-length studio album for the Oakland, California metal band was produced with Steve Albini.
The debut full-length release for the Australian singer-songwriter was produced by Dean Tuza.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Atlanta indie rock band was produced with Ben H. Allen III.
The 10th full-length studio release for the Boston Celtic punk band was produced by Ted Hutt.
The latest full-length release for the Polish alternative band led by Grzegorz Kwiatkowski was recorded, produced and mixed by Michal Kupicz.
The debut album for Tom Krell, a singer from Germany, includes tracks that were previously released on EPs.
Married couple Buddy and Julie Miller release their latest album together featuring guest artists including Robert Plant, Emmylou Harris, Patty Griffin, the McCrary Sisters, and Larry Campbell.
The second full-length release for the Scottish artist was again self-recorded and produced.
The third full-length release for the Queens-based experimental artist Alexandra Drewchin features guest appearances by Moor Mother and Odwalla1221.
In the works for over two years with producer Tony Visconti, this is the first new studio release from David Bowie in ten years.

The latest full-length solo release for Buffalo rapper Conway The Machine features guest appearances from 7xvethegenius, Benny The Butcher, Lil Wayne, Novel, Keisha Plum, Annette Price, Rick Ross, Jill Scott, Beanie Sigel, Jae Skeese, T.I., and Westside Gunn.
The third full-length release for the Philadelphia quartet features Jacob Ewald and Brendan Lukens splitting songwriting duties between themselves with production by Hop Along's Joe Reinhart.
Patti Smith's first album since 2004's Trampin' features guest appearances by her children Jesse and Jackson, Tom Verlaine, and Jack Petruzzelli.
Unreleased songs from folk legend Woody Guthrie are interpreted by Son Volt's Jay Farrar, Centro-matic's Will Johnson, Anders Parker, and My Morning Jacket's Jim James.
The fifth full-length studio release for the Austin singer-guitarist was co-produced with Jacob Sciba.

recordname: Never Were the Way She Was
description: The debut full-length collaboration between Arcade Fire's saxophonist Colin Stetson and violinist Sarah Neufeld was produced by Hans Bernard.
Vijay Iyer collaborates with Prasanna and Nitin Mitta to combine their different styles of music to create this jazz album.

The third album for the singer-songwriter was produced by The National's Aaron Dessner, who also guests on the release with fellow band member Bryce Dessner, Julianna Barwick, Zach Condon of Beirut, Matt Barrick of The Walkmen, and Jenn Wasner of Wye Oak.

recordname: Get Yer Ya-Ya's Out! The Rolling Stones In Concert [40th Anniversary Deluxe Box Set]
description: The rerelease of the two-night concert at Madison Square Garden in 1969 features five unreleased tracks and tracks from the opening acts: BB King and Ike & Tina Turner.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Boston-based post-hardcore band was produced by Kurt Ballou and is its first with new bassist Converge's Nate Newton.
The debut full-length release for the Los Angeles-born, London-based singer-songwriter who won the BBC Sound of 2020 features production from Josh Crocker, Jamie Hartman and John Hill.
The fifth full-length solo release for Dawn Richard was influenced by her hometown of New Orleans and features contributions from Cole M.G.N, Hudson Mohawke and Kaveh Rastegar.
The latest full-length release for Jaime Fennelly's solo project was originally Commissioned by the  Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago and was produced by Tortoise's John McEntire.
The second full-length release for the British alternative rock band was recorded by Dominic Mitchison.
The third full-length release for the Canadian country singer features a duet with former Civil Wars member John Paul White.
The latest full-length release for the Malian guitarist was produced by Philippe Sanmiguel.

recordname: Common Ground: Dave & Phil Alvin Play and Sing the Songs of Big Bill Broonzy
description: Blasters Dave and Phil Alvin come together for this tribute to Big Bill Broonzy.

recordname: Nashville, Vol. 1: Tear the Woodpile Down
description: The latest album from country singer Marty Stuart features his band, the Fabulous Superlatives and includes guest appearances by Hank Williams III and Lorrie Carter Bennett.
The Moonhearts singer-bassist, who also works with Ty Segall, releases his solo debut album.
This is the second of three planned volumes of newly recorded piano solo versions of Randy Newman's songs.
The Irish singer-songwriter releases his follow-up to his 2006 Mercury Prize-nominated album "The End of History."
The latest solo disc for the anticon producer (best known for his work in cLOUDDEAD) finds him joined by guests Mike Patton, Andrew Broder (Fog), and members of Subtle, Themselves and why?

The fourth full-length release for the Los Angeles rapper features guest appearances from Anderson .Paak, E-40, Jadakiss, Miguel, Candice Pillay, Lance Skiiiwalker, Vince Staples, SZA, Tha Dogg Pound, TF and Kanye West.
The debut full-length release for the Brooklyn singer-songwriter features contributions from Father John Misty, Tobias Jesso Jr. and The Dap-Kings.
The second release for the North Carolina indie rock band since they reunited in 2007 is its sixth full-length album.
The 14-track release for the Philadelphia R&B singer features guest appearances from Anderson .Paak, H.E.R. and Ari Lennox.
The 24-track release from the country singer-songwriter features songs co-written with Anderson East, Natalie Hemby, Jack Ingram, Ashley Monroe, Josh Osborne, Liz Rose, and Foy Vance.

The fifth full-length release for California alternative artist was produced by Converge's Kurt Ballou and features guest appearances from Queens Of The Stone Age's Troy Van Leeuwen and Isis/Sumac's Aaron Turner.
After his Grammy-winning collaboration with Emmylou Harris, the singer-songwriter returns with his 14th self-produced solo release.
The full-length release for the South African duo of Emmanuel Nzaramba and producer John Withers includes influences from African, electronic, R&B, reggae, and soul music.
The fifth full-length solo studio release for the pop singer-songwriter was produced by Four Tet.
The debut release for the Stereolab frontwoman's project with the Source Ensemble features a duet with Hot Chip's Alexis Taylor.
This is the debut full-length release for British electronic musician William Doyle.
Darren Cunningham's latest album as Actress was partially inspired by John Milton's Paradise Lost

recordname: Waterslide, Diving Board, Ladder to the Sky
description: The third full-length release for British indie rock quartet Porridge Radio was co-produced by Tom Carmichael with the band's own singer Dana Margolin and drummer Sam Yardley.
The second full-length release for the Nashville-based singer-songwriter was produced with Jarrad Kritzstein.
The fourth full-length release for the indie trio is its first since breaking up in 2014 and was produced with Rob Barbarto.
The second full-length release for the New York City alternative rock/pop band was produced by Joe Chiccarelli.

No, it's not *that* kind of drum'n'bass album. Instead, Rhode Island's Lightning Bolt literally consists of just two instrumentalists on drum and bass, and together the pair generate an experimental sonic fury on this, their second full-length.

Missy Elliott reunites once again with super-producer Timbaland on this, her fourth studio album. The lead single is "Work It," a huge success even before the album's release. Guests on the disc include Jay-Z, Ludacris, Beyonce Knowles, TLC and Method Man.

Singer-songwriter Suzanne Vega fills her sixth studio album with 13 new compositions. Former producer (and former husband) Mitchell Froom is gone, replaced by Rupert Hine, who creates an overall sound that is more like Vega's earliest recordings than her Froom-produced output during the 1990s.
The third full-length release for the New York-based Alabama singer-songwriter Katie Crutchfield was co-produced with Kyle Gilbride and Keith Spencer.
The third full-length release for the Atlanta-based indie singer-songwriter was co-produced with Drew Vandenberg.

The 14th full-length solo studio release for British singer-songwriter was recorded in just over three weeks and features contributions from Rod Argent, Martin Carthy, Erland Cooper, Connor OBrien, and Danny Thompson.
This is the fourth full-length for the Canadian indie-rock band led by Carey Mercer (also of Swan Lake).
The third full-length release for the Canadian indie band led by Jasamine White-Gluz was produced by Jorge Elbrecht.
The third full-length solo release for the British cellist and producer features guest appearances from Chrysanthemum Bear, Malibu and Kathryn Williams.
Al Green's latest album includes guests John legend and Anthony Hamilton. It was also produced in part by Willie Mitchell and Ahmir "?uestlove" Thompson.
This double-disc set is the influential singer-songwriter's first album in a dozen years.

The latest solo release for the former Screaming Trees lead singer features contributions from such artists as Greg Dulli, the Bad Seeds Warren Ellis, Ed Harcourt, Led Zeppelins John Paul Jones, Lamb of Gods Mark Morton, and Portisheads Adrian Utley.
The first new release in 15 years for the Ethiopian keyboard and accordion player features contributions from Tony Buck and Mike Majkowski.
The second full-length release for the London indie rock band was produced by Rory Atwell.

recordname: Parting the Sea Between Brightness and Me
description: Recorded over five days with producer Ed Rose, the second album for the Los Angeles post-hardcore band is its first on the Deathwish label.
The third full-length release for the Canadian singer-songwriter was written in a 19th century church near Lake Erie.
This ten-track album compiles versions of songs first released in 2005 as AFX's "Analord" series of (quite expensive) vinyl singles.
The second full-length release for Aly Spaltro as Lady Lamb was co-produced by Nadim Issa.
The debut full-length release for the British rapper features guest appearances from Jay Critch, Giggs, and Not3s.
The second full-length studio release for the R&B sister duo of Chloe and Halle Bailey features guest appearances from Swae Lee and Mike Will Made-It.
The fifth full-length release for the Oakland, California quartet was produced by the Black Keys' Dan Auerbach.

The debut full-length release from Cocteau Twins' bassist Simon Raymonde and Dif Juz's drummer Richie Thomas features guest appearances from such artists as Ghostpoet, Marissa Nadler, Horse Thief's Cameron Neal, The Innocence Mission's Karen Peris, Hilang Child/Ed Riman, ex-Midlake frontman Tim Smith, Sharon Van Etten, and Lanterns On The Lake's Hazel Wilde.

recordname: Now You Are One Of Us
description: The experimental Dallas, Texas outfit led by John Congleton returns with a spooky, noisy fourth album.
The Ohio country-rock singer is backed by Nick German, Ben Lamb, and Todd May on her third full-length release.
The third full-length release for the Philadelphia indie rock band led by Frances Quinlan was self-produced and recorded.
The latest album for the Canadian rapper was nominated for a Polaris Music Prize.
This is the fifth solo disc for the former Blur guitarist.
The latest full-length solo release for the British singer-songwriter was self-produced.
The Knife's Karin Dreijer Andersson releases her solo album under the name Fever Ray.
Produced by James Ford and Ross Orton, the fifth full-length studio release for the indie rock band includes guest appearances by Josh Homme, Bill Ryder-Jones, and Pete Thomas.
The second album for the rock band was produced by band member, Rostam Batmanglij.

The duo's fifth long-player, destined to be known as GBMS in record reviews everywhere, was recorded in their Detroit studio. While not a total departure from previous efforts, it does find them expanding their sound away from their usual guitar+drums formula.

The debut full-length release from British artist Kojey Radical features guest appearances from Cashh, Ego Ella May, hakka, Kelis, Lex Amor, Knucks, Masego, Rexx Life Raj, Tiana Major9, Shaé Universe, and Wretch 32.
The latest full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was self-recorded and produced.
The fourth full-length solo release for the Wilco singer was produced with Tom Schick and features his sons Spencer and Sammy.

The collaborative project brought together by Coldcut and Keletetla! Library founders Rangoato Hlasane and Malose Malahlela features appearances from such artists as Tony Allen, Antibalas, Shabaka Hutchings, Nono Nkoane, Tamar Osborn, Afla Sackey, Dele Sosimi, Tenderlonious, Thabang Tabane, The Watts Prophets, and Sibusile Xaba.
The eight-track soundtrack to the short film of the same name is a collaboration between Denzel Curry and Kenny Beats.
The second full-length release for the South African actor/singer was produced by Ben Christopher.
The fourth full-length release for the Swedish singer-songwriter features a 20th century pipe organ and was produced by Randall Dunn.

recordname: By the Way I Forgive You
description: The sixth full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter was co-produced by Dave Cobb and Shooter Jennings.
The fifth full-length release for Joan Wasser was produced with Thomas Bartlett and Parker Kindred.

The sixth full-length release for the British alternative rock band features contributions from Liz Corney, Ed Cross, Simon Dennis, Pete Fraser, Sarah Hayes, Ele Leckie, Jo Montgomery, and Chrissie Slater.
The second full-length release for the British alternative rock band was produced by Justin Meldal-Johnsen.
The debut full-length release for the New York City-based artist was recorded over a three year period with guest appearances from Jesse & Forever and Onyx Collective.

The third release for the John Colpitts project features guest appearances by Laurie Anderson, David Byrne, Nick Hallett, Trans Am's Phil Manley, Quince Contemporary Vocal Ensemble, TIGUE, and Yo La Tengo.
This is the first full-length studio release since 2009's Thriller for the British noise rock band.
This is the 12th and final release for the British collective led by Glen Johnson.
This is the debut full-length release for the Brooklyn R&B singer best known for being sample on Drake's "Jungle" track.
This is the debut full-length release for the London-based J-pop-influenced trio.
This is the second full-length solo release for the former frontman of Archers of Loaf and Crooked Fingers under his name.

recordname: If I've Only One Time Askin'
description: The fourth full-length release for the Canadian alt-country singer-songwriter was self-produced.
The second release of jazz classic from Keith Jarrett and Charlie Haden are from the same 2007 sessions as those on 2010's Jasmine.

The debut release for the British electronic duo of Guy and Howard Lawrence features guest appearances from AlunaGeorge, Eliza Doolittle, Sasha Keable, London Grammar, Ed Macfarlane, Sam Smith, Jesse Ware, and Jamie Woon.
The latest solo album for producer/MC Oh No utilizes sound samples from the soundtracks of Rudy Ray Moore's blaxpoitation films.
The fourth album for the Northumberland folk group was produced by Adrian McNally.
The more emotional third album for the New York-based singer/songwriter has a much simpler title than her 2008 release.
This is the debut album for the Long Beach, California-based rock band led by Avigdor Zahner-Isenberg, who also goes by the name Avi Buffalo.
The second album for the W. Cullen Hart-led indie rock band is its first in eight years.
The San Francisco-based band led by John Dwyer releases its follow-up to last year's "The Masters Bedroom is Worth Spending a Night In."
The French dance duo known for remixing songs from the likes of Franz Ferdinand emerge with their debut album.
This collaboration between MF Doom and Danger Mouse includes voices and skits from Cartoon Network's Adult Swim shows. Non-animated folks like Ghostface Killah, Cee-Lo & Talib Kweli also lend a hand.
The fourth album for the veteran Scottish band is their first album release in eight years and first U.S. release since 1993's 'I've Seen Everything.'
This is the second full-length for the Olympia, Wash-based indie-punk trio led by powerful singer Beth Ditto.
The 12th studio release for the singer-songwriter includes contributions from Jason Falkner, Smokey Hormel, Roger Joseph Manning Jr., Justin Meldal-Johnsen, and Joey Waronker.
The first release in over 15 years for the Los Angeles rock quartet was produced by band co-founder, Steven McDonald.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn indie rock band led by Adrianne Lenker was produced by Andrew Sarlo.
This is the follow-up to the British electronic producer's 2006's The Idiots Are Winning.
The debu full-length release for the New Orleans based singer-songwriter was produced by Andrija Tokic.
The second full-length release for the Irish noise rock band was recorded at Ballintubbert House.
Mary J. Blige, Anthony Hamilton, Miguel, Rick Ross, Swizz Beatz, and the late Amy Winehouse are guests on the tenth release for the rapper.

recordauthor: S U R V I V E
description: Fresh off scoring Netflix's Stranger Things, Michael Stein and Kyle Dixon and the other three members of the Austin synth band return with its self-recorded second full-length album on new label, Relapse Records.
Chris Walla produced this third album for the literary Portland, Ore.-based five-piece led by Colin Meloy.
The second full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was recorded in Nashville with Jay Joyce and mixed by Spike Stent.
The debut full-length solo release for former frontman of Wild Beast was produced by Leo Abrahams.
The first of two releases in 2017 for the award-winning country singer-songwriter was produced by Dave Cobb.
The fourth full-length release for the soul-jazz singer-songwriter was produced by Kamau Kenyatta.
This is the debut album for the Alan Palomo-led band.
The eighth studio full-length release for the indie rock band is its first with new member Alex Fischel and was produced by Joe Chicarelli and Dave Fridmann.
The fourth full-length release for the electronic artist was inspired by river moments and is "about cosmogony and creation/destruction myths."
This is the first album in three years for the Portland, Oregon-based instrumental post-rock quartet.
The fifth full-length studio release for electronic artist Darren Cunningham was inspired by such things as Blade Runner, Rammellzee, and Gabriel Faurés Requiem.
The second album for the indie Canadian quartet was produced by Chad VanGaalen.
The fourth full-length release for the British indie rock band was produced by James Ford.
The fifth album for the singer-songwriter was produced by Sam Kassirer.
This is the latest full-length release for the Philadelphia-based alternative singer-songwriter.

recordname: Club Future Nostalgia: The Remix Album
description: The British pop singer worked with DJ The Blessed Madonna on the remix of her recently released album, Future Nostalgia. It features guest appearances from [the singer/actress] Madonna, Missy Elliott, and Gwen Stefani.
The third full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was produced with Ben Hillier.
The second release for the British electronic duo of Dominic Maker and Kai Campos features the guest appearance of King Krule on two tracks.
The experimental electronic composer collaborated with gagaku ensemble Tokyo Gakuso on his ninth full-length release.
The 10th full-length release for the Canadian alt-country band features a guest appearance from Kurt Vile.
Joe Henry produced the Grammy-winning folk singer's second album for the Anti- label.

recordname: Down in the Weeds, Where the World Once Was
description: The first release for the indie rock trio since 2011 album The People's Key features contributions from Jon Theodore and Red Hot Chili Peppers' Flea.
This split LP includes seven new Akron/Family tracks and five new songs from Michael Gira's Angels Of Light project (which, of course, features backing by Akron/Family).

recordname: American Dollar Bill - Keep Facing Sideways, You're Too Hideous To Look at Face On
description: The collaboration between Keiji Haino and Sumac was recorded during improvised sessions.
The Baltimore duo, named after Marylands state tree, is made up of musicians Andy Stack and Jenn Wasner  a couple of indie rock and folk favorites.
The ninth full-length studio release for Daniel Lopatin as Oneohtrix Point Never features contributions from Arca, Caroline Polachek and The Weeknd.
The long-delayed release of the fifth studio album from the Maynard James Keenan-led rock band comes after overcoming a number of issues between the 13 years since 2006's 10,000 Days.
The debut release for the music project between Olivia Chaney and The Decemberists features English-Irish-Scottish folk songs and was produced by Tucker Martine.

Like a more accessible, poppier version of Matmos, UK electronica artist Matthew Herbert likes to record concept albums with instrumentation derived from real-world objects. 'Scale' (which again features Dani Siciliano on vocals) samples 723 items (including coffins and fuel pumps) in its 11 politically-charged dance tracks.

The seventh full-length solo release for the singer-songwriter features full-band versions of tracks from 2016's Ruminations (plus seven new songs) with contributions from Pearl Charles, Jim James, Blake Mills, Gus Seyffert, Maria Taylor, Nathaniel Walcott, M. Ward, Gillian Welch, and Jonathan Wilson.
The Brooklyn band return with a follow-up to their indie-rock landmark album, Hospice.
The third release for the Nigerian ensemble was recorded with the help of producer Jamie Carter.
The singer-songwriter's fifth studio album is the first for his new record label, Lonely Astronaut.
The fourth full-length release for the country singer-songwriter was produced by Dave Cobb.
This is the second full-length release for the Massachusetts-based electronic duo of Jae Matthews and August Miller.
This seven-song follow-up to 2004's 'Blue Cathedral' adds a bit more melody and cleaner sound to the band's usual noise assault.
This is the debut release for the experimental electronic project of Joe Williams (who also releases albums under the name White Williams).
The 42nd studio release for the country singer features duets with Kenny Rogers and Willie Nelson.
The third full-length release for the San Francisco-based experimental electronic-pop artist features vocals from Claire Tolan.

The fifth full-length studio release for the Los Angeles-based rapper features guest appearances from ASAP Rocky, Dev Hynes, Frank Ocean, Playboi Carti, Santigold, Kanye West, Pharrell Williams, and Charlie Wilson.
Continuing with the same lineup as 2008's "Imperial Wax Solvent," the British rock band led by Mark E. Smith releases its 28th studio album on new label Domino records.
This is the second full-length electronic release for producer Sebastian Gainsborough as Vessel.
The debut full-length release for the Canadian singer-songwriter features production from Black Keys' Patrick Carney, Ariel Rechtshaid, and Girls' Chet White.
The fifth release for experimental electronic artist Daniel Lopatin is his first disc with Wrap Records as Oneohtrix Point Never.
The 15th release for Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds was produced by Nick Launay and is its first without Mick Harvey, who left in 2009.
The latest full-length release for the Mike Kinsella solo musical project features a guest appearance from KC Dalager and was produced by Sean Carey.
The latest release from the Canadian Cree singer-songwriter features two new songs with 11 rerecorded versions of her older songs.
The latest full-length release for Canadian artist Scott Morgan as Loscil features contributions from Josh Lindstrom, Ashley Pitre, Elaine Reynolds, Kelly Wyse, and Jason Zumpano.

The five piece album from the experimental Australian composer features contributions from such artists as Matt Chamberlain, Thomas Brinkmann, Crys Cole, the Icelandic Symphony Orchestra, Eyvind Kang, Jim O' Rourke, John Tilbury, and U-zhaan.
This is the second full-length release from the Seattle-based experimental hip-hop group led by Ishmael Butler.
The seventh solo release for Mike Kinsella as Owen was produced by Neil Strauch.
The third and final part of the British singer-songwriter's Essex trilogy of albums is about the seventeenth century Essex Witch Trials.
The latest album from the British group is with yet another different lineup from 2007's "Reformation Post TLC."
The debut album was nominated for the Mercury Prize for best British album this year.
The third full-length release for the Austin hardcore band was produced by Ben Greenberg.
This is the fourth solo disc for the illustrator and Sea And Cake guitarist.

The debut full-length studio release for the Canadian electronic producer under the name Kaytranada (he has six credited under Kaytradamus) features guest appearances from such artists as AlunaGeorge, BadBadNotGood, Craig David, Little Dragon, Vic Mensa, Anderson .Paak, Phonte, and Syd tha Kyd.
The latest full-length release for the Baltimore folk rock band led by Dave Heumann was recorded by Steve Wright and features guest appearances from Hans Chew and David Bergander.
The debut full-length release for the Houston rapper features guest appearances from DaBaby and Juicy J.
The fifth full-length release for M.C. Taylor features Phil and Brad Cook of Megafaun, William Tyler, Scott Hirsch, and Alexandra Sauser-Monnig of Mountain Man.
The fourth full-length release for the Tennessean country singer was produced by Kevin Agunas and Dan Auerbach.

recordname: The Man Who Died in His Boat
description: The latest release from Liz Harris contains songs unreleased from her recording session for 2008's Dragging A Dead Deer Up A Hill.
Using a computer, the Tennessee-born musician manipulated her vocals to form her experimental electronic debut full-length release.
Mike Kinsella's latest solo album under the name Owen was recorded over two years.
The second album for the British singer-songwriter was produced by Ethan Johns.

recordname: You're Not As _____ As You Think
description: The third full-length release for the Connecticut-based indie rock band led by Cam Boucher was produced and mixed by Mike Sapone.
The producer/singer/songwriter releases his lastest solo album.
Leaving Songs is the Nashville-recorded second solo disc for Tindersticks frontman Stuart Staples, who is joined by Maria McKee on one track.
The fifth album for the indie rock band is its first as a duo (Justin Harris and Danny Seim) after the departure of Brent Knopf, who left to concentrate on his solo project, Ramona Falls.
The second full-length release for Brooklyn-based electronic producer James Hinton used vocal samples he found on YouTube.
The debut full-length solo release for former frontman of The Only Ones was produced by Chris Kimsey.
The third full-length studio release for the Southern California rapper features guest appearances from J. Cole, Future, Jeremih, Kendrick Lamar, and SZA.
This debut by Australian Dan Whitford mixes retro-synth pop with some guitars and live instrumentation.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn-based singer-songwriter was co-produced with Rob Ellis.
Paramour returns without Josh and Zac Farro to release its fourth full-length release produced by Justin Meldal-Johnsen.
The two-disc set includes track recorded by the BBC between 1996 and 2001.

Produced by Nicolas Vernhes, the sixth release for the Atlanta indie rock band led by Bradford Cox includes two new band members: bassist Josh McKay (taking over from Joshua Fauver) and guitarist Frankie Broyles.
Born Aaron Dontez Yates, the Kansas City rapper releases his latest LP on Strange Music, featuring appearances from Busta Rhymes, E-40, T-Pain, and more.
The Chicago-based singer-songwriter returns with his tenth album of literate and eclectic indie rock.
The Brooklyn-based Elephant 6-style band (which shares some members with Ladybug Transistor) returns with a second LP.

While the first full-length for the English chill-out duo, 'LemonJelly.KY,' was a collection of previously released singles, 'Lost Horizons' represents their first true album, with eight new tracks clocking in at precisely one hour in length.

You won't read very many reviews of this New York band without seeing the words Joy Division pop up, and although there are some similarities, Interpol has something new to offer as well. This debut LP includes the tracks "PDA" and "NYC" from the group's well-received first single for Matador.

The Bay Area's Josh Davis (aka DJ Shadow) finally returns with a proper full-length follow-up to 1996's groudbreaking 'Endtroducing,' which achieved near-legendary status for its imaginative use of samples (a style that would later be adopted by acts such as The Avalanches).
The latest full-length studio release for the pop singer-songwriter artist was produced by Jack Antonoff and features guest appearances from Zella Day and Weyes Blood.
This is the first album in over five years for the electronic duo from New York City.
This the final album for Pete Swanson and Gabriel Mindel Saloman. The experimental music duo from Portland, Oregon broke up in 2008.
The singles collection for the Brooklyn, New York, electronica duo, which was previously released on the digital music site eMusic, is released physically via Thrill Jockey.
The debut full-length studio release for the British jazz saxophonist was produced with Kwes.
The third solo release for the former Beta Band frontman was recorded with producer Craig Potter.
The fifth full-length release for the British folk singer-songwriter was self-produced.
The second full-length solo release from the former member of Be Good Tanya features Al Green's back up band, Hi Rhythm Section.
The debut full-length release for the collaboration between Laura Marling and Mike Lindsay was recorded in London.
The latest full-length release for the Beatles artist was self-recorded and produced during the COVID-19 pandemic lockdown.
The fourth album for the funk/soul group from New York was produced by Bosco Mann.
The second full-length release for the electronic producer who worked on Kanye West's Yeezus, FKA twigs' LP1, Björk's Vulnicura and Kelela's Hallucinogen EP.
Sam Shepherd is the latest electronic producer to add to the Late Night Tales mix series.
The debut full-length release for the duo of Eilidh Rodgers and Rachel Aggs was produced by Tony Doogan.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Canadian post-rock collective is its first album in a decade.
The third full-length release for the British duo was self-produced.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Swedish metal band was produced by Tom Dalgety.

The second full-length release for the British electronic pop trio led by Olly Alexander features contributions from such artist as Greg Kurstin, Steve Mac, Julia Michaels, Justin Tranter, and Two Inch Punch.
The third full-length release for the Canadian post-punk band was produced by Nicolas Vernhes.
The fifth full-length solo release for the singer-songwriter was produced by Cate Le Bon.
The third full-length release for the Massachusetts alt-folk band was co-produced with Dan Cardinal.
Richard Swift, who worked on Damien Jurado's 2010 release, St. Bartlett, returns to produce on this live recorded album.
The British folk band changed its name from Rachel Unthank & the Winterset to its current (shorter) name after a lineup change.
Originally a quintet known as the Chicago Underground Orchestra, the duo of Chris Taylor and Rob Mazurek releases its fifth album.
Following positive reviews for his EPs, James Blake releases his first full-length album.
The sixth full-length release for the Chicago instrumental rock trio was produced by Kurt Ballou.

recordname: I Don't Like Shit: I Don't Go Outside
description: The second full-length studio release for the Los Angeles rapper features guest appearances from Dash, Na'kel, Vince Staples, and Wiki.
The Modesto, CA band returns with a concept album reminiscent of Radiohead's 'OK Computer.'
The latest full-length release for experimental electronic duo Matmos features recordings from Polish electronic artist Boguslaw Schaeffer.

The two tracks from the experimental artist were originally commissioned in 2017 for art installations by Evelina Domnitch and Dmitry Gelfand features the sounds of two black holes merging together that captured by the LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory).
The third full-length studio release for the California rapper features guest appearances from E-40, Jay Rock, Kamaiyah, Kehlani, Earl Sweatshirt, Ty Dolla $ign, and Tyga.
The fourth solo album for the rapper/actor features Talib Kweli, Slick rick, and Georgia Anne Muldrow as guest artists.
The second full-length solo release for the British folk singer-songwriter was produced by Thomas Bartlett.
The third studio release for the Tuareg artist features influences from reggae and rock music and was produced by Dave Longstreth.

The Doug Martsch-led band returns with its first album in five years, and its first in 13 years not to utilize producer Phil Ek. Recent touring guitarist Jim Roth makes his recorded debut with the band, and Quasi's Sam Coomes returns to help on keyboards.
The second full-length release for the masked Canadian country artist Orville Peck was inspired in part by '70s country and California psychedelic rock music.
This is the third full-length release for Benjamin John Power's solo electronic project.
The debut full-length studio release for the Baton Rouge rapper features guest appearances from Jamie Foxx, Trey Songz, and Ty Dolla $ign on "Jam."
The 12th solo release for the British rock singer was produced by Jan "Stan" Kybert.
The latest album for the Japanese hardcore rock quintet brings some post-rock styles to its music.
The debut full-length release for the Australian band features elements of Afrobeat, funk, pop and psychedelia music.
The debut full-length release for the Irish singer-songwriter was produced with Cian Nugent.
After gaining acclaim for a densely melodic sound that anticipated the coming emergence of grunge, Scotland's Teenage Fanclub return with a harmony-driven album to inspire a power pop revival.
Louisville-born Will Oldham releases his latest album produced by Mark Nevers.
This compilation collects tracks recorded from 1998-2001 that, for various reasons (and not because they were of inferior quality), were not included on the rapper's albums released during that time.
The third full-length release for Swedish duo Maria Lindén and Fredrik Balck was inspired from Lindén watching some of her favorite films.
The fifth LP for the chamber-pop trio is a collaboration with the New York-based progressive theater collective SITI Company.
Another solo release from the former Throwing Muses singer.

Britpop, New Wave, and Kraftwerk-style electronica come together in the debut full-length from Britain's Ladytron (named after a song from Roxy Music's debut album). The album repeats three of the songs from 2000's "Commodore Rock" EP (including the ever-catchy "Playgirl") and adds 12 new tracks plus the 1999 single "He Took Her To A Movie."
This is the first LP for the Sheffield, England co-ed five-piece fronted by Kate Jackson. Steve Mackey (Pulp) produced.
This is the fourth full-length release for the British experimental/post-rock group.

The second full-length solo release for the former Loved Ones frontman includes contributions from David Hidalgo Jr. of Social Distortion, Bo Koster of My Morning Jacket, Scott Hutchison of Frightened Rabbit, Matt Skiba of Alkaline Trio/The Watson Twins, and Bob Thomson of Big Drill Car.
The third full-length release for the Massachusetts hardcore quintet tells the story of the father of the characters introduced in the band's previous albums.

Brendan O'Brien produced (and plays bass on) the singer's 19th album, which finds Springsteen backed by a variety of guests. Several of the 12 tracks here have previously surfaced in live performances, including two dating back to 1995.
The 21st release for the Australian instrumental trio of Chris Abrahams, Tony Buck, and Lloyd Swanton features three 20+-minute long tracks.
The debut album for Nashville's Mackenzie Scott was recorded live to tape over five days.
The singer-songwriter's latest album was recorded with the help of Gillian Welch, Old Crow Medicine Show, Benmont Tench, and Nate Walcott.
'City' finds veteran underground rapper Aceyalone backed by beats from RJD2.

recordauthor: A Winged Victory for the Sullen
description: The second full-length release for the ambient duo of Adam Wiltzie and Dustin O'Halloran was a score for a dance piece by Wayne McGregor.
The seventh studio release for the Seattle doom metal is a 30 minutes three-track album.

The first new full-length solo release for the Carter Tutti/Throbbing Gristle artist in 17 years was influenced in part by the death of Throbbing Gristle's Peter Christopherson, British folk music and the BBC Radiophonic Workshop.

The third release for the Los Angeles jazz/R&B/soul project begun by Syd tha Kyd and Matt Martians features guest appearances from James Fauntleroy, Kaytranada, Steve Lacey, Vic Mensa, Janelle Monae, and Tyler, the Creator.
Escovedo's first solo disc since 2000 was produced by John Cale.
The debut full-length release for the Los Angeles-based rock band was produced by Norm Block.
The debut full-length release for the British R&B singer-songwriter features contributions from Dizzee Rascal, Amanda Ghost, and Tom Misch.

Producer Terrace Martin brought together a group of musicians that included Chachi, Robert Glasper, Rose Gold, Trevor Lawrence Jr., Brandon Owens, Wyann Vaughn, and Marlon Williams for this album of music inspired by the west coast jazz, R&B and hip-hop.
The fourth full-length release for the progressive bluegrass band was produced by T Bone Burnett.
The follow-up to 2013 release "Austerity Dogs" from the British punk duo of Jason Williamson and Andrew Fearn.
The debut release on Epic for Death Grips is the first of two albums released this year by the Sacramento alternative rap trio.
The second album for the indie pop band was produced by Clor's Luke Smith.
The project consisting of The Bug, Roger Robinson and Hitomi releases its first album together.
The first full-length album on the Warp label for Steven Ellison.
The debut album for the British quartet was produced by Erol Alkan.
Boasting a somewhat higher profile after a tour supporting Broken Social Scene, fellow Canadians Stars return with a third LP, produced by Tony Hoffer.
The seventh release for the Swedish band led by Gustav Ejstes is its first in five years.
The third full-length studio release for the Nashville-based country singer-songwriter was produced by Sturgill Simpson.
This is the tenth album for the very large Nashville band led by Kurt Wagner.
The latest full-length release for the Nashville-based singer-songwriter was written after the end of a long-term relationship and was produced by Andrew Sarlo.
While the trio of Roger Miller, Clint Conley and Peter Prescott typically wait a few decades between albums, this third LP follows just two years after their second.
Mike Mogis produces the second album for the Swedish sisters.

The first solo release in over ten years for the British rock artist was recorded in upstate New York with contributions from his wife Amy Rigby, Brian Dewan, Jane Scarpantoni, and Alexander Turnquist.

The singer-songwriter's fifth release finds him backed for the first time by a full band, which includes Rachel Blumberg (The Decemberists) and Jordan Hudson (The Thermals). Neko Case and My Morning Jacket's Jim James guest.
The third full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was produced by Cenzo Townshend.
The two-CD and DVD set features the recording of Brad Mehldau at the 2006 Marciac Jazz Festival.

recordname: Med Sud I Eyrum Vid Spilum Endalaust
description: The fifth album for the group was was co-produced by Flood and its first recorded in less than a year.
The first full-length in four years for Sam Shepherd as Floating Points features strings and woodwinds in additional to classic electronica synths.
The 17-track release from the California garage rocker was produced by Chris Woodhouse.
The second posthumous release from the acclaimed hip-hop producer, this double-disc set is actually a greatly-expanded resissue of his hard-to-find 2003 EP of the same name.
Steve Albini returns as engineer for this fifth album from the Japanese post-rock outfit.
The first release on the Warp label for the Brooklyn-based composer, producer and multi-instrumentalist features influences from black metal, classical, dream pop, and jazz music.
The 23rd full-length studio release for the Los Angeles rock duo of Ron and Russell Mael is the first new material in eight years (not including 2015 collaborative album FFS).
This is the fourth full-length release for the British trio of Alice Merida Richards, Sam Pillay and Christopher Duffin.

The sixth full-length studio release for the British electronic band was produced with Mark Ralph. On every CD and LP release, the artwork will feature a color variation of a design due to a bespoke printing technique.
Mark Ronson and Salaam Remi produced the British soul singer's second album, which was released to great acclaim in the UK in 2006.
The third full-length release for the jazz quartet led by the tenor saxophonist Shabaka Hutchings features contributions from Josh Idehen and Congo Natty.
The fifth full-length studio release for the rock band led by Emmett Kelly features contributions from Ty Segall.

recordname: Max Richter: Three Worlds  Music from Woolf Works
description: Wayne McGregor commissioned the German-born British composer to create a score for his ballet production based on the three novels by Virginia Woolf (Mrs. Dalloway, Orlando, and The Waves).
The sixth full-length release for M.C. Taylor was self-produced with Bradley Cook.

This is the debut album for the downbeat electronica duo from Norway, which has drawn comparisons to bands such as Air, Groove Armada, and Boards of Canada. Erlend Oye (Kings of Convenience) provides vocals on several tracks.
The seventh full-length studio release for the British singer-songwriter was produced by Joshua Block, Austin Jenkins and Charlie Hugall.
The eighth full-length release for the California singer-songwriter features contributions from Angel Olsen and Blake Mills, with production by Rob Schnapf and Dan Horne.

The debut full-length release from the former Danity Kane/Diddy Dirty Money singer was produced by Andrew "Druski" Scott, The Fisticuffs, and Deonte. It is the first of a planned trilogy of albums about love, loss, and redemption.
This is the sophomore album for the indie-rock band from Madison, Wisconsin.
The 11th full-length studio release for the folk rock band was recorded in Stinson Beach, California.
The third full-length release for the Brooklyn-based indie rock band was inspired by lead singer Zachary Cole Smith's recovery from drug addiction.
The second full-length release for the Baltimore hardcore band was produced by Will Yip.
The third full-length release for the British metal band was inspired by 1970s exploitation films.

The debut solo album from the former lead guitarist of The Coral was written as a musical adaptation of Italo Calvino's 1979 novel, If on a Winter's Night a Traveler and features The London Philharmonic.
This is the second album for Bradford Cox's solo project.
The 28-track collection of unreleased tracks from the rapper/producer, who passed away three years ago, was produced by his mother and arranged by Pete Rock.
The former Anti-Pop Consortium member's second solo release is a nine-song EP, with six new tracks and three remixes by Kings, Prefuse 73 and El-P.
This is the major-label debut for the Bay Area punk rockers (whose initials stand for "A Fire Inside"), who got their start in Ukiah, Calif. in 1991. Garbage's Butch Vig produces.

This is not your ordinary jazz trio. For their major-label debut, The Bad Plus work with alt-rock producer Tchad Blake, and include covers of Nirvana's "Smells Like Teen Spirit," Blondie's "Heart of Glass," and Aphex Twin's "Flim" among their seven original tracks.

Although the Birmingham, England band has been recording and performing since 1995, 'The Noise Made By People' marks their official full-length debut (following 1997's singles compilation 'Work And Non-Work'). In the UK, the group is signed to Warp Records (although they don't sound too much like the other bands on Warp's all-electronic roster).
The second full-length release for the country singer was produced by Dave Cobb.
The debut full-length release for the British jazz collective was produced by Kwes.
The 11th full-length studio release for the Chicago alternative rock band was produced by Jeff Tweedy.
The fourth full-length release for the Nashville singer-songwriter was written mostly while staying in a cabin in Mississippi.
The debut full-length release for the Canadian punk quartet was produced by Josh Korody and Leon Taheny.

recordname: The Rose Has Teeth In The Mouth Of A Beast
description: M.C. Schmidt and Drew Daniel's latest Matmos album includes contributions from Bjork and Antony. Each of the ten tracks focuses on a specific person who has influenced the group in some way, such as William S. Burroughs and Valerie Solanas.
The latest release for electronic artist James Holden was recorded with his band The Animal Spirits in single takes.
The sixth full-length release for the Brooklyn post-punk band A Place to Bury Strangers is its first LP with John Fedowitz and Sandra Fedowitz.
The Seattle heavy metal band's second album was produced by Kurt Ballou.

recordname: Barbara Barbara, We Face a Shining Future
description: The ninth full-length studio release for the British techno duo was co-produced with High Contrast.
The newest release for the California-born country singer-songwriter is his first on Vanguard Records.

Producer Rick Rubin attempts to do for Neil Diamond what he did for Johnny Cash, resulting in a rare stripped-down, intimate set for the veteran performer. (Don't expect any Nine Inch Nails covers, though; these are all Diamond originals.)
This is the debut full-length release for the project formed by Shearwater's Jonathan Meiburg, and Emily Cross and Dan Duszynski of Cross Record.
This is the debut full-length release for the British-Filipino alternative rock artist.
The latest full-length solo release for the former Yuck member was recorded by Peter Walsh.
The second full-length release for the Philadelphia punk quartet was recorded by by the band's bassist Hart Seely.
The fifth full-length solo release for the singer-songwriter was produced by Sam Cohen.
Annie Clark's second album was produced with John Congleton.
The fifth full-length release for the now Los Angeles-based quintet led by Carrie Keith and Dylan Sharp was inspired in part by classical and post-modern mythologies.
The poems of Russian Anna Akhmatova are the basis of the latest release from the singer-songwriter.

The sixth full-length release for Erin Birgy as Mega Bog features contributions from Matt Bachmann, Zach Burba of iji, Andrew Dorset of Lake, Meg Duffy of Hand Habits, James Krivchenia of Big Thief, Alex Liebman, Aaron Otheim, Will Segerstrom, and Jade Tcimpidis,
The debut full-length solo release for the Savages singer features The xx's Romy Madley Croft, Cillian Murphy and IDLES' Joe Talbot.
The Chicago-based indie rock band releases its second full-length album.
The fourth full-length release for the Scottish synth-pop trio features a guest appearance from Robert Smith.
