The latest collaboration between Marianne Faithfull and Warren Ellis features poems by the Romantics (Byron, Hood, Keats, Shelley, Tennyson, and Wordsworth) set to music with contributions from Nick Cave, Brian Eno and Vincent Segal.
The debut full-length release for the Australian garage punk band was produced by Ross Orton.
The fifth release for the British electronic artist Matt Cutler as Lone features hip-hop influences.

recordauthor: Robert Plant & the Sensational Space Shifters
description: The tenth solo album for the British rock singer backed by his band the Sensational Space Shifters feature influences from African, dance and jazz music.
The second full-length release for the Philadelphia noise-pop band Empath was produced by Unknown Mortal Orchestra's Jake Portrait.
Fiona Apple, Courtney Barnett, Aaron Dessner, IDLES, Shamir, St. Panther, Justin Vernon and Lucinda Williams cover songs from the singer-songwriter's 2010 album.
This is the second album for the band led by Spencer Krug (who can also be found in both Wolf Parade and Frog Eyes).
The blues-rock duo of Dan Auerbach and Patrick Carney return with their third album, so-named because it was recorded in a deserted rubber (tire) factory.
This is the latest full-length ambient studio release for Wolfgang Voigt under the name GAS.
The debut full-length release for the R&B artist features production from Hit-Boy MeLo-X, and Rakhi.
Laura Cantrell, Peter Holsapple, and Annie Hayden guest on Mac McCaughan's second Portastatic album of 2006.
Jay-Z's mortal enemy returns with his third (!) release of 2002, which includes collaborations with Alicia Keys and 2Pac (yes, that 2Pac, who, as you may recall, died several years ago).
The 12th full-length studio release for the Swedish prog metal band was produced by Tom Dalgety.

'Human Kindness' is the latest disc of psychedelic electronica from Dan Snaith, who formerly recorded under the name Manitoba (before a threatened lawsuit from a similarly-named artist caused the switch to the similarly-Canadian Caribou).
The first release of original songs from the singer-songwriter in 16 years focuses on life on the Arkansas delta.
This is the second album for the Austin, Texas indie rock band.
This is the fourth full-length studio album for the Canadian singer.
The latest full-length release from the Japanese post-rock band Boris is its first on the Sacred Bones label.
The first new full-length studio release for singer-songwriter in seven years was recorded in Santa Monica with producer Ross Hogarth.
The second release in 2021 for the Australian rock band was recorded remotely at home during the COVID-19 pandemic lockdown.
The 16th full-length solo release for the British rock artist features contributions from Andy Fairweather Low, Lia Metcalfe, Hannah Peel and his daughter Leah.
The first new release in over eight years for British singer-songwriter Damon Gough features production from Gethin Pearson, Youth, Keir Stewart, and Seadna McPhail.
The first full-length release in seven years for the British singer-songwriter was written and produced with Romeo Stodart of the Magic Numbers.
The latest release from the British producer Stephen Wilkinson features a variety of stringed instruments including the mandolin and fiddle.

The California folk singer-songwriter worked with such artists as Devendra Banhart, Nels Cline, Julia Holter, Wilco's Glenn Kotche, and Mark Pritchard on her third full-length release that was produced with Pat Sansone and Fernando Perdomo.
The second full-length release for the British indie rock band was self-recorded.
This is the debut full-length solo release for the Wand frontman.
The debut full-length release for the Australian singer-songwriter was recorded in New Zealand with producer Ben Edwards.
The 10th full-length studio release for the husband-and-wife duo of Brett and Rennie Sparks features contributions from David Gutierrez, Alex McMahon, and Jason Toth.
The fourth full-length release for the Scottish alternative rock band was inspired by its hometown of Glasgow.
The sixth full-length studio release for the indie rock guitarist was recorded and mixed by Andy Hong.

recordname: No Man's Sky: Music for an Infinite Universe [Original Video Game Soundtrack]
description: The soundtrack from the British post-rock band features six tracks of soundscapes along with 10 originals for the first-person survival video game released on Playstation 4 and Windows PC in August.
The third full-length solo release for the ex-The Coral guitarist was written and recorded in the house he grew up in.
The second solo release for the former drummer of the Felice Brothers was co-produced with David Baron.
This is the first new release of recently recorded songs in over 10 years for the British singer-songwriter Paddy McAloon.
The second full-length electronic release from Marcos Ortega as Lorn and his first on the Ninja Tune label.
The Canadian indie band's fifth album is its first on the Arts & Crafts label.
The third album for the Spencer Krug-led project is its first with newest member Mark Nicol.
The Iowan-born singer-songwriter releases his first album on the Anti label.
Originally released in Japan in 2000, 'Gold And Green' finally reaches U.S. shores at a non-import price on Thrill Jockey. Yuko Honda and Sean Lennon guest.
This is the third album for Mark Linkous and Sparklehorse.

The bands fifth studio album (and first for Beggars Banquet), 'Can Our Love...' features eight new tracks produced by the band with Ian Caple. It expands on the more-soul-based sound that appeared on 1999's 'Simple Pleasure.'

The release notes say that this is the third installment in the trilogy that began with "Not For Threes" and "Rest Proof Clockwork" and that it deals with the "duality of the ear." Hey, as long as it sounds good.
The Liars go more electronic on their sixth album that includes production with Mute Records founder Daniel Miller.
Michael Collins is joined by a full band--plus guests like Natalie Mering of Weyes Blood--on his second album as Drugdealer.
The fourth full-length solo release for the British singer-songwriter was self-produced and features guest vocals from The Orielles and Our Girl.
The debut full-length collaboration between Dave Alvin and Jimmie Dale Gilmore features 10 covers and two originals, including the title track co-written by the duo.
The third album for Nashville-based singer-songwriter is his first on Bloodshot Records.
When Rammstein's tour was postponed by the COVID-19 pandemic, they started writing and recording this eighth studio release during the lockdowns.

recordname: The Raging Wrath Of The Easter Bunny Demo
description: The Northern California experimental rock band reunite Mike Patton, Trey Spruance, and Trevor Dunn, with Anthrax's Scott Ian, and ex-slayer Dave Lombardo to re-record its trash metal-influenced demo.
The second full-length studio release for the British rock band was produced with John "Spud" Murphy (and one track by Marta Salogni).

The remix album from the experimental pop duo of Dylan Brady and Laura Les features guest appearances from Tommy Cash, Charli XCX, Count Baldor, Hannah Diamond, Nicole Dollanganger, Dorian Electra, Fall Out Boy, GFOTY, Kero Kero Bonito, Lil West, Craig Owens, Rico Nasty, and Tony Velour.
The eleventh album for the upstate New York death metal band was produced by Erik Rutan.
This debut album showcases the British band's symphonic, shoegaze-y sound.
This is the eighth solo full-length studio release for the Scottish singer-songwriter.
The fourth full-length solo release for the former Beta Band frontman was recorded with producer Stephen Street's live band.
Will Oldham and members of the Jesus Lizard and Lambchop guest on David Berman's country-tinged fifth Silver Jews disc, which also sees the return of on-again, off-again band member Stephen Malkmus.
This debut full-length by the Norwegian singer is preceded by quite a bit of critical buzz on both sides of the Atlantic.
The sixth full-length release for the Haley Fohr project is the first on the Matador label.

recordname: New History Warfare, Vol. 3: To See More Light
description: The final volume to the saxophonist's New History Warfare series was produced by Ben Frost and features guest vocals Bon Iver's Justin Vernon on four tracks.
The fifth release for the experimental electronic British duo of James Ginzburg and Paul Purgas was recorded live.
The second album from Mike Hadreas under the Perfume Genius name was recorded in England and Washington.
Leyland Kirby used Austrian composer Franz Schubert's music to create the soundtrack to Grant Lee's film of the same name.
The Portland, Oregon-based singer-songwriter included more strings on her seventh album produced by Tucker Martine.
This is the debut full-length for the Baltimore four-piece whose frontman (James Johnson) bears a strong vocal resemblance to John Lydon.
The British indie rock band releases its fifth full-length studio album.
This is the highly-anticipated debut release for the pairing of Danger Mouse and Cee-Lo.
The first full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter in four years was written during the pandemic lockdown in Cornwall, England.
The third full-length release for the David Moore project finds it streamlined to a five person ensemble.
The slowcore trio (including new bassist Matt Livingston) reunites with producer Dave Fridmann.
The eight full-length studio release for the Sacramento alternative metal band features a guest appearance from Alice in Chain's Jerry Cantrell.
The third full-length studio release for the Norwegian pop artist AURORA features a guest appearance from Pomme.
The fourth full-length studio release for the R&B singer-songwriter features guest appearances from J. Cole, Salaam Remi, Rick Ross, Travis Scott, and Kali Uchis.
This is the latest release from the Congolese collective produced by Vincent Kenis.
Tim Armstrong returns to produce the reggae singer's first release in over seven years.
This full-length debut for the UK-based indie-pop band led by Fyfe Dangerfield includes the previously-released single "Trains To Brazil."
The British rock band's first studio release in 12 years was recorded while on tour in Asia and produced with Stephen Street.
The first full-length release in six years for the British rock band features Paul Molloy on guitar (filling in for Lee Southall) was produced with Richard Turvey.
The final album for the electronic artist is an in-studio collection of nine songs the LCD Soundsystem's career.
The third full-length release for the Brooklyn indie rock band led by Dustin Payseur features guest appearances from Cities Aviv and Slowdive's Rachel Goswell.
The debut album for the Cardiff, Wales-based indie rock band was produced by David Newfeld.
The sixth full-length release for the Canadian pop singer-songwriter was mixed by Rob Schnapf.
The latest full-length release for the Seattle-based indie singer-songwriter was self-produced.
This is the third full-length album for the Welsh alternative rock band.
The debut full-length debut for the Massachusetts indie rock band led by Sadie Dupuis was produced by Justin Pizzoferrato.
This is the Brighton-based Australian singer's third and final release in her Penelope trilogy of albums.
The Sierra Leone artist Janka Nabay is backed by Boshra AlSaadi, Doug Shaw, the Skeletons' Jon Leland, Michael Gallope, and Jason McMahon as the Bubu Gang on his debut full-length release.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn artist was produced with Marco Buccelli.
The official release of The Clash's second performance at Shea Stadium in 1982.
The fifth album from the Nebraska-born singer-songwriter is indeed influenced by the music of 1972 (the year Rouse was born).

Portastatic is a side project for Superchunk's Mac McCaughan (who also is part owner of Merge Records). On this, his first Portastatic LP since 1997, he is joined by Sleater-Kinney's Janet Weiss as well as members of Sparklehorse and Lambchop.

Singer-songwriter Chan Marshall is Cat Power, and on this album she reinterprets (sometimes drastically) the works of some of her favorite artists, including Smog, the Rolling Stones, the Velvet Underground, and Bob Dylan.
The first release in six years for the laughter of June Carter and stepfather Johnny Cash was produced by Don Was and features guest appearances from Vince Gill, Kris Kristofferson and Willie Nelson.

recordname: Let The Blind Lead Those Who Can See But Cannot Feel
description: The debut solo album from the lead singer of Deerhunter.

The debut release for the Nickelodeon actress from Victorious and Sam & Cat was produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds and includes guest appearances from Big Sean, Mac Miller, Mika, and the Wanted's Nathan Sykes.
The second album for the duo was produced by the two artists with John Leckie coproducing one song.
The latest DFA artist to create a buzz in the music press is former Six Finger Satellite guitarist John Maclean, whose "Less Than Human" is his full-length debut as The Juan Maclean.
The London-based bands debut is full of fuzzy noise rock and guitar-heavy anthems, seemingly influenced by the 90s grunge era.
The second full-length release for the collaboration between 21 Savage and Metro Boomin features guest appearances from Drake, Morgan Freeman, Young Nudy, and Young Thug.
This is the third full-length solo release for the San Francisco Bay Area artist.
The latest album for the rock band features guest appearances by MGMT, the Yeah Yeah Yeah's Karen O, and German mathematician, Dr. Thorsten Wormann.
This is the debut full-length release for the former member of Canadian indie pop band, Makeout Videotape.

The debut solo studio release for the rapper, who began his career as part of the rap duo Clipse, features guest appearances from such artists as 2 Chainz, Big Sean, Chris Brown, Future, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell, Rick Ross, and Kelly Rowland.
The third full-length studio release for the British electronic producer duo of Josh Lloyd-Watson and Tom McFarland features guest appearances from Bas and Priya Ragu.
The third full-length release for the R&B artist was recorded in Los Angeles and features guest appearances from Robert Glasper, Ink and Terrace Martin.
The seventh full-length release for the Austrian experimental electronic artist was recorded in his bedroom when he lost his studio space.
This is the sixth full-length release for New York-based Roberto Carlos Lange as Helado Negro.

recordname: Diversions Vol. 4: The Songs and Poems of Molly Drake
description: The folk group's fourth full-length album features interpretations of the songs Molly Drake recorded in the 1950s (and released in 2013) with readings of her poems by her daughter, Gabrielle Drake.
This is the fourth and final release for the Michael Gira-led experimental rock band's line-up that includes Christoph Hahn, Thor Harris, Christopher Pravdica, Phil Puleo, and Norman Westberg.

recordname: You Can't Go Back if There's Nothing To Go Back To
description: The final album from the Oregon alt-country band was produced by John Morgan Askew.
The Welsh singer-songwriter releases her second full-length album.
The debut full-length release for the London-based singer-songwriter was produced by William Doyle.
The debut full-length release for the indie singer-songwriter was recorded with Bramwell Bronte.
The debut full-length release for London-based electronic producer James Greenwood was co-produced by Erol Alkan
'Demo' is the self-produced debut for British rapper Derek DeSafo.

Although a New York band, Scissor Sisters (as evidenced by this debut disc) are definitely not part of the typical New York scene, eschewing garage and no wave to embrace campier, glammier 70s and 80s rock and dance music sounds. Included here is the band's cover of Pink Floyd's "Comfortably Numb."
The 14th studio release for the folk rock band led by John Darnielle features horns by Matthew E. White.
This is the debut full-length release for the music project that includes Lush's Miki Berenyi, Modern English's Mick Conroy, Moose's K.J. McKillop, and Elastica's Justin Welch.
The fourth full-length release for the Nashville psychedelic rock band led by Charles Michael Parks Jr. was produced by Dave Cobb.
The solo album for Ponytail's Dustin Wong was composed almost entirely with only a guitar.
The latest release for the garage rock band led by John Dwyer is its first with drummers Ryan Moutinho and Dan Rincon.
The fourth full-length release for the British post-punk duo was recorded in London at Steve Mackey's studios.
The fifth full-length studio release for the indie singer-songwriter was co-produced with Rob Ellis and Peter Miles.

recordname: Song Machine, Season One: Strange Timez
description: The latest full-length studio release for the Damon Albarn and Jamie Hewlett's virtual band features music that was part of its web series and features guest appearances from 6lack, Roxani Arias, Beck, Fatoumata Diawara, Georgia, Peter Hook, Elton John, Leee John, Kano, Octavian, ScHoolboy Q, Slaves, slowthai, Robert Smith, and St. Vincent.
The second full-length release for the British post-punk band was produced by Dan Carey.

Following on the heels of one of 2005's best-reviewed world music discs is this second installment in the Congotronics series of electronica-esque African music, this time featuring the work of Konono No. 1 plus six additional (but similar) artists from Kinshasa.
This is the debut full-length release for the British electronic producer Matthew Barnes.
The rock group from Georgia recorded the album in a week in Brooklyn, New york.

You Are Not Alone finds Mavis Staples teaming up with Wilco's Jeff Tweedy, who produced the album and penned several of the songs, and while Tweedy may seem an odd fit, he obviously knew what he was up to, crafting material that fits Staples' gospel-fueled vocals.

When you record one of the most acclaimed albums of the decade, what do you do for an encore? If you are Jeff Tweedy & co., you return with both old (Jim O'Rourke again producing) and new (yet another lineup change) for your fifth studio LP.
The third full-length release for the indie folk quintet from Seattle was co-produced by the band's Robin Pecknold and Skyler Skjelset.
The second full-length studio release for the British artist was co-produced by Mica Livi and Coby Sey.
The 10th full-length studio release for the heavy metal band features guest appearances from Chuck Billy and Jamey Jasta.
Self-produced and recorded, the fourth full-length release for the New York indie-pop artist is a concept album about a person taking off for Los Angeles to seek fame.
This is the debut full-length release for the British experimental electronic duo of Harry Wright and Robin Stewart.

The fifth full-length release for the garage punk band features guest appearances from Matthew Hoopengardner of the Golden Boys, Jana Misener, Seth Moody, Jack Oblivian, Patrick Stickles of Titus Andronicus, John Whittemore, and Krista Wroten-Combest of the Memphis Dawls.
The second full-length release from the Louisiana-based blues singer-songwriter was produced by Dan Auerbach.
The third full-length release for the Belgian jazz singer was self-produced.
The fourth full-length release for the Philadelphia indie rock band led by Adam Granduciel is its first on the Atlantic label.
The third full-length release for the folk project for Damon McMahon features guest appearance from Elias Bender Rønnenfelt of Iceage and was produced by Dave Bryant and Efrim Menuck.
The latest release from the Glasgow-based folk artist includes contributions from such artists as Olivia Chaney, Rafe Fitzpatrick, Ben Reynolds, and music ensemble Concerto Caledonia.
Marc Ribot, Jean McClain, Lisa Hannigan, and Patrick Warren appear as guests on Henry's home-recorded acoustic album.

recordname: Micah P. Hinson and the Pioneer Saboteurs
description: This is the fourth album for the Texas-based singer-songwriter.
The Perceptionists feature Boston-based MCs Mr. Lif and Akrobatik backed by the beats of DJ Fakts One. El-P also shows up on one track.
The eighth full-length release for the indie rock band includes guest appaearnces from the Brooklyn Youth Choir, Gail Ann Dorsey, Lisa Hannigan, Kate Stables, Mina Tindle, and Sharon Van Etten.
The third full-length studio release for the pop artist features guest appearances from The Dap-Kings Horns, Eagles Of Death Metal, Dolly Parton.
The third full-length solo release for the singer-songwriter was produced with Clemens Knieper and recorded live to tape in upstate New York.
The latest full-length release for the British electronic artist Elizabeth Bernholz features elements of folk music, as well as the harpsichord and recorder.
The fourth full-length release from the Swedish husband-and-wife duo of Mariam Wallentin and Andreas Werliin was self-recorded and produced.
The eight-track surprise release is one of the two new albums (Ghosts VI: Locusts being the other) that continues Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross' instrumental Ghosts series.
The third full-length release for the Boston rock band led by Rick Maguire was produced by Ben Brodin.
The blue-collar Boston punk band's newest release is just in time for St. Patrick's Day--staying true to its Irish roots with its traditional punk-folk anthems.
Straightforward pop songs are this Boston band's specialty, and its latest release builds around its trademark sound with melodious guitars, sweeping vocal harmonies, and hook-filled songs.
The fourth full-length studio release for the pop singer features guest appearances from Nicki Minaj, Missy Elliott and Pharrell Williams.
The seventh album for the space rock band was produced by frontman Jason Pierce.
The latest release for the Texas-based singer-songwriter is a concept album about two men, one from Italy and the other from Mexico, as they seek to immigrate to the United States.
This is the second full-length studio album for the French-born electronic artist.
MF Doom drops his first solo record (under the MF Doom name) since 1999's 'Operation Doomsday.'
The seventh full-length studio release for the rock band led by Josh Homme was produced by Mark Ronson.
The third full-length release for the rock band that includes Ty Segall, Charles Moothart and Chad Ubovich was recorded with Steve Albini.
The soul singer worked with producer Thomas Brenneck on his second release on Daptone Records.
Robert Forster's first album in 11 years also features songs written by his now-deceased Go-Between partner.
Alan Moulder mixed this sophomore disc for the hard-rocking Los Angeles band, known for their black and red "uniforms" and strong live sets.
On an indie label for the first time in almost two decades, the veteran British folk-rocker returns with a stripped-down sound, courtesy of producer John Chelew.
Indie Boston rapper Mr. Lif returns with his fourth album.
This is the fourth Ninja Tune release for the innovative London-based hip-hop outfit, mixing somewhat more traditional rap cuts with acid-jazz and trip-hop instrumental pieces.
The Chicago-based avant-garde musician (best known for his work in Gastr Del Sol) offers up seven new tracks in his follow-up to 1999's 'Eureka.' Wilco's Jeff Tweedy adds guitar.
This debut effort from Liverpool's The Coral is an inventive mix of numerous musical styles.
The seventh studio release for Matthew Cooper is a double LP with a guest appearance by Ira Kaplan of Yo La Tengo.
The second full-length release for the Australian indie pop trio was produced with Architecture In Helsinki's James Cecil and Cameron Bird.
The debut release for the avant-garde jazz group that includes Kushal Gaya, Ruth Goller, Shabaka Hutchings, Satin Singh, Tom Skinner, and Pete Wareham was produced by Leafcutter John.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Icelandic band is its first on XL Recordings and as a trio (Kjartan Sveinsson left in 2012).
The eighth full-length release for indie singer-songwriter was recorded by Trevor Brooks and mixed by John Congleton.

recordname: Hissing Fauna, Are You The Destroyer?
description: Kevin Barnes injects atypically autobiographical subject matter into his danceable indie-pop tunes on his latest Of Montreal release.
The debut full-length release for the British alternative R&B artist was written/produced with Mica Levi.

recordname: The Bravest Man in the Universe
description: The fist album of new material from Bobby Womack since 1994 was co-produced by Damon Albarn and Richard Russell.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Australian psychedelic rock band was produced by Tame Impala's Kevin Parker.

Known for his genre-bending instrumentation and soulful lyricism, the Detroit-born indie rocker returns five years after his last proper album with an experimental variety of electro-orchestral folk pop songs.
The latest release for Kenny Anderson as King Creosote was created for a documentary film of the same name, to be released for the Commonwealth Games.
The third full-length release for the British post-rock band was influenced by works from Byetone, Powell, Prurient, Raime, and Pete Swanson.
The debut full-length release for the Atlantic grindcore three-piece was produced by Andy Nelson.
Produced by John Siket, the New York duo of Brian Harding and Amalie Bruun expands into a indie rock quintet on its debut full-length release.
Andrew Bird self-produced his seventh collection of songs featuring a duet with Annie Clark (St. Vincent).
The sixth album for Brooklyn-based electronic artist Daniel Lopatin utilizes samples of 1980's commercials.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Boston-born artist was produced by Justin Meldal-Johnsen.
This is the third full-length release for British electronic artist Ryan Lee West as Rival Consoles.
This is the seventh full-length studio release and the first non-soundtrack album since 2011 for the Texan post-rock quartet.

recordname: If All I Was Was Black
description: The 16th full-length studio release for the soul singer was written and produced by Jeff Tweedy.
The sixth release from the Oakland, California, hip hop group led by Boots Riley features guests such as Das Racist, Joe Henry, Jolie Holland, Japanther, Killer Mike, and Justin Sane of Anti-Flag.
The third full-length release for the New Orleans-based singer-songwriter was produced by Video Age's Ross Farbe.
Ty Segall and Strange Boys' Tim Presley (under the name White Fence) collaborated on the eight-track release recorded in San Francisco.
The 17th full-length studio release for the Los Angeles rock band includes covers of songs about Los Angeles or were written by fellow natives of the City of Angels.
The debut full-length studio release for the rapper from New Jersey features The Ebonys on one track.

The 15th full-length release for the singer-songwriter features contributions from such artists as T Bone Burnett, Elvis Costello, Kris Kristofferson, John Leventhal, Lera Lynn, Tucker Martine, and Sam Phillips.
The fifth full-length release for the French Canadian husband-and-wife duo was inspired by n Philip K. Dick's A Scanner Darkly.
The second full-length release for the British indie pop band was produced by Dan Carey.
The debut full-length album for the Brooklyn artist showcases her vocals more than her previous ambient electronic EPs.
The Chilean-born artist now based in Paris and Buenos Aires releases his second solo album.
The latest release from the trio of rockers from San Francisco.
The second full-length release for the southern rock band was produced by Blake Mills.
The latest solo album for the ex-Japan band member features work with musicians from the United Kingdom, Austria, and Japan.
The debut full-length release for the British pop/R&B singer was produced by Pop Wansel.
This is the second full-length release for the Swedish pop duo of Malin Dahlström and Gustaf Karlöf.
The eighth full-length solo studio release is the indie artist's first in five years.

This posthumous release--the late James Yancey's third solo album--was near completion at the time of his February 2006 death. Unlike 'Donuts,' this disc (featuring appearances by Madlib, Busta Rhymes and Common) is largely based on live instrumentation rather than samples.
This is the Buffalo, NY band's follow-up to their acclaimed 1998 release 'Deserter's Songs.'
The first mixtape from FKA twigs features guest appearances from Dystopia, Rema, Pa Salieu, Shygirl, Jorja Smith, Unknown T, and The Weeknd.
This is the full-length debut release for the New York City-based indie pop singer-songwriter Valerie Teicher.
The third full-length release for the Philadelphia rock band was produced by Thomas Brenneck with contributions from Dean Ween and tUnE-yArDs' Merrill Garbus.
This is the first studio release for the Mercury-nominated British folk band in over four years.
The second full-length release for Erika M. Anderson was produced with Leif Shackleford.
The journey from the beginning to the end of a relationship is the concept behind the 19th studio release for the Australian singer-songwriter.
The first new full-length solo release for Canadian singer-songwriter Julie Doiron in nine years was recorded in Montreal.
The second full-length release for the indie rock band that includes members based in Ohio and New York was recorded in five days by Cameron Konner.
The six-track EP was recorded during the same sessions as 2016's Hopelessness with production from Oneohtrix Point Never and Hudson Mohawke.
The Grammy-winning bluegrass trio of Chris Thile, Sara Watkins, and Sean Watkins return from its 2007 "indefinite hiatus" to release its Eric Valentine-produced sixth studio album.
Jack and Meg White spent a whopping three weeks (an eternity by White Stripes standards) in Nashville recording their sixth studio album.

recordname: No One Wants To Be Here and No One Wants To Leave
description: The fourth studio release for the Scottish trio was mixed by Peter Katis.
The third album for the Antony Hegarty-led band features music arrangements by Nico Muhly.
Sidi Toure's second solo album was recorded live in Mali with several of his friends over a few days.
The second solo release for the Grammy-winning folk singer includes nine original songs.
The latest full-length solo release for the Pavement co-founder features a 12-string acoustic guitar.
The latest solo album from the Hüsker Dü founding member was inspired by John Milton's Paradise Lost.
The first release from the Britpop band in 11 years was produced by Ed Buller.

The tribute album to Guy Clark features contributions from such artists as Terry Allen, Shawn Camp, Rodney Crowell, Emmylou Harris, Jim McGuire, Gary Nicholson, Mickey Raphael, Verlon Thompson and Jerry Jeff Walker.

The covers album from the singer-songwriter features such 1980-90s songs as George Clinton's "Atomic Dog 2017," Janet Jackson's "Funny How Time Flies (When You're Having Fun)," Prince's "Sometimes It Snows in April," Sade's "Smooth Operator," Tina Turner's "Private Dancer," and "TLC's "Waterfalls."

recordname: I Need To Start a Garden
description: The debut full-length release for the Portland, Oregon singer-songwriter was produced by Zak Kimball.

The fourth full-length release for the alt-country-rock singer-songwriter features features guest appearances from Tim Easton, Craig Finn, Jason Isbell, Austin Lucas, Caitlin Rose, and Steve Selvidge.
The second solo album for the Drive-By Truckers lead singer features his father (bassist with the Muscle Shoals) and his DBT bandmates.
This is the second LP for the Montreal-based indie-pop quartet featuring actor Torquil Campbell, Evan Cranley (also a member of Broken Social Scene), Amy Millan and Chris Seligman.

One-hit wonders, you say? Well, the New York trio did score an MTV hit with "Popular," from their 1996 debut album, but it is a more mature and less commercial Nada Surf that returns now with a third LP, their first for indie label Barsuk.
Canadian singer-songwriter Ron Sexsmith returns with his fifth album, produced by Steve Earle and Ray Kennedy.

Seemingly unwilling to stick to a successful formula, Radiohead follow their breakthrough album 'OK Computer' with this much more experimental work (recorded during sessions that also spawned the later-released 'Amnesiac' album), which ventures even further away from conventional song structure and embraces electronica more fully (even sounding at times like Aphex Twin).
The follow-up to Madonna's hit 'Ray of Light' was produced by 'Light's producer William Orbit and French electronica artist Mirwais.

recordname: The Louder I Call, The Faster It Runs
description: The sixth full-length release for the Baltimore duo of Jenn Wasner and Andy Stack was mixed by John Congleton.

The latest release for the composer features two pieces: Pulse includes winds, strings, piano and electric bass with the International Contemporary Ensemble and Quartet includes two vibraphones and two pianos with the Colin Currie Group.

recordname: I Liked It Better When You Had No Heart
recordauthor: Butch Walker And The Black Widows
description: The producer-singer-songwriter returns with his first album to be credited with his new backing band, The Black Widows.
The latest neo-folk outfit under the tutelage of Michael Gira are the Brooklyn quartet Akron/Family, who make their debut with this self-titled release.
The 12th full-length release for the Canadian indie rock band led by Dan Bejar was produced and mixed by John Collins.
The debut full-length release for the Las Vegas dance-pop artist was produced by Nick Sylvester.

Recorded at the same time and released on the same day, 'Aw C'Mon' and 'No, You C'Mon' are actually intended as separate albums, rather than two parts of a double album. The Nashville String Machine lends strings to each.
Norway's Lindstrom and singer Christabelle join up to release their first album of disco-influenced music together.
The third full-length release for the Japanese rock band features guest appearances from Mndsgn, Ric Wilson, and YMCK.
The seventh full-length release for the French metal band was produced by Joe Duplantier and mixed by Andy Wallace.
The debut full-length release for the Boston-based singer-songwriter was produced by Justine Bowe of Photocomfort and Gabe Goodman.
The Pavement frontman releases his latest rock album with The Jicks, produced by Beck.
The debut disc for the new band from former Unicorns members Nick Diamonds and J'aime Tambeur includes appearances from members of Royal City, Wolf Parade and Arcade Fire.
This sophomore LP (and U.S. debut) for the English band was produced by the Cocteau Twins' Simon Raymonde.
The third full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was recorded in England and France with Mickey Smith.
Members of Calexico guest on the singer-songwriter's Matador debut.
The title of Plant's new album revives the name of his pre-Zeppelin psychedelic band from the '60s and combines folksy rock with his own solo work.

The surprise digital release from the alternative country band includes songs from recording sessions from the recently released, The Unraveling plus a few songs written while under the pandemic quarantine.
The 41st full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter features contributions from Jay Berliner and The Righteous Brothers' Bill Medley.
The experimental doom band worked with Bobby Krlic (also known as the Haxan Cloak) on its fourth full-length release.
This debut LP for Scotland cut-and-paste artist Myles MacInnes was released in the UK in 2004 and finally hit American shores in early 2006.
Wilco's Jeff Tweedy returns to produce the singer's latest release that includes songs written by Alan Sparhawk of Low, Nick Lowe, and Tweedy.
The 16th full-length studio release for the experimental rock band features a guest appearance from Kacey Musgraves
The Los Angeles band's debut album is the latest to incorporate afropop to its sound.
The fourth full-length solo release for the Nashville guitarist was produced by Bradley Cook and Tucker Martine.
The ex-Pipettes singer worked with Oli Bayston (aka Boxed In) on her second full-length solo release.
The fourth release for the Polaris Prize-winning Inuit throat-singer features a guest appearance from Shad.
Audion is the dirty-minded techno alter-ego of Matthew Dear.
The debut solo album from Steve Hauschildt, member of the Cleveland-based electronica trio Emeralds, was named for the Greek muses of tragedy (Melpomene) and geometry (Polyhymnia).

The fifth full-length release for Sarah Assbring features influences from music and instruments from around the world including Africa, the guzheng (a Chinese string instrument) and the Japanese shakuhachi flute.
This is the third full-length release for the British electronic producer.
Produced by Odd Nosdam, the Chicago rapper's latest full-length release is a follow-up to his Kenny Dennis EP as his mustached alter ego.
This is the third album for the group led by Mark Kozelek, who also wrote and produced the album.

recordname: For Those That Wish to Exist
description: The ninth full-length release for the British metalcore band features guest appearances from Mike Kerr, Winston McCall, and Simon Neil.
The second full-length solo release for The Walkmen frontman was self-produced and mixed.
The second full-length release for the London-based electronic producer features guest appearances from DRS and James Massiah.
The sixth full-length release for the British rapper features production from Four Tet and Adrian Sherwood.
The 22nd studio release for the British metal trio was produced by Cameron Webb and features a cover of The Rolling Stones' Sympathy For The Devil.
This is the debut full-length release for the Barcelona-based house producer John Talabot.
The California rapper who worked on Dr. Dre's Detox album releases his third independent album, featuring Colin Munroe, GLC, RZA, Schoolboy Q, Ashtro Bot, BJ the Chicago Kid, and Ab-Soul as guests.
Saul Williams, Matt Sweeney and Josh Klinghoffer appear as guests on the sixth release for the desert blues rock band from Mali.
The fifth studio album for the metal band from Oakland, California, was produced by Greg Fidelman.

The soundtrack to the Black Panther film was curated by Kendrick Lamar (and he features on five songs) includes appearances from such artists as 2 Chainz, Ab-Soul, Anderson .Paak, James Blake, Future, Jay Rock, Swae Lee, Mozzy, ScHoolboy Q, Travis Scott, Vince Staples, the Weeknd, and Zacari.
The first release in eight years for the Irish electronic artist who was one-half of Moloko was produced by Eddie Stevens.
Well over to the indie-rock side of anticon's indie-rap -- indie-rock continuum, Why? (aka Yoni Wolf) returns with an eight-song EP.
The first full-length release for the Canadian singer-songwriter in eight years was co-produced by Jim Bryson and Ian Fitchuk.

The debut full-length release for the supergroup that includes Le Butcherettes' Terri Gender-Bender, The Mars Volta/At The Drive-In's Omar Rodriguez-Lopez, the Melvins' King Buzzo and Dale Crover was produced by Rodriguez-Lopez.
The fourth full-length release for Spencer Krug as Moonface is simplified with only piano and vocals.
The second of a trilogy of mixtapes from Canadian artist The Weeknd was produced by Doc McKinney and Illangelo.
The first full-length solo release for Lone Justice singer in 13 years features a 19-piece orchestra.
The debut full-length release for the Dutch producer Mitchel van Dinther features contributions from such artists as Steve Kuhn, Thundercat, and Arthur Verocai.
The sixth full-length release for the New Jersey indie rock band is its first album in six years.
This is the first studio release for the Japanese noise rock duo of Yako and Agata since 2007's Bambi's Dilemma.
The second full-length studio release for the Atlanta rapper features guest appearances from Andre 3000, Casino, Drake, Pharrell, Pusha T, Kanye West, and Wiz Khalifa.
The New Pornographers singer (and accomplished solo artist) offers up a live set of originals and eclectic covers, backed by The Sadies.
The fourth full-length album for the band led by Johnny Jewel features 17 tracks.
The fifth full-length solo studio release for the Canadian indie pop artist features a guest appearance from Jarvis Cocker and was produced with Mocky and Renaud LeTang.
The 10th solo release for the Throwing Muses lead singer was released as a book of essays and stories.

recordname: Music for the Age of Miracles
description: This is the first new release of music in seven years for the British indie rock/pop band.

recordauthor: A Winged Victory for the Sullen
description: The latest full-length release from the duo of Dustin O'Halloran and Stars of the Lid's Adam Wiltzie was originally created for a Leo Warner-directed multimedia stage production based on Italo Calvino's 1972 novel Invisible Cities.
This is the second full-length release for British singer-songwriter Archy Marshall under the name King Krule.
The debut full-length release for the psychedelic folk rock band formed by Meg Baird, Ethan Miller, Noel Von Harmonson, and Charlie Saufley was recorded by Eric Bauer in San Francisco.
The underground hip-hop producer (also a member of Soul Position) returns with a follow-up to his acclaimed 2002 Def Jux Debut, 'Dead Ringer.'
Kelis' third LP (second in the States) features production from the Neptunes, Dallas Austin and Andre 3000.

This 16-track compilation offers an impressive sampling of the New York underground scene from the late 1970s and early 80s, including cuts from "no-wave," post-punk, experimental and hip-hop artists such as ESG, Material, DNA, Defunkt, and Liquid Liquid.
A former member of UK hip-hop outfit So Solid Crew, Ms. Dynamite (aka Niomi McLean-Daley) earned Britain's Mercury Music Prize for this debut effort.
Singer/songwriter Josh Rouse's third solo LP was produced by Roger Moutenot.
The second full-length release for the London-based artist features guest appearances from Miguel Atwood-Ferguson and Lauren Faith.
The debut full-length release from British singer-songwriter was produced by Joe Rubel.
The third full-length solo release for the San Francisco-based indie rock artist was produced with Tim Sandusky.
The seventh full-length release for the Baltimore dream pop duo was recorded in part in its home studio with some help from Peter Kember (aka Sonic Boom).

recordauthor: The World Is a Beautiful Place & I Am No Longer Afraid to Die
description: The third full-length studio release for the Connecticut emo group was produced by Chris Teti.
Kevin Barnes' eighth Of Montreal disc finds the Georgian heading into more electronic territory, enlisting his laptop to assist in the recording process. Music on a laptop--who knew?
The seventh full-length solo release for the Detroit rapper/producer features guest appearances from Ab, Dwele, and Sudie.
This is the fourth full-length release (and its first on the SideOneDummy label) for the West Virginia pop-punk band led by Jordan Hudkins.
The fifth full-length release from the Vermont-born indie folk artist features contributions from Bill Frisell and was produced by Valgeir Sigurðsson.
The follow-up to the Oklahoma singer-songwriter's 2012 Grammy-nominated debut From The Ground Up was co-produced with Wes Sharon.
The Canadian electronic band releases its sophomore album.

recordname: Hey Hey My My Yo Yo
description: The Danish duo return with their second album.
This is the debut full-length release for Houston-based electronic producer Eric Burton.
The fifth full-length release for the Pennsylvania punk band was produced by Will Yip.
Chicago's Smith Westerns take psychedelic rock to the next level with their second album of David Bowie-inspired vocals and catchy melodies.

The eighth full-length studio release for North Carolina-based indie folk band led by M.C. Taylor was produced with Brad Cook and features contributions from Tift Merritt, Skylar Gudasz, Mac McCaughan, Alexandra Sauser-Monnig, Tamisha Waden, and John Paul White.
The Scottish duo of Aidan Moffett and Malcolm Middleton return with a sixth studio album.
This the first solo studio release to feature the guitarist on an electric guitar.
The fifth full-length solo release for the The Sea and Cake band member is his first in five years.
The fifth full-length release for the London-based experimental/post-rock band was produced by Erol Alkan.
The debut full-length release for the Berlin-based Finnish experimental electronic duo of Ville Haimala and Martti Kalliala features guest appearances from Pan Daijing and Oracle.
The second full-length release for the Atlanta-based R&B/soul artist was produced with Danger Mouse and Sam Cohen.

The follow-up to Dave and Phil Alvin's Grammy-nominated Common Grounds release is another covers album that includes songs from such artists as James Brown, Thomas Dorsey, Lead Belly, and Big Joe Turner.
The swamp rock veteran's latest release is his first on the Yep Roc label.
The Grammy-nominated singer-songwriter's ninth album features Rodney Crowell as a guest singer.
'Superwolf' is the first collaboration between singer-songwriter Will Oldham (aka Bonnie Prince Billy) and Zwan's Matt Sweeney.
The legendary socially conscious rocker joins forces with producer Daniel Lanois, creating an album full of self-proclaimed folk-metal music.

recordname: The Power Of Negative Thinking: B-Sides & Rarities
description: The four-disc collection of B-sides and rare recordings from the Scottish band.
A year after the release of the self-titled compilation albuum from the Brooklyn-based electronic duo of Sam Haar and Zach Steinman comes its follow-up full-length with nine new tracks.
This is the fifth album for the Seattle-based singer-songwriter.
This second studio LP for the Sunderland, England trio once again finds the band being compared to XTC.
The second full-length release for the Oklahoma-born singer-songwriter was produced with Mark Neill.
The 12th full-length release for the Virginia six-string and lap guitarist features contributions from Forrest Marquisee and Ian McColm.
UK producer Gold Panda's debut is a fusion of psychedelic pop, samples and dance beats.
Former The Band drummer/singer returns with a solo album.
The latest release for the Los Angeles R&B artist features guest appearances from Shana Jenson and Dudley Perkins.

Released digitally, the instrumentals and vocals for the fifth full-length studio release for the Sacramental experimental hip-hop band was also released as a free download. A physical release of the entire album is scheduled for July.

The debut full-length release for the collaboration between Sufjan Stevens and Angelo De Augustine was inspired by such films as All About Eve, Bring It On Again, Night of the Living Dead, Mad Max, Point Break, Silence of the Lambs, and The Thing.
The third full-length release for the award-winning country singer-songwriter was produced with Dave Cobb.
The third full-length release for the Illinois emo band features guest appearances from Rachel Goswell, Elizabeth Powell and Hayley Williams.
The Tuareg group releases their fifth studio album, fusing blues and styles of the nomadic people of the Sahara.
Steve "Kode9" Goodman, the London-based electric artist, collaborates with Stephen "The Spaceape" Gordon for a second album of dubstep and techno jams.
The Swedish singer's second studio album features guest singers Frida Hyvonen and El Perro del Mar.
The Manchester, England, native wrote, produced, recorded, and mixed his sophomore album.

The 20th studio release for the British singer-songwriter features contributions from such artists as Anna Calvi, Nick Cave, Steve Earle, Ed Harcourt, Tom McRae, Portishead's Adrian Utley, and Pink Floyd's Roger Waters.
The debut full-length release for the Houston-born and Berlin-based electronic producer J'Kerian Morgan was inspired partly by marching bands and Ta-Nehisi Coates' "Between The World And Me."
The 16th full-length release from the British heavy metal band was produced by Kevin Shirley.
The third solo album for the folk singer was produced by Rob Schnapf.
The debut album for the Bristol, England experimental music duo.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Canadian artist features contributions from such artists as Belly, Max Martin, Metro Boomin, Oneohtrix Point Never, and Tame Impala.
Formerly known as Dive, this is the debut album for the rock-pop quartet led by Z. Cole Smith of Beach Fossils.

The 12th full-length release for North Carolina indie rock band Superchunk features contributions from such artists as Tracyanne Campbell of Camera Obscura, R.E.M.'s Mike Mills, Owen Pallett, Andy Stack of Wye Oak, Sharon Van Etten, Norman Blake and Raymond McGinley of Teenage Fanclub.

recordname: Nearer the Fountain, More Pure the Stream Flows
description: The second full-length solo release for Blur/Gorillaz's Damon Albarn was inspired by Icelandic and was originally planned as an orchestral project for Lyon's Fête des Lumieres.
Produced by John Congleton, the latest full-length release for the trio of sisters was influenced in part by the death of their mother and the birth of Emily's first child.
The debut full-length release for the Canadian singer-songwriter features contributions from Valentin Ignat, Jake Portrait and Gabe Wax.
The debut full-length solo release for The Maccabees frontman was produced by Markus Dravs.
The second full-length release for the Australian indie rock band was produced by Burke Reid.
The latest full-length studio release for the British post-punk band features an eight-minute-long track.
The fifth full-length release for the Florida metal band is its first with new new bassist Eric Hernandez of Wrong.
The second full-length studio release for the New York City-based hardcore punk trio was produced with Chris Coady and Gabriel Millman.
The sixth full-length release for the British alternative rock band is its first with the Dangerbird (and Rock Action in the UK) label.

The collaboration with Lucinda Williams, the saxophonist and the Marvels (Bill Frisell, Greg Leisz, Reuben Rogers, and Eric Harland) features new versions of Williams' songs Dust, Ventura and Unsuffer Me, as well as Thelonious Monks Monks Mood, Jim Hendrixs Angel, and three original instrumentals.

recordname: I Love You Like a Brother
description: The debut full-length release for the Australian pop singer-songwriter was produced with Oscar Dawson.
The third full-length release for the Chicago post-punk band was recorded by Steve Albini.
The seventh full-length studio release for the British alternative rock band is its first without drummer Richard Jupp, who left to pursue his own projects.
This is the second full-length release for the New York City-based industrial metal duo of vocalist Michael Berdan and Ben Greenberg.
The 16th studio release for the British folk-rock singer was produced by Wilco's Jeff Tweedy.
This is the latest full-length release for Emil Amos' solo project Holy Sons.
The tenth studio release for the drone metal band led by Dylan Carlson, features guest appearances from Mark Lanegan, Brett Nelson of Built to Spill, Rabia Shaheen Qazi, and Jodie Cox.

The first full-length release in four years for the singer-songwriter includes contributions from Beth Nielsen Chapman, Ben Glover, Scott Nolan, Gretchen Peters, Darrell Scott, and the McCrary Sisters.
Garage/psych rocker John Dwyer moves to Los Angeles and worked with Casafis, Mikal Cronin, Greer McGettrick and Woodhouse on the his latest studio release.
The first release in five years for the Argentinean singer-songwriter was written, recorded and produced by herself.

recordname: Reason to Believe: The Songs of Tim Hardin
description: Gavin Clark, Diagrams, Alela Diane, Mark Lanegan, Magnetic North, Okkervil River, Hannah Peel, Pinkunoizu, Smoke Fairies, The Phoenix Foundation, The Sand Band, and Sarabeth Tucek contributed to the tribute album to folk singer-songwriter Tim Hardin.
This is the second all-crew release from the Minneapolis, hip-hop collective. Produced by Paper Tiger and Laserbeak, it features emcees: P.O.S., Sims, Cecil Otter, Mike Mictlan, and Dessa.
This is the debut release for the group that includes producer Black Milk, Guilty Simpson, and Sean Price.
The Texas-born singer-songwriter's second album features nine original songs and covers of Bob Dylan and Radiohead.
Talib Kweli and Hi-Tek reunite for their second album together in ten years. It features guest appearnces by such artists as Mos Def, Bun B, Estelle, Bilal, Jay Electronica, and J Cole.
Silver Mt. Zion Orchestra return for the Athens, GA-based singer-songwriter's latest album, the first of two album released this year [the live album, "Skitter On Take Off" was released October 6th].
The latest EP for the Atlanta, Georgia indie-rock band was produced by Nicolas Vernhes.
The South African indie-rock band releases its first EP produced by Secret Machines' Brandon Curtis.
Rage Against the Machine's Zack De La Rocha releases his solo EP, which includes Mars Volta's Jon Theodore on drums.
One of the rare country music stars who is both a critical and commercial success (and without crossing over into pop), Jackson returns with a follow-up to his huge 2002 hit 'Drive.'
This is the third full-length album for the challenging, intensely personal Bay Area post-punk outfit led by Jamie Stewart.

Rilo Kiley's Blake Sennett is the mastermind behind this collective, which includes contributions from members of Azure Ray and Ozma and production from Mike Mogis (Bright Eyes) and Jimmy Tamborello (DNTEL, Postal Service).

This is the third full-length for the Detroit garage rockers led by guitarist Mick Collins (ex of the Gories) and featuring a supersized rhythm section of two bass players and two drummers. Included in early versions are bonus covers of Brian Eno's "King's Lead Hat" and Robyn Hitchcock's "Executioner of Love."
This is the second album for the quriky Scottish indie-pop duo of Colin MacIntyre and Alan Malloy.

Ugly Casanova is the alter ego of Modest Mouse singer/guitarist Isaac Brock, who makes his solo debut with this release. The 13 tracks were produced by Brian Deck (Tortoise, Sea and Cake), and the backing band includes Pall Jenkins (Black Heart Procession) and Tim Rutili (Red Red Meat), but it sounds a lot like a Modest Mouse release.

Produced by Matt Hyde, 'God Hates Us All' is the eighth studio album (and first in three years) for the Southern California thrash-metal band. Originally set for a July 2001 release, the album was delayed so that American Recordings head Rick Rubin and producer Sean Beavan could remix each of the tracks.
The follow-up album from the trio headed by Zach Condon.
The singer-songwriter three-disc set continues his exploration of the Great American Songbook and was produced by Jack Frost.
The second full-length studio release for the Atlanta-born R&B/soul singer was recorded in Memphis, Tennessee and in Germany with his co-producer, Patrice Bart-Williams.

The first new release for the London-based actress/singer in six years features contributions from Paul McCartney, Daft Punk's Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo, Connan Mockasin, Owen Pallett, and SebastiAn.
Bringing back his blend of Motown and neo-soul to pop music, Cee-Lo returns with his third solo album featuring his viral hit, "F*** You".

recordname: A Chance To Cut Is A Chance To Cure
description: The fourth LP (and the first on Matador) from the experimental San Francisco outfit is a concept album about plastic surgery, utilizing samples from actual surgical procedures in its seven electronic/techno tracks. A track from this LP was included in the Whitney Museum's Bitstreams Exhibit in Spring 2001.
The Canadian electronic pop duo of Jeremy Greenspan and Matt Didemus return from a five-year break (they each worked on other solo projects) to release their fifth full-length release.

recordname: X: The Godless Void and Other Stories
recordauthor: ...And You Will Know Us by the Trail of Dead
description: The 10th full-length release for the Austin-based alternative rock band was produced by the band's own Conrad Keely and Charles Godfrey.

recordname: Tell Me How You Really Feel
description: The second full-length release for the Australian singer-songwriter was produced with Burke Reid and Dan Luscombe.

The debut full-length collaboration between Primal Scream's Bobby Gillespie and the Savages' Jehnny Beth includes contribution from Johnny Hostile and Primal Scream's Martin Duffy, Andrew Innes, and Darrin Mooney.
The second album for the Los Angeles folk-rock band was produced by Jonathan Wilson.

recordauthor: David Kilgour and the Heavy Eights
description: The latest solo release (his second with the Heavy Eights) from the former co-founder of New Zealand indie-pop band the Clean was recorded over three years.
The second release from the Danish post-punk band was self-produced.
The Japanese band named after a Melvins song releases their latest album.
The third full-length release for the British electronic producer Stuart Howard features guest appearances from GABI, JFDR, Louisahhh, and Talvi.
The second full-length release for the Los Angeles-based harpist was created in a Northern California barn during a residency at the Headlands Center for the Arts.
This is the first release on the Hyperdub label for the London-based electronic DJ/producer.
Inspired in part by his 2013 memoir, the first solo studio release for the Kinks founding member in a decade was co-produced with Guy Massey and John Jackson.
The debut full-length release for the British five-piece led by Ryan Smith was recorded and mixed by Alex Greaves.

Not commonly known for his subtlety, the singer from Wales returns with an album that keeps it simple and goes back to basics--blues and traditional gospel songs that are spiritual and speak nothing but the truth.
The debut full-length release for the Wisconsin indie rock band that includes Raina Bock, Isaac de Broux-Slone, Shannon Connor, Logan Severson, and Brendan Manley was produced by Rob Schnapf.
The singer/songwriter's fifth release, funded by a Kickstarter campaign, is lyrically poignant and melodic with a folk edge.
The seventh full-length album self-produced by the band strips the music down to nothing more than guitar, bass, precussion, and Britt Daniel's voice.

The sixth full-length studio release for the experimental electronic producer/rapper features guest appearances from Anderson Paak, George Clinton, Denzel Curry, Little Dragon, David Lynch, Shabazz Palaces, Solange, Thundercat, Tierra Whack, and Toro y Moi.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles-based Kuwaiti electronic composer was inspired by poetry written by Arab women.
The third full-length release for the soul singer discovered by Daptone founder Gabriel Roth features a cover of Black Sabbath's track.
The fourth full-length release for Stephen Bruner as Thundercat features guest appearances from Wiz Khalifa, Kendrick Lamar, Kenny Loggins, Michael McDonald, and Pharrell.
The fourth album for the Scottish band was produced by Jari Haapalainen.
The Swedish duo releases their second album.
The fourth full-length studio release for Axel Willner as The Field was created without computers.

recordname: Dragging A Dead Deer Up A Hill
description: The third album for the Portland, Oregon-based indie pop singer Liz Harris.
The San Francisco band, now relocated to Los Angeles and with two new members, releases its latest album.
The 12th full-length solo studio release for the singer-songwriter was produced by Paul Butler.

Daughter of Loudon and sister of Rufus, Martha becomes the third Wainwright to release an album in 2005. This self-titled effort is her full-length debut, following on the heels of her subtly-titled EP "Bloody Mother Fucking Asshole."
The debut full-length release for the Australian punk trio of Matt Boggis, Josh Price, and Eamon Sandwith was recorded in Geelong by Billy Gardner.
The latest full-length release from the Jamaican dub artist was produced by Adrian Sherwood.
The seventh full-length solo release for the rapper features guest appearances from Andra Day, G-Eazy, Cee Lo Green, Lil Wayne, and P.U.R.E.
The British singer-songwriter's concept album was based on the poetry by socialist activist William Morris.
The debut full-length release for the British producer features guest appearances by Steffaloo, Co Ma, and Birds Of Passage.
The 21-year-old British singer-songwriter's second solo recording again sets his instrumentation against a moody electronic backdrop.
The third full-length studio release from the Brooklyn rapper includes such guests and producers as Pharoahe Monch, The Alchemist, 9th Wonder, and Khrysis.
The second full-length release for the British psychedelic/noise rock quintet is its first with new drummer, JN.
The latest release for the New York indie pop project of Greta Kline is its first on the Sub Pop label.

recordname: Songs From The Year Of Our Demise
description: 'Songs' is the first solo LP for the co-founder of The Posies, who is also a member of the current lineup of Big Star.
The third full-length release (and the first on the Columbia label) for the Swedish sister duo was produced by Mike Mogis.

recordname: The Return To Form Black Majick Party
description: A member of Ladytron's touring band as well as the trio Super Numeri, English multi-instrumentalist Jonathan Pop Levi (yes, Pop is indeed his middle name) makes his full-length solo debut with this eclectic disc.
The San Francisco-based garage revivalist returns with a new record, the first on Drag City's label.
This is the fifth album for the rock band from Rhode Island.
This is the seventh album for the New York noise-rock three-piece. Phil Manley of Trans Am guests.
Nas co-produced this double album along with Salaam Remi, Q-Tip and L.E.S. Also stopping by to lend a hand (or a voice) are Busta Rhymes, Kelis, Ludacris and Maxwell.
The second solo release for the former Pavement leader (although it is credited to "Stephen Malkmus & The Jicks"), 'Pig Lib' features 11 new tracks.

This is the second full-length album for the Los Angeles-based indie band, who are now labelmates of Omaha's Bright Eyes. Fans of the TV program "Boy Meets World" (all three of you) may recognize guitarist Blake Sennett, who played Joey on that show. (Singer Jenny Lewis has also guested on numerous sitcoms over the years.)
Former Galaxie 500 members Damon Krukowski and Naomi Yang unite with Japanese outfit Ghost for an album of dreamy, contemplative folk-rock.
The 12th studio release for the British alternative rock band is its first album without founding member Jon Brookes, who passed away in 2013 from brain cancer.

recordname: There Is a Hell, Believe Me I've Seen It, There is a Heaven, Let's Keep It a Secret
description: The British metal band's third album was produced by Fredrik Nordstrom and features guest appearances by Lights, You Me At Six's Josh Franceschi, and The Chariot's Josh Scogin.
The Russia-born, New York-based anti-folkie returns with a dozen new tracks produced by David Kahne (The Strokes).
The fourth full-length release for Katie Crutchfield's music project was produced with John Agnello.
This is the second studio album for the the indie rock duo from Los Angeles.
The double album from the Canadian indie rock band was produced with James Murphy and Markus Dravs.
The first daughter of modern French pop releases her third album, IRM (the album's title is French for the MRI machines), produced by Beck.
This is a recording of the special concert of Willie Nelson and Wynton Marsalis who performed together in January 2007 at Jazz at Lincoln Center.

recordname: Mourning in America and Dreaming in Color
description: Produced by Jake One, the fifth album for the Minnesota rapper features guest appearances from Dr. Cornell West, Amir Sulaiman, Choklate, and Tone Trezure.
The swirling organ, hymn-filled group harmonies, and choral percussion from this Duluth band's latest album make it sound like it was recorded in a church, which it was: a converted Catholic church.

The latest full-length release for the Canadian experimental artist was written and recorded while starting a new long distance relationship, living in a city hit by forest fires and the death of his grandfather.
This is the debut full-length release for the Brooklyn-based psych-pop jazz-influenced quartet of Lila Ramani, Brian Aronow, Jesse Brotter, and Jonathan Gilad.
The debut full-length release for Australian Oliver Hugh Perry was self-produced and recorded in London.
The second full-length release for the Canadian post-punk band led by Tim Darcy was recorded in Montreal.
This is the second full-length release for the British quartet (that also perform as the band Monotony).
The fifth full-length release for the British folk ensemble was produced by Rupert Christie.
This is the seventh album from the Australian indie-pop group led by singing drummer Tali White.
The Boise, Idaho trio returns with a follow-up to 1999's 'Keep It Like A Secret.'

recordname: We Are the 21st Century Ambassadors of Peace & Magic
description: The second full-length release for the psychedelic rock duo was produced by Richard Swift.

Despite the misleading title, 'The Greatest' is not a best-of collection, but rather is Chan Marshall's first album of original songs in three years. It was recorded in Memphis and finds the singer backed by some of that city's legendary session musicians.
The debut full-length release for the collaboration between Heems and Riz MC was produced by Redinho.
The third full-length release for the British art rock band was produced by Stuart Price.
The ninth full-length release for the Malian Afro-pop duo was produced by Adrien Durand.
Unlike his Welsh-language solo debut, the more accessible 'Candylion' finds the Super Furry Animals leader singing mainly in English.
The British artist reworked and rerecorded some of her songs from 1989's The Sensual World and 1993's The Red Shoes albums.
The British singer's latest album was produced by John Parrish and Flood.

The third full-length studio release for the Mississippi rapper features guest appearances from Bilal, Robert Glasper, CeeLo Green, Keyon Harrold, Joi, Lloyd, Jill Scott, Sleepy Brown, T.I., Burniss Earl Travis II, UKG, and Kenneth Whalum.

Grammy-nominated Dierks Bentley releases an all-acoustic bluegrass country album featuring guest appearances by Kris Kristofferson, Miranda Lambert, Jamey Johnson, the Del McCoury Band, and the Punch Brothers.
The rock-influenced piano trio's fifth album mixes originals with covers of songs by David Bowie ("Life On Mars"), Tears For Fears ("Everybody Wants To Rule The World") and Rush ("Tom Sawyer").
Dedicated to the late Vic Chesnutt, Mr. M is the latest album from the alt-country group led by Kurt Wagner and was recorded in Mark Never's studio.
The sixth full-length studio release for New York indie rock band led by Peter Silberman is its first album of new songs in seven years.

recordname: How Did I Find Myself Here?
description: The first studio release in 29 years for the rock band led by Steve Wynn was produced with Chris Cacavas.
The sixth full-length release for the singer-songwriter was produced with Jim James of My Morning Jacket.
The Afghan Whigs' Greg Dulli and Screaming Trees' Mark Lanegan team up on their debut album as The Gutter Twins.

recordname: A Loud Bash of Teenage Feelings
description: The second full-length studio release for the Philadelphia pop-punk band led by James Alex was produced by Dave Downham.
This is the solo debut album for the Black Keys singer/guitarist.
The eighth full-length solo release for the British singer-songwriter was co-produced by Colin Elliot and Shez Sheridan.
The latest release for the Colorado-based singer-songwriter features contributions from Jon Estes, Victor Herrero, Chris Scruggs, Gyða Valtýsdóttir, as well as members of The Cherry Blossoms.
The latest release from the Nigerian saxophonist Orlando Julius is a collaboration with the British funk ensemble The Heliocentrics.
The debut album from the Canadian rapper, who has also remixed songs for Lady Sovereign and Ciara.
The sixth full-length studio release for Sam Beam was recorded live by Tom Schick at The Loft in Chicago.
The second full-length release for Margaret Chardiet as Pharmakon was recorded with Sean Ragon.
The 11th full length release for Liz Harris was written and recorded in Wyoming over a week-and--a-half.
The third full-length release for Australian trio Camp Cope was recorded, produced and mixed with Anna Laverty.
The second full-length album for the indie band was produced with Ken Thomas.
The debut full-length solo release for the Sonic Youth co-founder was produced by Justin Raisen with contributions from Shawn Everett and Jake Meginsky.

recordname: A Rush Of Blood To The Head
description: The UK quartet follows the critical and commercial success of their 2000 debut album 'Parachutes' with this long-awaited follow-up release, which the band has suggested may be their last.
The latest full-length release for the John Darnielle-led band was recorded in March 2020.
The soundtrack to Brady Corbet's 2015 film that was inspired by a short story by Jean-Paul Sartre about the childhood of a future Fascist leader is the second film score for the avant-garde artist.
Produced with Chris Coady, the sixth studio album is the Baltimore duo's second album for 2015.
The second release since Parker and the Rumour reunited in 2011 was recorded in six days.
Produced by Tucker Martine, the ninth full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter features guest appearances from Neko Case, My Morning Jacket's Jim James, and members of the Decemberists.

recordname: We've Been Going About This All Wrong
description: The sixth full-length release from singer-songwriter Sharon Van Etten was produced with Daniel Knowles.
The ninth full-length studio release for the New York alternative rock band was recorded in Wales.
The eighth full-length solo studio release for the rock producer/singer-songwriter features a duet with Ashley Moore.
The British band's sophomore album was produced by Peter Katis.
The posthumous release for the Ohio singer-songwriter was recorded in 2008.
The 12th full-length studio release for the alt-country/southern rock band was recorded in Memphis with Matt Ross-Spang and producer David Barbe.
The debut full-length release for 18-year-old British indie rock singer-songwriter Lindsey Jordan was produced by Jake Aron.
This is the debut full-length solo studio release for Chicago house producer Jamal Moss.

recordname: When the Cellar Children See the Light of Day
description: The second release for the Finnish singer-songwriter was produced by Vladislav Delay.
The debut full-length release for the Olympia, Washington indie punk quartet formed by brothers, Alex Coxen and Joe Rutter.
The latest ambient album for Scott Morgan, the Canadian producer, features a spoken word track with Destroyer's Dan Bejar.
This is the first solo release for Carl Newman, who can also be found leading indie-rock supergroup The New Pornographers as well as the (now defunct) Canadian power-pop band Zumpano.
The Glasgow, Scotland-based band follow 2000's stunning 'The Great Eastern' with this, their fourth (and almost equally stunning) LP. Dave Fridmann (Mercury Rev) returns as producer.

Slightly (and confusingly) changing their name to Godspeed You! Black Emperor for this outing, the Canadian instrumental band recorded these 5 tracks (clocking in at 75 minutes) with Steve Albini as a follow-up to their extremely well-received 2000 effort 'Lift Yr Skinny Fists Like Antennas To Heaven.'
This is Slint guitarist David Pajo's first solo LP under his own name (well, at least half of his own name).

recordname: The Bones of What You Believe
description: This is the debut full-length studio release for the Scottish synth-pop trio.

recordname: The Besnard Lakes Are The Roaring Night
description: The indie rock quartet led by music producer Jace Lasek and his wife Olga releases its second album on the Jagjaguwar label.
The second album from Side One Dummy Records for the New York band who are influenced by gypsy music.

While some eponymous albums suggest a lack of creativity, the heralded UK rock outfit's sophomore disc is titled 'The Libertines' because it is indeed about The Libertines--or, more specifically, about the ongoing conflict between the band's two songwriters, Carlos Barat and Pete Doherty (the latter of whom was subsequently kicked out of the band after three failed rehab attempts). The Clash's Mick Jones returns as producer.
The fourth full-length release for the Toronto punk rock trio was co-produced with Uniform's Ben Greenberg.
The debut full-length studio release for the Tennessee rap artist features guest appearances from Deacon Blues, Kari Faux, Hugh Augustine, Kendrick Lamar, Jay Rock, SiR, Syd the Kid, SZA, and Zacari.
The 12th full-length studio release for the alt-country band was recorded in Nashville and was produced by Vance Powell.
The debut full-length release for the solo project from former Slow Club member Rebecca Taylor was produced by The Very Best's Johan Karlberg.
The second full-length release for the British pop-punk trio led by Lande Hekt was produced and mixed by Lewis Johns.
The soundtrack by Daniel Lopatin for the 2017 film directed by Josh and Benny Safdie was awarded the Best Soundtrack Award at Cannes.
This Eastern European-sounding, multi-instrumental effort is actually the work of Albuquerque teenager Zach Condon. Members of A Hawk And A Hacksaw also lend a hand.
The latest full-length studio release for the South Korean pop band features production from Brasstracks and Cosmo's Midnight.

This is the third Hawk album for former Neutral Milk Hotel drummer Jeremy Barnes. Like previous efforts, it has an Eastern European flavor, although unlike previous efforts, it also includes contributions from Beirut's Zach Condon.
The second album for the Baltimore-based indie rock band led by Jana Hunter was produced Drew Brown.
The debut full-length studio release for the Los Angeles rapper features guest appearances from Drake, Jeezy, Kendrick Lamar, Jay Rock, Schoolboy Q, and Ty Dolla $ign.
The debut full-length collaborative album for Beyonce and Jay-Z was a surprise release and features guest appearances from Migos, Offset, Quavo, Rory from Stone Love, and Ty Dolla $ign.
The debut full-length studio release for the Brooklyn-based rap trio of Meechy Darko, Zombie Juice and Erick The Architect Elliott features guest appearances from Diamante and Anthony Flammia.

13+God is a collaboration between German rocktronica outfit The Notwist and American indie-rappers Themselves. Also guesting are members of Ms. John Soda, Lali Puna, and cLOUDDEAD; basically, if they're on Morr Music or Anticon, you'll find them here.
The second full-length release for Canadian duo Devon Welsh and Matthew Otto features contributions from Owen Pallett.
The fourth full-length release for the British electronic producer features guest appearances from André 3000, Metro Boomin, Rosalía, Travis Scott, and Moses Sumney.

recordname: All My Demons Greeting Me as a Friend
description: The Norwegian dark pop singer-songwriter worked with Odd Martin Skalnes and Magnus Skylstad on her debut full-length release.
The fourth release for the quintet-turned duo of Luke Temple and Michael Bloch was self-produced.
The sixth release for the Swedish rock band is said to be its final album.
The debut full-length release for the Los Angeles-based punk band The Linda Lindas was recorded, mixed and produced by Carlos de la Garza.
The ninth full-length studio release for the Austin rock band features some songs that were either demos, outtakes or were not included in previous albums.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Nashville-based country artist was produced by Jay Joyce.
The second full-length release from the indie rock artist was produced with Trey Pollard.
The fifth studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from Ab-Soul and Nikki Jean.
The third full-length release for the Canadian doom metal band was produced by Ian Blurton.
This second Maritime LP is the final one to feature former Dismemberment Plan bassist Eric Axelson, who left the group (which also includes former members of the Promise Ring) after its recording.
This is the debut release for the indie London-based quartet that began at an Edinburgh art school.

recordname: Besnard Lakes Are the Last of the Great Thunderstorm Warnings
description: The latest full-length release for the Canadian psych-rock group was produced by the band's own Jace Lasek and Olga Goreas.
The Canadian twins' latest album features members of Death Cab for Cutie and AFI.
The seventh full-length studio release for the British rock band was produced by Ben Allen and features a guest appearance from Pauline Murray.
The eighth full-length studio release for the Texas rock band was recorded in Austin over eight weeks.
The sixth full-length studio release for the alternative rock band led by Tom DeLonge is its first on the Rise label.
The first release in over 11 years for the doom band was produced by Nick Raskulinecz.

recordname: I Like to Keep Myself in Pain
description: The first solo album in over 11 years for the Georgia singer includes songs written for her by Andrew Bird, Vic Chesnutt, John Wesley Harding, Robyn Hitchcock, the Mekons' Jon Langford, Stephin Merritt, and M. Ward.
This is the latest four-track EP for the Los Angeles-based indie rock duo.
This self-titled disc marks the debut for the Vermont freak-folk outfit.
The latest release from James Jackson Toth as Wooden Wand was recorded over six different sessions.
Their music sounds British and the vocals are sometimes in Japanese, but this four-piece shoegaze outfit (returning here with a second album) hails from Brooklyn.
The third full-length release for the alternative pop artist features guest appearances Dominic Fike, Alanis Morissette and BTS' Suga.

The fourth full-length release for the indie folk band led by Justin Vernon features contributions from such artists as James, Blake, the Brooklyn Youth Chorus, BJ Burton, S. Carey, Aaron & Bryce Dessner, Phil Cook, Moses Sumney and Bruce Hornsby, and Wye Oak's Jenn Wasner.
The second full-length release for the Southern California metal band was produced by Converge guitarist, Kurt Ballou.
The veteran British folkie is joined by Espers, Devendra Banhart and Beth Orton on his latest release.
This is the third album for London-based rapper Rodney Smith.
The half-English, half-Italian singer's self-titled debut showcases her sophisticated songwriting abilities -- drawing comparisons to PJ Harvey -- and her musical prowess.
The 11th full-length studio release from the Memphis alt-country punk rock band was produced by Ted Hutt.
The tenth full-length studio release for the British rock band was produced by Christer-André Cederberg.

recordname: Here's My Song You Can Have It... I Don't Want It Anymore/Yours 4-Ever
description: The Swedish singer-songwriter and former soccer player is backed by Mercury Rev on his latest release (which originally emerged in 2004 in Europe).
This is the second release for the alternative rock band led by former Royal Trux member Jennifer Herrema.
The debut album for the Brooklyn trio is less than 22 minutes long.
The sixth full-length solo release for The Hold Steady's Craig Finn features a 14-piece string section and was produced by Josh Kaufman.
