This sophomore set finds the Texas five-piece utilizing a 1970's classic rock / soft rock sound.
The third full-length release for Chrystia Cabral as Spellling was self-produced.
This is the debut full-length release for the London-based duo from Belfast, Matt McBriar and Andy Ferguson.
The latest release from the Ukrainian pianist was inspired by a variety of waterways including The Amazon.
Dr. John revives the Night Tripper persona for his new album Tribal, which features guest spots from Derek Trucks, Donald Harrison, and tunes by Bobby Charles and Allen Toussaint.
The quartet from Spain releases its third album.
The third full-length release for Nathaniel Rateliff and his band was produced by Brad Cook and R.M.B.(Rateliff, Patrick Meese, and James Barone).
The 11th full-length studio release for the Minnesota alt-country band was recorded over two weeks.
The 12th full-length release for the Maryland rock band was produced by Vance Powell.

The debut full-length release for the all-female supergroup of African artists that includes Pamela Badjogo, Massan Coulibaly, Mariam Doumbia, Mamani Keita, Angelique Kidjo, Mariam Kone, Rokia Kone, Kandia Kouyaté, Nneka, and Mouneissa Tandina was produced by Liam Farrell.
The third full-length release for experimental pop duo of Daniel OSullivan and Alexander Tucker
The latest album from the Nashville-based singer-songwriter was produced with Eric McConnell.

Losing none of the momentum put in motion by his 2009 effort, Deeper Than Rap, Rick Ross keeps a very good thing going on Teflon Don, arguably his best album to date. You want rap-style luxury? Then Deeper is the better fit, but Teflon plays up the chilled and soulful elements of its predecessor, meaning Ross has graduated to a level where words like âorganicâ and âpoignantâ come into play. The former is best represented by âMayback Music IIIâ and itâs swirling, â70s-flavored dreamscape created by the J.U.S.T.I.C.E. League production team. Ross allows guests T.I. and Jadakiss to go first on the cut, then grabs his cigar for an uplifting story of ghetto triumph that goes from pushing to pleasing the folks (âParents never had a good job/Now itâs black American Express cards"). When it comes to âpoignant,â the evidence is dotted throughout the album with the rapper reflecting on where heâs been, and he often questions his own lust for fame. He chants the title to the opening âIâm Not a Starâ as if it was a remindful mantra, but itâs his new love of contrasts thatâs really interesting, following Kanyeâs swaggering on âLive Fast, Die Youngâ with âSeems to me we gettinâ money for the wrong things/Look around, Maseratis for the whole team/Look at Haiti, children dyinâ round the clock/Iâd send a hundred grand but thatâs a decent watchâ. The familiar party and thugging tunes work too with âB.M.F. (Blowin' Money Fast),â âNo. 1,â and the mixtape favorite âMC Hammerâ -- now with added Gucci Mane verse -- all coming correct. Add all the Illuminati references in the Jay-Z team-up (âFree Masonâ), a decent smoking song (âSuper Highâ), and a track where Cee-Loâs performance just might make you misty (âTears of Joyâ), and itâs obvious Rossâ albums are no longer just vessels for his singles. ~ David Jeffries
Vanessa Carlton's third album is her first on The Inc. label.
This 31-song live set was recorded during a pair of 2005 shows in the band's native Texas.
The first of two planned 2005 releases for the Colombian pop star is this Spanish-language disc, with its English counterpart due in the fall.
The fourth release of a planned six-part conceptual series for the progressive rock band led by Casey Crescenzo.
This is the tenth full-length release for the California-based techno DJ/producer.
The second retro soul release on Daptone Recordings for the gospel/R&B singer was recorded live on eight-track tape.

recordname: A Church That Fits Our Needs
description: The death of lead singer Ari Picker's mother in 2009 was the catalyst for the second full-length release from the North Carolina chamber folk group.
The latest album for the Irish musician who also contributed to a variety of film soundtracks, including "Ocean's Eleven" and its sequels.
The underground New York MC returns with her sophomore LP, with some production assistance from 9th Wonder.
After some delays, the sequel to the release of the first collaboration together, Blackout!, is finally released.
The nine-track mini-album from the Southern California rapper features guest appearances from Big Freedia, Blood Orange, Jay Cue, Kari Faux, God Colony, Bruno Ribeiro, and Jamila Woods.
This is the debut full-length release for the punk band that includes Huggy Bear's Chris Rowley, Male Bonding's John Arthur Webb and Kevin Hendrick, and Sonny Barrett.
This highly-anticipated and highly-theatrical concept album follow's the New Jersey band's 2004 breakthrough hit 'Three Cheers For Sweet Revenge.'
This disc compiles tracks from all five sessions the band recorded for the BBC's John Peel and Steve Lemacq shows.
The second release for the Nashville singer-songwriter was produced by Jordan Lehning and Skylar Wilson.
This is the third album for the British electronica duo of Alison Goldfrapp and Will Gregory.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Canadian pop artist features a guest appearance from Electric Guest.
This is the second full-length release for the electronic project of Matthew Barnes.
The debut full-length release for the British house music producer features guest appearances from Bixby, Sam Dew, Heavy D. & the Boyz, J'Danna, Julie Mendoza, and Okmalumkoolkat.
Laura and Lydia Rogers were signed onto Jack White's label after an audition in October 2009. The debut album was executive produced by T. Bone Burnett and features both covers and original songs.
The Detroit producer introduces some funk and rock music with a backing band on his fourth full-length solo album.
The second full-length studio release for the collaboration between Nicolás Jaar and Dave Harrington features six track written in 2018.
This the second full-length release for the Denver-based electronic producer Ryan McRyhew.
This is the British dubstep producer's second full-length album and his first on the 4AD label.
This is the third full-length release for the Brooklyn-based quintet was self-recorded.
The debut full-length release for the New York City producer from Sacramento includes contributions from Juan Alderete from Mars Volta and Black Atlass.
The Canadian trio's third album sees its music changing to a more electronic feel under new producer Dan Lissvik.
The fourth full-length release for the British indie rock trio Alt-J was produced by Charlie Andrew.
The first full-length solo studio release in 10 years for the Fleetwood Mac guitarist was self-recorded, produced and mixed in his Los Angeles home studio.
The latest full-length release for the alternative band led by Kurt Wagner was produced and mixed with Jeremy Ferguson.
The debut full-length solo release for the Brooklyn-based indie-pop artist features guest appearances Melanie Faye, Nick Hakim and Shelly.
the 11th full-length release for the alt-country band was produced by Vance Powell.
The second full-length release for the Scottish singer-songwriter was written while she was staying in Nova Scotia.
The second full-length release for the Canadian experimental/art rock five-piece was produced by the band's drummer, Alaska B.
The sixth full-length studio release for the British indie rock band was co-produced by Guy Garvey and Craig Potter of Elbow.
The third full-length album for the hardcore punk band was produced by Kurt Ballou.
The debut album for the indie rock quartet from Leeds.
The first full-length release of new material from the British rock band in 13 years was co-produced by Pete Townshend & D. Sardy with vocal production by Dave Eringa.
This is the debut full-length release for the Brooklyn folk-influenced rock band led by Adrianne Lenker.

Micky Dolenz, Michael Nesmith, and Peter Tork celebrate the 50th anniversary of the pop band with its first new release in 20 years that features songs written by such artists as Rivers Cuomo, Neil Diamond, Noel Gallagher, Andy Partridge, and producer Adam Schlesinger.
Produced by Tucker Martine, the fifth studio album for the New York-based singer-songwriter features Jay Brown, John Convertino, Eric Heywood, and Marc Ribot as guest musicians.
After a 10-year hiatus, Sade returns with her sixth studio effort and first since 2000's "Lover's Rock."
The 15th studio release for John Darnielle is a professional wrestling-themed concept album.
This is the sixth full-length release for Wolfgang Voigt under the GAS moniker.
The fifth full-length studio release for British pop artist Charli XCX features guest appearances from Christine and the Queens, Caroline Polachek, and Rina Sawayama.
The debut full-length release for the Canadian indie rock duo of Courtney Garvin and Connor Mayer was recorded and mixed by Joo-Joo Ashworth.
The debut full-length studio release for the Chicago-based rapper features guest appearances from Michael Anthony, BADBADNOTGOOD, J-Stock, Ravyn Lenae, Noname, Xavier Omär, and theMIND.
The duo's second remix compilation this year includes their take on tracks by Junior Senior, N.E.R.D., Nine Inch Nails, Goldfrapp and more.
The John Dwyer-led band shortens its name from Thee Oh Sees to just Oh Sees for its 19th full-length studio release.
The first album in four years for the New York band led by Pat Gubler adds more rock elements to its acoustic folk style.

recordname: How To Dismantle An Atomic Bomb
description: The band's first new album since 2000, a more stripped-down, "classic U2" disc than previous efforts, was recorded chiefly with producer Steve Lillywhite, with Chris Thomas and Nellee Hooper also helming some tracks.

recordname: Investigate Witch Cults Of The Radio Age
description: Broadcast joins up with The Focus Group to release a 23-track mini album together.
This is the New York-based funk band's third studio album.
The North Carolina husband-and-wife duo of Ivan Howard and Kelly Crisp return with a second album, produced by Brian Paulson.
The trio's seventh studio album is its first to include vocals, which are provided by guests Chan Marshall (Cat Power) and Sally Timms (The Mekons).
Owen Ashworth (previously known as Casiotone for the Painfully Alone) returns under the Advance Base name with an album recorded in a rehearsal room at the Chicago Public Library.
The Swedish electronic duo releases its second studio album.
Howe Gelb is joined by producer John Parish and singers Vic Chesnutt and Patsy Jean on his latest Giant Sand offering.

On her seventh album, a sparser affair than her 2000 effort 'Stories From The City?,' PJ Harvey produced, mixed, and played all of the instruments herself (aside from drums, handled by Robert Ellis), with some additional production from Head.

London-born, 19-year-old jazz vocalist Nellie McKay makes her debut with this 2-disc set produced by Beatles engineer Geoff Emerick. Unlike contemporaries such as Norah Jones, McKay brings a darker edge and a sense of humor (and even a hint of hip hop) to her songs, all of which she wrote herself.
The Kentucky-based Southern rappers return with a sophomore LP.
This party album from the Danish band Junior Senior has garnered attention throughout Europe with its mix of garage rock, pop and disco.
Working with a variety of producers, the acclaimed New York rapper returns with his second album. Mos Def, Bilal and members of the Roots are among the guests.
The third proper LP from the second incarnation of Underworld features the singles "Push Upstairs" and "Moaner" (the latter of which previously appeared on the "Batman & Robin" soundtrack).
The fourth full-length studio release for the Ohio indie rock band led by Dylan Baldi is its first with new lead guitarist, Chris Brown.
The third full-length release for the Chicago footwork artist features guest appearances from Crossfire and DJ Phil.

recordname: When You Walk a Long Distance You Are Tired
description: Originally begun as a solo project for Kristine Leschper, the debut full-length release for the Athens, Georgia quartet was produced by Drew Vandenberg.
The double album from the punk legends was produced by John Agnello.
The debut full-length release for the British rock trio was produced by Pulp's Steve Mackey.
Keith Wood and Leon Dufficy release their first album on the Ecstatic Peace label.
The 11th full-length release for the Los Angeles artist features a guest appearance from DaM-FunK.
Mitchell Froom produced this eighth album for the Canadian singer-songwriter.
The newly reconfigured Philadelphia band, known mainly for their carnivalesque, acquired-taste sound and well-received live shows, return with a second LP.
This is the debut full-length release for the Australian dance-pop band that includes Janet Planet, Sugar Bones, Reggie Goodchild, and Clarence McGuffie.
The latest release by the jazz singer was recorded in her house in Jackson, Mississippi.
Kurt Wagner & co. return for the band's sixth album, which is a more stripped-down affair than their previous effort, 'Nixon.'
The latest full-length release for Philadelphia artist Shamir was produced by Hollow Comet and mixed by Justin Tailor.
The debut release by the pop duo of Robin Hannibal and Mike Milosh was recorded in Copenhagen and Los Angeles.
The ninth full-length studio release for the Americana string band was produced by Ted Hutt and includes a song co-written by Bob Dylan.
This is the sixth full-length release for the Polish rock band Trupa Trupa.
The Soft Cell artist worked with producer Chris Braide on his first full-length solo release since 2010's Variete.
The fifth full-length studio release for the Welsh indie pop band was produced by John Goodmanson.

recordname: Splinter: Songs From a Broken Mind
description: The 20th studio release for the British electronic artist features guitarist Robin Finck and was produced with Ade Fenton.
The debut full-length release for the Los Angles indie pop trio of sisters was produced by Ariel Rechtshaid and James Ford.
The fourth full-length release for the Canadian punk rock band was produced by Lars Stalfors.
The debut release for the British instrumental trio of Gemma Barkerwood, Sophie Barkerwood, and Louise Croft features an appearance from A Little Orchestra.
The first full-length release in nearly six years for Los Angeles indie rock band Warpaint was produced with Sam Petts-Davies.
The latest full-length release for the Scottish rock band is its first with Euro Childs of Gorkys Zygotic Mynci and the first without co-founder Gerard Love who left in 2018.
The third full-length release for the project of Michael Lovett features guest appearances from Amber Strother of King and VIAA.
The latest release in RVNG Intl.'s FRKWYS series features the collaboration between Kaitlyn Aurelia Smith and Suzanne Ciani.
The eighth full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter was recorded in two weeks and was produced with Trina Shoemaker.
The ex-Pulp guitarist releases his sixth solo album, which was recorded in Sheffield, England.
The fifth full-length release for Nika Roza Danilova was written in her Wisconsin hometown where she retreated after dealing with depression and dark times experienced by her close friends.
The seventh album for the English trio is its first in more than five years.
The ABBA covers album from the pop singer/actress was produced by Mark Taylor.

The seventh full-length studio release for the British rapper features guest appearances from Chip, D Double E, Frisco, Ghetts, Alicaì Harley, Kano, P Money, Ocean Wisdom, Rob Jones TV, Smoke Boys, and Steel Banglez.

recordname: There Is No Love in Fluorescent Light
description: The eighth full-length release for the Canadian indie pop band was produced by Peter Katis.
The fourth studio and first major label release for the New Orleans rapper who popularized bounce music, a subgenre that mixes house and hip-hop music with chants, was produced by Thomas McElroy.
The Emeralds singer and guitarist releases his debut solo album on the Edition Mego label.

Since 2009's covers collection "Mockingbird," Allison Moorer felt it was time to do something entirely different for her next record. The country-folk singer-songwriter releases her first collection of original material in four years. It features guitarist Joe McMahan, a former member of Moorer's road band for Miss Fortune; and bassist Brad Jones, who contributed to Getting Somewhere.
The two-disc album contains more than two dozen guests, including Gerard Way of My Chemical Romance, Chris Carrabba of Dashboard Confessional, and Chad Gilbert of New Found Glory.
This is the second full-length release for producer Alejandro Ghersi, who is known for his work on Kanye Wests Yeezus and FKA twigs albums.
The latest release from Chicago DJ/producer Cornelius Ferguson includes not only footwork, but influences from soul, funk, jazz, and hip-hop.
The debut album for Dee Dee (aka Kristen Gundred) was recorded with the help of producer Richard Gottehrer.

recordname: C U L T U R E
description: The second full-length studio release for the Atlanta rap trio features guest appearances from 2 Chainz, DJ Khaled, Gucci Mane, and Travis Scott.

The latest full-length covers album from Cat Power features songs from such artists as Jackson Brown, Nick Cave, Lana Del Rey, Billie Holiday, Iggy Pop, Frank Ocean, The Replacements, and Kitty Wells.
The debut full-length release for the grime artist was self-produced.
The third full-length release for the Swedish electronic duo features a 26-piece orchestra.
The 17th release for the Australian improvised jazz trio is an over hour piece.
The debut full-length release on the Hyperdub label for the footwork producer features appearances from DJ Earl, DJ Phil, DJ Spinn, Addison Groove, Manny, and Taso.
The British folk singer-songwriter created the songs for her third release with a computer.
The 14th studio album from the UK masters of doom-and-gloom metal is their first album in 28 years featuring the band's original lineup.
The eighth full-length studio release for the British post-punk experimental band is "a satirical take on British culture" and its first studio album in seven years.
The sixth full-length release for the Cincinnati indie rock band was produced by Jerri Queen and John Hoffman.
This is the second release in 2009 for Owen Ashworth following last month's release of his compilation album, Advance Base Battery Life.
The fourth album for the British electropop rock band aims for a more pop feel.
The 12th full-length release for the British alternative band led by Stuart Staples was recorded in six days.
The debut rap collaboration from Evidence and Alchemist features guest appearances from such artists as Action Bronson, Fashawn, Domo Genesis, Roc Marciano, Oh No, and Styles P.

recordname: The Historical Conquests of Josh Ritter
description: It's the fifth album for the Idaho-born singer-songwriter.
This is the sixth album for the Vancouver, Canada indie rock outfit led by Dan Bejar (also of the New Pornographers).
The Australian rockers, who have attracted attention in their homeland and in Europe with their early EPs, make their full-length debut with this LP.
This CD collects the first three 10-inch EPs from the British electronica duo, whose Fred Deakin also designs the band's album covers.
The increasingly-popular indie-pop outfit led by James Mercer returns with a third album.
The debut release for the side project from Wilco's Jeff Tweedy and his son Spencer features contributions from Scott McCaughey of the Baseball Project, Jess Wolfe and Holly Laessig of Lucius.
The fourth full-length release for the Canadian punk band was produced by Bill Skibbe.
The daughter of Johnny Cash releases a country covers album. Elvis Costello, Bruce Springsteen, Jeff Tweedy, and Rufus Wainwright appear as guest singers.
The fifth album for the daughter of blues guitarist/singer Johnny Copeland was produced by Oliver Wood.
The latest album from the singer-songwriter includes Sean Haynes as a guest on one track.
The rapper's delayed follow-up to 2001's 'Malpractice' was produced by Timbaland, Eminem, Erick Sermon, Scott Storch, and Rockwilder. Method Man and Nate Dogg also guest.
The second full-length album for the New York rock band features Matias Aguayo, Gary Numan, Kazu Makino, and Yamantaka Eye as guest musicians.
The collaboration between rapper Open Mike Eagle and producer Paul White features guest appearances from Aesop Rock and Future Islands' Hemlock Ernst.

recordname: I Grow Tired But Dare Not Fall Asleep
description: The fifth full-length release for the British artist features guest appearances from Art School Girlfriend, Katie Dove Dixon, Skinny Girl Diet's Delilah Holiday, and SaraSara.
The third full-length studio release for the duo that includes the Mazzy Star singer and My Bloody Valentine's Colm Ó Cíosóig features a guest appearance from Kurt Vile.
The second full-length solo release for the electronic producer is his first in five years.
The sixth full-length release for the French artist was self-recorded and produced in Spain.
San Francisco Bay Area DJ/producer David P. Madson's latest album.
The latest solo album for the singer was produced by the late Jerry Finn.
The Canadian post-punk previously known as known as Viet Cong return with a new name and a new album produced by Graham Walsh.
This is the fifth full-length studio release from the indie brother duo of Peter and David Brewis.
Sarah Cracknell & co.'s latest is a concept album about the residents of a London high rise.
The third full-length album for Nika Roza Danilova was coproduced with Nudge (aka as Brian Foote).
The theme of maternal love is central to the 10th full-length release from the singer-songwriter.
Produced with Andy Park, the fifth full-length release is the first in nearly 15 years for the Seattle indie band led by David Bazan.
The second full-length release for the French indie electronic collective led Marlon Magnée and Sacha Got was recorded in Paris and Los Angeles.
The debut full-length collaboration from the Berlin-based producers Max Graef and Glenn Astro features influences from electronic, funk, hip-hop, and jazz.
The debut full-length release for the Atlanta trio of Franklin James Fisher, Ryan Mahan, and Lee Tesche was produced by Tom Morris.
The debut release for the collaboration between Aimee Mann and Ted Leo was produced by Paul Bryan.
This is the debut full-length release for the British pop quartet.
The New York punk rock band named after a 1960s crime novel by Jim Thompson releases its debut full-length album of songs about a post-apocalyptic future.

recordname: The Lost Notebooks of Hank Williams
description: Bob Dylan recruited Rodney Crowell, Sheryl Crow, Jakob Dylan, Vince Gill, Merle Haggard, Levon Helm, Alan Jackson, Norah Jones, Patty Loveless, Jack White, Holly Williams (Hank's granddaughter), and Lucinda Williams to sing some of Hank Williams' unfinished and unrecorded songs.
The album produced by Thomas Brenneck is the debut album for the 62-year-old singer Charles Bradley, who was discovered singing at the Tarheel Lounge.

recordname: Full Of Light And Full Of Fire
description: This is the topical seventh album for the indie rockers fronted by the recently married Shannon McArdle and Timothy Bracy.
The eclectic southern blues-rockers return with an album produced by Jim Dickinson (father of band members Cody and Luther). Lucinda Williams guests.

The Chicago-based post-rockers return with their sixth album, their once frenetic pace of releasing albums slowed over recent years due to numerous side projects (solo albums for vocalist Sam Prekop and guitarist Archer Prewitt, and work in Tortoise, among other things, for drummer John McEntire). Included here is the band's cover of David Bowie's "Sound and Vision."
The fifth full-length album for the British indie electronic band is its first on the Domino label.
The second full-length release for the New York-based singer-songwriter was recorded in Iceland with Alex Somers.
The currently San Francisco-based folk singer recorded her latest solo album with two of her with Espers bandmate Helena Espvall and Sharron Kraus.
The eighth album from the New York-based group.
This is the debut full-length for the Glasgow band fronted by James Graham.

The veteran Scottish band's first album for Sanctuary (after a long run on Matador Records) is also their first without singer/cellist Isobel Campbell. The 12 tracks here were produced by Trevor Horn.
The debut full-length release for British alternative singer-songwriter Hannah Rodgers features production from Dan Carey.
The second release for the Pat Metheny band that includes Chris Potter, Antonio Sanchez, and Ben Williams is its first with new member Giulio Carmassi.
The 12th studio release for Ben Harper features a collaboration with veteran blues artist Charlie Musselwhite.
The latest release for the rock band was produced with Roger Moutenot.
The sixth full-length for the Virginia grindcore band is its first in six years and features guest appearances by Full Of Hell's Dylan Walker, Agoraphobic Nosebleed's Richard Johnson and Kat Katz.
The debut full-length release for the Australian singer-songwriter was produced with Tarquin Manek.
The debut full-length release for the New York pop-punk duo of Alex Luciano and Noah Bowman was produced by Christopher Daly.
With upbeat, experimental pop songs and psychedelic synthesizer sounds, this duo defines their music under the genre of chillwave.
The first studio full-length release from the New Zealand indie pop band led by Martin Phillipps in nearly 20 years.
This is the debut full-length release for the New York-born rapper/producer.
The Martha's Vineyard native recorded this debut LP of intelligent, folky rock when he was 19.
The third full-length studio release for the Australian alternative singer-songwriter was produced with Stella Mozgawa.
The debut full-length release for the London-based Welsh electronic producer features a guest appearance from Jenny Hval.

recordname: I Used to Spend So Much Time Alone
description: The third full-length release for the Seattle indie rock band led by Julia Shapiro was recorded in Portland, Oregon with producer Matthew Simms.
The Canadian indie rock band releases its sophomore album.
This is the first release in four years for the Mekons/Waco Brothers member and his band that includes Joe Camarillo, Jean Cook, Alan Doughty, Jim Elkington, and Tawny Newsome.

The New Orleans rapper returns with his second album in 2010 which features guest appearances by Snoop Dogg, Mos Def, Devin the Dude, Jay Electronica, Mikey Rocks, Big K.R.I.T., Smoke DZA, Trademark Da Skydiver, and Young Roddy.
The first release in five years for the Baltimore-based experimental electronic duo includes guest appearances from Dan Deacon, Angel Deradoorian, Dominique Leone, and Wye Oak's Jenn Wasner.
The debut full-length release for the British alternative rock band led by Felix Bushe was produced with James Bragg.
The debut full-length solo release for the Ash frontman is a tribute to his late father, who suffered from Alzheimers disease.
The third full-length studio release for the Southern California blues-rock band was produced by Dave Cobb.
Toronto-based singer-songwriter Afie Jurvanen releases his second album of guitar-centric music.
The debut album of the Connecticut rock group was originally released overseas in 2006.
Structured as a rock opera complete with 9-minute-plus songs and a somewhat complicated storyline, 'American Idiot' is the Berkeley punk band's first album in over four years.
The third full-length solo release for the Pearl Jam frontman Eddie Vedder features a guest appearance from Elton John and was produced by Andrew Watt.
The first new release in five years for the British alternative dance trio was co-produced by Shawn Lee.

The 14th full-length studio release for the San Francisco indie rock band features guest appearances from Awkwafina, Devin Hoff, Juana Molina, Chad Popple, Matana Roberts, Xenia Rubinos, Laetitia Sadler, The Staple Singers, and Jenn Wasner.

Produced by John Agnello, the third full-length release for the indie rock band led by Elizabeth Powell was written while taking care of her father and features a guest appearance from Sharon Van Etten.
The Anti-Pop Consortium returns to release their first album together in six years.
The second full-length release for the Australian singer-songwriter was co-produced with Chris Messina and Zach Hanson.
The seventh full-length studio release for the country pop artist features a guest appearances from the Dixie Chicks and Brendon Urie of Panic! at the Disco.
The fourth full-length release for the London-based artist was produced by Leo Abrahams.
The first solo release in five years for the electronic producer features guest appearances from Beans, Bibio, Thom Yorke, Thom Yorke.
The indie rock English outfit made up of brothers David and Peter Brewis (original drummer in the Futureheads) has reunited with founder/director Andrew Moore on its latest, Field Music (Measure).
The latest release for this folk singer was produced with Mike Napolitano and was recorded in Louisiana.

Stephin Merritt handles all of the vocal duties on Magnetic Fields' latest release (so named because each song title begins with the letter I), though the musicians who helped flesh out '69 Love Songs' return, including Claudia Gonson (also of Future Bible Heroes and the band's manager), John Woo and Sam Davol.

The former Style Council and Jam frontman returns with a solo album, and finds Weller producing and playing most of the instruments himself, with the help of a few celebrity guests such as Noel Gallagher, Kelly Jones and Aziz Ibrahim.

The distinctive Liverpool indie/garage band is back with a follow-up to their well-received 2000 debut 'Internal Wrangler' (which was just released last fall in the U.S.). The positive press generated by these two releases led to the band signing a major-label deal with Universal, which re-released 'Walking With Thee' on August 6, 2002.
This is Sam Phillips' first new album in five years, following 1996's poorly-received 'Omnipop.' Phillips' husband, T-Bone Burnett, produces.

The first full-length solo album from Red House Painters frontman Mark Kozelek (following his 2000 EP, 'Rock N Roll Singer') consists entirely, believe it or not, of Bon Scott-era AC/DC covers. You'd never guess it by listening to the album, however, as Kozelek transforms them into something entirely new.
The fourth studio release for the Cleveland indie rock band led by Dylan Baldi was produced by John Congleton.
The debut full-length release for the 16-year-old New Zealand pop singer-songwriter was produced by Joel Little.
The indie folk duo from San Francisco return with a fourth album of psychedelic, atmospheric, genre-bending rock.
The San Francisco-based psych-rock solo artist returns with a third full-length.
Recorded during a live performance by the Jason Molina-led four-piece in Brussels in 2003, 'Trials' includes seven songs from the Songs:Ohia catalog as well as three new Magnolia Electric Co. tracks.
The debut full-length solo release for Speedy Ortiz's Sadie Dupuis was self-produced and features a guest appearance from Sammus.
The second full-length release for the British indie rock was produced by Dreamtrak.
The eighth studio release for the Brooklyn folk rock band led by Jeremy Earl includes the use of a saloon piano, singing saw, and more percussion.
This is the debut full-length release for the British trio led by Nik Colk Void.
The second full-length release for former P.S. Eliot singer Katie Crutchfield includes backing from Swearin' members Keith Spencer, Kyle Gilbride, and her twin sister, Allison Crutchfield.
The seventh studio release for the southern blues-rock/folk band was self produced.

recordname: Some Say I So I Say Light
description: Co-produced with Richard Formby, the second release for the British electronic artist features guest appearance from Gwilym Gold, Charles Hayward, Dave Okumu, Lucy Rose, and Woodpecker Wooliams.
The debut album for the Florida-based rock band known as the band Tom Petty was in before the Heartbreakers.
The latest full-length release for singer-songwriter Omar Apollo features guest appearances from Daniel Caesar and Kali Uchis.
The fifth Full-length studio release for the British grime artist features guest appearances from B Live, Boy Better Know, Lancey Foux, J Hus, Key, Lay-Z, Cheb Rabi, Nafe Smallz, and WizKid.
This is the second full-length release for Ty Segall's side project with Charlie Moothart and Chad Ubovich.
The fourth full-length studio release fro the punk band led by Patrick Stickles is a rock opera inspired by his own experience with manic depression.

recordname: Spiritual Songs For Lovers To Sing
description: The debut full-length release for the duo of WU LYF's Ellery Roberts and Ebony Hoorn was produced by The Haxan Cloak.
The latest full-length release for Modern Nature was inspired in part by Shakespeare's The Tempest.
The indie rock/slowcore band returns with its first new release in nine years which was written over that course of time between albums.
The British folk rock guitarist's latest solo release was produced by Buddy Miller and includes guest appearances by Alison Krauss and Siobhan Maher Kennedy.
The fourth full-length release for the Brooklyn-based experimental artist features guest appearances from Jónsi, Mary Lattimore and Nosaj Thing.

recordname: I'll Be Your Mirror: A Tribute to the Velvet Underground & Nico
description: Courtney Barnett, Matt Berninger of The National, Andrew Bird, Doveman, Fontaines D.C., Bobby Gillespie, Iggy Pop, King Princess, Lucius, Thurston Moore, Angel Olsen, St. Vincent, Michael Stipe, Matt Sweeney, Sharon Van Etten, and Kurt Vile & the Violators cover songs from The Velvet Underground's 1967 debut album with German singer Nico.
The 14th full-length solo release for the Canadian singer-songwriter was recorded with his touring band and was produced by Ron and Don Kerr.
Lambchop's Kurt Wagner and Cortney Tidwell teamed up as KORT and released this album of songs originally recorded by the Chart Label.
The Canadian electronica artist releases his latest album.
The fifth full-length release for the singer-songwriter features contributions from Russian Circles guitarist Mike Sullivan and was produced by John Congleton.
The third album for the rock trio was produced by Brandon Curtis.

recordname: In The Court Of The Wrestling Let's
description: The debut full-length album for the British rock trio was named after the King Crimson album, In the Court of The Crimson King.
The Brothers Followill reunite with producers Ethan Johns and Angelo Petraglia for their first album in over two years.
The sixth full-length studio release for the French metal band was recorded at their own studio in New York.
The eighth release for Daniel Lopatin as Oneohtrix Point Never features a backstory about an alien named Ezra and a band called Kaoss Edge.
The Australian singer-songwriter releases her fifth solo album.
The fourth full-length studio release for the British rock band was produced by Dave MacLean and features a guest appearance from Charlotte Gainsbourg.
The second full-length solo release for the Paramore singer was recorded at her Nashville home during the COVID-19 lockdown.
The alt-country rocker releases his latest album on Merge Records.
The debut full-length release for the Louisiana-born singer-songwriter was self-recorded and mixed by Brandon Summers and Benjamin Weikel of The Helio Sequence.
The second album for the Chicago-based band is the final album with original drummer Graeme Gibson who left the quartet to be closer to his family.
The Oscar nominated film's soundtrack features three songs with M.I.A. and A.R. Rahman's score.
The rock band's 14th album is promised to be more rocking than its last release, Around the Sun.
The second full-length release for the New Zealand indie pop quartet was produced by the band's guitarist Jonathan Pearce and lead singer Elizabeth Stokes.
This is the third full-length release for the Scottish indie-pop quartet.
The third solo release for the indie singer-songwriter was co-produced with Thom Monahan.
The debut full-length release for the indie pop singer-songwriter was produced by Ariel Rechtshaid and Justin Raisen.
The second solo full-length release for the British artist is his first on the Rough Trade label.

The first non-soundtrack release from the Icelandic composer features appearances from the Air Lyndhurst String Orchestra, The Dirac Quartet, Paul Hilliers Theatre of Voices, Clarice Jensen, and Anthony Weeden.
The Los Angeles-based duo's sophomore album was recorded in Los Angeles and London, England.

The third full-length release for the rapper features a track from the 2018 animated film Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse as well as guest appearances from DaBaby, Future, Halsey, Meek Mill, Ozzy Osbourne, Travis Scott, SZA, and Young Thug.

recordname: A Bad Wind Blows in My Heart
description: The second solo release for the ex-Coral singer was recorded at his mother's house and produced by James Ford.
The second album for the Los Angeles-born rapper features guest appearances by such artists as Aesop Rock, Aloe Blacc, Roc Marciano, Prodigy, Raekwon, and Slug.
The Florida-based quintet shows the influence of 1990s alternative and indie rock music on its debut full-length album.
Co-produced by Jeremy Greenspan, the debut full-length release for Canadian music teacher-turned R&B singer includes influences from funk, jazz, and synth pop.
The debut full-length collaboration between Jimbo Mathus and Andrew Bird as a duo was recorded live to tape and was produced by Mike Viola.
This is the debut full-length release for the Andy Shauf band that includes Dallas Bryson, Darryl and Avery Kissick.
The debut full-length solo release for The Zincs frontman features influences from avant-rock, British folk, and jazz.
The second full-length release for the New Orleans blues/garage rock singer-songwriter was produced by Sam Cohen and features a guest appearance from Mavis Staples.
The second full-length release for the Louisville rock band led by Tony Esposito was produced by Kevin Ratterman.
New York noise artist Margaret Chardiet explored trance states for her third full-length release as Pharmakon.

recordname: Heaven Adores You [Original Motion Picture Soundtrack]
description: The soundtrack to the 2014 Elliott Smith documentary features outtakes, demos, alternative takes, and unreleased songs.
The third full-length release for the Scottish singer-songwriter was produced with Dani Castelar.
This is the latest album from New York noise artist Dominick Fernow.
Horrors singer Faris Badwan pairs up with soprano singer Rachel Zeffira on an album of pop songs that are reminiscent of 1960s girl groups.
This is the second album for New Zealand's James Milne as Lawrence Arabia, who previously was a touring musician with Okkervil River.
The New Jersey indie rock band that includes ex-Titus Andronicus member Martin Courtney releases its debut album.
The sophomore album for the folk band from Portland, Oregon.

recordname: The Greater Wrong Of The Right
description: A reunited Nivek Ogre and cEvin Key return with their first Skinny Puppy album in eight years, with Ken Marshall (Tool) producing. (Apparently, their brand of hardcore political industrial noise is only needed during Republican administrations.)
'Permission To Land' is the debut LP for the rock four-piece from Norfolk, England (and we're talking the big, loud, stadium-rock end of the rock continuum, not the indie-rock end).

Byrne's latest release originated as the soundtrack to the film 'Young Adam' (itself based on the novel by Scottish beat writer Alexander Trocci). Since the film is set in Scotland, and since the former Talking Head himself was born there, he decided to enlist members of Glasgow-based groups such as Mogwai, Belle & Sebastian and The Reindeer Section to assist with this music (only a small portion of which actually is heard in the film).
The eleventh album from Bill Callahan and (Smog) features new vocalist Sarabeth Tucek.
This is the sophomore effort for the duo of DJs from a popular London club known as The End. It is not a mix album, however; instead, the 14 trance-house tracks are original compositions.
The singer's third solo album was produced by T-Bone Burnett.

The full title of this sophomore effort from the 22-year-old singer-songwriter runs a whopping 90 words: When the Pawn Hits the Conflicts He Thinks Like a King What He Knows Throws the Blows When He Goes to the Fight and He'll Win the Whole Thing 'Fore He Enters the Ring There's No Body to Batter When Your Mind Is Your Might So When You Go Solo, You Hold Your Own Hand and Remember That Depth Is the Greatest of Heights and if You Know Where You Stand, Then You Know Where to Land and if You Fall It Won't Matter, 'Cuz You'll Know That You're Right.
The debut on ATO Records leans more toward rock than the last studio release for the Athens, Georgia, band.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Georgia sludge metal band was influenced by a rough period of time for both Laura Pleasants and Phillip Cope.
The fourth full-length solo release for the former frontman of The Czars was produced with Midlake's Paul Alexander and Wrangler's Benge.
The second instrumental rock release from the trio of Sir Richard Bishop, Ben Chasny, and Chris Corsano was influenced by Easter European and Middle Eastern music.

This is the debut album for the London-based electronica duo, who blend their minimalist, experimental tendencies with more organic elements, including vocals (think of a more playful version of Mum).
The second full-length release for the brother and sister duo of Barbara and Ethan Gruska was produced with Shawn Everett.
The latest album for the country singer was produced by Brian Ahern with Dolly Parton and Vince Gill as guest vocalists.
The second full-length release for William Doyle as East India Youth was recorded at home.
The 14th full-length studio release for the Ambient techno duo was recorded while on tour.
The debut full-length release for the British experimental pop teen duo of Rosa Walton and Jenny Hollingworth was recorded by Will Twynham in a former nuclear bunker-turned-studio.
The latest album for the singer-songwriter was produced by Steve Albini and is her first with Drag City.
Sasu Ripatti's fourth album as Luomo features Johanna Iivanainen, Sascha Ring (aka Apparat), Robert Owens, Sue-C, Panorama Bar's Cassy, and Scissor Sisters' Jake Shears.
The third album for the Swedish singer was produced with Rasmus Hagg.
The posthumous release for the soul singer features songs recorded during sessions from his previous three releases.
The debut full-length release for the trio that includes Anaïs Mitchell, Josh Kaufman and Eric D. Johnson includes new interpretations of traditional folk songs, many hundreds of years old.
The second full-length release for the Montreal duo Raphaelle Standell-Preston and Alexander Cowan was inspired by Standell-Preston's unrequited relationship with someone online.
The third full-length release for the Scottish instrumental band led by Graeme Ronald was recorded by Tony Doogan.
This is the debut full-length release for the Manchester rock quartet of Scott Beaman, Billy Byron, Charlie Cocksedge, and Jamie Lee.

recordname: Blue Moon: The New York Session
description: Jazz pianist Ahmad Jamal pays tribute to some of his favorite Broadway, Hollywood, and Great American Songbook classic songs.
The eighth full-length studio release for the Canadian sister duo was produced by Greg Kurstin.
The seventh full-length studio release from the singer-songwriter was written after his divorce from his wife, singer Dawn Landes.

The second full-length release for sisters Lisa-Kaindé and Naomi Diaz was produced by Richard Russell and features guest appearances from Chilly Gonzales, Meshell Ndegeocello, Mala Rodriguez, and Kamasi Washington.
The one 33-minute track release from the Australian artist was recorded and performed by himself in one day.

recordname: All We Could Do Was Sing
description: The indie band based in Oakland, California wrote songs for its sophomore album while up in Alaska for the summer.
The latest full-length release for the singer-songwriter is a covers album and features a guest appearance from Beth Orton.
The debut album for the Canadian indie artist, who was nominated for the Polaris Music Prize in 2007.
Audioslave's Tom Morello is among the musicians providing the framework for the politically-charged rap duo's first release in five years.
The seventh full-length release for the Georgia sludge metal band features influences from New Wave, Americana, Eighties goth, and death rock music.
This is the solo debut for Irishman Conor J. O'Brien, a member of the rock band The Immediate who split up in 2007.
This is the Ohio band's fourth album of jazzy prog-rock.
1980's influences exist throughout the latest album for the Texas-born electronic artist.
The second studio album for the hip-hop artist features guest appearances from Andre 3000, Birdman, Kendrick Lamar, Lil Wayne, Nicki Manah, Rick Ross, Rihanna, and The Weeknd.
Ben Chasny returns with a follow-up to 'School Of The Flower.'
The debut full-length studio release for the the Israeli dancehall MC was produced by The Bug.
The fifth solo release for the Sonic Youth guitarist was produced by Paul Epworth with contributions from My Bloody Valentine's Debbie Googe and Sonic Youth's Steve Shelley.
The sixth full-length release for the Malian singer-songwriter was produced by John Parish and features guest appearances from Devendra Banhart, John Paul Jones, and Toni Morrison.
Jazz, hip hop, electronic, rock, and funk are just some of the music styles influences on the debut solo 34-track release from the jazz drummer and hip hop producer.
This is the debut release for the South Carolina husband and wife duo of Michael Trent and Cary Ann Hearst.
The duo of Alessio Natalizai of Banjo or Freakout and Sam Willis of Allez-Allez releases its sophomore album.
The seventh studio album from the alternative rock band has Dave Grohl bringing in producer Butch Vig (of Nirvana's Nevermind fame) for its latest release.
The Austin, Texas band releases its ninth album.
The Brooklyn Afro-beat ensemble releases it first album in four years on new label Daptone Records.
Christian Fennesz is the first collaborator of a planned four part series of albums from experimental trio King Midas Sound.
The fifth full-length release for the New York rapper is a concept album about a computer hacker in Burundi features guest appearances from Emily Kokal and Haleek Maul.
The latest full-length release for the R&B singer features songs sung by other female artists and was produced by Steve Jordan.
The first release from the Chicago indie rock band's original line-up since 1997's Eight Arms To Hold You was produced by Brad Wood.
The second release for the Berlin-based Scottish producer moves further away from the traditional electronic sounds of his 2010 debut.
The latest album for the country singer produced by T Bone Burnett features popular bluegrass, country, and folk songs.

The first full-length release on Verve Records for Philadelphia rock artist Kurt Vile was self-produced with contributions from Chastity Belt, Cate Le Bon, Sarah Jones, Stella Mozgawa, Rob Schnapf, James Stewart, and The Violators.

The latest full-length release for Chicago-based jazz drummer Makaya McCraven features remixes of Blue Note jazz songs with contributions from Matt Gold, Marquis Hill, DeSean Jones, Jeff Parker, Junius Paul, Joel Ross, and Greg Ward.

recordname: A Star Is Born [Original Motion Picture Soundtrack]
description: The soundtrack to the 2018 remake of the 1937 film features tracks written by Lady Gaga and Bradley Cooper as well as Jason Isbell, Hillary Lindsey, Lukas Nelson, Mark Ronson, Anthony Rossomando, Justin Tranter, and Diane Warren.
The third full-length studio release for the London electronic music producer features guest appearances by Andrea Galaxy, Jammz, Jessy Lanza, and Sweyn J.
The second full-length release for the Chris Porterfield-led folk band was produced with Robbie Lackritz.
The Montreal quartet recorded its sophomore album at Arcade Fire's church studio.
The first solo album for the electronic artist in more than 10 years.
The electronic music duo return with a new album, their fourth release on Domino Records.
The latest full-length release for British electronic artist Darren Cunningham as Actress features guest appearances from Aura T-09, Vanessa Benelli, Sampha, Christel Well, and Zsela.
The collaboration between 21 Savage, Offset and Metro Boomin features guest appearances from Quavo and Travis Scott.
The fourth full-length release for the Canadian electronic band was recorded in a studio over three days.
Produced by Ross Orton, the second full-length release for the British rock band formed by the Loveless brothers includes a new bassist, Ron Graham.
The Western Sahara band that comprises Salmou Baamar's family releases its latest album of North African, Mauritanian, and Gnawa music.
The band's sixth album is their first for Polyvinyl and sees them branching out, into "1970s Afro beat and '80s new wave" as they say.

This is not my beautiful opera. The Talking Heads most verbose member returns with one of his more eclectic solo albums to date (and that's saying something), featuring covers of Lambchop, Bizet and Verdi (we're talking arias, people) scattered amongst originals that range from African rhythms to doo-wop. The Tosca Strings and Rufus Wainwright guest.

recordname: Some Of My Best Friends Are DJs
description: Turntablist Eric San (aka Kid Koala) finally emerges with a follow-up to his acclaimed 2000 debut 'Carpal Tunnel Syndrome' after spending a few years touring, writing a comic book, and serving in the band Gorillaz.
Frequently compared to the Beta Band, this equally eclectic Isle of Wight-based duo of Paul Butler and Aaron Fletcher literally recorded this debut album in their shed.
The groundbreaking English four-piece art-punk band has reunited (25 years after their debut) to record this 6-track EP, representing their first new studio output together since 1990's 'Manscape.'
The major label debut release for the Los Angles rapper features guest appearances from 2 Chainz, BJ the Chicago Kid, Kurupt, Jay Rock, Raekwon, Suga Free, and Tyler The Creator.
The eleventh album for the San Francisco noise-rock band is said to be influenced by Cuban party-noise music.

The singer-songwriter's first solo album in six years also marks his first collaboration with legendary producer and artist Brian Eno. (Finally, a worthy successor to Garfunkel!) Bill Frisell and Herbie Hancock guest.

Think Nancy Sinatra-Lee Hazlewood, and you won't be too far off the concept of this album-length pairing of former Belle & Sebastian vocalist Campbell and former Screaming Trees leader (and Queens Of The Stone Age collaborator) Lanegan.
Natasha Khan worked with such artists as Beck, Dan Carey, Rob Ellis, David Kosten, TV on the Radio's David Sitek, and Portishead's Adrian Utley for her third studio release.
After 40+ years in the business, Neil Diamond finally receives his first No. 1 record with this album produced by Rick Rubin.

recordname: In the Morse Code of Brake Lights
description: The eighth full-length studio release for the Canadian indie rock group was produced by its frontman, A.C. Newman.
This is the third full-length studio release for the New York City-based producer Drew Lustman.
The first release in over 20 years for the Harlem trio of Abiodun Oyewole, Umar Bin Hassan, and Baba Donn Babatunde was produced by Ben Lamdin and Prince Fatty.
The 17th full-length release for the Canadian artist's project features a new version of "Truth" (from the 1998 album Infinity) as well as a cover of Ween's "Transdermal Celebration."
This is the debut full-length release from Danish singer-songwriter Majke Voss Romm.
This is the debut release for the former Low Anthem member Jocie Adams.
The latest release from the synth-pop pioneer with the Maths includes contributions from The Soft Moon, Xeno & Oaklander, and Matthew Dear.
The second solo album for the New Pornographer singer/keyboardist was produced by Colin Stewart.
The eighth full-length studio release for the indie rock band features contributions from Marissa Nadler, Shearwater's Jonathan Meiburg, and yMusic.
The latest release from Grizzly Bear's Daniel Rossen and Fred Nicolaus was dedicated to Rossen's father who had passed away recently.
The fourth full-length release for the North Carolina folk singer-songwriter was self-produced.
This is the eighth album for the experimental pop band led by Jamie Stewart.
This is the final album with Jon Mueller and Thomas Wincek, who both left the the Milwaukee instrumental six-piece in 2010.
The British group's fourth album was produced by the duo and Flood.
This is the debut full-length release for the Los Angeles-based punk/hip-hop duo of of Yeti Bones and The OGM.
Produced by Adrian Younge, the concept album from the Wu-Tang rapper Ghostface Killah is about a drug lord in 1960s Italy.
The ninth studio release for the country singer features co-production with Greg Droman, Jay Joyce, and Mark Wright.
The third album for the electronic duo features Mark Lanegan as the main singer, with Bonnie "Prince" Billy, Jason Pierce, Mike Patton, Richard Hawley, and Gibby Haynes as guest vocalists.
The Sonic Youth guitarist's fourth album, produced by Beck, features guest appearances by Bram Inscore, Mary Lattimore, Samara Lubelski, and Joey Waronker.
The latest release for the Australian experimental metal duo of Takiaya Reed and Sylvie Nehill was produced by Unknown Mortal Orchestra's Ruban Nielson.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Brooklyn indie rock band was produced with Rodaidh McDonald.

recordname: The Things We Do To Find People Who Feel Like Us
description: The debut full-length release for the Pennsylvania punk band led by James Alex includes JP Flexner of Nona and Ex-Friends, Ed McNulty of Nona and Crybaby, and Ruben Gallego.
The latest release for the music project of Copenhagen's Loke Rahbek features vocals from Alto Aria, Frederikke Hoffmeier, Soho Rezanejad, Jonnine Standish of HTRK, and Yves Tumor.
The ninth full-length release for the musical project of Lisa Gerrard and Brendan Perry was inspired by European festivals that began as celebrations for the Greek god Dionysus.
The third full-length release for the duo of George Xylouris and Jim White was produced by Fugazi's Guy Picciotto.
This is the fourth full-length solo release for the Texas-born producer/pop artist.
Coproduced with Josh Sklair and her sons, Danto and Sametto, The Dreamer is said to be Etta James' final album as she retires to take care of her health.
T-Bone Burnett returned to produce the singer-songwriter's latest album which was recorded while Mellencamp was touring the Southern states.
The sixth album for the rock band was recorded and released as a substitution (with Sergio Vega on bass) to Eros which was put on hold when bassist Chi Cheng was involved in a serious car accident.
The latest full-length release for the indie folk band led by John Darnielle features a guest appearance from Charles Hodges and was produced by Matt Ross-Spang.
The third full-length release for the Spanish indie rock band was produced by Jenn Decilveo.
The third full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from Black Thought, E-40, Tory Lanez, Gucci Mane, Manman Savage, and Dana Williams.
The fourth release for the New York singer-guitarist features new drummer Kid Millions of Oneida (replacing Zach Hill of Death Grips).
This is the second full-length release for German electronic band Tangerine Dream after the death of Edgar Froese in 2015.

Andrew Broder's third Fog album reprises the song "Hummer" from a recent EP of the same name, and adds 12 new tracks. It's both more vocal-oriented and (at times) more electronic than earlier efforts.

recordname: All My Friends Are Funeral Singers
description: The Chicago rock band's latest album is also the soundtrack to the film of the same name.
The singer's fourth album features the same producer (Marius deVries) and backup musicians as his previous outing, 'Want One.'
The sixth album for the duo from Arizona features Iron & Wine, Douglas McCombs, Amparo Sanchez, and Pieta Brown as guest musicians.
The trio from Australia releases its first album of instrumental rock since 2005's Cinder.
The Seattle band's follow-up to their debut album.
The second full-length release for the British rapper features guest appearances from A$AP Rocky, James Blake, Deb Never, Denzel Curry, Dominic Fike, Mount Kimbie, and Skepta.
The latest full-length release for the alt-country band led by Kurt Wagner is covers album with each member selecting one song for the for the group to cover.
The latest full-length release for the Finnish electronic producer Sasu Ripatti is his first credited under his Vladislav Delay moniker in six years.

The fourth full-length release for the London-based singer-songwriter was self-produced and features contributions from Sam Amidon, Chris Cohen, Jamie Whitby Coles, Neil Smith, Kate Stables, and Joel Wästberg.
This is the latest full-length release for the Scottish folk rock group led by Alex Neilson.
The second full-length solo release for the Crooked Still member was inspired by memories of her Irish grandfather and was produced by Tucker Martine.
Produced by Adrian Younge, the fifth full-length studio release for the R&B/soul artist features guest appearances from Big K.R.I.T., Kimbra, and Kendrick Lamar.
The third release for the Swedish singer was inspired by her trip to Hawaii and was co-produced by The Tough Alliances Henning Fürst.
This is the third album for the Alexisonfire lead singer's other music project, City and Colour.
Jason Swinscoe's first Cinematic Orchestra disc in five years is indeed a soundtrack... to an imaginary film.
This is the third album of 60s-influenced tunes from the Brooklyn-based indie-pop band.
The fourth album for the the Brooklyn, New York, experimental rock band.
The second full-length solo release for the My Morning Jacket frontman was produced by Blake Mills.
The second full-length release for the Texas trio of Laura Lee, Mark Speer, and Donald DJ Johnson adds influences by Mediterranean and Middle Eastern music.
The Tim Kasher-led band has lost its cellist (Gretta Cohn) but added a horn section for its latest release, produced, as always, by Mike Mogis.
The sophomore album for the Chicago-area avant-garde rock band.
The latest album for the Grammy-nominated singer-songwriter was produced with Chris Bruce.
The latest full-length release for the Los Angeles indie pop artist was produced by Gordon Raphael.
The second full-length release in 2020 for the British electronic producer features contributions from Hannah Diamond and Caroline Polachek.
The five-track release from the Detroit noise rock trio is its first on its own label.
The third release for the Chicago band led by Todd Rittman is its first on the Drag City label.
The debut album for the indie supergroup led by Ryan Olson features musicians from such Minneapolis-area bands as Solid Gold, Megafaun, Rhymesayers, and Bon Iver.
The third full-length release for the indie rock band was produced by Tom Schick and recorded at Wilco's studio in Chicago.
This is thee fifth full-length release for Swedish producer Axel Willner.
The third full-length release for the Washington, D.C.-based producer Martijn Deykers features collaborations with Kieran Hebden and Inga Copeland.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn-based rock band led by Andrew Savage follows the title track's 7-inch single release on Record Store Day.
This is the second album to be released in the United States for the Swedish singer.

recordname: Trust Not Those In Whom Without Some Touch Of Madness
description: A 20-year veteran of the indie music scene, the former Come frontwoman returns with her second solo LP.

Using a 2003 European tour as inspiration, the Athens, Georga indie-rockers recorded this sixth album as a series of narratives about both Americans traveling abroad and about recent immigrants to the United States.
The official solo debut for the Phish head features 12 new Anastasio-penned tracks, with the guitarist backed by an eight-piece band.
The sixth full-length solo release for the Irish folk singer-songwriter was made in his hometwon of Bray.
The 13th full-length release for the British band led by Mike Scott was co-produced by Paul Brown and Simon Dine.
The fifth full-length release for British indie artist was co-produced with Ash Workman and features guest appearances from Jason Williamson of Sleaford Mods and Rose Elinor Dougall.
The second full-length release for the British indie rock band was co-produced by Alan Moulder.
The debut release for the San Francisco singer-songwriter is also the first album on Tim Presley's Birth Records.
The Dublin-based singer fuses blues and rockabilly on her rocking new album.
The seventh album for the experimental band is promised to include many kinds of synthesizers.
The debut full-length release for the Boston singer-songwriter Ella Williams was recorded in New York City with producer Gabe Wax.
Produced with Ron Aniello, Springsteens 17th studio album was inspired by the impact of the financial crisis and is the last album with Clarence Clemons, who passed away in June 2011.
The debut full-length release for the Dirty Projectors' bassist Angel Deradoorian was co-produced with Kenny Gilmore.
The second full-length release for the Canadian indie pop artist features guest appearances from Mitski and Troye Sivan.
The first album in 12 years for the jazz pianist is his first on the ANTI label and was produced by Joe Henry.
This is the veteran producer's first solo artist album in 14 years.
The second full-length release for the British electo-pop artist features guest appearances by Maurice and Shygirl.
The first full-length studio release in five years for the Ben Bridwell-led band Band Of Horses.
The debut full-length release for the Dutch indie rock band was recorded by Dave McCracken.
The debut full-length release for the New York hip-hop group that includes Wiki, Hak, and producer Sporting Life, features guest appearances from King Krule, Solomon Faye, and Wavy Spice.
The Portland, Ore. singer-songwriter's fourth album includes contributions from members of Rilo Kiley, My Morning Jacket, The Decemberists and Giant Sand.
The second full-length release for Australian dance quartet Confidence Man was self-produced and mixed by Ewan Pearson.
The latest solo album for the Icelandic composer is the second of a planned triology about technology and American brand names.
The second EP for the Chicago-based rap duo was produced by Evan Ingersoll.
The debut full-length release for the Texas soul singer was recorded live to tape with White Denim's Josh Block and Austin Jenkins.
The fourth full-length release for the Austin rock band was produced by Andrew Cashen.
The second full-length release for the duo of Emily Cross and her husband Dan Duszynski was recorded in their ranch in Texas.
The third release in 2011 for the Japanese band was produced by Shinobu Narita.

recordname: Nine and a Half Psychedelic Meditations on British Wrestling of the 1970's and Early '80s
description: Haines has said that his motivation for writing this 30-minute, 10-song concept album about wrestling was his father's recent illness and how it caused him to reflect on childhood memories of watching the sport.
The all-female Japanese experimental rock outfit led by The Boredoms' Yoshimi P-We returns with a fifth album.
The seventh full-length solo release for the Philadelphia-based singer-songwriter was recorded over two years in a variety of location in the US while he was on tour or vacationing.
The third full-length release for the Swedish metal band was produced by Klas Åhlund.
The third studio album for indie band was written while on tour and explores the emotions that came from the relationship band members Nona Marie Invie and Marshall LaCount had with each other.
The latest album for the Grammy Award-winning country singer was produced by Frank Rogers.
Produced by John Agnello, the seventh full-length release for the Austin indie rock band was inspired by frontman Will Sheff's childhood in his New Hampshire hometown.
The fifth full-length release for the Pittsburgh rapper features guest appearances from Dam-Funk, Dicaprio, Dev Hynes, Snoop Dogg, Syd, and Thundercat.
The third full-length release from the Baltimore indie rock band was co-produced by Chris Coady and lead singer Jana Hunter.
The latest release of acoustic blues from the veteran singer-songwriter was produced by Doug Lancio.
Cat Power's Chan Marshall returns with her first album of original material since 2006's The Greatest. The release mixed by Philippe Zdar of Cassius also features Iggy Pop on "Nothin' But Time."
Seven years later, Q-Tip finally sees his second album officially released. Arista Records shelved the album in 2002, which features a more jazzy feel than his debut, "Amplified."
Lily Allen and the Arctic Monkeys guest on the UK artist's third album.
The first full-length release in seven years for the electronic pop quartet features a guest appearance by Iggor Cavalera on drums.
The four-track EP features songs from the band's "Strawberry Jam" studio sessions.
The debut pop solo release for Fucked Up guitarist Ben Cook features a guest appearance from Jef Barbara.
The second full-length release for the indie folk trio led by Hollie Fullbrook was recorded with Tom Healy.
This is the fifth full-length release for the experimental jazz band led by Sebastian Rochford.
The Brooklyn-based band formed by former students at the New England Conservatory releases its second full-length studio album.

The fourth full-length studio release for the British electronic/nu-jazz project led by Jason Swinscoe and Dom Smith features guest vocals from Grey Reverend, Roots Manuva, Moses Sumney, Tawiah, and Heidi Vogel.

The surprise release for the music project of Phoebe Bridgers and Conor Oberst features contributions from Carla Azar, Anna Butterss, Christian Lee Hutson, Yeah Yeah Yeahs' Nick Zinner as well as Dawes Wylie Gelber and Griffin Goldsmith.

recordname: The Things We Think We're Missing
description: The second full-length release for the Pennsylvania alternative rock band was produced by Will Yip.
The fourth album for the Grammy-winning country singer was produced by Joe Henry.
Yes, this is indeed the fifth full-length for the band led by Sam Jayne.
The third full-length release for the New York indie rock band led by Joseph D'Agostino was produced by John Agnello.
The English-language version of the Icelandic singer-songwriter's debut release which went triple platinum in his native country was translated by John Grant.
The fifth album for the trio was recorded in Los Angeles with Tom Biller.
With a mix of country, rock and soul, the ninth album from the Georgian alternative band is genre-defying and full of their trademark Southern rock influences.
The 11th full-length studio release was recorded over 11 days in Los Angeles with contributions from Martin Jenkins, Rob Marshall, and Sietse van Gorkom.
This is the second full-length release for the British indie pop duo of Rachel Aggs and Eilidh Rodgers.
The third full-length release from Detroit-based electronic producer Zach Saginaw was written after a move back to Michigan and the end of a long-term relationship.

The jazz group celebrated its 50th anniversary with a live concert at Carnegie Hall with such guests as Steve Earle, Givers, Merrill Garbus (aka Tune-Yards), Mos Def, My Morning Jacket, and Pete Seeger's grandson, Tao Rodríguez-Seeger.
The band led by Phil Cook releases a six-track album which was completed in six weeks.
This is the third full-length release since the British post-punk band reformed in 2011.
The second full-length release from the Irish singer-songwriter was self-produced and recorded in the US.
The follow-up to the British rock band's 2008 debut Antidotes was produced by Luke Smith.
The sixth full-length release for the British electropop band led by Joseph Mount was recorded in his home studio.
The debut full-length solo release for The Antlers frontman was influenced by a period of time when he was suffering from temporary total hearing loss.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Canadian trio was recorded in France.
The sixth full-length release for the Canadian electronic artist features guest appearances from Feist, Kim Gordon, and Simmone Jones.
The trio led by Saturday Night Live's Adam Samberg returns with its follow-up to its 2009 parody debut album.
This is the latest album for the California singer-songwriter, who started out as the nanny to Tom Waits' children.
Jerry Finn (blink-182) produced this follow-up to 'Good Mourning.'
The debut full-length release for the Dublin noise-rock band was self-produced.
The first new studio release in six years for the experimental pop artist was written and recorded in his Minnesota home.
The sixth full-length studio release for the grime artist features production from The Arcade, Cardo, Darkness, Deputy, Donae'O, Dan Farber, Heavy Trackerz, Valentino Khan, and Salva.
The former Creedence Clearwater Revival singer returns after three years with his latest solo album.
The Swedish garage rockers return with a sophomore LP.

Although lumped in with the New York garage-rock scene, The Walkmen (which includes members of defunct bands Jonathan Fire Eater and The Recoys) stand out by incorporating a wider range of influences and instrumentation. (Plus, they own their own New York recording studio, which puts them about as far from an actual garage as you can get). This is the band's second LP, which follows their acclaimed 2002 debut 'Everyone Who Pretended to Like Me Is Gone.'
The duo of Sam Coomes and Janet Weiss (Sleater-Kinney) return with their fifth LP.
One of the four releases on the same day for Arca's KICK anthology is said to be "more manic, violently euphoric and aggressively psychedelic."

The latest release from the Scottish singer-songwriter was produced by Hot Chip's Alexis Taylor and features contributions from such artists as KT Tunstall, The Pictish Trail, Hot Chip drummer Rob Smoughton, Fimber Bravo, Jon Thorne, and Emma Smith.
Polyphonic Spree member Annie Clark releases her debut album.
The debut full-length release for the Chicago indie pop band led by Lili Trifilio was recorded with producer Joe Reinhart.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Atlanta punk rock trio was produced by Nic Jodoin.
This is the second release for the British symphonic rock five-piece (Adam and Brendan Sykes left the group in 2012).

The multiple Grammy-winning R&B/soul singer returns to the Stax label with an album featuring guest appearances from such artists as Gary Clark, Jr., Estelle, Anthony Hamilton, Mayer Hawthorne, Luke James, Sheila E., and Vintage Trouble.
The first release in over ten years for the alternative rock band is a 32 songs set with a book by singer Kristin Hersh.
The 10th full-length studio release for the Portland, Oregon-based alternative rock duo was self-produced.
The fifth full-length release for the British indie rock band was produced by John Congleton.
The second solo release for the now Portland, Oregon-based electronic artist was created while Urick was moving from Baltimore and dealing with his personal relationships.
The latest album for the twin singer-songwriters was produced with Chris Walla.
This is the debut full-length studio release for South African Shangaan electronic artist Richard Hlungwani as Nozinja.

recordauthor: Thee Silver Mt. Zion Memorial Orchestra & Tra-La-La Band
description: The sixth album for the Canadian group is the first credited under the shortened name of Thee Silver Mt. Zion Memorial Orchestra.
The debut full-length release for the New Zealand alternative pop artist features guest appearances from Lily Allen, Bakar, Kenny Beats, Gus Dapperton, Flo Milli, Grimes, Mallrat, and Muoki.
The second full-length release for electronic producer Oliver Johnson as Dorian Concept was inspired by '60s jazz, '70s fusion, '80s neo prog-rock, and 90s electronica.
The third full-length release for the indie band led by Honey Owens is its first in seven years.
The second full-length release for the British indie folk artist features two tracks over 15 minutes long.

'Powder Burns' is Greg Dulli's fourth album under the Twilight Singers name, and was recorded in New Orleans before, during (using generators) and after Hurricane Katrina. Joseph Arthur and Ani DiFranco guest.
The second full-length release for the British trio was produced by Charlie Andrew.
The latest solo release from the former Sun City Girls guitarist was self-recorded in Morocco.
This is the debut full-length release for the Los Angeles-based electronic artist.

The Mississippi-born rapper's debut studio album was delayed from its original release in the fall of 2011 due to legal issues. The 16 track release features guest appearances by such artists as Bun B, B.B. King, Devin the Dude, Melanie Fiona, and Ludacris.
Spencer Krug's second album under the name Moonface was recorded with the Finnish band Siinai.
Unfinished material from 1979-80 were the framework for the latest release from the British post-punk band.
Jim Abbiss (Kasabian) produced this third album for the UK band, which finds them expanding slightly away their electroclash sound.
The Denver, Colorado-based quartet known for its work on the "Little Miss Sunshine" soundtrack and score releases its latest album on the Anti label.
Jeffrey Lewis' latest album is his first to be credited with his backing band, The Junkyard.

The second full-length release for the side project of Iceage's Elias Bender Rønnenfelt features contributions from Choir of Young Believers' Sonja La Bianca as well as members of the Stargaze Orchestra.
This is the debut full-length release for Boston singer-guitarist Ellen Kempner.
Acoustic guitar accompanies the debut album for the singer-songwriter from Ethiopia now living in Finland.

recordname: The Devil And God Are Raging Inside Me
description: The Long Island emo band's major-label debut was co-produced by Mike Sapone.
This is the third album for the English electro-indie rock band.
The 14th full-length studio release for Georgia rock band Drive-By Truckers features background vocals from Schaefer Llana, R.E.M.'s Mike Mills, and Margo Price.
Matthew Houck releases his cover album of Willie Nelson songs.
This debut disc from the hyped London garage band (deemed the UK's version of The Strokes by British music mags) was produced by The Clash's Mick Jones.
Amy Winehouse's debut album is finally out in the US four years after it was first released in the UK.
Jason Isbell's first solo album since he left the Drive By Truckers.
The live album of the metal band performing with the San Francisco Symphony at San Francisco's Chase Center features songs recorded over two nights in September 2019.
The debut release of the collaboration between German electronic artists Marcus Wargull and Danilo Plessow features guest appearances from Jaki Liebezeit of Can and Dominik Von Senger.
This is the debut full-length release for the Amherst, Mass., rock trio.
The latest EP for the San Francisco indie rock quartet was recorded at Louder Studios; its first outside the band's own home studio.
The latest full-length release for the Canadian singer-songwriter includes instruments like a homemade lithophone and pipes from his basement.
The second full-length release for the Swedish post-punk band led by Sebastian Murphy features production from Daniel Fagerström, Pelle Gunnerfeldt, Matt Sweeney, Justin and Jeremiah Raisen.
This is the first album for the San Francisco experimental rock outfit since the departure of guitarist Chris Cohen.
The noisy, intense Michigan band returns with a follow-up to 2004's 'Burned Mind.'
The debut full-length release for the collaboration between Meg Baird and Mary Lattimore was recorded in Los Angeles with Thom Monaghan.
The debut full-length release for the London-based singer-songwriter was recorded with Nathan Jenkins (aka Bullion) in Portugal.
The second full-length release from Arthur Ashin was influenced by the music of such artists as Laurie Anderson, David Byrne, Annie Lennox, Katy Perry, Lee "Scratch" Perry, and Rihanna.
The latest album from the Magnolia Electric Co. is a tribute concept album for their deceased bassist, Evan Farrell.
The debut full-length release for the British alternative rock band was produced by Mike Crossey.

The fourth solo release for the New York rapper is a concept album influenced by his own experience with depression and features guest appearances from Black Thought, dEnAuN, Talib Kweli, and The Stepkids.

Neil Hannon returns with his first album since 2001's 'Regeneration.' Basically a solo effort (though retaining the Divine Comedy name), 'Friends' was produced and largely performed by Hannon, with Nigel Godrich handling the mixing.
'Misery' is the first 4AD release for the noisy, experimental indie rockers, who have mellowed/refined their sound a bit to fit their new label.
America's favorite party animal attempts to move past the frat party/beer commercial sound of his hit debut album with this slightly more mature follow-up. Slightly.
The sixth studio LP for the distinctive English band is preceded by the EP "Don't Even Go There" (which shares one track with the album).
This major-label debut for the Massachusetts alt-metal band finds the group willing to experiment with and open up its sound, adding more adventurous elements into the mix.
The roots rocker tackles a variety of tough, contemporary issues on this latest release, perhaps his most political, issue-oriented album yet. Sheryl Crow and Emmylou Harris guest.
The suddenly-prolific 74-year-old Mississippi bluesman offers up a back-to-the-basics live set, recorded in Portland in January 2001 with two backing musicians.
The latest full-length release for the country singer-songwriter was produced by Ian Fitchuk and Daniel Tashian.
The fourth full-length release for the post-punk trio was mixed and produced by Nick Sylvester.
The first solo release of new material from the Grateful Dead guitarist in 30 years was produced by Josh Kaufman with contributions from Aaron and Bryce Dessner, Josh Ritter, and Scott Devendorf.
This is the debut full-length solo release for Vampire Weekend's Chris Baio.
The third full-length release for the New York alternative rock band was produced by Mike Ditrio.

recordname: A Hundred Things Keep Me Up At Night
description: The Swedish indie-rock band releases its sophomore album.
The third full-length release for the duo of Malawian Esau Mwamwaya and Swedish producer Johan Hugo feature contributions from Baaba Maal, Seye, and Chris Baio of Vampire Weekend.
The sixth album for the Robert Schneider-led indie-pop band is packed with 24 songs (although a dozen of them are brief instrumental segues).
