The fourth solo album for the Broken Social Scene member includes appearances by Liam O'Neil, Tony Scherr, and Andrew Whiteman.
The second collaboration between Steve Gunn and The Black Twig Pickers was recorded live.
Field Music's David Brewis releases his first album under his solo project School Of Language since 2008's Sea from Shore.
Chicago-based David Cohn's latest album as Serengeti was produced by Why's Yoni Wolf and Owen Ashworth.
This is the second album for the New York-born, Nashville-based singer-songwriter.
The San Francisco-based singer-songwriter releases his second album for the year.
The third full-length release for the Canadian punk rock band was produced by Jesse Gander.
Eric Johnson returns to the indie rock band for its fourth album after having worked with The Shins and Vetiver.

Produced by Kevin McMahon, the third full-length album for the indie rock band focuses on singer-guitarist Patrick Stickles recent life experiences, including accidental electrocution and battling an eating disorder.

recordauthor: Jenny Lewis With The Watson Twins
description: This is the solo debut for former child star, Rilo Kiley frontwoman and occasional Postal Service vocalist Jenny Lewis. Contributors include Bright Eyes' Conor Oberst, Death Cab For Cutie's Ben Gibbard and singer-songwriter M. Ward.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn indie pop trio of Julia Cumming, Nick Kivlen, and Jacob Faber was co-produced by Unknown Mortal Orchestra's Jacob Portrait.
The sixth full-length release for the Portland, Oregon post-rock band was self-produced.
The debut full-length solo release from Parts & Labor's keyboardist and singer is a follow-up to his debut EP Valedictorian/Exoskeleton, released in November 2012.
The indie rock band releases its latest album produced by Brian Beattie.
Eight songs from the British rock band's 2015 self-titled release were reworked for this "mini-LP."

recordname: Drill A Hole In That Substrate And Tell Me What You See
description: The always interesting Florida-based singer-songwriter's third album was co-produced by Joe Henry, with appearances from Aimee Mann, Chocolate Genius, M. Ward, Bil Frisell and The Sadies.
The second album of indie pop from Steve Marion was recorded and produced in his home.
The fourth full-length release for the Luis Vasquez solo project was produced by Maurizio Baggio.
This is the first release in seven years for the trio of super-producer Steve Albini (guitar), Todd Trainer (drums), and Bob Weston (bass).
The debut full-length release for the British post-punk trio features contributions from Chris Duffin of XAM Duo.

The 10th full-length studio release for the Chicago rapper was produced by No I.D. and features guest appearances Jhené Aiko, Snoh Aalegra, Big Sean, Elijah Blake, Cocaine 80's, Dreezy, Lil Herb, and Malik Yusef.
The Buffalo, NY, hardcore band's sixth album is its last with bassist Josh Newton, who left the band in October 2011.
The debut release for the collaboration between Franz Ferdinand and Sparks was produced by John Congleton.
The debut record for the New York quintet includes two drummers and a piano player.

The debut full-length release for the London-based electronic producer features guest appearances from Damon Albarn, A$AP Rocky, Bonzai, Charli XCX, Christine And The Queens, Desiigner, Jamie Lidell, NAO, A. K. Paul, and Tom Tripp.
The Swedish trio returns with a more pop sound for its third release.
The debut full-length collaboration from The Bugs Kevin Martin and Earths Dylan Carlson was recorded in two days in Los Angeles.
The second full-length release for the band led by Tom Petty was produced by band members Petty and Mike Campbell with Ryan Ulyate.
Previously known as Games, Joel Ford and Daniel Lopatin release their debut full-length album under their new name.
The second release for the Canadian rock duo of Benjamin Nelson and Paul Saulnier was produced by Matt Rogalsky and inspired by dreams Saulnier had while on tour.
The Portland, Ore-based singer-songwriter reunites with producer Tucker Martine (The Decemberists) for her sixth album, which is titled after her backing band.

Former members of Teenage Fanclub Dave McGowan and Brendan O'Hare along with The Pastels' Tom Crossley, and Belle & Sebastian's Bob Kildea contributed to the debut solo album for Teenage Fanclub's Gerard Love as Lightships.
Malkmus' third post-Pavement recording is his most "solo" effort to date (not to mention his weirdest), with only some of the songs featuring the full complement of Jicks backing him up.
Tony Hoffer produced this seventh studio LP for the veteran Scottish indie-pop band.

The debut release for the Canadian five-piece indie pop band that includes Molly Rankin, daughter of Rankin Family member John Morris; former Two Hours Traffic member Alec O'Hanley; and Danks drummer Phil MacIsaac was produced by Chad VanGaalen.
The pop-rap experimentalists release its debut full-length album.
This solo debut for the Azure Ray member includes appearances from fellow Saddle Creek-ers Conor Oberst and Andy LeMaster.
The second full-length release for the band led by Kathleen Hanna was mixed by Eli Crews.
This much-anticipated release for the eclectic performer--a return to the "fun" Beck of 'Odelay' and 'Midnite Vultures'--was produced by the Dust Brothers and Tony Hoffer.
The fifth album for Eef Barzelay & co. includes contributions from members of Lambchop and Crooked Fingers. Barzelay himself produced the entire disc.

Poet, musician, and singer/songwriter Gil Scott-Heron is one of the most influential progenitors of hip-hop music. Such artists as Kanye West, Mos Def, Black Star, and Air have sampled his work. Now, the poet returns with his first album in 15 years released on XL Recordings.
Fans of his acclaimed 2002 pair of discs will have to settle for just one album this time out, co-produced by Waits with Kathleen Brennan. Marc Ribot and Les Claypool guest.
The seventh full-length studio release for Chaz Bear as Toro y Moi features guest appearances from Salami Rose Joe Louis, The Mattson 2, and Sofie.
The debut full-length release for the collaboration between The Body and BIG|BRAVE was recorded, produced and mixed by Seth Manchester.
The latest full-length solo release for indie artist who was a member of Dinosaur Jr., Sebadoh and The Folk Implosion, was recorded by Marc Seedorf.
The fifth full-length studio release for the rock band led by Amy Lee was produced by Nick Raskulinecz.

The fifth full-length release for the New Jersey singer-songwriter was co-produced with Ben Tanner with contributions from Seth Avett, Britt Daniel, David Hood, Spooner Oldham, Erin Rae, McKenzie Smith, and John Paul White.
The latest full-length release for the singer-songwriter from Seattle was self-produced.
The fifth full-length release for the indie pop husband-and-wife duo of Alaina Moore and Patrick Riley was self-produced and mixed by Claudius Mittendorfer.
The debut full-length solo project for Kasabian's Serge Pizzorno features guest appearances from Little Simz and slowthai.
The 12th full-length release for Scott Morgan as Loscil was inspired by Alfred Stieglitz's photographs of clouds from the '20s and '30s.
The third album from the British trio features a variety of producers, including Marta Salogni, Andy Smith, Ash Workman, and Joe Wills.
The second full-length releases for the Los Angeles post-punk band was produced and mixed by Tim Green.
The ninth full-length solo release for the singer-songwriter was recorded over four days in Nashville and was mixed by Tucker Martine.
The fourth full-length release for the Manchester-based jazz trio features elements of electronic music.
The 12th full-length release for indie rock band led by Dan Bejar was was produced by Josh Wells of Black Mountain.

recordname: 20 Years in a Montana Missile Silo
description: The 16th full-length release for the Cleveland rock band led by David Thomas
The first full-length released in seven years for the indie rock artist was funded via Kickstarter and was self-produced/recorded.
The third full-length release for the Rhode Island punk rock band was produced by Greg Norman and Fugazi's Guy Picciotto.
The third full-length release for the Nashville-based country singer-songwriter was produced with Jonathan Tyler.

recordname: Pas Pire Pop, I Love You So Much
recordauthor: Avec le Soleil Sortant de Sa Bouche
description: This is the second full-length release for the Montreal kraut-funk band that includes Jean-Sebastien Truchy, Sebastien Fournier, Eric Gingras and, Samuel Bobony.
The third full-length studio release for the British prog rock band was recorded in Devon, Isle Of Wight and London.
The 13th full-length release for the British prog rock band that features Peter Hammill, Hugh Banton and Guy Evans.
The fourth full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was co-produced with James Dring.
The second full-length release from the trio that includes Nils Frahm, Frederic Gmeiner and Sebastian Singwald features more tracks made from their early 1990s four-track recordings.
The debut full-length solo release for the French electronic artist who makes up one half of Air was inspired by Glenn Gould's performances of Bach.
The latest solo release from the Guided By Voices leader was produced by Nick Mitchell.
The seventh full-length studio release for the British folk rock band was produced with Ali Staton.
The debut collaboration between James Yorkston, Jon Thorne, and Suhail Yusuf Khan features influences from folk, Indian, and jazz music.
The third full-length studio release for the Chicago R&B artist features guest appearances from Jhené Aiko, Big Sean, J. Cole, Future, Juicy J, Migos, Twista, Ty Dolla $ign, and YG.
The debut full-length studio release for the New York rapper features guest appearances from DonChristian, Devonté Hynes, House of LaDosha, Junglepussy, and Miss Geri.
The fourth full-length release for the Australian rock quartet was produced by Lawrence English.
The first new release in six years for the Canadian folk artist features production from Michael Wojewoda, Chris Birkett, and Jon Levine.
The latest experimental full-length release for the Toronto-based guitarist features four instrumental tracks produced with Radwan Ghazi Moumneh.
The latest release from the British artist features influences from punk, garage rock, and pop.

recordname: Man It Feels Like Space Again
description: The sixth full-length release for the Australian psychedelic rock band was actually written before 2013's Hobo Rocket.
The third full-length release for the Canadian band led by Colin Huebert features contributions from Colin Stetson and Owen Pallett.
The debut full-length release for the Mississippi hip hop duo of Slim Jimmy and Swae Lee features guest appearances from Big Sean, Jace of Two-9, Nicki Minaj, and Young Thug.
This is the second solo release for the solo music project from Cold Pumas/Faux Discx member Dan Reeves.
This is the third full-length release for the Scottish six-piece indie group.
The fifth studio release for the singer-songwriter sees the addition of influences from rock music to his jazz, R&B, and soul sounds.
The first release for the Australian group since the death of founding member Sean Stewart in 2010 returns as as a duo with Nigel Yang and Jonnine Standish.
The debut full-length release for the Keysound contributor features guest appearances from Rebel MC and Sully.
The Ethiopian pianist melds American jazz, funk, and his native music together on his debut release.
Originally recorded in 2011, Barn Owl's Evan Caminiti reworked it this year into this seven-track release.
Produced by Joe Chiccarelli, the latest album from the Los Angeles artist was written during a breakup and recorded while she was pregnant with twins.
This is the second album of Spanish folk music Josephine Foster has recorded with the Victor Herrero Band.
The latest album from the Australian musician includes Knots, a 33-minute song.
The Congo-born Belgian-raised rapper returned to the Democratic Republic of the Congo to work with some local musicians on his latest album.
The second solo album for the folk singer was produced by Joe Henry.
The fourth studio album for the metal band from Pennsylvania was produced by Jason Suecof.
King Creosote collaborates with electronica producer Jon Hopkins to rerecord seven of his songs.

recordname: Peanut Butter Blues and Melancholy Jam
description: This is the debut full-length album for British rapper/producer Obaro Ejimiwe.
The Mercury Prize-nominated experimental jazz band releases its fourth album.
The concept album about a group of Irish US soldiers who deserted to join the Mexican army during the Mexican-American War was an idea by The Chieftains' Paddy Moloney and co-producer Ry Cooder.
The latest album for the blues singer, who most recently collaborated with Eric Clapton on their 2006 Grammy-winning album, "The Road to Escondido."
The latest album for the Brooklyn, New York band is the first with new drummer Joe Wong and guitarist Sarah Lipstate.
The debut album for the Dresdan Dolls singer was produced with Ben Folds.
The latest album for the country artist was produced by Emory Gordy, Jr.
After releasing an EP every month for a year in 2006, the Brooklyn-based band returns with a full-length album.
His fifth album finds the Texan singer-songwriter backed by a full band.
Co-produced by Rick Rubin, this 12-song disc was recorded during the same sessions as 'Mesmerize,' and is intended to be heard with that earlier 2005 disc as one complete set.
The New York band returns with a third album.
The Led Zeppelin singer's first full solo album of original songs in a dozen years finds him backed (as on 2002's 'Dreamland') by The Strange Sensation.

recordname: The Difference Between Me And You Is That I'm Not On Fire
description: Steve Albini returns as producer for the Welsh indie-punk trio's third album.

'Almost Killed Me' is the debut for the New York City band featuring two former members of Lifter Puller, including band founder Craig Finn. Unlike most recent NYC bands, they draw their influences from classic American rock.

Known for her work as half of the 4AD group Dead Can Dance, as well as more recent efforts scoring such films as Gladiator and Whale Rider, Lisa Gerrard here unites with Irish classical composer Patrick Cassidy for ten new tracks, including songs sung in Aramaic, Latin and Gaelic.
The ever-prolific Robert Pollard returns with a brand-new GbV studio disc (the 15th or so since 1987), retaining the core group of musicians that has been with him for the last few albums.

The best indie rock band to come out of Modesto, California in quite some time (well, ever, we'd think) returns with a long-awaited fourth LP, arriving a full three years after The Sophtware Slump thanks to worldwide tours and a lengthy recording process.

The trip-hop duo continues to expand their sound on their third album, which features guest appearances from Michael Franti (Spearhead), Me'Shell Ndegeocello, Jimi Goodwin (Doves) and the Scratch Perverts.
The New York-based experimental jazz trio expands its sound on this album by adding turntablists DJ P Love and DJ Olive and a five-piece horn section.
This is the fourth album (and third record label) for the Athens, GA indie outfit.

The veteran Chicago house producer offers up 16 tracks of modernized 80's electro (think Daft Punk or Ladytron), highlighted by "Silver Screen (Shower Scene)." The album picked up a great deal of acclaim in the UK when it was released in mid-2001, and finally secured U.S. distribution (through Emperor Norton) in early 2002.

recordname: If You're Reading This It's Too Late [Mixtape]
description: The surprise 17-track mixtape from the Canadian artist features guest appearances from Lil Wayne, PARTYNEXTDOOR, and Travi$ Scott was produced by Noah 40 Shebib and Matthew Jehu Samuels.
The second release for the psychedelic rock band led by Ruban Nielson was written while on tour.
The eighth full-length studio release for the indie rock band was recorded by producer Josh Kaufman and engineer D. James Goodwin.
'Fear' is the second solo disc for the unique Los Angeles-based MC (born Regan Farquhar), who is backed here by beats from Daedelus, Danger Mouse, and others.
The third full-length release for the Canadian experimental pop trio was produced with Damian Taylor.
The fourth full-length release for the alternative folk rock project of Kate Stables was produced by John Parish.
The fifth full-length release for the Canadian is self-described as his country album.
The UK indie rock group's fifth album.
The latest release for the British electronic producer features vocal/choral recordings.
The fourth live release for the rock band was recorded from two appearances at KCRW's Santa Monica studios in April 2013.

Borrowing a page from late-80s to early-90s DM in terms of sound (and possibly even quality), the Ben Hillier-produced 'Angel' is the first Depeche Mode album to feature some David Gahan-penned songs in addition to the usual assortment of Martin Gore tracks.
Thom Monahan produced the band's fourth studio album.

The fourth full-length studio release for the British singer/rapper features a guest appearance from The Weekend as well as production from Danja, Doc McKinney, Hit-Boy, Illangelo, The Partysquad, and Switch.

Only Josh Homme remains from the QOTSA's previous LP, and he's now joined by guitarist Troy Van Leeuwen (A Perfect Circle) and drummer Joey Castillo (Danzig). The band's fourth album also includes appearances by Brody Dalle, Shirley Manson and ZZ Top's Billy Gibbons.
The British musician teams with legendary New Orleans songwriter and producer Allen Toussaint for this mix of covers and new material.
This is the second full-length release for London producer Jack Latham as Jam City.
The New Mexico-based band releases its newest album of indie rock, fusing world music with pop to develop a unique sound all of its own.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn-based duo was self-produced and recorded.
This is the second or third album (depending on how you keep score) for the Oregon-by-way-of-Los Angeles singer-songwriter.
The second full-length release for the experimental psychedelic rock duo of Les Claypool and Sean Lennon was self-produced.
The second album for the indie rock band from Rhode Island is a follow-up to its self-titled debut.

The first album on new label Blue Note for the saxophonist Ravi Coltrane features two different groups backing his compositions. One led by his long-time pianist Luis Perdomo, bassist Drew Gress, and drummer E.J. Strickland and the other led by trumpeter Ralph Alessi, pianist Geri Allen, bassist James Genus, and drummer Eric Harland who worked on his second album, From the Round Box.
Asian instrumentation is highlighted on the Chicago minimalist, avant-garde outfit's sixth release.

'Professor' marks the second solo outing for the Sea And Cake leader. He's backed by the same group of musicians that performed on his previous 1999 release, including S&C bandmate Archer Prewitt and Josh Abrams (Town & Country).
The second full-length release for the Danish R&B artist was produced with Natal Zaks.
The Christmas-themed album from the country singer-songwriter features guest appearances from Daddy Cool & The Yule, Mary Kerr, Brennen Leigh, and Lera Lynn.
The debut full-length solo release for the lead singer of The Gaslight Anthem was produced by Butch Walker.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn artist is a techno-inspired instrumental album.

The latest full-length release for the indie folk/rock artist from Boston features contributions from Brooke Bentham, Jemima Coulter, Katy J Pearson, Tencis Jess Shoman, Tomberlin, her father and her two brothers, Nate and Jameson Williams.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles singer-songwriter was produced by Lewis Pesacov.
The third studio album for the Scottish indie band produced by Peter Katis is its first with new member Gordon Skene.
Conor Oberst & co. branch out into country and orchestral pop on their latest 13-track set, which finds them joined by guests Gillian Welch, Janet Weiss, and M. Ward.
This is the fifth solo album of anti-folk ditties for the former Moldy Peaches member.
Steve Revitte produced the experimental Brooklyn four-piece's third album (and first for Matador).
Digitally released in June, the Baltimore indie duo of Jenn Wasner and Andy Stack collected and completed eight outtakes from its previous two albums for the band's fifth studio release.

The all-female indie-rock band from Brighton, England (who in the past have crossed Stereolab's love for vintage electronics with a more raucous sound) worked with producer Steve Albini on this second full-length, which incorporates vocals into the mix for the first time.
Popular San Francisco-based indie producer and former MK Ultra frontman John Vanderslice returns with his fourth solo album.
Adams' 'Love Is Hell' 2-part album concludes with seven more tracks.
The Virginia band's sophomore disc has a more immediate sound compared to their trip-hoppy self-titled debut.

Even the most casual DMB fan knows the story by now: Dave & Co. record a dark, challenging album with producer Steve Lillywhite, those "Lillywhite Sessions" are leaked onto the Internet where the tracks quickly become fan favorites, and the band chooses not to release them, instead heading back into the studio with producer Glen Ballard to record 'Everyday.' The new studio LP 'Busted Stuff' does not contain those original tracks from the 2000 sessions, but nine of those songs (plus two new tracks) are here, newly recorded.

This long-awaited fourth album from the London-based outfit headed by Tjinder Singh and Ben Ayres is an even more eclectic mix of styles than previous efforts. The 13 new tracks include the excellent (and excellently titled) lead single "Lessons Learned From Rocky I to Rocky III," and a reworking of "People Power (In The Disco Hour)" from Singh and Ayres' Clinton side project.
'Gold' is the second solo release for former Whiskeytown frontman Ryan Adams, and garnered a good deal of attention for the singer-songwriter in 2001.
French band Fugu mines the pop sounds of the Beach Boys and the Beatles, a la contemporaries Stereolab (who contribute to this album) and Apples In Stereo.

recordname: Dreamt For Light Years In The Belly Of A Mountain
description: Mark Linkous' first Sparklehorse album in five years includes collaborations with Danger Mouse, Christian Fennesz, and Tom Waits.
The 10th full-length studio release for the Arizona alt-rock/emo band was produced with Justin Meldal-Johnson.
The first new full-length studio release for the English alternative rock band since 1991's World Outside was produced with Richard Fortus.
The seventh full-length release for Eric D. Johnson's indie folk-rock project was produced by Thom Monahan and is the first release on the Merge label.
The second full-length release from the rapper in two weeks features guest appearances from Rihanna and The Weeknd.
The New York-born singer releases an eight track album inspired by her current fame.
This is the first album for the trio since Ryan Vanderhoof left the band in the fall of 2007.
This is the sixth studio album for the indie rock band led by David Berman.
The singer/songwriter's sophomore set (delayed for a year due to an acrimonious split with her record label) includes collaborations with k.d. lang and Cyndi Lauper.
This is the self-produced third album for the Manchester, England band.
The follow-up to the country singer's Grammy-winning major label debut release was co-produced with Luke Laird and Shane McAnally.

recordname: The Life Of The World To Come
description: This is the latest album for the North Carolina-based band.
The seventh full-length release for the singer-songwriter was produced by Mike Mogis.
The veteran Irish trio return with a rock-oriented affair, their fifth studio disc overall.
The seventh solo release for the former Rodan bassist is her first on the Kranky label.
The Berlin-based ex-sound engineer releases her debut full-length album of electronic music influenced by dubstep.
Greg Fidelman and Rick Rubin produced the latest disc for the thrash metal band.
The debut full-length release for the dream-pop trio led by Grouper's Liz Harris was recorded over several years with Scott Simmons and Jed Bindeman.
The fifth full-length release for the Ohio-based band is its first without contributions from the group's late violinist Noel Sayre, who drowned in 2008.
A$AP Rocky, Dom Kennedy, Curren$y, and Kendrick Lamar are some of the guests on the Los Angeles rapper's second album on Top Dawg Entertainment.
The debut album for the Montreal, Quebec-based indie rock trio.

Soul singer-songwriter Maxwell returns with his third studio album, following 1998's 'Embrya' and his well-received 1996 debut 'Maxwell's Urban Hang Suite.' The disc includes a cover of longtime live staple "This Woman's Work" (a Kate Bush cover).
The latest full-length studio release for rapper Nas was produced by Hit-Boy and features guest appearances from A$AP Rocky and DJ Premier.
The third full-length release for the Chicago trio was produced by the band's guitarist, Jason Balla.
The first new studio release in six years from the Danish art rock band sees the return of original bassist Johan Wohler and was produced by Michael Beinhorn.
The fifth album for the Scottish band was recorded in Portland, Oregon with producer Tucker Martine and features guest appearances from Neko Case and Jim James.
This is the debut album for the side project of Liz Harris of Grouper and Jesy Fortino of Tiny Vipers.
Gonjasufi, who appeared on the Flying Lotus track "Testament," releases his debut album with producer Gaslamp Killer.
The fourth album for the Florida-based alt-country singer features the band Olabelle and was produced by Joe Pernice.

recordname: Everything Not Saved Will Be Lost, Pt. 1
description: The fifth full-length release for the British indie rock band was produced by frontman Yannis Philippakis.
Stephen Street (Blur) produced this debut disc for the Leeds, England five-piece.
The second full-length studio release for the Atlanta-based electronic producer features a track Totally Enormous Extinct Dinosaurs.
The third album for the Portland, Oregon, folk rock band was produced by Adam Selzer.
The garage rock band from Tacoma, Washington, return with three original members and producer Jim Diamond for its first studio release since 1967.
The seventh full-length studio release for the indie rock band was produced with Dave Sardy and Jacknife Lee.
The 12th full-length solo studio release for the Black Sabbath singer features guest appearances from Elton John, Post Malone and Travis Scott.
The eighth full-length studio release for British experimental electronic producer Stephen Wilkinson is mostly improvised musical pieces.
The director/composer re-recorded 13 themes from his films including Halloween Escape From New York, and Assault on Precinct 13 with his son, Cody Carpenter, and godson, Daniel Davies.
The debut full-length release for the Chicago indie rock band was recorded in Dave Vettraino's basement studio on 8-track analog tape.

recordname: Chaos And Creation In The Backyard
description: Radiohead producer Nigel Godrich helms the bassist's 20th post-Beatles album, which finds McCartney in true solo mode, playing every instrument on these 13 songs.
The first full-length release in five years for the Australian duo of Jonnine Standish and Nigel Yang was self-produced.
First recorded in 2010, the collaboration between the Detroit techno producer with the Les Siecles Orchestra, French conductor François-Xavier Roth, and Francesco Tristano is finally released.
The eighth studio release for the Irish artist was inspired by Roma Ryan's poetry books about islands, especially the island of Sark.
Jim O'Rourke produced the singer-songwriter's fourth LP.

The third full-length solo release for the ex-Smiths guitarist was recorded at Manchester's Crazy Face Studios and features a future society at the brink of destruction that ultimately find help from "a different intelligence from the cosmos.'
The debut full-length release for the Nashville indie singer-songwriter was produced by Gabe Wax and mixed by Ali Chant.
The first solo release for the co-founder of Everything But the Girl since 1983's North Marine Drive features contributions from Bernard Butler, David Gilmour, and Tracey Thorn.
The debut full-length release for the collaborative project of Lightning Bolt's Brian Chippendale and Ty Segall was recorded at Segall's house.
Produced by guitarist Thomas Brenneck, the fourth release for the New York-based funk band sees influences from psychedelia and metal music.
This is the final album with both Tim Bracy and Shannon McArdle in the group, in light of their divorce.

recordname: The World And Everything In It
description: The second album from the Baltimore band was produced by band leader and vocalist Roman Kuebler.
This is the second album for the garage-blues duo of VV and Hotel (known to their parents as Alison Mosshart and Jamie Hince).
The second album by this Brooklyn band ventures further into the musical landscape of guitar-led experimentation while maintaining a pop sound.
The latest full-length release for Scottish indie pop band Belle And Sebastian was self-produced and features contributions from Kevin Burleigh, Shawn Everett, Brian McNeil, and Matt Wiggins.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter was produced by Thomas Bartlett.

The surprise album release of the British electronic producer's third full-length features a collaboration with Bon Iver as well as the track "Radio Silence," which had been the tentative title of the album in 2015.
With the help of Joe Thompson--one of the last of North Carolina's African-American string-band players--the trio seeks to continue the style with its third album.
The Rick Rubin-produced album for the heavy-metal band is its first to feature Robert Trujillo on bass.
The third full-length release for the indie rock band from Brooklyn was produced by Nigel Godrich.
The debut full-length release for the Norwegian pop artist was produced by Martin Sjølie, Odd Martin Skålnes, and Oscar Holter.
The second full-length from Eminem (aka Marshall Mathers) garnered two Grammys for the rapper and became the fastest-selling rap album in history.
The debut full-length release for the the British indie rock band led by by Alex Rice was produced by Burke Reid.
This is the second album from Reine Fiske, Johan Holmegard (both members of the Swedish band, Dungen), and Christopher Gunrup.
The latest from the DJ-Kicks mix series is from Glasgow-based DJ that was influenced by some of his first shows.
On his first album with the Rhymesayers label, rapper Freeway teams up with producer Jake One.
The debut solo release for the Galaxie 500 and Luna frontman was produced by Jason Quever of Papercuts.
Felix Martin and Al Doyle of Hot Chip along with Tom Hopkins collaborated on their debut album together as New Build.
This is the second full-length album for the Brooklyn-based rock band.

recordname: The Fine Print (A Collection Of Oddities And Rarities 2003-2008)
description: The collection of b-sides and rare tracks contains songs from the "Dirty South" recording sessions.
The seventh full-length release for the Canadian indie rock band led by A.C. Newman does not feature Dan Bejar (he was working on music for a Destroyer album).

recordname: To Be Everywhere Is to Be Nowhere
description: The California alternative rock band return from a five year hiatus with its ninth full-length studio release produced by Eric Palmquist.
The third full-length solo release for the son of Crowded House's Neil Finn was recorded in Brooklyn.
The latest solo release from the British singer is a blend of psych rock and ambient pop.
After releasing two albums in 2010, the singer-songwriter returns with her 12th studio album.

Fol Chen continues to embrace mystery and avoid the obvious on Part II: The New December. As on Part I: John Shade, Your Fortuneâs Made, the enigmatic band makes a virtue out of indirectness, sending songs through secret passages and tunnels that end in hooks some distance from where they were expected. Thereâs a strong experimental streak in the brainy way Fol Chen takes what seems like a straightforward idea and twists it into something completely different; like the Dirty Projectors, the group flirts with and subverts mainstream pop ideas, and like labelmates Cryptacize, theyâve got a flair for the deceptively simple. The band goes even further down the rabbit hole than on Part I, beginning The New December with some of its strangest music. âIn Ruinsâ contrasts deep, whispered vocals with lively girlish ones atop busy keyboards playing busy, vaguely Eastern-tinged melodies; âYour Curtain Callâ begins with breathy beats and woozy flutes, expanding into bells and a drunken sax solo before pulling back again; and âMen, Houses or Beastsâ tiptoes so slowly that it almost sounds like it was recorded at the wrong speed. Fittingly for a band so committed to disguising its identity, some of The New Decemberâs best songs deal with miscommunication and missed connections. On âThe Holograms,â a tale of forgotten names and words doubling into optical illusions, bounces along on one of the albumâs catchiest melodies, while the excellent âC/Uâ keeps its lovers apart despite its almost perversely straightforward beat. Likewise, the band buries some of its best songs on the albumâs second half: âAdeline (You Always Look so Bored)ââs sharp-tongued chamber pop recalls St. Vincentâs abundant musical and lyrical wit, and âThey Came to Meâ boasts rubbery beats that are just as danceable as they are strange, and could be heard at a club with a trampoline for a dancefloor. How exactly these songs fit together with âHolesââ delicate plucking and the title trackâs pixelated folk might be locked in Fol Chenâs brains, but even if there are more pieces of their puzzle-pop missing here than there were on John Shade, Your Fortuneâs Made, The New December is never boring. ~ Heather Phares
Dan Bejar, the New Pornographer member, releases his ninth album.
The third album for the Vienna-based electronica-infused post-rock trio was recorded partially in Austria and partially with John McEntire in Chicago.
The Swedish garage-rockers return with their third full-length disc.

The experimental/psychedelic Japanese collective returns with their first album in five years, with co-founder Taishi Takizawa re-joining the group as a member (in addition to continuing to serve as the band's producer).

The New-York four piece makes its full-length debut with this 10-track effort that has drawn comparisons to the usual suspects (Joy Division, The Cure, The Pixies, et al) as well as to newer bands who also draw from the same sources (Interpol, Hot Hot Heat, et al).
The Glaswegian guitar rockers emerge with their second full-length album, an even more intense affair than their 2001 debut 'Story In White.'

The normally prolific DiFranco hasn't released a new album since 1999's 'To The Teeth,' but now she returns with a vengeance: this 2-disc, 2-hour, 29-track collection of new songs. Ani goes solo on about half the tracks; the others feature members of her touring band. Guest musicians include trumpter Jon Hassell, sax man Maceo Parker, and guitarist Lloyd Maines.
The third full-length from the Scottish outfit.
The second full-length release for the Washington, D.C. post-punk band was produced by John Congleton and is its first without bassist Taylor Mulitz (who left to focus on Flasher).
The second full-length release for the duo of Joe Goddard and Raf Rundell includes guest appearances from Sbussio and Kwaito icon Senyaka.
The eighth full-length studio release for the British alternative rock band Placebo is its first album in nine years and the first as a duo (drummer Steve Forrest left in 2015).
Volker Bertelmann's latest album sees the composer creating house and techno music with help from violinist Hillary Hahn, Mum's drummer Samuli Kosminen, and Calexico's John Convertino and Joe Burns.
This is the debut full-length release for the Los Angeles-based indie pop duo of Mica Tenenbaum and Matthew Lewin.
The fourth full-length release for the Andy Butler dance project features guest appearances from Faris Badwan, Sísý Ey, Gustaph, Mashrou' Leila, Rouge Mary, and Sharon Van Etten.

The latest release from the Tex-Mex band features guests such as Sam Beam from Iron and Wine, Ben Bridwell from Band of Horses, Neko Case, Gaby Moreno, Carla Morrison, Amparo Sanchez, Takim, and Nick Urata from Devotchka.
The second full-length release for the Denver-based band was produced by Richard Swift.
Trent Reznor slips in another digital album release.
The latest release from Chicago rapper David Cohen as Serengeti (he also releases albums under the name Kenny Dennis) was recorded with Odd Nosdam and DJ/producer Jel.
This is the debut full-length album for Cameron Mesirow as Glasser.
The third full-length solo release for The Dresden Dolls singer was recorded in a month by John Congleton.

The second full-length release for the singer-songwriter features guest appearances from such artists as Jackson Browne, Mike Campbell, David Crosby, Taylor Goldsmith of Dawes, Graham Nash, Patrick Sansone of Wilco, Benmont Tench, and Josh Tillman.
The second full-length release for the solo project of Sadie Dupuis was mixed by Sarah Tudzin.
The third full-length release for the pop artist was produced with Kieron Menzies and Rick Nowels.

recordname: We Were Dead Before The Ship Even Sank
description: 'We Were Dead,' the Isaac Brock-led band's follow-up to its breakthrough 2004 hit 'Good News for People Who Love Bad News,' is their first release to feature their newest member, former Smiths guitarist Johnny Marr. The Shins' James Mercer guests on three tracks.
The debut solo release for Brazilian Girls' Sabina Sciubba was produced with Frederik Rubens.
The third full-length release for Melbourne-based indie rock band Rolling Blackouts Coastal Fever was produced with Matt Duffy.
The second full-length release for the emo/indie rock band comes 15 years after its debut.
The second live album for the duo features the June 14th, 2007 concert at the Palais Omnisports de Paris-Bercy.
The indie MC moves from Anticon to Epitaph for his sophomore release. Will Oldham, Danger Mouse, Alias and Saul Williams guest.
The fifth full-length solo release for the Nashville-based singer-songwriter was produced by Kate Haldrup.
The fifth full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter was produced by Dan Auerbach.
The cello and piano duo from Massachusetts releases its full-length debut.
The debut solo album for the member of the French duo Zombie Zombie was produced by Carl Craig.

recordname: I Can Feel You Creep Into My Private Life
description: The fourth full-length release for Merrill Garbus and Nate Brenner was mixed by Mikaelin "Blue" BlueSpruce.

Named after a recent documentary about him, Westerberg's latest home-recorded solo disc contains some of the songs first heard in that film, as well as new material. It was released concurrently with 'Dead Man Shake' by his alter-ego, Grandpaboy.
The 10th full-length solo studio release for the Throwing Muses singer is her first on the Fire Records label.
The third album for the Manchester, England-based singer-songwriter was co-produced with Shawn Everett, Blake Mills, and Tony Berg.
The fourth full-length release for the indie pop band was produced by Chris Coady.
The sophomore album for the New York composer is divided into three suites of music.

Will Oldham's tribute album to Merle Haggard features contributions from Van Campbell, Mary Feiock, Emmett Kelly, Nuala Kennedy, Danny Kiley, Drew Miller, Cheyenne Mize, A.J. Roach, Chris Rodahoffer, and Matt Sweeney.
The third album for the electronic band was produced by its lead singer, Joseph Mount.
The string quartet performs Sufjan Stevens' 2001 album, "Enjoy Your Rabbit."
The fourth full-length release for Natasha Khan is a concept album about a woman who takes her honeymoon trip alone after her fiance was killed just before their wedding.
The third full-length album for the San Francisco indie band was recorded over a week.
This is the debut album for the New York rock quartet.
The second full-length release for the Canadian trio was produced by Graham Walsh.
The Grammy award-winning electronic dance duo--and their masked identities portraying them as man-machines--make a logical pairing to score the soundtrack of the innovative science fiction film.
This is the second studio solo set for the folk singer-songwriter who also performs with the Be Good Tanyas.
The second full-length release for the British electronic duo of Joe Andrews and Tom Halstead was inspired by Raime side-project Moin's 2013 self-titled EP.
The fifth full-length studio release for the indie rock band is its first since the death of bassist Gerald Smith and was produced by guitarist David Sitek.
With sparse percussion and acoustic instrumentation, the Dinosaur Jr guitarist, singer and songwriter releases a solo album of low-key, unplugged tunes.
The latest disc from the Danielson Famile's Daniel Smith boasts--in addition to a shorter band name--a whopping 34 contributors, including Sufjan Stevens, Steve Albini, and the members of Why?.
The ninth full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter was written, produced, arranged, and recorded with Noah Georgeson and Josiah Steinbrick.
The second full-length release for the Seattle post-punk band was recorded in a deconsecrated church and mixed by Wire guitarist Matthew Sim.
Dave Longstreth reimagines Black Flag's album "Damaged."
This fourth album marks the Barsuk debut for the eclectic Portland, Ore. husband-and-wife duo of Kevin and Anita Robinson.
The Matthew Houck-led band returns with its first album of new material since 2007's Pride.
The debut full-length solo release for the Scissor Sisters frontman was produced by Kevin Ratterman and features members from My Morning Jacket and the Preservation Hall Jazz Band.
The second full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was produced by Thom Monahan.

The debut full-length release for the French-Cuban twins Naomi and Lisa-Kaindé Díaz (daughters of Buena Vista Social Club percussionist Miguel Díaz) includes influences from Cuban folk music, electronic, French jazz, R&B and pop music.
The ninth full-length studio release from the ex-Screaming Trees singer was produced by Alain Johannes and features contributions from Duke Garwood, Sietse van Gorkom, and Shelley Brien.
This is the debut full-length album for the British quartet led by American-born Greg Hughes and Tessa Murray.
This second song-based album of unconventional indie-rock from the Portland, Ore. trio marks their Barsuk debut.
Joe Pernice & co. return with an album produced by Michael Deming.
The latest full-length solo release for the British singer-songwriter was produced with Sebastian Krys and recorded in Helsinki, New York and Paris.

The third full-length release for the Australian duo of Zoe Randell and Steve Hassett features contributions from The Nationals Aaron Dessner, Matt Eccles, J Mascis, Dave Nelson, and Jim White of Dirty Three.
The sophomore album from the New Zealand trio.
The first full-length studio release in 20 years for British synth-pop duo Soft Cell features a song collaboration with the Pet Shop Boys.
The latest full-length solo release for the Nashville-based singer-songwriter was produced with Gregory Lattimer.
The fourth full-length solo release for the former Everything But The Girl member features a guest appearance from Alan Sparhawk of Low.

recordname: The Salt Doll Went to Measure the Depth of the Sea
description: The fifth full-length release for the Rhode Island indie folk band was inspired by a Buddhist fable about a doll made of salt who searches for herself by going into the sea.
The fifth full-length release for the R&B/soul singer was recorded over four days and features influences of more gospel and blues than his previous album.
The 12-track release from German musician Blixa Bargeld and Italian composer Teho Teardo took nearly two years, with recording done in Berlin and Rome.

recordname: The Bunkhouse, Vol. 1: Anchor Black Tattoo
description: The fourth release fro the Irish singer-songwriter was recorded at his home studio.
The third full-length release for the Swedish metal band was produced by Don Alsterberg.
Ex-Working For A Nuclear Free City guitarist Gary McClure added Ian Reitz, Josh Van Hoorebeke, and his wife, Bridgette Imperial for his second full-length release as American Wrestlers.
The fourth full-length release for the British indie rock band was self-produced and self-mixed.
The first full-length in nearly 20 years for the alternative rock band was self-produced.
This is the full-length debut release for the London-based indie electronic trio of Lewis Rainsbury, Matt Law, and Alex Bailey.
The second release for the band led by the Sleater-Kinney singer-guitarist is said to be more collaborative.
The third album for the indie-pop outfit is, for one thing, a lot shorter (at 30 minutes) than their previous double-album effort On Vacation.

9th Wonder is among the producers on the veteran Brooklyn MC's fifth full-length (rumored to be his last), a prequel to previous disc ?Disposable Arts.' Guests include Rahzel, Jean Grae and The Beatnuts.

This self-titled disc marks the debut for the unique-sounding New York post-rock/experimental trio of Philip Wann and twin sisters Claudia and Alley Deheza. Steve Rivette (Liars) produced, with guest drumming from Interpol's Sam Fogarino.
21-year-old Norwegian pop singer-songwriter Sondre Lerche returns with his second U.S. release.
This debut LP for the Brooklyn retro rap outfit (consisting of three female vocalists--including two high school students--backed by a pair of DJs) includes their surprise hit single, "Cameltoe."
The talented singer-songwriter reunites with producer David Rawlings for her fourth album.
The debut full-length album from Damon Gough (who records under the Badly Drawn Boy name) earned Britain's Mercury Prize for Best Album in 2000.
This is the debut full-length release for Vienna-based British electronic producer Christopher Taylor.
The first studio solo release for the American-born singer-songwriter since 2006's The Drift was recorded over three years.
The second full-length release for the Dutch quartet was recorded over three weeks and was self-produced.
Originally released in the UK in February 2011 with the title Treefight for Sunlight, this is the debut album from the Danish quartet.
The fourth album for the R&B singer features Fabolous, Lil Wayne, and Trey Songz as a guest artists.
This self-titled effort marks the full-length debut for the Brooklyn-based shoegazers.
The third full-length release for the North Carolina trio features guest appearances from Amy Ray, Angel Olsen, and Mirah Zeitllyn.

recordname: Let's Cry and Do Pushups at the Same Time
description: This is the second full-length release for Brooklyn producer Luke Wyatt as Torn Hawk.
This is the seventh album for the Swedish progressive metal band.
The fourth album for the indie-rock duo from North Carolina.
The sixth full-length release for the Grammy-nominated hard rock quartet was produced by Nick Raskulinecz.
The ninth full-length studio release for the Arizona-based rock band led by Joey Burns and John Convertino was recorded in California and was co-produced with Craig Schumacher.
The second full-length album for Stephen Wilkinson is his first on Warp records.
The three tracks from the collaboration between Sunn O))) and Ulver was recorded over one night in 2008.
The 11th full-length studio release for the indie rock band was produced with BJ Burton.
The second full-length release for the London-based trio of Joshua Idehen, Shanaz Dorsett and Tom Leaper was inspired by the London nightclub scene.

The debut full-length solo release for the former Fifth Harmony member features contributions from such artists as Shawn Mendes, Machine Gun Kelly, Pitbull, Skrillex, Ryan Tedder, Pharrell Williams, and Young Thug.
The second full-length release for the British rock trio was self-produced and mixed with Adam Lasus.
A man sent to die in the desert is the concept behind the seventh full-length release from the Atlanta progressive metal band that was produced by Brendan O'Brien.
With influences of psychedelic and Krautrock, the debut full-length release for the Canadian trio that includes former members of DD/MM/YYYY was produced by Mike Haliechuk.
The ninth studio release for the Philadelphia psychedelic rock band led by Michael and John Gibbons is five tracks long.
The 15th release for Steve Earle is the first to feature his band, The Dukes, and includes three songs written for the HBO series Treme.
The first album on new major label Universal Republic for the Los Angeles-based soul singer includes a guest appearance by Snoop Dogg.
This is the Northern Ireland artist's fourth album under the name Boxcutter.
Elvis Costello and the Imposters recorded and mixed the album in a week.
The southern rockers have no overarching concept this time out, but they still boast three singers and guitarists in Patterson Hood, Mike Cooley and Jason Isbell.
This is the full-length debut for the Seattle band (featuring members of the now defunct Carissa's Wierd) that has drawn comparisons to, among others, Neil Young.
The Australian-based band is back with their first album since 1993.
Produced by David Barbe, the 10th studio release for the alt-country band features six songs written by Mike Cooley and takes over the microphone for one track.
The 13th full-length studio release for the Los Angeles punk rock band was produced by Cameron Webb.
The Swedish foursome release a third album of experimental electro-pop.
The latest release for the experimental guitarist is the final instrumental album in a trilogy that included 2010's Infinite Love and 2013's Dreams Say, View, Create, Shadow Leads.
Adam Pierce's fifth Mice Parade album adds a greatly increased vocal presence (by Pierce, Ikuko Harada and Mum's Kristin Anna Valtysdottir) to his tropicalia-infused post-rock.

recordname: Let the Dancers Inherit the Party
description: The latest full-length studio release for the British indie rock band was produced by Cam Blackwood.

recordname: Under Branch and Thorn and Tree
description: The fourth full-length release for the singer-songwriter was produced by John Vanderslice.

recordname: Fuck Off Get Free We Pour Light on Everything
recordauthor: Thee Silver Mt. Zion Memorial Orchestra
description: The seventh full-length release for the often described Canadian post-rock five piece band includes influences from blues, garage, and metal music.
Recorded over three performances at the Music Hall of Williamsburg in April 2009 in Brooklyn, New York, it is the Scottish rock group's first live album/DVD release.

The third full-length release for the Canadian singer-songwriter was recorded in Toronto with a band that included Gary Craig, Bazil Donovan, Robbie Grunwald, Garth Hudson, Emmett Kelly, and Mary Margaret O'Hara.
The latest release for the produced by experimental group formed by Jamie Stewart was produced by John Congleton, Greg Saunier of Deerhoof and the band's Angela Seo.
The seventh full-length release for the indie rock band led by Jim James was recorded near Stinson Beach, California with Tucker Martine.
The New York band releases its latest EP, written during the Fever To Tell tour.
The debut full-length release from Winston Yellen was written and recorded in a rented Nashville house previously owned by Johnny Cash and June Carter.
Written and produced together for the first time, the latest release for the group that features influences of jazz, R&B, hip-hop and pop was recorded in New Orleans.
The sales of the digital version of the band's latest album will be donated to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and the Joy Fund.
The British indie rock band collaborate with Bubbley Kaur to create a Punjabi folk-tinged new album.
The live album features recording from the duo's summer tour of Canada in 2007 which was also filmed for a documentary of the same name.
The third full-length release for the psych-rock band led by Ruben Nielson includes contributions from his brother Cody and his father Chris.
This is the second full-length studio release for the indie-pop project of Greta Kline.
The sixth full-length release fro the Canadian indie artist was self-produced.
The latest full-length release for the folk-rock band led by MC Taylor was produced with Brad Cook.
The third full-length release for the Canadian noise rock trio of Alex Edkins, Chris Slorach and Hayden Menzies was produced by Steve Albini.
The fourth full-length release for the British rock band is its first with new drummer Tommy Davidson was produced by Ross Orton.

Buddy Miller invited such artists as Brandi Carlile, Shawn Colvin, Kris Kristofferson, The Lone Bellow, Kacey Musgraves, Lucinda Williams, and Lee Ann Womack on the annual Cayamo Festival Cruise to perform and record their performances.
The debut full-length release for the British R&B singer Kwabena Sarkodee Adjepong features production from SOHN and Dave Okumu.
The latest release for the Scottish flamenco-influenced guitarist was produced by Paul Savage.
The fourth album for the Norwegian experimentalist features Erik Vister as a guest performer.
The debut album for the British folk singer was produced by Mike Lindsay of Tunng.
The second album for the British singer includes darker-themed songs influenced by the death of her husband.
The Brooklyn-based band releases another noise-rock album, this time featuring a slightly more pop sound than previous proto-punk efforts.
The debut full-length solo release for the ex-member of Dirty Projectors was produced partly by David Longstreth.

recordname: You, Whom I Have Always Hated/Released from Love
description: The collaboration between the heavy metal bands The Body and Thou includes the previously vinyl-only four-track EP release with six additional tracks recorded during their tour in July 2014.
This is the debut full-length release for Milwaukee-based grime producer Peter Runge.
Scotland's Pastels and Japan's Tenniscoats release their first album together, which was recorded over a three year period while the bands were touring.
The second full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was produced by Ben Hiller.
The indie rock trio led by Low guitarist Alan Sparhawk releases its second album.
The second full-length release for the Chicago metal band was recorded by Matt Russell.
The 21st studio release for the British metal band led by Lemmy Kilmister was produced by Cameron Webb.
Keyboardist Katie Lee left the band before the completion of the Canadian trio's mostly guitar-less second full-length release.
The Massachusetts trio releases a second EP to follow-up its first release, "Sun Bronzed Greek Gods" with more indie-pop and synth-heavy songs.
This is the second album for the Brooklyn- (formerly Ohio-) based indie rockers fronted by singer Matt Berninger.
This sophomore effort for the former Whiskeytown member was, like her acclaimed 2002 debut, produced by Chris Stamey. Mary Chapin Carpenter and Mitch Easter are among numerous guests on the album.
This third album for the Jersey City rockers (who come across a bit like an emo Tenacious D) was produced by Steve Albini.
Kathleen Hanna (also of Bikini Kill) returns for her second album with Le Tigre, the follow-up to the band's well-received 1999 debut.
"Money" Mark Nishita has worked with the Dust Brothers and the Beastie Boys. This is his third album and first for Emperor Norton.
This is the smash-hit debut album from 20-year-old singer-songwriter (and classically-trained pianist) Alicia Keys.
The fifth album includes contributions from Akron/Family, Bill Rieflin, Julia Kent, and Christoph Hahn.
This is the debut full-length release for the London-based electronic producer, Benjamin Stefanski.
This quick follow-up to 'Fishscale' includes production work from Pete Rock, Madlib and Hi-Tek.
This is the debut full-length release on Merge label for the Washington, D.C. band that includes Daniele Yandel of Priests and Mary Jane Regalado of Downtown Boys.
The fourth full-length release for the pop singer-songwriter features guest appearances from ASAP Rocky, Sean Ono Lennon, Stevie Nicks, Playboi Carti, and The Weeknd.
The third full-length release for the Philadelphia shoegaze band led by Domenic Palermo was produced by John Agnello.
The fourth release for Ahmed Gallab expands his African-influenced soul sound with aspects of country, pop, and reggae music.
The debut full-length release for the Austin duo of Adrian Quesada and Eric Burton who were named Best New Band at the 2019 Austin Music Awards.
The debut mini-album for the North Carolina producer features guest appearances from DJ Earl, DJ Taye, Feloneezy, Jackie Dagger, Keiska, Nangdo and Tielsie.
The 17th full-length studio release for the indie folk band led by John Darnielle was produced by Owen Pallett.
The fifth full-length release for the Ohio indie rock band was produced by John Congleton.
The 10th album for the Los Angeles artist was produced by Brian "Danger Mouse" Burton.
The fourth album for the British rock band was co-produced with Dan Austin and John Leckie.

Mario Caldato Jr. (Beastie Boys) produced the Furries' follow-up to 2003's "Phantom Power," which sees all of the band members (rather than just Gruff Rhys) taking turns at writing and singing. There are no Welsh songs this time out, although there is one in Portugese.
The debut full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from Kendrick Lamar, Travis Scott and Don Toliver

recordname: Temporary High in the Violet Skies
description: The third full-length studio release for the Los Angeles-based R&B artist features guest appearances from James Fauntleroy and Tyler, The Creator.
The ninth full-length studio release for the Memphis alt-country band was recorded live in studio with Matt Ross-Sprang.
The 23rd full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter feature Carlene Carter (daughter of June Carter Cash) and a track with Martina McBride.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Irish singer-songwriter features some songs from the same recording sessions as her 2015's Hairless Toys.
The latest release for the musical humorist "Weird Al" Yankovic features parodies of songs sung by Iggy Azalea, Imagine Dragons, Lorde, Robin Thicke, and Pharrell Williams.
The debut full-length release for the Philadelphia band led by Domenic Palermo was produced by Jeff Zeigler.
This is the debut album for the indie rock band led by former Broken West member Ross Flournoy.
The second self-titled album for the Canadian duo was recorded in a variety of places, including a garage in Detroit, a church in Iceland, a cabin in Canada, and a real music studio in London.

recordname: I Know You're Married But I've Got Feelings Too
description: The sophomore album for the sister of Rufus Wainwright includes a track written by Annie Lennox and Dave Stewart.

recordname: In the Shape of a Storm
description: The latest release for the now Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter was recorded in two hours with only "occasional accompaniment from Josh Gordon."
The third full-length release for the Canadian band led by Nigel Chapman was recorded and mixed by Howard Bilerman and Mike Wright.

recordname: For the Sake of Bethel Woods
description: The fifth full-length studio release for Texas folk rock band Midlake was produced by John Congleton.

The second full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from 24hrs, Future, Lauren Jauregui, Tory Lanez, Swae Lee, Lil Wayne, MadeinTYO, Damian Marley, Skrillex, The-Dream, Pharrell Williams and Wiz Khalifa.
The third full-length for indie singer-songwriter Mirah Yom Tov Zeitlyn was recorded with Calvin Johnson and Phil Elverum (The Microphones).

The third album for Damon Albarn and Jamie Hewlett animated group features guest appearances by Snoop Dogg, Kano, Mos Def, De La Soul, Gruff Rhys, Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, The Fall's Mark E. Smith, Little Dragon, Lou Reed, Bobby Womack, The Clash's Mick Jones, and Paul Simonon.
Produced by Salim Nourallah, the 11th release for the alt-country band led by Rhett Miller features guest appearances from Tommy Stinson and Jon Rauhouse.
The fifth studio album from Kelis features producers David Guetta and Benny Benassi, bringing dance and techno tidbits within her soulful R&B mix.
The singer-songwriter's debut is informed by the losses of his father (actor Anthony Perkins) to AIDS and of his mother (photographer Berry Berenson) in the 9/11 attacks.
The second full-length release for the London-based electronic duo from Belfast features guest appearances from Julia Kent, Clara La San and machìna.
The second full-length release for the Spanish indie rock band was was co-produced with Gordon Raphael.
Britt Daniel of Spoon, Dan Boeckner of Wolf Parade, and Sam Brown of the New Bomb Turks releases their debut album as the Divine Fits.
The debut full-length release for the British indie artist Archy Marshall as King Krule was produced with Rodaidh McDonald.

recordauthor: The Good, the Bad & the Queen
description: The second full-length release for the supergroup that includes Damon Albarn, Paul Simonon, Simon Tong and Tony Allen was influenced by the Brexit vote.
The ninth full-length release for the Minneapolis alt-country band was co-produced by R.E.M guitarist Peter Buck and Tucker Martine.
This is the second full-length release from the British electronic artist-producer David Corney.
The fourth album for the indie-rock band was mixed by John O'Mahony.
The fifth full-length release for the New Jersey indie rock band features a guest appearance from Sylvan Esso.
The latest full-length solo release from Dap-Kings saxophonist Cochemea Gastelum features influences from North Africa, India and Mexico.
Mark Kozelek goes acoustic with just his guitar on his fourth album under the name Sun Kil Moon.

One of two concept albums released on the same day for the hip-hop duo of Ishmael Butler and Tendai "Baba" Maraire about a being from another world named Quazars was recorded in Los Angeles with producer Sunny Levine (grandson of Quincy Jones).

recordname: Ancient Dreams in a Modern Land
description: The fifth full-length release for the Welsh pop artist who previously went by the name Marina and the Diamonds features production with Jennifer Decilveo and James Flannigan.
This is the debut full-length collaboration between Matthew E. White and Lonnie Holley.
Once again produced with Dave Fridmann, the latest release for the rock band led by Wayne Coyne is darker than previous works.
The latest solo release from the 60-year old British singer-songwriter was produced by Paul Noble.
The debut album for the Montreal band was mixed by Sune Rose Wagner of The Raveonettes.
'Black Gold' marks the first (and likely only) full-length release for the new project from former Beta Band frontman Steve Mason.
Brothers Ron and Russell Mael's first album in four years is their 20th LP overall.
This is the debut full-length release for the Canadian quartet that includes members of the band Women.
The third release for the Welsh singer was produced by Noah Georgeson and recorded in Los Angeles.
The 14th solo studio release for the rock singer-songwriter was self-produced.
The first album in over 22 years for the Australian rock band led by Simon Bonney was recorded in Detroit and co-produced with Dave Feeny.

The third full-length release for Brooklyn experimental artist was self-produced and features contributions from Mas Ysa's Thomas Arsenault, Dutch cellist Maarten Vos and percussionist, Jamie Ingalls.

recordname: Lily We Need to Talk Now
description: The debut full-length solo release for the Palberta band member was produced by Nate Amos.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Portland-based psychedelic rock duo of Ripley Johnson and Sanae Yamada was mixed by Sonic Boom.
The 12th full-length release for the orchestral pop band led by Neil Hannon was recorded in London and Ireland.
The 5th LP from the L.A.-based psych-rock band is a 15-song double-album.
The third full-length release for the North Carolina folk singer-songwriter was self-produced and mixed by Jason Meagher.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Norwegian group led by Jørgen Munkeby was mixed by Sean Beavan.
The fifth full-length release for the Scottish folk rock band was influenced by Greek tragedies, psychedelia, early-70s prog and rock music.
The second full-length release for the Canadian band led by Dean Tzenos was produced by Colin Stewart.
The double-disc release for the former Dire Straits leader was co-produced with Guy Fletcher and Chuck Ainlay.

recordname: The Raven That Refused to Sing and Other Stories
description: Co-produced with Alan Parsons, the third solo release from Steven Wilson was based on short stories the Porcupine Tree singer/guitarist wrote or co-wrote with Hajo Mueller.
The seventh studio album for the alternative rock band sees the return of their first producer Steve Lillywhite, who worked on the band's first three studio albums.
The sounds of an electronic device-driven world are the influences on Ferraro's first full-length release on the Hippos in Tanks label.
This is the first album on the Jagjaguwar label for the British rock quartet.
The fifth album for the trio from New York was produced by John Goodmanson.
This mini-album marks the debut for the New York-based all-female hip-hop trio (think "Beastie Girls" and you won't be too far off).
This is the latest challenging release for Sole, one of the founders of the anticon collective of underground hip-hop artists.
The aptly named 'Three' is the third solo release for graphic artist/Sea And Cake guitarist Archer Prewitt.
The Sunshine Fix is a 60s-themed side project for Olivia Tremor Control's Bill Doss.

After the breakup of Olivia Tremor Control, Will Hart went on to form Circulatory System along with fellow musicians from that group as well as others, such as Jeff Magnum (Neutral Milk Hotel). This is their debut release.
The first new release in 12 years from the influential Australian band features founding members Robert Forster and Grant McLennan with backing from members of Sleater-Kinney.
The first solo release for the former Rilo Kiley frontwoman in six years was produced by Ryan Adams and Mike Viola.
The Sonic Youth singer releases his first solo album since 1995 on his own label.
Hey Venus! is the Welsh band's follow-up to Love Kraft.
Produced by Jack Frost, the latest release from the singer-songwriter features cover songs written by such artists as Harold Arlen, Sammy Cahn, Carolyn Leigh and Johnny Mercer.
The latest album for the soul singer was produced by Jeff Silverman and Leon Michels.
The 13th studio release for the singer-songwriter was self-produced.
The first full-length non-collaborative release for the Chicago experimental electronic trio in three years.

Howie Beck produced this latest studio outing for the Toronto singer-songwriter, who is also a member of Broken Social Scene. Many members of that band guest on this record, including Emily Haines and Kevin Drew.
The second full-length release for the British duo of Ebony Hoorn and Ellery James Roberts was produced by John Congleton.
Originally set to be released in 2012, the debut full-length studio album from the New York rapper surfaces as a digital release.
The third full-length release for the new York rapper was producer by Jonwayne and is his first on the Stones Throw label.
Atlanta rapper Tip Harris (who also stars in the current theatrical release "ATL") returns with a fourth album, which finds him joined by Young Jeezy, Jamie Foxx, Pharrell, and Common.
The third full-length release for the British trio features production from Charlie Andrew, Everton Nelson, George FitzGerald, and Steve Mac.
The 10th full-length studio release for the North Carolina metal band sees the return of singer/guitarist Pepper Keenan and was produced by John Custer.
This is the second album from the ex-Menomena band member Brent Knopf as Ramona Falls.
The live album was recorded during Richard Thompson's tour of the West Coast in February, with a majority of the tracks from performances at San Francisco's Great American Music Hall.
The fifth full-length release for the indie rock band led by Nathan Williams was produced by Woody Jackson.
Sun Araw and M. Geddes Gengras who traveled to Jamaica to work with The Congos on the ninth entry in RVNG Intl.s FRKWYS series.
The New York folk-rock quintet drop their eighth album of roots rock and Americana, tinged with a country sound that combines the use of electronic-based instrumentation.
This is the fifth album for the New York City rock band led by Tim Harrington.
The third full-length release for the hip hop artist/actor Donald Glover features influences of funk and soul music.
This is the second full-length release for British electronic artist Michael Greene.
This is the debut full-length release for Bristol-based electronic producer, Sebastian Gainsborough.
Originally intended as the last album for the Japanese experimental metal band, but they came out of the recording studio with three albums worth of material.

'Valende' is the third album overall and American debut for the Italian psychedelic rock band Jennifer Gentle. (Note that there is nobody in the band actually named Jennifer, and we are unsure about exactly how gentle they are.)

The third full-length release for the rock artist was produced with Dan Molad and features contributions from Nicole Atkins, Holly Laessig & Jess Wolfe of Lucius, Jack Lawrence, Aaron Lee Tasjan, and Butch Walker.
The Benin group who first gained fame in the 1970s releases its first studio album in more than 20 years.
The eighth full-length release for the garage rock artist was produced with F Bermudez.

recordname: This Is For The White In Your Eye
description: This is the debut full-length album for the Danish group.
Singer/guitarist Bill Janovitz had dismissed ideas of a reunion over the years, but Buffalo Tom is back with their new album since 1998.
Produced by Dave Cobb, the first release of new songs in 13 years for the singer-songwriter features contributions from such artists as Dan Auerbach, Brandi Carlile, Jason Isbell, and Amanda Shires.
The second full-length release for the British all-female punk/riot grrrl band was produced and mixed by Tarek Musa.
The 10th full-length studio release for the alternative rock quartet was produced by band guitarist, Jade Puget, with co-production by Matt Hyde.
This is the debut full-length release for the trio formed by Thalia Zedek, Jason Sidney, and Gavin McCarthy.
The 14th full-length release for the Canadian singer-songwriter was produced by Jim Scott.
This is the second solo release for the Boo Radleys' guitarist/songwriter under his real name.
The tenth studio release for the Los Angeles singer-songwriter was inspired by the pop music of the 1960s and 70s.
The third full-length studio release for the British garage rock band was produced by Jim Sclavunos.
The debut solo release for the Crooked Still singer-songwriter was produced by Tucker Martine.
Dance producer Matt Cutler's latest album as Lone features two tracks with vocals.
The fourth solo acoustic album for the guitarist was recorded in his apartment.
The fourth album for the quartet comprising Sunn0))'s Stephen O'Malley, Ulver's Daniel O'Sullivan, Kristoffer Rygg, and Steve Noble was recorded in Oslo, Norway.
The fourth album for the British singer was produced by Liam Watson.
This politically-charged effort is the veteran country-folk artist's first album in three years.
Rob Cavallo coproduced two tracks on the fifth solo album for the ex-Fleetwood Mac guitarist.
The two-disc album compiles live and unreleased tracks from the Ben Chasny-led band.
The eighth full-length release for the now solo project of David Longstreth was influenced by his breakup with former bandmate Amber Coffman.
The fourth album for the rock band is the first with its new guitarist, Matthew Fazzi (Fred Mascherino left to pursue a solo career.)
The Grammy-winning neo-soul singer's follow-up to 'Get Lifted' was produced by Kanye West, will.i.am and Raphael Saadiq.
The seventh full-length studio release for the R&B artist features guest appearances from Snoh Aalegra, Diamond Platnumz, Khalid, Miguel, Sampha, Jill Scott, and Tierra Whack.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Canadian alt-country singer-songwriter was inspired by spaghetti western and was produced by Skylar Wilson.
This is the debut full-length release for the London-based artist who previously performed under the name Throwing Shade.
The second full-length release for the Indiana singer-songwriter features contributions from guitarist Laur Joamets and Wilco's Ken Coomer, who also produced the album.
This is the debut full-length release for the Canadian-based punk band led by Drew Thomson.
This is the debut full-length folk-influenced electronic release from the North Carolina duo of Mountain Men's Amelia Meath and Megafaun's Nick Sanborn.
This is the first album in four years for the folk band led by Dawn McCarthy.
This is the debut album for the side project of the Artic Monkeys' Alex Turner and The Rascals' Miles Kane.
The second full-length release for the Australian band led by ex-The Drones members Gareth Liddiard and Fiona Kitschin was recorded and mixed by Mike Deslandes.
The sophomore album for the rapper from Chicago features artist such as Snoop Dogg, Pooh Bear and Unkle.
Dawn McCarthy and Bonnie "Prince" Billy collaborated on this tribute release of songs by The Everly Brothers.

The debut album for the Washington, D.C. rapper features Lady Gaga, Pharrell, Bun B., Chrisette Michele, K'naan, Marsha Ambrosius, J.Cole, Melanie Fiona, Gucci Mane, Jazmine Sullivan, and Weensey as guest artists.
The debut full-length release for the British rock duo of Mike Kerr and Ben Thatcher was produced with Tom Dalgety.

Neil Hannon returns with a follow-up to 2000's 'Gin Soaked Boy.' A bit of a departure, this album utilizes Radiohead producer Nigel Godrich and a larger group of musicians to highlight a more serious side to Hannon's music.

recordname: The Lonely, The Lonesome & The Gone
description: The ninth full-length studio release for the country singer-songwriter was produced by her husband, Frank Liddell.

Chrissie Hynde returns after an eight year absence as the Pretenders backed by Dave Roe, Russ Pahl, Kenny Vaughan, Leon Michels, and Richard Swift on this release recorded with the Black Keys' Dan Auerbach.
The second full-length release for the Russian five-piece was recorded in less than five days.
The string quartet worked with National guitarist Bryce Dessner, who composed the four tracks.
The debut full-length release for Ryan Hunn as Illum Sphere features guest appearances from such artists as Shigeto, Shadowbox, and Mai Nestor of Facit.

recordname: Blood Oaths of the New Blues
description: The second release on Fire Records for James Jackson Toth under the Wooden Wand name sees the singer-songwriter working with a band that includes David Hickox, Janet Elizabeth Simpson, Jody Nelson, Brad Davis, and Les Nuby III.
This is the debut album for the northern England band that shares members with Futureheads and Maximo Park.
One of the four releases on the same day for Arca's KICK anthology features a guest appearance from Ryuichi Sakamoto.
The latest full-length release for the Ohio singer-songwriter was recorded in Chicago with producer Tom Schick.
The debut full-length release for King Britt as Fhloston Paradigm combines electronic music with science fiction movie soundtrack elements.
Swedish saxophonist Mats Gustafsson joined the last collaboration of Steve Reid and Kieran Hebden of Four Tet on this final album from Reid, who died in April 2010.
The New York-based rapper known for his complex rhyming ability and lyrical social commentary releases his third studio album on Duck Down Records.
The husband-and-wife Swedish duo's third album was recorded with an Icelandic choir.
Stephin Merritt's soundtrack to the film "Pieces of April" includes previously released tracks from his bands The 6ths and Magnetic Fields, as well as four brand new songs from the latter.

recordname: Who Will Cut Our Hair When We're Gone?
description: This is the second album for the lo-fi indie-pop trio based in Montreal, Canada.

recordname: A Mark, A Mission, A Brand, A Scar
description: This is the fourth album for the Florida-based emo band led by Christopher Carraba.

The Los Angeles-based indie-rock band led by Blair Shehan (formerly of Knapsack) makes its long-awaited full-length debut after several years of touring with bands ranging from Death Cab For Cutie to the Foo Fighters.
Nominated for Britain's Mercury Music Prize for his 2001 debut 'Here Be Monsters,' DIYer Ed Harcourt returns with his second studio recording.

Forget the Chemical Brothers; British producer/DJs Dan and John Kahuna really are brothers, and this, their debut LP, plays like a tour of electronica, venturing from electro to disco to acid to downtempo.
This is the third album for the San Francisco band featuring drummer Lynn Perko and former Faith No More keyboardist Roddy Bottum.
Although Los Angeles-based rappers Jurassic 5 formed in 1995, 2000's "Quality Control" is their first full-length release.

recordname: Original Motion Picture Score for The Virgin Suicides
description: The soundtrack to Sofia Coppola's film features instrumental tracks from Air, as well as the single "Playground Love," featuring vocals from Gordon Tracks.
Such orchestral instruments as the bassoon, cello, clarinet, trumpet, and violin are featured on the second album from Oklahoma indie rock band Other Lives, previously known as Kunek.
The second full-length release for the Seattle-based indie rock band was recorded in a Southern California surf shop and produced by Ty Segall.

The latest release for the Scandinavian free jazz trio of baritone saxophonist Mats Gustafsson, bassist Ingebrigt Håker Flaten, and drummer Paal Nilssen-Love includes three originals and two jazz standards.
The latest album for Daniel Dumile, who dropped MF from his name and now goes by Doom.
The third full-length release from the Irish singer-songwriter features production from Nineteen85, Two Inch Punch, and Frank Dukes.
The fourth full-length release for Los Angeles indie pop duo Girlpool was produced by Yves Rothman.
The debut full-length solo release for the Superchunk frontman under his own name features influences from 1980s music.
The Swedish death metal band releases its first studio album since 1995's Slaughter Of The Soul.
This is the third full-length Latin electronic pop release from Roberto Carlos Lange as Helado Negro.

recordname: Have You Lost Your Mind Yet?
description: The latest full-length release for the two-time Grammy winner was inspired by socially and politically-aware albums from 1960s-70s.
The eighth full-length release for the Australian psychedelic rock band was produced with Tame Impala's Kevin Parker
