The debut release from the psychedelic rock band led by Harvey W. Bassett (aka DJ Harvey) with three members of Orgone: Dan Hastie, Ethan Phillips, and Sergio Rios.
This is the debut Irish folk-influenced release for the collaboration from Martin Hayes, Thomas Bartlett aka Doveman, Iarla Ó Lionaird, Dennis Cahill and Caoimhín Ó Raghallaigh.
The Italian metal trio's sixth album is part one of a planned two-part epic (Oro: Opus Alter is due in September, 2012).
The British guitarist releases his first solo album since 1998's Traveller's Prayer.
The two-disc collection of live shows and radio recordings covers the years of 1994 to 2004.
The 15th full-length release for the New Jersey indie rock trio is its first featuring new songs since 2013's Fade.
The fourth full-length release for the Nashville-based singer-songwriter was recorded in Brooklyn and is her first on the Merge label.
This is the full-length debut release for the Brooklyn industrial rock duo of Rick Daniel and Noah Kardos-Fein.
The husband-and-wife duo of Carl Hultgren and Windy Weber release their eighth album that began as a solo album by Carl to be a Valentine's Day present to Windy.
Modeselektor and Apparat team up to release their first full-lenth album together.
The second full-length release for the Washington, D.C. alternative rock trio was produced by Jonah Takagi and mixed by Collin Dupuis.

The seventh solo album from the singer-songwriter was produced by Mark Ronson and features Nels Cline of Wilco; The Dap-Kings; Sean Lennon, Martha Wainwright; Andrew Wyatt from Miike Snow; and Nick Zinner of Yeah Yeah Yeahs as guest musicians.
The eighth full-length release for the rock band led by Jim James features 10 tracks from the same recording sessions as 2015's The Waterfall.
The debut full-length release for the Brooklyn-based singer-songwriter was mixed by Shawn Everett.

Nick Launay produced this sophomore set for the New Zealand band led by Finn Andrews, who has drawn numerous Nick Cave comparisons. Aside from Andrews, it's a completely different lineup than the one that recorded 'Runaway Found.'
Victor Van Vugt (Nick Cave, Beth Orton, PJ Harvey) produced this debut disc for the Glaswegian band.
The fifth full-length studio release for the New Orleans hardcore band is the final album with drummer Joey LaCaze, who passed away in August of 2013.
Nashville's country-rocker releases his third studio album.
The fifth full-length release for the British indie pop band was co-produced by Brendan Williams and Phil Bulleyment.
The debut full-length release for the folk-rock sisters Emily, Jessica, and Camilla Staveley-Taylor was produced by the father-and-son team of Glyn and Ethan Johns.
This is the 13th studio release for the electronic duo of of Alex Paterson and Thomas Fehlmann.
The holiday album from the R&B singer was produced by Raphael Saadiq feature guest appearances from Esperanza Spalding and Stevie Wonder.
The six-track project is the third and final part of a planned trilogy of EPs for Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross.
The latest solo release for the Minnesota-based singer-songwriter was produced with Jacob Hanson.
The debut album from the country-folk artist takes the unadorned simplicity of acoustic guitar and emotional vocals to create bittersweet songs of love, hate and life.
Taking his sound back to Motown, the R&B hit maker tones down his controversial image, releasing classic love songs inspired by '50s and '60s slow jams.
The LA-based indie band's album continues its excursion into experimental rock infused with psychedelic soundscapes and dreamy, melodic vocals.
The 15th full-length studio release for the Australian psychedelic rock band features heavy metal influences.
The latest album from the Scottish singer-songwriter features his drummer from Appendix Out.
The fifth full-length solo release for the British progressive pop artist features guest appearances from Sophie Hunger and Ninet Tayeb.
The latest album for the punk rock band features guest artists from such bands as Cave In, Genghis Tron, Neurosis, and Hatebreed.

recordname: The Man with the Iron Fists [OST]
description: The Wu Tang's RZA releases a soundtrack to his martial arts film of the same name featuring tracks by such artists as The Black Keys, Ghostface Killah, Freddie Gibbs, Method Man, Pharoahe Monch, Kanye West, and Wiz Khalifa.
Ryuichi Sakamoto worked with Alva Noto, and Bryce Dessner on the soundtrack of Alejandro G. Iñárritu's 2015 film starring Leonardo DiCaprio.
This is the second album for the garage-psych outfit led by Greg Ashley.
The debut full-length release for the New York singer-songwriter was recorded with producers Caleb Hinz, Hippo Campus' Jake Luppen and Nathan Stocker.
The debut full-length studio release from the New York rapper Destiny Frasqueri features remastered tracks from her 2016 mixtape and eight new tracks.
The second release for the Swedish singer has already nominated for Swedish Grammys and a Nordic Music Prize.
Flogging Molly's Ted Hutt returns to produce the eighth studio release for the Boston punk rock band.

George Drakoulias produced this sophomore release for the singer-songwriter, who garnered praise for her 2002 debut 'Bramble Rose.' Here, she adds some Muscle Shoals-style soul to her roots and country repertoire.
The veteran New York band, again operating as a five-piece (with Jim O'Rourke still in the group), return with a successor to one of their best albums in recent memory, 2002's 'Murray Street.'
The trio worked with producer Dave Eringa (Ash, Manic Street Preachers, Kylie Minogue) for this sophomore release.

21-year old Rjyan Kidwell seems to have all the bases covered on his latest full-length, which might be considered your typical glitchtronica-indie-folk-hip-hop-emo-electro-party jam, if it weren't for the fact that there is absolutely nothing typical about it at all.

Not the true follow-up to 'Toxicity' that fans were hoping for, 'Steal This Album' instead consists of outtakes from that 2001 album, originally leaked on the Internet in rough versions and now polished up for release on CD.

recordname: Lifted or The Story Is in the Soil, Keep Your Ear to the Ground
description: Prolific 22-year-old Nebraska singer-songwriter Connor Oberst returns to his Bright Eyes guise for this 13-track effort, following a stint fronting the band Desaparecidos.
The 54-year-old singer-songwriter returns with his first album of new material since 1997's Grammy-winning 'Hourglass.' Russ Titleman produces.

recordname: Take Care, Take Care, Take Care
description: The Austin, Texas quartet release their sixth studio album of experimental post-rock.
The second album for Sleigh Bells sees the Brooklyn-based indie duo adding more pop and guitar elements to their sound.

The typically eclectic guest lineup on Bjork's first studio album in three years includes Timbaland, a ten-piece all-female horn section, and members of Konono No. 1, Lightning Bolt, Antony & The Johnsons, and LFO.
The latest full-length solo release for the country artist features guest appearances from his sons Lukas and Micah Nelson.
The San Francisco-based group takes its eccentric, innovative music making to the next level on its new album, creating solid rock that is as much noisy as it is melodic.
The 15th solo album for the California singer was self-produced and written with his son, Joachim Cooder.
This is the first album in four years for the Dayton, Ohio indie rock band fronted by Dave Doughman.
The five-track third full-length release for the Chicago-based psychedelic rock band includes a nearly 12-minute song.
Steve Albini produced album #2 for the Chicago post-punk outfit.

This eagerly-awaited second LP for the heralded/hyped New York five-piece was produced by Gordon Raphael (who also produced their debut 'Is This It?') after aborted sessions working with Radiohead producer Nigel Godrich.
The third full-length release for French artist Melody's Echo Chamber was produced by Dungen's Reine Fiske and The Amazing's Fredrik Swahn.
The fourth full-length release for the singer-songwriter was written in less than a month in 2018 after visiting her parents in Hong Kong.
The second full-length release for the singer-songwriter was produced by Cowboy Junkies' Michael Timmins and recorded in five days.
The debut full-length release for the Seattle alternative rock trio was co-produced with Dylan Wall.
The major label debut full-length release for the New York rapper features guest appearances from Big Body Bes, Black Atlass, Chance the Rapper, Meyhem Lauren, and Party Supplies.
The third full-length release for the British electronic band features guest appearances from Isolde and Snow Fox.
The 26th release for the singer-songwriter was produced by David Mansfield and features Aofie ODonovan as well as Loudon's daughter Martha Wainwright on backing vocals.
This is the debut full-length release from the British duo of Beck Wood and John Ridgard.
The seventh release for the Japanese experimental group was inspired by the Javanese style of gamelan.
This is the full-length debut from the Fresh and Onlys' guitarist.
One of the four releases on the same day for Arca's KICK anthology features guest appearances from Oliver Coates, Shirley Manson, No Bra, and Planningtorock.
The fifth full-length release for the singer-songwriter was produced by Steve Osborne.
The electronic music project of Paul Grossi is filled with diverse sounds and many synthesized instruments.
This is singer-songwriter's fourth full-length album with guitarist Phil Wandscher.
This is the second album for the Philadelphia-based band.
This is the second full-length release for the side project of Justin Vernon and members of Collections Of Colonies Of Bees.
The singer-songwriter recorded this strongly political (and anti-Bush) ten-song set in just two weeks earlier this year.
The collaboration between David Byrne and St. Vincent, first planned more than two years ago, was produced with John Congleton.
The fifth full-length release for the indie San Francisco duo of Logan Kroeber and Meric Long was influenced by the sudden death of guitarist Christopher Reimer in February 2012.

recordname: The Iron Gates at Throop and Newport
description: The second album for the singer-songwriter was written in Brooklyn and recorded in Nashville.
The fourth full-length release for the Swedish synthpop band includes a track co-written with Dave of De La Soul.
The debut full-length release for the British quartet led by David Bayley was self-produced by Bayley.
This is the third album for the San Francisco duo of Evan Caminiti and Jon Porras.

recordname: The Art of Pretending to Swim
description: The fourth full-length release for the solo project for the Irish singer-songwriter Conor J. O'Brien was self-produced.
The third full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was influenced by her experience living in the United States while working as a journalist the past three years.
The seventh full-length studio release for the alternative rock band was produced with Billy Bush.
The eighth full-length release for David Longstreth project features guest appearanmces from Dear Nora, Empress Of, Haim, Amber Mark, Fleet Foxes' Robin Pecknold, Rostam, and Syd of The Internet.
This is the second full-length solo release for the London-based Australian experimental artist.

recordname: Quazarz: Born on a Gangster Star
description: One of two concept albums released on the same day for the hip-hop duo of Ishmael Butler and Tendai "Baba" Maraire about a being from another world named Quazars was recorded over two weeks in Seattle with producer Erik Blood.
The eighth full-length solo release for ex-Destroyer drummer Scott Morgan was inspired by the score to the 1982 experimental film Koyaanisqatsi by Phillip Glass.
The latest solo release from the singer-songwriter was co-written and executive produced by Michael League of Snarky Puppy.
The latest solo release for the British singer-songwriter is his first non-concept album since 2009's 21st Century Man.
The first full-length studio release in four years for the anti-folk artist was produced by John Agnello.
This is the first release for British ambient electronic musician Leyland Kirby as The Stranger in five years.
Neneh Cherry worked with the Norwegian/Swedish jazz trio The Thing on this jazz-inspired album.
The first new material in 18 years for the Los Angeles alternative rock band is its first with the original line-up since 1995's Her Highness.
The Portland-based band returns with less rock and more atmospheric, orchestral arrangements with a little bit of country-folk thrown in as well.
The debut full-length release for the British industrial electronic/dancehall artist features production from Aart, DADRAS, Dre Skull, Dutch E Germ, Jam City, Nick Leon, Buddy Ross, and SOPHIE.

The first full-length studio release in a decade for the folk singer-songwriter features covers of songs by such artists as Anohni, Mary Chapin Carpenter, Tim Eriksen, Joe Henry (who also produced the album), and Josh Ritter.
The first release in eight years for the Chicago-based punk trio was co-produced with Matt Allison.

recordname: Heat Lightning Rumbles in the Distance
description: The third solo album for the Drive-By Truckers singer was based on a semi-autobiographical novel he never completed.
The second full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was self-produced with additional production from Brett Cox, James Flannigan and Jacknife Lee.
The third full-length release for the British indie rock/pop band led by Jo Bevan was self-produced.

Working with Arcade Fire's Richard Reed Parry, the second full-length release for the Canadian-based indie artist Laurel Sprengelmeyer features guest appearances from such artists as Sufjan Stevens, Sharon Van Etten, and Kyp Malone.

The collaboration between Wu-Tang Clan's Inspectah Deck, 7L, and Esoteric features guest appearances by Action Bronson, Cappadonna, Ghostface Killah, Roc Marciano, Mr. MFN eXquire, Oh No, and Vinnie Paz
The third full-length solo release for the My Morning Jacket frontman was self-produced and was inspired by a photo in the 1970s magazine, The Last Whole Earth Catalog.
The second full-length release for Damon Riddick features guest appearances from such artists as Computer Jay, Flea, Junie Morrison, Nite Jewel, Q-Tip, Snoop Dogg, Novena Carmel, and Jody Watley.
The 18th studio album from the North Carolina indie-folk trio features production by Hate Eternal frontman Erik Rutan, as well as others.
The 11th full-length studio release for the Chrissie Hynde-led rock band was produced by Stephen Street.
The latest full-length solo release for the singer-songwriter was originally part of a planned stage musical adaptation of Girl, Interrupted.
The 11th studio album for the singer includes guest appearances from Noel Gallagher and Blur's Graham Coxon.
Aaron Espinoza and Ariana Murray return with this follow-up to last year's "Mentor Tormentor."
The third full-length release for Jilian Medford indie pop project features production from Andrew Sarlo and Andy Seltzer.
The debut full-length release for the garage rock quartet from Kentucky was produced by Kevin Ratterman.
The debut full-length release for the British indie pop trio of Esme Dee Hand-Halford, Sidonie Hand-Halford, and Henry Wade was produced by Marta Salogni.

recordname: No More Lamps in the Morning
description: The singer-songwriter re-records some of her songs live with simpler backing from her husband Victor Herrero on a 12-string Portuguese guitar and cello from Gyða Valtýsdóttir.
The British poet's debut solo rap release was produced by Dan Carey.
The debut full-length release for the London-based band led by Nathan Hewitt was self-produced.

The animated band returns after a seven year absence with a studio album featuring guest appearances from Jehnny Beth, Danny Brown, Benjamin Clementine, D.R.A.M., Del La Soul, Peven Everett, Anthony Hamilton, Grace Jones, Zebra Katz, Kelela, Popcaan, Jamie Principle, Pusha T, Mavis Staples, Vince Staples, and Kali Uchis.
The debut full-length release for the electronic project from Berlin-based DJ Nomad and producer Dirk Leyers that features influences from West African music.
The debut album for the British indie rock quintet was produced By Dan Carey.
The fourth album for the British indie rock quartet runs just over 30 minutes and spans 15 tracks.
The Everything But The Girl singer's third solo album was produced by Ewan Pearson.

This six-track disc is a collaboration between Wilco frontman Jeff Tweedy, drummer Glenn Kotche, and Jim O'Rourke (known for both his acclaimed recent solo albums and work with Wilco and Sonic Youth).

The Chicago indie band's fifth album is the first in a planned trilogy, and features a bit more electronics than previous outings. Members of Tortoise guest on the album, as does Rebecca Gates from the Spinanes.

recordname: Hardcore Will Never Die, But You Will
description: The Scottish five-piece noise-rock bands latest album is a mix of distorted guitars, piano and synthesizers - minimal and with little to no vocals whatsoever.
The second full-length release for Daniel Woolhouse sees more emphasis on his vocals.

Members of TV On The Radio produced and contributed to this debut Celebration LP from Baltimore husband and wife Sean Antanaitis and Katrina Ford (joined in Celebration by drummer David Bergander), who have previously played in bands Jaks and Love Life.
The first new release in 22 years for the post-hardcore band led by Walter Schreifels was produced by Will Yip.
The seventh full-length release for producer Stephen Wilkinson as Bibio features guest appearances from Gotye, Olivier St. Louis, and Wax Stag.

Phife Dawg's posthumous release features guest appearances from Cheryl Boyce-Taylor, Darien Brockington, Busta Rhymes, Dwele, Illa J, Lyric Jones, Little Brother, Maseo of De La Soul, Renée Neufville, Pos of De La Soul, Q-Tip, Rapsody, Redman, V.Rich, and Angela Winbush.
The fourth full-length studio release for the indie rock duo of Andrew VanWyngarden and Ben Goldwasser was produced with Patrick Wimberly and Dave Fridmann.
The latest release from the indie rock band led by the prolific Robert Pollard introduces Mark Shue and Bobby Bare, Jr. to the line-up.
Following a four-track EP of the score, the Scottish post-rock instrumental band returns with a full-length soundtrack to the French zombie television series called Les Revenants.
Produced by Sheldon Gomberg, American Music Club's Mark Eitzel returns with his sixth solo album after suffering a heart attack in 2011.
The debut full-length release for the trio of DJ Adam Freeland, Steve Nalepa, and Ry X features sounds and influences from bass, field recordings, rock, and pop music.
This is the debut release from the indie group formed by David Bazan of Pedro the Lion; Will Johnson from Centro-Matic; and brothers Bubba and Matt Kadane after the death of Vic Chesnutt.
The fourth album from the deathcore metal band was produced by Mark Lewis.
Recorded in less than four days, this is the eighth full-length album released by the Seattle-based band.
Bonnie "Prince" Billy, Sonic Youth's Steve Shelley, KT Tunstall, and M. Ward appear as guests on the latest Arizona-inspired solo release from the Giant Sand founder.
The Bob Dylan covers album from the Nashville-based Australian singer-songwriter was produced by Patrick Sansone.

16 years since the last volume, Josh Homme and a new group of artists including Carla Azar, Matt Berry, Les Claypool, Billy Gibbons, Mike Kerr, Stella Mozgawa, and Jake Shears came together in Joshua Tree to record eight new songs over five days.

recordname: Step 2: A Different Kind of Human
description: The third full-length release for Norwegian electronic pop artist is the follow-up to 2018's Step 1: Infections of a Different Kind.
The fifth full-length release for the synthpop trio features a guest appearance from Debbie Harry and was produced by John Congleton.
The 16th studio release for the British rock band was produced with Tom Dalget.
Now a duo, Dan Smith and Shingai Shoniwa release their third album of music influenced by disco, jazz, pop, and soul.
The quintet's sixth album produced by Rob Schnapf is its first on the Anti label.
Tim Rutili & co. reunite with producer Brian Deck for another moody, experimental take on American roots rock.
The seventh full-length release for the Rhode Island noise rock duo of Brian Chippendale and Brian Gibson was recorded with Seth Manchester.
This compilation includes a dozen songs recorded live for BBC Radio.
The sixth solo studio album for the The Old 97's frontman features Black Prairie, Peter Buck, and Scott McCaughey.
The eighth full-length release for the Trent Reznor-led band is its first in five years was produced with Atticus Ross and Alan Moulder.
The second album for the Danish band led by Jannis Noya Makrigiannis includes influences from orchestral pop, krautrock, folk, and avant-garde music.
The third full-length release for the Kentucky rock band l;ed by Tony Esposito was produced by Jay Joyce.
The sixth full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from such artist as Blu, Bun B, Random Axe, and Pete Rock.
Barbara Streisand sings the lyrics of Alan and Marilyn Bergman, and also produced the album.
The latest album for the singer-songwriter features Allison Krauss, Ben Harper, Bill Frisell, Jon Brion, and Vic Chesnutt as guest artists.
The eighth full-length release for the Boston singer-songwriter features contributions from Dum Dum Girls' Kristin Kontrol, Mary Lattimore, Janel Leppin, Angel Olsen, and Sharon Van Etten.
This is the debut full-length release for the Australian indie pop artist.
The first release in six years for the country artist features a guest appearance from Willie Nelson.
Producer Mike Mogis helped tighten the sound on the Philadelphia quartet's fourth full-length release.
The seventh album for the Tennessee-based folk band was produced by Don Was.
'Slappers' is the second solo album for the vocalist best known for her work with Herbert.
The second full-length solo release for the Big Thief guitarist was produced by Andrew Sarlo.
The first new studio release for the duo of Jennifer Herrema and Neil Hagerty since 2000's Pound for Pound was produced by David Briggs.
The third album for the rock band from Brooklyn was produced by Gary Olson of The Ladybug Transistor.

recordname: Astral Weeks Live At The Hollywood Bowl
description: The live album features Van Morrison performing songs from his 1968 album, Astral Weeks, on November 7 and 8, 2008, at the Hollywood Bowl.
Norwegian producer Joakim Dyrdahl releases his debut album.

recordname: How Big, How Blue, How Beautiful
description: Produced by Markus Dravs, the third full-length release for the British indie rock band features contributions from Paul Epworth, Kid Harpoon and John Hill.
The 10th full-length studio release from the singer-songwriter features contributions from Blake Mills and Fiona Apple.
The debut full-length release for the masked outlaw cowboy singer-songwriter was self-produced.
Recorded in his bedroom, Trevor Powers' songs on his debut album were influenced by his personal feelings and struggles with anxiety.
The first release of new solo material in six years from the former Beatle includes production from Paul Epworth, Ethan Johns, Giles Martin (son of Beatles producer George Martin), and Marc Ronson.
The seventh full-length studio release for the New Zealand band led by Martin Phillipps was produced by Tom Healy.
The second full-length release for the Haley Fohr music project includes the Bitchin Bajas' Cooper Crain, Rob Frye, and Dan Quinlivan.
The debut full-length release for the collaboration between R.E.M.'s Peter Buck and The Auteurs' Luke Haines includes contributions from Scott McCaughey and Linda Pitmon.
The third full-length release for the Michigan/Ohio indie rock band led by Mat Kerkes was produced by Will Yip.
This is the second solo release for Fuck Buttons' Benjamin John Power.
The fourth studio release from Philadelphia-based rock band was self-recorded and produced.
The Australian psych-rock band's fourth album was recorded in two weeks at a friend's farmhouse.
The North Carolina metal band's EP is part one of a two-part concept album that will conclude in an upcoming full-length album.
'Idealism' is the full-length debut for the German electronica duo of Jens Moelle and Ismail Tuefekci.
The second album for the Norwegian singer features guest appearances by Franz Ferdinand's Alex Kapranos and Datarock's Fredrik Saroea.

In 2006, Antony Hegarty and filmmaker Charles Atlas worked on creating a performance piece exploring femininity and identity that evolved into a concert tour with an orchestra. The tour was recorded and resulted in Turning, a documentary by Charles Atlas as well as a live album of the band's performance in 2006 at London's Barbican.
The fifth full-length solo studio release for the singer-songwriter was produced by Matt Pence.
The fourth full-length release for the Seattle-based band was co-produced by Jay Som.
The first full-length collaboration between Calexico and Iron & Wine was recorded over four days in Nashville by producer Matt Ross-Spang.
This is the second LP for the Atlanta five-piece known for their experimental psyche tunes and blistering live shows.
Mixed by Converge's Kurt Ballou, the Miami doom/sludge band returns with its first release since they disbanded in 2003.

recordname: If I Could Make It Go Quiet
description: The debut full-length release for the Norwegian indie pop artist features production from FINNEAS.
The third full-length release for the Atlanta post-punk band led by Philip Frobos was recorded in a cabin in Georgia.
This is the fourth solo album for the Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter (and occasional Gilmore Girls actor) formerly of the group Grant Lee Buffalo.

Unlike Jack and Meg White, this brother-sister garage-blues duo really are brother and sister. 'Gallowsbird's Bark' marks the full-length debut for New Yorkers Eleanor and Matthew Friedberger after several years touring with the likes of Spoon, The Kills and French Kicks.
The sixth album from Mary J. Blige features guest appearances from Lenny Kravitz, Eve, and Missy Elliott and production work from The Neptunes and Dr. Dre.
The duo of Walter Becker and Donald Fagen return after a 20-year hiatus, with this Grammy-winning comeback album sounding as if they had never left.
The 11th full-length studio release for the rock band was produced with Shooter Jennings.
The debut collaboration between Daniele Luppi and Parquet Courts features vocals from Karen O and was inspired by the youth/art subculture in Milan in the 1980s.
The sixth full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter was recorded while she was six months pregnant and features a guest appearance from Sam Beam.
The latest release from Michael Collins features guest appearances from Ariel Pink, Danny James, Sheer Agony, and Weyes Blood.
The Rosebuds bandmates Ivan Howard and Kelly Crisp reunite to record an emotional album of failed love and a hopeful future.
The sophomore release for the Los Angeles indie rock quartet produced by The National's Aaron Dessner is its first without bassist Andy Hamm (who left the band in 2011).
The fourth full-length release for the Canadian art rock trio was was co-produced with Chris Walla.
The Congolese band worked with producer Batida for its fifth full-length release.
Kieran Hebden's fourth Four Tet album dispenses somewhat with the "folk" portion of his folktronica sound, resulting in a more beat-driven effort.

The fifth album from the experimental electronica duo of M. C. Schmidt and Drew Daniel (best known in the past few years as Bjork's backing "band") takes a 21st century approach to 19th century themes. Members of Radar Brothers and Acetone guest, as does pianist David Grubbs.
The British punk rock band returns with Alexisonfire's Wade Macneil on lead vocals for its third full-length album.
The sophomore album from the New York-based post-hardcore band are back with a more focused, more dynamic, melodious sound.

recordname: What We Lose In The Fire We Gain In The Flood
description: Former Georgie James band member Laura Burhenn releases her debut album produced by Richard Swift.
This is the second release from the British chamber pop trio.
The fifth solo album for the German-born artist is based on music he wrote for a 2008 Royal Ballet production.
This is the first new full-length studio release for the hard rock artist in nine years.
The sixth full-length release for the Oakland, California-based garage rock band was recorded in Nashville by producer Dan Auerbach.
The latest full-length release for the Swedish death metal band was produced and mixed by Jens Bogren.
The impact of deindustrialization on Welsh mining industry is the theme of the third full-length release from the British art-rock band.
One of two Kickstarter-funded releases [Bubblegum was also released on the same day] for the Brooklyn indie rock singer is a solo album produced by Rob Schnapf.
The full-length debut for the Brooklyn-based indie rock band was produced by Chris Zane.
This is the final release for At The Drive-In, who later split to form groups Sparta and The Mars Volta.
The second full-length release for the Norwegian quartet was produced with Marcus Forsgren.
The latest full-length release for the Canadian composer features recordings of a variety of church organs in Amsterdam, Chicago, Vancouver, Copenhagen and Los Angeles.
The debut full-length release for the hip hop duo Olu (aka Johnny Venus) and WowGr8 (aka Doctur Dot) features guest appearances from Kehlani, Malik, Arin Ray, T-Pain, and Young Thug.
The latest volume of improvisational songs from the Philadelphia alternative rock band that are usually released on limited number of CD-Rs gets a wider distribution.
The first live album for the band features 17 live tracks recorded on October 31, 2007 and a DVD about the release of "Boys ands Girls in America."
The debut full-length release for the Norwegian pop-punk band led by Haley Shea was produced by Dan Austin.
The third full-length release from the Baltimore screamo band led by Kyle Durfey was produced by Will Yip.
The singer-songwriter's third album is the first that she wrote entirely on her own and remains true to her country-pop roots that made her one of the biggest selling artists of 2009.
John Hiatt's latest album was produced by the singer-songwriter and features his daughter on two songs.
John Darnielle's fifth Mountain Goats disc in the past two years was produced by John Vanderslice.
The debut release for the British alternative quartet led by Harry Burgess was produced by Tom Howe.
Birthed from the British punk explosion, Wire's rousing experimental rock has lasted decades and continues with the release of the post-punk trio's 12th studio album.
After almost 25 years and more than 25 albums, the unstoppable Melvins have the same sludgy, Sabbath-styled post-punk heaviness that solidified their place in rock history since the early '90s.
The Danish band's second full-length album features 30 guest musicians.

Produced by Joe Henry, the final release for the New Orleans artist, who passed away in November 2015, features guest appearances from Bill Frisell, Rhiannon Giddens, Greg Leisz, Charles Lloyd, and Van Dyke Parks.
Joe Henry releases his 10th album after producing records for other artists.
Fugazi drummer Brandon Canty produced this third solo disc for ex-Helium leader Timony, who is joined here by guitarist Devin Ocampo.
The sixth full-length release for the Los Angeles-based British electronic artist features guest appearances from Innov Gnawa, Nicole Miglis, Nick Murphy, and Rhye.
The 13th studio release for Tom Petty with the Heartbreakers is said to be a return to straight up rock'n'roll and was produced by Petty, Mike Campbell, and Ryan Ulyate.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn, New York-based indie rock band was recorded with Kevin McMahon.
The indie-folk Texas band's first release in nearly three years is an experimental endeavor, full of moving piano ballads; sonic saxophone sounds; and expressive, raw vocals.
The first full-length release in five years for British electronic producer Matt Cutler under the Lone name is also his first with guest vocals.

recordname: Standing in the Doorway: Chrissie Hynde Sings Bob Dylan
description: The Bob Dylan covers album from the Pretenders founder was recorded with lead guitarist James Walbourne.

recordname: What to Look for in Summer [Live]
description: The 23-track release from the Scottish indie pop band features live tracks recorded during its 2019 world tour.
The 16th full-length release for the Australian psychedelic rock band was recorded remotely from each member's home during the COVID-19 quarantine.
The ninth full-length studio release for the Scottish indie rock band led by Fran Healey features a guest appearance from the Bangles' Susanna Hoffs.
The second full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was recorded in Chicago with producer Brian Deck and Steve Albini.
The third full-length release for the Minneapolis duo of John Pelant and Micky Alfano was produced by Spoon's Jim Eno.

The fourth full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from 21 Savage, Anuel AA, Cardi B, Drake, Ella Mai, Fabolous, Future, Jay Z, Jeremih, Kodak Black, Melii, PnB Rock, Rick Ross, Roddy Ricch and Young Thug.
The holiday album from the alt-country band features nine original songs and five yuletide classics.

The second full-length release for the music project of Melody Prochet features contributions from Pond's Nicholas Allbrook, Dungen's Reine Fiske, Gustav Ejstes, Johan Holmegard, and The Amazing's Fredrik Swahn.

recordname: Moosebumps: An Exploration Into Modern Day Horripilation
description: The follow-up to 1996's Dr. Octagonecologyst sees the return of Dan The Automator, MC Kool Keith and DJ Q-Bert as well as guest appearances from Paul Banks of Interpol and Del the Funky Homosapien.
The 18th full-length studio release for the British heavy metal band led by Rob Halford was produced by Tom Allom and Andy Sneap.
The debut full-length release for the Toronto-based trio led by Bria Salmena was self-recorded, produced and mixed.
The latest release for the Washington-state indie artist was produced by Tucker Martine.
The third full-length release for the Montreal-based folk band features a guest appearance from Lucius.
This is the debut full length release for the singer-songwriter who was the former frontwoman of the Furrs.

The eighth full-length release for the hip hop trio was funded by Kickstarter campaign and features guest appearances from 2 Chainz, Damon Albarn, David Byrne, Estelle, Justin Hawkins, Little Dragon, Roc Marciano, Pete Rock, Jill Scott, Snoop Dogg, and Usher.

The debut full-release for the trio that includes Stereolab's Tim Gane, Joe Dillworth, and synth maestro Holger Zapf, features guest appearances from Deerhunter's Bradford Cox, Spacemen 3's Sonic Boom, and Mouse on Mars' Jan St. Werner.
The second full-length release for the British post-punk trio was produced by Jamie Grier.
The fourth full-length release for the Swedish hard rock band was recorded live with Truls Mörck taking over bass duties from departing bassist Rikard Edlund.
The third full-length release for the Brooklyn dream pop duo features Woods drummer Aaron Neveu and was produced by Jarvis Taveniere.

The third full-length release for the Canadian pop singer features songs co-written by such artists as Rostam Batmanglij of Vampire Weekend, Dev Hynes, Dan Nigro of As Tall As Lions, Ariel Rechtshaid, Sia, and Peter Svensson of The Cardigans.

recordname: What a Terrible World, What a Beautiful World
description: The seventh studio release for the Oregon indie band led by Colin Meloy was produced by Tucker Martine.

Curated by Lorde (who also sings on four songs), the soundtrack to the third film of the Hunger Games franchise includes songs from Bat For Lashes, Vampire Weekend's Rostam Batmanglij, Charli XCX, The Chemical Brothers, Chvrches, Ariana Grande, Haim, Grace Jones, Duran Duran's Simon LeBon, Major Lazer, Miguel, Pusha T, Q-Tip, Raury, Stromae, Tinashe, Tove Lo, and xoV.
The fifth full-length studio release for the heavy metal band is its first since the departure of drummer Joey Jordison at the end of 2013 and the death bassist Paul Gray in 2010.
The 13th full-length release for the San Francisco singer-songwriter features contributions from Peter Buck and Bill Rieflin.
The first release in eight years for the Los Angeles blues rock artist was executive produced by Johnny Depp and Tom Waits.
The debut full-length from Finnish post-punk rock band was produced by Kurt Ballou.
Berlin-based British electronic artist Steven Warwick describes his latest release as a "cybernetic poem."

recordname: Dear Mark J. Mulcahy, I Love You
description: The fourth full-length solo release for the former Miracle Legion member is his first since 2005's In Pursuit Of Your Happiness.
This is the debut full-length release for the Montreal electronic producer Airick Woodhead as Doldrums.
The latest full-length release from the Appalachian folk band was recorded during the same sessions as its 2012's Wompyjawed EP.
The eight-track release from London-based Kevin McAuley includes influences from UK bass, dubstep, and techno music.
The second solo album for the electronic DJ/producer is his the first release in eight years.
Taylor Swift's fourth album was produced by Max Martin and features Mark Foster (Foster the People) and singer/songwriter Lori McKenna.
The British singer-songwriter's seventh album is his first on the Parlophone label.
The London-based trio continues to mix different electronic music styles on its second album.

recordname: Kitty Wells Dresses: Songs of the Queen of Country Music
description: Laura Cantrell covers songs by country music's first female star, Kitty Wells, on her fourth full-length release.
The British trio releases its first full-length album, which features the Vivian Girls on one song.
Clive Langer and Alan Winstanley return to produce the band's first album of new music since 1999.
The latest album for the producer/singer-songwriter features Marc Ribot and Jason Moran as guest musicians.
Lloyd Maines produced the Texan country trio's first album in five years.
The indie rock band started by ex-Bedhead members Matt and Bubba Kadane releases its third album.
The group featuring ex-Noise Ratchet founders releases its debut album, which was recorded in a cabin in Julian, CA.
The latest studio album for the Canadian singer-songwriter.
The latest album includes guest appearances by Constellation artists A Silver Mt. Zion, members of Godspeed You! Black Emperor, and Fugazi's Guy Picciotto.
Recorded in Nashville, the UK band's third studio album is slightly peppier and happier than past efforts (for The Clientele, anyway).
Brendan Canty produced the band's first album for their new label, Touch and Go.

recordname: You, You're A History In Rust
description: This fifth release from the adventurous Toronto-based instrumental post-rock outfit is their first album in four years.
This is the veteran post-punk band's first release in six years.
The Swedish-French indie rockers make their full-length debut with this genre-hopping disc.
The country singer-songwriter follows 'Fate's Right Hand' with an 11-song set that includes a collaboration with Emmylou Harris and John Prine on Bob Dylan's "Shelter from the Storm."
The long-lived Grammy-winning gospel-blues group's latest finds them joined by David Hidalgo and Billy Preston.

Eight years ago, Wedding Present leader David Gedge put that band on hold to pursue--at first--a more cinematic sound with his new outfit, the aptly named Cinerama. With Cinerma's sound more closely approximating the Wedding Present's in recent years, Gedge has revived the WP name (but retained the most recent Cinerama lineup) for this latest release, produced by Steve Fisk.
Portland, Oregon's The Thermals recorded this "no-fi" (otherwise known as "very, very, very lo-fi") debut album direct to four-track at the house of founding member Hutch Harris.

The R&B singer returns with a follow-up to 2000's 'The Heat' which sees her moving in more of a hip-hop direction, with production help from hitmakers Rodney Jerkins, Babyface, Irv Gotti and the Neptunes.
The Boys' eighth studio release features features Johnny Marr on guitar.

Although the 20-something New York City rockers have the names of two former Can vocalists in their moniker, their sound is more frequently compared to the MC5. 'Electric Sweat,' their second album, attracted a good deal of attention for the band from music publications in the U.S., drawing the now-mandatory Strokes comparisons.

The second full-length (not including a collection of EPs) from Britain's heralded Beta Band is just as eclectic as the band's first outing, combining pop and indie rock with touches of hip hop and electronica. The ten new tracks are highlighted by the singles "Squares" and "Broke." (And if the immodest album title reminds you of the Stone Roses' 'Second Coming,' don't worry--the comparisons end there.)

This is the third full-length and first major-label release for the low-fi duo of Lou Barlow (Sebadoh, Dinosaur Jr.) and John Davis, who earlier achieved brief commercial success with the single "Natural One" off the soundtrack to the movie "Kids."
The 12th studio release for the San Francisco alternative rock band was recorded live in guitarist Ed Rodriguez's basement and was produced by Nick Sylvester.
This is the debut full-length release for the now duo of Montreal producer Devon Welsh and Matthew Otto. [Welsh released II, a collection of songs in 2011 as a solo project.]
The second full-length solo release for the British composer features new instruments not heard on 2016's Varmints.
The third album from the bluegrass group Punch Brothers includes a cover of Radiohead's Kid A.
The fourth full-length release for the British indie pop band was produced by Brendan Williams and features guest appearance from Stealing Sheep.
The debut solo release for the former member of The Walkmen was inspired by religious/mythological ideas and his childhood living in ashrams.
The latest album for the Australian rock band is the first studio album to feature current guitarist Dan Luscombe, who replaced Rui Pereira.
The second full-length release for the Scottish synthpop trio was recorded at the band's studio in Glasgow.

The Lion King-inspired album was executive-produced by Beyoncé and features 070 Shake, Yemi Alade, Burna Boy, Busiswa, Blue Ivy Carter, Childish Gambino, Jay-Z, Kendrick Lamar, Mr. Eazi, Nija, Pharrell, Jessie Reyez, Salatiel, Moonchild Sanelly, St. Jhn, Tekno, Shatta Wale, Tierra Whack, and Wiz Kid.
The singer-songwriter returns to her jazz roots on her sixth full-length solo release that includes three cover songs.

The fourth full-length release for the British psych-pop duo of Alexander Tucker and Daniel O'Sullivan features guest appearances from This Heat's Charles Bullen and Isobel Sollenberger from Bardo Pond.
This is the third full-length release for the collaboration between Modeselektor's Gernot Bronsert, Sebastian Szary and Apparat's Sascha Ring.
This is the fourth studio album for the British folk rock singer-songwriter.
The Baltimore-based artist releases his follow-up to his 2007 album, Spiderman of the Rings.
The debut full-length release for the New York rapper features guest appearances from Jean Deaux, Jeremiah Meece, and Woodkid.
The latest full-length release for the Cleveland indie rock band led by Dylan Baldi was produced by Steve Albini.

recordname: It Was Good Until It Wasn't
description: The second full-length studio release for the R&B artist from Oakland, California features guest appearances from Jhene Aiko, James Blake, Tony Lanez, Lucky Daye, and Masego.
The Scottish post-rock band reworked a version of the soundtrack to Mark Cousins' documentary Atomic: Living in Dread and Promise for its .
This is the fifth album for the Argentinean artist.
The debut full-length album for the alternative rock artist has Spank Rock and Trouble Andrew as featured guests.
The debut full-length release for the Nashville alternative rock band led by Alicia Bognanno features re-recorded some tracks from its self-titled 2014 EP.
The 14th studio release for the singer-songwriter is said to be a return to her piano-centric alternative pop/rock sound.
The latest album for the blues artist includes Gary Moore and Jason Moran as guests.
The metal band releases its first album with Frederic Leclercq on bass.
The debut full-length studio release for the Canadian producer features guest appearances from Sinead Harnett, Kitty (formerly known as Kitty Pryde), Lofty305, Haleek Maul, and Tinashé.

The Welsh rock band's fifth album was produced by Romesh Dodangoda. It is the first full-length album since Gavin Burrough moved from bass to guitar and Richard Boucher joined the band as its new bassist.
The second full-length release for the Montreal-based rock artist was produced by Wayne Gordon.
The Latin pop band returns with its follow-up to its 2006 Grammy-winning album, "Oye."
The fifth release since the Robert Pollard-led band reformed in 2010 is its first without drummer Kevin Fennell.
The eighth solo release for the former Orange Juice frontman is his second (but first written) since he suffered a cerebral hemorrhage in 2005.
A majority of the latest release for Steve Spacek as Beat Spacek was created on iPhone and iPad apps.
Producer-songwriter Benjamin Garrett's second release as Fryras was produced with Luke Smith.
The British artist releases her debut album produced by Wayne Lotek.

recordname: A Snowflake Fell (And It Felt Like A Kiss)
description: The Scottish band's Christmas-themed album was recorded over 12 days.
This is the debut full-length release for British electronic producer Felix Clary Weatherall.

The 11th full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from A$AP Rocky, Big Sean, Chris Brown, Migos, Nicki Minaj, Monica, Rico Love, ScHoolboy Q, Slim Jxmmi, Ty Dolla $ign, The Weeknd, and Young Dolph.
The latest album from the Grammy-winning R&B singer features pianists such as Dr John, Henry Butler, and Tom McDermott.

recordname: Like, Love, Lust & The Open Halls Of The Soul
description: Nicolai Dunger guests on the singer-songwriter's third LP.

recordname: I Dont Want: The Gold Fire Sessions
description: The fourth full-length release for the Los Angeles-based artist was recorded in two weeks with Dre Skull and features a guest appearance from Shenseea.
Contributions from Bonde do Role's Marina Ribatski, Solex, the Double Dutch Divas, Rapper's Delight Club, and Public Enemy's Chuck D appear on the second album from the British group.
The first release in five years for the Scottish rock band and is its first with new members Luciano Rossi and Andrew Mitchell.
The debut release for the indie pop quartet that includes Veronica Falls' James Hoare, Max Claps, Daniel Nellis, and Robert Syme was recorded on a reel-to-reel four track.
This is the debut full-length release for the Indiana dream-pop band led by Drew Auscherman.
The song titles for the experimental German musician's second solo release was inspired by photos of vacant cities and was recorded in 10 days in his home studio.
This is the third full-length release from the Estonian-born electronic producer.
The debut album for the band that includes members of Gayngs was written in month and produced with Jim Eno of Spoon.
The debut album for the African artist features guest appearances by M.I.A. and Vampire Weekend's Ezra Koenig.
The second full-length release for the London-based trio was produced and mixed by Marta Salogni.

recordname: Wise Up Ghost and Other Songs
description: Originally begun as an album of reworked Costello songs, the debut collaboration between Elvis Costello and the Roots is instead a largely original release produced by Steven Mandel.

recordname: What It Means to Be Left-Handed
description: The New York City band led by Adam Pierce releases its seventh album.

recordname: Are You Thinking What I'm Thinking?
description: This debut for the all-girl L.A.-based trio (who are daughters of music industry bigwigs) was produced by former Prince backing musician Wendy Melvoin.

recordname: No More Songs About Sleep And Fire
description: The veteran Illinois-based college-radio favorites offer up more new wave (or is that post new wave or new new wave?) tunes on their eighth studio LP.

Denmark's Raveonettes--now including two new members in addition to founders Sune Rose Wagner, Sharin Foo and their drum machine--make their major-label debut with this 13-track effort produced by Richard Gottehrer (Blondie). As on their debut EP, all songs are restricted to a single key (here, b-flat major) and must be shorter than 3 minutes.

The days of hard-rocking Yo La Tengo appear to be over (at least on record), as the Hoboken, NJ trio continues along the atmospheric, lower-volume path begun on 'And Then Nothing Turned Itself Inside-Out.' Included among the 13 Roger Moutenot-produced tracks is a cover of Big Star's "Take Care" and the James McNew-sung "Tiny Birds."

After wowing music critics and winning Britain's Mercury Music Prize for his 2000 debut album, 'The Hour of Bewilderbeast,' Damon Gough (who is the one and only member of Badly Drawn Boy) took a bit of time off, recording only the soundtrack for 'About A Boy' in the interim. He now returns with a proper follow-up, preceded by single "You Were Right."
This is the fifth LP for the Athens, GA-based indie-pop band (part of the Elephant 6 collective) fronted by Andrew Rieger and Laura Carter.
Busta's fourth solo album includes 20 new tracks produced by the likes of Dr. Dre, the Neptunes, and Pete Rock. Guest vocalists include P. Diddy, Mary J. Blige, and the Flipmode Squad.
The third set of English translated Serge Gainsbourg songs from the Bad Seeds member features contributions from Xanthe Waite and Katy Beale.
The third full-length solo release for The Gaslight Anthem frontman was produced by Peter Katis.
The debut full-length solo release for the guitarist from South Carolina was produced by the Black Keys' Dan Auerbach.
The latest solo release from the Giant Sand artist features guest appearances from Pieta Brown, his daughter Talula Gelb, Anna Karina, Kira Skov and M. Ward.
The fifth full-length solo release for the Everything But The Girl singer features guest appearances from Bailey Rae and Shura.

The debut full-length release for Erol Alkan and Richard Norris as Beyond the Wizard's Sleeve features guest appearances from Euros Childs, Blaine Harrison of The Mystery Jets, Holly Miranda, Hannah Peel, and Jane Weaver.
The debut full-length release for the British rock quartet was produced by Dominic Mitchison.
The debut album for the British trio was produced by David Kosten.
The fourth full-length release for the Canadian jazz group features guest appearances from Future Islands' Samuel T. Herring, Mick Jenkins, Kaytranada, Colin Stetson, and Charlotte Day Wilson.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter was inspired by her recent move to California from Texas.
The fourth full-length release for the North Carolina garage rock band led by Dan McGee features a guest appearance from Superchunk's Mac McCaughan.
The third album for the British rock band was produced by Ben Allen, along with contributions from Jim Abbiss and Jack Steadman.
The country singer self-produced his ninth studio release that features guest appearances from Dierks Bentley, Charlie Daniels, Hunter Hayes, Eric Idle, Mat Kearney, LL Cool J, and Roger Miller.

With John McEntire as producer, Kevin Drew, Brendan Canning, Charles Spearin, Andrew Whiteman, Sam Goldberg, and Justin Peroff worked together to write the group's fourth studio album (outside of the two Broken Social Scene Presents...albums). Other BSS members do appear as guests on this release, including Leslie Feist, Amy Millan and Evan Cranley of Stars, Emily Haines and Jimmy Shaw of Metric, Jason Collett, and Ohad Benchetrit of Do Make Say Think and Years.
The Brooklyn, New York-based artist explores the idea of an apocalypse on his latest album.
This is the first of two releases in 2011 for the San Francisco indie rock band led by John Dwyer.
The Yeah Yeah Yeahs' Karen O and several of her musician friends compose the soundtrack to Spike Jonze's adaptation of the children's book, Where The Wild Things Are.
Martin Crane expands his Brazos music project with the addition of drummer Ian Chang and bassist Spencer Zahn on his second full-length release.
The sophomore full-length album for the indie rock trio from Champaign, Illinois.
This mini-album finds seven new originals written and sung by Sam Beam (Iron & Wine) with Calexico's Joey Burns and John Convertino performing as his backing band.
The third full-length release for the Chris Stewart music project was self-recorded and produced.
The two-track, 40-minutes album for Kieran Hebden as Four Tet was created using Ableton Live software.
This is the debut full-length techno release for Chicago-based producer Ryan McRyhew.
The fifth album from the Australian band includes Luke Steele, Julian Hamilton, and Paul Mac as guests.

recordname: You Can't Imagine How Much Fun We're Having
description: The underground hip-hop duo of Slug and Ant return with a new two-disc set.
Produced by Facundo Bermudez, Seth Bogart shares lead vocals with Shannon Shaw on the garage punk band's second full-length release.

recordname: They Threw Us in a Trench and Stuck a Monument On Top
description: This debut LP from the experimental punk outfit from Brooklyn known for their strong live sets features lengthy song titles and an even lengthier closing track (clocking in at over half an hour).
The eighth full-length studio release for the British rock band led by brothers David Brewis and Peter Brewis was inspired in part by music from The Beatles, Free, Fleetwood Mac, and Led Zeppelin.
The fifth full-length release for the Mike Patton-led band that includes Duane Denison, John Stanier, and Trevor Dunn was co-produced with Paul Allen.
The fourth full-length release for the Brooklyn indie pop band-turned-solo-project by Jonny Pierce who wrote and produced the album.
The recording of The Cure's appearance at Britain's Bestival in September 2011 is the band's first live album since 1993.
This is the debut solo full-length album for violinist/producer K. Ishibashi.
The fifth full-length studio release for the black metal duo is a five-track companion album to 2011's Celestial Lineage.
The second full-length release for the Austin-based singer-songwriter was produced with Erik Wofford.
The 40th anniversary for British post-punk band brings its 15th studio release that was partly recorded in Wales.
The full-length debut for the Berlin-based electronic artist features guest appearances from Suad Khalifa and Sonja Immonen.
The rock band from Long Island returns with a new album produced by Queens of the Stoneage's Eric Valentine and features the original lineup from its 2002 debut.
This is the debut full-length album on Atlantic for the Welsh trio and continues to be a cacophony of rock riffs and pop sensibility.
Ski Beatz produced most of the New Orleans-born rapper's first solo album with Def Jam.
This is the fifth studio album for the ex-Arab Strap band member.
The latest full-length release for nu metal band Korn was produced by Chris Collier.
The 18th full-length solo release for the British electronic artist is said to be about climate change from the Earth's point of view.
The final release for Dolores O'Riordan (who passed away in January 2018) and the Irish rock band was produced by Stephen Street.
The latest solo release for the Mouse on Mars artist is the fourth album in St. Werner's experimental Fiepblatter series.
This is the latest release for the solo project of Sarah Lipstate.
This is the debut full-length release from one of the pioneers of footwork.
British producer Wrongtom remixes a collection of Roots Manuva's tracks.
Check out the latest album from the British punk-rock band formed in 1977.
The debut full-length release for the Brooklyn pop singer-songwriter was self-produced like her 2015 EP, Bleaksploitation.
The eighth album for the R&B singer was produced with help from The-Dream, Ne-Yo, Stargate, Dre & Vidal, and Timbaland.
Tom Krell's second release as How to Dress Well shows more R&B influences.
The country singer-songwriter releases a live acoustic album recorded at Nashville's Belcourt Theatre in 2009.
The Dirtbombs fourth full-length album includes covers of songs by Alan Moore, Dead Moon, and Sparks.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Baltimore-based electronic artist was self-produced.
The third full-length release for the British rock duo was self-produced except for two tracks with production from Paul Epworth.

The covers album from the garage rock artist features songs by The Dils, Amon Düül II, Funkadelic, Gong, Grateful Dead, John Lennon, Rudimentary Peni, Sparks, Spencer Davis Group, War, and Neil Young.

The debut album featuring Reigning Sound's Greg Cartwright and The Ettes' Coco Hames includes appearances by Dan Auerbach, Patrick Keeler, and fellow band members Jem Cohen, Poni Silver, and Dave Amels.
This is the first solo release for the Scottish artist since the breakup of his band Arab Strap.

recordname: We All Raise Our Voices to the Air: Live Songs 04.11.08
description: The two-disc live album collects 20 live songs from the band's tour for its 2011 album, The King Is Dead.
The ninth album for Paul Weller features Blur's Graham Coxon, Little Barrie, Oasis' Noel Gallagher and Gem Archer, Ocean Colour Scene's Steve Cradock, and Stone Roses' Aziz Ibrahim.
The third full-length release for Alicia Bognanno's rock project was produced by John Congleton.

recordname: The Bob's Burgers Music Album [Original Television Soundtrack]
description: The soundtrack to the Fox animated comedy features songs from the first 107 episodes as well as five exclusive cover songs performed by Lapsley, The National, St. Vincent, and Stephin Merritt of Magnetic Fields.
The fourth full-length release for the Swedish indie rock band was live recorded over a few days.
The fifth full-length release for the Ohio trash metal band was produced by Kurt Ballou.
This is the experimental techno three-track release from Cold Cave member Dominick Fernow.
The third full-length release for the New Zealand folk band was produced by Tom Healy.
The second album Robyn Hitchcock has recorded with The Venus 3 (Peter Buck, Scott McCaughey, & Bill Rieflin) features a track used in the film Rachel Getting Married.
The Detroit-based group and backing band on Loretta Lynn's "Van Lear Rose" release their sophomore album.
The latest full-length solo release for the Scottish singer-songwriter was recorded in his Scottish home and was produced with David Wrench.
The eighth full-length studio release for the alt-country band led by Jay Farrar was inspired by blues music.
The third full-length release for the Philadelphia rock band was produced by Jonathan Low.
Chris Zane (Les Savy Fav) produced this third album for the Toronto duo-turned-foursome.
The debut full-length release for the ex-Vampire Weekend member features guest appearances from Angel Deradoorian and Kelly Zutrau.
With the end of LCD Soundsystem, Nancy Whang becomes a full-time member of Juan Maclean's synth-pop project for the duo's third full-length studio release.
Hannes Norrvide's project expands into a trio with the addition of Loke Rahbek and Malthe Fisher (who also produces the album) for its fourth full-length release.
The British country-punk rock band releases its latest album on Sin Record Label, which the band ran from 1985 to 1988.
The sixth album for the indie-folk singer-songwriter was recorded in Texas and Arizona with a cast of up to eight backing musicians.
The late Beatle's final studio album was produced by Jeff Lynne with Harrison's son, Dhani.

Working again with longtime producer Allen Reynolds, Brooks' first country-pop album in four years includes duets with George Jones and Trisha Yearwood. If Brooks' claims are to be believed, this will also be his farewell album.
Los Angeles-based alt-country outfit Beachwood Sparks return with a second album for Sub Pop. The disc includes a cover of Sade's "By Your Side."

The first album in four years (since 1997's 'The Drop') for Brian Eno finds the legendary musician/producer paired for the first time with German DJ/percussionist J. Peter Schwalm. Longtime Eno friend Laurie Anderson provides vocals on one song, although most of the thirteen tracks are atmospheric, soundtrack-like instrumentals (some with strings). Believe it or not, Eno will be performing live in support of the album, with at least one scheduled date (at the Fuji Rock Festival on 29 July 2001).

recordname: Let's Get Out Of This Country
description: The six-piece Glaswegian indie-pop band really did leave the country, recording this third full-length with producer Jari Haapalainen (The Concretes) in Sweden.
The first release in four years for the band led by Will Toledo was recorded over two sessions and is said to "contain elements of EDM, hip hop, futurism, doo-wop, soul, and of course rock and roll."
Backed by The Roots, John Legend delivers his fourth studio album of soul-conscious classics and original material.
The eighth full-length studio release for the British alternative rock band was produced by Alan Moulder.
The third full-length release for the Swedish singer-songwriter was produced with Björn Yttling and Greg Kurstin.
The seventh album for the member of the Wu-Tang Clan.
The first album for the punk band without Bruce Gilbert, who left in 2004.
The fifth full-length studio release for the duo of Ishmael Butler and Tende Baba Maraire feature guest appearances from Darius, Carlos Overall, Purple Tape Nate, and Stas THEE Boss.
The fourth full-length release for the Australian indie rock band is its first on the Sub Pop label.
The sixth full-length studio release for the New York R&B singer was produced by Dave Sitek with guest appearances from CSS and Priscilla Ahn.
Electronic producer Travis Stewart's latest album under the Machinedrum moniker is his first on the Planet Mu label.
The 14th full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter features contributions from Paul Epworth, Sky Ferreira, Terrell Hines, Greg Kurstin, Chris Martin, and Pharrell Williams.

Australian singer-songwriter Sia Furler (also known for her work with Zero 7) received a boost when a track from her second solo album was featured during the conclusion of HBO's "Six Feet Under," prompting a very belated U.S. release of the album in 2006.
The conclusion of the ex-Danity Kane member's Heart trilogy features a guest appearance from PJ Morton.
The latest full-length release for Welsh electronic artist Kelly Lee Owens was created in Oslo with Lasse Marhaug.
Previously known as The Extra Glenns, the duo that comprises John Darnielle of The Mountain Goats and Franklin Bruno of Nothing Painted Blue, releases its first album under the new name.
Pink's sixth studio album features Eminem, Fun.'s Nate Ruess, and Lily Rose Cooper. It is her first album recorded for RCA Records.
The first new release in 17 years for the New York blues-punk band that includes Cristina Martinez and Jon Spencer.
The first record for the San Francisco-based band since Devin Hoff joined as their bass player.

recordname: Everything Will Be Alright in the End
description: The ninth full-length studio release for the alternative rock quartet led by Rivers Cuomo was produced by Ric Ocasek.
The third full-length release for the Denver husband-and-wife indie pop duo features production from Patrick Carney of The Black Keys, Jim Eno of Spoon, and Richard Swift.

recordname: Everything Not Saved Will Be Lost, Pt. 2
description: The second part to the British indie rock band's earlier this year released Everything Not Saved Will Be Lost Pt. 1 was produced by frontman Yannis Philippakis with assistance from engineer Brett Shaw.
The third album recorded at Justin Vernon's studio with Brian Joseph for the North Carolina trio is said to be bigger, bolder, and broader than previous releases.
The fifth full-length release for the New York-based trio of Ani Ivry-Block, Lily Konigsberg and Nina Ryser was recorded over four days with producer Matt Labozza.
The second full-length release for the Los Angeles-based band is the first with new drummer and bassist Brooke Dickson and Drew Thomsen.
The third release for Eva Moolchan as Sneaks was produced by Carlos Hernandez and Tony Seltzer (as well as Jacknife Lee on "Hong Kong to Amsterdam").
The latest solo release for the British artist who is also a member of Hidden Orchestra was self-produced.
The second full-length release for the Toronto-based indie-pop band led by Molly Rankin was produced by Alec O'Hanley and John Congleton.
The debut full-length release for the Irish-born country artist was produced by Paul Gregory of Lanterns On The Lake.
The latest solo release for the multiple Grammy award-winner was produced by Eric Krasno.
The follow-up to the British singer-songwriter's Mercury Prize-nominated debut was produced by Chris Bond.
The third full-length studio release for the Scottish indie rock band was produced by Paul Savage.

Self-produced, the first release in four years for the New York rock band is also its first without bassist Carlos Dengler and features contributions from Secret Machines' Brandon Curtis, Jellyfish's Roger Joseph Manning, Jr., and Bon Iver's Rob Moose.
The second full-length release for the Los Angeles pop trio comes five years after their 2009 debut, Expressions.
The second full-length release for the British producer/singer-songwriter was produced by Ryan Adams.
The fourth full-length release for the British band sees the addition of Kristian Robinson and the return of Duke Garwood.
The fourth full-length solo studio release for Mountains' Koen Holtkamp includes a disc of music that were first released on vinyl.
The debut solo project for Cherry Ghost frontman Simon Aldred was produced by Ash Workman.
The debut full-length release for the British indie rock quintet includes influences from psychedelic and krautrock.
Ex-Beta Band-er Steve Mason's latest group releases its debut full-length.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn-based post-punk trio was produced by Monte Vallier.
This is the debut full-length release for the London based indie-pop trio of Rakel Mjöll, Alice Go, and Bella Podpadec.
The sixth full-length release for the New Jersey rock trio was produced by Matt Bayles.
With the death of Daddi Gee, who worked under the name the Spaceape, dubstep producer Steve Goodman goes solo with this release, which does feature Spaceapes vocals on one track.
The fourth full-length release for the British indie rock band was recorded in France with producer James Ford.
The fourth solo release for the Dirty Three guitarist features guest appearances from Peggy Frew, Caroline Kennedy-McCracken, Oliver Mann, Kishore Ryan, Ian Wadley, and Jeff Wegener.
The sixth full-length release for British electronic producer Alan Myson is said to have a "much greater focus into the sound design and palette."
The third full-length release for the British rock band was recorded live with producer Jonathan Schenke.
The 17-track album from the prolific singer-songwriter is his 19th solo release.
The tenth studio release for the Scottish rock band was produced by David Holmes and features guest appearances by Robert Plant, My Bloody Valentine's Kevin Shields, and Mark Stewart.

Fresh off the Roxy Music reunion tour, Bryan Ferry resumes his solo career with this 13-track effort, a mix of Ferry originals and covers (including two Dylan tracks). Ferry has actually been working on this album for parts of the last eight (!) years, and it includes contributions from former Roxy Music partner/nemesis Brian Eno, the Eurythmics' Dave Stewart, and Radiohead's Johnny Greenwood.

recordname: Go Tell Fire To The Mountain
description: The British rock band self-produced its debut full-length album, which was recorded in an unused church.
The underground rapper/poet returns with his second album for Epitaph, joined by guests Buck 65, Jolie Holland and Mark Isham.
Roberto Carlos Lange's second solo electronic album was written while he was staying at an isolated cabin in Connecticut.

Though known for always being on the road, Against Me! has finally released its second major label album, which continues to blend elements of its trademark punk and folk rock with fist-pumping anthems celebrating teenage anarchy and encouraging all to fight the good fight.
Switch and Diplo team up to release their first album as Major Lazer.
Stephen Street produces the former Blur guitarist's fifth solo disc.
The second full-length release for the Norwegian pop singer-songwriter Sigrid features a guest appearance from Bring Me The Horizon.
The fifth full-length release for Ryan Lott's solo-project-turned-trio that now includes Rafiq Bhatia and Ian Chang is its first on the City Slang label.
The fourth full-length release for the Philadelphia indie rock trio led by Mike Polizze is its first recorded in a professional studio.

Taking the best of post-punk, new wave, and pop as inspiration, Sunderland's Futureheads were among the best of the U.K.'s "angular" movement. Their capability of delivering their trademark pop thrills on this album sustains their position as Sunderland's sharpest export.
The latest album for the singer-songwriter was produced by Richard Swift and recorded in just under week.
The sophomore album for the New Jersey punk-rock band was produced by Ted Hutt.
The solo full-length debut for the New Zealand singer-songwriter was co-produced with Ben Edwards.
The debut full-length solo release for The National's frontman was recorded over 14 days with producer Booker T. Jones.
Noah Lennox, Animal Collective's founding member, releases his fourth solo album.
The fourth album but the first with Merge Records for the Brooklyn-based band.
The noise punk band led by Meredith Graves releases a full-length follow-up to its 2013's four-track EP, I Have Lost All Desire For Feeling.
Singer-guitarist Jeremy Earl and his band release their sixth full-length of sunny West Coast pop and folk rock.
Onelinedrawing is the alter ego for Sacramento, Calif.-based singer/guitarist Jonah Matranga, formerly of the emo band Far.
'Margerine Eclipse' marks the London-based band's first LP since the death of long-time member Mary Hansen, as well as the once-prolific group's longest-ever gap between albums (2 1/2 years).
'Punk Rock' is just that, combining new recordings of some of the band's edgier late-70s output with live performances culled from their 25th anniversary tour in 2002.
Less punk, more pop is the motto for the fourth album by the New Jersey emo band led by singer-songwriter Chris Conley.
The second installment in the "Art Official Intelligence" series (following 2000's 'Mosaic Thump') features the hit single "Baby Phat" and guest appearances from Slick Rick and Cypress Hill's B Real.
The first release in over a decade for the California indie rock band was produced by frontman Jason Lytle.
The fifth full-length release for the noise rock band was produced by Arthur Rizk and Lydia Lunch.
Ben Chasny's psych-folk project releases its seventh album in five years, producing a more playful, atmospheric sound with Ben's trademark twangy, country-folk feel.
The Welsh rock band goes with a poppier sound on its Dave Eringa-produced 10th studio album.
The Philadelphia/Brooklyn-based band returns with its latest studio album following a Christmas album in 2005.
The seventh full-length release from the Philadelphia psych-punk trio includes influences from pop and indie rock music.
The is the debut full-length release from the London-based house/techno producer.
The British folk singer's latest album is a concept album about the relationships we have with the sea.
The punk band led by Conor Oberst returns from a 13-year hiatus for its second full-length release that was co-produced by Mike Mogis.
Nigel Godrich produced this 9-song solo debut for the Radiohead frontman, which mainly sounds like--shockingly--a Radiohead album, albeit with much less guitar.

The third full-length solo release for the South American dance producer/artist includes contributions from Philipp Gorbachev, Ana Helder, Daniel Maloso, Alejandro Paz, Juliana Gattas, A'rea Negrot, Liset Alea and Jorge Gonz lez.
The Swedish singer-songwriter's first album in five years was influenced by a break-up.

The debut full-length studio release for the Los Angeles hip hop/R&B artist features guest appearances from such artists as Babyface, Brandy, E-40, Fetty Wap, Future, Kendrick Lamar, Rae Sremmurd, Trey Songz, Kanye West, Wiz Khalifa, and YG.
The eighth full-length release for the Scottish post-rock band was produced with Paul Savage.

This three-disc box set contains more than 50 previously unreleased recordings by the legendary Seattle band, including demos, live tracks, and alternate versions. Also included is an extensive bonus DVD filled with live performances.
The second full-length release for the British synthpop artist Elly Jackson (Ben Langmaid left the band during the recording of the album) was co-produced with Ian Sherwin.
Alan Moulder and Dan Carey produces the first album in four years from New York's Chairlift.
The North Carolina-born singer's 13th album was produced by Glyn Johns, and it is his first since he left the band in part to Meniere's disease in 2009.

The latest full-length release for Atlanta hip-hop duo EarthGang features guest appearances from Baby Tate, Nick Cannon, J. Cole, Future, CeeLo Green, JID, Ari Lennox, Musiq Soulchild, and Lynae Vanee.
The Canadian dance artist returns with L'Oeil Nu (Pierre Guerineau and Asaël R. Robitaille) with a pop and rock-inspired album.
This is the debut full-length release for the collaboration between Venetian Snares and Daniel Lanois.
This is the debut full-length release for the Icelandic (unrelated) duo of Kaktus Einarsson and Gulli Einarsson who previously released techno music under the name Captain Fufanu.
The pop release produced by John Williams reunites Beautiful South's Paul Heaton and Jacqui Abbott.

The Sacramento noise rap trio's second release ended its contract with Epic after it released the album online for free [1 Oct 2012] with an obscene cover image. It was officially released on CD/vinyl in 2013.
This is the debut album for the Canadian electronic group now comprised of Dibani Azari, Alphonse Alixander Lanza III, Starving Yet Full, and Fritz Helder.
This is the debut album for the British dubstep producer whose real name is unknown.
This is the solo debut album for the Sleater-Kinney singer/guitarist.

recordname: Memoirs At The End Of The World
description: The second album for the Florida trio features songs influenced by the music of various films.
The fourth solo album for the Old 97s singer was produced by Salim Nourallah and features Jon Brion, The Apples In Stereo's John Dufilho, and Billy Harvey.
The folk rock band from upstate New York formed by three brothers and their friend releases its first studio album in the US.

The second full-length release for the Swedish sisters Johanna and Klara Söderberg was produced by Tucker Martine with contributions from R.E.M.'s Peter Buck, Wilco's Glenn Kotche, and Midlake's McKenzie Smith,
The second part to the Swedish pop artist's trilogy of albums combines pop, dance, and hip-hop and includes collaborations with Diplo and a duet with Snoop Dogg.
After several EPs, the Los Angeles based band releases its debut full-length of 1960s influenced pop songs.
The second album for the San Francisco-based band led by Sonny Smith includes some tracks he wrote for his 100 Records gallery project.
New Zealand-based Nick Harte presents songs from his previously released EPs in this full-length album.
This is the debut full-length release for the Canadian indie electronic duo of Megan James and Corin Roddick.
The third full-length release for the British punk rock band features contributions from Kenny Beats.
The second full-length solo release for the Wild Beasts frontman was produced by Richard Formby and Nathan Jenkins.
The seventh full-length release for Cécile Schott as Colleen was self-recorded, produced and mixed.
The second full-length studio release for Nick Zammuto was self-produced and recorded in his home studio.
Produced by T-Bone Burnett, the covers album from Diana Krall includes songs culled from the collection of 78s her father had.
The third full-length release for the rock band was produced by David Holmes and features guest appearances from Paul Weller and Johny Marr.
The latest release from the husband-and-wife duo Brett and Rennie Sparks is a concept album based on animals and real-life historical figures.
The fourth full-length studio release for the California alternative rock band includes appearances from all the original band members.
The first new full-length studio release for Animal Collective in six years was mixed by Marta Salogni.
The Los Angeles artist recorded songs over two days from her back catalog live in London's RAK Studios.
Th eighth full-length solo release for the British singer-songwriter was produced with James Hoare.
Produced by Alain Johannes and Mark Lanegan, the fifth full-length solo release for the London-based artist features contributions from Johannes, Paul May, Jehnny Beth and Johnny Hostile of Savages.

recordname: Tales from the Realm of the Queen of Pentacles
description: The first release of original material in seven years for the New York singer-songwriter was produced by Gerry Leonard.
The latest album for the band from Connecticut was produced by Scott Colburn.
After releasing an album with boyfriend Alex Somers in 2009, the Sigur Ros singer returns with his first solo album produced with Peter Katis.
British electronica artist Ben Jacobs returns from a six year absence to release his third album under the Max Tundra name.
The posthumous solo release of the Suicide frontman's songs recorded with Liz Lamere in 1995-1996.
This is the latest album for the Canada-based Taiwanese lo-fi indie singer Alex Zhang Hungtai.
The UK singer's debut album is an eclectic mix of electronic pop, dubstep and R&B.
Alison Krauss brings a bluegrass feel to rock with the help of Union Station, her first album with them since 2004's Lonely Runs Both Ways.
This is the second full-length solo release from the former member of The Former Alliance, Erick Berglund.
The second full-length release for the Israeli electronic pop artist/producer features guest appearances from BLIMES, Reo Cragun and ROUSSO.
The follow-up to the singer's 2010 debut was self-produced and mixed by Michael H. Brauer.

The first full-length release for the rapper as Naeem (previous albums were under the name Spank Rock) features guest appearances Amanda Blank, Micah James, Swamp Dogg, Velvet Negroni, and Justin Vernon.

The third full-length studio release for the rapper features production from BADBADNOTGOOD, Aaron Bow, Crooklin, Dupri, DNYC3, ESVYBE, Kaytranada, Lambo, Jay Nari, Blair Norf, Pops, SLWJMZ, Speakerbomb, and Teddy Walton.
