The second full-length release for the Brooklyn band formed by Lizzie & Teeny Lieberson is its first with new bassist Boshra AlSaadi.
the 16th full-length studio release for the British indie band was produced by Jacknife Lee.
The fifth full-length release for the electronic project led by Scott Hansen features the vocals of Saint Sinner (aka Hannah Cottrell).
The second full-length solo release for the Metric/Broken Social Scene singer was produced with Metric guitarist Jimmy Shaw (who also mixed the album).

recordname: Art in the Age of Automation
description: The fourth full-length release for the British band (2015's Living Fields was released as a trio under the name Portico) was recorded in London and sees them returning as a four-piece.
The third full-length release for the British band led by Tom Hudson was produced by Matt Peel.
The latest album for the British grime artist features Armand Van Helden, Calvin Harris, Chrome, Shy FX, and Tiesto.
The third album for the Ohio rock band was produced by Mike McCarthy.
This is the fourth release for the British electronic producer, Luke Blair.
The third album for dubstep DJ Paul Rose aka Scuba mixes dubstep, techno, and bass.
The seventh full-length release from the indie rock band was produced with Kevin Ratterman and is its first with new band member, David Fountain.
The third full-length release for the Kyle Thomas' psychedelic rock project includes contributions from Ty Segall.
The debut release from the collaboration between John Schmersal and former Triclops!/Anywhere member Christian Beaulieu includes a guest appearance from Robert Pollard.
The Los Angeles-based rock band returns with its first album on new label Fantasy.
The fourth full-length release for the New York rock trio features production from Nick Launay, James Murphy of LCD Soundsystem, and Dave Sitek of TV On The Radio.

recordauthor: Laura Jane Grace & the Devouring Mothers
description: The debut full-length release for the music project from the Against Me! singer/guitarist features Atom Willard and Marc Hudson.

The debut "full-length" [16 tracks with a run time of about 16 minutes] album from the hardcore punk quartet that includes ex-Black Flag and Circle Jerks singer Keith Morris; Dimitri Coats of Burning Brides; Mario Rubalcaba of Hot Snakes and Rocket from the Crypt; and Steven McDonald of Redd Kross was recorded over three days.
The second full-length studio release for the Atlanta rapper features guest appearances from Future, Kid Cudi and Kanye West.
The sixth studio release continues the story from The Afterman: Ascension and sees the return of drummer Josh Eppard.
The Afrobeat Academy band appears on the second solo release for the guitarist and songwriter from Ghana.
The fourth full-length release for Tom Krell features production from the Bleachers' Jack Antonoff, CFCF, Kara-Lis Coverdale and Dre Skull.
This is the second full-length release for the British trio of Rebecca Hawley , Emily Lansley, and Lucy Mercer.
The 17-track solo release from the Los Angeles artist features two songs co-written with Kim Fowley.
The second Guided By Voices release in 2017 for Robert Pollard was recorded in New York and Ohio.
The debut album for the Brooklyn indie rock trio was produced by Jarvis Taveniere of Woods.
The latest full-length release for the country singer-songwriter features two new songs and was produced by Buddy Cannon.
The debut full-length release for the Nashville singer-songwriter Sophie Allison features some newly recorded songs previously released on Bandcamp as well as some new songs.
The third full-length release for the San Francisco garage rock band was recorded to tape by Kelley Stoltz.
Drummer Jay Lane returns to Primus on its first full-length release since 1999 album, Antipop.
This is the thrid album for Norwegian Susanna Wallumrod.
The fourth album for the rock band was influenced by Carl Jung.
The first album from Mark Pritchard under the name Harmonic 313.
Sunn O)))'s Oren Arbarchi, Stephen OMalley and producer Randall Dunn expand on the themes and sounds from their work on the score for Alexis Destoop's film "Kairos."

Rjyan Kidwell's second release of 2003 (third, if you count his all-instrumental alternate version of 'Being Ridden') features 8 new songs that run the gamut from rap to industrial rock to glitchy electronica.
The rap outfit's first album since 1996's 'Stakes Is High' is the first in a planned trilogy.
This second studio album for the experimental Elephant 6 band led by William Cullen Hart and Bill Doss includes the single "Hideway" among its 27 (!) tracks.
The London four-piece try to capitalize on press generated by recent support slots for the Libertines with this debut disc, produced by Paul Epworth (Bloc Party).
Th eighth full-length release for the German electronic band is its first studio album in over five years.
The seventh studio album for the R&B singer features songs produced and/or written by Diplo, Max Martin, the Neptunes, Rico Love, Salaam Remi, and Swedish House Mafia.

The fifth full-length release for the Canadian psychedelic rock band was inspired by frontman Stephen McBean receiving his driver's license in 2017 and is its first with and Adam Bulgasem and Rachel Fannan.

recordname: Shine a Light: Field Recordings from the Great American Railroad
description: Billy Bragg & Joe Henry recorded the 13 train-themed tracks at several stops along their journey from Chicago to Los Angeles by train.
The debut full-length release for the Elbow frontman was backed by I Am Kloot's Pete Jobson, The Whip's Nathan Sudders, Ben Christophers, and Alex Reeves.
This is the first release in six years for the garage punk duo of Mark Sultan and Arish Ahmad Khan.
The latest album for the Norwegian singer was produced by Tobias Froberg.
The Portland, Oregon, dance duo's latest album is a concept album about man's search for utopia.
Working with producer T. Bone Burnett, Robert Randolph picked songs representing the roots of 20th century American music.
The first release on Blue Note for the R&B/Soul singer co-produced by by Keith Richards and Don Was covers some of the classic doo-wop songs that influenced his works.
The third full-length studio release for the Australian trio was produced by Stuart Price.

The debut full-length studio release for the Brooklyn rapper features guest appearances from Action Bronson, BJ The Chicago Kid, Chronixx, Kiesza, Dyemond Lewis, Raury, Maverick Sabre, and Elle Varner.
The fourth full-length studio release for the hip hop trio features guest appearances from Justin Bieber, Cardi B, Drake, Future, Juice WRLD, Polo G, Pop Smoke and YoungBoy Never Broke Again.
This is the debut release for the ambient band formed by William Cashion of Future Islands and Bruce Willen of Double Dagger.
The debut full-length album for the Jose Gonzalez-led trio.

recordname: I Wasn't Born to Lose You
description: This is the first new release in over 15 years for the British alternative rock band formed by Adam Franklin and Jimmy Hartridge.
This is the debut full-length album for the British electronic producer/artist.
The second full-length release for Oliver Hill and Eliza Bagg was influenced by the breakup of their six-year relationship.
This is the third full-length release for the British duo of Tobin Prinz and Suzi Horn.

recordname: I Have Fought Against It, But I Can't Any Longer.
description: The seventh full-length release for the duo of Lee Buford and Chip King features contributions from Sandworm's Ben Eberle, Lingua Ignota's Kristin Hayter and Assembly of Light Choir's Chrissy Wolpert.
The second release for the dream-pop project of Jack Tatum was produced with Nicolas Vernhes.
The 12th full-length release for the band led by Stephen Merritt features songs as short as 13 seconds to just over two and a half minutes.
The 12-song collection from prior recording sessions was originally released digitally in 2010.
The British duo returns with its latest album of electronic music featuring such guest singers as Bryan Ferry, Nick Littlemore, and Will Young.
Captured Tracks releases the New York-based indie band's debut full-length album following positive reactions and comparisons to The Cure on the group's previously released singles.
The latest album for the Seattle, Washington, artists.
This is the sophomore album for the French/Finnish duo of Olivia Merilahti and Dan Levy.
The fourth full-length solo release for Jack White is the first of two albums expected in 2022 (Entering Heaven Alive is set for July 22 release).
After making three successful mixtapes, the rapper releases his debut studio album featuring guest appearances from Drake, Missy Elliot, Jay-Z, and Trey Songz.
The 16th release for the Southern California punk band was co-produced by the band and Joe Barresi.
The fourth studio album for the R&B singer from Barbados features Slash, will.i.am, and Young Jeezy as guest artists.
The eight-track mini-album was self-recorded by the Canadian singer-songwriter.
The latest full-length solo release for singer-songwriter Andrew Bird was recorded live and produced by Mike Viola.
The latest full-length release for Neil Young & Crazy Horse was recorded in a replica of the barn (the original had collapsed) they recorded 2019's Colorado.

recordname: What You Gonna Do When the Grid Goes Down?
description: The 15th full-length studio release for the rap group features guest appearances from Ad-Rock, Black Thought, George Clinton, Daddy-O, DJ Premier, Ice-T, Jahi, James Bomb, Mark Jenkings, Mike D, Ms. Ariel, Nas, PMD, Pop Diesel, Questlove, Rapsody, Run-DMC, The Impossebulls, and YG.
The second full-length release for the Australian punk trio of Jenny McKechnie, Nick Brown and Shauna Boyle was produced by Paul Maybury.
The first new full-length release in over a decade from the pop artist/actor was produced by Mike Viola.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles trio features a guest appearance from Delicate Steve and was produced by Carlos de la Garza.
The ninth full-length studio release for the California hip-hop group was produced by DJ Muggs.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles-based indie pop band originally from Seattle was inspired by both the physical and psychological features of Los Angeles.

New songs were created from Johnny Cash's letters, poems and unfinished or rejected lyrics by T-Bone Burnett, Carlene Carter, Rosanne Cash, Chris Cornell, Elvis Costello, Dailey & Vincent, Robert Glasper, Im With Her, The Jayhawks, Jewel, Jamey Johnson, Kris Kristofferson, John Mellencamp, Kacey Musgraves (with her husband Ruston Kelly), Willie Nelson, Brad Paisley, and Union Station.

recordname: Everything Was Beautiful, And Nothing Hurt
description: The 15th full-length release for the Los Angeles-based electronic artist is said to be inspired by trip-hop music.

recordname: Everything Is Recorded by Richard Russell
description: The full-length debut release for Richard Russell features guest appearances from Peter Gabriel, Giggs, Green Gartside, Ibeyi, Infinite, Obongjayar, Owen Pallett, Sampha, Kamasi Washington, Wiki, and Rachel Zeffira.
The second full-length release for the Canadian electro-pop artist features a cover of Chris Isaak's Wicked Game.
The second full-length release for the Canadian indie rock trio was self-produced and mixed by Vince Casamatta.
The first release in six years fir the Jimmy LaValle-led band is also the first on the Relapse label.
This is the debut full-length solo release for the British electronic producer, Joe Cowton.
The debut full-length release for the trio that includes Nils Frahm, Frederic Gmeiner and Sebastian Singwald was recorded over a period of ten years on four-track tape recorders.
The first studio release of new tracks since Chris Difford and Glenn Tilbrook reunited in 2007 features some songs recorded for the BBC series based on Danny Baker's life.
The fifth full-length release for the Texas heavy metal band was produced by Adrian Quesada.
The fourth full-length release for the Brooklyn-based singer-songwriter was co-produced with Thomas Bartlett (aka Doveman).

recordname: Everyday I Get Closer to the Light from Which I Came
description: The fourth full-length studio release for the British post-rock project led by Justin Broadrick features a 17-minute track.
This is the latest release for the Canadian indie singer-songwriter.
Produced by Larry Klein, the jazz singer's second release on Decca features songs from Ray Charles' 1962 album, Modern Sounds In Country & Western Music.
This is the second full-length release from the Finnish electronic rock band.
With the help of producers Greg Kurstin, Justin Meldal-Johnsen, Mike Elizondo, and Rob Cavallo, the Canadian twins display a more mainstream pop sound with their seventh release.
This is the third full-length album for techno producer Rene Pawlowitz as Shed.
The debut album for the British indie pop band that includes guitarist Dan Moss and singer Katherine Whitaker was produced by Rory Atwell.
The fourth album for the Canadian hardcore rock quartet was produced by Eric Ratz and Kenny Luong.
Backed by the Roots, Betty Wright releases her first studio album in ten years. It features Lil Wayne, Joss Stone, and Snoop Dogg as guests.
Hercules Aand Love Affair's Andrew Butler produced the first album in over more than a decade for Thomas August Darnell's alter ego Kid Creole.
The second album for the Leeds, England-based band was produced with Damian Taylor.

The rapper and producer's fifth album is Diddy's attempt at fashioning an alter ego and creating a conceptual album. The release features collaborations with Felix da Housecat, the Neptunes, and The-Dream.
The third album credited with The Venus 3 was originally recorded in 2006 and features contributions from such artists as Led Zeppelin's John Paul Jones, The Smiths' Johnny Marr, and Nick Lowe.
The latest album for the Nebraska-born singer-songwriter features a track released on his Valencia EP.
The latest solo album for the Grammy Award winner features machines that mimic the sound of a full orchestra.
The sophomore album for the English indie rock band was produced by Erol Alkan.
The very young Scottish four-piece shot straight to #1 on the UK charts with the release of this Britpop-flavored debut album, produced by Owen Morris (Oasis, The Verve).
After a diversion into jazz-pop (2006's 'Duper Sessions'), the Norwegian artist returns with a more muscular rock album produced by Tony Hoffer.
The stadium-sized English trio returns with a follow-up to its 2004 hit 'Absolution,' again produced by Rich Costey.
Bob Weston produced this third studio album for the Louisville indie rockers.
The oh-so-punny industrial rockers return with, believe it or not, their 10th LP (although that does include their early synth-pop releases when they were scary for very different reasons).

The modern-jazz trio stick to the formula of their well-received 2003 debut on this sophomore effort, working again with producer Tchad Blake on a mix of originals and unlikely covers (this time out including Black Sabbath's "Iron Man" and The Pixies' "Velouria").
This is the fourth release for the all-female Japanese rock band fronted by Yoshimi P-We of the Boredoms.

Mice Parade is the solo moniker adopted by Adam Pierce (drummer for the east coast indie rock band The Swirlies) for his forays into electronica and post-rock. Although he has expanded Mice Parade into a full-band effort on some previous releases, Pierce recorded this fourth studio LP mainly on his own.

The first of two planned 2003 releases for the far-from-prolific Bristol-based electronica collective sees the group pared down to one original member: Robert "3-D" del Naja (although Grant "Daddy G." Marshall intends to return to the group for the next disc). Horace Andy returns to provide vocals on several tracks, and Sinead O'Connor also guests on two songs.

The No-Cal rap-metal outfit returns with a second album for Dreamworks (their third overall). Lead singer Coby Dick has reverted back to his given name, Jacoby Shaddix, but otherwise, the band and sound remain the same.

Former Camper Van Beethoven frontman David Lowery once again leads Cracker for the band's first new album in four years. Sparklehorse's Mark Linkous co-produces and adds backing vocals and instrumentation.
This is the third album for the Washington-based indie rockers.

Mark Eitzel's fifth solo release since the breakup of American Music Club is his first album in three years. Unlike on his previous albums, Eitzel is mostly alone here, both producing and playing most of the instruments.
The band's first album of new material in five years was produced by Tool with David Bottrill and features 13 tracks.

recordname: Wish I Was In Heaven Sitting Down
One Day It Will Please Us To Remember Even This
description: The first album in 32 years for the legendary glam-punk band features guest appearances from Michael Stipe, Bo Diddley and Iggy Pop. Only David Johansen and Sylvain Sylvain return from the Dolls' original lineup, however.
The first release for the Berlin-based psychedelic soul rock band in six years was named after a Canadian indigenous-rights movement.
This is the second full-length release for the Swedish indie rock trio.

recordname: A City By The Light Divided
description: The New Jersey emo-rockers (not to be confused with the day of the week of the same name) are back with a fourth album, with Dave Fridmann producing.
The full-length debut release for the Brooklyn indie band led by the married duo Devon Church and Aleksa Palladino continues the atmospheric and emotional sound from their 2011 EP, From Silence.
The first album in 15 years from the avant-garde pop duo of Yuka Honda and Miho Hatori is a concept album about a hotel haunted by a female ghost.
The Cincinnati rock band led by Craig Fox reunites after Jack Lawrence and Patrick Keeler formed The Raconteurs with Jack White and Brendan Benson during The Greenhornes' hiatus in 2005.
The fourth album for the rock band formed by Kim Deal of the Pixies was produced by Steve Albini.
The third full-length release for the Australian indie pop quartet was produced by Mike Young.
The British-born, Portland-based artist was backed by Jose Medeles, Dan Wilson, Saunder Jurriaans, Banny Bensi, and Emil Amos on her sixth full-length studio release.
The fifth full-length release for the Canadian electronic band features guest appearances from Nicholas Allbrook, Angus Andrew and Alexis Taylor.
The debut full-length debut for the trio of Ezra Tenenbaum, Shane O'Connell and Michael Stasiak was produced by Jarvis Taveniere.

Hot Band members James Burton, John Ware, and Bill Payne, as well as Vince Gill, John Jorgenson, Bill Payne, Stuart Duncan, and Steuart Smith appear as guests on the duets album between Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell.
The debut full-length release for the London trio includes "Help Me Lose My Mind," its collaboration with Disclosure. [US edition includes "Maybe," "High Life," and a remix of "Strong."]

recordname: One Hand on the Steering Wheel the Other Sewing a Garden
description: Montreal is the theme of the second full-length release for the Canadian singer-songwriter.
The eighth solo release for the singer-songwriter features guest appearances from R.E.M.'s Peter Buck, Neko Case, k.d. lang, The Secret Sisters, and Joey Spampinato of NRBQ.

recordname: Reason and Rhyme: Bluegrass Songs by Robert Hunter & Jim Lauderdale
description: The latest partnership between Jim Lauderdale and the Grateful Dead's Robert Hunter produces an album of bluegrass songs.

Josh Homme's fifth QOTSA disc includes guest appearances by The Strokes' Julian Casablancas and returnee Mark Lanegan. Oddly, however, the disc does not include its title track collaboration with Trent Reznor, which was released separately.
The debut collaboration between Jesu and Sun Kil Moon features contributions from such artists as Modest Mouse's Isaac Brock, Slowdive's Rachel Goswell, Low, and Will Oldham.
This is the debut full-length release for the electro pop twin sister duo of Miranda and Elektra Kibley-Jansson (daughters of The Church's Steve Kilbey and Pink Champagne's Karin Jansson).
The Swedish rock band led by Gustav Ejstes releases its sixth album.
This long-awaited follow-up to 2002's 'I Phantom' once again reunites the indie MC (also known as Jeffrey Haynes) with producer El-P. Also appearing are Aesop Rock, Akrobatik, Blueprint, and Murs.
The debut full-length release for the husband-and-wife duo of Steve Clarke and Slowdive's Rachel Goswell was produced by Steve's brother, Michael Clarke.
The fourth solo release for the Pink Floyd guitarist was produced with Phil Manzanera.
The Los Angeles-based solo project of Cameron Stallones releases the fifth LP of psychedelic electro noise pop.
This is the Toronto-based trio's debut album of electronic synth-pop.
Jack White plays drums and produced this album for the band headed by The Kills' Alison Mosshart, which also includes The Raconteurs' Jack Lawrence and Queens of the Stone Age's Dean Fertita.
The third full-length release for the British indie singer-songwriter was co-produced with Alex Epton, Inflo aka Dean Josiah, and Paul Epworth.

Hawk is the third collaborative album between former Belle & Sebastian songbird Isobel Campbell and former Screaming Trees frontman Mark Lanegan. Like the two records before it, it draws inspiration from the sultry torch songs once performed by Nancy Sinatra and Lee Hazlewood. Unique to this album is a solid list of guest appearances, however, and the duo covers two Townes Van Zandt songs to boot.
The third full-length release for the London-based, New-Zealand born and Australian-raised alternative R&B artist was inspired by "dystopian views of our future."
The debut full-length release for the Colorado country blues-rock band led by Nate Cook was produced by Cracker's Johnny Hickman,
The latest release for Brooklyn-based producer Daniel Martin-McCormick was mixed with M. Geddes Gengras.
This is the debut solo release for footwork artist, David Davis.
The English trio of brothers look to leave a mark in the US with their third album.
The third full-length release for the Swedish alternative band is said to be a folk album and features pan flutes.
The rappers latest album features such guest artists as DJ Shadow, Mr. Lif, Damian Marley, and MF Doom.
The hip-hop producer--unusually recording under his own name--offers a soundtrack to an imaginary movie.
Joey Burns and John Convertino return with an album produced by J.D. Foster (Dwight Yoakam).
This is the final album in his Pledge Allegiance to the Grind series of releases.
Kurt Heasley's eighth Lilys album finds him working with hip-hop producer Michael Musmanno.
Originally released as piano sheet music, the debut solo piano release for the French artist was inspired by the island in Brittany where he lives.
The second album for the singer-songwriter from Brooklyn, New York, was written while she was in Vermont.
The fourth album for the Brooklyn rock band.
The third full-length studio release for the rock band was produced by band co-founder Jack White.
Hersh's sixth solo album finds the Throwing Muses founder working with Howe Gelb (Giant Sand).
This is the third full-length album from the Brooklyn-based art-school indie rockers.
Singer-songwriter Ben Folds has ditched the other two members of his band (Ben Folds Five) for this 12-track solo album, on which he plays every instrument himself.

The "Madchester" scene is long over, but the Charlatans [U.K.] are still making music, following 1999's well-reviewed 'Us And Us Only' with this, their seventh album, which sees the band take a more playful, soulful approach.
The 10th full-length studio release for the alternative rock band led by Dave Grohl was produced with Greg Kurstin.
The latest EP for A Place to Bury Strangers was mixed, recorded, and produced by the New York rock band.
The debut full-length release for New Zealand's Amelia Murray was self-produced and mixed by Murray Fisher.
The second full-length release from the Los Angeles duo of Lindsey Troy and Julie Edwards was produced by Yeah Yeah Yeahs guitarist Nick Zinner.
The debut album for Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter AM and London-based Shawn Lee was influenced by 1960s and 70s rock music.
After a five year absence the British singer returns with her third album produced by Jon Brion.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles indie rock/pop band was produced by Jacob Bercovici.
The 13th full-length studio release for the British rock trio led by David Tattersall was produced by Billy Childish.
Alabama native Lionel Richie brings a country twang to some of his hits on this album of duets.

The recording of the collaboration between the Icelandic band, Hilmar Örn Hilmarsson, Steindór Andersen and Maria Huld Markan Sigfúsdóttir with the Schola Cantorum of Reykjavík and LOrchestre des Laureats du Conservatoire National de Paris is finally released after having premiered it live on stage back in 2002.
The second full-length release for the Canadian electronic-pop trio was mixed by Chris Coady.
This is the fourth full-length release for the Japanese psychedelic rock group.
The debut full-length release for the Canadian noise rock band was recorded in ten days.
This is the 10th release for the Canadian indie pop singer.
The fifth full-length studio release for the mostly instrumental Chicago post-rock band is the first without founding guitarist Laurent Schroeder-Lebec.
Songs by Madisen Beaty, Ella Fitzgerald, Helen Forrest, and Jo Stafford join music composed by Radiohead's Jonny Greenwood on the soundtrack for Paul Thomas Anderson's latest film, The Master.
The third full-length release for the British soul rock band was recorded in Columbus, Georgia with a gospel choir.
Karen O guests on the second studio album from Santigold featuring production by such artists as Boyz Noise, Bureka Som Sistema, Diplo, Greg Kurstin, Q-Tip, Dave Sitek, and Switch.
The sixth studio album for the Italian metal band includes a cover of R.E.M.'s Losing My Religion and was produced by Don Gilmore.

recordname: Submarine (Original Songs from the Motion Picture)
description: The Arctic Monkeys singer wrote and performed all six tracks of the soundtrack for the British movie Submarine.
Ruth Cameron, Renee Fleming, Melody Gardot, Norah Jones, Diana Krall, and Cassandra Wilson contribute vocals to the jazz quartet's latest album.

recordname: When I See The Sun Always Shines On TV
description: The Toronto-based duo of Aidan Baker and Leah Buckareff release their latest album, featuring eight cover songs.
The fourth album from the Los Angeles band blends latin music with rock, ska, hip-hop, and other genres.
This is the fourth album for the husband-and-wife team of Jason Hammel and Kori Gardner.

The eighth release for the Swedish indie-pop duo Karolina Komstedt and Johan Angergård includes samples of sounds from Russian field recordings, children's choirs, erotic movies, and construction sites.
This is the debut full-length album for the duo from Roanoke, Virginia.
The sixth full-length studio release for the British artist was co-produced with with David Kosten.

The sequel to her 2007 remix album features collaborations with such artist as Peter Bjorn and John, Death Cab For Cutie, Sean Lennon, Moby, Penguin Prison, Portugal. The Man, Miike Snow, Sparks, and tUnE-yArDs.
Maya Angelou, John Legend, and Nas appear as guests on the Chicago rapper's latest album produced by No I.D.
The fifth full-length studio release for the Welsh alternative rock trio was recorded in Utah.
The second full-length release for the London-based grime producer features guest appearances from such artists as Denai Moore, P Money, Palmistry, and Py.

Experience has only made their work richer, bringing gravity to the subject matter and lightness to the sound of this new album. Keeping things honest--and often rapturous--has become a modus operandi.
The Norwegian producer, who has worked with Lindstrom on several albums, releases his debut solo album.

The band's 15th studio LP is a story-driven concept album with narration from The Clash's Mick Jones. The album was originally released (on vinyl only) as a Record Store Day exclusive on April 13, 2019, but was later re-released in multiple formats on July 19, 2019.
This is the second album of home-made recordings for multi-instrumentalist and former Fridge bassist Adem Ilhan.

recordauthor: A Winged Victory for the Sullen
description: The third full-length release and first soundtrack for the electronic duo is a soundtrack for Jalil Lespert's French 2016 film.
The latest studio outing from the prolific singer-songwriter features production by Mike Napolitano (along with DiFranco herself) and contributions from touring musician Todd Sickafoose.
The Seattle band returns with a fourth album.
The second full-length release for the electronic artist features a guest appearance from Bipolar Sunshine.
The recording of songs reworked by JG Thirlwell with the Mivos Quartet was originally performed at the Guggenheim Museum.
This is the Sub Pop debut (and third overall album) for the Seattle-based punk trio.
The singer-songwriter from The Magnetic Fields releases a solo album of B-sides, compilation cuts, and various unreleased material.
The second live recording for the band features songs from its five-night residency at Dublin, Ireland's Olympia Theatre in 2007.
The sixth studio album for the band is its first in four years and was produced by Nick Raskulinecz.
The third full-length release for the British trio features guest appearances from Anna Calvi, Rosie Lowe, Connan Mockasin, and Jessie Ware.
The second full-length release for the metal trio was produced by Kurt Ballou.
The third full-length release for the California psychedelic rock trio was recorded at singer Jonny Bell's home studio.
R&B and electronic music influences are apparent on the three-track debut EP release from singer Aluna Francis and producer George Reid.
The second full-length release for the Los Angeles indie rock band was produced with Flood
The fifth full-length release for the British folk rock band was recorded in four days in Wales with contributions from Joan Shelley, and Tara Jane O'Neil.
The third full-length studio release for Southern California rapper/producer features a guest appearance by Scoop DeVille.
This is the debut album for the newest band led by John Reis of Rocket From the Crypt, Drive Like Jehu, and Hot Snakes.
The 13th release for the Canadian singer-songwriter was produced by Mitchell Froom.
Each track on the third release from the Los Angeles-based artist is said to represent the sound of an animal's spirit.
The two-disc release is the second electronic album with Ultravox founding member John Foxx and producer Benge.
Manu Chao produced the third album for the Mali rap group. The band name stands for the original members of the band (Sam, Ousco, Dronsky, and former member Mouzy).
The debut full-length album for the Portland, Oregon-based indie rock band.
Dave Fridmann produced the Baltimore jam band's latest.
'Happenstance' is the first solo LP for the Chicago-based singer-songwriter, who has also recorded with the funk band Bumpus.
The second full-length release for the British indie rock band was influenced by 1970s soul music and was recorded in Atlanta with producer Ben H. Allen III.
The Somalian-born rapper releases his second album, which features Chubb Rock, Damian Marley, Adam Levine (Maroon 5), Kirk Hammett (Metallica), Mos Def, and Chali 2na as guests.
The second full-length release for British alternative rock trio led by Oli Burslem was produced by Jason Pierce and features a guest appearance from J Spaceman.
This is the 11th full-length studio release for the orchestral pop band led by Neil Hannon.
The third full-length release for the Canadian band led by Dean Tzenos features guest vocals from New Pornographers' Kathryn Calder.
The debut full-length release for the solo project of ex-Working for a Nuclear Free City member Gary McClure was recorded in his St Louis home studio with a Tascam eight-track cassette deck.

recordname: So You Are... So You'll Be
description: The seventh full-length release for the Brooklyn-based space rock trio was produced by Martin Bisi.
The second album for the Los Angeles band features a guest appearance from Dam-Funk.
The eighth album for the British techno band is its first since 2004's Blue Album and the duo reforming in 2008.
This is the second album for the Seattle-based indie rock duo.
The fourth album for the Pittsburgh indie band was produced by Dave Fridmann.
The sophomore effort from the Long Island emo band was produced by Lou Giordano (Ataris), and features new vocalist Fred Mascherino (joining band founder Adam Lazzara).

Founding member of Los Angeles punkers X and occasional actor John Doe returns with his fourth solo album, this one produced by Joe Henry with guest appearances from Rhett Miller (Old 97s), Aimee Mann, Jakob Dylan and Jane Wiedlin.

Known mainly for his work with PJ Harvey (most notably, 'To Bring You My Love' and 'Dance Hall At Louse Point'), producer/musician John Parish has previously released just one solo record under his own name. On this mostly instrumental record, he is supplemented by numerous guests, including Harvey and Portishead's Adrian Utley.

This debut LP for the electric English quartet was originally released in March 2001 to enough critical acclaim that Sony/Epic picked the album up for a re-release in the summer of 2002. Their sound combines harder-edged alt-rock with "shoegazing"-style noise manipulation.
This is the sixth studio LP from the Scottish three-piece.
The second full-length album for the pop band includes songs written after the death of the mother of singer Dee Dee.

recordname: World, You Need a Change of Mind
description: The debut release for Adam Bainbridge was produced by Philippe Zdar.
The latest studio release for the Los Angeles rapper features guest appearances from Aesop Rock, Danny Brown, Open Mike Eagle, Pegasus Warning, and VerBS.
This is the posthumous debut release by the British indie rock quartet who (along with their manager) died in a car accident while on tour in Sweden.
The second full-length release for the British indie rock trio was produced by Hookworms' MJ.
The Oregon-born singer-songwriter/producer went to Switzerland and recorded this album with a Swiss backing band with producer Timo Keller.

The latest release for the Baton Rouge rapper formerly known as Lil Boosie features guest appearances from Akelee, Chris Brown, J. Cole, Keyshia Cole, Jeezy, PJ, Rich Homie Quan, Rick Ross, T.I.,Webbie, Young Thug.
The sixth studio release for the San Francisco duo of Meric Long and Logan Kroeber was recorded soon after completing 2013's Carrier.
This is the second full-length release for the alternative rock band that includes Allison Crutchfield (her twin sister's solo project is Waxahatchee), Kyle Gilbride, and Jeff Bolt.
The ninth studio release for the alternative rock band led by Davey Havok was produced by Gil Norton.
This is the second album for the solo project for Deerhunter guitarist Lockett Pundt.
The country singer releases his 39th studio album.

The Boston-based trio has developed a devoted following over the course of three albums and ten years of touring. This fourth album, produced by Roger Moutenot (Yo La Tengo), adds additional elements such as bass and drums to their ususal mix of two acoustic guitars and bongos.
This is the third album (and first American release) for the Swedish brother-sister electro-pop duo of Olof Dreijer and Karin Dreijer Andersson.
The San Francisco Bay Area native recorded his latest album in seven days after a tour in Europe.
The Nashville singer's follow-up to her 2008 EP Dead Flowers is her full-length debut disc.
The first full-length solo release for the British artist better known for his work as a member of Thenewno2 and as the only son of the Beatles' George Harrison.
The second full-length solo release for The Civil Wars co-founder features a guest appearance from The Secret Sisters.
This is the debut full-length release for the British pop-rock band.
The 15th album for the British grindcore band was produced by Russ Russell.
The second album for the singer, who recently lost her father, explores themes of grief and was produced by Luther Russell.
The indie-pop duo releases its twenty-first album.
Hatfield's fourth solo disc (and first since 2000) finds her working with producers and engineers David Way (Pink, Madonna), David Leonard (Avril Lavigne, Prince) and Dave Cook (Nick Cave).
Will Oldham's latest album under his Bonnie "Prince" Billy moniker features appearances by such guest as Wilco's Leroy Bach and Mekons' Jon Langford.
The fourth album for the British group is its first without cofounder Sam Genders.
The fourth full-length release for the British pop singer features guest appearances from Burna Boy, Giggs and Lady Chann.
Elvis Perkins returns with the follow-up to his debut album with a full band.
The first full-length studio release in nine years for the Swiss electo-pop duo of Dieter Meier and Boris Blank features guest appearances from Malia and Fifi Rong.
The second full-length studio release for the Philadelphia rapper features guest appearances from Chris Brown, Jeremih, Nicki Minaj, Rick Ross, and The Weeknd.
The second solo album for the alt-country singer who was one-half of Freakwater was produced by Tara Jane O'Neil.
This is the seventh album for the New Zealand rock quartet.
This is the third studio album for the Toronto collective headed by Joel Gibb.
The 10th release for the German electronic music duo of Andi Toma and Jan St. Werner is their first album since 2006's Varcharz.
The seventh studio release for the California alternative rock band led by Adam Durvitz was produced by Brian Deck.
In spite of being diagnosed with Alzheimer's Disease, the country pop musician releases a new album.
The latest full-length release for the California hip-hop group Cypress Hill features guest appearances from Demrick and Dizzy Wright.
The acronym for the eight-track second studio release for the R&B singer stands for Keep That Same Energy and was produced by Kanye West.
The first studio release for the band in four years sees Buzz Osborne and Dale Crover joined by Butthole Surfers' Paul Leary and JD Pinkus.
Influenced by early 1980's romantic/new wave, LA's Abe Vigoda's fourth album continues to re-create synth pop and post punk, comparable to The Cure and David Bowie.
The debut full-length release for the Brooklyn pop duo was recorded in New York and London.
The London-based artist releases his follow-up to his Mercury Prize-nominated debut album.
The third full-length release for the South Carolina duo of Michael Trent and Cary Ann Hearst was home-recorded.

The debut full-length studio release for the hip hop producer features guest appearances from such artists as 2 Chainz, Big Sean, Fabolous, Lil Wayne, Rick Ross, Ty Dolla $ign, Yo Gotti, Young Jeezy, and Wiz Khalifa.
The second album by Katy Goodman of Vivian Girls was produced by Rob Barbato.
Weller's latest--his first disc of new material in three years-- is louder and rock-ier than other recent efforts.
The fourth full-length release for the singer-songwriter features contributions from Jedd Hughes, Parker Millsap, Aoife O'Donovan, Luke Reynolds, Joey Ryan, and Sara Watkins.
The third full-length album for the Scottish electronic producer was a surprise release.
The seventh full-length release for the Norwegian pop singer-songwriter was written after his divorce from Mona Fastvold.
Thomas Meluch's latest release as Benoît Pioulard was inspired by religious iconography and cathedrals in Europe.

'Black' finds the Danish duo expanded to a more melodic, less noisy trio, with new bassist Anders Christensen joining vocalist Sharon Foo and guitarist Sune Rose Wagner. Also appearing are Velvet Underground drummer Maureen Tucker, Suicide's Martin Rev, and Ronnie Spector.
The second full-length release for the Texas soul artist was executive-produced by Ricky Reed.
The Mountain Goats' latest album was produced by Scott Solter and John Vanderslice.
The French electronica band returns with its long-awaited follow-up to its hit 1998 debut, Homework.
The Chicago post-rock outfit fronted by Sam Prekop switches producers (from John McEntire to Brian Paulson) for this latest 10-track set.
The first release of new songs from the British post-punk band in 35 years was produced by Paul Epworth.
The singer's second 2005 release is sung entirely in English, and includes two tracks originally sung in Spanish on Fijacion Oral Vol. 1.
This is the third full-length studio release for the Buffalo indie punk-pop trio.
The British rock quintet releases its debut full-length album produced by Ken and Jolyon Thomas.
The latest solo album for the singer-songwriter includes one track co-produced by Mark Ronson.
The debut full-length release for the band led by Chad Ubovich of Fuzz and Mikal Cronin was recorded with Eric King.
Arif Mardin produced this follow-up to the singer's hugely successful 2002 effort 'Come Away With Me.' Dolly Parton guests.

Tool vocalist Maynard James Keenan's side project returns with a second LP on which he's backed by Jeordie "Twiggy Ramirez" White (Marilyn Manson), Billy Howerdel (Tool's guitar tech) and Josh Freese (Guns N' Roses).

recordname: If We Meet In The Future
description: This sophomore LP for the Reading, England band continues the retro-futuristic pop sound (frequently compared to Stereolab) from their debut, with vocals sung in English, Spanish and French.
The fourth album for the alt-country trio (whose song "Moment in the Sun" is the theme for NBC's "Ed") was produced by Joe Chiccarelli (American Music Club).
This is the second album from the post-punk outfit, one of the edgier, less-mainstream bands on the current New York underground circuit.
This self-titled release is the fourth studio album for the California alt-metal outfit.

Another member of the new generation of neo-art-punkers (think Interpol or Liars, perhaps), this Los Angeles-based British four-piece makes its debut with 'Chat & Business,' which comes with a complimentary set of stickers with which to decorate the album cover.

This Sub Pop debut for the British Columbia band falls into the 80s/punk revival category occupied by the likes of French Kicks and Radio 4, although Cure comparisons are more likely (since lead singer Steve Bays' voice sounds, at times, almost identical to Robert Smith's).

This is the second album for the eclectic indie-rock band fronted and founded by John Schmersal (Brainiac). For this outing, the band has expanded to a four-piece, with new members Matt Schultz and former Blonde Redhead bassist Toko Yasuda (who replaces Steve Calhoon and handles some vocals).
The latest release for the soul artist was produced by Poliça's Ryan Olson (with assistance from Bon Iver's Justin Vernon) and features guest appearances from Bon Iver and Guitar Shorty.
The third release for the Oregon duo of Matt Carlson and Jonathan Sielaff was recorded over two years.
The Canadian indie rock band's mellow fourth album.
This is the electronic band's first album since its 2002 album, "Neon Golden."
The second full-length release for the Georgia trio was recorded in a cabin and produced by ex-Carnivore Nathaniel Higgins.
This is the first solo release for Cleveland-based electronic artist since the Emeralds disbanded in 2013.
The latest album for the Japanese quartet is the band's first release since 2006's "Taiga."

recordname: No One Dances Quite Like My Brothers
description: The debut full-length release for Ice Age's Elias Bender Rønnefelt's side project with Loke Rahbek of Sexdrome, Kristian Emdal of Lower, and Lukas Højland of Redflesh was recorded in New York.
Bonnie Raitt returns after seven years with her first studio album since 2005's Souls Alike.
The second full-length release for the British pop singer-songwriter was produced by Benny Blanco and Two Inch Punch.

This self-released effort for the Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter (and former Til Tuesday frontwoman) is her first release since the twin 2000 critical successes of 'Bachelor No. 2' and the soundtrack to "Magnolia."
The sixth full-length studio release for the British pop group features contributions from such artists as Kamille, MNEK, Tayla Parx, and TMS.
The fourth full-length release for the singer-songwriter from Texas was self-produced with some co-production from Al Carlson, Dan Duszynski, and Shane Renfro.
The second full-length release for the band led by ex-Replacements bassist Tommy Stinson was recorded live in studio.
A portion of the sixth full-length release for the experimental electronic trio was recorded in a church.
The debut solo release for Foxygen drummer Shaun Fleming was recorded in two weeks while he was at home recovering from the flu.
The second full-length release for the Danish singer-songwriter was recorded in Berlin and self-produced.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Scottish singer-songwriter was produced with Howe Gelb and includes a guest appearance by PJ Harvey.
The second full-length release for the British indie folk-rock group was produced by Tobi Gmur.
The fourth full-length studio release for the son of late Malian bluesman Ali Farka Touré includes appearances by Sidiki Diabáte and Idan Raichel.
The EP for the electronic artist also known as Hugo Manuel moves away from chillwave to a pop sound.
The third album from the L.A. band is indie pop with an emotional edge.
"A Thing of the Past" also features guest appearances by Vashti Bunyan, the Chapin Sisters and Michael Hurley
This is the second LP for the Chicago-based avant-pop outfit.
The DFA produced this full-length debut for the unconventional rap outfit consisting of MC Jesse Levine and a live five-piece backing band.
Adam Kasper again co-produced the band's belated follow-up to 2002's 'Riot Act.' It is Pearl Jam's eighth studio album overall.
The third full-length release for the indie rock band led by Jack Tatum was recorded in Los Angeles and Stockholm.
This is the debut album for the singer from Norway.
The second album for the British trio was produced by Jim Abbiss and features Peaches as a guest singer on one track.
The debut non-soundtrack release for the director best known for his horror films was improvised instrumental music with his son Cody.
The fifth full-length release for the Seattle sludge metal band now composed only of Jared Warren and Coady Willis was recorded in Joshua Tree with Dave Curran.
The fourth full-length studio release for the electronic artist/producer features guest appearances from Björk, Rosalía, Shygirl, and SOPHIE.
The first full-length studio release in five years for the British indie rock band was produced with John Congleton.
The 17th full-length solo studio release for the indie singer-songwriter was self-produced.
The fourth solo release for the Barn Owl guitarist sees Porras moving toward an electronic ambient sound.
The sixth solo album for the Old 97's frontman sees more country music influences than his previous solo releases.
The former Faith No More singer releases a live solo album of classic Italian pop songs featuring a 40-piece orchestra.
Compared to a no-wave B-52's, the garage-rock trio Rogers Sisters return with a second LP, produced by Tim Barnes.
The first full-length studio release in six years for the British band is its first as a duo.
The debut album on the Warner Bros. label for the Los Angeles rapper features Snoop Dogg and will.i.am as guest artists.

The Game, Akon, Twista, Mariah Carey and Bow Wow help with vocals--as does jailed group member Flesh-N-Bone--on the latest comeback attempt from the trio. Jermaine Dupri and will.i.am are among the producers.
The second solo album for the Pulp frontman was produced by Steve Albini.
The second full-length solo release for the pop singer features a guest appearances from A$AP Rocky.
The debut full-length release for the duo of Ioanna Gika and Leopold Ross includes Asian instruments.
The Modesto, Calif. band has announced that it will break up after the release of this final 14-track album.

The full-length debut for the Los Angeles pop singer-songwriter features production and songs co-written by Tim Anderson, Lil Silva, Justin Parker, Shlohmo, Sohn, Totally Enormous Extinct Dinosaurs, and Jamie Woon.
The fifth full-length studio release for the Texas-born singer-songwriter was produced by Lee Townsend.
This is the third album for the Chicago-based band.

Bryce Goggin (Phish, Pavement) produced this final album for Dean Wareham & co., who have since announced their intent to disband. It includes a new version of the song "Astronaut" from the 2003 EP 'Close Cover Before Striking.'
This is the 70-year-old singer-songwriter's first studio album in nearly a dozen years.
The first release with original member Cee Lo in nearly 15 years for the Atlanta rap group includes guest appearances from Big Fraze, Big Rube, Janelle Monáe, and T.I.
The Sadies join up with John Doe to release their first album of country music together.
The third album for the Philadelphia band is its first on the Anti label.
The second full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from such artists as A$AP Mob, Big Sean, Chris Brown, Chuck D, Missy Elliott, Future, ScHoolboy Q, and Ty Dolla $ign.
The seventh full-length release for the Austin rock band was recorded live and produced by Ethan Johns.
The second full-length solo release for the pianist/composer features contributions from Kyle Crabtree, Scott Moore and Scott Morgan of LOSCIL.
The writing of the songs on the 11th studio release from the Canadian power pop band was divided between the four members.
This is the second group album (as cLOUDDEAD) for three of the founders of the indie hip-hop collective anticon: Why?, Doseone and Odd Nosdam.
The San Francisco noise-rockers' latest is a concept album about the Pied Piper-esque title character, who is based on the drawings of illustrator Ken Kagami.

Love Is Hell, Part 1 is one-half of the planned 'Love Is Hell' full-length that Adams had intended as his official follow-up to 2001's 'Gold' until Lost Highway refused to release it intact (instead encouraging the singer to record a more upbeat LP, 'Rock n Roll'). John Porter (The Smiths) produces.
Skull Ring marks Iggy Pop's first appearance with his original band The Stooges in 30 years, as they provide backing on four tracks here. Also guesting are members of Green Day and Sum 41.

Yup... Up's two-letter name signifies that this is indeed a brand-new Peter Gabriel studio recording, his first since 1992's 'Us.' The music goes in a now-typical multi-cultural direction, with input from gospel singers The Blind Boys of Alabama and the late Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan.
The 60's star offers up ten new tracks with the help of friends Pulp, Blur, Billy Corgan, Beck, and Dave Stewart.
Australian alt-country singer Kasey Chambers follows her acclaimed 2000 debut ('The Captain') with this sophomore effort. Lucinda Williams guests.
The second album from New York City dance-punk outfit Radio 4 utilizes the production work of DFA (U.N.K.L.E., David Holmes) to create a sound reminiscent of Primal Scream's 'XTRMNTR.'
The Icelandic band first studio album in four years is a collection of songs stemming from several uncompleted projects, including the original idea to create s choral album.
The sixth full-length release for the British rock trio was produced by Ric Ocasek.

recordname: Who Needs Actions When You Got Words
description: 'Actions' is the first album for UK grime artist Plan B (aka Ben Drew), who has drawn comparisons to both Eminem and The Streets' Mike Skinner (which often happens when you are white and kinda rap), although his music is more eclectic than either of those artists.

The 2020 solo release from the Beatles artist is remixed and covered by 3D RDN, Damon Albarn, Anderson .Paak, Beck, Blood Orange, Phoebe Bridgers, EOB, Dominic Fike, Josh Homme, Khruangbin, St. Vincent, and Idris Elba (only on the physical releases).
Atmosphere's Ant produces the Minnesota rapper's long-awaited follow-up to his 2003 debut 'Shadows On The Sun.'
The fifth release and the first major label full-length album for the New York-based singer-songwriter.
This is the second full-length release for the British electronic artist Sara Abdel-Hamid.
The sixth release with the Jicks for the former Pavement frontman was inspired by his move to Berlin and was produced with Remko Schouten.

The debut full-length release for the backing band for Anderson .Paak features guest appearances from .Paak , Kadhja Bonet, Daniel Caesar, Callum Connor, Chronixx, Conway, Jid, Miknna, Mac Miller, T. Nava, Benny Sings, Syd, T.I., Kali Uchis, Unknown Mortal Orchestra, Westside Gunn, and Joyce Wrice.

recordname: Love Is the Plan, The Plan Is Death
description: The latest album from the James Blackshaw finds the guitarist using a nylon six-string guitar instead of his usual 12-string steel guitar.
This is Pablo Diaz-Riexa's second album as El Guincho.
The sixth album for the rapper features guest artists such as Ludicris, Rihanna, Usher, Jay-Z, kayne West, Lil Wayne, Justin Timberlake, and John Legend.
The debut full-length solo release for the ex-Gossip singer was produced by Jennifer Decilveo.
Before forming the 1990s, Jackie McKeown and Jamie McMorrow were in The Yummy Furs, which once included two members of Franz Ferdinand.
The Josh Homme band fronted by Jesse Hughes releases its third album.
The 13th studio album from the English pop band of the '80s blends glam with disco and modern pop, melding the various genres together into a catchy collaboration.
This is the debut full-length release for the collaboration between Gold Panda and Simian Mobile Disco's Jas Shaw.
This is the fourth full-length solo studio release for the Grammy-nominated soul singer-songwriter.
This is the debut full-length release for the electronic project of Roger Sellers.
The second release for the solo project of Michael Lovett features the addition of Charlotte Hatherly and Sarah Jones as well as more influences from rock music.
The third full-length solo release for the Swedish singer-songwriter is his first in seven years.
The second release for the singer-songwriter features Rodaidh McDonald and a duet with Cat Powers.
The indie rock trio returns with its original lineup to release its first new album in 10 years.
The fourth album for the Danish rock duo was produced with Thomas Troelsen.
Frequent Will Oldham collaborator (and member of The Anomoanon) Dave Heumann offers the second album of rustic rock from his own project, Arbouretum.
The indie rock band led by Tim Kinsella reunited in 2012 after disbanding in 2002 and worked for 18 months to release its first studio release in 13 years.

Described as a companion piece to the earlier released Break It Yourself, it features one new track, two new versions of songs from Break It Yourself, as well as covers of songs by Alpha Consumer, the Carter Family, the Handsome Family, and Townes Van Zandt.
This is the second album for Anti label by the rap artist.

Dan the Automator, The Funky Homosapien, and Kid Koala return 13 years later with the follow-up to the sci-fi concept album about Deltron Zero and his fight against corporations. Guest appearances include: Damon Albarn, Black Rob, Zack De La Rocha, David Cross, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, The Lonely Island, Mike Patton, and Amber Tamblyn.
The fourth full-length release for the British rock quintet was recorded with co-producer Craig Silvey.

After walking away from his deal with Rough Trade Records due to alcohol and exhaustion two years ago, the Alabama singer-songwriter worked with the Civil Wars' John Paul White and the Alabama Shakes' Ben Tanner on his third full-length release.
The second album for the British alternative rock band was produced by Dan Weller.
The third album for the San Diego indie rock quartet sees the influence of the music of Pavement.
The blues guitarist's latest solo album features Carlos Santana and B.B. King as guests.
The fourth album for the indie rock band from Montreal.
The seventh full-length release for the British electro-pop duo was produced by Haxan Cloak and John Congleton.

The latest full-length release from Cowboy Junkies features covers of songs by such artists as David Bowie, Vic Chestnutt, The Cure, Bob Dylan, Gordon Lightfoot, Gram Parsons, The Rolling Stones, and Neil Young.
The latest solo release for David Pajo as Papa M features just acoustic guitars and drums.
The fifth full-length release for the British comedian/musician was recorded in part in his home studio.
The sixth full-length studio release for the punk-pop band was produced by John Feldmann and features guest appearances from blink-182's Mark Hoppus and Good Charlotte's Joel Madden.
The singer-songwriter's latest release from Sun Records is a cover album of hit songs that were originally recorded by such artist as Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis, and Elvis Presley.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Baltimore band is its first as a quartet with drummer Mike Lowry and was produced with Steve Wright.
The sixth full-length studio release for the hard rock band was produced by Andre Betts.
The second full-length release for the collaboration between Cate Le Bon and White Fence's Tim Presley was produced by Stephen Black and recorded in a house in the south of France.
The fifth full-length release for the Florida rock band that includes former members of Creed and Myles Kennedy was produced by Michael "Elvis" Baskette.
The R&B singer worked with Disclosure, Jimmy Napes, Naughty Boy, Sam Romans, Emeli Sandé, and Sam Smith during her month-long visit to London for her 13th studio release.

recordname: The Tragic Treasury: Songs From A Series Of Unfortunate Events
description: The first album for the latest "band" from Magnetic Fields' Stephin Merritt (he's pretty much solo here) is intended as a companion to Lemony Snicket's series of books.

recordname: Take Them On, On Your Own
description: The London-by-way-of-Los-Angeles-by-way-of-San Francisco rockers known as JAMC--er, make that BRMC--return with their second LP, which actually finds the group distancing themselves (at least a little) from the Jesus and Mary Chain-influenced sound of their debut.
The third full-length release for the Houston trio features a dub version of its 2018's Con Todo El Mundo.
Leslie Feist, Joan Jett, Josh Homme and Beth Ditto are among the guests on the electro-sleaze (and we mean that in a good way) artist's third LP.
The second full-length release for the indie-pop singer-songwriter was produced with Sam Evian.
The British folk group releases its debut full-length album produced by band member Paul Gregory.
The Babyshambles/Libertines lead singer releases his first solo album produced by Stephen Street.
The Canadian folk trio releases its follow-up to its self-titled 2009 album.
The fourth full-length release for the British indie rock band was produced with Laurie Latham.
Dear God, I Hate Myself is the art-rock band's first release featuring new band member Angela Seo (keys). The album also features contributions from producer/Deerhoof member Greg Saunier.
The debut full-length release for the London-based singer-songwriter was produced by Bill Ryder-Jones.
The second full-length release for the Dutch indie pop artist was co-produced with Deerhoof's Chris Cohen and Trey Pollard.
This is the debut release for the collaboration between Guillermo Scott Herren (aka Prefuse 73) and Michael Christmas.
The debut full-length release for the Spanish garage rock trio led by Diego Garcia was recorded in a week.
The third full-length release for the British soul singer-songwriter is her first in six years and was co-produced with her second husband, Steve Brown.
This is the second release for the Los Angeles-based rock band since they returned from disbanding in 1995.
The third full-length studio release for Casey Dienel was self-produced in a home studio in her parents' basement.
The latest release for the the British ensemble includes influences of jazz, rock, and world music with instruments such as kalimba, the koto, marimbula, and santur.
The sixth solo album for the singer-songwriter includes member of the Vaselines, Dr. Dog, Au Revoir Simone, Misty's Big Adventure, The Wave Picture, Johnny and the Sussex Wit, and Schwervon.
The second full-length album for the British indie rock band was produced by Steve Albini.
The Brooklyn-based alternative rock band--featuring former members of Hot Snakes and Drive Like Jehu--release their second full-length on Sub Pop.

recordname: Baseball Project, Vol. 2: High and Inside
description: The second album from the Baseball Project continues with more baseball-themed songs with guest singers such as Death Cab for Cutie's Ben Gibbard, Yo La Tengo's Ira Kaplan, Los Lobos' Steve Berlin, The Hold Steady's Craig Finn, and The Decemberists' Chris Funk and John Moen.
The band led by Rhett Miller releases the first volume of songs that were originally planned as part of a double album. Volume two is scheduled for a May 2011 release.
The debut album for the trio formed by The Bird And The Bee's Inara George, Lavender Diamond's Becky Stark, and Eleni Mandell.
Sweden multi-instrumentalist Emil Svanangen (aka Loney, Dear) makes his American debut with this re-release of his fourth album.
This new side project for Pedro The Lion's David Bazan finds that group's guitars replaced with synthesizers.

The legendary rocker's ninth album is a lowercase effort (song titles included), featuring her daughter Jesse on piano on the title track, as well as the same backing band that has been with her for the past decade.
The latest LP from the Chicago-based experimental indie-rockers returns the same four-piece lineup (led, as always, by Tim Rutili) from 2003's Quicksand/Cradlesnakes.
The Akron, Ohio guitar-drums blues duo (needless White Stripes comparison omitted) of Dan Auerbach and Patrick Carney recorded this sophomore effort in a single 14-hour session.
The fun-loving Britpop outfit, popular in the U.K. but unsuccessful to date in the U.S., returns with its fourth LP.
This debut album from the Richmond, Virginia band (featuring Maura Davis and members of Engine Down) was produced in part by Sparklehorse's Mark Linkous.
A 20-track compilation of B-sides, studio outtakes, and radio performances from the Mercury Music Prize-winning band.
The Scottish band's debut album was produced by Rich Costey and lead singer James Allen.
The second full-length release for the British indie trio was produced with Nicolas Vernhes.
The latest solo album from The New Pornographers frontman was recorded in Woodstock and features Neko Case as a guest vocalist.
The Canadian trio's latest release is a concept album about a young man's journey to fulfill his dreams and was co-produced with Nick Raskulinecz.
The second album for the British punk-rock band was produced by Garth "GGGarth" Richardson.
This is the third full-length album from the Canadian artist.
The third full-length release for the Canadian indie folk trio was co-produced by Matt Lederman and Leon Taheny.

The solo album of former Tulsa member (and current Lower Dens member), Carter Tanton, features vocals by folk artist Marissa Nadler and is said to have been inspired by David Bowie's song, "Wild Eyed Boy From Freecloud."
The second full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was produced by Dave Cobb.
The Danish quartet's second album weaves various music influences, such as jazz, techno, house, and rock, into its electro-pop sound.
'Virginia' is the second album for the cabaret-punk outfit fronted by Amanda Palmer.
This is the second album of country-folk-rock tunes for the Gainesville, Florida band led by John Orth.
The debut full-length release for the Australian singer-songwriter was co-produced with Adrianne Lenker.
Paul McCartney returns to record under the Fireman name with this third album produced with Youth.

recordname: Learn To Sing Like A Star
description: The singer/songwriter (and member of both Throwing Muses and 50 Foot Wave) returns with her seventh solo release.
The fourth full-length release for the Barcelona-based indie rock band was produced by Santi Garcia and Borja Pérez.

recordname: Between the Times and the Tides
description: The Sonic Youth guitarist's latest solo album produced by John Agnello features fellow Sonic Youth member Steve Shelly, Bob Bert, Jim O'Rouke, Nels Cline of Wilco, Irwin Menkin, Alan Licht, and John Medesk.
The 21st full-length studio release from the British electronic/industrial artist is a concept album about a post-apocalyptic world where much of it has become a desert.
The Florida punk rock band's fourth album was produced by Butch Vig.
Sean O'Hagan's first High Llamas album in four years sticks to his usual script of '60s-influenced pop.
Arctic Monkeys partners with producer James Ford for a third time for a fourth album of indie pop songs.
Rapper Snoop Dogg reinevents himself again as Snoopzilla for this funk project with Dâm-Funk.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Danish alternative rock trio is its first without guitarist Bo Madsen.
This is the second full-length release for the Japanese metal-pop trio of Suzuka Nakamoto (Su-metal), Moa Kikuchi (Moametal) and Yui Mizuno (Yuimetal.
This is the fourth album for the Portland, Ore. band fronted by Tim Putnam.
The first new release from the Arizona rock trio with its original lineup of Curt Kirkwood, Cris Kirkwood and Derrick Bostrom in 24 years.
The fist solo release from Pavement guitarist Scott Kannberg in eight years features guest vocals from The National's Matt Berninger and Broken Social Scene's Kevin Drew.
The fourth full-length release for the Danish singer-songwriter was self-recorded and produced.
The second full-length solo release from the Oasis singer features contributions from producer Greg Kurstin, Damon McMahon, Michael Tighe, and Andrew Wyatt.
The seven-track mini-album release from the South Korean boy band features a guest appearance from Halsey.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Southern California metal band is its first with former Bad Religion drummer Brooks Wackerman was produced by Joe Barresi.
The debut release for the collaboration between Tim Burgess and Peter Gordon features contributions from Ernie Brooks, Peter Zummo, Mustafa Ahmed and Nik Void.
The second full-length release for the Canadian punk quartet led by Kier Griffiths was produced by Ben Greenberg.
The fourth full-length release for the British hardcore band is its first without Steph Carter, who left in 2013 for his own band, Ghost Riders In The Sky.
Eight songs from Swedish electronic-pop duo's discography were rerecorded with their live tour arrangements.
The debut full-length solo release for James Kelly, the frontman of black metal band Altar of Plagues, was produced by the Haxan Cloak and includes influences from electronic, metal, and pop music.
The fourth full-length release for the Afropop-influenced indie pop band led François Marry was produced by Ash Workman.
The sixth studio release for the melodic thrash band was produced by Disturbed's David Draiman.
The debut release for the British quintet was self-produced by band guitarist Jerome Watson.
The second full-length release for the folk singer-songwriter was produced by Sean Kae.
The debut full-length release for the British punk band was produced by Brian McTernan.

Steve Reich's composition about the September 11 attacks was written for the Kronos Quartet. The album also includes the Mallet Quartet performed by So Percussion and Dance Patterns with Steve Reich and Musicians.
The LA-based band releases a blues-rock, heavy-sounding second full-length album.
The folk artist wrote, recorded, and produced the album of songs with the help of Mads Brauer.
The debut album for the Reading, England, quintet was produced by Gareth Parton.
The third full-length solo release for The White Stripes/The Raconteurs artist features contributions from C.W. Stoneking, Esther Rose and Ann & Regina McCrary of The McCrary Sisters.
The fifth full-length solo release for the experimental electronic artist is his first in nearly five years.
The band's third album is the first to feature its new keyboardist Alex Rose, who replaced Matt Bayles.
The fourth full-length release for the Michael Milosh project features the Danish National Girls' Choir and was mixed by mixed by Alan Moulder.
The first release in seven years for the rock band is its first with Daxx Nielsen on drums.
The holiday album from the R&B/soul singer and her band features both standards and original songs.
Slick Rick, The Neptunes, M.I.A., Tweet and Mary J. Blige are among the guests on Elliott's first new disc in two years. Longtime collaborator Timbaland produces just two tracks here.
The 14th full-length studio release for the British electronic band was produced by Simian Mobile Disco's James Ford.
The first of a planned series of acoustic solo releases for the Wilco artist features songs from his career with Wilco and his side projects.
This is the second full-length release for the British electronic duo of Gabe Gurnsey and Nik Void (drummer Dominic Butler left the band after the release of its debut in 2013).
When the music videos first appeared in 2010, the identity of the person(s) who was iamamiwhoami was unknown. It has since been revealed Swedish singer Jonna Lee is the person behind the music.
The sophomore album for the Los Angeles group.
Gillian Welch guests on Hitchcock's latest solo offering, produced by David Rawlings.
'Heroes' marks the third album for the ever-strange UK outfit, who self-produced the disc and handed it off to Nigel Godrich (Radiohead) for mixing.
Tom Jenkinson's latest full-length attempts to incorporate more of his live sound into the overall feel.
The distinctive-voiced singer hopes to rebound from the disappointing sales of her 2001 sophomore effort 'The Id' with this third LP, which includes Beck and Pharoah Monche among its guests.
American's favorite high school rockers have graduated and grown up, resulting in this, their fifth (and most mature) album to date.

This is the debut full-length release for the retro-pop band (think Cardigans or St. Etienne) founded by Lush guitarist/vocalist Emma Anderson and vocalist Lisa O'Neill. Many of the band's earlier singles appear here (in reworked versions), along with new material, all produced by Mark Van Hoen (Locust).
Fog is 23-year-old turntablist Andrew Broder, and this is his debut album, a cut-and-paste mix of various sounds combined with guitar and vocals.
Markus Popp returns with eleven untitled tracks of noise and sounds of skipping CDs. Some people like that.
Second full-length from the British production duo.
The debut full-length album for the Oxford, England-based band.
The second full-length release for the Welsh rock band was produced by Hookworm's MJ.
The Ted Leo-led rock band moves to Matador Records for its sixth album.
Produced by John Congleton (St. Vincent, Black Mountain, Polyphonic Spree, Explosions in the Sky), Golden Archipelago is Shearwater's third album released on Matador Records.

recordname: Out of Touch, In the Wild
description: This is the third release for the British five-piece led by Duncan Wallis.
The second solo release of country and electronic music for the former drummer of Pearls And Brass is his first on Sub Pop and was co-produced with Benjamin Balcom.
The Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter's first outing in five years is a loose concept album set in the year 1947.
The eigth full-length release for the Berlin-based electronic trio of Robert Lippok, Ronald Lippok, and Stefan Schneider features Arto Lindsay on three tracks.
After several days of streaming video of himself building a wooden staircase, Frank Ocean releases an 18-track visual album on Apple Music.
The second full-length release for the Pittsburgh rock band features guest appearances from Tim Midyett of Silkworm and Bottomless Pit, and Joe Casey of Protomartyr.
The fourth full-length release for the Oakland, California-based garage rock trio was produced by Sonny Smith of Sonny & The Sunsets.
The sixth release for the Canadian collective was produced by Pierre Chrétien and Jason Jakunas.
This is the third full-length studio release for the Los Angeles punk band led by Keith Morris.

The album mixes recording sessions from New York and Mali featuring such guests as Tunde Adebimpe, Bertrand Cantat, Ebony Bones, Kyp Malone of TV on the Radio, Santigold, Jake Shears of the Scissor Sisters, Theophilus London, and Nick Zinner of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs.
The third full-length release for the British indie pop duo of Rebecca Taylor and Charles Watson was produced by Colin Elliot.

recordname: Pieces Of The People We Love
description: The New York City dance-punk outfit returns with a sophomore album a full three years after their debut 'Echoes.' 'Pieces' sees them ditching The DFA for new producers Ewan Pearson, Paul Epworth and Danger Mouse.

Produced with Justin Niebank, the first country release for the singer-songwriter includes songs co-written with Al Anderson, Brandy Clark, Rodney Clawson, Chris DuBois, Luke Laird, Shane McAnally, and Brad Paisley.
Produced with Jamie King, the sixth studio album for the metal band is a sequel to its 2011 EP release The Parallax: Hypersleep Dialogues.
Recorded during a Christmas show in 2004, this live set includes a mix of solo and Smiths material.
King Midas Sound's 2009 album is redone by a variety of artists, including Flying Lotus, Gang Gang Dance, Nite Jewel, Hype Williams, Kode 9, and the Spaceape.
Iconoclastic country singer k.d. lang returns with her third Nonesuch effort, 2011's Sing It Loud.
The third full-length release for the Australian indie singer-songwriter was inspired by his relationship with Jemima Kirke and was produced by Jonathan Rado.
The second full-length release for the Canadian rock band was recorded live to tape over four days.
This is Matthew Herbert's first full-length dance release in eight years under the Herbert name.
This is the first release in seven years for the indie pop duo of Melissa Dyne and Khaela Maricich.
The third full-length release for the New York-born singer-songwriter was produced by Dan Carey.
The fifth album for the British indie rock band was recorded a cappella.
The fourth album for the Canadian rocker was produced with Digitalism, Simian Mobile Disco and Soulwax.
This is the eighth full-length studio release for the British electronic duo of Ed Handley and Andy Turner.
Stephin Merritt returns to his indie-pop side project with ex-Figures On A Beach keyboardist Christopher Ewen and Claudia Gonson for the trio's first full-length release in over a decade.
The duo make their debut as a trio and turn away from traditional dubstep sounds on their new album, creating a dense, complex collection of dance music.
A true solo effort, this self-titled release finds the 25-year-old Kweller handling all of the instrumentation himself for the first time.
This is the first full-length release in 11 years for the British experimental pop band.

recordname: It's Alright Between Us as It Is
description: The fourth full-length solo release for the Norwegian electronic producer features guest appearances from Grace Hall, Jenny Hval, and Frida Sundemo.
Dave Fridmann produced album number seven for the duo of Sam Coomes and Janet Weiss.

recordname: Drokk: Music Inspired by Mega-City One
description: Portishead leader Geoff Barrow releases his latest project, a soundtrack to the comic strip series, 2000 A.D with composer Ben Salisbury.
The third album for the Swedish indie rock band is the first with Polyvinyl.
The second full-length studio release for the Canadian artist features guest appearances from Lana Del Rey, Labrinth, and Ed Sheeran.
The singer-songwriter, dubbed "unobtrusively brilliant" by John Peel, releases his fifth LP.

Produced by Jenn Wasner and Andy Stack, the third full-length release for the singer-songwriter features contributions from Olivia Gerber, Stephen Steinbrink, Boy Scouts' Taylor Vick, and Lambchop's Kurt Wagner.
The 10th full-length release for Kieran Hebden as Four Tet features vocals from Ellie Goulding on "Baby."
The second collaboration between Aidan Moffat and RM Hubbert in 2018 features original Christmas songs as well as covers of Yazoo's Only You and Mud's Lonely This Christmas.
The debut full-length solo release for the B-52's singer features contributions from Marie Davon, Lemuel Hayes, Suny Lyons, and Ryan Monahan.
The second full-length release for the Swedish pop artist features guest appearances from Joe Janiak and Wiz Khalifa.
The debut full-length release for the Irish electronic producer Jack Colleran was recorded in Los Angeles.
The debut release for the African-electronic music project led by Eno Williams was produced by Max Grunhard, Leon Brichard, and Benji Bouton.
The London-based, Australian alternative rock quartet recorded parts of its second full-length release around the countryside and caves in the UK.
The self-released album from the San Francisco-based indie singer-songwriter was funded by Kickstarter and recorded on analog tape.
The 10th full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter was funded through PledgeMusic and includes guest appearances from Ben Harper, Jim Keltner, Juliette Lewis, and Joan Wasserman.
The debut release for the Dutch artist Cole Williams features guest appearances from Damon Albarn and DOOM.

recordauthor: Jello Biafra & the Guantanamo School of Medicine
description: The second full-length release for the punk band led by former Dead Kennedys frontman was produced by Marshall Lawless and Matt Kelley.
The second full-length collaboration between Kim Krans and her husband/guitarist Jonny Ollsin (with contributions from bassist Scott Hirsch) was produced by Dan Rossen of Grizzly Bear.

recordname: Krzysztof Penderecki: Threnody for the Victims of Hiroshima; Polymorphia; Jonny Greenwood: Popcorn Superhet Receiver; 48 Responses to Polymorphia
description: Radiohead's Jonny Greenwood collaborated on a collection of classical compositions inspired by Polish composer Krzysztof Penderecki's Threnody For the Victims of Hiroshima and Polymorphia.
The British indie-rock band releases its third album.
This is the debut LP for the New York-based indie-rock trio.
The third full-length release for the band led by Will Hart Hart features guest appearances from Jeremy Barnes, Peter Erchick, John Fernandes, AJ Griffin, Heather McIntosh, and Jeff Mangum.
The country legend's latest album was coproduced with Lou Bradley.
The second solo album for the drummer includes such guests as Devendra Banhart, Gil-Scott Heron, No Age, and Greg Saunier.
The latest full-length release for the Manchester-based electronic producer features guest vocals from Alison Skidmore.
The album is part of a multimedia project from the British artist better known as King Krule and his older brother Jack.
This is the debut full-length release for the British grime producer.
The first new release for the New York experimental band in seven years features contributions from Jorge Elbrecht and Ryan Sawyer.

The third full-length solo release for Liam Gallagher was produced by Andrew Wyatt and features contributions from such artists as Dave Grohl, Vampire Weekend's Ezra Koenig, Greg Kurstin, and Ariel Rechtshaid.
