The 17th release for the British metal band led by Rob Halford is its first without founding guitarist K.K. Downing.
The highly political singer-songwriter returns with his 13th studio outing, which includes a duet with Emmylou Harris and a love song ("Condi Condi") about the current National Security Advisor.
The 22-year-old Brooklyn-based singer-songwriter returns with 11 new tracks produced by Ethan Johns (Kings Of Leon).

'Shine' is the first solo album in more than a decade for Daniel Lanois, best known for his production work for artists such as U2, Peter Gabriel, Emmylou Harris, and Bob Dylan. Harris guests on vocals here, as does U2's Bono.
Bonnie Raitt's first new album in four years was produced by Mitchell Froom and Tchad Blake.
The fifth full-length release for the country-pop singer was produced by Mark Bright and Jay Joyce.
Produced by Dave Cobb, the fourth full-length release for the Nashville-based singer-songwriter features contributions from Tim Bergling, Johnny McDaid, Ed Sheeran, and Chris Stapleton.

recordname: Dreams Say, View, Create, Shadow Leads
description: A majority of the second album for Ponytail's guitarist Dustin Wong was live recorded.
This is Ben Harper's first solo album of soul, reggae, and rock since 2006.

The jazz pianist's latest album of original and cover songs features guest appearances by Bilal, Erykah Badu, Lalah Hathaway, Shafiq Husayn, Ledisi, Lupe Fiasco, KING, Chrisette Michele, Mos Def, Musiq Soulchild, Meshell Ndegeocello, and Stokley Williams.
Guest appearances by El-P, Cage, Breeze Brewin, Rob Sonic, and John Darnielle of The Mountain Goats are featured on Aesop Rock's latest album.
British alternative rock band Everything Everything's frontman Jonathan Higgs tried A.I. to help form lyrics for the quartet's sixth full-length release.
The seventh full-length release for the Canadian indie pop band was co-produced with Liam ONeil.
The fourth full-length studio release for the British artist features guest appearances from blackbear, Diplo, Juice WRLD, Lauv, serpentwithfeet, and Swae Lee.
The fifth full-length release of African-influenced music for Ahmed Gallab was self-produced.
This is the third full-length release for Brighton producer, Alan Myson.
The 20th full-length studio release for the Brooklyn duo of John Flansburgh and John Linnell was mixed by Patrick Dillett.

The San Francisco-based band shifts away from the country sound of its last album back to garage pop with its fourth release colored by Sonny Smith experience with a psychic and the death of his friend, Esme Barrera.
Self-recorded and produced, the latest release from the now five-piece band led by Carson Cox is its first with its two new members: Chris Horn and Elsner Nino.
The fourth release for the 2011 Grammy-winning Best New Artist is described as a more upbeat album with two cover songs.

recordname: Recording A Tape The Colour Of The Light
description: This is the long-in-the-making debut album for the instrumental Montreal band that shares two members (Sarah Neufeld and Richard Reed Parry) with the Arcade Fire.
The eighth full-length solo studio release for the British experimental singer-songwriter features influences from drone music, science fiction and cosmic horror comics.

After seven years working on their own projects, Pharrell Williams, Chad Hugo and Shay Haley return with the trio's fifth full-length release that features guest appearances from André 3000, Kendrick Lamar, Gucci Mane, M.I.A., Rihanna, Ed Sheeran, and Wale.
The second full-length release for the British indie rock band was produced by Edwyn Collins.
The album contains some of the recordings from five days of rehearsal before a concert by Afrobeat/Fela Kuti drummer Tony Allen with local Haitian and western musicians in Port Au Prince.
This is the debut full-length release for London-based artist James Page.

The electronic trio formed by Apparat (aka Sascha Ring) and Modeselektor (Gernot Bronsert and Sebastian Szary) worked in the studio for six months on the follow-up to the group's 2009 self-titled debut.
The third full-length release for the harp-playing singer-songwriter was produced by Joe Cocker.
The Grammy-winning jazz singer covers songs by the songwriters who lived in the Brill Building in the '50s and '60s.
This is the debut full-length album for the indie rock duo from San Diego, who were formerly called the Muslims.
The fourth album for the singer from Canada was coproduced with Jim Scott.
The producer and former Bad Seeds member returns with his first solo disc in four years.
Bernhard Fleischmann's latest work utilizes amplified guitar and other "conventional" instruments in an electronic context.
The English indie rockers garnered a lot of attention with this debut album, which combines elements of ska, dance and punk.
The second full-length release for the electronic-rock duo of Sarah Barthel and Josh Carter was produced by John Hill.
The debut full-length release for the Brooklyn art rock/post-punk group led by Ben Hozie was produced by Parquet Courts' Austin Brown.
The first release in over eight years for the Florida post-hardcore rock band led by Chuck Ragan and Chris Wollard was produced by Bill Stevenson and Jason Livermore.

'Underachievers' is the first U.S. release for the Glasgow, Scotland-based band, who mine some of the same musical territory as fellow Scots Belle & Sebastian (as well as drawing more than a few Nick Drake comparisons).
The full-length major label debut for Texas blues-rock singer was produced by Mike Elizondo.
The first full-length studio release in six years for Lucius features guest appearances from Brandi Carlile and Sheryl Crow.

The seventh full-length release for British electronic artist Simon Green as Bonobo features guest appearances from Miguel Atwood-Ferguson, Kadhja Bonet, Joji, OFlynn, Jordan Rakei, and Jamila Woods.
This three-track release is the debut collaboration between Body/Head (Kim Gordon and Bill Nace) and Aaron Dilloway.

The debut full-length solo release for the frontwoman of Mount Moriah features contributions from such artists as Phil Cook, Kathleen Hanna, Mary Lattimore, Tift Merritt, Angel Olsen, Amy Ray, and William Tyler.
The debut full-length release for the Scottish sextet includes songs inspired by Senegal poet Aby Ngana Diop, Liverpool's Kazimier club, and Glasgow's nightlife.
The fourth album for the Andy Cabic-led band was produced by Thom Monahan.
The second solo release for the Three Trapped Tigers pianist is a collaboration with Brian Eno, who suggested they use a device called the Moog Piano Bar to translate piano notes into MIDI sounds.
The second full-length release for the Nashville-based indie rock trio that includes Alicia Bognanno, Clayton Parker and Reece Lazarus was engineered and mixed by Bognanno.

The fourth full-length release for the Canadian band led by Stephen McBean was produced by Joe Cardomone with contributions from such artists as Daniel Allaire, Rob Barbato, Gregg Foreman, Stephen Kille, and J Mascis.

The latest concept album for the New York rock band is the first of a planned double album (The Afterman: Descension is scheduled for Feb 2013) about Sirius Amory's discovery of what is holding the Keywork together.
The debut full-length improvised collaboration between Marisa Anderson and Jim White was recorded in Mexico City and Portland, Oregon.
The second full-length release for Lorely Rodriguez features contributions from Blood Orange's Dev Hynes, DJDS, and Pional.
The latest release for the Martin Phillipps indie pop band was produced by Greg Haver.
The 36th full-length release for the Hall of Fame singer-songwriter from Belfast was self-produced.

recordname: Tumble Bee: Laura Veirs Sings Folk Songs for Children
description: Laura Veirs' children's album produced by Grammy-nominated Tucker Martine was inspired by the birth of their son. It features such guest performers as Colin Meloy of the Decemberists, Jim James of My Morning Jacket, and Bela Fleck.
This is the debut album for the duo of Euros Childs and Teenage Fanclub's Norman Blake.
Delta Spirit continue its Americana sound on the California band's second full-length album.
The third album for the Norwegian band features Robyn, Lykke Li, and The Knife's Karim Dreijer as guests.
Malcolm Burn (Shawn Colvin) produced much of this fifth studio album for the indie rockers.
'Dens' is the debut LP for England's Mystery Jets, who are led by vocalist Blaine Harrison and whose guitarist is Blaine's 55-year-old father, Henry.
The veteran singer-songwriter is still going strong nearly 40 years after launching his recording career.
'Reality' finds a now 56-year-old David Bowie working once again with longtime producer Tony Visconti. Included among the 11 tracks is a cover of Jonathan Richman's "Pablo Picasso."
First appearing on Jay-Z?s The Dynasty, rapper Freeway finally arrives with his full-length debut, which features appearances by Jay-Z, Snoop Dogg, Faith Evans, Nelly, and Mariah Carey.

What good's an Eminem movie without an Eminem soundtrack? It's not all Slim Shady here, though, as the soundtrack album incorporates other artists (Xzibit, Macy Gray, Jay-Z, Nas) in a mix of old and new tracks.
The man behind Built to Spill issues his first album under his own name, with a more acoustic, stripped-down, blues-influenced sound than you'll find on his BTS albums.
The Icelandic band releases a two-disc set of unreleased and acoustic songs.
The five-track release features rare and unreleased improvised songs from Sonic Youth between 2000 and 2010.
The second release for the 1960s-influenced Boston trio was produced by the Woods' Jarvis Taveniere.
The latest full-length studio release for the reggae group was produced by its frontman, Frederick "Toots" Hibbert.
The Icelandic singer-songwriter's second album was produced by Sigur Ros' Kjartan Sveinsson.
The second full-length album for the Canadian band is the conclusion to a trilogy of albums that began with the debut album The Pink Ghosts and the EPs Blankets and Tin Fist.
The legendary Canadian singer-songwriter and poet, now 70 years old, returns with his 11th studio album.
This is the debut full-length release for the New York art-rock four-piece, following a string of EPs.
The second release for the Brooklyn indie pop trio was co-produced by Nathan Michel and Matt Boynton.
The 17th full-length solo studio release for the rock and pop singer-songwriter was produced by Greg Kurstin (and one track produced by Ryan Tedder and Zach Skelton).
The latest soundtrack score for the Scottish post-rock band is for Jonathan and Josh Baker's sci-fi crime drama film.
The fifth full-length release for the British rock band led by Rou Reynolds was produced by David Kosten.

recordname: You Have Already Gone to the Other World
description: The sixth studio release for the indie duo of Jeremy Barnes and Heather Trost was produced by John Dieterich of Deerhoof and inspired by the 1964 film Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors.
This is the fourth solo album for the Pinback frontman.

The second full-length release for the British singer features production from Artwork, George FitzGerald, Geeneus, Jacques Greene, Joker, and Route 94 as well as guest appearances from Jessie Ware and Sampha.
This is the debut full-length release for the music project of producer David Wrench and Evangeline Ling.
The seventh full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter was self-produced.
The sixth full-length solo release for the Norwegian artist features folk songs as well as covers of songs from such artists as Joy Division and Lou Reed.
The debut full-length release for the trio that includes Dillinger Escape Plan's Greg Puciato, Josh Eustis, and Steven Alexander was produced by Justin Meldal-Johnsen.
Produced by Sodi Marciszewer, the album with influences from Afrobeat, Caribbean, and Latin music from the oldest son of Fela was recorded in Paris.
The debut release for Seattle rapper Macklemore and producer Ryan Lewis features such guests as Ab-Soul, Ben Bridwell of Band of Horses, ScHoolboy Q, and Allen Stone.
This is the expansive second album for the New York state emo outfit.

This disc marks the first new studio recording for the Jason Molina-led four-piece since he dropped the Songs: Ohia name. (Just to be confusing, however, the new band name was the title of the last Songs: Ohia album.)
The third full-length release for the Canadian electronic band led by Katie Stelmanis was inspired from her time living in Montreal and Mexico City.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Oregon indie rock trio was produced by Chris Walla.

After visa problems forced him to return to the United Kingdom, the rapper teamed up with rapper/producer Jneiro Jarel for this album featuring guest appearances from Damon Albarn, Beth Gibbons, and Khujo Goodie.
The first album for the British rock band in six years features Chrissie Hynde and a new lineup.
The fifth full-length studio release for the pop singer features guest appearances from Iggy Azalea and Sirah.
The second full-length release for the Indiana folk-influenced rock band was produced by Dave Cobb.
With the the departure of bassist Joanna Bolme, the Portland, Oregon-based indie rock band returns with remaining duo, Sam Coomes and Janet Weiss, for its ninth full-length release.
The Chicago four-piece release a follow-up to "The Ruminant Band" that is more atmospheric, yet still rooted in rock, with Eric Johnson at the forefront.
The third full length album for the rock band includes guest artists such as Sam Baker, Simon Chardiet, Daniel Collas, Mickey Finn, PowerSolo, and Those Darlins.
Guillermo Scott Herren (aka Prefuse 73), Eva Puyuelo Muns and Roberto Carlos Lange release the band's fourth album.
The eighth full-length studio release for the R&B singer/actor features guest appearances from Future, Rubén Blades, and Young Thug.
The Brooklyn-based rock trio releases its second full-length album.
Ethan Johns produced this sophomore album for southern rockers and brothers Caleb, Nathan, Jared and Matthew Followill. (OK, so Matthew is only a cousin, but he was still allowed to join the band.)
The second full-length release for the British hardcore punk band was mixed by Catherine Marks and recorded by Thomas Mitchener.
The Russian-born singer-songwriter's latest album was produced by Jeff Lynne, Mike Elizondo, David Kahne and Garret "Jacknife" Lee.
The soundtrack to the movie about Notorious B.I.G. features many of his singles and new songs sung by Jay-Z, Santogold, Jadakiss, Faith Evans and the late rapper's son CJ.
The third full-length release for the pop singer-songwriter was produced by Dan Auerbach and recorded live with a seven-piece band.
The mostly instrumental eight-track EP is the lastest release from the Montreal DJ/producer Mike Silver.
Robert Pollard reunites with Guided by Voices to release the indie band's first album of new material in eight years.

The debut solo release for The Walkmen frontman features guest contributions from Rostam Batmanglij of Vampire Weekend, Amber Coffman of Dirty Projectors, Morgen Henderson of Fleet Foxes, former bandmate Paul Maroon and Richard Swift of The Shins.
The latest album for the Chicago rock band was recorded live in Louisville, Kentucky, and Tokyo, Japan.
The punky, all-girl Toronto-based trio's debut was produced by MSTRKRFT.
The seventh full-length release for the Cincinnati alternative rock band led by Greg Dulli is its first album of new material since 1998's 1965.
The third full-lenght release for Virginia-based trio was produced by Doug Gillard.
The eighth album for the Japanese metal band includes the song Hageshisa To, Kono Mune No Naka De Karamitsuita Shakunetsu No Yami, which was featured on the Saw 3D soundtrack.
The seventh album for the Atlanta, Georgia rock band features their latest guitarist, Luther Dickinson from the North Mississippi Allstars.

The second full-length studio release for the North Carolina rapper features guest appearances from Chance the Rapper, Kevin Gates, Gucci Mane, Lil Baby, Migos, Nicki Minaj, Moneybagg Yo, Stunna 4 Vegas, and YK Osiris.
The third full-length solo release for the New Pornographers singer/keyboardist was co-produced by Colin Stewart.
The latest release for the experimental artist/producer was inspired by the city of New York.
The fifth studio album for the Scottish five-piece was produced, like its predecessor, by Tony Doogan.
This is the debut full-length release for the Leeds post-punk band.
The Chameleons' Mark Burgess worked on the second full-length release from the post-punk band led by Hether Fortune.
The Tears' debut album reunites Suede's Brett Anderson and Bernard Butler for the first time in over a decade.
The ninth full-length studio release for the British doom metal band was produced by lead singer Jus Oborn & guitarist Liz Buckingham.
The debut full-length studio release for the British artist Jordan Cardy features contributions from Damon Albarn, Graham Coxon of Blur and Mallory Merk.

The 13th full-length studio release for the British indie rock band features contributions from such artists as Sharon Horgan, Johnny Marr, Stephen Morris, Anton Newcombe, Ian Rankin, Kurt Wagner, and Paul Weller.

Curated by his mother, Ma Dukes, Dillatronic offers 41 rare instrumentals from the late Detroit hip-hop producer James "J Dilla" Yancey, with the focus being on his "electronic music influences," who are as much Kraftwerk as George Clinton. Case in point, the funky, slinky track seven included here -- none of the tracks are titled -- which slowly rocks back and forth like Clinton's solo hit "Atomic Dog," while the 26th cut comes off as a cross between Madlib and "Maggot Brain" with Funkadelic guitars spinning and swaying in a psychedelic manner. The latter track also strays from the "electronic music influences" concept, which happens with about a quarter of the album's tracks. Good thing too, as the chugging and organic track three is a much bigger surprise than the half-speed redo of "Trans Europe Express" that is track 20, plus the drifting, Janet Jackson-esque closer has little to do with electro but is likely to become a favorite with the target audience (a combination of the Dilla faithful, underground beatheads, and amateur MCs looking for mixtape productions). While the collection doesn't come with the purposeful feel of Donuts, it flows extremely well for a beat tape, and one released nine years after the artist passed. Add to that the amount of new flavors and unexpected twists (Was track 12 influenced by early dubstep? What was the plan for the dark and dense track 28?) plus crisp, clean recordings that beat the bootlegs, and Dillatronic is a necessary pickup for fans. ~ David Jeffries
The 22nd studio album for the singer-songwriter was self-produced (T Bone Burnett was credited as executive producer) and is his first release on the Republic Records label.
This is the full-length debut for the side project formed by Deftones' Chino Moreno Far's Shaun Lopez. and Chuck Doom.
The fourth full-length release for the Texas rock band is its first without singer Tim Smith, who left in November 2012.
Now based in Baltimore, the synthpop trio from North Carolina releases its first album on the Thrill Jockey label.
The debut full-length album for the rock band featuring members of Seattle's The Blood Brothers was produced by Steve Fisk
Kevin Barnes expands his musical experimentation with the latest release from this Athens, Georgia indie-pop band, adding R&B stylings to the mix with the appearance of guest vocalist Janelle Monáe.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles-based punk band features a guest appearance from K. Flay and was produced by Ricky Reed.
This is the second full-length album of self-described instrumental hip-hop from the Brooklyn-based electronic producer Brian Lindgren.
The rock quartet worked on writing the songs over the Internet before coming together to record the album.
This is the second album for the French synth-rock outfit, who attracted some international acclaim with their 2000 debut 'United.'

Over two years in the making, 'Let It Come Down' is the UK band's first album of new material in four years. It utilizes over 100 musicians (including an orchestra and choral singers), although the music was entirely written and arranged by guitarist Jason Pierce.
The sixth full-length release for Tim Presley was produced by Ty Segall.
The UK band (now named in triplicate in the U.S.) fronted by former British Sea Power member Eamon Hamilton recorded this brief second album in Nashville.

recordauthor: ...And You Will Know Us by the Trail of Dead
description: The ninth full-length studio release for the Austin-based alternative rock band was produced by Chris "Frenchie" Smith.
The Danish trio traveled to an abandoned Russian settlement near the North Pole to record some of the music for its fourth release.

The charity CD features artists such as Bruce Springsteen, Bob Dylan, David Bowie, and Paul McCartney, each of whom picked one of their classic songs to be sung by such musicians as TV on the Radio, Elbow, Beck, Lily Allen, and Franz Ferdinand.

'Runaway Found' marks the debut LP for the London (by way of New Zealand) rock outfit led by 19-year-old singer/guitarist Finn Andrews. Their epic sound has drawn the band comparisons to many of the usual suspects (Coldplay, Radiohead, the Verve).

recordname: Coal Miner's Daughter: A Tribute to Loretta Lynn
description: The tribute album to the country legend which also includes Loretta Lynn herself, features Lee Ann Womack, Alan Jackson, Martina McBride, Faith Hill, Carrie Underwood, Gretchen Wilson, Lucinda Williams, Steve Earle, Allison Moorer, The White Stripes, Kid Rock, Paramore, Reba McEntire, Sheryl Crow, and Miranda Lambert singing many of her hits.
This is the debut full-length release for the Spanish garage rock band from Madrid led by Ana Perrote and Carlotta Cosial (who began as the band Deers).
The third full-length release for the London-based duo of Jack Cooper and James Hoare was recorded in their home studio.
This is the latest album for the New Jersey-based rap duo.
This is the second full-length release for the Dutch producer.
The second album for the band was produced by Spoon's Britt Daniel.
The fifth full-length release for the British electronic band led by Joe Mount features guest appearances from Mixmaster Mike and Robyn.
The Super Furry Animals Welsh musician's third solo album, full of influences -- ranging from Latin to lounge music -- is both inventive and mellow.
Los Angeles-based singer Inara George teams with multi-instrumentalist Greg Kurstin for their first LP as The Bird And The Bee, which blends '60s pop, tropicalia, and electronic elements.
The first full-length studio release in nearly 18 years for the reformed British ska-punk band sees the return of Terry Hall to the line-up.
The second full-length release for the British artist Kwesi Darko features elements from blues, rap, and rock music.
This is the third full-length release for bass artist/producer James Boyle.
The first album by Yo La Tengo under the Condo Fucks band name.
The fourth full-length release for the Berlin-based electronic producer was recorded in Berlin, London, Los Angeles, and New York.
The sixth full-length release for the folk rock band led by Taylor Goldsmith was produced by Jonathan Wilson.
The English singer-songwriter returns with his fourth album in four years.
Based out of Portland, the experimental rock trio's latest album delivers more of its unconventional instrumentation and showcases its genre-defying capabilities.
These 14 new tracks from the Los Angeles punk band mark the 20th anniversary of the group's first LP.
The Brooklyn boy-girl duo make their major-label debut with throwback pop songs.
The third full-length release for Luis Vasquez as Soft Moon was written and recorded while in Berlin and Venice, Italy.

recordname: The Sound The Speed The Light
description: This is the fourth album for the punk rock band from Boston.
The second full-length release for the indie folk band led by Ben Schneider was originally started as an idea for a feature film.
The second release from Trevor Powers was produced by Ben H. Allen.
This is the first solo release in North America in over 10 years for the Japanese producer Keigo Oyamada.
The seventh full-length studio release for Canadian pop-punk artist Avril Lavigne features guest appearances from blackbear, Mark Hoppus and Machine Gun Kelly.
The debut full-length solo release for the frontwoman of The Ettes was co-produced with Andrija Tokic.
The third full-length release for the Idaho singer-songwriter was recorded in Britain with Ali Chant.
The third full-length release for the British indie rock band was produced by Rory Atwell.
This 15-song live set from Conor Oberst & co.'s 2005 tour is heavy on material from 'I'm Wide Awake, It's Morning' and includes covers of Elliott Smith and Feist.

recordauthor: Someone Still Loves You Boris Yeltsin
description: The indie-pop quartet's third album was produced by Death Cab for Cutie's Chris Walla.
The debut release for the project formed by Ex-Cult's Chris Shaw, Ty Segall and Charles Moothart features guest appearances from Mikal Cronin, Cory Hanson of Wand, and Denee Petracek of VIAL.
'Absence' finds the acclaimed singer-songwriter once again collaborating with Eric Fisher. Crooked Fingers' Eric Bachman guests.
The third full-length solo release for the Los Angeles singer-songwriter/producer features guest appearances from Father John Misty, Lana Del Ray, Laraaji, and Lucius.
The third full-length release for Obaro Ejimiw as Ghostpoet features guest appearances from Etta Bond, Melanie De Biasio, Lucy Rose, Nadine Shah, and Paul Smith
The collaborative project of the California rap collective Anticon and German experimentalists The Notwist return with a new album of genre-bending music.
Mixed by Tucker Martine, the latest release from the alt-country singer-songwriter was written using an electronic autoharp and an octave-shifting pedal.
This is the first album for London's 24-year-old, one-man-garage-band Tom Vek.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles-based indie rock duo of Cleo Tucker and Harmony Tividad was produced with David Tolomei.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Sacramento dance punk band features production from Jim Eno and Patrick Ford.
The Virginian metal band's follow-up to its Grammy-nominated 2006 album, "Sacrament," was produced by Josh Wilbur.
The sixth full-length release for the Welsh band was recorded in Portugal with producer John Goodmanson.
The third album for the NY-based experimental rock group.
The third full-length release for the Chicago band was inspired by the rock albums released in 1968.

recordname: I'll Never Get Out of This World Alive
description: The politically active singer-songwriter returns with another album of country rock, produced by T-Bone Burnett.
The debut full-length release for the London-based all-female instrumental quartet Los Bitchos was produced by Franz Ferdinand's Alex Kapranos.
The second full-length release for the Irish post-punk band Silverbacks was produced by Girl Band's Daniel Fox.
The ninth full-length studio release for the Chicago punk band features production from Bill Stevenson, Jason Livermore, Andrew Berlin, and Chris Beeble.
This is the fifth studio release for the Los Angeles noise rock duo fo Randy Randall and Dean Spunt.
The fifth full-length release for the experimental artist Tom Krell was co-produced by Oneohtrix Point Never's Joel Ford.
The 13th full-length studio release for the R&B singer-songwriter features guest appearances from DJ Khaled, Missy Elliott, Kaytranada, Quavo, and Kanye West.
The fourth full-length release for the British actor/singer-songwriter features contributions from Cosmo Sheldrake and Dave Tattersall.
The debut full-length solo release for Ween's Mickey Melchiondo features four instrumentals.

recordname: How to Be a Human Being
description: The second full-length release for the British band was inspired people telling stories.
The debut full-length release for the Canadian indie rock quartet was recorded by Josh Korody and mixed by Alex Newport.
The sixth full-length studio release for the country rock singer-songwriter was originally intended to be part of a double album with 2014's Single Mothers.
The 11th full-length release from Will Oldham contains reworked versions of songs from 2011's Wolfroy Goes to Town.

recordauthor: Lee Bains III & the Glory Fires
description: The second full-length release for the Alabama Southern rock band led by Lee Bains III was produced by Tim Kerr.
The eighth release for the French artist best known for his work on the Amélie soundtrack was inspired by Iceland and the islands of Brittany.
The second full-length release for the Swedish indie project of Maria Lindén and Fredrick Balck was produced, written and mixed by Lindén.
The debut release for the collaboration between Juliana Hatfield and Nada Surf's Matthew Caws was produced with Tom Beaujour.
The 14th full-length release from the Arizona alternative rock band was described by singer Curt Kirkwood as "blown-up folk music."
Jon Barthmus worked both at home and in the studio with David Wrench for his second indie pop release.

The Australian duo of Nick Littlemore and Peter Mayes, who were signed onto Elton John's management company after hearing their debut, reworked some of Elton John's songs from the 1970s on this release.
The death of singer/guitarist Dave Okumu's mother influenced the second full-length release for the London, England-based trio.
The second release for the Brooklyn indie trio led by Jorge Elbrecht was more of a collaborative effort than its 2010 debut.
The trio, who worked on the tours of Lauryn Hill, Alicia Keys, and 50 Cent, releases its debut album.
The abstract hip hop Anticon musician returns with a new album of experimental rap.
The latest album for the artist is a solo acoustic guitar album that covers some classic pop songs from 1960 to the 1970s.
The Swedish trio's newest album highlights their fondness for blending noise rock with indie pop.
The latest album for the Washington DC death metal group was produced by Peter Wichers of Soilwork.
The Los Angeles band led by Michael Fitzpatrick goes for 1960s soul on its debut album.
Paul Manley returns as a producer for the rock band's second full-length album.
This is the second album for the Swedish electronic quartet.
This is the first album of new material in more than 35 years for the Brazilian group.
This double CD set contains unreleased and rare tracks from singer-songwriter Samuel Beam.
The third album for the English quartet was produced by Paul Savage.
The Grammy-winning singer returns with her latest album featuring ballads and bossa nova.
The compilation album features tracks from a variety of indie-rock/folk musicans to benefit Red Hot Organization, a charity for HIV/AIDS.
The debut album for the Montreal trio was produced by Justin Vernon.
Album #2 for the in-demand singer-songwriter includes duets with Jay-Z and Jennifer Hudson.
This is the first studio recording in three years for the Grammy-winning bluegrass act.
Talib Kweli and Redman are among the guests on this solo outing for Sermon, half of the legendary rap duo EPMD.

This 19-track live CD from the former Son Volt and Uncle Tupelo member includes two new songs, 15 tracks culled from his three solo discs, and covers of Neil Young and Pink Floyd. It was recorded during his tour in the fall of 2003 while he was backed by a five-piece band (Canyon).
The number in the title indeed refers to the total running time of the Finnish electronica duo's latest album, which consists of a whopping four CDs of all-new ambient experimental music.

This entertaining electronica-with-vocals debut by France's Marc Nguyen Tan (aka Colder) is informed by the last 25 years of electronic music, especially 70's and 80's artists such as Cabaret Voltaire and New Order.
El-P and Mr. Lif guest on Aesop Rock's second LP for the Def Jux label.

A 16-year-old white British girl singing covers of American soul classics? Odd as it may sound, that is the recipe for a hit, as evidenced by this debut album for Dover, England teenager Joss Stone, who tackles works by everyone from Aretha Franklin to, well, the White Stripes.
The Seattle hard rock band's sophomore album was produced by Phil Ek (Modest Mouse, Built To Spill).

recordname: Long Walk Home: Music From The Rabbit-Proof Fence
description: Philip Noyce's period film about Austrialia's Aboriginal people, "Rabbit Proof Fence," serves as the inspiration for Peter Gabriel's return to recording for only the second time since 1992's 'Us.' Gabriel turns to Aboriginal music throughout the album, but don't expect any true "songs" from this work, which consists chiefly of longer, moody, instrumental pieces with a world music flavor.
The second release for the duo of Molly Hamilton and Robert Earl Thomas was produced by Kevin McMahon.

recordname: We All Want the Same Things
description: The third full-length solo release for The Hold Steady frontman was produced by Josh Kaufman.
This is the second album in six months for the British grime artist.
The sountrack to Belle & Sebastian's Stuart Murdoch musical movie of the same name, which is scheduled to be filmed in 2010.
The Wu-Tang members latest release is long overdue  the fifth solo album from this hip hop legend clearly demonstrates his unique lyrical style.
The 10th full-length studio release for the California metal band was produced by Greg Fidelman.
The second full-length release for the Canterbury psych-rock quartet was self-produced.

Herbert's first disc in two years is a sample-driven concept album about the relationship of food to politics, society and celebrity. It is best consumed while reading the detailed album website, rather than as a stand-alone piece of music.
The latest installment in Thirsty Ear's Blue Series features prolific indie hip-hop artist Mike Ladd, backed by pianist Vijay Iyer and drummer Guillermo E. Brown.

The Clienteleâs 2009 album Bonfires on the Heath was one of the best, most hauntingly beautiful records of the bandâs impressive career. So strong that it spawned an equally wonderful EP made up of songs recorded at the Bonfires sessions that were deemed suitable for the album itself. Hard to believe that they couldnât find room for the title track "Minotaur" as its fragile melody and sweetly swaying dynamics would have fit in perfectly. The same with the bouncing and sweet "Paul Verlaine"; it would have been one of the more memorable tracks there. That these songs were indeed left off only points out how good Bonfires was, and how easily the Clientele concoct note-perfect autumnal pop. Add in a moodily drifting cover of The West Coast Pop Art Experiment's creepy ballad from the late 60s,âAs the World Rises and Falls,â a couple of tracks that hit the usual Clientele sweet spot between heartbreak and tender melancholy, and a long spoken word ramble from leader Alasdair MacLean, and you have a record that rises above stopgap or left-overs status. Minotaur is as essential as anything else the band has released and whether as part of Bonfires or on its own, the record stands as a welcome addition to their legacy as one of the great indie pop bands of their era. ~ Tim Sendra
The actor/singer/songwriter (and father of recording artists Martha and Rufus) is joined by Bill Frisell (and others) on his first disc in five years.
This is album nubmer five for the UK rockers led by Gaz Coombes.
James Jackson Toth's latest album is his first on the Young God label.

The second full-length release from the brother duo of Guy and Howard Lawrence features guest appearances from Kwabs, Lion Babe, Lorde, Miguel, Nao, Gregory Porter, Jordan Rakei, Brendan Reilly, Sam Smith, and The Weeknd]
The second full-length studio release for the British indie pop band led by Dan Smith was produced with Mark Crew.
This is the debut album for Mauro Remiddi under the name Porcelain Raft.
The latest release for the San Francisco garage rock band led by John Dwyer is not a sequel to an album named Putrifiers (this is the first one).
The British band's fourth studio album was produced by its lead singer Paul Butler.
The debut release from the British indie rock band was produced by Pulp's Steve Mackey.
The debut full-length release for the British singer-songwriter features production by Rodaidh McDonald, Mura Masa and Paul O'Duffy.
The second full-length release for the Oklahoma indie band led by Cameron Neal was produced by Thom Monahan.

recordauthor: J. Roddy Walston and the Business
description: The third full-length release for the rock band was co-produced by Mark Neill and Matt Wignall.
This is the debut for the trio of Josh Homme (Queens of the Stone Age), Jesse Hughes and Timmy VanHamel, who, in case you were wondering, sound like neither The Eagles nor death metal.
The latest album from the alternative rock band led by Anton Newcombe was recorded in Berlin with session musicians and features the return of original band member, Matt Hollywood.
This is the second album for the New York indie rock band led by Juan Wauters.
The 11th album for the jam rock band features a cover of Vic Chesnutt's "This Cruel Thing."

The incarcerated rapper won't be touring for a while, but that didn't stop him from releasing his first album in four years, which features collaborations with Just Blaze, Cam'ron, The Neptunes, Snoop Dogg and Buckwild.
One of two releases from the Rhode Island alternative rock band, Vol. 1 features 10 acoustic folk tracks.
The debut full-length release for German producer Marius Lauber was self-recorded and produced.

The rapper's second album is missing contributions from the Dr. Dre / Eminem / 50 Cent clan who helped power 'The Documentary' to success, but it does feature production work by Kanye West, Just Blaze and Swizz Beatz.
The Bay Area post-punkers get political on their third album, which was recorded without departed guitarist Sara Jaffe.
The second full-length release for Irish rock band Pillow Queens was written over three months and recorded by returning producer Tommy McLaughlin.

The fifth full-length solo release for Chaz Bear (he officially changed his name from Chaz Bundick) was created when he had an identity crisis and started listening to music including Daft Punk, Frank Ocean, and Oneohtrix Point Never.
The eighth studio album from the rapper features guest appearances from such artists as 2 Chainz, Marsha Ambrosius, Big K.R.I.T., Estelle, Pharrell, Wale, and Wiz Khalifa.

recordname: The Long Shadow of the Paper Tiger
description: The Chicago-based indie band move toward a more electronic sound on its first album without guitarist Jeff Carrillo.
The second compilation album for the electronic duo includes a new track, 'Keep My Composure' which features Spank Rock.
Willie Nelson and Merle Haggard's tribute to Django Reinhardt and Jimmie Rodgers was produced by Buddy Cannon.
The Slint and Tortoise guitarist's second solo album under his given name expands on the sound of his first by adding a rhythm section into the mix.
The second album since the band returned in 2006 was produced by their first producer, Todd Rundgren.
This is the debut full-length release for the Norwegian duo of Henriette Motzfeldt and Catharina Stoltenberg.
This is the debut full-length release for Atlanta electronic producer Michael Rathbun as Distal.
Jeremy Barnes is backed by additional musicians on this second eclectic AHAAH disc, which encompasses styles from folk to klezmer to mariachi.
After much speculation and delays, the R&B artist's eighth full-length release was released for free on Tidal.
The debut full-length release from Robert Hood under his DJ alias Floorplan includes elements of gospel, house, jazz and techno music.
The third collaboration between 9th Wonder and Buckshot includes guest appearances by Dyme-A-Duzin and Rapsody.
The British singer-songwriter releases her second album of folk music.
Janine Rostron, otherwise known as Planningtorock, returns with another dark, electronic album.
Howe Gelb leads a group of Danish musicians in his latest album.
The debut full-length release from the New York indie pop duo of Kay Kasparhauser and Lulu Landolfi features ukeleles and a song about a TV character in Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.
Zooey Deschanel and Matt Ward return with their second album together, which features two cover songs.
The effects of World War I is the theme for the 19-song cycle that originated as a project for the Imperial War Museum from the British rock band.
The ninth full-length studio release for the duo of Dan Auerbach and Patrick Carney was recorded in Nashville and is their first album in five years.
The fifth full-length release for the French artist was recorded in a small chapel in Tarn-et-Garonne and at La Chartreuse, a monastery turned-artists residence near Avignon.

Originally set to be released in 2002 before being shelved by MCA, the sixth full-length posthumous release for the Detroit rapper featured production from such artists as Bink, Hi-Tek, Madlib, Nottz, Pete Rock, and Kanye West.
The debut solo full-length from the Ariel Pink's Haunted Graffiti, Cass McCombs, and Deerhoof's guitarist was recorded in Vermont.
Originally intended as an EP, 'Warrior,' at seven tracks and 45 minutes, now stands as the Brooklyn band's second full-length release.
The Scottish band led by Gary Lightbody (also leader of the Reindeer Section) returns with a third LP.
Marc Bianchi continues his indie pop/electronica solo project Her Space Holiday with this latest 10-song release.

A showcase for their record label Star Trak, 'Clones' is a compilation of 22 Neptunes-produced and/or performed tracks, featuring A-list artists such as Nelly, Busta Rhymes, P. Diddy, Ludacris, Snoop Dogg and Nas.

This "green album," produced by Ric Ocasek, is actually the second untitled album for the Los Angeles band, not to be confused with 1994's "blue album." The album is the band's first since leader Rivers Cuomo's graduation from Harvard -- in fact, it is their first since their 1996 sophomore effort, 'Pinkerton,' which alienated some fans with a shift toward an angrier sound.
The seventh full-length studio release for the experimental trio was produced by Randall Dunn.
This is the first album of new material in 25 years from the power pop quartet and its first with the original members in 30 years.
This is the Irish band's first album without Brian Crosby, who left to pursue other projects.
The third full-length release from the Chilean trio was self-recorded with additional synth sounds from Atom TM.

The U.K.'s eclectic music group -- led by founding member/beatmaker Ian Parton -- fuses funky rhythms, hip hop, soul and noise rock together for a melding of styles with pop sensibilities still in tact.
The duo's fourth album includes vocals from Linda Lewis, Lady Marga, and a chorus of 30+ African orphans (hey, we don't make this stuff up).
This is the sixth full-length release for the New York-based duo of Alexis Krauss and Derek Miller.
The fifth full-length release for the Jason Quever music project was recorded mostly in his San Francisco home studio.
A solo project from Cleveland's Dylan Baldi, Cloud Nothings' debut is full of poetic teen angst and lo-fi pop melodies.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Scottish rock trio was produced by Rich Costey.
The second solo release from former Appliance member James Brooks was inspired by various location in Europe and was recorded with only one electric guitar.
The sophomore album for the rap duo includes guest artists Estelle, Buckshot, Bun B, and The Cool Kids.
This is the fourth album for the duo of Richard Dorfmeister (of Kruder & Dorfmeister fame) and Rupert Huber. Vocals are handled by a variety of guests, including Chris Eckman (The Walkabouts).
The sixth release for experimental electronic project of Jaime Fennelly features contributions from Janet Beveridge Bean, Jim Becker, Haley Fohr, and Jon Mueller.

recordname: Dances in Dreams of the Known and Unknown
description: This is the 13th studio release for the Swedish rock band led by former Lungfish singer Daniel Higgs.
This is the debut album for the lo-fi indie band led by Dustin Payseur.
The San Diego indie rockers return with an 11-track set that ditches the Latin elements of the previous record but retains their moody, cinematic sound.
The fifth solo release for the Eagles drummer features guest appearances from Vince Gill, Merle Haggard, Mick Jagger, Jamey Johnson, Alison Krauss, Miranda Lambert, Martina McBride, and Dolly Parton.
The fifth release for the British experimental folk collective is its first recorded with all six members present at the studio.
Rick Rubin produced the first album in nine years for the blues rock trio from Texas.
Hiatt's 20th studio album was recorded in Nashville and produced by Kevin Shirley (Led Zeppelin, Aerosmith, The Black Crowes).
The sixth full-length release for Canadian indie rock band Arcade Fire is its final one with Will Butler, who left the band after the album was completed.
The third full-length release for the British artist was produced by Dave Okumu and features contributions from Jay Electronica, Kwabs, Jamie Lidell, Jordan Rakei, Jamie Woon, and Henry Wu.
This is the debut album for the Portland, Oregon-based band led by New Zealand-born Ruban Nielson of the Mint Chicks.
The Battles band member releases his latest solo album on the Warp label.

The latest release for the New Jersey indie rock band features covers of songs by the Cure, the Lovin' Spoonful, Darlene McCrea, the Parliaments, Sun Ra, and Hank Williams, as well as reworkings of its own older songs.
This is the first release on Ninja Tune for Berlin-based electronic artist Travis Stewart.
The rocker's third solo disc has only one Heartbreaker (Mike Campbell) in tow, with the rest of the instrumentation handled by Jeff Lynne (who also produces) and Petty himself.

recordname: Good Apollo, I'm Burning Star IV, Volume One: From Fear Through The Eyes Of Madness
description: This is the third emo-sci-fi album from the prog-rock foursome fronted by Claudio Sanchez.

recordname: Memory of a Cut Off Head
description: The 20th full-length studio release for John Dwyer is the first since 2005 credited under the OCS name.
The fifth studio album for the group from Georgia.
This is the second album for the Pennsylvania stoner-rock outfit.
The fifth full-length release for the North Carolina rap artist feature tracks about addiction and rap culture.

The third release for the comedy rap trio of Andy Samberg, Akiva Schaffer, and Jorma Taccone includes guest appearances from Billie Joe Armstrong, Lady Gaga, Hugh Jackman, Kendrick Lamar, Adam Levine, Robyn, Solange, T-Pain, Justin Timberlake, Too $hort, Kristen Wiig, and Pharrell Williams.
The second release from the collaboration between Mobb Deep's Prodigy and The Alchemist includes guest appearances from Action Bronson, Domo Genesis, Havoc, Raekwon, and Roc Marciano.
This is the debut full-length release for the London-based eight-person indie pop collective.
The triple album is the second of the band's "Thank Your Parents" trilogy of releases.
Beta Band founder Gordon Anderson (also of Lone Pigeon) reunites with most of his former bandmates for this new, equally quirky project.
Rick Rubin produced this double-disc, 28-song set for the veteran Los Angeles rock outfit.
The debut full-length release for the British singer-songwriter the was produced by Charlie Andrew.
The eighth full-length release for the Virginia rock trio was recorded without computers.
The follow-up to his 2004 album Solo Piano was recorded over 10 days in Paris.
The debut full-length release for the British psychedelic five piece band was produced by Nathaniel Lennox Jr.'s.
The debut album for the ex-Noah And The Whale member was nominated for the 2008 Mercury Prize.
The third album for the Mexican electronica artist Fernando Corona.
The trio (which includes Fountains of Wayne's Adam Schlesinger) return with their first new album in four years, produced by Steve Osborne.
This is the third album for the indie rock outfit led by Armistead Burwell Smith IV (formerly of 3 Mile Pilot) and Rob Crow.
The Atlanta alternative band release a third album of grunge-y indie-pop.
The latest full-length studio release for the Australian psychedelic rock band features elements from blues music.
This the third album for the Canadian folk trio includes a cover of Prince's "When Doves Cry."
The seventh full-length release for the North Carolina prog metal band was produced by Jamie King.

recordauthor: Bruce Springsteen & The E Street Band
description: The Boss is back with his E Street Band.
The fifth release for the solo project of Real Estate's Matt Mondanile was produced by Rob Schnapf.
The second full-length release for the Austin-based indie pop band was produced by Danny Reisch.

Robert Glasper took master takes and outtakes of Miles Davis' work and produced new songs with vocals from Erykah Badu, Bilal, Hiatus Kaiyote, Illa J, Ledisi, KING, Laura Mvula, John Scofield, and Stevie Wonder.
This sophomore disc finds the New York foursome moving a bit further into 80s synth-pop territory.
The first new release in 21 years for the British rock band was produced by DJ Erol Alkan and mixed by Alan Moulder.
Fleetwood Mac's famed songwriter and guitarist returns with another solo release that was recorded entirely in his home.
The seventh studio album from Drake is a surprise release and features a guest appearance by 21 Savage.

recordname: There Existed an Addiction to Blood
description: The third full-length studio release for the Los Angeles experimental rap trio features guest appearances from Ed Balloon, Benny The Butcher, Sarah Bernat, Counterfeit Madison, Elcamino, Robyn Hood, La Chat, and Pedestrian Deposit.
This is the debut full-length release for the collaboration between South African producer Okzharp and Die Antwoord's Manthe Ribane.

recordname: I'm Rich Beyond Your Wildest Dreams
description: The second full-length release for the Nashville pop-punk six-piece band was produced by Kevin McMahon.
The fifth release for Mat Sweet as Boduf Songs includes more guitars and electronics.
R. Kelly's latest release is a continuation of the 1950-70s R&B and soul music he explored on his 2010 album, Love Letter.
This is the fourth solo album for the Moldy Peaches singer.

Producer T-Bone Burnett compiled this collection of traditional Americana, country and blues tunes to complement Anthony Minghella's Civil War epic. Among the performers here are Alison Krauss and the White Stripes' Jack White.

Techno pioneer Richie Hawtin returns with his first Plastikman album in five years. Unlike his DJ sets, 'Closer' is a dark, minimalist, challenging affair (note how often the word "paranoia" pops up in reviews).

No, it's not actually a soundtrack, but it is--shockingly enough--the legendary German electronic band's first new studio recording since 1986's 'Electric Cafe.' While the title track "Tour De France" was released as a single in 1983 (and is found here in four new versions), the remaining 8 tracks are brand new compositions.

The seventh album for the Minnesota alt-country outfit features a smaller-than-usual lineup of songwriter/vocalist Gary Louris, bassist Marc Perlman and drummer Tim O'Reagan, joined by new guitarist Stephen McCarthy. Matthew Sweet and Jakob Dylan guest.

This is the debut album for psychedlic British indie-rockers Electric Soft Parade (actually two teenage brothers, Tom and Alex White), drawing comparisons to everyone from Grandaddy and the Charlatans to Teenage Fanclub and Buffalo Springfield.
The fourth album from Bob Wratten under the Trembling Blue Stars name features yet another new lineup (although Annemari Davies does return for a couple of tracks).
This is Bill Callahan's follow-up to 2000's acclaimed 'Dongs of Sevotion.'

recordname: G.O.A.T. Featuring James T. Smith: The Greatest of All Time
Personality (One Was A Spider, One Was A Bird)
description: This is the second album for the Australian band led by Luke Steele.
The sixth album for the Danish duo was produced by Richard Gottehrer and singer Sune Rose Wagner.
The fifth full-length solo release for Moderat's Sascha Ring is his first as Apparat since 2013's Krieg und Frieden (Music for Theatre).

Originally, the album was to be released with a book of photographs by director David Lynch and vocals by such artists as The Flaming Lips, Super Furry Animals' Gruff Rhys, Jason Lytle, the Strokes' Julian Casablancas, Frank Black, Iggy Pop, the Shins' James Mercer, Suzanne Vega, Vic Chestnut, The Cardigans' Nina Persson, and David Lynch.
This two-disc set culled from live performances in San Francisco focuses mainly on material from the singer-songwriter's two most recent albums.

The Silent League is the new orchestral pop outfit for Mercury Rev touring keyboardist Justin Russo. On this debut disc, Russo and the other five permanent group members were joined by Grasshopper from Mercury Rev, Interpol drummer Sam Fogarino, and Grand Mal's Bill Whitten.

recordname: Last Night All My Dreams Came True
description: The final release for the British rock band features 13 of its hit songs recorded live in studio over two days.
This is the third full-length release for the Brooklyn psychedelic pop band.
'Let It Go' is the country star's first album in three years.

recordname: In the Pit of the Stomach
description: Unlike the Scottish rock band's debut, which was recorded in eight days, the second album was recorded in three weeks.
The debut solo music project of former Yuck frontman Daniel Blumberg was produced by Neil Hagerty of Royal Trux and The Howling Hex.
The fifth full-length release for the Americana singer-songwriter was co-produced with Adam Bednarik and recorded live.

recordname: In the Mountain in the Cloud
description: The Portland-based band releases its sixth studio album of psychedelic rock.

The 14-track mixtape from Dev Hynes was self-produced and features guest appearances from Arca, BennY RevivaL, Gangsta Boo, Ian Isiah, Joba, Kelsey Lu, Porches, Project Pat, Justine Skye, Tinashe, and Toro y Moi.
The debut full-length solo release under the real name of the former member of Yuck member was recorded live in five days with Billy Steiger, Tom Wheatley, and Jim White.
The debut full-length release for the Swedish-based rock band was produced by Dan Carey.
The fourth release for the Chicago rapper features guest appearances from Hannibal Burress and Kool A.D.

recordname: Live at the Great American Music Hall, San Francisco Aug 31-Sept 1 2011
description: The second live release for the slide guitarist is a collaboration with The Corridos Famosos band and recorded from two nights at San Francisco's Great American Hall in 2011.

recordname: What We Saw from the Cheap Seats
description: The sixth studio album for singer-songwriter Regina Spektor was produced with Mike Elizondo and includes songs she had until now, only sung live.
The debut album for the Sydney, Australia-based producer was influenced by the films of Norman McLaren.

recordname: The Soul of All Natural Things
description: The first release in 44 years for the psychedelic folk singer was co-produced by Chris Price and Fernando Perdomo.
The solo debut album of Deerhunter's Lockett Pundt.
The fifth full-length studio release for the New Jersey rock band was self-produced and mixed by Death Cab For Cutie's Chris Walla.
The third full-length release for Atlanta-based quartet was produced by Randall Dunn and Ben Greenberg.

recordname: Bobbie Gentry's the Delta Sweete Revisited
description: Phoebe Bridgers, Vashti Bunyan, Rachel Goswell, Norah Jones, Marissa Nadler, Beth Orton, Margo Price, Laetitia Sadier, Hope Sandoval, Kaela Sinclair, Susanne Sundfør, Carice van Houten, and Lucinda Williams provide vocals to the indie rock band's reimagining of Bobbie Gentrys 1968 album.
Beatnik & K-Salaam produced this debut collaboration between California hip-hop artists Murs and Fashawn.
Ne-Yo's latest effort takes on the influence of themes and character archetypes found in sci-fi fantasies and comic books and structures them around a musical plot to create a daring concept album.
The band's sixth album is inventive and dreamy, shifting in sounds using strings, harpsichords, and dulcimers to combine its psychedelic lullabies with folk rock.
The fourth full-length release for the Los Angeles-based singer includes contributions from Kendrick Lamar, Jessie Ware, and Pharrell Williams.
The debut solo full-length release for the White Fence artist under his real name was produced by Cate Le Bon.
Recorded over four years, this electronic release from the Mouse on Mars member features contributions from Dylan Carlson, Markus Popp, Kathy Alberici, and Taigen Kawabe.
The third full-length release for the Icelandic composer was orchestrally arranged by Nico Muhly and features the vocals of Agent Fresco singer Arnór Dan Arnarson on four tracks.
Two members from the electro-rock group Simian reform and release their own debut album.
This is the third full-length release for Ellis Ludwig-Leone chamber pop solo project-turned seven-piece indie rock group.
This is the second volume of the compilation of electronic music recorded in the 1980s.
This is the second solo album for the New Pornographers' Carl Newman.
The Dallas-based alt-country quartet releases its seventh studio album.
The second full-length release for the Swedish Iranian R&B artist was executive produced by No I.D.
The debut full-length release for the Los Angeles-based indie pop trio of Crisanta Baker, Matt Lowell, and Sam Stewart was produced by Death Cab For Cutie's Chris Walla.
The San Francisco-based trio releases its first album on the Kill Rock Stars label after a successful release of its self-titled debut.
Recorded in Hoboken, this New Jersey band continues their post-punk/new wave sound with their first collection of new music in nearly 19 years.
DiFranco breaks from her usual DIY practice by enlisting Joe Henry to co-produce this latest release.
This is the third release in 2012 for the Robert Pollard-led band that boasts the original lineup that played together between 1992 and 1996.
The Australian rock trio releases its first album as PVT, after an American band claimed legal rights to the name Pivot.
The singer-songwriter/actor's latest album is again produced by Don Was and features Bob Dylan on the backing vocals of the title track.
The English rock quartet releases its third album on its own label, Nul Records.

recordname: None of Us Are Getting out of This Life Alive
description: The first full-length release in nearly 10 years for the British rapper features guest appearances from Oscar #Worldpeace, Hak Baker, Dapz on the Map, Donae'O, ELIZA, Greentea Peng, Rob Harvey, IDLES, Kasien, Jimothy Lacoste, Chris Lorenzo, Ms Banks, Jesse James Solomon, and Tame Impala.
The seventh full-length release for the Canadian indie rock band was produced by Justin Meldal-Johnsen.
Produced by Mike Sapone, the seventh full-length studio release for the alternative rock band was inspired in part by music from such artists as Tom Petty and Bryan Adams.
The second full-length release for the British electronic pop trio was produced by David Wrench and Dave Eringa.

The third full-length release for the German experimental electronic trio of Daniel Brandt, Jan Brauer, and Paul Frick features guest appearances from such artists as Gudrun Gut, Nina Kraviz, Jamie Lidell, and Om'Mas Keith.
The female Brighton, England trio (with backing music by The Cassettes) reinvents the 1960s girl group for a new century with this debut LP, which features the lead single "Pull Shapes."
The second full-length release for the indie pop band led by Avi Zahner-Isenberg was self-produced.
Low, The Drums' Jonny Pierce, and The Raveonettes' Sune Rose Wagner appear as guests on the third full-length release for the Danish producer.
This is the latest album for the California-based indie rock trio.

Thom Monahan produced the Los Angeles-based country-rock band's first album in nearly 12 years and it features contributions from Ariel Pink; Neal Casal, Darran Rademaker of The Tyde, Dan Horne, and Jen Cohen.
The veteran rocker's first release since recovering from a brain aneurysm includes contributions from Emmylou Harris and Spooner Oldham.
The fifth full-length release for the Irish singer-songwriter features guest appearances from Jeff Beck and Jools Holland and was produced by T-Bone Burnett.
The debut full-length release for the R&B/hip-hop artist features guest appearances from Roman GianArthur, Nana Kwabena, Janelle Monáe, and St. Beauty.
The third full-length release for French artist Ludovic Navarre features Malian instrumentation and influences of jazz.
The latest album for the John McCauley's band Deer Tick is its first with former Titus Andronicus guitarist Ian O'Neil.
Sigur Ros' Jon Thor (Jonsi) Birgisson and his boyfriend Alex Somers release their first album together.

Born in France and now residing in Berlin, Miss Kittin (aka Caroline Herve) has provided vocals for a variety of electronica producers, including Felix Da Housecat and The Hacker. Here, she works with producers Tobi Neumann and Thies Mynther.
The Eels fifth album finds head Eel Mark Oliver Everett (aka "E") injecting more humor into his otherwise dark alt-rock tunes.

This debut release from Anti-Pop Consortium rapper Beans continues the experimental, genre-defying approach to hip-hop of that now-defunct group, mixing intelligent lyrics with cutting-edge production.

If you're even reading this, you most likely already know the life story of Queens' Curtis Jackson (aka 50 Cent), whose first attempt at rap stardom in the mid 1990s ended in a brutal attack that almost cost him his life. In recent years, however, 50 Cent was lucky enough to hook up with Eminem (who signed him) and producer Dr. Dre, which resulted in a track on the 8 Mile soundtrack and now this, his much-anticipated first full-length release.
The fifth album for the British metalcore band includes guest appearances by Jon Green of Deez Nuts, Oli Sykes of Bring Me The Horizon, and Drew York of Stray From The Path.

The fourth full-length release for the singer/producer was co-produced with Jeff Bhasker and features guest appearances from such artists as Bruno Mars, Mystikal, Tame Impala's Kevin Parker, Stevie Wonder, and Andrew Wyatt. The lyrics come from an unlikely source: novelist Michael Chabon.
The six-song EP was recorded during the same time frame as 2009's Pigeons and was produced by the band's bass player Jen Turner.
The debut album for the band that includes System of a Down's Daron Malakian and John Dolmayan.
The sixth full-length release for the Kansas-based singer-songwriter was recorded in Texas with producer Brad Cook and completed remotely during the pandemic lockdown.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Damon Albarn's animated band features guest appearances from George Benson, Jamie Principle and Snoop Dogg.
The debut full-length release for the Los Angeles surf/psych rock band who met while working at Amoeba Records was produced by Nick Waterhouse.
The debut full-length release for the Brooklyn trio of Julia Cumming, Nick Kivlen, and Jacob Faberwas produced by Matt Molnar.

The debut full-length solo release for the indie singer-songwriter features contributions from Warpaints Stella Mozgawa and Wye Oaks Jenn Wasner and was recorded with John Agnello and Richard Formby.
The latest release for Neil Hagerty's Howling Hex project was recorded over eight days and was produced by Clay Jones.
The third full-length release for Archy Marshall as King Krule was inspired in part in his move away from London.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Canadian singer-songwriter was mixed with Rob Heaney.
The third full-length solo release for the British electronic artist features contributions from Erick Legrand and Nina Walsh.
the 13th release for the avant-garde Norwegian trio of Arve Henriksen, Helge Sten (aka Deathprod) and Ståle Storløkken was recorded from the music coming out from its stage PA system.

recordname: One Day All of This Won't Matter Any More
description: The fourth full-length release for the British indie pop duo of Charles Watson and Rebecca Taylor was produced by Matthew E. White.
This is the second full-length studio release for the London-based group led by Kushal Gaya.
The third full-length release for the singer-songwriter singer was inspired in part by her life in California (she has since moved to a farm in Iowa).
The latest full-length release for the Glasgow-based techno producer Alex Menzies features his own vocals.
Produced by Glyn Johns, the debut solo release for the Heartbreaker member includes support from Don Was, Ethan Johns, Jeremy Stacey, and Blake Mills.
The eighth album produced by Paul Bryan for the singer-songwriter is influenced by the pop music of the 1960s and 70s.
The solo debut for the drummer of WhoMadeWho was inspired by both the film, Blade Runner, and the California body of water the album is named after.
This is the solo debut full-length album for the Cliffie Swan (formerly known as Lights) member.
Originally planned as a double album before it was split into two albums, the second volume is also produced by Salim Nourallah.
The latest album features such guests as Edan, Mr. Lif, and members of the Dap-Kings.
Tony Hoffer (Beck) produced this first album for the Brighton, England four-piece.
This is the debut for the new band led by Dinosaur Jr.'s J. Mascis (here on drums), joined by members of psych-rockers Feathers.
The third full-length release for the New York experimental rock trio is its first in four years.
The Scottish singer-songwriter's third studio release combines country-tinged blues with bits of folk-rock and dance textures to create a contemporary, upbeat album.
Bryan Ferry re-recorded 13 songs from Roxy Music's catalog as well as his own solo work as jazz instrumentals.

recordname: Regions of Light and Sound of God
description: The debut solo release for My Morning Jacket's Jim James was inspired by Lynd Ward's 1929 graphic novel God's Man.
The debut full-length release for the soul band led by the Denver-based singer-songwriter was produced by Richard Swift.
The debut full-length release for the Canadian quartet of Kieran Adams, Carmen Elle, Paul Mathew, and Joseph Shabason was co-produced with Roger Leavens.
The Philadelphia native releases her fourth studio album of soulful pop and R&B.
'Needle' is the Morr Music debut for the German duo of Ronald Lippok (who is also in To Rococo Rot) and Bernd Jestram.
The fourth album for the Tony Dekker-led group.
British composer Leo Chadburn, who has worked with such artists as Patrick Wolf and Saint Etienne, releases a more pop-oriented album as Simon Bookish.
The second full-length release for the experimental electronic producer was influenced by the events at Ferguson as well as the Occupy and Black Lives Matter movements.
The fifth full-length release for the singer-songwriter Shara Nova was inspired by such artists as Carl Craig, Patti Smith, The White Stripes, and Stevie Wonder.
The debut full-length release for the Los Angeles-based electronic features guest appearances from Najee Daniels, Shacar, Syd, and SZA.

'Experience' is certainly evident here as former dB's Chris Stamey and Gene Holder are joined by all three members of Yo La Tengo, Caitlin Cary and producer Mitch Easter for a trip through material by the likes of Television, Cream and the Yardbirds (as well as some originals).
The second full-length release for Ernest Greene was produced with Ben H. Allen.
The seventh full-length studio release for British indie rock band Foals features production from Dan Carey, John Hill, Miles James, and A. K. Paul.

recordname: You Know I'm Not Going Anywhere
description: The fourth full-length release for the Pennsylvania indie rock band was produced with Keith Abrams.
The debut full-length release for the London-based quintet features songs about masculinity, repression, violence, and western capitalism.
The 13th full-length studio release for the Welsh alternative rock band was produced by Dave Eringa.
The duets album between British singer-songwriter Teddy Thompson and American singer-songwriter Kelly Jones was produced by Mike Viola.
This is the debut full-length release from London-based electronic producer Archie Fairhurst as Romare .
The second full-length album from the psych pop Australian band was self-produced.
The eighth solo release for the pop singer, better known as one half of Yazoo, was produced by Guy Sigsworth.
The Jamaican producer releases his latest album, produced with Andrew W.K.
Husband Steve Earle lends a hand on the singer-songwriter's latest release.
The 14th full-length studio release for the British electronic artist was recorded in Berlin.
They Might Be Giants with co-producers The Dust Brothers come with their latest rock album after a children's album for Disney in 2005.

The fifth full-length release for New York electronic producer Alexis Georgopoulos is his first for the Mexican Summer label and features elements of psychedelic jazz, pop, kosmische, and African music.
Sleepy Sun, the California rock band who most recently guested on UNKLE's Where Did The Night Fall, releases the follow-up to its 2009 debut.
The debut full-length release for Beth Jeans Houghton as Du Blonde was produced by Bad Seed and Grinderman member Jim Sclavunos.
The fifth full-length release for the Philadelphia-based experimental rock band was produced by Mike Mogis.
The fourth full-length release for the Canadian singer-songwriter was produced by Jim James.
The fourth full-length release for the Kentucky alternative rock band was produced by Dan Auerbach.
The fifth full-length release for the indie-pop rock band was self-produced by James Mercer.
With just Angus Andrew at the helm, the eighth full-length release for the now solo act was recorded in Australia and mixed by Gareth Jones.
With this full-length album, Ween move away from their electro-heavy "Friends" EP released earlier this year.

The second solo release for the drummer of WhoMadeWho includes guest appearances from his WhoMadeWho bandmates Jeppe Kjellberg and Tomas Høffding as well as Nina Kinert, Sleep Party People, and Luke Temple.
The self-produced release for the former 10,000 Maniacs singer is her first album of original songs since 2001's Motherland.

Justin Vernon was so impressed with Sean Carey's ability that he was invited to be a part of Bon Iver's touring band. Now comes Carey's solo debut album recorded at his own home and Vernon's studio in Wisconsin.
The latest album for the emo rock band was produced by Neal Avron.

recordname: Devin Dazzle And The Neon Fever
description: The producer and electroclash artist returns with a proper follow-up to 2001's 'Kittenz and Thee Glitz.' Guest vocalists include the titular Neon Fever as well as James Murphy (the DFA).
The seventh LP for the Sean O'Hagan-led indie-pop band features backing vocals from the late Mary Hansen (Stereolab) and does away with drums on all but a handful of tunes.
The only "rock" act signed to Peter Gabriel's Real World label, Akron, Ohio native Joseph Arthur returns with his third album.
This is the alternative metal band's follow-up to their hit 1998 self-titled debut. Rick Rubin produced the 14-track effort.

Similar in sound to 1995's adventurous 'Wrecking Ball,' this album of original Harris tunes features guest appearances from Bruce Springsteen, Dave Matthews and Jill Cunniff (Luscious Jackson), among others.
This Brazilian dance-rock outfit may be "Tired Of Being Sexy," but that didn't stop Sub Pop from making them the first South American addition to its roster. This is their debut.
The Weakerthans' lead singer releases his debut solo full-length album.
Portishead's Geoff Barrow and Adrian Utley produced this fourth LP for the UK retro-rockers.
The latest release for the Alabama rock artist features songs inspired by the electro-pop music of the 1980s.
The second album in the band's Nomad series contains covers of Vic Chesnutt songs.
Produced with Shane Stoneback and Ben Allen, the emotions around a breakup is the central theme of the second full-length release from the Brooklyn pop duo of Madeline Follin and Brian Oblivion.
This is the third full-length album for the San Francisco-based indie rock band.
The properly-hatted New York City four-piece make their debut with this ambitious CD.
The album is the final release for Oneida's Thank Your Parents trilogy.
This is the first album of new material in six years for the rock band led by Glenn Danzig.
The eigth album for the indie rock band formed in Chicago was recorded in three months.
Nigel Godrich produced the latest eclectic release for the prolific Los Angeles-based artist, which is more varied and uptempo than their previous collaborations.
This is the third full-length album for Dayve Hawk as Memory Tapes.
The 12th full-length release for the Canadian power-pop band features three songs written by each of its four members.

The covers release from the debut collaboration between Flo Morrissey and Matthew E White features songs from a variety of artists including Leonard Cohen, Barry Gibb, Frank Ocean, Frankie Valli, and the Velvet Underground.
The Seattle producer's debut album features such guests as MF Doom, Young Buck, Brother Ali, Busta Rhymes, and Prodigy.
The debut album for the group is led by the Unicorns' Alden Penner and Arcade Fire member, Brendan Reed.
Their 18th album overall, 'Snakes' is the Canadian trio's first studio outing since 2002's 'Vapor Trails.' Nick Raskulinecz co-produced.

The third full-length studio release for the Southern California artist features guest appearances from Kadhja Bonet, BJ The Chicago Kid, J. Cole, Dr. Dre, Kendrick Lamar, Norelle, Pusha T, Q-Tip, Cocoa Sarai, Snoop Dogg, and The Last Artful, Dodgr.
The fourth full-length release for the British electronic producer features guest vocals from Prurient and the Braids' Raphaelle Standell-Preston.
This is the debut release from the collaboration between the Packway Handle Band and Jim White.
The second full-length release for the indie pop duo of Kacey Underwood and Alice Costelloe was produced by Rory Attwell.
The indie pop band releases its first album since the 2007 death of drummer San Fadyl.
Graham Sutton produced this sophomore set for the English band fronted by Greg Gilbert.
This is the debut full-length release for Swedish electro-pop duo of Malin Dahlström and Gustaf Karlöf.
The first album for the Iranian producer in over eight years is also her first under the Warp label.
The tenth studio release for the Eddie Vedder-led rock band was produced by Brendan O'Brien.

recordname: You Can Have What You Want
description: The third album for the indie-pop band led by Jason Quever.

This is the debut full-length release from the rock supergroup that features Sleater-Kinney's Corin Tucker, R.E.M.'s Peter Buck, The Minus 5's Scott McCaughey, The Fastbacks' Kurt Bloch, and King Crimson's Bill Rieflin.
The follow-up to the band's second album was produced by Rob Cavallo.
The fourth full-length solo release for Here We Go Magic's frontman was recorded in an upstate New York cabin with backing from Dirty Projectors' Mike Johnson and We Go Magic bandmate, Eliot Krimsky.
This is the Chicago-based psychedelic band's first album as a quartet.
Dave Alvin collaborates with a female group on his latest album.
The rock quartet from Nottingham releases its debut album.
The latest release from the Detroit garage rock band led by Mick Collins was inspired by 1970s Bubblegum pop music created by Jerry Kasenetz and Jeff Katz.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn noise-rock duo of Andrya Ambro and Sarah Register emphasizes melodies.
The latest 40th full-length release for the singer-songwriter features six new original songs as well as eight covers of classics jazz and R&B songs.
The singer-songwriter from New Zealand releases his second solo album.
After two EPs, the band led by Nine Inch Nails's Trent Reznor releases its full-length debut album.
The solo debut for the electronic artist Tobacco also features Aesop Rock
The second release for the Minneapolis indie band led by Channy Leaneagh includes a duet with Justin Vernon.
The second full-length release for the British indie-pop group was produced by Marta Salogni.
The Baltimore indie pop band is now a duo with just Jana Hunter and Nate Nelson on its fourth full-length release.
The fourth full-length release for Will Wiesenfeld as Baths was mastered by Daddy Kev.
The debut full-length release for the Birmingham Conservatoire graduate includes influences from gospel, jazz, R&B, and soul music.
The indie rock trio's second album was produced by John Parish.
The R&B/soul singer covers songs by such British rock legends as the Beatles, Elton John, Led Zeppelin, Pink Floyd, The Who, and the Rolling Stones.
The German rock group returns with original members Jean Herve Peron, Werner "Zappi" Diermaier, and Ulan Bator's Amaury Cambuzat.
After touring with the Pixies, Black Francis (aka Frank Black) returns to solo work on his latest album.
The third album for the North Carolina duo of Ivan Howard and Kelly Crisp is more synth-driven than previous efforts. The Shout Out Louds guest.
After 20 years and over 20 albums, Dayton, Ohio's Guided By Voices (led throughout its duration by Robert Pollard) is calling it quits with this final release.

This is the second solo release for English singer-songwriter Gordon Anderson, who was a member of the original Beta Band lineup (and author of several of their hits including "Dry The Rain"). He tends to get labeled an "eccentric" by the music press, with frequent Syd Barrett comparisons.

This debut disc for Shady Records signee and Detroit native Obie Trice was produced by pals Dr. Dre and Eminem (along with the ubiquitous Timbaland) and features appearances from Em as well as 50 Cent, Nate Dogg and Busta Rhymes.

'Sheath' marks the first album for the groundbreaking Sheffield, England techno outfit since 1996's 'Advance.' Gez Varley has left the duo, leaving Mark Bell (who in recent years has kept busy producing the likes of Bjork and Depeche Mode) as the sole member.

The fourth release for the Portland, Ore. four-piece is a trip through 70's glam- and 80s synth- rock, complete with contributions from Duran Duran's Simon Le Bon and Nick Rhodes (the latter produced much of the album), Chic's Nile Rogers, Bowie/T. Rex producer Tony Visconti, and, well, Evan Dando.

Sarah Cracknell, Bob Stanley & Pete Wiggs build on the sparse, cool electronica sound of their last album, 'The Sound of Water,' with this latest release. Doves guitarist Jez Williams makes a guest appearance.

Hull, England-based production duo Fila Brazillia have gained acclaim for their remixing work (Lamb, The Orb) and string of club-oriented releases which mix trip-hop, breakbeat, house, funk, hip-hop, and drum'n'bass. This studio effort (on the band's own 23 label) follow's last year's mix album 'Another Late Night,' and is their first album to feature vocals, courtesy of Steve Edwards, who sings on four tracks.
