Melding post-rock and electronica, German trio To Rococo Rot have garnered attention by releasing a series of well-received albums on indie labels (most notably 1999's 'The Amateur View') and producing Saint Etienne's 'Sound of Water' LP. Here, they combine with New York turntablist I-Sound for their first release on Mute Records.

Scott Herren's latest Prefuse 73 album features about as many guest appearances as you can fit on a single compact disc, including contributions from The Books, El-P, Ghostface, Aesop Rock, Broadcast, RZA, Beans and Café Tacuba.
This is the first solo album for the former frontwoman of the folk-rock band Espers.

The Portland, Oregon, indie band's fifth album features guest appearances by Lavender Diamond's Becky Stark, My Brightest Diamond's Shara Worden, My Morning Jacket's Jim James, Robyn Hitchcock, and the Spinanes' Rebecca Gates.
The second full-length release for the Philadelphia-based indie rock band led by Kristine Leschper was produced by John Congleton.
The second release for the Los Angeles avant-garde hip-hop trio was produced by William Hutson and Jonathan Snipes.
The fourth album for the singer-songwriter was produced by Jacquire King.
The seventh full-length solo release for the Raconteurs member was self-produced.

The debut release for Martha Wainwright and her half-sister Lucy Wainwright Roche features lullabies sung by their mothers as well as songs by such artists as Woody Guthrie, Jimmie Rogers, and Townes Van Zandt.
The latest album from the German electronic rock duo includes cover versions of D.A.F.'s Sato Sato and John Lennon and Yoko Ono's Do the Oz.
The latest release for the indie band led by ex-Lync member Sam Jayne is its first on Isaac Brock's label.
The fourth full-length release for Katie Stelmanis' music project features contributions from Cecile Believe, c_RL, Rodaidh McDonald, and Joseph Shabason.
Jakob Dylan & co.'s fifth long-player was produced by Brendan O'Brien.
The collaboration between Dungen and Woods was recorded in a week after performing together at the Marfa Myths festival in 2017.
The third release for the Brooklyn garage punk band was recorded in Virginia with Nikhil Ranade.
The third album for the Swedish rock band features Daniel Higgs of Lungfish, who is the newest member of the group.
Two former members of the band Elkland comprise the New York indie rock quartet The Drums, who releases the follow-up to its 2009 EP "Summertime!"
The second full-length release for the Australian trio was recorded in Los Angeles with producer Lars Stalfors.
The third full-length studio release for the electro-pop duo of Amelia Meath and Nick Sanborn was produced by John Hill in Los Angeles and completed in North Carolina.
The fourth full-length solo release for The Strokes' guitarist was produced by Gus Oberg.
The son of Afobeat legend Fela Kuti releases his latest album which features more piano and trumpet.
The Brooklyn-born hip-hop artist's third album features such guests as UGK, Justin Timberlake and Norah Jones.
The Slovenian collective re-records the songs from The Sound of Music film as well as some North Korean songs (they performed in North Korea in 2015).

The group that includes Slowdive's Rachel Goswell, Mogwai's Stuart Braithwaite, Editors' Justin Lockey and his brother, James give a new re-worked instrumental version of its 2015 self-titled release.
The second full-length release for the British quartet led by Nathan Hewitt features guest appearances from Liv Willars and Heather Perkins.
The second release for the British singer-songwriter was produced by Joe Chiccarelli and features Band of Horses and Jesca Hoop as guests.
The British bass artist's instrumental release integrates hip-hop with a variety of music styles including electronic, Latin, jazz, and soul.
Tell Me is 21-year-old songwriter Jessica Lea Mayfield's sophomore effort and is produced by the Black Keys' Dan Auerbach.
The sophomore album for the English trio was produced by Butch Vig.
The Canadian singer-songwriter's sophomore release again blends country and rock sounds, and includes a guest appearance by Benmont Tench (The Heartbreakers).
The lo-fi indie pop trio from Ohio return with their fifth album--their first album recorded in a proper studio.
The first album of new music in seven years from the Velvet Underground co-founder includes a song featuring Danger Mouse.
The third album for the rapper features such guests as Foxy Brown, John Legend, Lil Wayne, Kayne West, The-Dream, Robin Thicke, Ne-Yo, and T-Pain.
Indie hip-hop/electronica producer Nobody (aka Elvin Estela) teams with Prefuse 73, Mia Doi Todd and members of Beachwood Sparks on his Plug Research debut.
The third album for the Scottish band was produced by Bernard Butler.
The fourth full-length studio release for the pop singer features guest appearances from Big Freedia, Sturgill Simpson, Brian Wilson, and Wrabel.
The Philadelphia psychedelic rock band named its seventh full-length release after its new recording studio where they recorded the album with producer Nathan Sabatino.
The Beastie Boys' Adam Yauch produced this first release in a dozen years for the original lineup of the lengendary hardcore punk outfit.
This is the second full-length solo release for the former Deerhoof guitarist.
Don Was co-produced the band's first new studio album in eight years. Keith Richards sings on two tracks.

This debut LP (which actually collects tracks from three previous EPs together with a few new songs) from the English singer-songwriter combines indie rock with lo-fi electronics and '60s and '70s pop influences.
The San Francisco quartet releases another album of psychedelic rock.

The soul-influenced eighth full-length studio release for the pop artist is her first on the Atlantic label and features production from Greg Kurstin, The Monarch, Maureen "Mozella" McDonald, Jesse Shatkin, and Mick Schultz.
The second full-length solo release for the Los Angeles singer-songwriter was co-produced with Kevin Augunas.

recordname: A Map of the Floating City
description: The concept album made up of three EPs about three imaginary continents is the first since the singer's 1992 album Astronauts & Heretics.
The Cracker and Camper Van Beethoven singer releases his solo debut album.
This is the debut album for the New York indie band led by Fred Thomas.
The latest full-length release for rock duo The Black Keys features a guest appearance from ZZ Top's Billy F Gibbons.
This is the second and final release for the London-based indie pop trio.
The New York indie-rock band releases its first mix album.
This third album is the most song-based effort yet for the Michigan electronic music producer, who also records under the name Audion.
The debut full-length release for the Los Angeles-based artist born in Australia was produced by Ben H. Allen and Justin Raisen.
The Minnesotan hip-hop group is back with a new album released through Rhymesayers.
Recorded during the same sessions as 2011's Ghost On The Canvas, some of the country singer's biggest songs are reworked by producers Dave Darling and Dave Kaplan.
The eighth album for the North Carolina punk metal band lacks Pepper Keenan and sees the return of the lineup that recorded its 1985's release Animosity.
The 18th full-length studio release for the San Francisco psychedelic rock project led by Anton Newcombe was recorded in Berlin.
The first release in eight years for the North Carolina-based trio of Amelia Meath, Molly Sarle and Alexandra Sauser-Monnig was mixed by Nick Sanborn.

recordname: Watching Movies with the Sound Off
description: The second release for the Pittsburgh rapper includes guest appearances from Ab-Soul, Action Bronson, Jay Electronica, Schoolboy Q, Earl Sweatshirt as well as production from Flying Lotus and Pharrell Williams.
The second solo album for the former Matchbox Twenty singer was produced with Matt Serletic.
The follow-up to "Testimony: Vol. 1, Life & Relationship" features MC Lyte, Musiq Soulchild, Gramps Morgan, Dobet Gnahore, Terrell Carter and Sezen Aksu as guest artists.
Fleet Foxes' newest member, Joshua Tillman releases his fifth solo album, the first on the Western Vinyl label.
The Texas noise-rock trio led by John Congleton returns with a third LP.
This is the third LP for the New York-based noise-rock trio, known for their intense live shows.

While, like other artists lumped under the "electroclash" label, the Canadian-born Peaches (Merrill Nisker) utilizes a vaguely early-80s style synth-based sound, no one else, then or now, has managed to be quite as raw, lewd and sexually graphic as she.
The first new album in four years from the former Diff'rent Strokes star. (OK, so we've been watching too much Nick at Nite lately.)
The third album for the Danish band was produced by Gareth Jones and recorded with a live band.
This is the debut full-length release for the Youth Lagoon artist under his real name.
Taylor Swift's follow-up to her triple-platinum debut album was produced with Nathan Chapman and features a duet with Colbie Calliat.
The debut full-length debut from Australian electronic producer Harley Streten includes influences from R&B, hip-hop, and pop music.
The British duo worked with Depeche Mode's Dave Gahan on The Light the Dead See.
Rick Rubin produces the latest album for the North Carolina band.
Cadence Weapon's sophomore album is said to be inspired by his summer in Edmonton.
Vancouver singer/songwriter Stephen McBean returns as the main musical mastermind behind this psychedelic rock outfit, combining stoner metal with dreamy pop.
The follow-up to his June release "Ambivalence Avenue" features eight remixes and four new songs.
The third full-length release for the Kentucky rock band was produced by Jay Joyce.
The latest "album" from the Japanese outfit contains just two tracks, albeit at 20 minutes apiece.
Death Cab For Cutie's Chris Walla returns as producer for the band's followup to 'Let Go.'
Over a thousand musicians from across the European Union contributed to the album about being British in the face of Brexit from the British-born electronic producer.
The quintet from England uses influences from 1980s pop on its sophomore album produced by Erol Alkan.
The fourth full-length release for the rock band was produced and recorded with Facundo Bermudez.

The sixth studio set for the Jeff Tweedy-fronted band is less experimental and adventurous than Wilco's previous few efforts. It is the first Wilco studio album to feature the work of touring guitarist Nels Cline.
The sixth full-length release for the alternative rock band led by Jakob Dylan is its first studio-recorded album in seven years.
The sophomore album for the Chicago-based instrumental band was produced by Matt Bayles.
This 17-song set was recorded during Will Oldham's 2004 tour.
The fourth release from Pantha du Prince sees the techno producer working with Norwegian percussion group The Bell Laboratory and sounds from a bell carillon--an instrument with 50 bronze bells.
The sophomore album for the British artist features Kanye West on her chart topping single "American Boy."
The second full-length release for the Los Angeles rock band was produced by Nick Launay.
The second full-length release for producer Sam Genders as Diagrams was inspired by relationships.
The debut full-length release for the Manchester indie pop quartet was self-produced.
The rockabilly singer-guitarist releases her 11th album.

The Rascals singer releases his solo debut, which features such guests as the Arctic Monkey's Alex Tuner, Super Furry Animal's Gruff Rhys, and Oasis' Noel Gallagher along with production work by Dan Carey and Dan the Automator.
The sophomore album for the Baltimore-based indie-rock duo.
The fourth full-length release for the songwriter and ethnomusicology PhD student was inspired by folk music.
The eighth full-length release for the San Francisco Bay Area punk band led by Tim Armstrong was produced by Brett Gurewitz.
The third full-length release for Thomas Fec as Tobacco is his first on the Ghostly label.

recordname: Robert Pollard Is Off To Business
description: The ex-Guided By Voices singer releases his latest solo outing on his own label.
This is the incredibly prolific Jason Molina's second studio album with his blues-rock outfit Magnolia Electric Co.

recordname: Dancing with the Devil... The Art of Starting Over
description: The seventh full-length release for the actress/pop singer-songwriter features guest appearances from Noah Cyrus, Sam Fischer, Ariana Grande, and Saweetie.
The second full-length solo release for the former Portico Quartet member was produced by Ethan Johns and Dan Carey.
The fifth full-length studio release for the British electronic duo features nine tracks plus an hour-long DJ mix.
The eighth studio release for the metal band led by Randy Blythe features guest appearances from the Deftones' Chino Moreno and Dillinger Escape Plan's Greg Puciato.
The first album after the death of Ol' Dirty Bastard.
This is the much-blogged-about first album for the Baltimore duo of Alex Scally and Victoria Legrand.
The second of five albums set to be released in 2017 by the Australian psychedelic rock group is a concept album about the end of the world.

recordname: Greenfields: The Gibb Brothers Songbook, Vol. 1
description: The latest full-length release for the Bee Gees singer and songwriter features guest appearances from Jay Buchanan, Brandi Carlile, Sheryl Crow, Tommy Emmanuel, Jason Isbell, Alison Krauss, Miranda Lambert, Little Big Town, Olivia Newton-John, Dolly Parton, David Rawlings, Keith Urban and Gillian Welch.
The first album of original compositions by the folk artist was produced by Leo Abrahams and features a guest by Milford Graves.
The second full-length release for Australian singer-songwriter Hatchie was produced by Jorge Elbrecht and features contributions from Joe Agius and Beach House's James Barone.
This is the Matador debut for the Northern California outfit founded by cabin- and tent-dwelling childhood friends (from Alabama) Nathan Shineywater and Rachael Hughes.
The seventh full-length release for the indie artist was self recorded in his apartment. [This album was originally credited under the name Alex G]
The third full-length release for the British indie rock band was produced by David Fridmann and Cole MGN.
The San Francisco duo formed by Sanae Yamada and Ripley Johnson of Wooden Shjips releases its second full-length studio album.
This is the third album for the British duo who recently moved to Georgia in the United States.
The Arizona emo band returns with a follow-up to their successful 2001 self-titled effort. Gil Norton produced.
The veteran Seattle rockers return with an album produced by Phil Ek, Johnny Sangster, and Tucker Martine.
The first studio release from the Chicago post-rock band in over six years features vocals from Yo La Tengo's Georgia Huble on one track.

The debut full-length release for the collaboration between Bon Iver's Justin Vernon and The National co-founder Aaron Dessner features contributions from Phoebe Bridgers, Bryce Dessner, Lisa Hannigan, Rob Moose, Arcade Fires Richard Reed Parry, and This Is the Kits Kate Stables.
Produced by Tucker Martine, the latest album for Grammy-nominated Tift Merritt features My Morning Jacket's Jim James and Greg Leisz as guests.
The first solo full-length release in six years for the experimental electronic artist features guest appearances from Queens, Joachim Schutz, and Kassian von Troyer.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn art-punk band BODEGA was mixed by Bryce Goggin.
The second album from the Texas-based singer-songwriter was produced by John Congleton.
The Sweden-based singer releases her latest album produced by Valgeir Sigurdsson.
The Boston duo's third album contains songs from recording sessions, b-sides, and songs left over from 2006's "Yes, Virginia..."

Rebounding from a vocal chord injury that almost ended her singing career, Rosanne Cash returns with her first album in seven years. Guests include Sheryl Crow, Steve Earle, Teddy Thompson, and daddy Johnny Cash.

One of 2002's much-hyped neo-garage rock bands, New York's Yeah Yeah Yeahs have opened for acts such as the White Stripes and the Strokes, and have drawn comparisons to both. This five-track debut EP was originally released in 2001 on the indie Shifty label, and saw a rerelease in the summer of 2002 on Touch & Go.

Aside from the track "Heal Me," which includes background vocals by Laura Dern and Meg Ryan, this is a true solo effort for Melissa Etheridge, who wrote and performed all 10 tracks on this, her seventh album. Much of the music was written during her breakup with her long-time companion, and the songs reflect this experience.
This is the first album in eight years for the duo of Jon Moore and Matt Black. Roots Manuva, Mike Ladd, Jon Spencer and Andrew Broder (Fog) are among the eclectic guests.
The fourth full-length studio release for Australian singer-songwriter Alex Cameron features contributions from Jackie McLeann, Lloyd Vines and Sleaford Mods' Jason Williamson.

The latest full-length release for the British ambient house project led by Alex Paterson features contributions from such artists as Roger Eno, Miquette Giraudy, David Harrow, Steve Hillage, and Youth.
The third full-length release for the London-based art-rock band features contributions from Metronomy's Anna Prior and Slow Club's Rebecca Taylor.
The third release for the Brooklyn improvisational rock band that features Greek and Middle Eastern music was recorded with Jason Meagher.
The debut full-length release for the New York post-punk band was recorded by Charles DeChants.
Produced by Don Was, the second Americana-influenced release from the singer-songwriter includes guest appearances from Frank Ocean and Katy Perry.

recordauthor: Inara George With Van Dyke Parks
description: Inara George Works pairs up with the famous arranger Van Dyke Parkson on her latest album inspired by Frank Sinatra and Richard Sherman.

recordname: I Used to Think I Could Fly
description: The debut full-length release for Canadian pop singer-songwriter Tate McRae features contributions from Finneas, Greg Kurstin, and Charlie Puth.
The first release in four years for the Connecticut-based trio of Elisa Ambrogio, Pete Nolan, and John Shaw.
The latest album for the Senegalese musician was produced with Barry Reynolds.
The sixth full-length release for the New York indie rock band was produced by Dave Fridmann.
The latest full-length release for Minneapolis band Poliça features the use of producer Ryan Olson and Seth Rosetter's "anthropomorphic production tool" AllOvers(c).
The debut full-length release for the side project from The Bees' Aaron Fletcher and Tim Parkin was recorded on the Isle of Wight.
The third full-length release for the Scottish alternative rock band was produced by Jacknife Lee and Gil Norton.
Wu-Tang's Method Man, Ghostface Killah, and Raekwon join up again with an album produced by RZA and Mathematics.
The second album from the indie electronic trio of Chris Karlsson, Pontus Winnberg, and Andrew Wyatt features Lykke Li as a guest singer.
The London-based duo mixed exclusive archive footage about the Space Race from the British Film Institute for their second full-length release.
The first solo album for the Metric singer finds her backed by members of Stars, Metric and Broken Social Scene (together billed as The Soft Skeleton).
The second full-length release for Canadian singer-songwriter Al Spx was produced by Jim Anderson.
The follow up to the band's 2008 album ProVisions was produced by Howe Gelb and Kent Olsen.
This is the third album for the hard-rocking Welsh band.

recordauthor: I Love You But I've Chosen Darkness
description: Paul Barker (Ministry) produced the Austin band's debut full-length.
This is the sixth full-length solo release for the singer-songwriter who previously was a member of The Raconteurs.
The indie rock band's first full-length releases in the US was originally self-released at its concert tour.
The debut full-length album for the Toronto duo of Ethan Kath and Alice Grass.
The eighth full-length studio release for the British alternative rock band is a double album and was produced by Rik Simpson.

recordname: Judy Sucks A Lemon For Breakfast
description: This is the first album for the British band since 2002's "Handcream For A Generation."
The seventh album produced by Kanye West (who also guests on one track), features appearances from Lily Allen, DJ Premier, D'Angelo, and Bilal.
The sixth full-length release for the Swedish band was self-produced and is its first on the Ninja Tune label.
The debut full-length release for the British artist features guest appearances from Poppy Ajudha, De La Soul, Loyle Carner, and GoldLink.

recordname: 24 Karat Gold: Songs from the Vault
description: The eighth solo studio release for the Fleetwood Mac singer contains songs she wrote during the 70s and 80s, plus two in the early 90s.
This is the debut release for Frankie Rose's side project with Drew Citron.
The tenth full-length solo release for the former Bauhaus singer was produced by Youth.

recordname: Do Whatever You Want All the Time
description: The Baltimore quartet return from its hiatus (guitarist Dustin Wong recorded a solo album and drummer Jeremy Hyman had a stint with the Boredoms) to reunite for its third album of experimental art rock.
The San Francisco band's debut on the Quarter Stick label.
The 15th full-length release for the San Francisco psychedelic rock band led by Anton Newcombe was recorded in Berlin and features a guest appearance from Serena-Maneesh's Emil Nikolaisen.
The California rapper received death threats after revealing the title of this digitally released album.
Diplo and Switch return as Major Lazer with a six-track EP which includes a remix by Thom Yorke (Radiohead) of one track from their 2009 release Guns Don't Kill People...Lazers Do.
The debut album for Laura Groves was recorded in different places with her family and friends.
The fifth release for the Los Angeles noise rock band was produced by The Haxan Cloak.

recordname: The Feast of the Broken Heart
description: Co-produced by Ha-Ze Factory and Mark Pistel, the third full-length studio release from the Andy Butler electronic collective features guest appearances from John Grant, Rouge Mary, and Krystle Warren.
The Los Angeles-based indie duo releases its second studio album.
The fourth album for the Philadelphia band was recorded on a 24-track tape.
The fourth full-length release for Los Angeles-based garage rock/power-pop artist was produced by Mike McCarthy.
The third full-length release for the Brooklyn duo of Caroline Polachek and Patrick Wimberly was inspired by New York City.
This is the debut release for the side project of The National's Matt Berninger and Menomena's Brent Knopf.
The third full-length release for the Austin band sees the addition of the touring guitarist Matty Tommy Davidson.
The San Francisco electro-punk trio make their Kill Rock Stars debut with this third LP.
This '60s-influenced sophomore release from the Isle of Wight-based duo was recorded at Abbey Road.
The fifth full-length release for the Brooklyn five-piece was recorded over two days before 2013's New Moon was released.
The second release based on Ben Chasny's new composition method features a more acoustic sound.
The Liverpool band's debut disc was, like similar-sounding recent discs by The Coral, produced by Ian Broudie. It was nominated for a Mercury Music Prize.
The first album from Van Halen in 14 years sees the band reunited with David Lee Roth.
The British Kraut-rock trio's fourth album of artsy dance music is full of funky guitar licks; club-ready bass; and melodic, trippy beats.
The sixth full-length release for the Seattle rock band was produced by Nick Raskulinecz and is its first on the BMG label.
Produced by Ketch Secor, the fifth full-length release for the St. Louis singer is his first on Third Man Records.
The fifth studio album from the singer-songwriter was produced by Don Was and was delayed from its original release date by Mayer's throat granulomas.
This is the second full-length album for the British band.
A ten-year music-industry veteran at age 25, Brandy returns with 15 new tracks, ditching long-time collaborator Rodney Jerkins in favor of producers Timbaland, Organized Noize and Kanye West.
Michael Stipe and Conor Oberst guest on this sophomore disc for the Athens, GA outfit led by producer Andy LeMaster (Bright Eyes), with vocals from Orenda Fink and Maria Taylor (Azure Ray).

Picking up on the sounds of late 70s / early 80s post-punk and no-wave, this all-female Bay Area quartet drew positive notices for their debut 'Other Animals' and now return with a sophomore LP two years later.
The Welsh band returns with 12 new tracks of indie rock mixed with folk, pop, and psychedelia.

Talk about apt titles. The British folk legend's first album in a whopping 17 years features 10 new songs recorded mainly with her son, Teddy Thompson, and numerous guests such as Rufus Wainwright, Van Dyke Parks, and ex-husband and recording partner Richard Thompson.

The former Led Zeppelin singer's first solo album in nearly 10 years is a mix of originals and covers, including Bob Dylan's "One More Cup of Coffee" (also recently covered by the White Stripes) and Tim Buckley's "Win My Train Fare Home."
This is the second full-length from the Kansas-based emo band.
San Francisco's Michael Franti (formerly of the Disposable Heroes of Hiphoprisy) and Spearhead mix rap, soul, R&B, funk, jazz, and trip-hop with intelligent and opinionated lyrics on these 22 tracks.
'Production' is a solo album from the French producer best known for his work with Madonna (who returns the favor by adding vocals to one track here).
Producer Peter Asher and a 13-piece Cuban orchestra help reinterpret some of Rodrigo y Gabriela favorite songs.
The latest full-length solo release for the former Sonic Youth guitarist features contributions from Nels Cline, Kid Millions, and Sharon Van Etten.
The second full-length release for the Philadelphia shoegaze band was produced by Will Yip.
The fifth full-length release for the British indie rock band is its first with new bassist Jack Flanagan.
The latest album for the group led by Daniel Smith was produced by the frontman.
The California indie-rock band releases a five-track EP.
The first release of new material in seven years for the death metal band led by Jesse Hughes was produced by Josh Homme.
The fourth full-length release for the British indie-pop band led by Joe Mount was recorded at Toe Rag Studios.
The electronic duo is now just Simeone Coxe (Dan Taylor passed away in 2005) and he returns with an album produced by Graham Sutton.
The final album for the industrial rock band.
The fifth release for the doom duo of Jon Porras and Evan Caminit includes a 17-minute track.
The third full-length release for the Canadian pop singer features guest appearances from Khalid and Julia Michaels.
The first album on the ATO label for the rock band from Memphis, Tennessee, was produced by Ted Hutt.
The British dance trio's second album was produced by Paul Epworth.
The latest album for the Danish band is its first with Friendly Fire Recordings.
The Portland, Oregon-based duo releases its fourth album.

recordname: Love, Pain & the whole crazy thing
description: The Australian country singer (who also doubles as Nicole Kidman's husband) wrote all or part of 10 of the 13 songs on this fourth solo album.
Tim Hecker and Oneohtrix Point Never's Daniel Lopatin collaborate on the first volume of SSTUDIOS, a series of collaborative releases on the Software Studios label.
The third album for the singer/songwriter was produced by Ethan Johns and recorded in England.

recordauthor: ...And You Will Know Us by the Trail of Dead
description: The group is down to four instead of their previous sextet lineup, but their newest album is still rich in sound and is compositionally sophisticated. It was recorded in 10 days and is thought to be their most conceptual record to date.
This is the debut release for the Denver folk-rock trio.
The British producer recorded the album mostly on the road in single takes with no edits.
The third full-length release for the alternative rock trio was produced by Boots.
The indie rockers' follow-up to their platinum album "Plans" features an eight-and-a-half-minute-long song.
The sixth full-length release for the Portland indie rock trio was produced by John Agnello.
The Detroit artist wrote the music for the Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM), to be performed in the Howard Gilman Opera House at the Next Wave Festival in October of 2007.
This stripped-down, all-acoustic set marks the solo debut for the Clem Snide frontman.
This is the second release for the psychedelic rock project led by Greg Fox.
The aptly titled fourth studio album from the pop songstress has both dance-floor-ready jams and down-tempo tunes that are a bit tamer than those in the last album.
The British quartert's fourth album features two songs sung in Bulgarian.

This is the debut full-length for the Lawrence, Kansas band consisting of Matt Suggs (Butterglory), Rob Pope (The Get Up Kids), and John Anderson, Zach Holland, Dustin Kinsey (Thee Higher Burning Fire).

Folk, jazz, and psychedelic rock are just some of the influences seen on the latest album for the Brooklyn singer-songwriter that includes contributions from At The Drive-In's Ryan Sawyer, trumpeter Nate Wooley, and violinist Jessica Pavone.
The second posthumous release for the rapper Juice WRLD features guest appearances from Justin Bieber, Polo G, Suga of BTS, and Trippie Redd.
The debut full-length release for electro-soul duo of Aluna Francis and producer George Reid includes a cover of Montell Jordan's "This Is How We Do It."
This is the third full-length release from the collaboration between Jonna Lee and Claes Björklund.
Produced by Dreamtrak, the latest release from the British quartet was inspired by Princeton professor Daniel T. Rodgers' book of the same name.
Produced with Charlie Peacock, the granddaughter of Hank and the daughter of Hank Jr. releases her first new recording in four years.
The debut album for the quartet includes Sam Genders of Tunng, Stephen Cracknell of The Memory Band, Hanna Caughlin of The Bicycle Thieves, and Liam Bailey.
The second full-length solo release for the Irish singer-songwriter was written over two years and recorded while she was pregnant in Ireland and Norway with producer Lasse Marhaug.
The Portland, Oregon-based experimental pop band releases a full-length album of 12 tracks selected from its five Privilege EPs.
This is the third album for the Los Angeles indie rock trio that includes married couple David and Meredith Matcalf.

The African-themed album brings Nas and reggae singer Damien Marley (the youngest son of Bob Marley) together. It features guest appearances by K'naan, Lil Wayne, Joss Stone, Dennis Brown, and Damien's brother Steven Marley, who also produced the release.
The Chicago band led by Eric Johnson (sometimes of Califone) returns with a third album.
The third full-length release for the Scottish synthpop trio was produced by Greg Kurstin.

recordname: Pour Une Âme Souveraine: A Dedication to Nina Simone
description: Meshell Ndegeocello co-produced the tribute album to Nina Simone with Chris Bruce and it features guest appearances by Cody Chesnutt, Valerie June, Sinéad O'Connor, Toshi Reagon, and Tracy Wannomae.
The debut full-length release for the British R&B artist features production from DJ Mustard and guest appearances from Chris Brown, H.E.R., and John Legend.
The third full-length solo release for former singer of The Slits was produced by Martin Glover.
The third solo release for the Irish guitarist features his vocals and was recorded in Dublin by Girl Band's Daniel Fox.

recordname: MTV Unplugged [Live at Hull City Hall]
description: The live recording of the Oasis singer's solo MTV Unplugged concert at Hull City Hall in August 2019 features the 24-piece Urban Soul Orchestra and Oasis guitarist Paul Bonehead Arthurs.
The third full-length album for the San Francisco rock band was produced by Rick Rubin.
The second album of electronica from Travis Egedy was produced by HEALTH's Jupiter Keye.
The fourth album for Simon Green, the British DJ who goes by the name Bonobo, weaves in orchestral strings, hip hop beats, afro-latin sounds, and vocals from Andreya Triana to his downtempo style.
The sixth album for the Texas-born country singer was produced by Tony Brown.
Nick Cave & co. return for a follow up to 2001's 'No More Shall We Part.'
Still going strong, the Seattle grunge band returns with its seventh studio album.
The legendary singer's third roots-country album for Sugar Hill Records includes 12 Parton originals as well as covers of Bread's "If" and, of all things, Led Zeppelin's "Stairway to Heaven."

The former backup singer for Missy Elliott and Timbaland comes into her own on this, her debut album, which was produced and co-written by her two benefactors. Tweet's presence and talent are evidenced by the surprising abundance of guitar/soul tracks here, instead of a reliance on electronic/dance numbers typical of a Missy-Timbaland production.

Based in Los Angeles, the Eels have had some stateside success on MTV but have perhaps found greater popularity in the UK and Europe. This new LP (their fourth) features guest appearances by Koool G Murder, John Parish (who also produces), and Joe Gore.
John Mellencamp's 18th album features guest appearances from India Arie and Chuck D.
This is the second full-length release from the Welsh alternative rock trio.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn quartet was produced by Martin Bisi.
The first album in nearly 10 years for the British rock band was recorded in France.
The third full-length release for the Canadian post-punk quartet was produced by Justin Meldal-Johnson.
The experimental electronic artist used keyboards, guitars and effect pedals on his latest solo release.
The ninth full-length release for the Atlanta rapper was recorded in six days after he was released from jail in May 2016 and features guest appearances from Drake, Kanye West, and Young Thug.
After establishing "shitgaze" as a subgenre of "shoegaze", the Ohio band continue on their wildly experimental path with a more electronic-based space-rock sound.
The eight full-length release for the British electronic dance duo features guest appearances from Beck, Annie Clark, Cate Le Bon, Ali Love, and Q-Tip.
The second full-length release for the British post-punk band was produced by Matt Peel.
This is the third full-length album from Swedish singer-songwriter Kristian Matsson.

Imagine the Arcade Fire dosed with happy pills, stocked with toy instruments and forced to score a musical about the 1980s, and you may start getting close to the idea of this eight-piece co-ed band from Melbourne, Australia. This second album follows recent tours with the likes of Death Cab For Cutie, David Byrne and Belle And Sebastian.
The latest full-length release for Chaz Bundick as Toro y Moi features guest appearances from ABRA and Wet.
This is the second full-length release for the Ohio rock band that includes Cloud Nothings' drummer Jayson Gerycz.
This is the first album of any kind in eight years (and the first true solo singer-songwriter album period) for the former leader of the Kinks.
The first new studio release from David Pajo as Papa M in 15 years comes after a suicide attempt in 2015 and a motorcycle accident in March.
This is the second full-length album for the Brooklyn-based black metal band.
This is the second album from the trio of Jeff Tweedy (Wilco), Glenn Kotche and Jim O'Rourke.
The fourth full-length studio release for British pop band Bastille features guest appearances from Riz Ahmed and BIM.

The debut full-length release for the New York band that includes Samantha York and Vince McClelland of Wall and Drew Citron and Scott Rosenthal of Beverly features elements of funk, disco, and punk music.
Rick Rubin produced the gypsy-inspired band's debut for Columbia Records, which also includes Brazilan influences now.
The third full-length release for the garage rock singer was co-produced with Michael Cheever.
The Colombian singer releases her third English-language album, which reunites her with Wyclef Jean, who appeared on their number one single "Hips Don't Lie."
Jerry Finn returns as producer for the band's first album in three years.
The latest full-length release for the Los Angeles-based garage/psych rock band features a children's choir.
The third full-length release for the Welsh alternative rock trio was self-produced and mixed by Alan Moulder.
The fourth full-length release for the Canadian pop band led by Jane Penny and David Carriere is its first with Marta Cikojevic.
The Texas songwriter releases his 16th album.
The second full-length album for the New Zealand-based artist, Annabel Alpers.

The Damon Dash-produced project features the Black Keys and several hip hop artists including Ol' Dirty Bastard, Mos Def, Ludacris, RZA, Raekwon, Jim Jones, Nicole Wray, Q-Tip, Pharoahe Monch, NOE, and members of M.O.P.
The second full-length solo release for the Los Angeles artist features guest appearances from NDambi, Patrice Quinn, Sheera, and Techdizzle.
The debut full-length release for the Louisiana-based rock band led by A.J. Haynes was produced by Jimbo Mathus.
The 11th solo studio release for the Wu-Tang rapper features guest appearances from AZ, Kool G Rap, Nems, Pharoahe Monch, The Revelations, Kandace Springs, Shawn Wigs, and Tre Williams.
The legendary country starlet releases an album of all-new studio material.
The 10th full-length release for the New York folk rock band was recorded in two months after the presidential election.
The debut full-length release for the collaboration between Shawn Colvin Steve Earle features six originals and was produced by Buddy Miller.
The seventh full-length release for the British singer-songwriter is her first since moving to California and was produced by Andrew Hung of Fuck Buttons.
This is the debut full-length release for Los Angles surf punk rock quartet.
The Berlin-based techno producer returns with her third artist album.
The first new full-length release from electronic producer Seth Haley in six years concludes Com Truise's story.
This is the second release for the Canadian electronic pop now-solo project of Robert Alfons (Maya Postepski left to concentrate on her position as Austra's drummer).
The fourth release for the metal band was produced by J. Robbins and is its first without dimmer Trivett Wingo, who left in 2010.
Robin Hannibal and Coco O.'s second release as Quadron features a guest appearance from Kendrick Lamar.
The debut album for Robert "Chicken" Burke and Simone Felice, who left The Felice Brothers last year.
This is the debut full-length collaboration between brothers Brian and Roger Eno.

The first solo release for the Talking Heads frontman in 14 years is part of a larger project called "Reasons to Be Cheerful" and features contributions from Brian Eno, Jam City, Oneohtrix Point Never, and Sampha.

recordauthor: Thee Silver Mt. Zion Memorial Orchestra & Tra-La-La Band
description: This wordy Canadian post-rock outfit (formerly known by similar variations of their current name), here with a fourth album, shares members with the equally wordy and Canadian but more instrumental Godspeed You! Black Emperor.
The punk-rock band's first album in more than six years was produced by Brett Gurewitz.
Ben Hiller (Elbow, Blur) produced the Manchester band's follow-up to 'The Last Broadcast.'
The multi-instrumental Denver four-piece fuse ambient world music with punk rock, pop and folk, continuing to push the genre envelope on their new album -- their first release in four years.

recordname: God Willin' & the Creek Don't Rise
description: Ray LaMontagne self-produced his fourth full-length, the first without producer Ethan Johns.
Members of the Jayhawks combine with Wilco's Jeff Tweedy, Soul Asylum's Dan Murphy and Big Star's Jody Stephens for the pseudo-supergroup's first release in eight years.
The fifth full-length release for British indie rock trio The Wombats was recorded remotely due to the COVID-19 lockdowns.
The latest full-length release for the Australian psychedelic rock band was self-produced.
The third full-length release for the indie rock band led by John Ross was produced by David Greenbaum.
The 15th full-length studio release for the Australian dance-pop was mostly recorded and engineered by Minogue at her home studio during the COVID-19 lockdown.
The third full-length release for the British electronic duo features guest appearances from Amine, Blick Bassy, ChannelTres, Common, Fatoumata Diawara, Mick Jenkins, Kehlani, slowthai, and Syd.

The fourth full-length release for Los Angeles singer-songwriter Kayla Cohen was inspired by her time in New Mexico and features contributions from members of Gun Outfit and Sun Araw as well as Chris Cohen, Cooper Crain, and James Elkington.

recordname: No Sounds Are Out of Bounds
description: The 15th full-length studio release for the British ambient house duo features contributions from Brother Culture, Andy Cain, Hollie Cook, Roger Eno, Gaudi, Emma Gillespie, Mary Pearce, Guy Pratt, Michael Rendall, Rianna, Roney FM, Jah Wobble, and Youth.
The sixth full-length release for the Pennsylvania experimental electronic band is its first full-length album in six years.
The 12th full-length release for the California indie rock band led by E (Mark Oliver Everett), who also produced the album with some tracks also produced with Mickey Petralia.
The sixth full-length release for the British rock band was produced with Leo Abrahams and Benjamin John Power.
The first new release in 24 years for the garage rock/power-pop band led by Chris Wilson features guest appearances by Tubes drummer Prairie Prince and members of the Fabulous Thunderbirds.
The debut full-length release for the British-Albanian artist features guest appearances from Coldplay's Chris Martin and Miguel.
The first new release in 32 years for the surviving members of the ensemble that began as the BBC's in-house musicians.
The first of a planned five albums in 2017 for the psychedelic rock band features microtonal tuning.
The second solo release for the Toy Soldiers singer/guitarist was produced with Joe Bisirri.
The latest solo release from the Giant Sand artist is a jazz-influenced album with a duet with Lonna Kelley.
The first solo release on the British soul singer's own label was produced by Justin Stanley and Ben Ash.

The fifth full-length release for the folk rock band led by Taylor Goldsmith was produced by Blake Mills and features backing vocals from Brittany Howard of Alabama Shakes, Jim James of My Morning Jacket, Mandy Moore, Will Oldham, Holly Laessig and Jess Wolfe of Lucius.
The debut full-length solo release for the Ultrababyfat and Luna, and Dean & Britta band member features five original and five cover songs.

recordname: Take All My Loves: Nine Shakespeare Sonnets
description: The latest release for the pop singer-songwriter is based on Shakespearean sonnets and features guest appearances from such artists as Helena Bonham Carter, Carrie Fisher, Sian Phillips, opera singer Anna Prohaska, William Shatner, Martha Wainwright, and Florence Welch.
The 16th studio release for the Texas-based singer-songwriter was produced with bassist George Reiff.
The fourth full-length release for the Scottish alternative rock trio features guest appearances from Bek Oliva and Cecilia Stamp.
Kanye West executive produces and appears as a guest on the second full-length studio release for the Trinidad-born, Brooklyn-based rapper.

Co-produced by Steve Bing and Jim Keltner, the latest release from the rock singer known as "The Killer," is backed by a band that includes such artists as Doyle Bramhall II, Jon Brion, Nils Lofgren, Keith Richards, Robbie Robertson, Derek Trucks, Ron Wood, and Neil Young, with guest vocals from Shelby Lynne.
The debut full-length studio release for the Maryland rapper was produced largely by 6ix.
The fourth full-length release for the duo of Liz Wendelbo and Sean McBride was mixed by Chris Coady.
The first release in four years for the British singer-songwriter was produced by Andy Barlow.
The third release for the Canadian hip-hop jazz trio of Chester Hansen, Alex Sowinski, and Matthew Tavares was produced by Frank Dukes.
The debut full-length solo release for the singer-songwriter who previously headed up The Courage was self-produced.

The first release in four years for the Grammy-winning Beninese singer-songwriter was produced by Patrick Dillett with guest appearances from such artists as ASA, Vampire Weekend's Rostam Batmagli, Dr. John, Yvonne Kidjo, the Kronos Quartet, Trio Teriba, and the Orchestre Philharmonique du Luxembourg.

Justin Vernon guests on the debut full-length studio release for the Minneapolis experimental project that includes Ryan Olson of Gayngs, Stef Alexander of Doomtree, Isaac Gale, Ben Ivascu of Poliça, Mark McGee of To Kill a Petty Bourgeoisie, and Jeremy Nutzman.
The third release for the Danish pop singer Nanna Øland Fabricius was produced by Dave Sitek.

Produced by Tom Hambridge, the latest release for the multiple Grammy-winning blues musician includes guest appearances from Gary Clark, Jr., Beth Hart, Kid Roc, Joe Perry, Steven Tyler, Keith Urban, and Brad Whitford.
Jungle producer Michael West's first album since 2005's Born Again as Rebel MC includes production from Benny Page, Serial Killaz, and Boyson & Crooks.
This is the debut release for the art rock band led by the Deftones' Chino Moreno with Isis members Clifford Meyer, Jeff Caxide, and Aaron Harris completing the line-up.
The debut solo album for the Underworld co-founder is less electronic than his partnership with Rick Smith.
The debut full-length release for the London-based trio of Remi Aguilella, Igor Haefeli, and Elena Tonra was produced with Rodhaidh McDonald and Jolyon Vaughan Thomas.
The debut full-length release from the Dublin folk rock quintet was produced by Markus Dravs.
The debut full-length release for the British indie rock band was produced by Jim Abiss.
The tenth studio release for the Maryland-based rock band is a heavier and faster than previous albums.
The eighth full-length release from the singer-songwriter is his first on Nonesuch and was co-produced with collaborator/guitarist Noah Georgeson.
The third album for the Canadian indie rock band was produced by John Collins.

The latest album from the multiple Grammy-winning bluegrass/country artist was produced by Russ Titelman and includes guest appearances by Eric Clapton, Marc Cohn, Keb' Mo, Alison Krauss, Mumford & Sons, and Paul Simon.
The latest album from the Arizona band led by Howe Gelb is a country rock opera about a man's road trip to escape from his hometown of Tuscon.
The debut album for the music project led by the Black Crowes' Chris Robinson features tracks that are over seven minutes long.
This is the second album from the Portland, Oregon-based band led by Joe Haege and Corrina Repp.
The Welsh singer's 1960s-inspired debut album was produced by Bernard Butler.
The New Orleans ensemble bring the sounds of Mardi Gras and Carnivale to its latest album of funk.
The third album for the British jazz band incorporates electronic elements to its sound.
This second installment of the legendary singer's Duets pairs him with Aretha Franklin, Norah Jones, Willie Nelson, and the late Amy Winehouse, among many others.
The hip-hop duo from Detroit consists of rappers Royce da 5'9" and Eminem.
The third folk album released by the daughter of Martin Carthy and Norma Waterson focuses on the last 10 years of her life.
Best known as the lead singer of the punk band X, Exene continues evolving her solo music career and in her latest release brings more rock influences to her folk and country style.
The experimental band from Minnesota led by Craig Minowa releases its first concept album about space travel, life, death, and babies.
The Swedish pop band named after the Serge Gainsbourg's song releases its third album.
This is the third album for the British rock band that has been compared to The Who for its 1960's sound.
This is the latest solo album for Portland-based Adam Forkner.
The lead singer of the punk rock band X releases her first solo album on the Bloodshot Records label.
The latest solo album for the former Stone Roses singer was produced by Dave McCracken.

recordauthor: James Yorkston & The Big Eyes Family Players
description: The Scottish singer-songwriter teams up with a different group of musicians for this folk song collection.
The second full-length album for the Canadian indie-rock band was produced by Aaron Fisher.
The latest album for the producer/singer from North Carolina features David Banner on the single 'Cool.'
The country singer returns with his latest album produced by Kyle Lehning.
Freeway's sophomore album features 50 Cent, Jay-Z, Jadakiss, Busta Rhymes, and Scarface as some of his guest artists.
Unlike debut 'Out Of The Shadow,' album number two is a full-band affair, with Zach Rogue joined in the studio by his touring band.
Miguel Trost Depedro's latest electronica release is a departure for him, as each track is more focused than on previous releases.
Less lo-fi and more band-oriented than previous efforts, 'Let Them Drink' is the second full-length studio release for the Philadelphia band led by Shai Halperin.
The English duo's third album is composed entirely of samples from their personal record collections, falling between the years 1964 and 1995.
This is the debut disc for the atmospheric Denton, Texas indie rockers.
The British band's eighth album sees Tim Burgess abandoning the falsetto he used on 2001's departure 'Wonderland' as the group returns to the more rock-oriented style of 'Tellin' Stories.'
This is the all-instrumental (think somewhere in between Out Hud and Daft Punk) debut album for the New York duo of Evan Mast and Mike Stroud (who formerly operated under the name Cherry).
This is the fourth LP (and first released by Epitaph) for the indie-minded Minneapolis-based duo of Slug and Ant.
The sophomore effort for the quirky Long Beach-based alt-rap trio is a concept album about their alleged time spent working at a fast food chain called Meatshake. Really.
This is the first solo album in over 10 years for the Echo & The Bunnymen frontman, who lately has developed a vocal fan in Coldplay's Chris Martin, who guests on this disc.

The debut album for Ireland's Gemma Hayes shows the twentysomething singer-songwriter attempting to synthesize her diverse influences, who range from My Bloody Valentine to Joni Mitchell. Dave Fridmann produces.

Not wanting to offend any potential listeners, the country superstar finally follows up the hit 'Come On Over' with two versions of her new album (both included in this two-CD set): a red disc of pop versions of her 19 new songs, and a green disc of those same 19 songs performed in a country music style. (A third, blue, disc of those songs performed in a world music style is targeted at international consumers.)

When it rains it pours: After going five years without a Weezer album, fans of the quirky alt-rockers get two new discs in two years, with this (their fourth release overall) quickly following 2001's Green Album.

Producer Dan "The Automator" Nakamura, a founder and member of acts such as the Gorillaz, Handsome Boy Modeling School, Deltron 3030 and Lovage, here offers his first mix album. Many of the cuts are from his own remixes or productions, and come from bands ranging from Tortoise to the X-ecutioners.

The band's first album together since 1993's 'Republic' finds the group moving away from electronica and back to guitar rock. The Smashing Pumpkins' Billy Corgan duets with Bernard Sumner on "Turn My Way" (and has been touring with the band as an additional guitarist), and Primal Scream's Bobby Gillespie and Innes contribute vocals and guitar to "Rock The Shack." Steve Osborne produced the 10-track album.
The second full-length from the Peter Hook-led band features a Bernard Sumner-esque lead vocalist and a sound that could be mistaken for New Order in places.
The fourth album for the Atlanta, Georgia singer and guitarist was produced by Malcolm Burn.
The Sacramento experimental rock band releases a new album.
Ryan Adams returns with his band The Cardinals to release its latest album produced by Tom Schick.
The Beach Boys-influenced Sacramento band release their second full-length rock-pop album.
The first album on Rounder Records for the singer-songwriter was produced by Malcolm Burn.
This is the debut full-length album for the Michigan trio led by John Holland.
The debut full-length solo release for the Dum Dum Girls' Kristin Welchez was produced by Kurt Feldman and Andrew Miller.
This is the second full-length release from New York producer/artist Daniel Martin-McCormick as Ital in 2012.
The rock band brings a space theme to its latest studio album.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Alec Ounsworth indie rock project was mixed by John Agnello.
The sixth full-length studio release for the reggaeton artist was produced by Sky Rompiendo.
The debut full-length solo release for the garage rock guitarist was recorded with Sam Coomes of Quasi and M. Sord.
This is the debut album for the Norwegian ska-pop quartet.
The debut full-length release for South Africa-born indie electronic artist Romy Xeno was produced by Sam Dust a.k.a. LA Priest.
The debut album of the collaboration between Benoit Pioulard and Rafael Anton Irisarri of the Sight Below.
The second full-length release for the British sibling duo of Jack and Lily Wolter was mixed by Dave Fridmann.
The 12th studio release for the indie band led by Kevin Barnes was recorded on a 24-track tape machine.
The largely instrumental fifth solo release for the Philadelphia producer features contributions from P. Blackk, Blueprint, Phonte Coleman, Aaron Livingston, Khari Mateen, and STS.
The third album for the Australian trio was recorded with Steve Albini and mixed by Scott Horscroft.
The third album for the Norwegian indie electronic band includes guest appearances by of Montreal's Kevin Barnes, K Ishibashi, and Bryan Poole.
The eighth full-length release for the blues rock duo of an Auerbach and Patrick Carney was produced by Danger Mouse.
The debut release for the side project of Animal Collective member Avey Tare with ex-Dirty Projectors bassist/keyboardist Angel Deradoorian, and ex-Ponytail drummer Jeremy Hyman was recorded live.
The second album for the British singer was produced by Paul Epworth.
The second full-length release for the Canadian R&B-pop singer-songwriter was co-produced with No I.D., Rick Nowels, Pop & Oak, and Ricky Reed.
This is the debut solo debut release for the former Smith Westerns band member.
The electro-pop group, which also includes Notwist's Markus Acher, releases its fourth full-length studio album.
The seventh album for the metal band was produced by Josh Wilbur.
Singer-songwriter Kathleen Edwards' latest album was coproduced with Justin Vernon of Bon Iver and features Norah Jones as a guest vocalist.
The second full-length release for the Michigan alternative rock band was produced by Will Yip.

recordname: The Hardest Way To Make An Easy Living
description: Unlike his previous release (which told an album-length story about a fictitious character), Mike Skinner's third Streets album is autobiographical in nature, dealing with the myriad problems that result from being rich and famous.

The latest album for the young jazz artist features both original and cover songs including Cole Porter's "Just One of Those Things," Rihanna's "Don't Stop the Music," Sweeney Todd's "Not While I'm Around."
Former Test Icicles member Dev Hynes releases a solo album of experimental '80s electronica.
Stephin Merritt's final album in his "no-synth trilogy" was largely inspired by 1960s-70s British folk.
This is the debut full-length release for the songwriter and producer who is best known for his work with his sister, Billie Eilish.

Probot is the all-star metal band founded by Nirvana/Foo Fighters drummer Dave Grohl and fronted by a variety of singers, including King Diamond, Max Cavalera (Sepultura), and Lemmy Kilmister (Motorhead).

The Canadian singer-songwriter worked with producer Marius deVries (Björk, Massive Attack) for this third LP, which is actually the first half of what was originally planned as a double album ('Want Two' will instead arrive next year).
Mary J. reunites with P. Diddy (who produced her debut 'What's the 411?') for this latest release, which features appearances from 50 Cent, Eve, Jay-Z and Method Man.

The band consists of former Luscious Jackson keyboardist Vivian Trimble and Breeders bassist Josephine Wiggs, who previously teamed up on another Lucscious Jackson side project, The Kostars (Wiggs produced their one album).
This is the second release for the San Francisco-based duo of Tamaryn and Rex John Shelverton.
The singer-songwriter self-produced (with the help of Pet Shop Boys' Neil Tennant) this follow-up to 'Want Two.' Richard Thompson guests.
The ninth full-length studio release for the rock band led by Dave Grohl was produced with Greg Kurstin.
This is the first album on the Virginia-born singer-songwriters own label, Everso Records.
Siouxsie Sioux of the rock band Siouxsie & the Banshees and The Creatures releases her debut solo album.
Pete Kember produced the second album with the rock band led by Andrew VanWyngarden and Ben Goldwasser, which also includes three members from the touring live band.
The second full-length release for the electro-pop sister duo of Piper and Skylar Kaplanwas produced with Sam Mehran.
The follow-up to their 2010 Grammy-winning debut album was produced by Buddy Miller.
The fourth full-length release for the Brooklyn duo of Alexis Krauss and Derek Miller was self-produced.
The duo that comprises Odd Future members Hodgy Beats and Left Brain releases its second studio album on Fat Possum.
The British indie rock band recorded new versions of some of their songs with a full brass orchestra.
Orginally self-released in early 2008, Saddle Creek re-releases the debut full-length album for the Canadian indie rock band.

recordname: De La Soul's Plug 1 & Plug 2 Present...First Serve
description: De La Soul's Plug 1 (Dave) and Plug 2 (Posdnous) with French producers Chokolate and Khalid release a concept album that follows the rise to fame of a fictional rap group.
This is the second solo LP from the co-founder of such legendary alt-country bands as Uncle Tupelo and Son Volt.
The debut full-length release for the collaboration between Fleetwood Mac's Lindsey Buckingham and Christine McVie features contributions from Mick Fleetwood and John McVie.
The second full-length studio release for the British folk rock band led by Jack Sharp features guest appearances from Olivia Chaney, Rachel Davies, Nic Kearey, and Jace Lasek.
The 12th studio album for the Irish rock band was produced with Brian Eno, Daniel Lanois, and Steve Lillywhite.

recordname: Nothing's Gonna Change the Way You Feel About Me Now
description: Skylar Wilson helped coproduce Justin Townes Earle's Memphis soul-influenced fifth album.

recordauthor: Bruce Springsteen & The E Street Band
description: Springsteen's latest solo album is the fourth time he has worked with producer Brendan O'Brien.
What began as a Roxy Music reunion album turned into Ferry's first album of new material in eight years and features contributions from original Roxy Music members like Brian Eno and Phil Manzanera.
The second release for the Los Angeles-based indie husband-and-wife duo was produced with Matt Thornley.
The indie rock trio from Berkeley, California, releases its first album on Rough Trade, which was produced by band member Chris Chu and Grizzly Bear's Chris Taylor.
The latest release for the synthpop duo is a holiday album featuring four originals and classic Christmas songs.
The latest album for the Atlanta-born rapper includes guest appearances by Nas and Kanye West.

recordname: Thank You for Stickin' with Twig
description: The fourth full-length release for the Canadian producer includes contributions from Michael Rault and Slim Twig's wife, Meg Remy of U.S. Girls.
The third full-length release for the British alternative rock band was recorded in 12 days with producer David Wrench.
The latest album for the krautrock pioneers features a new lineup with James Johnston and Geraldine Swayne joining original members Jean-Herve Peron and drummer Zappi Diermaier.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles pop-punk artist was produced by JEFF the Brotherhood's Jake Orrall.
Roberto Carlos Lange's second solo electronic album was written while he was staying at an isolated cabin in Connecticut.
The fourth full-length release from Chaz Bundick features contributions from Julian Lynch and Unknown Mortal Orchestra's Ruban Nielson.
The British soul singer's debut full-length album was produced by Paul Butler.

recordname: The Flaming Lips and Heady Fwends
description: The latest album from The Flaming Lips was originally released on Record Store Day and it includes collaborations with Erykah Badu, Biz Markie, Bon Iver, Nick Cave, Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros, Jim James of My Morning Jacket, Ke$ha, Chris Martin of Coldplay, Neon Indian, New Fumes, Yoko Ono, Prefuse 73, and Tame Impala.
The "American Idol" winner returns with her follow-up to her multiaward winning debut.
This is the first studio output for the original lineup of the metal band since 1990's Seasons In The Abyss.
All 12 songs on the band's first album in two years have been released as singles.
The third full-length release for the artist first discovered on YouTube is the first on the Sumerian Records label.

recordname: Time Bend And Break The Bower
description: The debut full-length release for Irish post-punk poet Sinead O'Brien was produced by Dan Carey.
The third album for the rock band features Gossip Girls Leighton Meester on one track.
Tim Gane and company release their latest album, mixed by Joe Watson.
The Russian-born singer/pianist makes her major-label debut with this disc produced by Gordon Raphael (The Strokes).
This is the fourth studio disc for the Washington D.C. psych-rock outfit, who are now a four-piece with the addition of guitarist Cory Shane.
Kanye West and Twista guest on the rapper's fourth disc.
This is the third Dischord release for the Washington, D.C. rockers, who are frequently mentioned next to hyphenated labels such as "post-punk" and "dance-punk."
On this solo outing, the Mekons singer tackles a range of material written by male artists, including songs by Ryan Adams, Mark Eitzel and bandmate Jon Langford.
This is the much-heralded debut album from the English foursome, produced by Steve Osbourne.
Fresh off her hit "Lady Marmalade" remake from the "Moulin Rouge" soundtrack, the pop diva returns with her second album. Former 4 Non Blonde member Linda Perry produced and wrote most of the tracks.
Grunge is long-gone, but somehow STP have survived. This is the fifth album for these long-time favorites of alternative radio.

Vanderslice continues his album-a-year pace (despite also serving as a producer on numerous indie-rock albums) with this typically literate and well-produced fifth disc, which was recorded with the help of The Mountain Goats' John Darnielle.
The fourth album for the English band was produced by Brian Eno and Markus Dravs.
The latest full-length release from the Los Angeles experimental producer and remixer of electronic music.

recordname: The World Is Just a Shape to Fill the Night
description: Jesse Lortz recorded this album in Washington state with his friends in a secluded cabin.
The latest album for the rock band led by Steven Wilson features a 55-minute piece (broken up into 14 tracks).
The singer-songwriter releases his first album on the Dead Oceans label after leaving Barsuk.
The fourth full-length release for the Oregon psychedelic duo explores the dark side on this first of a two-part concept that explores dark and light/ying and yang energies.
The seventh release from Stephen Wilkinson as Bibio sees the British producer going back to more ambient and folk style of his earlier albums.
Broken Social Scene's singer goes solo in what will be a series of albums featuring each member of the band plus a few guests.
Detroit's Adam Miller and Nicola Kuperus return with their first release since 2007's Why Bother?.
The Seattle-based indie singer-songwriter and former lead singer of Pedro the Lion, releases his second solo album.
The six-piece band from South Carolina releases its debut album on the Dead Oceans label.
The sixth album for the Celtic punk band finds them on a new label.
The third full-length release for the Canadian indie rock duo of Paul Saulnier and Benjamin Nelson was produced by Matt Rogalsky.
The Canadian musician's follow-up to 'Infiniheart' was once again recorded solo at his home.
The third full-length release from Michael B. Lerner as Telekinesis was produced by Jim Eno of Spoon.
John Dwyer and company return with yet another name change for its 23rd album.
The third full-length release for the Minneapolis-based synthpop duo was produced by Ryan Olson.
This is the debut release for the collaboration between Canadian indie electronic quartet Suuns and Radwan Ghazi Moumneh (a.k.a. Jerusalem In My Heart).

recordname: Born to Sing: No Plan B
description: The 35th album for the Northern Irish singer-songwriter sees him returning to the Blue Note label, after several releases with Exile/Polydor and EMI.
Political issues influenced the fourth album from the indie rock band and was produced by Gil Norton.
Nas, Busta Rhymes, Drake, Rick Ross, Beyonce, and Diddy are some of the guests on the R&B singer's sequel to her 1994 album, My Life.
Techno artist Ricardo Villalobos and experimental artist Max Loderbauer teamed up to produce music inspired by music label ECM's catalog.
The latest album for the New York-based indie rock band was recorded in three days at Oneida's studio and Oneida's Kid Millions provided the drumming for the recording.
Nigel Godrich produced this second album for the French singer and actress (and daughter of the legendary Serge Gainsbourg), with Jarvis Cocker, Neil Hannon and Air also lending a hand.
The seventh full-length release for British electronic group Metronomy features a guest appearance from Porridge Radio
This is the debut full-length release for the Cincinnati punk-pop band.
This is the debut full-length album for the Portland, Oregon-based band.
The Jamaican-American singer, model, and actress releases her 10th studio album.
Dave Sardy and Tony Doogan produced this debut LP for the new band from former Libertines member Carl Barat.
The ninth release for the Alabama singer-songwriter includes a cover of The Nife's Pass This On.
Thom Monahan produced the latest album from the San Francisco-based quartet.
The second full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from James Fauntleroy, Ellie Goulding, Juicy J, Kid Cudi, Miguel, Nicki Minaj, Nas, Pharrell Williams, and Young Jeezy.
The latest full-length release for indie rock band Eels was produced by frontman E and John Parish.
The fifth full-length release for the New York indie pop project of Jonny Pierce was mixed by Chris Coady.
The debut full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from 21 Savage, Big Rube, Cardi B, J. Cole, CeeLo Green, Gucci Mane, Gunna, Quavo, and Travis Scott.
The original self-released 2001 debut album from the Pennsylvania psychedelic rock band was reworked and recorded as its ninth official full-length release.
This is the self-produced debut release for the British quartet formed by Orlando Leopard and Elliot Barnes.

After the band Pela ended, singer Billy McCarthy and bassist Eric Sanderson, along with new drummer Rob Allen, formed We Are Augustines. The death of Billy McCarthy's brother had a great influence on the songs on the debut album produced by Dave Newfield.
The Swedish band releases its second album, produced by fellow Swede Björn Yttling of Peter Bjorn and John.
The debut album from the London quartet earned the band a Mercury Music Prize nomination and frequent comparisons to Jeff Buckley and Travis.
The third full-length release for the Spanish producer Pablo Diaz-Reixa was inspired by the Hiperasia chain of Chinese bazaars in Madrid.
The latest release from the Canadian artist is a suite of chamber music with a string and piano quartet.
The pop rapper reissues her second release with eight new tracks featuring guest appearances by Thomas Brinx, Cassie, Ciara, Lil Wayne, Parker, and Tyga.
An early candidate for Album Title of the Year, 'Sexy' marks the second outing for Josh Homme's rockin' side project.
The seventh release for the California psych-pop duo of Glenn Donaldson and Donovan Quinn was recorded by Jason Quever of Papercuts.
The Danish six-piece pop group releases its debut album.

recordname: All Days Are Nights: Songs For Lulu
description: The sixth album for the singer-songwriter has a more stripped-down feel with Rufus' voice and piano as the focus plus three tracks based on Shakespeare's sonnets and an aria from the opera he wrote.

recordname: The Lights from the Chemical Plant
description: The third full-length release for the Nashville-based singer-songwriter was produced by Jacquire King.
The second album for the Canadian singer-songwriter was produced by Howard Bilerman.
This is the fifth album for the indie-rock band from Philadelphia.
The soundtrack to the 2018 installment of the Halloween franchise directed by David Gordon Green.
The fourth full-length studio release for the R&B/soul singer features guest appearances from Rick Ross and Stacy Barthe as well as production from Kanye West and Dave Tozer.
The 10th solo album for the artist was produced by Andy Chase and features Richard Butler, Matthew Caws, Jody Porter, and Tracy Bonham as guests.
Greek-born Londoner Andy Dragazis returns with his second album of chill-out electronica.

This is the second studio release for the London-based electronica/rock/funk band. Vocals are handled by a group of guests, including Bootsy Collins and Lisa Millet, following the departure of the group's vocalist Wrekked Train.

The fourth full-length for production duo Tom Rowlands and Ed Simons features the singles "Star Guitar" and "It Began In Afrika." Guest vocalists include long-time Chemical Brothers staple Beth Orton and Richard Ashcroft.
The third album from the London-based indie outfit.
This eponymous disc is the debut for the Washington D.C. duo of Dischord Records/Fugazi head Ian MacKaye and drummer Amy Farina (The Warmers).
This is the fifth full-length studio release for the San Diego indie rock band led by Zach Smith and Rob Crow.
XL Recordings signed the founding member of the hip-hop group Odd Future Wolf Gang Kill Them All for a one-album deal to release his second solo effort.
The debut album for the English quartet was produced by Tony Hoffer.
The debut solo studio full-length release for Georgia-based Ben Asbury was produced by Jarvis Taveniere.
The seventh full-length album from the Los Angeles singer/songwriter.
The third full-length release for the British indie pop band was produced with Mark Crew and Dan Priddy.
One of two albums [the other is "Should I Remain Here At Sea"] released on the same day for the indie rock band, the seventh full-length release features more electronic music influences.

recordname: Adrian Younge Presents: Twelve Reasons to Die II
description: The sequel to the rapper's 2013 concept album about the DeLuca crime family is set in 1970s New York City with guest appearances from Bilal, Chino XL, Lyrics Born, Raekwon and RZA, Scarub, and Vince Staples.

After a seven-year hiatus, the Sacramento band's long-awaited album mixes alt-country sounds of steel guitars with their trademark bass-and-horn combination to create their sixth playful pop/rock record.
The 2-CD set for the singer/songwriter was produced by Mike Mogis and John Alagia.
The second full-length release for the Los Angeles rock band was produced by Nick Waterhouse.
Frankie Rose, who previously was in several up-and-coming indie rock bands, such as Vivian Girls, Dum Dum Girls, and Crystal Stilts, returns with the debut album for her own band.
The second full-length release for the Seattle folk rock group was produced with Shawn Simmons and mixed by Peter Katis.
The west coast rapper's debut boasts an all-star production and guest roster including the likes of Eminem, Timbaland, Kanye West, Just Blaze, Busta Rhymes, Dr. Dre and 50 Cent.

the 13th full-length solo release for the rapper features guest appearances from Anderson Paak, ASAP Ferg, AZ, Big Sean, Brucie B, Cormega, Dr. Dre, The Firm, Fivio Foreign, Foxy Brown, Hit-Boy, Lil Durk, Don Toliver, and Charlie Wilson.

recordname: Is This the Life We Really Want?
description: The first solo rock release for the Pink Floyd co-founder in 25 years was produced by Nigel Godrich.

recordname: God Don't Never Change: The Songs of Blind Willie Johnson
description: The tribute album to blues singer Blind Willie Johnson features such artists as the Blind Boys of Alabama, Rickie Lee Jones and the Cowboy Junkies, Maria McKee, Sinead OConnor, Derek Trucks & Susan Tedeschi, Tom Waits, and Lucinda Williams.
This is the fourth studio release for the British band formed by two pairs of siblings.
The three-track suite was created using a 10-second audio sample of a bomb falling in Libya recorded by war photographer Sebastian Meyer in 2011.
The second solo release for the Italian-American rapper features guest appearances from such artists as Immortal Technique, Kool G Rap, Mobb Deep, and Scarface.
The New Zealand indie electronic band's debut album opened at number one on the New Zealand album chart.
The follow-up to her 2005 debut album, "The Way It Is."
The New York indie band releases its sophomore album.
Gareth Jones produced this fourth album for the distinctive Liverpool band.
The sixth full-length release for the San Francisco psychedelic rock band was written in Oregon by Ripley Johnson and Omar Ahsanuddin.

The debut full-length release for the collaboration between Sufjan Stevens, Nico Muhly, Bryce Dessner, and James McAlister is a song-cycle about the solar system which was originally commissioned by Dutch concert hall Muziekgebouw Eindhoven.
The latest release for the Japanese experimental metal band includes influences from doom, psychedelic, punk, shoegaze, and sludge-rock music.
The third solo album for Mojave 3 singer was produced by Nick Holton and features members of Wallingfords Band of Hope.
Portland's indie-punk trio's fifth album is full of fist-pumping rock anthems about relationships and regret.
The debut album for the Canadian indie-pop trio was influenced by music from the 1950s and '60s.

The second solo release for the OutKast rapper features guest appearances from such artists as A$AP Rocky, B.o.B, Kid Cudi, Killer Mike, Little Dragon, Ludacris, Phantogram, Kelly Rowland, T.I., and Wavves.
The latest release for the New York-based new age artist features the piano and was recorded at a Brooklyn church.
The 12th full-length release for the Norwegian ambient Geir Jenssen is his first in five years.
The first volume of a planned two album release is the third full-length release for Tim Presley.
The second solo album for The Jayhawks' Mark Olson was produced by Beau Raymond.
Brian Wilson and the Beach Boys are influences on the debut album for the trio from North Dakota, who started out as a duo named White Foliage.
Philadelphia rapper Beanie Sigel releases his fourth album, featuring R. Kelly, Styles P, Jay-Z, Ghostface Killah, and Scarface.
The third full-length release for the band that includes Portishead's Geoff Barrow, Billy Fuller and Will Young.
The debut full-length solo release for the Ought frontman was produced by Ross Gillard and Amy Fort.
The covers album from Amanda Palmer and her father Jack was produced with Joe Costa.

The singer-songwriter returns after a five year absence with his sixth full-length release featuring guest appearances from Joel Compass, Lianne La Havas, Prides, Josef Salvat, Luke Sital-Singh, and Sweet Billy Pilgrim.
The latest full-length solo release for the punk artist includes contributions from Noveller and Leron Thomas.

The veteran rock-and-rollers return with their first studio album in nearly a decade. With Petty's trademark drawl and snarling blues-driven guitar, Mojo delivers a return to their roots as they continue to push the boundaries of classic rock and roll.

The long-delayed full-length studio album for the rapper features guest appearances from Ashanti, Drake, French Montana, Kendrick Lamar, Mack Maine, Nicki Minaj, Post Malone, Travis Scott, Snoop Dogg, Sosamann, and XXXTentacion.
The fifth full-length studio release for the indie rock band led by John McCauley was produced by Steve Berlin of Los Lobos.
The four-track EP was recorded at different places between December 2006 and June 2008.
Fog's fourth album includes contributions from: Why?, Low, Andrew Bird, Dosh, pedestrian, Phil Elverum, Jeremy Ylvisaker, and Mike Lewis.
The fourth full-length release for the husband and wife duo of Alaina Moore and Patrick Riley was written while on a five-month sailing trip.
The third full-length release for the Canadian singer-songwriter was co-produced with Arcade Fire's Tim Kingsbury and Mark Lawson.
This is the first new studio release of new songs in 40 years for the Swedish pop quartet.
The Brooklyn duo of Imani Coppola and Adam Pallin release their debut album.
The latest solo release for the producer/guitarist who worked with Bob Dylan and Brian Eno features the pedal steel guitar and Rocco DeLuca on lap steel.
The singer's first album in four years features contributions from the Neptunes, Jermaine Dupri and Mario Winans.
The second solo album for the former frontman of The Wallflowers was produced by T-Bone Burnett.
The latest album from the indie band led by Tjinder Singh features several tracks that were originally released through the band's website.
The fifth full-length release for the Chicago indie rock band was produced by John Congleton.
The latest release for the British singer-songwriter is influenced by Americana music.
The second album for the British trio of siblings continues its retro pop sounds that this time includes influences from country, blues, Latin, and ska music.
The debut full-length album for the British quartet was produced by David Kosten.
Norah Jones guests on the second (and most straight-ahead country) of a planned three 2005 releases for Adams, who is once again backed by The Cardinals. Tom Schic produced.

The 50th anniversary for The Chieftains sees the Irish folk group working with Bon Iver, Carolina Chocolate Drops, The Civil Wars, The Decemberists, Imelda May, Lisa Hannigan, The Low Anthem, Carlos Nunez, Paolo Nutini, Pistol Annies, Punch Brothers, and The Secret Sisters on the T-Bone Burnett/Paddy Moloney-produced album.
The third full-length solo release for the musician who worked with Ty Segall features a full string quartet.
The third full-length release for the alternative rock band is its first in 23 years and was produced by the band's guitarist Tom Gorman and Paul Q. Kolderie.
