The sixth full-length for Matt Mondanile as Ducktails was recorded over two years in Los Angeles and New Jersey.
The A$AP Mob's rapper debut studio solo release includes guest appearances from such artists as A$AP Rocky, Bone Thugs-n-Harmony, French Montana, and Waka Flocka Flame.
The sixth album for Minnesota group comprised of former punk and rock band members is full of acoustic guitars and bluegrass sounds.
The English quintet's debut album features samples of the voices of Harvey Keitel and Al Pacino.

recordname: WLIB AM: King Of The Wigflip
description: The latest album for the California hiphop artist includes guest appearances from Talib Kweli, Murs, Oh No, Guilty Simpson, and Defari.

The second full-length release for the British singer-songwriter features collaborations with Patrick Carney, Father John Misty, George Harrisons son Dhani, Laura Marling, Wilcos Pat Sansone, and Bright Eyes Nate Wolcott.
The debut full-length release for the collaboration between Interpol's Paul Banks and Wu-Tang Clan's RZA features guest appearances from Ghostface Killah, Method Man, Kool Keith, and Florence Welch.
The latest solo release for the British rock artist produced by Glyn Johns features some originals as well as Blues standards/covers.
The second full-length solo release for the producer features guest appearances from Alex G, Doss, Dawn Golden, GTW, Little Cloud, Kotomi, and Lontalius.
The third full-length studio release for the Minneapolis punk band was produced by Bill Stevenson of the Descendents.
This is the third full-length release for the indie-pop band led by Julian Koster.

recordname: Standing In The Way Of Control
description: This is the third LP for the Washington state punk trio.

recordname: Okemah And The Melody Of Riot
description: Jay Farrar has revived his post-Uncle Tupelo outfit Son Volt for their first album in seven years.
Mike Mogis produced this fourth album for the dance-inducing Nebraska indie rockers. Azure Ray's Orenda Fink and Maria Taylor add vocals on several tracks.

The third disc for the Twilight Singers, the side project for the Afghan Whigs' Greg Dulli, is a covers album, tackling such interesting, diverse subject matter as Bjork's "Hyperballad," John Coltrane's "A Love Supreme," and Marvin Gaye's "Please Stay (Once You Go Away)."

Better known to the indie-rock crowd than the hip-hop community (perhaps because in his former life, he was a white, balding computer programmer), San Francisco-based Topher Lafata (aka Gold Chains) follows a series of well-received EPs and singles with this full-length debut.

The singer/songwriter/guitarist returns to the studio for the first time since 1996, when he recorded his final album as leader of the Lemonheads. Here, he's joined by Jon Brion on four tracks, as well as members of Giant Sand, Calexico, and Spacehog.
The Amsterdam-based rockers who gave us college-radio hit albums 'Palomine' and 'Lamprey' return with their fifth LP.
The debut album from Adelaide, Australia's Mark Mitchell (who records as Clue To Kalo) is a mix of indie rock and electronica, drawing comparisons to everyone from Badly Drawn Boy to Dntel.
Kinky is a five-piece band from Monterrey, Mexico that combines rock, electronica, and traditional Latin music. This debut album was produced by Chris Allison (Coldplay, Beta Band).

recordname: From The Desk Of Mr. Lady [EP]
description: Le Tigre features Kathleen Hanna of Bikini Kill. This seven-track EP follows the band's 1999 self-titled debut album.
The British duo's debut full-length album was mixed by Rich Costey.
The second album for the rock band led by John J. McCauley III, now includes three new members.
The former Delgado singer releases her second solo album and has her former band member Paul Savage producing it.
The debut full-length release for the British indie pop band led by brother-and-sister Jack and Lily Wolter was produced by Dave Izumi.

The third full-length studio release for Australian electronic producer Flume features guest appearances from Damon Albarn, Kucka, Laurel, Emma Louise, Virgen Maria, May-A, Oklou, and Caroline Polachek.
The debut full-length release for the New York City indie rock band led by Dan Lardner and Alex Niemetz was produced by Suede's Bernard Butler.
The second full-length release for the British punk duo was produced by the Beastie Boys' Michael "Mike D" Diamond (who also guests on one track).
Andrew Wyatt teamed up with Swedish producers Chris Karlsson and Pontus Winnberg (best known for their Grammy-winning work on Britney Spears' "Toxic") to form the new group.
This is the solo debut for the Strokes lead singer.
This is the third studio album for the English artist now based in Germany.
The debut full-length release for the all-female noise-pop quintet from Dublin includes four singles from its previously released EPs.
Ben Chasny returns to his solo project to release his 11th studio album.
The real-life musician couple's debut album combines classic-rock textures with more pop-oriented love songs.
At 65, the British blues-rock guitarist returns with a new album that rediscovers and reinvents classic jams, including songs by noted composers such as Irving Berlin and Fats Waller.
'Need' marks the solo debut for Chris Adams of the Leeds, England band Hood.

The legendary trip-hop trip, Massive Attack releases its fifth studio album Heligoland featuring an all star cast of guest vocals from Damon Albarn, Hope Sandoval, Martina Topley-Bird, Guy Garvey and Tunde Adebimpe. The duo also collaborated with DFA's Tim Goldsworthy on selected tracks.
This is the first solo album for the guitarist for The Strokes, whose father was also a successful singer-songwriter. Guests include Sean Lennon and Ben Kweller.
Rick Rubin returns to produce the seventh studio release for the indie folk-pop band.
The third studio release for the folk-inspired rock band led by Taylor Goldsmith was produced by Jacquire King.
The debut full-length release for the British electronic producer features vocals from HTRK's Jonnine Standish (although credited as Frankie and Jonny) Dale Cornish, and Loke Rahbek.
The quartet from New York mixed and produced its own sophomore album.
This is the first studio disc in four years for the Irish quartet, who are massively popular in their native country.
Many of the songs on the former Guided By Voices leader's second solo set of the year originated in tracks recorded for the soundtrack to the Steven Soderbergh film "Bubble."
The second full-length release for the British electronic producer features guest appearances from Lil Silva, Hudson Scott, Tracey Thorn.
The second album for the Mark Ronson-produced quartet goes for a 1960's sound.
Chan Marshall releases her second covers album.
The third full-length major studio release for the pop singer-songwriter was produced by Patrick Carney.
Known for his appearance on Zero 7's album, he releases the follow-up to his debut.
The now New York-based psych-rock five-piece worked with producer Bill Racine on this fourth album.
This is the debut release for the collaboration between Matthew Cooper of Eluvium and Mark T. Smith of Explosions In The Sky.
The third album for the Washington-state native features a variety of influences, ranging from 1950's songs to the TV series Twin Peaks.
The 13th full-length release for the pop singer-songwriter was recorded with Greg Kurstin between 2013 and 2017.
The fifth full-length release for British psychedelic punk duo of Holly Ross and David Blackwell was produced by Dave Fridmann.
The third full-length release for the Canadian band formed by twin sisters Sari and Romy Lightman features contributions from Blue Hawaii's Alex Cowan, Ryan Driver, Simone Schmidt and Brodie West.
The latest release from the duo of Russ Waterhouse and Lea Cho is their first on the Drag City label.
The live soundtrack to Martin Scorsese's documentary of the Rolling Stones' concerts at New York's Beacon Theater.
Joel Thibodeau worked with Alex Somers and Jónsi on his third release as Death Vessel.
The second full-length release for the British psychedelic pop band was self-produced.
This is the first album in 11 years for the English band led by the troubled Dan Treacy.
The major-label debut from the British-influenced rockers from Los Angeles.

The second full-length solo release for the Canadian artist who co-founded Godspeed You! Black Emperor and Thee Silver Mt. Zion is said to be inspired by the short relationship between TV host Mary Hart and Saudi arms dealer Mohammed Khashoggi.

The third full-length studio release for the Detroit rapper features guest appearances from Jhené Aiko, Chris Brown, Drake, E-40, Ariana Grande, John Legend, Lil Wayne, PARTYNEXTDOOR, Ty Dolla Sign, and Kanye West.

Produced with Alain Johannes, the debut solo release for the former frontwoman of The Distillers and Spinnerette features guest appearances from Warpaint's Emily Kokal, Garbage's Shirley Manson, Queens of the Stone Age's Michael Shuman, and The Strokes' Nick Valensi.
The Crowded House co-founder worked with Dave Fridmann on his first solo work since 2001's One Nil.
The full-length debut release for the British indie rock quartet was produced by Charlie Hugall.
Tim Presley's fifth solo release as White Fence continues his psychedelic 1960s-inspired sound.
The second full-length solo release for Jason Chung as Nosaj Thing features Blonde Redhead's Kazu Makino and Chaz Bundick of Toro y Moi as guest vocalists.
The first album in four years for the Boston rock band is its first on its own label, Scrawny Records.
The indie rock band led by Elephant 6 label co-founder Robert Schneider releases its seventh studio album.
The rapper teams up with the producer for their fourth album together, which features Kurupt, Verbs, 9thmatic, Suga Free, Sick Jacken, and Uncle Chucc as guest performers.
This is the fifth album for the O.C.-endorsed band.

'Cashville' is the solo debut for the G-Unit member (who in real life is Nashville, Tenn. native David Brown). Production on the disc is handled by Dr. Dre, Eminem, and Lil' Jon, with 50 Cent and Lloyd Banks also making appearances.

Hailing from Dublin, Ireland, The Thrills incorporate the sounds of California rock from the 1960s and 70s (the Byrds, Beach Boys) as well as a bit of Beatles thrown in for good measure on this debut album, already a hit in the UK (and a nominee for the Mercury Music Prize).
The Los Angeles- (no, not Bay Area-) based alt-rock band led by singer-songwriter James Grundler returns with a Rick Rubin-produced sophomore LP.

recordname: Holy Wood (In the Shadow of the Valley of Death)

description: Released on Bella Union Records, The Courage Of Others is Midlake's third full-length album.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Chicago pop-punk band is its second since returning from its five year hiatus in 2013.
This is the second full-length release for the San Francisco band led by Luis Vasquez.
Four years since its sophomore release, the British band worked with producer Tim Goldsworthy on its third album.
The Japanese experimental band release their 17th studio album on the same day as their other latest album, Heavy Rocks.
The Raconteurs band member releases his fourth solo album produced by Gil Norton.
The latest full-length solo release for the shock rocker features a few songs from his 2019 EP Breadcrumbs, new covers and songs.
The debut full-length release project from Fountains Of Wayne's Chris Collingwood was produced with Mitchell Froom.

The debut full-length release for the punk-metal supergroup led by My Ruin's Mick Murphy, Corrosion of Conformity's Reed Mullin, and producer John Lousteau, features guest appearances from such artists as Dead Kennedys' Jello Biafra, Lamb Of God's Randy Blythe, Clutch's Neil Fallon, Dave Grohl, Sunn 0)))'s Stephen O'Malley, Nick Oliveri, Alkaline Trio's Matt Skiba, Slipknot's Corey Taylor, Prong's Tommy Victor, Fear's Lee Ving, and Eyehategod's Mike "IX" Williams.

The debut release of covers for the band that includes Todd Snider, Neal Casal of the Chris Robinson Brotherhood, Dave Schools of Widespread Panic, Chad Staehly of Great American Taxi, and Duane Trucks of King Lincoln.
This is the debut full-length release for the metal project led by former Metallica bassist Jason Newsted.
The second solo album for The Charlatans singer was written with Lambchop's Kurt Wagner and produced by Mark Nevers.
The Danish quintet's third album was produced by Fridolin.
The ninth studio album from the alternative rock band led Billy Corgan is part of The Smashing Pumpkins' Teargarden by Kaleidyscope concept album series.
The first release in five years for the Andy Butler project Hercules And Love Affair features guest appearances from ANOHNI and Elin Ey.
The third full-length release for the Swedish pop artist features a guest appearance from Young Thug.
The second full-length release from the country trio was produced by Dann Huff.

The UK electro-rock group's latest release -- a reemergence from their reign in the '90s -- carries on their trademark slow-tempo sound with a mix of shoegaze and electronica, samples and soft vocals.
Rick Rubin "executive" produced the controversial country outfit's first release in four years. John Mayer, Bonnie Raitt, and members of Red Hot Chili Peppers and The Heartbreakers guest.
The group, named after surrealist Andre Breton and formed by filmmakers who created music for their work, releases its debut album.
The debut album for Luke Temple as Here We Go Magic was recorded in two months.
The Long Island indie pop quintet led by Andrea Estella releases its second album.
The 45-year-old former squiggle makes a return to form with his first release in three years.

Dr. John's tribute album to Louis Armstrong features James "12" Andrews, Terence Blanchard, the Blind Boys of Alabama, Shemekia Copeland, The Dirty Dozen Brass Band, Anthony Hamilton, Mike Ladd, Ledisi, The McCrary Sisters, trumpeter Nicholas Payton, Bonnie Raitt, and Arturo Sandoval.

Plagued by numerous delays, the Chris Martin-led band's third album finally surfaced 3 years after the hugely successful 'A Rush Of Blood To The Head.' The band co-produced with Danton Supple (Elbow) and Ken Nelson (Kings Of Convenience, Badly Drawn Boy).
The fourth full-length release for Darren Cunningham is considered a sequel to his 2008 debut Hazyville.
The first new full-length release in nine years for the Jakob Dylan-led rock project was produced by Butch Walker.
Each song on the British multi-instrumentalist's latest release was based on a single minor-guitar chord.

recordname: Too Weird to Live, Too Rare to Die!
description: Produced by Butch Walker, the fourth full-length studio release for the emo pop band was inspired by the city of Las Vegas.
Death in Vegas returns after Richard Fearless' stint in America to release the duo's first album in nearly seven years.
With her husband and father providing support as part of her backing band, Alela Diane's fourth album was produced by Scott Litt.
The David Heumann-led band releases its latest album.

recordname: I Can't Go On, I'll Go On
description: This is the first album for the Los Angeles-based power-pop band formerly known as The Brokedown.
Steve Albini produced this debut album for the St. Louis-based Berlin brothers (Lillian, Eve and Bosh) who make up the Living Things.
The sixth album for the progressive rock band is the first album without Isaiah "Ikey" Owens and John Frusciante.
The mega-stars follow 'Speakerboxxx/The Love Below' with their own 'Purple Rain,' a sure-to-be-huge (and definitely all over the musical map) soundtrack to their movie musical of the same name.
The San Francisco folk band release their fifth full-length album.

Jazz influences the debut full-length pop album from the New Zealand singer, who was featured in Gotye's single "Someone I Used To Know." It includes six new songs in addition to the tracks that appeared on the Australia/New Zealand release.

recordname: Small Craft On A Milk Sea
description: After five long years, Brian Eno finally releases his first solo album since Another Day on Earth and continues to take a more ambient musical approach, collaborating with Leo Abrahams and Jon Hopkins.
The singer collaborated with Timbaland, Justin Timberlake and Ne-Yo for her third album.
The London-based Scottish quartet's follow-up to its Mercury-nominated debut release was recorded in a professional studio.
The debut album for the trio from Bristol was written in 12 days.
The fifth album for the English rock trio was produced entirely by the band.
This sophomore LP from the UK duo of vocalist Allison Goldfrapp and multi-instrumentalist Will Gregory follows their acclaimed 2000 debut, 'Felt Mountain.'
Pink Floyd's David Gilmour joins the electronic duo on this album that includes two 20-minute-plus tracks.
The debut album for the Scottish indie-rock quartet.
The latest solo album from the Radiohead frontman was a surprise Friday release through BitTorrent.

The British singer-songwriter's latest album was supposed to be a part of a double album titled Battle. It was later announced that it would be split into two releases, 2009's The Conqueror and this release.
The third full-length release for the Nashville psychedelic rock band was recorded in six days.
The full-length debut for the Gothenburg-based singer (her sister Yukimi is in Little Dragon) was produced by Dustin O'Halloran.
The first release of new solo material since 2004's My Secret Life for the British singer-songwriter was co-produced with Tony Barnacle.
The debut full-length release for the Australian indie pop group was produced by Lachlan Mitchell and won the 2011 Australian Music Prize.

The multiple Grammy-winning group's latest album combines gospel with country and is produced with Jamey Johnson. It features such guest singers as Vince Gill, Willie Nelson, the Oak Ridge Boys, Hank Williams, Jr., and Lee Ann Womack.
Peter Katis produced the debut album for the Simon Balthazar-led band.

Buddy Miller and guitarists Bill Frisell, Marc Ribot, and Greg Leisz come together to sing classic country songs and a few originals. Julie Miller, Shawn Colvin, Emmylou Harris, Lee Ann Womack, and Ann McCrary are some of the guests on the album.
The rapper turns toward pop-punk on his fifth full-length release executive produced by Travis Barker and featuring guest appearances from Blackbear, Iann Dior, Halsey, and Trippie Redd.

recordname: Unknown Rooms: A Collection Of Acoustic Songs
description: The debut acoustic folk release for the singer-songwriter was produced by Ben Chisholm.

A commercial and critical success in the UK upon its release in the fall of 2003, 'Absolution' marks the third album for the English rockers (who frequently draw comparisons to Radiohead--but then again, who doesn't?). It also marks their first time working with producer Rich Costey.
This instrumental hip-hop disc marks the solo debut by the longtime producer for Aesop Rock and other Def Jux artists.
The Austin, Texas-based drone-pop qunitet--known to friends and reviewers as AmAnSet--returns with their fifth LP.

The Detroit-based electronica duo of Nicola Kuperus and Adam Lee Miller (who also run the Ersatz Audio label) have gained a great deal of acclaim for their early singles and work with other artists. Here, on their full-length debut, they offer 10 brand-new tracks. (Yes, the period at the end of their name is necessary.)
This is the critically-acclaimed Alabama singer's third album, and first for her new label Universal South.
Believe it or not, these guys have been around for over 15 years now, and this is their eighth release (and first since 1998's 'Dizzy Up The Girl').

This is the solo debut for founding Pavement guitarist Scott Kannberg (aka "Spiral Stairs"). As Preston School of Industry, Spiral is joined by Andrew Borger on drums and Jon Erickson on bass, with other musicians guesting.
The third full-length release for the indie pop band led by Dee Dee Penny was produced by Richard Gottehrer and Sune Rose Wagner of the Raveonettes.
The second full-length release for the Baltimore rock band was produced by J Robbins of The Office of Future Plans.
The third full-length release for the Baltimore-based noise rock band led by Andrew Laumann was produced by Travis Harrison.
The London rapper makes his debut of hip-hop and pop jams.
The Danish duo's latest album features a 3D cover.
The third studio release for the Swedish five-piece band was recorded in three days.
Produced by Johann Scheerer, Mars Volta's Omar Rodríguez-Lopez forms a new group with Mars Volta drummer Deantoni Parks, Teri Gender Bender of Le Butcherettes, and Nicci Kasper.
Steve Earle's latest album features his wife Allison Moorer, as well as the Brazilian group Forro in the Dark.
The 10th studio release for the British trip-hop artist features guest appearances by Francesca Belmonte, Nneka, Fifi Rong, and Antlers' Peter Silberman.
This is the debut full-length release for the British indie funk band formed by Tom McFarland and Joshua Lloyd-Watson.
The latest solo release for the British artist features contributions from James Hoare, Franic Rozycki, Jonny Helm and Pam Berry.
The first Plastikman release from Richie Hawtin since 2003 was created for the Guggenheim's International Gala.
The third full-length release for the British dance-rock artist was self-produced.
This is the third full-length psychedelic pop release for Mancunian Alan Roberts as Jim Noir.
Kurt Elling's latest album of jazz and classic rock was produced by Don Was.
The third album for the dance quartet was inspired from a night at a Berlin club and was produced with Stuart Price.

The collaboration between Sufjan Stevens and Lowell Brams was recorded over several years and features contributions from such artists as the Shins' Yuuki Matthews, the National's James McAllister and Sunn O)))'s Steve Moore.
Morrissey's first studio release since 1997 (and seventh overall) was recorded in Los Angeles with producer Jerry Finn (Blink-182, Green Day) and longtime collaborators Alain Whyte and Boz Boorer.
Executive produced by Dr. Dre & Rick Rubin, the eight studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from Skylar Grey, Kendrick Lamar, Rihanna, and Nate Ruess of fun.
The second full-length release for the Australian psychedelic rock trio features contributions from Stella Mozgawa of Warpaint, Ewan Pearson and producer James Ford.
The second release for the British producer was recorded in part live over a six week period.
This is the third studio album for the French synth-rock band.
The 20th full-length studio release for Australian psychedelic rock band King Gizzard & the Lizard Wizard was produced by Stu Mackenzie.
Alex Willner's debut album for his solo project, Loops of Your Heart, features synth-based electronic music.
The rap duo releases their first studio album in seven years.

recordname: Sol-Angel And The Hadley St. Dreams
description: The sophomore album for the younger sister of Beyonce Knowles.
Bob Erzin (Jane's Addiction) produced the alt-metal band's fifth album. System Of A Down vocalist Serj Tankian guests.
The debut release for the Dean Blunt project features guest appearances from Arca and Micachu.

The latest solo album fpr the alternative rock singer-songwriter features covers of songs sung by such artists as Nick Cave, Bobby Darin, Hall & Oates, Frank Sinatra, Nancy Sinatra, and Andy Williams.
The second full-length release for the New Zealand alternative rock five-piece was produced with Justin Meldal-Johnsen and mixed by Alan Moulder.
The second covers release for the singer-songwriter features songs by such artist as The Beach Boys, Irving Berlin, Bob Dylan, Emerson, Lake & Palmer, Willie Nelson, and Sonny & Cher.
The second full-length studio release for the Grammy-winning British singer-songwriter features production from Emile Haynie, Tyler Johnson, Malay, Jimmy Napes, Stargate, and Timbaland.
The sophomore album for New York-based singer, Shara Worden.
The latest full-length release for the Canadian singer-songwriter was produced by The National's Aaron Dessner.
The third-full-length release in 2019 for the prolific band led by Robert Pollard.
The fifth full-length release for the Scottish indie rock band band was produced by Philippe Zdar of Cassius and is the first with Julian Corrie (who took over for Nick McCarthy).
The third full-length release for the Virginia rock band led by Austin Getz was produced by Will Yip.
The debut full-length from the New Zealand alternative rock trio was recorded in a 1930s dancehall.
This is the first studio album for the band since adding new drummer Emil Amos.
The debut album for the Canadian quartet was produced by Chad VanGaalen.
The first album on the Cooking Vinyl label, Nitin's latest album features Sir Paul McCartney on one track.
The third album for the R&B artist was produced with The Neptunes and Pro Jay.
The fourth release for the side project from Real Estate guitarist Matt Mondanile includes contributions from such guests as Big Troubles, Madeline Follin, Joel Ford, Daniel Lopatin, and Sam Mehran.
The second full-length release for the Swedish punk quartet was produced by Stefan Brändström.
The fifth full-length studio release for the R&B singer features guest appearances from B.o.B, Future, and Nicki Minaj.
The album was a live recorded four-song set with Chris Carter and Cosey Fanni Tutti of Throbbing Gristle and Factory Floor guitarist Nik Coik at London's Roundhouse in 2011.

It's nearly impossible to read an indie music review these days without seeing the words "Gang Of Four" pop up, but that influential band hasn't been around to take advantage of its newfound fame. Until now, that is, as the reunited Gang (in its original lineup for the first time since 1981) returns with newly re-recorded versions of 14 of its classic songs.
The third full-length release for the Canadian electronic pop duo is their first new album in five years.
The seventh release from the British band was self-produced in Liverpool.
The fourth full-length release for the Chicago rock band led by Brian Case was produced by John Congleton.

recordname: Carnival II: Memoirs Of An Immigrant
description: The sixth album for the ex-The Fugees features guests such as T.I, Shakira, Mary J. Blidge, Chamillionaire, Norah Jones, and will.i.am.
The fifth full-length release for Sun Kil Moon contains 17 tracks of music made primarily on a nylon string guitar.
The fifth album for the New Jersey rock band was produced by Dave Fridmann.
The second release for the duo of John Kowalski and Rian Trench includes guest appearances from from Sarah P of Keep Shelly in Athens and Beth Hirsch.

Recorded in world-renowned Sweet Tea studios, the experimental musical project started by San Diego-based Nathan Williams leaves laptop production and fuses fuzzy garage-rock with psychedelic pop for the new album.
Five years after the last release, Dynamite Steps brings Greg Dulli back to the Twilight Singers.
The surprise release of the sixth full-length studio release for the pop artist features guest appearances from Doja Cat, Ty Dolla Sign and the Weeknd.

Whereas its predecessor (2002's acclaimed 'Phrenology') clocked in at 79 minutes, 'The Tipping Point' is a concise 45-minute listen, featuring guests Devin The Dude, Ol' Dirty Bastard, Jean Grae and Television's Dave Chappelle.
The lo-fi Portland, Ore. band returns with a second album, recorded with engineer Chris Walla (Death Cab For Cutie).
The fourth album for the London-based duo of Ed Handley and Andy Turner contains ten new tracks that promise to recall the darker mood of their work together in the Black Dog.
The debut solo release for the Arcade Fire keyboardist was recorded in a week.
The second full-length release for the British "punktronica" band was mixed by Danalogue.

The third full-length release for the British singer-songwriter features a guest appearance from Paul Buchanan and contributions from such artists as Benny Blanco, Cashmere Cat, Francis and the Lights, Julia Michaels, Ed Sheeran, Starsmith, Ryan Tedder, and Two Inch Punch.

The second full-length solo release for the Hot Chip lead singer features stripped down and re-imagined versions of songs from Hot Chip and his side project About Group as well as some of his favorite artists.
The debut full-length release for the British indie pop artist features a guest appearance by Marika Hackman.
The long-awaited fourth album by model, actress, and R&B superstar Ciara features Ludacris and Usher, balancing back and forth between club beats and slow ballads.
The first album in seven years from Chris Isaak--who also returns with his own talk show on the Biography Channel--was produced by Eric Rosse and John Shanks.
The Swedish band worked with Pharrell Williams, Jacknife Lee, and Dennis Herring for their fourth album.
The third album from the Irish band, which previously included Damien Rice.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn-based indie rock band led by Zachary Cole Smith was self-recorded and produced.
Chicago-based singer-songwriter Haley Fohr, who also released music under the name Circuit des Yeux returns as Jackie Lynn in this concept album.
This is the 10th full-length studio release for the British post-punk band led by John Lydon.
The debut solo release for the project of former Field Music bassist Ian 'Blackie' Black was co-produced with Peter and David Brewis of Field Music.
This is the debut full-length album for the Japanese trio.
Qui covers Pink Floyd's 'Echoes' and Frank Zappa's 'Willie the Pimp' on their latest album.
The second album for the band comprising Daniel Bejar (Destroyer, New Pornographers), Spencer Krug (Sunset Rubdown, Wolf Parade), and Carey Mercer (Frog Eyes, Blackout Beach).

recordname: Micah P. Hinson And The Opera Circuit
description: This is the second full-length album for the young Texas-based singer-songwriter, recorded at his home while he was recovering from major back surgery.

The debut full-length solo release for Bombay Bicycle Club's Jack Steadman features guest appearances from Alexandria, Horace Andy, BJ The Chicago Kid, Charles Bradley, De La Soul, Elli Ingram, and Lalah Hathaway
This is the Norwegian singer-songwriter's second album.
This tongue-in-cheek Canadian duo mixes 70s and 80s electro, funk, rock, and dance sounds on this debut.

The latest solo studio release for the rock artist was produced by Bob Ezrin and features guest appearances by ZZ Top's Billy Gibbons, Deep Purple's Roger Glover and U2's Larry Mullen Jr. A second bonus disc contains two tracks featuring the original Alice Cooper band and six live tracks recorded in Columbus with his current backing band.
Alasdair Roberts and Mairi Morrison collaborated on the album of traditional Gaelic songs for Ceols Craic, a Gaelic arts center in Glasgow.

The 11th full-length release for the singer-songwriter is said to be her last and features contributions from Brandi Carlile, Chuck D, Eric Clapton, Gary Clark, Jr., Andra Day, Vince Gill, Emmylou Harris, Jason Isbell, Kris Kristofferson, Lucius, Maren Morris, Lukas Nelson, Stevie Nicks, Margo Price, Bonnie Raitt, Keith Richards, St Vincent, Mavis Staples, Chris Stapleton, Sting, James Taylor, and Joe Walsh.
The second full-length release for the Scottish soul singer features guest appearances from Jay Electronica, Joel Sande & The Serenje Choir, and Áine Zion.
Recorded by Steve Albini, this is the first album without cofounder G. W. Sok, who left the Dutch experimental punk band in 2009 to pursue other interests.
This is the British duo's third album.

The 12th full-length studio release for the Northern California punk trio was self-produced and includes songs about gun violence in the US as well as a track lead singer Billie Joe Armstrong wrote for the movie he stars in.
The Texan siblings release their second full-length album.

recordname: Roadsinger (To Warm You Through The Night)
description: The latest album for the singer-songwriter previously known as Cat Stevens was recorded live in various studios around the world.
The third release for the indie artist was influenced by her move to New York and working with Weekend's Shaun Durkan and producer Jorge Elbrecht.
The third album on the Thrill Jockey label for the space rock band was produced by Martin Bisi.

recordname: I Go Missing in My Sleep
description: The debut full-length release for the Brooklyn-based trio of Tamsin Wilson, Drew Arndt, and Johnny Simon was recorded with producer Ben Baptie.

recordname: I Wanna Go Back to Detroit City
description: The latest release from the R&B artist was inspired by Detroit and features contributions from such artists as Dennis Coffey, Dan Kroha, Matthew Smith, and Jim White.
25% of the profits from the debut release from the celebrity cat adopted by Mike Bridavsky go to an ASPCA-affiliated charity group helping special needs animals.
The latest album for the folk singer features a duet with Elvis Costello.
James Mercer's label Aural Apothecary releases The Shins' first studio album in five years.

The second full-length release for the collaboration between electronic producers Danilo Plessow (aka Motor City Drum Ensemble) and Innervisions' Marcus Worgull features guest contributions from Tadhg Murphy, Dermot O'Mahony, and Robbert Van Der Bildt.
The second studio release for the Brooklyn indie rock band (previously known as We Are Augustines) was co-produced with Peter Katis.
The North Carolina bluegrass quartet releases its follow-up to the band's 2008 album IV.
The debut album for the UK artist Helena Costas was produced by Danger Mouse.
The sixth album for the Andrew Kenny-led band is their first for Canadian label Arts & Crafts.
Handsome Furs is a side project for Wolf Parade's Dan Boeckner, who is joined by his fiancee Alexei Perry and Wolf Parade drummer Arlen Thompson.
The latest comic book-inspired hip-hop release for Czarface is a collaboration with Ghostface Killah.
The fifth full-length studio release for the psychedelic rock band was mixed by Cooper Crain.

The second full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was influenced by her Jamaican and Greek heritage and features production from Paul Epworth, Matt Hales, Jamie Lidell, and Stephen McGregor.
The third full-length release for the British band that includes Richard Dawson, Rhodri Davies, Dawn Bothwell and Sally Pinklington.
Broken Social Scene's Jason Collett releases his fifth solo album produced by Zues band members Carlin Nicholson and Michael O'Brien.

recordname: Life Is Sweet! Nice To Meet You
description: The former Test Icicles frontman Devonte Hynes of Lightspeed Champion returns with the follow-up to 2008's Falling Off The Lavender Bridge. Produced by Ben Allen (Animal Collective, Gnarls Barkley), Life Is Sweet! Nice To Meet You is a collection of songs influenced by classical music and musical theatre.
This is the fifth full-length release from the synth-pop trio led by Hannes Norrvide.
The first release in five years for the band led by Sean OHagan is a concept album based on a stage production about the changes that happened in Peckham, a district in south-east London.
The third full-length release for the indie pop band led by Laura Burhenn was produced by Bradley Hanan Carter.
This is the fifth studio album for Jake and Jamin Orrall, who were previously in the indie rock band Be Your Own Pet.
The latest album for Sweden's Emil Svanangen is his first on the Polyvinyl label.

The former Throwing Muses and Breeders member's third solo release finds her collaborating with the likes of Dean Fisher (who doubles as Juliana Hatfield's bassist and Donelly's husband) and Rich Gilbert.
The Berlin-based trio (who share a member with the band Tarwater) continue to mix electronica with post-rock on their first album in three years (and first for Domino).

This sophomore release for Minnesota-based turntablist/multi-instrumentalist Andrew Broder, like recent releases from "folktronica" artists such as Four Tet, utilizes organic sound samples, but mixes them with both indie rock elements (including some vocals) and shades of hip-hop.
The veteran prog-rock outfit led by guitarist Robert Fripp returns with their first full album of new material in thee years.
On this long-delayed release, the Minus 5's Scott McCaughey, Ken Stringfellow (the Posies) and Peter Buck (R.E.M.) team up with all four members of Wilco for 13 original tracks.
Although the album cover may say it's by J. Mascis & The Fog, there's not much left of The Fog other than J. himself on this 10 track effort.
The Brooklyn-based band releases their latest album.
The fifth full-length release for the five-piece experimental band was funded in part by a Kickstarter campaign.
The debut full-length studio release for the Atlanta rapper features guest appearances from Birdman, Boosie BadAzz, Duke, Jacquees, T.I., Yak Gotti, and Young Dolph.
The first release since 1978's Never Say Die! with Ozzy Osbourne was produced by Rick Rubin and includes former Rage Against the Machine drummer Brad Wilk taking over for Bill Ward.

recordname: Make Sure They See My Face
description: Ethiopia-born Kenna's sophomore album was produced by the Neptunes' Chad Hugo and features Pharrell Williams on some tracks.
The Canadian duo of Robert Alfons and Austra's Maya Postepski offers a mix of synth-pop and goth on its debut release.
The fourth album for the New Jersey rock band is its first on the Mercury Label and was produced by Brendan O'Brien.
The debut full-length release for the Australian indie rock trio was influenced by Brit-pop music.
This is the debut release for the indie group led by Austin-based artist Stefanie Franciotti.
Originally self-released in 2012, the concept album from Canadian experimental artists Max Turnbull was inspired by Vladmir Nabokovs Lolita.
The fourth full-length release for the Lieberson sisters was self-produced.
This is the second full-length release for the electronic/alt-R&B project of Mike Milosh.
The fourth full-length release for the Icelandic singer-songwriter was produced by Dan Carey.
The third release from the Chicago self-described "ambient soul" duo of Marie-Claire Balabanian and Karl Briedrick added drummer Chris Dye and organist Linda Malonis to the band.
The 13th album for the heavy metal band was produced by Johnny K.
The debut album for the Chicago-based group featuring The Zincs' James Elkington and Eleventh Dream Day's Janet Bean.

Formally of the Flat Duo Jets, Dexter Romweber returns with his sister on drums on his latest album produced by John Plymale. Special guests include Neko Case, Cat Power, Exene Cervenka and Rick Miller of Southern Culture on the Skids.
The sixth full-length release for the British indie rock band features vocals from the Kansas City Girl Choir.
The sixth studio release for the alternative rock band was produced by Marc Jacob Hudson and Mike Sapone.
The duo from San Francisco releases their first album in three years.
The fourth studio album for the Athens, Georgia, indie pop band tells the story of someone using drugs to stop the pain he or she feels after the end of a relationship.
The Norway-based indie-folk duo of Erlend Øye and Erik Glambek Bøe reunite for a third album, following some detours by Øye into more electronic-based music.
The second full-length album for the duo of James Mercer and Brian Burton follows the release of a short film with Kate Mara as an astronaut and Anton Yelchin as her lover, Oliver.
The Texan singer's fourth album features M Ward and Marc Ribot as guest musicians.
The latest release from the Minneapolis hip hop duo of Slug and Ant features guest appearances from Aesop Rock, deM atlaS, Doom, The Grouch, Kool Keith, and Kim Manning.
The second full-length release for the British indie-pop trio was produced by Tom Morris.
The music project headed up by Damon Albarn was mainly recorded outside, with the help of 11 other producers working with more than 50 Congolese musicians.
Rhymefest, the Chicago rapper who co-wrote Kanye West's hit "Jesus Walks," releases his second studio album featuring guest appearances by Little Brother, Saigon, Glenn Lewis, and Darien Brockington.
The moody Chicago group is down to two remaining members (Lindsay Anderson and Joseph Costa) on this third album.
The sixth album for the Detroit rocker is more party-rock than rap-metal, although some hip-hop elements are retained from previous outings. Included is a cover of "Feel Like Makin' Love."
The debut full-length studio release for the Chicago rapper features guest appearances from Chief Keef, The Dream, Joey Purp, Pusha T, Syd, Ty Dolla $ign, Weezer, Pharrell Williams and Saul Williams.
Don Was produced the first album of new music from the actor/singer in four years.
The fourth self-titled release for the alternative rock band led by Rivers Cuomo was inspired by Southern California beach life and was produced by Jake Sinclair.
The third album for the Portland, Oregon, duo of Luke Wylands and Dan Valtka is the first on the Leaf Label.
The eighth release for the Michigan indie pop project led by Fred Thomas is its first album in five years.
The debut full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was produced by Noah Georgeson (Joanna Newsom) and Phillipe Zdar.
The second full-length album for the Canadian trio led by Elizabeth Powell was written while she was recovering from a hemorrhagic vocal polyp.

The first full-length release from the rap group in 16 years features vocals from Guru, who died in 2010 and guest appearances from Big Shug, J. Cole, Freddie Foxxx, Group Home, Jeru The Damaja, Talib Kweli, M.O.P., Ne-Yo, Nitty Scott, Q-Tip, and Royce Da 5'9".
The second full-length release for the indie pop duo of Elizabeth Sankey and Jeremy Warmsley was produced by Stephen Street.
The second release for the British indie pop band was produced by Rory Attwell.
Jim White's wife left him for another man while he was working on this album.

This full-length debut for the Glasgow indie-rock trio (who are not actually brothers, despite adopting the same last name) includes the song "Flathead," which can be heard soundtracking a recent iPod commercial.
This is the debut album on Secretly Canadian for indie rock quartet from Los Angeles.
Jim Heath & co. return for an eighth album of rockabilly tunes.

Best known as the female vocalist on Tricky's first three albums, Martina Topley-Bird finally arrives with her first solo release, which earned her a Mercury Music Prize nomination. Guest collaborators include the Tricky kid himself, as well as David Holmes and Josh Homme (Queens Of The Stone Age).
The New Zealand retro-rockers scored a major-label deal in the U.S. on the strength of this 2002 debut album, which received an American re-release in March 2003.
This is the sophomore American release from the Norweigian group, following their eponymous debut on Kindercore (which shares about half of the same tracks with this album).

The posthumous release for the rapper features guest appearances from Benny The Butcher, Bono, Conway The Machine, Cross, Denaun, Icepick, Infrared, Jay-Z, Brian King Joseph, Alicia Keys, Lil Wayne, Moneybagg Yo, Nas, Exodus Simmons, Snoop Dogg, Swizz Beatz, The LOX, Usher, and Westside Gunn.
The second full-length release for the British alternative rock band led by Rhys Edwards was recorded and mixed at their house.
The debut full-length release for the British indie pop band was produced by Rich Turvey and The Coral's James Skelly.
This is the debut release for the collaboration between producer Joanne Pollock and Aaron Funk of Venetian Snares.

The eighth solo album for the Pop Group singer features guest appearances by Primal Scream, Factory Floor, Keith Levene of Clash, Richard Hell, Lee "Scratch" Perry, Gina Birch of The Raincoats, Tessa Pollitt of Slits, Douglas Hart of Jesus and Mary Chain, and Daddy G of Massive Attack.
The third full-length release is dance pop combined with down-tempo transitions using various instrumentation and heavy, pulsating rhythms.
The debut solo album for the ex-Razorlight drummer Andy Burrows was produced by Eliot James.
The Meat Puppets return with its second album since reuniting in 2006.

Produced by T-Bone Burnett, the first solo album in over seven years for the pop singer-songwriter is a return to the more stripped down sound of his earlier career built around a piano, bass and drums.
The first release in six years since 2008's Fasciinatiion for the Omaha post-punk band was produced with Mike Mogis.
The second full-length release for the Berlin-based electronic producer Derwin Schlecker was inspired by the sounds and music he heard through his travels.
The fifth album for the San Francisco indie rock quartet is its first full-length on the Drag City label.
After many delays and controversy over the title, Nas' latest album is finally released with no title.
Fuck Button's Benjamin John Power releases his debut solo album of ambient electronic music.
The New York indie-folk band's seventh album (their first in four years) is co-produced by Warren Defever (His Name Is Alive).
Ian Broudie (Lightning Seeds) produced this debut LP for the co-ed English trio of teenagers.

The second full-length release for the Jack Antonoff solo project was influenced by the death of sister from brain cancer and features guest appearances from Sam Dew, Carly Rae Jepsen, Lorde, and Julia Michaels.
This is the latest album from the Denmark-based electronic producer.
The second full-length solo studio release for the Sigur Rós frontman was co-produced by A. G. Cook and recorded in Berlin, Helsinki, London, and Reykjavik.
The New York City five-piece band releases its third album of Americana-influenced music.
The final album for the soul singer who passed away in October 2010 features a collaboration with Dutch artist De Dijk.
The surprisingly successful party band's second album includes a track co-written with Elton John.

The third full-length release for the electronic pop duo of Aiden Whalley and James Young (James Buttery left the band in 2014) was co-produced with Lexxx and features samples of interviews of young people in Huddersfield, England.
The debut album for the indie rock band was produced by Ian Davenport.
The sixth full-length release for the British power metal band now led by Marc Hudson was produced by Jens Bogren.
Phil Elverum rerecorded with MIDI instrumentation and used Auto-Tune to create new sounds from a selection of tracks from his 2012 releases: Clear Moon and Ocean Roar.
The fifth full-length studio release for the French rock band was co-produced with Philippe Zdar of Cassius.
The British artist's debut album was one of the nominees for the 2007 Mercury Prize.
The Washington, D.C. band formed by ex-Fugazi drummer Brendan Canty and Blowoff member Rich Morel includes Devin Ocampo and Mark Cisneros of Medication on its debut release.
The third full-length release for the French-Finnish duo of Olivia Merilahti and Dan Levy was recorded at their personal studio.

The 18-track double release from the country singer features duets with such artists as Brandi Carlile, Sheryl Crow, Emmylou Harris, Norah Jones, Wynnona Judd, Alison Krauss, Miranda Lambert, Loretta Lynn, Shelby Lynne, Dolly Parton, Mavis Staples, and Carrie Underwood.
The Kevin Barnes-led sextet releases its follow-up to 2007's Hissing Fauna, Are You the Destroyer?
This is the 13th full-length studio release for the indie rock band led by E, who also produced the album.
The eighth full-length release for the Northern Ireland trio was produced by the band's frontman, Tim Wheeler.
The seventh full-length release for the gypsy punk rock band led by Eugene Hütz features a guest appearance by Regina Spektor.
The first solo release for the British electronic producer since 2009 was co-written with the Sabrettes Nina Walsh.
Producer Chris Coady returns for the third release for the Chicago indie rock trio.
The debut full-length release from the Berlin-based British DJ/producer features vocals from Boxed In's Oli Bayston and Lawrence Hart.
This is producer Darren Cunningham's second album under the name Actress.
R.E.M. returns with their 15th album, mixing up their winning musical recipe of the past with a new approach, featuring guest appearances by Patti Smith, Eddie Vedder, and Peaches.
This is the debut full-length release for the Berlin-based pop trio.
The first post-GBV solo outing for the prolific Pollard was produced by Todd Tobias.
The fifth full-length release from the British producer/singer was influenced by 1980s pop-soul.
The first full-length for the pop singer since 2012's Lotus features guest appearances from 2 Chainz, GoldLink, Keida, Demi Lovato, Shenseea, Ty Dolla $ign, and XNDA.
Mark Lanegan collaborates with British Blues artist Duke Garwood on the release recorded by Justin Smith in California.
This is the debut album for The Shins James Mercer and producer Brian Burton (aka as Danger Mouse).
The fifth full-length release for the psychedelic rock band led by Montreal husband-and-wife duo of Jace Lasek and Olga Goreas features two new band members, Sheenah Ko and Robbie Macarthur.
The second full-length release for the Aaron Jerome project features guest appearances from A$AP Ferg, Ezra Koenig, Koreless, Denai Moore, Caroline Polachek, Raury, Sampha, Jessie Ware, and Warpaint.
The debut full-length for the indie-rock band from Long Beach, California.
The first new release since 1979 would be the final album for the rock 'n' roll legend.
This is the full-length debut release for the Brooklyn-based duo of Eric Emm and Jesse Cohen.
The latest album for the metal band from Washington includes members from Big Business who joined the band on their last album.
Though it's been seven years since Social Distortion's last release, the newest album picks up where they left off with visceral, hard-driving rock songs about love and life.
The debut full-length release for the former Oasis lead singer was produced by Dan Grech-Marguerat and Greg Kurstin.
The follow-up to her 2007 debut album was produced by Greg Kurstin.
The third full-length release for Years & Years is now an Olly Alexander solo project after Mikey Goldsworthy and Emre Türkmen stepped back as active members.

The fourth and final installment of the Maryland rapper's Young Sinatra series features guest appearances from Big Lenbo, Cappadonna, Ghostface Killah, Inspectah Deck, Jackpot Scotty Wotty, KAjo, John Lindahl, Masta Killa, Method Man, Raekwon, RZA, Lucy Rose & The RattPack, Slaydro, Jaden Smith, Hailee Steinfeld, Ryan Tedder, U-God, and Wale.

recordname: This Girl's in Love (A Bacharach & David Songbook)
description: The fourth full-length release for the British singer-songwriter features songs written by Burt Bacharach and Hal David was recorded with her husband Rob Shirakbari and with Bacharach on piano.
The full-length debut for the electro-pop quartet that includes Nick Krill and Joe Hobson of the Spinto Band.
The third full-length release for the indie pop band led by Michael Angelakos was co-produced with Chris Zane, Alex Aldi, and Benny Blanco.
The latet solo release for the New York singer-songwriter features contributions from Peter Buck, Craig Finn, Wayne Kramer and J. Mascis.

The first studio solo release in 20 years for the founding member of The Byrds and Crosby, Stills & Nash features guest appearances from Mark Knopfler, Wynton Marsalis, Leland Sklar, and Steve Tavaglione.
The second full-length release for the rapper features guest appearances from Amber Coffman, Miguel, and Kendrick Lamar.
Tom Jones latest release is a disc of covers of contemporary blues and classic rock songs.
The latest album for the San Francisco-based indie band is its first since 2008's U.S. EZ.
This is the debut album for the band led by Portland's Kevin and Anita Robinson. The Swords' Evan Railton, The Decemberists' Chris Funk, and The Golden Bears' Seth Lorinczi round out the quintet.
The debut album for the brothers from New Orleans.

recordname: The Hair, The TV, The Baby & The Band
description: After a five-year hiatus, the San Francisco band returns with their fourth album.
Put a woman on drums and her (ex-)husband on guitars/keyboards, and you have Quasi, The White Stripes, and... The Like Young, whose Amanda and Joe Ziemba return for a third album.
This is the debut album for the Florida-based electronic-pop duo of Ben Cooper and Alex Kane.
Before reuniting The Pixies, Black recorded this mellow solo disc in four days in a Nashville studio, backed by veteran southern session musicians.
John Schmersal and Enon return with their third LP, which features an increased vocal presence by Toko Yasuda.
He's nothing if not prolific. Black's fourth album in two and a half years features 13 new tracks and appearances from some of his usual cohorts (Stan Ridgway, Joey Santiago).

The popular electronica band, now down to two members (founders Rick Smith and Karl Hyde) after the departure of DJ Darren Emerson, move forward with their first studio recording in three years, highlighted by 9-minute lead single "Two Months Off."

recordname: Ray Guns Are Not Just The Future
description: The second full-length album for the duo of Greg Kurstin and Inara George.
The first release in three years for the Atlanta rock band was recorded in New York with Tommy Brenneck and in Tennessee with Patrick Carney.

The fifth full-length release for the Australian psychedelic rock band led by Nick Allbrook was originally planned as the sixth album [Original fifth album, Man, It Feels Like Space Again is now the planned sixth disc].
The 10th full-length release for the rock band was co-produced with Tyler Bates.
Q-Tip and Tim Burgess (The Charlatans) guest on the UK dance duo's fifth full-length.
The second full-length release for the Manchester singer-songwriter features a 16-minute-long track.
The trio from New York City (who have only one female member, and none of them are from Brazil) releases its third album.
The Grammy award-winning electronic dance duo--and their masked identities portraying them as man-machines--make a logical pairing to score the soundtrack of the innovative science fiction film.

Eno sings! And while those words are sure to excite fans of the bald one's 70s classics such as 'Taking Tiger Mountain (By Strategy),' his first vocal album in 15 years is much closer in sound and mood to more recent efforts as well as the final handful of tracks on 'Eno Box II: Vocals' (the latter's "Under" even appears again on this disc).
The Portland, Oregon-based electronic dance band releases its sophomore full-length album.
The 12th full-length release from the Norwegian experimental group features tracks recorded live from 12 different shows in February 2014.
The second full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was co-produced with Lexx and features contributions from Robin Hannibal, Willy Mason, and Royce Wood Jr.
The third full-length studio release for the Texas quartet is described by the band as doomgaze.
The third album for the indie rock band from Tennessee was produced by Sparklehorse's Scott Minor.
The Brooklyn indie rock duo from Texas releases its debut album.
The melodic emo chart-toppers from Washington return with their seventh album.
The fifth full-length studio release for the Sacramento dance-punk band was produced by Spoon's Jim Eno.
The fourth full-length release for the indie rock group was produced by Adam Landry and Justin Collins.
The post-rock group releases its latest album, which has only four tracks (each are eight or more minutes long).
The debut album for the British indie rock trio.
The fifth studio album for the Canadian singer and producer is also the soundtrack to the documentary of the same name.
The third album from the indie-rock Texans features some of their most mood-driven music thus far, with dreamy vocals and eclectic arrangements to add dimension to their sound.

recordname: VYP: Voice of the Young People
description: The debut album includes Hot 100 single "Lip Gloss" released last year, as well as the Avril Lavigne remix of "Girlfriend."
The latest solo release for the former member of The Boo Radley was mixed by Greg Haver and Clint Murphy.
The Austin group added four members since its 2008 album for the band's fourth album.
This is the second album for the indie rock band formed in Washington D.C.
This is the debut album for Rick Froberg's latest band.

recordname: Man On The Moon: The End Of Day
description: The debut album for the Cleveland-born who helped cowrite four tracks on Kayne West's "808s & Heartbreak."
The singer-songwriter releases his latest album of roots rock recorded at his home studio.

The fifth full-length studio release for the Detroit rapper features guest appearances from 42 Dugg, Anderson.Paak, Jhené Aiko, Boldy James, Cash Kidd, Diddy, Drego, Dwele, Earlly Mac, Eminem, Hit-Boy, Kash Doll, Dom Kennedy, Lil Wayne, Nipsey Hussle, Payroll, Post Malone, Royce da 5'9", Sada Baby, Travis Scott, Tee Grizzley, Twenty88, Ty Dolla Sign, Wale, and Young Thug.
Alan Moulder and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs' Nick Zinner are among the producers on the UK goth-punk band's debut LP.
The latest release for the Boston singer-songwriter is said to be a continuation of her 2010 self-titled album.
The fourth full-length release (and fourth self-titled album that was released in March 2015 in Spain) for the Spanish blues rock trio was recorded in London with producer Liam Watson.
This is the second full-length indie pop release for K Ishibashi.
This is the second album for the Philadelphia-based singer-songwriter.
The third full-length release for the band led by Ari Picker is down to from a quintet to a quartet.
The self-produced second release for the British folk-pop band was mainly written in a camper van in Oxford.
The second full-length release for the grime artist features Kozzie, Meleka, Riko, Trim, MCs Deadly, Mayhem, and Saf-One as guest vocalists.
The UK rockers (making their full-length debut with this Flood- and Simon Raymonde-produced disc) are fronted by Liela Moss, who has drawn comparisons to Patti Smith and PJ Harvey.
The debut full-length release for the Wisconsin indie pop group was produced by Brian Joseph.
The second album for the all-women rock band from Atlanta was produced by Ed Rawls.
Edan mixes a variety of songs from the Traffic Entertainment Group into a 29-minute track.
The third full-length release for the Nashville-based garage rock band was produced by Vance Powell.
The first release in six years (and his first on the Capitol Records label) for the singer-songwriter was produced by Don Was and Jacknife Lee.

Some early versions of the songs on the sixth full-length studio release for the British indie rock band were released as part of six EPs that were released in conjunction with its monthly Krankenhaus club nights.
Whoa, Nelly indeed. Timbaland produced the bulk of the singer's dancier, poppier third album, and even sings on one track.
This is the second album for the electronic artist from Rhode Island.

Following the unexpected critical and commercial success of M!ssundaztood, Pink returns with a third, even more rock-oriented album. Linda Perry returns to helm just a few tracks, with the bulk of the producing/writing chores falling to Rancid's Tim Armstrong.
This is the sophomore LP (third, if you count their debut demo collection) for the Toronto band led by Joel Gibb.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Canadian dance-punk duo was self-produced and recorded.

The debut full-length release for the Seattle rapper features guest appearances from Alana Belle, Black, Cashtro, Fly Guy Dai, JD, Nate Jack, The Palaceer, Aslan T. Rife, Shabazz Palaces, Stas THEE Boss, Debra Sullivan (his mother), Thad, and THEESatisfaction.

'Brother Is To Son' is nominally a solo effort for Daniel Smith (aka "Brother Danielson," aka leader of the Christian indie-rock outfit the Danielson Familie), although fellow Familie (and, in real life, family) members appear throughout this acoustic-only disc, as does frequent collaborator Sufjan Stevens.
The Def Jux rapper expands into the realm of modern jazz, with the help of Blue Series stalwarts Matthew Shipp, William Parker and Guillermo Brown.
What sounds like a Steely Dan clearance sale is actually the veteran duo's first album of new material since their 2000 comeback effort 'Two Against Nature.'
The English singer-songwriter finally returns with a follow-up to his 1999 breakthrough hit 'White Ladder.'
The Manchester-based pyschedelic pop quartet returns with a follow-up to their 2001 debut, 'Chemistry Is What We Are.'
Ivy's Andy Chase produced this sophomore effort from the French band that gave us 2000's irresistibly poppy 'Puzzle.'
The popular German trance DJ offers up his first set of original songs, featuring guest vocals by the likes of Kelis and Finley Quaye.

Playgroup is the brainchild of producer/designer Trevor Jackson, who has remixed artists such as Massive Attack, U2, and Death In Vegas. On this eponymous debut, a variety of guests from the hip-hop and indie music worlds (Kathleen Hanna, Shinehead, Edwyn Collins, KC Flightt, Roddy Frame, Rowetta) lends vocals to the twelve eclectic tracks, including a cover of Paul Simon's "50 Ways To Leave Your Lover."
The second album from Los Angeles rap outfit Dilated Peoples features contributions from JuJu, DJ Premier, Tha Liks, Alchemist and Da Beatminerz.
This is the follow-up to the singer's acclaimed 1999 debut. Rick Rubin produces, with guest appearances from Slick Rick, Mos Def, and Erykah Badu.
This debut album from two-step pioneer MJ Cole was nominated for the Mercury Prize in the UK (but lost out to Badly Drawn Boy).

recordname: The Good, the Bad, and the Funky

description: The third full-length release for the indie pop duo of Madeline Follin and Brian Oblivion was produced by Shane Stoneback.

recordname: Texas Rose, The Thaw & The Beasts
description: Rafter Roberts produced the latest album for the Raymond Raposa-led band.
This is the latest release for the Chicago-based experimental indie rock band.
This is the debut full-length release for the British duo of Isaac Holman and Laurie Vincent.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Vancouver indie rock duo of Becky Black and Maya Miller was produced by Jim Diamond.
Pianist Chick Corea and vibraphonist Gary Burton team up again on this album of pop and jazz cover songs.

recordname: Dark Is the Way, Light Is a Place
description: The fifth album for the alternative rock band was produced by Brendan O'Brien.
Originally called Peggy Sue And The Pirates, the British trio shortened its name to just Peggy Sue for its debut full-length release.
Tchad Blake co-produced the singer-songwriter's seventh album. The Red Hot Chili Peppers' Flea guests.

recordname: Heard It in a Past Life
description: The debut full-length major label release for the singer-songwriter features contributions from such artists as Rostam Batmanglij, Kid Harpoon, Greg Kurstin, and Ricky Reed.
'Lost Marbles' collects six years of previously uncompiled material by the John Schmersal-led band, including internet-only tracks and limited-edition singles.
The debut album for the rock band headed up by The Strokes' Fabrizio Moretti and Rodrigo Amarante.
Ben Hillier produced the English band's sophomore set, which is a bit more varied in sound than their debut.
Recorded in Sacramento, the third full-length studio release for the garage rock artist is his first on the Merge label.
The fourth full-length release for the all-female punk rock band is its first without keyboardist Candice Jones.
The songs on the Boston band's EP were originally written as a Valentine's Day present for lead singer Michael Angelakos' girlfriend.
The fourth album for the San Francisco indie duo of Adam Stephens and Tyson Vogel was produced with John Congleton.
This is the second album for the artist who is also working on a Ph.D. on ethnomusicology.

recordname: Such Pretty Forks in the Road
description: The ninth full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter is her first since 2012's Havoc And Bright Lights.
The latest full-length for the noise rock band from Boston was recorded over six weeks in upstate New York.
The fourth studio release for the Irish rockabilly singer was produced by Mike Crossey.
The eighth full-length studio release for the Grammy-winning British electronic funk band led by Jay Kay is its first in seven years.
The sixth full-length release for the Northern California punk band is its first on the Relapse label.
Co-producer with Eric Bauer, the fourth full-length release for rock band led by Ethan Miller, was conceived as part one of a planned trilogy.
Jason Cupp returns to produce the second album for the indie rock quartet from Chicago.
The debut full-length release from Seth Haley is a concept album about the life and death of a robot astronaut.
The second album for the Grammy-winning singer features Ne-Yo as a guest artist.
This is the debut LP for the new project from Chris Lopez (Rock*A*Teens).
The first full-length release in six years for the Red Hot Chili Peppers is also the first with John Frusciante since 2006's Stadium Arcadium.
The second full-length release for the garage rock band formed by Mississippi-born John Barrett was self-produced.
This is the debut album on the Dead Oceans label for the trio from Brooklyn and Chicago.
The collection contains various covers recorded for tribute albums, plus radio recordings and two instrumentals.
The San Francisco indie band Imperial Teen returns to release its fifth studio album five years after its 2007 album, The Hair, The TV, The Baby & The Band.
The German electronic trio is now just a solo project of remaining member Markus Popp.
This is the second release for the side project of Portishead's Geoff Barrow.
The British indie pop band incorporates more experimental textures and electronic instruments into its sophomore album produced by Ben Allen.
The concept album produced by Atticus Rose and Joe Barresi is the prequel to the prog rock band's Amory Wars narrative, written by singer Claudio Sanchez.
The Mississippi rapper's fourth album includes appearances by Talib Kweli and Too Short.
The fourth full-length release for the folk rock band was produced by David Rawlings.
The third solo album for the Eski-Beat/Grime UK artist.
The English electronic duo releases its ninth album, which was also released as a download earlier this year.
The second full-length solo studio release for the Arcade Fire member was self-recorded and produced at his Brooklyn home during the COVID-19 pandemic lockdown.
The sixth full-length release for the Brooklyn post-punk quartet was recorded over a weekend in January and produced by Jordan Lovelace.
Carla Bozulich releases her latest album under the new band name of Evangelista.
This is the fourth album for the San Diego, Calif. instrumental post-rock outfit.
The third solo album for the member of Blackalicious was co-produced with G Koop.
The 10th album for the alt-rocker features Susanna Hoffs on backing vocals on one track.
The Australian psychedelic garage band's second release in 2015 is an acoustic album recorded mainly at frontman Stu Mackenzie's family farm.

The follow-up to the jazz musician's Grammy-winning R&B release includes contributions from such artist as Marsha Ambrosius, Brandy, Common, Dwele, Faith Evans, Anthony Hamilton, Lalah Hathaway, Norah Jones, Jill Scott, Snoop Dogg, Fall Out Boy's Patrick Stump, and Malcolm Jamal Warner.
This is the Japanese artist's fourth album of experimental pop.
The British industrial music pioneers return with their first studio album in 25 years. The band's original lineup is present, including Genesis P-Orridge and Chris Carter.
Dan Wilson (Semisonic) produced this solo effort for the former Soul Coughing frontman, which finds him backed by a band for the first time since leaving that band. Dave Matthews guests.
The second full-length studio release for the South Korean pop group features guest appearances from Cardi B and Selena Gomez.

The full-length debut from Joy Williams and John Paul White  featured on an episode of Greys Anatomy  is a collection of lyrically deep songs of love and the human condition, using the simplicity of multiple instruments and soulful vocals.
The Scottish band's follow-up to its debut album "Fourteen Autumns and Fifteen Winters" was produced by guitarist Andy McFarlane and Paul Savage.
This is the second album on the Jive label for the rock quartet from St. Louis.

Recorded live at Los Angeles' Wiltern Theater in 2003, this 2-disc set finds Reed supported by a small (drummerless) band on material culled from his recent disc 'The Raven' as well as older albums from his 35-plus-year career (including Velvet Underground tunes "Venus In Furs," "Candy Says," and "Heroin").
The New York singer-songwriter works with producer Patrick Leonard (Madonna, Jewel) for this, his fourth album.

A comeback of sorts, 'Title TK' comes a full nine years after The Breeders' previous effort (1993's 'Last Splash') and sees the group with a new lineup (only Kim Deal and sister Kelley remain) and producer (Steve Albini).

Warren Zevon's eleventh studio recording (his first, 'Wanted Dead or Alive,' was released in 1969!) features songs penned with the help of an unusual group of collaborators, including novelist Carl Hiaasen and sportswriter Mitch Albom (whose song, "Hit Somebody! (The Hockey Song)," features a vocal spot from David Letterman, of all people).

Scottish composer Craig Armstrong has provided his arranging and writing talents to numerous film soundtracks (including Moulin Rouge) and albums by the likes of Massive Attack and Madonna. This is his third solo album, and features guest appearances by Evan Dando, Mogwai, Bono, and Photek.
The second release for the duo Joy Williams and John Paul White followed an announced hiatus in November 2012 due to "internal discord and irreconcilable differences of ambition."
The indie band formed in Portland, Oregon, releases its first album with new official member, bassist Joanna Bolme.
The South African DJ/electronic producer's first full-length release on the Hyperdub label features guest appearances from K-$, K Rizz and Queezy.
Andrew Cohen, the Michigan-born singer-songwriter, releases his debut album.

The 11th full-length studio release for the rock band led by Debbie Harry features contributions from such artists as Laurie Anderson, The Gregory Brothers, Dev Hynes, Joan Jett, Sia, Dave Sitek, and Nick Valensi.
The fifth release from the blues singer was created on a guitar made from hubcaps.
This is the fifth album for the reunited version of the punk band (still featuring Pete Shelley and Steve Diggle), now marking over 30 years since their original formation.
The second full-length solo release for the former Fifth Harmony singer features guest appearances from DaBaby and Shawn Mendes.
The eighth full-length studio release for the Los Angeles-based rock band was produced by Nick Launay.

recordname: Man on the Moon, Vol. 3: The Chosen
description: The third and final installment of the rapper's Main On The Moon trilogy features guest appearances from Phoebe Bridgers, Pop Smoke, Skepta, and Trippie Redd.

The classically-trained, Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter returns with her rich and varied fifth full-length which, like her previous outing, finds her utilizing (at times) a backing band. Members of Beachwood Sparks, Dead Meadow and Brian Jonestown Massacre guest.
The follow-up to Vast Aire and Vordul Mega's debut release Cold Vein comes 14 years later with an album produced by Bill Cosmiq.
The latest release for the Chicago singer-songwriter is a cover album of the Dave Matthews Band's unreleased (but bootlegged and some rerecorded for Busted Stuff) Lillywhite Sessions.
The debut album for the duo from Australia was produced by band member Johnny Siera.
This is the debut full-length release for Kansas singer-songwriter Taryn Miller was produced by Nicolas Vernhes.
The Pinback co-founder releases his latest solo album.
The sixth full-length release for Nathan Williams-led band features influences from 1950s doo-wop, Cambodian pop, and South American '70's psychedelia.

Co-produced by Rhett Davies, the Roxy Music singer's latest solo release features original songs and two covers songs as well as contributions from Flea, Mark Knopfler, Johnny Marr, Maceo Parker, Nile Rodgers of Chic, Ronnie Spector, and Todd Terje.
The debut full-length solo release for the Hot Chip artist-producer features a guest appearance from SLO (Jess Mills).

recordname: T R O U B L E
description: Featuring guest appearances by David Thomas Broughton and Mary Margaret O'Hara, the sixth full-length studio release from the Canadian collective led by Mark Andrew Hamilton was inspired by his two years traveling around the world.
The seventh full-length release for the Australian rock band sees the return of original drummer Christian Strybosch.
The latest release for the Seattle-based rock trio features guest appearances from Hayes Carll and Lydia Loveless.
The four-track EP from the British alternative rock band founded by Robert Hampson comes after the group reunited in 2013 for the All Tomorrow's Parties festival.
The latest album from Masaki Batoh, the singer for the band Ghost, includes sounds made from brain waves he records with his Brain Pulse Machine.

This acoustic, live album from the former Soundgarden frontman features songs from every musical side project he has had a part in, including music from Temple of the Dog; Audioslave; and his solo album, Scream.
The second solo album for the cellist from Kentucky blends ideas from other music genres and was produced by Duane Lundy.

recordname: I Can Wonder What You Did with Your Day
description: The Canadian singer's latest solo album was produced by ex-Eric's Trip bandmate Rick White.
The 11th full-length for the British electronic duo of Ed Handley and Andy Turner features flute and guitar from Benet Walsh.
The 14th release for the San Francisco psych-rock band led by Anton Newcombe includes contributions from Ricky Maymi, Joachim Alhund, Constantine Karlis, and Ryan Van Kriedt.
This is the second solo release for the prolific Guided By Voices' singer-songwriter.
This is the third solo release for the former Stereolab singer.
This is the second album (and Saddle Creek debut) for the San Francisco duo of Adam Stephens and Tyson Vogel.
The second full-length studio release for rapper Cordae features guest appearances from Ant Clemons, Eminem, Freddie Gibbs, Gunna, H.E.R., Lil Durk, Lil Wayne, Roddy Ricch, and Stevie Wonder.
The two-disc release from Nils Frahm features 23 solo piano compositions recorded between 2009 and 2021 that were not included on previous albums.
The ninth full-length studio release for the folk rock band was self-produced and recorded at a farm in upstate New York.
The former singer of The Delgados releases her debut solo album.
Among the producers and guest vocalists appearing on Usher's fourth album are Ludacris, Nelly, Jermaine Dupri, The Neptunes, and Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis.
The Strokes' self-produced fourth album strikes a neo-garage rock chord with the past, recalling the early sounds of their 2001 debut.
Amos Lee and Trombone Shorty guest on the latest album from the country band.
Justin Vernon (of Bon Iver), Jon Mueller, Chris Rosenau, Jim Schoenecker, Daniel Spack, and Thomas Wincek of Collections of Colonies of Bees join up to release their debut together as Volcano Choir.
22 years after their debut release, the alternative rock trio fronted by Juliana Hatfield returns with an album funded by Pledge Music.
This is the second album for the D.C.-based duo of Ian MacKaye (Fugazi) and Amy Farina (The Warmers).
This first solo disc in eight years for the former Birthday Party and Bad Seeds member mixes covers with two Harvey originals.
The ninth full-length studio release for the British indie rock band led by David Gedge was inspired by his trip across the United States in 2014.
The fourth full-length release for the British blues and folk duo was produced by Kristofer Harris.
The second full-length release for the Tom Dougall-led rock band was produced by Dan Carey.
The 13th full-length studio release for the synth-pop band was self-produced.
This is the fourth release from the London-based Australian indie trio (previously known as Pivot).
On of the many aliases of rapper Daniel Dumile (who is best known these days as the masked MF Doom), Viktor Vaughn is joined by a guests such as DJ Sure Shot and Kool Keith on this second release.
The German noisemakers return with a somewhat quieter affair, marking their first studio recording in four years.
The neo-soul singer returns two years after the success of 'Songs In A Minor' with this sophomore disc.

Richard Warren's third LP, produced by Flood, finds the multi-instrumentalist moving more toward mainstream electro/synth pop, closer to bands such as New Order and Primal Scream than his more experimental albums 'Volume 1' and 'Volume 2.'

The second album for acclaimed German electronica outfit Schneider TM (actually just one man, Dirk Dresselhaus) contains a mix of Mouse On Mars-like glitchy instrumental compositions and more poppy vocal tracks.

This is the eighth full-length release for British art-pop ensemble. Not surprisingly, John McEntire and Jim O'Rourke co-produced the album, with additional contributions from Sean O'Hagan (The High Llamas).
The fifth full-length release for the Las Vegas rock band was produced by Jacknife Lee.
The British alternative rock band's its eleventh album was produced by Martin Glover.
The second full-length album for the singer-songwriter from Philadelphia was produced by Larry Klein.
The veteran South Bronx, New York no-wave outfit returns after a four-year recording hiatus, with a multi-generational lineup that includes the daughters of some of the original members.
The debut release for the British drum and bass band includes guest appearances from such artists as Angel Haze, Alex Clare, and Emeli Sandé.
The indie rock trio led by Dinosaur Jr. bassist Lou Barlow releases its first album in 14 years.
This is the debut full-length release for the Nashville indie quartet that includes Cheap Time's Jeffrey Novak and Jessica McFarland and Heavy Cream's Mimi Galbierz and Dillon Watson.
This is the latest full-length release for the Mike Sniper project.
This genre-hopping eponymous disc is the debut for the duo of guitarist Dan Gullucci (Modest Mouse) and MC Sean Reveron.
The debut full-length release for the British indie rock band was produced by Jolyon Thomas (James Dring and Hugo White also produced one track each).
The second full-length release for the music project of Australian Craig Dermody was influenced by his move to New York.
The second full-length release for folk rock singer-songwriter Dan Willson was produced by Tony Doogan.
Buddy Miller and Jim Lauderdale recorded their debut country duet release in three days.
The latest album from Los Angeles singer-songwriter Ramona Gonzales is her first release on the Secretly Canadian label.
The San Francisco-based band that started in Santa Cruz, releases its debut album.
The fifth full-length album for indie rock band was produced by Metric's guitarist Jimmy Shaw.
The fourth album for the British singer features Tilda Swinton as a guest artist.

recordname: Do You Want New Wave Or Do You Want The Soft Pink Truth?
