description: A side project for Matmos' Drew Daniel, The Soft Pink Truth here offers (in their own, unique way) a variety of punk covers, including songs by the Angry Samoans, Minor Threat and Die Kreuzen.
Chaz Bundick is the one-man project behind Toro Y Moi. He mixes the best musical elements from across the globe, including electronic, psychedelic-rock, and R&B on his first full length record.
This is the third album for the Brooklyn, New York duo.
The reigning pop queen releases her second full-length studio album.
Dave Sardy produced this sophomore album for the Canadian band, whose lineup now includes guitarist Luke Paquin (replacing Dante DeCaro).
The fourth full-length solo release for The Last Shadow Puppets/The Rascals frontman Miles Kane features a guest appearance from Corinne Bailey Rae.
The latest release for the project led by David Moore features a Farfisa with clarinet from Jeremy Viner and double bass from Jeff Ratner.
The debut full-length release for the Los Angeles rock band led by Arrow DeWilde was produced by Ryan Adams.
The latest release for the hip-hop producer was self produced and features guest appearances from Blueprint, Jordan Brown, Phonte Coleman, Josh Krajcik, and Son Little.
The second full-length release for the pop project led by Justin Paul Vallesteros was produced by Dylan Wall
This is the official debut solo studio release for the London-based producer who previously was part of the electronic duo, Hype Williams.
Produced by Peter Asher, the third release on the Rounder label for Steve Martin sees the comedian/banjo player teaming up with Edie Brickell on this album of bluegrass music.
Iggy Pop sings a duet on the second full-length release produced by Dr. Luke for the dance-pop singer.
The duo who was part of the group Galaxie 500 returns with its fourth album with Ghost guitarist Michio Kurihara.
Recorded in just a few days, Chicago's long-standing indie rock band returns with their tenth album of rootsy '90s rock.
This is the debut album for the Philadelphia duo of Jon Barthmus, formally of the A-Sides, and Patrick Marsciell.
The eighth full-length studio release for the Atlanta rock band was produced by Sean Lennon.

recordname: Right Thoughts, Right Words, Right Action
description: The fourth full-length studio release for the Scottish indie rock band was self-produced.
The debut album for the songwriter includes songs written and produced by RedOne and Space Cowboy.
The second full-length release for the New York indie rock duo was produced by Christopher Daly.

The 11th full-length studio release for the German electronic duo features contributions from such artists as Sam Amidon, Amanda Blank, Eric D. Clarke, Zach Condon, Aaron and Bryce Dessner, Ensemble Musikfabrik, Lisa Hannigan, Spank Rock, Swamp Dogg, and Justin Vernon.
The three-disc set (two CDs and a DVD) features a recording of the ex-Beatle's three-night concert in New York City's Citi Field on July 17, 18, and 21, 2009.
This is the second album for the eclectic, multi-lingual New York band that, despite its name, is largely male and definitely not Brazilian.
This is the first full-length studio release for British rock band Porcupine Tree since 2009's The Incident.
The eighth full-length studio release for George Evelyn features guest appearances from Allan Kingdom, Andrew Ashong, LSK, Mozez, Jordan Rakei, Kuauhtli Vasquez, Sadie Walker, and Wixarika Tribe.

recordauthor: The Pains of Being Pure at Heart
description: The fourth full-length release for the New York indie pop band led by Kip Berman was produced by Andy Savours and features guest appearances from A Sunny Day in Glasgow's Jen Goma, Jacob Danish Sloan, and Kelly Pratt.
The Canadian four-piece returns with another album of catchy post-punk tunes, complete with the high energy and quirkiness Tokyo Police Club has cultivated throughout the years.
This is the fourth album for the indie project led by Jason Robert Quever.
'Death' is the third album for Seattle's David Terry, who almost single-handedly is Aqueduct.

After much delay due to their other projects, Damon Albarn of Blur and Gorillaz, Red Hot Chili Peppers' Flea, and Tony Allen's super group formed in 2008 finally releases its debut album featuring guest appearances by Erykah Badu, Fatoumata Diawara, M.anifest, M3nsa, and Cheick Tidiane Seck.

The latest solo album for the Brooklyn rapper was originally set to be a self-released digital-only album (Duck Down signed on to release the physical version). It features production from Ski Beatz, S1, Marco Polo, M-Phazes, 88-Keys, Shuko, 6th Sense, E. Jones, Nick Speed, KYRYSIS!, Blaq Toven, Oh No, and Maurice Brown.
The debut full-length release for the British trio that includes Pete & The Pirate's singer Thomas Sanders was produced by Bernard Butler.

Foo Fighters, Jennifer Hudson, Kid Rock, Miranda Lambert, My Morning Jacket, Brad Paisley, Bob Seger, and Keith Urban are some of the guests helping the Creedence Clearwater Revival singer cover some of his songs.
The heavy metal legends return with their 15th studio release, still reinventing rock 35 years into their careers.

recordauthor: The Pains of Being Pure at Heart
description: The four-track EP features a song remixed by Saint Etienne.
The Scottish rock band's first album since 2008's The Gift was produced by JD Twitch.
Producer Gil Norton returns for the Foo Fighters' sixth album.
Th eighth full-length release for the pop singer-songwriter features guest appearances from Cash Cash, Khalid, Chris Stapleton, and Wrabel.
The latest solo release from the Black Dice founding member expands the experimental dance style he begun on 2011's Limbo with samples and beats.
Darker My Love's Tim Presley releases his second solo album.
The 12th album for the musician was released both with and without his backing band, The Blokes.
Will Ozanne's debut album as Gang Colours features a mix of downtempo and UK garage music.
"Mercy," the single from Duffy's debut album, made her the first female Welsh singer to hit number one on the UK pop charts in over 20 years.
The six-track min-album is the first credited to the Brooklyn-based duo's new name of Young Ejecta after a legal dispute over the name Ejecta with a similarly named DJ Ejeca.
The self-released seventh solo album for the Seattle-based singer-songwriter was funded by fan donations.
The country star covers 15 classic gospel hyms with this acoustic collection.
The English singer-songwriter has drawn comparisons to PJ Harvey, Cat Power and even Kurt Cobain for her sometimes abrasive, sometimes minimal, bluesy sound.
The Swedish metal band's 10th studio album is the last with keyboardist Per Wiberg.
The second album for the band features a film directed by the band's lead singer, Charles Fink.
The latest release for Mark Oliver Everett is what he calls his "divorce album."
The second full-length release for the British indie-pop trio was produced by Ash Workman.
The life of Italian publisher, Giangiacomo Feltrinelli is the concept behind the second release from Gruff Rhys and Boom Bip.
This is the sophomore album for the metal band from Austin, Texas.
The third album for the British band (now down to three members) was co-produced by Steve Osborne and Jim Abbiss along with Clearlake frontman Jason Pegg.
The English rock band reunites after its 1999 split to release its fourth album.
This is the debut full-length album for the British quartet who met at Leeds University.
The second full-length release for the electronic duo of Nick Weiss and Logan Takahashi features guest appearances by Kelela, Panda Bear, Laurel Halo, and Romanthony.
After catching the ear of Sub Pop with its self-released album There's No Sky (Oh My My), the Milwaukee, Wisconsin, quartet recorded its major label debut with Justin Perkins.
The two-disc set for the Swedish rock band is its fifth studio album.
The first of the double EP set, March of the Zapotec, features Mexican music influences, whereas the second, Holland, includes songs made by Zach Condon under the name Realpeople.
The second set of demos from the Weezer singer ranges from 1993 to 2008.

Elvis has returned to the land of rock--or at least, country-flavored rock, as he's joined on several tracks by Lucinda Williams and Emmylou Harris. It's his second disc to feature (and first to credit) his new backing band, The Impostors, who look an awful lot like his former backing band, The Attractions, save for the addition of bassist Davey Faragher.
The Toronto lo-fi indie-rockers, led by Will Oldham-esque singer-songwriter Aaron Riches, make their Sanctuary debut with this third album.
The UK five-piece worked with producer Tchad Blake for this fourth LP.
On their third full-length, the Icelandic band Mum continues to blend pastoral electronica with the distinctive vocals (think The Cranes as a comparison) of Kristín Anna Valtýsdóttir.
The country singer's fourth studio album and Sugarhill debut was recorded in just two weeks with returning producer R.S. Field.

recordname: Wherever I Am I Am What Is Missing
description: The London, England band's fourth LP finds them stripping away some of the layers (and extra musicians) found on previous outings for a more organic trip-hop approach.
The band's first album of new songs since 1999's Viva el Amor contains 12 mostly reggae-tinged tracks.
The fourth album for the Orange County frat-rockers.
Guitarist Nathan Thelen is out, and keyboardist Leona Marrs is in, for the third LP from the Andrea Zollo-fronted band.
The five-track EP from the Tampa indie rock trio is its first release on the Night people label.
The debut release for the Canadian-born, London, England-based singer-songwriter Al Spx was produced by Jim Anderson.
The Canadian duo of Jim Guthrie and Islands singer Nick Thorburn release their debut album as Human Highway.
The fourth studio album for the Southern California band is based on Alex Greenwald's ideas about spending time with a fictional cult.
The fifth full-length release for the Canadian indie rock band was produced by Richard Swift.
After the breakup of Port O'Brien, Van Pierszalowski traveled and eventually decided to return to Oslo to work on this debut solo release.
John Doe coproduced his latest solo album with Dave Way, which features guest appearances from Howie Gelb, Patty Griffin, Smokey Hormel, and Jill Sobule.

recordname: Interpreting The Masters, Volume 1: A Tribute to Daryl Hall And John Oates
description: Inara George and Greg Kurstin cover eight Hall & Oates classic songs, including one original song influenced by the duo.

The Canadian semi-rapper (think more Beck than Eminem) returns with his first album of all-new material in two years, which includes contributions from DJ D Styles, Chicago post-rockers Tortoise and singer Lesley Feist.
The second full-length release for the Olympia, Washington, garage-punk band was self-recorded.
This is the debut solo release for Simone Felice, singer for The Duke & The King and former member of The Felice Brothers.
The latest album from the Brooklyn-based artist also known as Mike Sniper, who's real identity remains mysterious.

The collaboration between Green Day frontman Billie Joe Armstrong and Grammy-winning singer Norah Jones is their take on the collection of reinterpreted Americana songs recorded by The Everly Brothers in 1958.

The 13th full-length release for the British trip-hop artist features guest appearances from Asia Argento, Francesca Belmonte, Terra Lopez, Avalon Lurks, Mina Rose, Scriptonite, Smoky Mo, and Martina Topley-Bird.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles-based indie band led by Ben Schneider (who also produced the album) was mixed by Dave Fridmann.

recordname: How to Solve Our Human Problems, Pts. 1-3
description: The 15-track release for the Scottish indie pop group led by Stuart Murdoch was produced by Leo Abrahams. It collects the songs from three earlier EPs released in December, January and February into one full-length album.
The final album for the singer-songwriter who passed away in November 2016 was produced by Mark Lambert.
The debut full-length release for the Canadian synth-pop duo features "A Real Hero," the collaborative song with Collage that appeared in the 2011 film "Drive."
The fourth full-length release for the Pennsylvania punk band was produced by Jonathan Low.
The Irish singer-songwriter returns to a more acoustic sound on his third full-length album.
The first Spanish-language album for the Canadian-born singer features Alejandro Fernyndez, Juan Luis Guerra, Julieta Venegas, La Mala Rodrýguez and Concha Buika, and Josh Groban as guests.
The concept album about the relationship between a man and a woman is the jazz trumpeter's fifth release on Blue Note.
This 19-song disc compiles songs from each of the Cincinnati, Ohio band's releases.
The second solo album features guests UGK, Krayzie Bone, Lil Wayne, Slick Rick, and Devin The Dude.
The band's follow-up to 2005's 'Gimmie Trouble' finds Adult. back down to the original duo of Nicola Kuperus and Adam Lee Miller.
The latest solo release for the Sonic Youth artist features three extended instrumental experimental tracks.
The third full-length solo release for the New Zealand artist was recorded live and is a companion album to a film he wrote and directed.
The latest full-length release for the Wire's Colin Newman and his wife Malka Spiegel features contributions from Holy Fuck's Matt Schulz as well as Gil Luz and Asi Weitz of Hexenschuss.

recordname: Take the Sadness Out of Saturday Night
description: The third full-length studio release for the Jack Antonoff solo project features guest appearances from Lana Del Rey and Bruce Springsteen.
Produced by Guy Fixsen and Ash Workman, the Scottish pop band releases its debut full-length album.
Officially an EP, this 10-track effort is actually a full 50 minutes long and contains all new material. Guests include Lenny Kravitz, Zap Mama, Queen Latifah, Angie Stone and Bahamadia.
The seventh studio release for the British electronic duo includes vocals from ETML, Mykki Blanco, Sam Brookes, Niara, Nina Miranda, Patricia Panther, and Shakka.
This is the San Francisco Bay Area punk group's first album on the Matador label.
The British electronic artist explores dubstep, industrial, hip-hop, jungle, and techo genres on this double album.
The third full-length studio release for the Pittsburgh rapper features guest appearances from Ab-Soul, Chief Keef, Lil B, Miguel and Little Dragon.
'Myths' marks the debut for the fun-loving dance-rock (or as the band themselves call it, "new rave") four-piece from Brighton, England.
The electronic artist worked with Vampire Weekend's Rostam Batmanglij, John Hill, Hit Boy, and Dave Sitek on her third full-length release that features guest appearances from B.C. and Ilovemakonnen.
The debut full-length album for the Australian band was produced by Jim Abbiss.
The British trio from Manchester releases their debut album of dance rock.
The fifth album for the married duo from Kansas.
The second full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was co-produced by Paul Epworth and Jon Green.
The debut full-length release for the latest side project of David Bazan features members from Pedro the Lion and Starflyer 59 including: Trey Many, Jason Martin and TW Walsh.
The debut electronic release for the Kurt Wagner project features Lambchop members Scott Martin and Ryan Norris.
This is the nine-track debut electronic album from Wolfgang Voigt and Jörg Burger.
Producer Joachim Dyrdahl's music was commissioned for Norway's Oye festival, which this third album contains.
The English post-punk legends release another album of minimalist dance punk; their first collection of new material in 16 years.
The fifth solo album for the Texas-based singer is his first on his own label, The Noise Company.

recordname: Tell Me if You Like To
description: This is the debut full-length release for the British indie rock band led by Tarek Musa.
Produced by Buddy Cannon, the country singer-songwriter covers songs by the Gershwin brothers features guest appearances from Cyndi Lauper and Sheryl Crow.
This is the third album for the side project led by Blake Sennett, the guitarist for Rilo Kiley.
The second full-length album from trio from San Francisco is its first on their own label.
This is the debut full-length release for the Swedish post-punk rock band.
The third album for the all-girl trio from Brooklyn, New York.
The eighth full-length release for the New York indie rock band was produced by Tom Beaujour.
Described as an adult breakup album by lead singer Jim Adkins, the eighth studio release for the Arizona rock band was produced by Alain Johannes.
The latest solo album for the former frontman of Grandaddy was recorded at his home studio in Montana.
The latest album from the Los Angeles hip-hop collective led by Tyler, The Creator includes all 11 members.
This is the second full-length for the Toronto group fronted by Emily Haines, who is also a member of Broken Social Scene.
After the success of the single "Foundations," her debut album was released five weeks early and opened as the number-one album in the UK.
The latest release for the Scandinavian synth/electro-pop duo of Hannes Norrvide and Loke Rahbek was produced by Malthe Fischer.
The fourth full-length release for Jason Chung as Nosaj Thing features guest appearances from Kazu Makino, Zuri Marley and Steve Spacek.
The debut full-length release for the Brooklyn-based experimental pop quintet was co-produced by Danny Molad and Sam Cohen.
The first solo release in 14 years for the British singer-songwriter was produced by Shane Fontayne.

recordauthor: The Red Krayola With Art & Language
description: The latest from Red Krayola and Art & Language features five tracks about the following people: Wile E. Coyote, President George W. Bush, President Jimmy Carter, John Wayne, and artist Ad Reinhardt.
The Norwegian rock band releases a collection of songs previously only available in Norway.
This more typically abstract effort for the German duo is their first release for Ipecac and their first album since 2004's poppier 'Radical Connector.'

Classically-trained guitarist Jimmy LaValle, who has played on albums by Tristeza and Black Heart Procession in addition to his own Album Leaf project, traveled from San Diego, CA to Iceland to record this third Album Leaf disc as a guest of Sigur Ros. Members of Sigur Ros, Mum, and Black Heart Procession appear on the album.

The B-Boys, who have moved back to New York from their temporary home of Los Angeles, return with their first album in six years and their second to utilize the beats of Mixmaster Mike. These 15 tracks are all self-produced by the band (a first) and recall the style of their earliest work.

Definitely not your typical blink-182 album, this eponymous release finds the once-juvenile band finally showing a mature side, and winning critics over in the process. The Cure's Robert Smith guests on one track.

The country singer seeems to enjoy pushing buttons (albeit with a sense of humor), and he continues his recent forays into politicized music with this latest LP, which features songs such as "American Soldier" and "The Taliban Song."
The punk outfit led by Brody Armstrong (oops--make that Brody Dalle, now) makes its major-label debut with 'Coral Fang,' the band's third release overall.
The two surviving members of the popular R&B trio completed this long-delayed fourth album after the early 2002 death of cofounder Lisa "Left Eye" Lopes.

Forget concept albums; this is a concept band. Formed by Dan "The Automator" Nakamura, Del tha Funkee Homosapien, Blur's Damon Albarn, Cibo Matto's Miho Hatori, and the Tom Tom Club's Tina Weymouth and Chris Frantz (with visuals by "Tank Girl" creator Jamie Hewlett), the Gorillaz are a "virtual" hip-hop outfit of cartoon characters based somewhere in the future. Hey, we don't make this stuff up; we just report it.
The latest full-length solo release for the Hot Chip co-founder was produced by Tim Goldsworthy.
The latest studio release for the British post-punk band led by Mark E. Smith was produced by Kieron Melling and Smith.
Supergrass' Gaz Coombes and Danny Goffey team up to form The Hot Rats and release a debut album of covers produced by Nigel Godrich.
The fifth full-length release for the British glam-metal band is its first with new drummer Rufus Tiger Taylor (son of Queen's Roger Taylor) and was produced by Adrian Bushy.
The latest album for the country singer-songwriter was produced with Billy Williams.

recordname: How Did We Get So Dark?
description: The second full-length release for the British rock duo was first written instrumentally in sessions in Brighton, Los Angeles and Nashville before being recorded (with vocals) in Brussels.

The debut full-length studio release for the New York City indie rapper features contributions from such artists as Chase, Ricky Dubs, Donnie Fontaine, Brady James, Joe Hov, Marie Matusz, New York, San Holo, Steel Tipped Dove, Wonder Breed, and Zois.
Merritt's third full-length studio album was produced by George Drakoulias.
This is the sophomore album for the indie rock band from Athens, Georgia.
The third full-length release for the Atlanta-based duo Mattiel was mostly recorded in Northern Georgia.
The debut full-length release for the Scottish rock quartet was produced by Jon Schumann.
The third full-length release for the indie rock band was produced by Will Yip.
The second full-length studio release for the Swedish electronic project of Jonna Lee and Claes Björklund contains music from videos released on YouTube before 2012's kin.
The first release for French artist Cecile Schott since 2007s Les Ondes Silencieuses was self-produced.
The former member of Magazine and Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds releases his 10th solo album.
The mysterious San Francisco-based artists--who have been at it now for over 30 years--return with a collection of vaguely animal-themed tracks.
Trent Reznor finally returns with a follow-up to 1999's 'The Fragile.' Dave Grohl guests.
The third album for the Florida artist features guests such as Chris Brown, Akon, Ludacris, Lil Wayne, Kanye West, Mary J. Blige and T.I.
The San Francisco-based singer releases his latest album on the Sub Pop label.
The second album for the Atlanta-based female rock band.
Victor Van Vugt produced this long-awaited full-length debut for the Austin, Texas group, who previously generated some buzz with a series of EPs.
The ninth studio album includes guest artists such as Charlie Wilson, Too Short, Raphael Saadiq, and Pharrell.
The Irish band's third album and is again produced by Tony Hoffer.
The side project of Robert Pollard release a double album of power pop, the ninth album in three years.
This is the debut album for the Australian-based electronic band.

recordname: How You Sell Soul to a Soulless People Who Sold Their Soul?
description: The New York rap group's latest album.
The legendary rock trio returns with a new album on Megaforce Records.
The box set includes rare singles, live tracks from 1977-2000, and a music video DVD.
The debut full-length solo release for the Irish singer-songwriter was co-produced with James Kelly.
The 11th full-length studio release for the British ska pop band was produced by Clive Langer and Liam Watson.
The third release for the Portland, Oregon metal band was produced by the Decemberists' Chris Funk.
From a family of famous country singer, the younger Hank Williams brings more rock music to his sixth album.

The debut full-length studio release for the Atlanta rapper features guest appearances from Pi'erre Bourne, Chief Keef, Gunna, Lil Uzi Vert, Red Coldhearted, Travis Scott, Skepta, Bryson Tiller, Young Nudy, and Young Thug.
This is the fourth full-length release for Canadian electronic producer David Psutka as Egyptrixx.
The Brooklyn punk rock band releases its debut full-length album.
James McAlister (Ester Drang) joins band leader David Bazan and his longtime collaborator TW Walsh on Pedro The Lion's fifth album.
The second full-length release for Brooklyn-based band was recorded in upstate New York.
Terri Walker and Nicole Wray team up on this R&B/soul release produced by Leon Michels and Jeff Silverman.

The third full-length studio release for the Southern California rapper features guest appearances by 2 Chainz, A$AP Rocky, Big Sean, Jay 305, Nicki Minaj, Mozzy, Quavo, Ty Dolla $ign, and YoungBoy Never Broke Again.
The fourth album for the Canadian indie band was recorded at Watson's home studio in Montreal.
After dabbling in solo projects, the band regroups for its fourth album, produced by Jason Lader.
The ninth full-length studio release for the rock band was co-produced with Tyler Bates.

The fifth full-length studio release for the British electronic group features guest appearances from Eska, Callum Finn, Dhani Harrison, Keaton Henson, Mark Lanegan, Mink, Liela Moss, Elliott Power, Steven Young, and Ysée.

The debut full-length release for the duo of producer Paul Jefferies (aka Nineteen85) and Daniel Daley features contributions from Adam Feeney, Majid Al Maskati of Majid Jordan, Stephen Kozmeniuk, and Noah '40' Shebib.
Produced by Harry Fraud, the debut EP release on Atlantic Records for the New York rapper features guest appearances by Big Body Bes, Prodigy, Raekwon, and Wiz Khalifa.
Produced by Ian Broudie, the second solo release for the British singer includes songs co-written with Andy Partridge and Paul Weller.
This eight-song EP pairs Prefuse 73 with cut-up artists The Books, and reprises their first collaboration, "Pagina Dos," from the most recent Prefuse 73 full-length.

This is the second DFA release for the Brooklyn outfit who have evolved from abrasive noise rock to a little less abrasive psychedelic electronica. Production was handled by the DFA, Steve Revitte (Liars) and Nicolas Vernhes (Fiery Furnaces).
New York singer-songwriter Leona Naess recorded this third album in Los Angeles with producer Ethan Johns (Rufus Wainwright).
The fourth collaboration between Michael Franti and Spearhead mixes the politically-inclined raps of Franti with the disco/funk rhythms of a live band.

Los Angeles-based Phantom Planet is best known for counting among its members "Rushmore" star Jason Schwartzman and "Donnie Darko" star Alex Greenwald. 'The Guest,' their second album, was produced by Mitchell Froom and Tchad Blake.

This double album from Jill Scott and her band, Fatback Taffy, includes a live disc of performances of material from her acclaimed debut album, 'Who is Jill Scott?', as well as a second disc of new studio recordings.

The follow-up to 2000's hit 'The Man Who,' 'Invisible Band' contains similar-sounding guitar pop from the Scottish rockers. The album was produced by Nigel Godrich, who worked with Radiohead on 'Kid A' and 'OK Computer.'

recordname: Take Back The Universe (And Give Me Yesterday)
description: The inaugural major-label LP from the Bay Area indie rockers, whose 1998 debut album 'I Become Small And Go' garnered them Best New Artist honors from Spin.
A sequel, of sorts, to Kelly's 1993 album '12 Play.'
Rhett Miller & co. recorded the stripped-down 'Drag It Up' (the band's first release in three years) in a 19th century church in Woodstock, NY.
The first solo release for the Sebadoh frontman in six years was recorded in six days with Justin Pizzoferrato.
The first album in four years for Warn Defever & co. is also the band's debut for new label Reincarnate (after multiple releases on 4AD).
This is the debut release for the collaboration by Ben Chasny of Six Organs of Admittance and Donovan Quinn of Skygreen Leopards.
The latest album for the dance music duo was produced with Xenomania.
The second full-length solo release for the Air frontman features guest appearances from Kadhja Bonet, Cola Boyy, musician Kirin J Callinan, Kate NV, and Hot Chip's Alexis Taylor.
The Cleveland electronic trio's latest release includes two tracks over eight minutes long.
The debut album for Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter Ramona Gonzalez.
The latest album for The New Pornographers features guest appearances by Beirut's Zach Condon, Annie Clark, Okkervil River's Will Sheff, and some members of The Dap-Kings.
The second album for the indie pop band led by Alex Craig and Ian Drennan was produced by Mitch Easter.
Until jj signed with Secretly Canadian to release its second full-length album, the identity of the Swedish duo was unknown to the industry at large.
The second release for Lightning Bolt's Brian Chippendale as Black Pus was produced by Keith Souza and Seth Manchester.
After sitting out an album, drummer Nick Jago rejoins his BRMC bandmates, who return with a harder-edged recording than their 2005 acoustic departure 'Howl.'
Joe Jackson's first record in four years was recorded in Germany.
The third album for the New Zealand-based indie band led by Ryan McPhun is its first on the Sub Pop label.
The sixth full-length studio release for the pop singer-songwriter features guest appearances from Future and Ed Sheeran.
The sophomore album for the Montreal-based indie group is its first on the Anti- label.
Along with Atkins' hauntingly hypnotic voice, her new album bursts with booming percussion, piano-driven pop ballads, and swirling string-heavy songs.
The fourth full-length release for the Swedish singer-songwriter features guest appearances from Aminé and Rostam Batmanglij.
Robert Pollard continues his prolific release of music with the indie band's fourth album since reuniting in 2012.
After writing a novel and a soundtrack for it, Joe Pernice returns to the Pernice Brothers to record the band's first album in four years.
This is the first release of new songs from the singer-songwriter since 2008's Time The Conqueror.
The runner-up in season eight of American Idol releases his debut album.
The debut release for the London-based folk-rock band was recorded in Malibu and produced by Noah Georgeson.
Owen Ashworth latest album is a collection of singles and compilation tracks released between 2005 and 2008.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Chilean duo recorded their parts individually and then had Uwe Schmidt to assemble them into four tracks.

The debut full-length studio release for the Chicago rapper features guest appearances from Taylor Bennett, Francis And The Lights, Ben Gibbard, Gucci Mane, John Legend, Megan Thee Stallion, Shawn Mendes, Nicki Minaj, Smino and Justin Veron.
The 10th full-length release for the saxophonist (and oldest son of Afrobeat artist Fele Kuti) was recorded mainly in Lagos with his band Positive Force.

The ninth full-length studio release for the pop artist features a guest appearance from G-Eazy as well as contributions from Dan Book, Burns, Cashmere Cat, Andrew Goldstein, Ian Kirkpatrick, Mattman & Robin, Mischke, Nick Monson, Justin Tranter, and Tramaine "Young Fyre" Winfrey.
The first release in five years for the Japanese post-rock/hardcore quintet is its shortest at 43-minutes long.
The fourth full-length release for the Tennessee band features production by Patrick Carney on two tracks.
The acoustic release from the former Sonic Youth guitarist was recorded live in Barcelona.

recordname: Oui Oui, Si Si, Ja Ja, Da Da
description: This is the 10th studio album for the British ska band.
The Philadelphia-based psychedelic rock band releases its first album on the Fire Records (UK) label.
Ivan Howard and Kelly Crisp worked with Justin Vernon on their sixth full-length release.
The official studio release for the Oakland, California rap duo of Squadda B and MondreMAN features guest appearances from DaVinci, Gucci Mane, Mon$ta, and Shady Blaze.
The latest album for the Los Angeles-based singer was inspired by 1950s rock 'n' roll and R&B.

Adams' fifth album with The Cardinals was recorded during the 2007 Easy Tiger sessions and is now being released as this double album. The two-disc effort is full of guitar-driven hard rock, as well as more downbeat, melodious tracks.

The ninth full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from Dej Loaf, Future, Gucci Mane, Anthony Hamilton, Jeezy, Meek Mill, Nas, Raphael Saadiq, Chris Rock, Scrilla, Ty Dolla $ign, Wale, Yo Gotti, and Young Thug.
The fourth full-length studio release for the British electronic artist features collaborations with Banshee, Burial, Darkstar, and Rezzett.
The fourth full-length release for the British psychedelic metal band was inspired by Italian slasher films and was produced by Laim Watson.
The solo debut for the No Doubt vocalist features an eclectic group of guests, including Martin Gore, Andre 3000, The Neptunes, New Order, Wendy & Lisa and Dr. Dre.

Available for several years on his own website, Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter Gary Jules' second album finally got a major-label release in 2004 thanks to the unexpected success of one of its tracks--a cover of Tears For Fears' "Mad World"--that appeared on the Donnie Darko soundtrack.
The eighth studio album for Gene and Dean Ween is their strangest (and definitely most eclectic) in quite some time. (And many Ween fans will probably see that as a good thing.)
The Florida ska-punk band's third major-label release includes a cover of Cheap Trick's "Surrender."
This is the second album for the alt-folk trio from Vancouver, Canada.

The former Australian teen grunge stars (whose 1995 debut was released when they were just 15) are still together, and this album marks their fourth release, highlighted by a more mature, refined sound.

The creation of Snow Patrol's Gary Lightbody, the Reindeer Section is a Scottish indie-pop supergroup. For this sophomore effort, the Section includes appearances from a whopping 27 people, including members of Belle & Sebastian, Arab Strap, Astrid, Mogwai, Mull Historical Society, Idlewild and Teenage Fanclub.

As you may have guessed from the title, this is an album of covers by Howe Gelb, mainly recorded with Calexico's Joey Burns and John Convertino. The ten studio tracks and three live performances include versions of Sonny Bono's "The Beat Goes On," Grandaddy's "Blue Marble Girl," and Black Sabbath's "Iron Man."
The official follow-up to 1999's 'Vertigo' finds the London duo collaborating with Richie Havens, Nile Rogers, Tim Hutton and Jeru Tha Damaja. The lead single is "Superstylin."
The latest release from the band formerly known as "Panasonic."
The fifth full-length release for the Oregon psychedelic duo explores the light side on this second of a two-part concept that explores dark and light/ying and yang energies.
The third release for the Brooklyn rock trio was self-produced.
This is the third album from the English electronic quartet.
The New York-based synth pop group -- which began as Wesley Eisold's (American Nightmare, Some Girls) solo project -- release their full-length debut.
This is the debut folk rock album for the British singer-songwriter.
The son of the British folk duo Richard and Linda Thompson releases his fifth album of folk pop, complete with rich harmonies and catchy melodies.
The rock band releases its first album of new material since 2004's "It's All Around You."
The first new release in six years for the Chicago indie rock band is its first without bassist Eric Claridge.
Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros' lead singer, Alex Ebert, releases his debut solo album.
Produced by Tyler Wood, the fourth full-length studio release for Joan Wasser features guest appearances from Joseph Arthur and Reggie Watts.
The sixth full-length release for the French pop artist was influenced by Brazilian music.
This is the second album for the Indiana-born musician. [The album was credited under Grampall Jookabox. The band changed its name to just Jookabox in 2009.]
The second full-length release from the San Francisco-based duo of Ripley Johnson and Sanae Yamada was inspired by Ralph Waldo Emerson's essay of the same name.
This is the debut full-length release for the Australian singer-songwriter.
The fifth studio album for the rapper features guest appearances by such artists as Andre 3000, Dr. Dre, Drake, Jay-Z, Meek Mill, Ne-Yo, Omarion, Usher, and Wale.
Tom Jenkinson's latest album as Squarepusher returns to electronica with a release created with a visual component for his live shows.
The live album for the duo of Kim Gordon and Bill Nace was recorded at Knoxville's 2014 Big Ears Festival.
The latest album by California noise rock band Thee Oh Sees led by John Dwyer was recorded in Sacramento and features a 14-minute song.
The debut full-length album for the New York indie rock band was produced by Chris Zane.
The debut solo release for the lead singer of Supergrass was produced by Sam Williams.
The Boston rapper releases his third full-length album featuring Bahamadia, Dumbtron, and Vinnie Paz as guest artists.

recordauthor: Thao & the Get Down Stay Down
description: Produced by John Congleton, the third release from the San Francisco indie rock band includes Joanna Newsom as a guest singer on one track.
This is the fourth album for the Brooklyn noise-rockers.
The collaboration between Jarvis Cocker and Chilly Gonzales is a song cycle about the various famous people who have stayed at Los Angeles's Chateau Marmont.
The first release in 11 years for the British garage rock band led by Carl Barât and Pete Doherty.
The debut full-length release for the Australian post-punk band was mixed by Nigel Lee-Yang of HTRK.
The fourth studio release for the Los Angeles duo of Nathan Williams and Stephen Pope was produced by John Hill.
Dierks Bentley returns to traditional country music with his sixth studio album after giving bluegrass a try on his 2010 release, Up On The Ridge.
Perry Farrell, The Flaming Lips and David Byrne guest on the Washington D.C. duo's fourth artist LP.

With its seventh studio album, the British dance duo continues to break down conventionality in electronic music, employing acid synths, break-beat rhythms, and genre-bending production that made it pioneers of the dance-music revolution.
The Canadian collective (who wowed critics with 2003's 'You Forgot It In People') offers a compilation of B-sides and previously unreleased tracks.
The seventh studio release for the Atlanta rapper is the first album credited under the name Jeezy and features guest appearances from Akon, Future, The Game, Jay-Z, Lil Boosie, and Rick Ross.
Willie Nelson's 66th studio album is a mix of classic songs, covers of rock songs, and originals by his son Lukas.

The first release on the Def Jam label for rapper Snoop Dogg features guest appearances from such artists as Eric Bellinger, Benny The Butcher, Mary J. Blige, Blxst, Busta Rhymes, D Smoke, Dave East, Fabolous, Jadakiss, October London, Malaya, Method Man, Redman, Ty Dolla $ign, Usher, and Wiz Khalifa.

The 14th full-length studio release for the Chicago rapper features guest appearances from Black Thought, Brittany Howard, Marcus King, Seun Kuti, Jessica Care Moore, Morgan Parker, PJ, and Isaiah Sharkey.
The fourth full-length release for the indie rock band led by François Marry features contributions from Owen Pallett and was produced by Ash Workman.
After scoring 2014 film Under The Skin, Mica Levi returns to his experimental pop trio for their first studio release in three years.
The debut full-length release for the Pennsylvania indie rock band was produced by John Congleton.
The full-length debut release for the alternative rock band led by Foo Fighters drummer Taylor Hawkins features guest appearances from Dave Grohl, Drew Hester, Rami Jaffee, and Pat Smear.
The second full-length release for Italian New York-based producer Mauro Remiddi includes contributions from Antlers bassist Darby Cicci, cellist Gaspar Claus and Yuck drummer Jonny Rogoff.
The debut full-length solo release for the daughter of the late blues guitarist Christ Whitley was produced by Thomas Bartlett.
The third album for the Brooklyn-based rock trio was produced by Dan Romer.
The latest album for the melodic death metal band from Sweden is its first with new studio material since 2007's Rise Of The Tyrant.
Interpol moves to Capitol Records with their third studio album.

recordname: My Heart Has A Wish That You Would Not Go
description: This is the first album in four years for the Scottish four-piece.
The sixth studio release for the Norwegian experimental jazz ensemble was inspired by Lars Horntveth's move to Los Angeles.

Wales' Jem Griffiths makes her debut with this 11-track LP, which combines her vocals with downtempo electronica from Jem and collaborator Yoad Nevo, reminding critics of recent albums from Dido and Zero 7.
The 18th full-length studio release for the Scottish rock band was co-produced with Gavin Goldberg and Andy Wright.
Produced by John Agnello, the second album from the British trio was recorded in Woodstock, New York.
The fourth album for the rock band was produced by Trina Shoemaker.
The first album in four years for the rock band led by E, aka Mark Oliver Everett.
One of two albums from Prince released on the same day was self-produced and is said to contain funk, R&B, and soul influences.

recordname: Justus Köhncke & the Wonderful Frequency Band
description: This is the German techno producer's first full-length studio release in five years.
The second full-length release from the indie rock duo of Mazes' Jack Cooper and Veronica Falls' James Hoare was recorded on one-inch tape.
The latest full-length release for the reformed British rock band was produced by Lynne with contributions from album engineer Steve Jay.
The veteran Nashville artist wrote and produced all 11 tracks on her latest album, and handled most of the instrumentation as well.
Brad Jones returns to produce the singer-songwriter's tenth studio release recorded in Spain.
'World' is the first solo album in a decade for the Sunny Day Real Estate and Fire Theft frontman.
The debut release for the trio formed by the Jesus Lizard's Duane Denison, Einsturzende Neubaten's Alexander Hacke, and Silver Jew's Brian Kotzur includes five improvised tracks.
Dance and R&B influences the full-length debut from Wye Oak's Jenn Wasner and Art Department's Jon Ehrens.
The Norwegian electronic duo follow-up to their 2011 album Schlungs is a collection of original tracks and songs they remixed for other artists.
The ambient duo of Brendon Anderegg and Koen Holtkamp releases its second album.

The 10th studio album from the British post-rock band sticks to the formula that contributes to its longevity--synth-laden instrumentation and experimental dream-pop over delicate female vocals, containing tracks from previous sessions.
This is the second album for the two Norwegian artists together.
The veteran singer's first completely self-produced album is his first studio recording since 2001's 'Songs From The West Coast.'
This is the first album in five years for the duo of DJ Premier and Guru.
This sophomore disc finds the young emo band expanding on its sound with the help of producer Steven Haigler (Pixies, Quicksand).

Perhaps finding "Chantal Passamonte" too dull a name for an experimental electronica artist signed to Warp Records, the former Warp publicist adopted the Mira Calix moniker prior to her 2000 debut. This is her second full-length release.
Chris Isaak's eighth album is his first since the disappointing sales of 1998s 'Speak of the Devil,' but also his first since he took to the small screen in a Showtime comedy series.
This is the fourth album for the Sacramento-based alternative rockers best known for their hits "Never There" and "The Distance."
The debut album from California electronic artist Timothy Wiles includes collaborations with Beenie Man and Davey Dave.

Paying tribute to the techno pioneers of Detroit, the garage rock band out of Michigan delve into a bit of disco and dance music with the reinterpretation of programmed drums and synths on their latest release.
This debut album for the New York City-based indie pop quintet was produced by Nick Stumpf.

Maps & Atlasesâ second EP, You and Me and the Mountain, found the band moving in a lighter direction than the mathematical frenzy of their first EP Trees, Swallows, Houses. Their first full-length sees them fully morphed into a sophisticated indie pop group. Perch Patchwork is a bold debut, filled with bombastic arrangements, twisting modal progressions, and percussive layers. The skill set is high, but itâs far less showy. Guitarists will still be enthralled by Dave Davidson's and Erin Elders' fingertapping, but acoustics take precedent, and moderately slow tempos maintain the album's balladic feel. If Trees, Swallows, Houses felt like a cousin to Don Cab or Hella, their first Barsuk outing has adapted the organic spirit of their Northwestern labelmates (particularly that of Menomena, the Long Winters, and John Vanderslice.) Of course, with Maps & Atlases' virtuosic chops and syncopated leanings, they kind of resemble BLK JKS or Minus the Bear, albeit with a Jethro Tull influence. Trendy South African rhythms and austere strings spin a web around Davidsonâs poetic lyrics, and in this intricate, introspective setting, their talent becomes very clear. ~ Jason Lymangrover
The first full-length release in six years for Austin indie rock band Shearwater was co-produced with Dan Duszynski.

recordname: Once Upon A Time In The West
description: The follow-up to their hit debut album for the British indie-rock group.

The first covers album for the Los Angeles grunge/metal band includes guest appearances from such artists as Mudhoney's Mark Arm, Jello Biafra, Neurosis' Scott Kelly, Melvins Lite, and J.G. Thirlwell.
The second full-length solo release for the singer-songwriter from Buffalo was co-produced with Ben Hillier.
The debut album for the British band was produced by Edwyn Collins.
The debut full-length album for the trio from Davis, California was produced by Greg Saunier (Deerhoof).
This is the sophomore album for the folk singer from Pennsylvania.
The third full-length release for the Mississippi artist was recorded in a haunted Victorian house in St. Augustine, Florida.
The third full-length release for the Icelandic singer is her first entirely sung in English.
Formerly known as Pure Ecstasy, Pure X's debut full-length album was recorded live.

Produced by Terry Date, the 11th full-length studio release for the California trash metal band is the first with Exodus guitarist Gary Holt who took over from co-founding guitarist Jeff Hanneman who passed away in 2013.
The second release from Rumer is a covers album of 1970s songs originally sung by such artists as Isaac Hayes, Bob Marley, Jimmy Webb, and Townes Van Zandt.
This is the first full-length studio release from alternative rock band led by Isaac Brock in eight years.
The sixth album for the British rock band features bassist Chris Wolstenholme on lead vocals for two tracks he wrote.

The rock-and-roll legend's latest release is his second album of duets with such artists as Eric Clapton, Sheryl Crow, Merle Haggard, John Fogerty, Kid Rock, Kris Kristofferson, John Mayer, Willie Nelson, Keith Richards, and Slash.
The third album for the indie rock band from Canada.
The Tampa band is back to a trio (Carson Cox, Dave Vassalotti, and Pat Brady) for its second full-length on the 4AD label and was for the first time recorded partly in a studio.
The New York industrial electronic duo of Aaron David Ross and Matthew Arkel releases their debut full-length on the Hippos In Tanks label.
The country singer releases a covers album featuring songs from contemporary rock groups such as U2 and Green Day as well as classic artists such as John Lennon and Velvet Underground.
The latest album for the punk rock trio from Illinois was produced by Josh Abraham.

recordname: Kick Up The Fire And Let The Flames Break Loose
description: This is the second album for the Reading, England rock band.

recordname: This Is Really Going To Hurt
description: The second full-length British indie trio was recorded in Los Angeles with Justin Raisen, Andrew Sarlo and mixing engineer Ali Chant.
The debut full-length solo release for Warpaint guitarist Theresa Wayman was co-produced with her brother Ivan, Dan Carey and Money Mark.
The fifth full-length release for the New York duo features a guest appearance from Hope Sandoval.
Martin Fry worked with Anne Dudley on the sequel to his 1982 album The Lexicon Of Love.
The 13th release for the rap group led by Chuck D was produced by Gary "G-Wiz" Rinaldo.
This is the fourth full-length release for the son of British rock artist Ian Dury.
The debut release for the solo music project from Australian Fergus Miller collects tracks he recorded at home and released independently.
The fourth studio album for the Grammy-winning country singer was produced by Mark Bright.
Chicago's hard rock arena-headliners return with another album of heavy metal hits that recall early Metallica and Iron Maiden while maintaining their trademark dark sound.
The eighth full-length album for the rock band was produced by Joe McGrath and Jacknife Lee.
The debut full-length album for the singer was produced by Steve Albini.
London-based singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Matt Hales returns with a second album following two years of touring in support of his debut 'Strange And Beautiful.'
Brendan O'Brien produced the singer's first post-Phish solo record.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Los Angeles noise rock band was produced by Lars Stalfors.
The eighth full-length release for the indie rock band was recorded twice [they discarded a majority of the first session] with production from Danger Mouse, John Hill, Mike D, and Ammar Malik.
The debut album for the New Zealander Pip Brown.
The fifth and last full album for the UK band. In the future they will release only singles.
Linda Perry and Susan Sontag (!) penned songs for the dance duo's belated sophomore release, which also features production from Tony Hoffer and Mirwais.
The second full-length release for the British quartet was recorded by Dave Catching in Joshua Tree.
This is Paul White's first full-length project with vocals, which features Nancy Elizabeth, Danny Brown, Homeboy Sandman, Guilty Simpson, Jehst, Marv Won, Moe Pope, and Tranqill.
The second album for the rock quintet from Brooklyn, New York was produced and recorded by the band in just over four months.

The fifth full-length release for the Scottish electronic producer features guest appearances from A-Trak, Big Sean, D.R.A.M., Future, Ariana Grande, Kehlani, Khalid, John Legend, Lil Yachty, Migos, Nicki Minaj, Frank Ocean, PARTYNEXTDOOR, Katy Perry, Jessie Reyez, ScHoolboy Q, Travis Scott, Snoop Dogg, Takeoff, Pharrell Williams, and Young Thug.
The second album for the Chicago-based band is its first on the Anticon label.
The Norwegian artist (backed here by The Faces Down Quartet) remakes himself as a cabaret singer, with a disc full of jazz-pop tunes including a cover of the standard "Night and Day."
Members of Portishead and The Bad Seeds guest on the multi-instrumentalist's third solo outing.
Tony Bennett and Lady Gaga reunite for an album of Cole Porter songs accompanied by the Brian Newman Quintet with arrangements by Marion Evans & Jorge Callandrelli.
This is the debut full-length album for British juke producer Tony Williams under the Addison Groove name.
The collaboration between Lee Ranaldo and Rau¨l Refree features little to no guitars.
The fourth full-length release for the Chicago garage-rock band was produced by Ethan Johns.
The Norwegian songwriter's self-titled sixth album features collaborations with Midlake percussionist McKenzie Smith and experiments with multiple genres, including jazz and bossa nova.
The Canadian indie rock band's first album on Soft Revolution was produced by Tom McFall.

Although the Dallas-based robe-wearing collective (who number close to 30) recorded their buzz-generating debut in just two days, this sophomore effort is the result of a full year in the studio. (Presumably, it's a very large studio.) Eric Feldman (Sparklehorse) and The Speekers produced.
'This Is For Real' is the full-length debut for the trashy electro-punk outfit out of Sheffield, England.
The Portland, Ore. duo of Brandon Summers and Benjamin Weikel are back with their third album, and first for Sub Pop.

Combining blues, R&B, jazz and funk influences, this latest offering from the ever-changing 4AD group headed by Warren Defever, like its predessor (2001's 'Someday My Blues Will Cover The Earth'), features the vocals of Lovetta Pippen. Included among the originals here are covers of The Equals' "Teardrops," Ida's "Maybe," and Jimi Hendrix's "Train."

Yes, it's *that* Soft Cell, the English band that brought you early 80s hits such as "Tainted Love" and "Sex Dwarf." Their first release since 1984's 'This Last Night in Sodom,' 'Cruelty Without Beauty' offers 12 brand-new tracks from the reunited duo of Dave Ball and Marc Almond.
The Los Angeles singer/songwriter's eclectic debut album comes after cuts on the soundtracks to "Bridget Jones's Diary" and "Shallow Hal."
This is the first solo release from Slowdive and Mojave 3 frontman Neil Halstead, and includes occasional guest contributions from the likes of his bandmate Ian McCutcheon and Locust's Mark Van Hoen.

The soundtrack to the Cameron Crowe comedy features music from the 1970's, including tracks from Simon & Garfunkel, The Who, The Allman Brothers Band, Elton John, and David Bowie (a cover of Velvet Underground's "I'm Waiting For The Man"), and one original track, from the movie's fictitious Stillwater.
The debut full-length release for the British quartet was self-recorded by the band.

The English hip-hop artist follows his Mercury Prize-nominated 2017 debut with his second LP. And it's perhaps the first rap album in history to feature a song about celebrity chef Yotam Ottolenghi. Collaborators include Sampha, Jorja Smith, Jordan Rakei, and Tom Misch.
This is the third album for the duo from Oregon led by Jona Bechtolt.
The second full-length release for the Los Angeles post-punk trio was produced by Alex Newport.
The second full-length side/solo project for Modern Baseball's Jake Ewald was produced by Ian Farmer.
The British electronic artist produced his sophomore album.

recordname: World Peace Is None of Your Business
description: The 10th solo studio release for the British indie singer-songwriter was produced by Joe Chiccarelli and recorded in France.
The third release in 2016 for the rock band led by John Dwyer is a companion album to A Weird Exits featuring six tracks recorded from the same sessions.
This is the debut release for the side project of Efetrklang with Finnish percussionist Tatu Ronkko.

recordauthor: Margot & the Nuclear So and So's
description: Described as cinematic chamber pop, this Indianapolis band's third album features heavier electric guitar rock with a mix of unique multiple instrumentation.
The first new release in four years for the French rock band was self-produced.
The second full-length solo release for The Smashing Pumpkins frontman (but the first under his full given name) was produced with Rick Rubin.
The debut album for the duo from Brooklyn was produced by Dave Sitek.
The Jack White-led rock band releases its follow-up to its 2009 debut, "Horehound."
The legend of Lemmy lives on as Motorhead releases their 20th album on the year of their 35th anniversary, continuing their hard rock, heavy metal roller-coaster ride.
The fourth full-length release for the band led by Ian Svenonius was recorded in Oregon and mixed by Brendan Canty in DC.
This is the Austin band's second full-length release and its debut for Matador Records.
Their first Sub Pop release finds the noisy Detroit band as a threesome, with founder Nate Young joined (as he has been since 2000) by Aaron Dilloway and John Olson.

The second posthumous release for the rapper features some previously released tracks as well as some unreleased ones that features collaborations with Era, Gab3, iLoveMakonnen, Lil Tracy, and Rich the Kid.
Produced by Samuel Bing and Julian Wass, the third release for the Los Angeles pop collective features Sinosa Loa on lead vocals.
The sixth studio album for the rock band led by Chris Cornell is its first release of new music in 16 years.
The live album was recorded in Paris on May 10, 2011, and includes tracks from Red Barked Tree as well as songs from earlier releases.
The latest full-length solo release for Travis Stewart as Machinedrum features guest appearances from Tosin Abasi, Jesse Boykins III, D?WN, Kevin Hussein, Rochelle Jordan, MeLo-X, and Ruckazoid.
This is the second full-length album for the Norwegian electronic duo.

The latest release for the singer-songwriter features new arrangements on 10 songs that span his career and features contributions from such artists as Jack DeJohnette, Bill Frisell, Steve Gadd, Wynton Marsalis, and yMusic.
The Grammy-winning California rock band led by Scott Weiland returns with its first album in nearly a decade.
The fourth full-length release for the British electronic producer is his first on the Wrap label.
This fourth LP for the metal band follow's 2004's acclaimed 'Panopticon' as well as an opening slot on Tool's latest tour.
The UK rockers' fifth studio album is their first to utilize an outside producer, Gil Norton (Pixies, Foo Fighters).
The Donnas' second major-label effort was produced by Butch Walker (Avril Lavigne, Injected).
The eighth studio album for the band was produced by Butch Vig.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Atlanta rock band was produced by Dave Cobb and features guest appearances from Jamey Johnson and Warren Haynes.
The sixth full-length solo release for Noah Lennox as Panda Bear was co-produced and co-mixed with Rusty Santos.
The second full-length solo release for the former One Direction singer features guest appearances from Nicki Minaj and Timbaland.
The fourth full-length release for the Canadian quartet was self-produced and mixed by John Congleton.
The full-length debut release for the side project of Here We Go Magic's Luke Temple was recorded on a four-track tape recorder and was inspired by his move to California.
The fourth full-length release for the Pittsburgh rapper feature gusset appearances from Bilal, CeeLo Green, Ariana Grande, Kendrick Lamar, Njomza, Anderson .Paak, and Ty Dolla $ign.
The full-length debut from the collaboration between Primus bassist Les Claypool and Sean Lennon was written over two weeks at Claypool's house in Northern California.
The third full-length release for the sister duo was produced by Paul Mahern.
This is the debut full-length release for the German electronic producer.
This is the debut release for the collaboration between Cate Le Bon and White Fence's Tim Presley.
Self-produced, the seventh full-length studio release from the blues artist features contributions from Luther Dickinson, Georgina Leach, Dan Magnusson, and Ben Miller.
The eighth full-length solo release for the former Dire Straits lead singer was produced with Guy Fletcher.
The second full-length solo release for The Smiths' former guitarist was written while he was on tour.
The tenth release for the upstate New York folk quintet was produced by Jeremy Backofen in Omaha, Nebraska.
This is the debut full-length release for the British duo of Amelia Rivas and Christian Pinchbeck.
The second full-length release for the New Zealand singer includes influences from funk, jazz, and psychedelic pop.
The debut solo release for the Department of Eagles co-founder Fred Nicolaus was produced with Fraser McCulloch.
The debut solo project from the Pantera and Down frontman with Bennett Bartley, Jose Manuel "Blue" Gonzales, and Marzi Montazeri as The Illegals was co-produced with Michael Thompson.
This is the second solo release for The War On Drugs' Dave Hartley as Nightlands.
The debut album for the British singer-songwriter was recorded in his bedroom.
The former Genesis singer rerecorded some of his songs with a 46-piece orchestra conducted by Ben Foster.
The second album for the British rapper features guest appearances by Etta Bond, Chipmunk, Example, Darren B, Alex Mills, Daley, and Ed Sheeran.
Benjamin Laub, aka as Grieves, releases his third album produced by Budo.
The post-rock band from Leeds, England, releases its second album produced by John Congleton.
The Scottish trio that won a Scottish BAFTA for its cybraphon (an interactive "mechanical band in a box") releases its third album.
The follow-up to the German artist's 2008 album Ferndorf was recorded with San Francisco's Magik*Magik Orchestra.

recordname: The Big Black And The Blue
description: This is the debut album for the Swedish teenage sisters.
Broken Social Scene cofounder Brendan Canning releases his first solo album as a part of the "Broken Social Scene Presents" series.
Dolly Parton's first record on her own label features songs that will appear in the musical version of "9 to 5."
The Seattle-based band featuring ex-Pretty Girls Make Graves' Derek Fudesco releases their first album.
The Atlanta rapper's second Def Jam album includes contributions from Three 6 Mafia, Timbaland, Ludacris, T.I., and Young Buck.

recordname: Death In The Garden, Blood On The Flowers
description: This is the second LP for the five-piece California indie pop band.
Jim Dickinson produced this 21st album for Hiatt, which finds him backed by members of the North Mississippi Allstars.
'Glamour' is the debut disc for the English band led by singer Greg Gilbert, whose voice has drawn him numerous comparisons to the Cocteau Twins' Liz Fraser (as odd as that may sound).
The Red Hot Chili Peppers guitarist returns with a follow-up to his 2001 solo release, 'To Record Only Water For Ten Days.'
This is the third album from the husband-wife duo of Kori Gardner (keyboards) and Jason Hammel (drums). Spoon's Jim Eno produced, along with John Croslin.

This solo release from the anticon collective's Jonathan Wolf (aka Why?), also a member of cLOUDDEAD, sees the experimental rapper mixing in a healthy dose of indie guitar with beats and samples that venture from lo- to hi- fi.

"Coincidentally" released on the same day as the fourth album by the White Stripes, to whom the Kills are frequently compared, 'Mean Side' is the debut full-length for the UK blues-rock duo of VV (aka Alison Mosshart) and Hotel, who are backed by a drum machine (a la the Raveonettes).

The English singer-songwriter's third LP features quite an array of guests, including Ryan Adams, Emmylou Harris, and the Chemical Brothers (who have utilized Orton's vocals on several of their own albums). Another longtime collaborator, William Orbit, appears for one track, with the remainder of the mixing duties falling to Everything But The Girl's Ben Watt.

Although their ride has been rocky at times, the Los Angeles band is nearing its 20th anniversary. (And if you grew up listening to the band, doesn't that make you feel old.) This, their eighth album, finds the Chili Peppers working with producer Rick Rubin.
The Netherlands-based techno artist returns with his fifth album, which is less experimental than previous efforts, instead offering a seamless set of hardcore techno.

The third and final album by the current lineup of this Chicago-based indie band (band member and Aesthetics label head Ken Dyber is leaving the group) includes 10 new tracks, featuring the alternating male/female vocals of Joseph Costa and Lindsay Anderson alongside the band's moody, haunting sound.

The Buzzcocks are back. Well, almost. Pete Shelley and Howard Devoto, founding members of that seminal punk band, have recorded together for the first time in over 25 years, resulting in these 14 brand-new electronica-laden tracks.
The Evan Dando-led band (now down to a trio) returns with its first studio disc in ten years. J Mascis guests.
The fifth full-length release for the Scottish indie rock band was produced by The National's Aaron Dessner.

Heavily influenced by the likes of Lou Reed and the Velvet Underground, Adam Green (the alternative-folk singer/songwriter better known for his stint with the lo-fi indie group Moldy Peaches) returns with his sixth studio album.
The third album for the London artist features covers of songs by such artists as Bjork, Aphex Twin, and PJ Harvey.
The second full-length release for the singer-songwriiter/producer includes production by Jeff Bhasker, Diplo, Paul Epworth, Mark Ronson, The Smeezingtons, and Andrew Wyatt.
Eminem, Dr. Dre, 50 Cent and Hi-Tek are among the producers on the rapper's second LP. Young Jeezy, T.I. and Snoop Dogg also guest.
The second release for the London-based indie pop band led by Greg Hughes was influenced by 1980s pop music.

'Free To Stay' is the second record for the indie-pop duo of sisters Chloe (drums) and Asya (keyboards, vocals), who have opened for Death Cab for Cutie, Pearl Jam, Sufjan Stevens, The Go! Team and others, and who just happen to be 12 and 14 years old.

The ELO frontman releases a covers album of songs that inspired him, including Bobby Darin's "Beyond the Sea," Fain & Webster's "Love Is a Many Splendored Thing," Etta James' "At Last," Rodgers and Hammerstein's "If I Loved You," Rodgers & Hart's "Bewitched, Bothered and Bewildered," and the Rolling Stones' "Mercy, Mercy."
The singer's fourth album features production from will.i.am, Cee-Lo, Linda Perry, Max Martin and Raphael Saadiq (but, for the first time, not the Neptunes). Husband Nas also guests.
Lyle Lovett's final album with Curb Records features guest appearances from k.d. lang, Kat Edmonson, and Sara and Sean Watkins.

recordname: Sketches from the Book of the Dead
description: The Australian artist releases his first solo album since leaving the Bad Seeds.

recordname: The Cautionary Tales of Mark Oliver Everett
description: The latest release from the band led by Mark Oliver Everett was inspired by lost love.
The third album for the German-Nigerian singer features guest appearances from Black Thought of The Roots and Ms. Dynamite.
The Australian group releases its first international effort on Warp Records, which offered them a 16-album contract.
The theme of pain and hope continues on the sixth full-length studio release from the Minnesota indie rap duo of MC Slug and producer DJ Ant.
This is the debut full-length release for the psych rock-inspired British quartet led by James Bagshaw and Tom Warmsley.
This is the debut full-length album for British artist Greg Feldwick as Slugabed.
The second full-length album for the indie-rock band from Atlanta was produced by Joe Chicarelli.
The Decemberists lead singer releases his live solo album featuring songs from his 2006 tour.
The third full-length release for the Syrian artist features more elements from electronic and techno music.
TV On The Radio's Kyp Malone returns to his other band, Iran, to release its third album.
With Stereolab on hiatus, Laetitia Sadier returns to release her first solo album.
The solo debut from Bloc Party singer/guitarist pushes boundaries with a blend of raw rock and energetic electro-pop.
The fifth full-length studio release for the British singer-songwriter was produced with (her brother) Rollo Armstrong, Simon Hulbert and Ryan Laubscher.
Berlin-based Canadian Scott Monteith's eighth techno dub album as Deadbeat features guest appearances from Dandy Jack, Mathew Jonson, and Danuel Tate.
The New Zealand indie rock band releases its fourth studio album.
The third album for the indie rock band was produced by Mike Mogis.
This is the full-length debut for the Durham, NC dance-punk outfit led by Finn Cohen.
The British singer-songwriter worked with producer Joe Boyd on his 20th full-length solo release that includes covers and new original songs.

Co-produced with Ben Harper, the debut solo release for the Dixie Chicks singer is a rock-influenced covers album of songs by such artists as Jeff Buckley, Patty Griffin, Pink Floyd, and The Jayhawks.

recordname: The Only Thing I Ever Wanted
description: The London duo of Galia Durant and Carim Clasmann--who have benefitted from recent American TV exposure--return with a second album of electronica and funny noises.
The fourth full-length release for indie pop project of Jack Tatum was produced with Jorge Elbrecht.
Rick Rubin produced this third LP for the popular mask-wearing Des Moines-based metal outfit, who are set to headline Ozzfest this summer.
The onetime budding star (you remember "One Of Us," right?) returns with an album of covers of classic soul and R&B tunes from the 1960s and 70s.

This is the eighth release from the nearly 15-year-old Seattle band, and it features new instrumentation (a horn section) and a new bass player (Guy Maddison, replacing departed founding member Matt Lukin).

The St. Louis rapper follows up the massive success of his 2000 debut LP 'Country Grammar' with 19 new tracks cut from the same cloth, including the Neptunes-produced single "Hot In Here." Justin Timberlake guests on one track.
Over two years in the making, 'After Everything' is the twelfth album from the Australian band, still best known for their 1988 hit "Under The Milky Way."
This is the fourth release for Quasi, which features Sam Coomes (formerly of The Donner Party, and sometimes bandmate of Elliott Smith and Built to Spill) and Sleater-Kinney's Janet Weiss.
This is the third album from the group since founding members Ian McCulloch and Will Sergeant reunited in 1997.
The fourth full-length release for the rapper features guest appearances from Eminem, Foxy Brown, Future, Ariana Grande, Labrinth, Lil Wayne, Swae Lee, and The Weeknd.

recordname: George Fest: A Night to Celebrate the Music of George Harrison [Live]
description: The live recording of the tribute concert at the Fonda Theater in Los Angeles on September 28, 2014 featured such artists as Black Rebel Motorcycle Club, Cold War Kids, Spoon's Britt Daniel, Perry Farrell, the Flaming Lips, the Killers' Brandon Flowers, Ben Harper, Dhani Harrison, Norah Jones, Conan O'Brien, The Strokes' Nick Valensi, Heart's Ann Wilson, Brian Wilson and Weird Al Yankovic.
The third album for the British duo was produced with Mike Crossey.
The Chicago producer/DJ's latest album of electronica features influences from a variety of genres, such as jungle and ragga, as well as the Chicago house subgenre known as juke or footwork.
The second full-length album for the Swedish indie pop band was produced by Patrik Berger.
The second album produced by Mike Crossey for Brighton's Laura-Mary Carter and Steven Ansell was recorded on analogue tape but still retains its punk influences.
The 33rd studio release for the British singer-songwriter was co-produced with T-Bone Burnett.
Mike Skinner had announced this fifth album would be his last as The Streets.
Neil Finn and his new band, featuring his wife Sharon, release their debut album.

recordname: Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon)
description: The French duo expand on the score they created for the restoration of Georges Melies' silent short film Le Voyage dans la Lune in this full-length soundtrack.
Eclectic Japanese indie-rocker Keigo Oyamada returns with his first Cornelius album in five years.
The second full-length release for the pop group formed during the second season of The X Factor features guest appearances from Missy Elliott, Fetty Wap, and Ty Dolla Sign.
The electronic second release for Cameron Mesirow was inspired by her move to New York.
The latest album for the actress/pop singer was produced with Mike Viola and on her manager's new record label.
Nick Talbot's fourth album on Warp sees the singer-songwriter moving back to a more folk-based sound.
The debut album for the band led by ex-Secret Machines member Benjamin Curtis.
The third full-length studio release for the British pop singer features production from Greg Kurstin, Max Martin, Ilya Salmanzadeh, and Ryan Tedder.

recordname: Nina Revisited: A Tribute to Nina Simone
description: The tribute album to the High Priestess of Soul was co-executive produced by Lauryn Hill and Robert Glasper with artist such as Mary J. Blige, Common, Lalah Hathaway, Gregory Porter, Lisa Simone, Alice Smith, Jazmine Sullivan, and Usher covering her standards.
The debut release for the Montreal indie rock band was co-produced by Daniel Lagac and Nygel Asselin.

recordname: The Lion the Beast the Beat
description: The fourth album for the band was produced by Jim Scott and includes several tracks written by Dan Auerbach of The Black Keys.

The soundtrack to the singer-songwriter's comic book of the same name released at SXSW in 2012 features songs by Deer Tick, Eleanor Friedberger, Fruit Bats, Lavender Diamond, and Unknown Mortal Orchestra.
The indie rock band formed by Cassie Romone of Vivian Girls and Kevin Morby of Woods releases its debut album.

The latest album for the electronic duo includes The Gossip's Beth Ditto, Hot Chip's Alexis Taylor, Super Furry Animals/Neon Neon's Gruff Rhys, Yeasayer's Chris Keating, Telepath, and Jamie Lidell as guest singers.

recordname: In Our Bedroom After The War
description: The fourth album for the Canadian indie rock band.

recordname: Light At The End Of The World
description: Gareth Jones produced this ten-song set from the duo of Vince Clark and Andy Bell.
The electro-pop duo's third album once again features vocals by Sia Furler.
The fourth album for the electronic producer/artist who has worked with Bjork features Mt. Sims.

recordname: Make Do With What You Got
description: The singer tackles songs penned by the likes of Bob Dyland and Van Morrison on this Don Was-produced disc.
The third full-length release for the Icelandic band was co-produced with Rich Costey.
The second album for the Canadian indie rock band was recorded in Montreal and Paris, France.
The third full-length studio release for the British alternative rock trio was produced by Nick Launay.
Frank Black of The Pixies releases his latest solo album coproduced with Eric Drew Feldman.
The sixth full-length release for the hip-hop artist features guest appearances from André Benjamin, Travis Scott, Willow Smith, and Pharrell Williams.
Produced by Anthrax's Paul Crook, the 13th full-length release from the singer-songwriter/actor sees the return of songs written by Jim Steinman.
The latest release for the Los Angeles producer is an instrumental album.
This is the third album for the English band led by brothers Alex and Tom White, who are also members of the band Brakes.
The third full-length release for the R&B singer-songwriter was produced by Shampoo Press & Curl.
The third album for the UK rock band was produced by Dan Carey.

recordname: Plays the Songs of Daniel Johnston
description: After working as part of the backing band for Daniel Johnston's 2017 tour, the trio (Doug Martsch, Jason Albertini and Steve Gere) recorded an 11-song tribute album to the singer-songwriter.
The third full-length release for the San Francisco-born artist was produced by Dan Auerbach.
The debut release for the side project for The Men's Nick Chiericozzi and Mark Perro was produced by Kyle Keays-Hagerman.
The follow-up to the British indie rock trio's Mercury Prize-winning debut was produced by Charlie Andrew and is its first without bassist Gwil Sainsbury, who left the band for personal reasons.

recordname: I Want That You Are Always Happy
description: The debut full-length album for the indie Australian group was coproduced with Mike Myers and recorded between touring.
Connecticut singer-songwriter Joan Wasser returns with her third studio album of soulful songs.
The second full-length release for the British electronic duo features guest appearances from Dreezy, Leikeli47, Pell, Popcaan, and ZUH.
The debut album for the folk-rock band led by Norwegian singer Peter Liddle was produced by Peter Katis.

The first full-length studio release for the funk artist in six years features guest appearances from Stanley Clarke, Manou Gallo, Alissia Benveniste, Big Daddy Kane, BlvckSeeds, Buckethead, Dennis Chambers, Chuck D, Tyshawn Colquitt, Dr. G., MC Eiht, Dru Down, Doug E. Fresh, Eric Gales, Justin Johnson, Mr. Talkbox, Musiq Soulchild, Snowbunny, October London, Kali Uchis, World-Wide-Funkdrive, Victor Wooten, Bernie Worrell, and X-Zact.
American violinist Hilary Hahn improvised tracks with Hauschka (German pianist Volker Bertelmann) on this release recorded in Iceland.
This is the first album to reunite the entire original lineup of the rock band since its 1985 release, Tomorrow the Green Grass.
The San Francisco-based singer-songwriter releases his eighth album.
This is the second full-length release for the Canadian electronic pop duo of Megan James and Corin Roddick.
The second full-length release for the indie rock band featuring Vivian Girls' Cassie Ramone and Woods' Kevin Morby was produced by Rob Barbato.
The debut full-length release for the Baltimore club rapper features guest appearances by Akon, Robyn, Tyga, and Porcelain Black.
The debut album for the Mars Volta guitarist.
The Alanta-based trio releases its debut album produced by Ben H. Allen.
The Indigo Girls guest on the pop singer's first album since 2003.
The Vermont jam band has announced that 'Undermind,' their 11th studio effort, will be their last. Tchad Blake produced.

Does the world really need another Buzzcocks album? Well, this new LP from Pete Shelley and Steve Diggle (which includes two tracks co-written by fellow original Buzzcock Howard Devoto), the band's fourth since re-forming in 1989, may be their best in many years.
The English band's second LP was recorded in Los Angeles with engineer Tony Hoffer (Beck, Air).
A male-female duo a la the White Stripes, Denmark's The Raveonettes make their debut with this brief disc of 8 neo-garage tunes.
Produced with Michael Ilbert, the Scottish alternative rock band returns with its first studio release in five years.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn indie folk five-piece led by Jess Wolfe and Holly Laessig was produced by Shawn Everett.
The fourth release for the New York experimental rock band includes produced by Royal Truxs Neil Hagerty.
The full-length debut for Brad Oberhofer was produced by Steve Lillywhite.
The full-length debut for Los Angeles-based sisters Jennifer and Jessie Clavin was influenced by 1970s punk and Southern California pop-rock.

The soundtrack to the second movie of the teen vampire book series features a remixed song from Muse's current album "The Resistance" and new songs from Death Cab For Cutie, The Killers, Bon Iver, St. Vincent, Thom Yorke, Lykke Li, Anya Marina, Black Rebel Motorcycle Club, Hurricane Bells, Sea Wolf, OK Go, Editors, and Grizzly Bear featuring Beach House's Victoria Legrand.
The third full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from Beyoncé, Chris Brown, Drake, Ariana Grande, Skylar Grey, Jeremih, Lil Wayne, Lunchmoney Lewis, and Meek Mill.

recordname: Berlin: Live At St. Ann's Warehouse [Live]
description: The live album features Reed, for the first time in 30 years, singing songs from "Berlin" at St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn, New York over five nights in December 2006.
This is the second full-length release for the Canadian producer/songwriter Arick Woodhead.
This is the fifth release for the indie rock band led by Nick Thorburn.

In 1999, Mike Kunka of godheadSilo and the Melvins (King Buzzo, Dale Crover, and Kevin Rutmanis) were set to release an album together when it was sidelined by a variety of factors. 16 years later, they reunited to complete the album.
