On his second full-length release, British singer-songwriter James Mathé introduced drum machines, keyboards, and synths to the largely acoustic sound he had established on his debut disc.
The experimental release sees the musician mixing various pieces of his own voice rapping, talking, and singing with music.

Hardly a real introduction--after all, the band has been recording since 1967--'Introduction' finds the Mayo Thompson-led underground rockers returning with an atypically accessible effort, produced by John McEntire.
This double-disc set from Dave Grohl & co. includes one full CD of acoustic tracks. Guests include John Paul Jones, Norah Jones, Josh Homme and Petra Haden.

The Atlanta rapper's long-delayed follow-up to 2008's The Recession features guest appearances by such artists as Andre 3000, Devin the Dude, Fabolous, Future, Jay-Z, Jadakiss, Ne-Yo, Jill Scott, Snoop Dogg, T.I., and Trick Daddy. The deluxe edition includes four additional tracks featuring Eminem, Freddie Gibbs, Lil Wayne, and Piles as guests.
The second album post-Drive-By Truckers for the singer-songwriter from Alabama is the first to feature The 400 Unit.
The 12th studio album for the singer was produced with L.A. Reid, Tricky Stewart, and The-Dream.
Formally known as The Cotton Jones Basket Ride, the band releases its second full-length album on the Suicide Squeeze Records label.

The latest full-length release for the pop singer-songwriter features both new originals and cover songs recorded remotely with such artists as 6LACK, Jimmie Allen, Glen Campbell, Brandi Carlile, Miley Cyrus, Gorillaz, SG Lewis, Lil Nas X, Dua Lipa, Nicki Minaj, Stevie Nicks, Charlie Puth, Rina Sawayama, Surfaces, Eddie Vedder, Stevie Wonder, Years & Years, and Young Thug.
After releasing three children's albums in five years, the alt-rock band from Brooklyn releases its 15th full-length album.
The Canadian singer-songwriter of the mid-'80s still achieves cult status success with his new album of silky-voiced, smooth-sounding melodic songs.
The veteran Southern California hardcore punk band returns with--as you may have guessed from the title--a political-themed disc, complete with carefully-footnoted lyrics.
This is the second full-length release for the supergroup that includes Alex Turner, Miles Kane, James Ford, and newest addition Mini Mansions' Zach Dawes on bass.
The fifth full-length release for the indie rock band sees it returning to its three-person line-up of Dan Boeckner, Spencer Krug, and Arlen Thompson.
The third full-length release for the British dance-rock trio is its first in eight years.
The debut full-length solo release for ex-WU LYF member Tom McClung was produced by Brendan Williams.

The first solo full-length release in 18 years for the Jane's Addiction frontman was produced with Tony Visconti and features contributions from his wife Etty Lau Farrell, the Cars' Elliott Easton, Dhani Harrison, and Foo Fighters Taylor Hawkins.

The fourth full-length studio release for the Southern California rapper features guest appearances from Boogie, DaBaby, Day Sulan, G-Eazy, Kamaiyah, Jon Z, Meek Mill, Mitch, Arin Ray, RJ, Rose Gold, SAFE, Ty Dolla $ign, Tyga, and Valee.
The third full-length release for the singer-songwriter was self-produced.
The debut release for the side project of Super Furry Animals bassist Guto Pryce and his wife Lindsey Leven includes contributions from Gid Goundrey and ex-Race Horses drummer Gwion Llewelyn.
Better known for his work with Broken Social Scene, Jason Collett's latest solo album was influenced by the economic crisis.
The Canadian folk-rock twins return with their third album.
This is the debut full-length release for the Brooklyn band formed by former Here We Go Magic keyboardist Teeny Lieberson with her friend, Jane Herships and Teeny's sisters, Katherine and Lizzie.
This 28-track, two-disc compilation culls radio performances, demos, and other previously unreleased tracks from throughout the band's history.
A radical departure from previous efforts, the band's third album adds a lot of acoustic guitars and other Americana and blues elements into the mix.
The sixth full-length release for the synth-pop artist was recorded during the same sessions as 2017's Screen Memories.

recordname: Mountains of Sorrow, Rivers of Song
description: Produced by Jay Joyce, Alison Krauss and Patty Griffin appear as guests on the fifth studio release for the Philadelphia singer-songwriter.
Stephen Street produced this sophomore set for Liverpool's Zutons.
The third full-length release for the Seattle indie-pop artist was co-produced with Small Black's Juan Pieczanski and Ryan Heyner

recordname: With A Cape And A Cane
description: This is the second album for the Portland, Ore. indie rockers.
The first studio release in 17 years for the Texas post-hardcore rock band was produced by Omar Rodriguez-Lopez and Rich Costey.
The fourth full-length release for the Scottish trio was produced by Gary Clark.
The debut release of a collaboration between Ben Lanz of Beirut and the National's Scott and Bryan Devendorf features music recorded in a Cincinnati church studio over three days.
This is the debut album from the Liverpool trio.
The eccentric Chicago artist returns with his first disc in three years.
The 14th full-length studio release for the pop artist features guest appearances from Anitta, Maluma, Quavo, and Swae Lee.
This is the debut full-length release for the Australian indie pop trio of Hannah Joy, Tim Fitz (who also produced) and Harry Day.
The seventh full-length release for the Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter was produced by Leo Abrahams.
The fifth album for the French electronic group led by Anthony Gonzalez was produced with Ken Thomas and Ewan Pearson.
Thrill Jockey releases the New York duo's sixth album.
The second release for the indie pop quintet from New York was produced by Shane Stoneback.

recordname: Maybach Music Group Presents: Self Made, Vol. 2
description: The second volume of the rap release from the Maybach Music Group features tracks with Rick Ross, Wale, Meek Mill, T.I., Nas, Stalley, Omarion, Wiz Khalifa, and T-Pain.
The Austin rock band that gained mainstream exposure on the UNKLE song With You in My Head featured in the film "The Twilight Saga: Eclipse," releases its third album on new label Blue Horizon.
The Brighton, England band re-teams with producer Steve Albini, but downplays the vocals of prior outing 'The Power Out' in favor of a mainly instrumental approach similar to that of their debut.
Another of the new new wave of New York bands, Elefant is fronted by Diego Garcia, who despite being born in Detroit and raised in Argentina, sounds awfully British on this short, ten-track debut.

recordauthor: Mark Ronson and the Business Intl
description: The DJ-turned-producer, who has worked with everyone from Lily Allen to Amy Winehouse, returns with his third studio album under his new moniker, with impressive dance-floor, disco-pop jams.
Recorded in 2012-2013, the 64th and final studio album for singer-songwriter (who was diagnosed with Alzheimer's in 2011) features guest appearances from Roger Miller, Willie Nelson, and Vince Gill.
Jennifer Herrema returns with RTX's Nadav Eisenman, Brian Mckinley, Kurt Midness, and Jaimo Welch under the name Black Bananas.
This is the debut full-length album for the singer-songwriter from England.
Timbaland, will.i.am and Rick Rubin are among the producers on the singer's second solo set.
The singer-songwriter (who also appears in the group The Thorns) releases his first official solo disc since 1999's 'In Reverse.' Van Dyke Parks guests.

The Canadian singer-songwriter's Nonesuch debut features covers of songs by other Canadian singer-songwriters, including Neil Young, Leonard Cohen, Ron Sexsmith, Jane Siberry, and William Shatner. (OK, so maybe not the last one.) There's also one lang original for good measure.
This loud but eclectic disc marks the debut for the sextet from Nottingham, England.
This is the second album for the nu-metal band out of Wales.

Featuring guitarists named Rock and Roll Indian and Surge Joebot, the latest indie-rock sensation to come out of Detroit combines punk, new-wave and disco on this debut full-length. Included here is a new version of their hit single "Danger! High Voltage" with the White Stripes' Jack White on backing vocals.

As the title implies, this is not a true follow-up to 2001's 'Gold,' but rather a collection of demo recordings--13 never-before-released tracks (down from a rumored four-CD set!) captured on tape during spare moments while on tour.
This is the Cincinnati, Ohio band's major label debut.
This is the fifth full-length release from Tom Jenkinson (aka Squarepusher). "My Red Hot Car" is the lead single.
The first album from the Philly trio since 1999's Philadelphonic features guest appearances from Medeski Martin & Wood keyboardist John Medeski and Morphine drummer Billy Conway.
The follow-up to the Leeds rock band's top selling sophomore album features Lily Allen and New Young Pony Club as guests.
The eigth full-length studio release for the alternative/progressive rock band is its first not tied to the Sanchez's conceptual Amory Wars story.
The fourth full-length release for the British singer-songwriter Rex Orange County features a guest appearance from Tyler, The Creator.
The Scottish band re-recorded its 2014's release Nobody Wants To Be Here And Nobody Wants to Leave acoustically at Glasgow's Oran Mor.
Pete Kember returns as producer on Christopher Porpora's album based on letters from an schizophrenic to her husband while she was in a German asylum.
This is the debut album for the British rap duo of Jordan "Rizzle" Stephens and Harley "Sylvester" Alexander-Sule that grew up together and met again in college.
This is the latest album for the San Diego-based indie rock band.
The Jurassic 5/Ozomatli member releases his debut studio solo album featuring such artists as Beenie Man, Anthony Hamilton, Talib Kweli, Damian "Jr. Gong" Marley, and Stephen Marley.
Leann Rimes 12th album features Bon Jovi and Reba McEntire as guests.
E Street Band member and the wife to Bruce Springsteen releases her third solo album.
The eclectic UK band self-produced this third album in their Isle of Wight studios.
The second full-length studio release for the Washington state-based artist is his first with indie label Tender Loving Empire.
This collection from Daniel Rossen (Grizzly Bear) and Fred Nicolaus contains B-sides and songs from the never released 2006 second album "The January Sessions."
Famous for its live performances, the indie rock band--based out of Brighton, England--weaves together atmospheric sounds to create an innovative new album.
The sixth full-length album for the Canadian indie rock band was produced with Graham Lessard and Marcus Paquin.
The live release features tracks from the Australian psychedelic rock band's 2019 tour.
The second full-length release for the Los Angeles trio led by Will Ivy was recorded by Steve Albini.
The third full-length release for the Las Vegas singer-songwriter was self-recorded and mixed.
This is the fifth full-length release from the self-described "beach goth" California band.
The fourth solo release for the British singer-songwriter includes guest appearances from deadmau5 and Vishal-Shekhar.
Romantic love is the theme behind the sixth solo release for the former Bad Seed member that includes collaborations with PJ Harvey and covers of songs by Van Morrison, Roy Orbison, and The Saints.
This is the sixth solo album for Mike Kinsella under the name Owen.
The tenth full-length studio release from the alternative rock band led by Billy Corgan includes Mötley Crüe's Tommy Lee on drums.
The sixth full-length release for the British rock quintet was produced by the band's lead singer, Serge Pizzorno.

The 11th full-length studio release for the trash metal band led by Joey Belladonna was produced by Jay Ruston and is its first with Jon Donais of Shadows Fall taking over lead guitars from Rob Caggiano.
Beyonce's second album features production by Rodney Jerkins, Sean Garrett, the Neptunes, Rich Harrison and Swizz Beatz and a guest appearance by Jay-Z.
The singer-songwriter takes inspiration from classical music to create a "21st century song cycle" for her 12th album, released on the world-renowned German classical label, Deutsche Grammophon.
The fifth full-length studio release for the Los Angeles-based electronic/hip-hop producer features guest appearances from Jon Bap, Asal Hazel and Pink Siifu.
The first studio release since 2011 from the band led by Mike Scott was recorded in Nashville.
Singer-songwriter Colin Caulfield's second full-length album and his first with a full band was produced by John McEntire of the Sea and Cake.
The Brooklyn trio blend dance and indie rock music together for a 1980s feel on its second album.

recordname: This Is Not a Safe Place
description: The sixth full-length studio release for the British shoegaze band was produced by Erol Alkan and mixed by Alan Moulder with Caesar Edmunds.
The debut album for the Montreal experimental rock quartet was produced with Jace Lasek of The Besnard Lakes.
The British rapper's eighth album was named in part after the area he grew up in.
The third full-length release for the Montreal indie pop band was recorded in a former brothel in the Los Angeles area.

The eighth studio release for the rap duo of Havoc and Prodigy features guest appearances from Bun B, Busta Rhymes, French Montana, Juicy J, The Lox, Nas, Snoop Dogg, and Mack Wilds. It also includes a disc of unreleased tracks from 1995's The Infamous sessions.
The sophomore album from the Oklahoma indie rock band.
Ernest Greene releases his first full-length of dreamy synth-pop under his Washed Out moniker.
The debut solo release for the Death Cab For Cutie singer under his name (he released a solo album under the name All-Time Quarterback! in 1999) features a duet with Aimee Mann.

recordname: Danger Days: The True Lives of the Fabulous Killjoys
description: My Chemical Romance's latest release -- four years after the last album -- reveals a slightly different sound and style for the band while keeping its recognizable emo meets rock-and-roll spirit.
This is the debut full-length release for the collaboration between Deap Vally and The Flaming Lips' Wayne Coyne & Steven Drozd.
The first studio release in six years for the the British guitarist was produced with Filippo Cimatti and features Rosie Bones and Carmen Vandenberg.
The second full-length release for the Arcade Fire band member features Jeremy Gara on drums.
The debut full-length studio release for Depeche Mode's Martin Gore contains 16 instrumental electronic tracks.
The fourth full-length release for the Brooklyn-based band features guest appearance by Suzzy Roche of The Roches and was produced by Joey Waronker.
The debut full-length solo release for Radiohead guitarist Ed O'Brien features guest appearances by Laura Marling and Portishead's Adrian Utley.
The latest album from the Grammy-winning country singer features guests such as B.B. King, Vince Gill, Buck Owens, Steve Wariner, and Keith Urban.
The second full-length release for the Australian rock band was produced by Jack Farley.
The latest album from the British band is produced by Craig Silvey (The Magic Numbers).
The Berlin-based duo named after the video director releases its second album.
The debut full-length release from the Brooklyn indie pop band led by Samantha Urbani and Lesley Hann.
Crowded House's Neil and Tim Finn reunite with producer Mitchell Froom for this disc, which also finds them joined by Los Angeles musicians Matt Chamberlain and Jon Brion.
The brother-sister duo of Matthew and Eleanor Friedberger return with a second quirky, challenging and eclectic LP.
This debut album from the French electronica trio features the Wild Colonials' Angela McCluskey on vocals on a number of tracks.
The Miami rapper's new album consists of club bangers and features collaborations with Marc Anthony and Ne-Yo.

recordname: It Feels So Good When I Stop
description: The covers album also serves as a soundtrack to his novel of the same name.
The francophone rock band from Montreal releases its third album.
The third full-length studio release from the Odd Future rapper features guest appearances from such artists as Erykah Badu, Hodgy Beats, Frank Ocean, Pharrell, Laetitia Sadier, and Earl Sweatshirt.
The second album from the R&B songstress includes a guest appearance by Eve. Rich Harrison returns as producer for about half of the disc.
The debut full-length album for the British R&B singer who graduated from the same infamous Brit School as Adele and Amy Winehouse was produced with Will Bevan (aka Burial) and Royce Wood, Jr.
The second full-length release for the Scottish electronic producer features guest appearances from Jhené Aiko, Antony, Devaeux, Irfane, Miguel, and Ruckazoid.
The ex-Husker Du singer moves away from the electronic sounds of his more recent releases and returns to the guitar stylings he played 20 years ago.
The debut album for the ex-Test Icicles member was produced by Mike Mogis.
The third full-length release for Adam Bainbridge features guest appearances from Bahamadia, Cosima, Nadia Nair, Robyn, Seinabo Sey, Samthing Soweto, and Jazmine Sullivan.
The debut full-length release for the Canadian R&B-pop singer-songwriter features all five tracks from her Four Pink Walls EP.
The Chicago-based singer-songwriter's debut album is the first release from Hot Charity, an imprint of XL Recordings.
Producer David Kahne worked on the singer-songwriter's fifth album.
Album number two finds the Nashville star reuniting with songwriter John Rich in an attempt to duplicate the mega-success of her debut, 'Here For The Party.'
Dr. Dre, Timbaland and the Neptunes are among the producers for an album that finds Snoop joined by The Game, Stevie Wonder, Ice Cube, R. Kelly, Brandy, and others.

recordname: Shoot For The Stars Aim For The Moon
description: The debut full-length studio release for the rapper is also a posthumous album following his death in February 2020. It features guest appearances from 50 Cent, DaBaby, Future, Karol G, King Combs, Lil Baby, Lil Tjay, Quavo, Roddy Ricch, Rowdy Rebel, Swae Lee, and Tyga.
The seventh full-length studio release for the Atlanta rapper features guest appearances from Gunna, Travis Scott and Young Thug.
Menomena's Brent Knopf releases the first album of his solo project, Ramona Falls, which features more than 30 guests musicians.
Toronto's Kheaven Brereton returns with his third studio album of indie hip-hop mixed with a variety of other genres.
The sixth full-length release for Brendon Urie was written after his stint in Broadway's Kinky Boots and was produced by Jake Sinclair.
The fourth full-length release for the Minneapolis band features songs written while frontwoman Channy Leaneagh was recovering from a back injury.
The second solo release from the Emeralds' Steve Hauschildt was recorded with nearly 20 different instruments.

The concept album about violence in America for the hip hip group features guest vocals from Black Thought, Michel Chion, Patty Crash, Raheem DeVaughn, Dice Raw, Mercedes Martinez, Greg Porn, Nina Simone, and Mary Lou Williams.
The seventh full-length release for the Scottish alternative rock band was produced by Youth and is its first new studio album in 18 years.
The second release for Gabe Fulvimar was produced by Conspiracy of Owls' Bobby Harlow.

recordname: Dry Land is Not a Myth
description: The debut full-length release for the Los Angeles five-piece includes influences from rock, electronic, and world music.
The debut studio release for the Atlanta rapper features production from DJ Mustard, Jake One, Metro Boomin, Southside, and Zaytoven.
The second release in 2012 for the Portland psychedelic rock band was recorded in its entirety instead of select tracks from hours of recording sessions.
This is the second album from the Canadian indie rock band led by Broken Social Scene singer-songwriter Jason Collett.
The fourth album for the R&B singer features such guests as Estelle, The Game, Jay-Z, Kid Cudi, and Snoop Dogg.
The ex-Beach Boys singer releases his latest solo album, which he produced himself.
The eighth full-length studio release for the pop singer-songwriter was co-produced with Don Was.
The second album for the Scottish indie rock band was produced by Tony Doogan.
The debut album for the rap artist features guest appearances by David Banner, Estelle, Kanye West and Too Short. It was originally scheduled to be released as "Dream Date" in 2008.

Produced and recorded by the band along with the helping hand of producer Matt Allison, the Chicago punk-rock natives' seventh studio album, This Addiction, is the band's first release on their label Heart & Skull and their first with Epitaph Records.

The third full-length studio release for the Black Hippy rapper features guest appearances from such artists as Action Bronson, Asaad, Danny Brown, Jay Rock, Kendrick Lamar, Lupe Fiasco, Rick Ross, Schoolboy Q, and SZA.
The second full-length release for the Los Angeles-based band that includes sister Jennifer and Jessie Clavin was co-produced by Joe Chiccarelli and Carlos de la Garza.
The fourth studio release for the Atlanta-based indie rock band was produced with Dan Hannon.
Trick Daddy, Nate Dogg, DMX and Nas guest on the latest from the Atlanta-based rapper, with production from Timbaland, among others.

recordname: The Boy Who Knew Too Much
description: The second album for the London-based singer was produced with Greg Wells and features Imogen Heap and Final Fantasy's Owen Pallett as guests.
The fifth full-length release for the electronic duo of Mike Stroud and Evan Mast features a cover of Springwater's "I Will Return."
The fifth full-length release for the band led by Ian Parton features contributions from Amber Arcades, Detroit Youth Choir, Lispector, and Darenda Weaver.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Ohio was produced and recorded remotely.
The latest full-length solo release for the singer-songwriter is a Billie Holiday covers album.
The third full-length release for the band features covers of songs from such artists as David Byrne, John Denver, Kelela, Moondog, Labi Sif, and SWV as well as a guest appearance from Waxahatchee.
The seventh full-length studio release for the alternative rock band was produced by Tom Dalgety.
The third solo album for the ex-Girls frontman was co-produced with JJ Wiesler and was a surprise release on Bandcamp.
The second full-length release for the New Zealand-born singer-songwriter was produced by Rich Costey.
The debut full-length release (which only contains eight songs) for the Southern California duo of Matt Pulos and Evan Laffer was produced by Foxygen's Jonathan Rado.
The ninth studio full-length release for the New Jersey stoner rock band was produced by band members ave Wyndorf & Phil Caivano.
The third full-length release for the Brooklyn duo includes influences from pop and R&B music with a majority of the melodies written by singer Alexis Krauss.
The first release with new drummer Arin Ilejay of Confide [takes over for James "The Rev" Sullivan, who passed away in 2009] for the California heavy metal band was produced by Mike Elizondo.
This is the third full-length release for the side project for Black Mountain band members Amber Webber and Josh Wells.
The more rock-flavored second solo release for the son of Paul Simon was co-produced with Tom Rothrock.
The 10th release for Sascha Ring as Apparat was originally commissioned for 2012 Ruhr Festival's stage production of Tolstoys War and Peace directed by Sebastian Hartmann.
The third release for the singer-songwriter was produced by Woody Jackson and features guest vocals by Inara George, Petra Haden, and Isobel Campbell.
The second full-length release from the rap supergroup features guest appearances from Eminem, Busta Rhymes, Skylar Grey, Cee-Lo Green, and Swizz Beatz.
The fourth album for the British pop singer was written while she was sidelined in Australia by Icelandic ash in 2010.
The Florida pop-punk band's seventh album was produced by Neal Avron and is about the different emotions that occur when a relationship ends.
The full-length debut release for the Louisiana indie pop band was produced by Ben H. Allen.
The electronica duo from Brooklyn, New York, releases its fourth full-length album.
David Newfeld produced the Canadian indie rock band's third album.
T Bone Burnett returns as producer for Elvis Costello's latest album, featuring an acoustic strings band.
The Stars vocalist makes her solo debut, backed by members of that band as well as of Broken Social Scene, Do Make Say Think, and Metric.
'Dimmer' is the Thrill Jockey debut for British ex-pat and current Chicagoan Jim Elkington.
This is the fourth release for the chamber-pop outfit led by--yes--Matthew Pond and based in--you guessed it--Pennsylvania (Philadelphia, to be exact).
'Get Born' marks the debut of the Australian garage-rock quartet Jet.

Fresh off the electroclash touring circuit (and apparently in need of a good shave), ever-vulgar Canadian Merrill Nisker (aka Peaches) follows her 2000 debut 'The Teaches of Peaches' with 12 new tracks, including a duet with Iggy Pop.

recordname: How I Learned To Write Backwards
description: The Bay Area indie-pop band returns with their third album (and first in three years).

recordname: American IV: The Man Comes Around
description: Johnny Cash, still going strong at age 70, returns for a fourth album with producer Rick Rubin. Like the previous three pairings, this disc mixes Cash originals with unlikely covers, which this time out include Depeche Mode's "Personal Jesus," Nine Inch Nails' "Hurt," and Simon & Garfunkel's "Bridge Over Troubled Water." Fiona Apple, Nick Cave, and Don Henley are among the guests.
The follow-up to their platinum debut album finds the band dropping the exclamation point from their name.
The Japanese experimental band's 16th album shares the same release date as Attention Please and seeks to redefine heavy music.
The third full-length release for Chaz Bundick was inspired by his recent move from South Carolina to Berkeley, California.
The second album from dubstep producer/DJ Christopher Mercer, aka Rusko, features influences from pop, R&B, house, reggae, dancehall, and garage music.
The fifth full-length release for the Baltimore psych-folk rock band led by Dave Heumann includes a guest appearance by Dave Hadley.
The latest album for the Canadian singer-songwriter was produced by Martin Terefe.

recordname: Just Who I Am: Poets & Pirates
description: The 11th album for the Knoxville, Tennessee-born country singer.
Cleveland-based Joe Williams' debut album was recorded in Ohio, New York, and California.

The 12th full-length studio release from the rapper/actor features guest appearances from A-Trak, BJ The Chicago Kid, Leon Bridges, Daniel Caesar. Leikeli47, Jonathan McReynolds, Samora Pinderhughes, Jill Scott, and Swizz Beatz.
The second full-length for the Austin trio features 16 tracks and is their first for Matador Records.
The fifth full-length solo release for the Nashville singer-songwriter features contributions from Tyler Cain, Nathan Chapman, Jake Mitchell, Niko Moon, Mikey Reaves, Jordan Reynolds, and Ben West.

recordname: Food & Liquor, Vol. 2: the Great American Rap Album, Pt. 1
description: Lupe Fiasco's third album was self-produced and features guest appearances by Bilal, Casey Benjamin, Guy Sebastian, Jane $$$, Jason Evigan, and Poo Bear.
This is the full-length debut release for the London-based singer-songwriter.
The fifth full-length studio release for the Chicago artist was produced with Nathan Cook.
The third full-length release for Ernest Greene's chillwave project features a DVD of the visual album.
This is the second album with ex-My Bloody Valentine drummer Colm O'Ciosoig for Hope Sandoval.
The 13th release for Sean Schuster-Craig as Jib Kidder features a duet with Julia Holter.

recordname: One Fast Move Or Im Gone: Kerouacs Big Sur
description: Son Volt's Jay Farrar and Death Cab For Cutie's Benjamin Gibbard helped write songs for a documentary about Jack Kerouac in 2007. This album is a further expansion of the project.
The fourth full-length release for the Los Angeles rock band was produced with Jarvis Taveniere.
The rock band formed by Band of Horses' Matt Brooke releases its debut album.
The debut full-length album for the pop duo of Elizabeth Sankey and Jeremy Warmsley was produced by Steve Mackey.

The third full-length solo studio release for the Outkast rapper features guest appearances from Eric Bellinger, Big Rube, Curren$y, Gucci Mane, Jeezy, Killer Mike, Kurupt, Adam Levine, LunchMoney Lewis, Pimp C, Scar, Sleepy Brown, Snoop Dogg, and Trozé.
The latest release from the Robert Pollard-led band features a new line-up that includes new members Bobby Bare Jr. and Mark Shue.
The fourth album for the duo from Finland is based on a 19th-century novel about Atlantis.
The debut full-length release for the London-based quartet was produced by Tom Morris.
The pop song parodist releases his 13th studio album, poking fun at Lady Gaga, Miley Cyrus, Taylor Swift and more.
The sophomore album for the rock quartet from Nashville, Tennessee.
The New York band fronted by Hamilton Leithauser self-produced this third album.

recordname: Skrillex And Diplo Presents Jack U
description: The Surprise release from the collaboration between Skrillex And Diplo features guest appearances from 2 Chainz, AlunaGeorge, Justin Bieber, Fly Boi Keno, Bunji Garlin, Kai, Kiesza, Snails and Taranchyla.
The American Idol songstress returns with her highly anticipated third album featuring--for the first time as a bonus track--Fantasia's signature song from her acting role in The Color Purple.
The second full-length studio release for the Berlin-based Finnish electronic duo features guest appearances from Code Orange, Lalita and LYZZA.
The second full-length release for the Los Angeles-based artist features contributions from Tim Anderson, Al Shux, Sohn,
Norah Jones is one of two vocalists (Richard Julian is the other) in New York's Little Willies, who make their debut with this mostly-covers album.
The American Idol winner releases her fourth album.
The third album for the pop punk group from Chicago was produced by Sam Hollander and Dave Katz.
Kelly Rowland continues with her second solo album since Destiny's Child ended.
Active Child, El Perro Del Mar, Totally Enormous Extinct Dinosaurs, and Twin Shadow are some of the guests on the Jonquil frontman's solo full-length debut.
The debut full-length release for the Los Angeles-based rock duo of Lindsey Troy and Julie Edwards was produced by Lars Stalfors.
After a three year hiatus, the rock band formed by four brothers return with its sixth full-length studio release produced by Angelo Petraglia.
Nick Raskulinecz returns to produce the fifth full-length studio release for the hard rock band and its second with William DuVall as lead singer.
The first Bright Eyes album in four years shows Conor Oberst sticking to his winning combination of indie and folk rock.
This ninth album for the Chicago rockers was recorded with Steve Albini.

recordname: Joan Of Arc, Dick Cheney, Mark Twain...
description: No, it's not a Jeopardy answer meriting the response "Who are three people who have never been in my kitchen?" but rather the latest noise-fest from Tim Kinsella & co.
This is the fourth album for the Kansas City (Mo.)-based emo band.
The soul singer's fifth LP is less political than previous efforts, as may be expected from a disc that lists three tracks titled "Love Song."

This is the third LP for the English trio of vocalist Sarah Nixey, former Auteurs frontman Luke Haines and former Jesus & Mary Chain member John Moore. Together, they sound a bit like Saint Etienne, but with a much more political and satirical approach to their lyrics.
The Thorns is a collaboration between singer-songwriters Matthew Sweet, Shawn Mullins and Pete Droge, with this disc marking their first release together.

This debut disc for the New York duo of Warren Fischer and Casey Spooner was originally released in 2001 on Germany's International Deejay Gigolos label and immediately generated such buzz (partly due to the album's infectious 'electroclash' sound, and partly due to the pair's notoriety in the fashion scene) that English label Ministry Of Sound snapped up the album (and the duo) for a reported £2 million.

The latest full-length from the Chicago-based multimedia collective is a big step forward for the group, adding more vocals and an emotive indie-pop feel to their experimental electronic sound. Recommended for fans of the latest releases by bands such as Dntel, Hood, and Boards of Canada.
This solo set by the frontman of the (still intact) Old 97s was produced by Jon Brion, and ventures away from the alt-country sound of that group's work.

The first solo album in seven years for the Fleetwood Mac vocalist was partially produced by Sheryl Crow. Sarah McLachlan lends her voice to one track. Other guests include Macy Gray and Natalie Maines from the Dixie Chicks.
The debut solo release from The Verve frontman Richard Ashcroft.
This is the second album for the duo from Brooklyn.
Welsh indie artist Stephen Black worked with arranger Paul Jones for his fifth release.
Produced by Joe Henry, Mann's first studio disc in three years is a concept album about the life of a boxer during the 1970s.

The eighth full-length studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from DaBaby, Doe Boy, Drake, Future, Lil Baby, Lil Durk, Lil Uzi Vert, Meek Mill, Travis Scott, YoungBoy Never Broke Again, and Young Thug
The second full-length release for the Los Angeles duo of Jesse Kivel and Zinzi Edmundson was produced by Pete Wiggs and Tim Larcombe.

The Little Willies with Norah Jones on vocals and piano return with their second disc of country covers song by such artists as Loretta Lynn, Dolly Parton, Johnny Cash, Cal Martin, Scotty Wiseman, Dangerous Curves, and Lefty Frizzell.
The first new music from the band in over 20 years reunites Shaun Ryder and Kermit on an album produced by Youth.
The latest release from the Oregon-based psych rockers was recorded in a cabin near Mount Hood.
The first album to be released by EMI in the US (previously Warner Music had US rights) for the English alt-electronic band.
Sigur Ros producer Ken Thomas helped mix iLiKETRAiNS' first studio album.
The fourth full-length studio release for the British singer-songwriter was produced with The National's Aaron Dessner.
The ninth full-length studio release for the singer-songwriter was co-produced with Jeff Trott and Tchad Blake.
The third full-length release for the California folk duo was recorded live on tour at the venues they would later performed on.

recordname: Dedicated: A Salute to the 5 Royales
description: The guitarist best known for working with Booker T & the M.G.'s releases a tribute album to the R&B band The 5 Royales.
This is the first album in over 17 years for the native american singer-songwriter.
The fourth album for the Bristol, England-based indie pop band led by Frenchman Francois Marry is its first on the Domino label.
The debut solo album of The Hold Steady's Craig Finn includes elements of country music.
This is the final section of the Eels' concept album trilogy, which began with last year's Hombre Lobo and End Times.
The third full-length release for Berlin-based Jam Rostron (formerly Janine Rostron) includes themes about gender equality and identity.
The CD/DVD set collects some of the performances the singer-songwriter gave during his world tour to promote his debut album, "Grace," from 1994 to 1996.
The second full-length studio album for the French electronic duo features guest appearances by Ali Love, Morgan Phalen, and Vincent Vendetta.
The debut album from Leon "Scratcha DVA" Smart features guest appearances by Natalie Maddix, Muhsinah, A.L. Zaki Ibrahim, Vikter Duplaix, Fatima, and Cornelia.
The 22-year-old writer of songs for the likes of Mary J. Blige steps into the spotlight with his debut as an R&B artist.
The ninth full-length studio release for the Berkley punk band led by Tim Armstrong was produced by Brett Gurewitz.
The country covers release for the multiple Grammy-winning singer was produced by Buddy Cannon.
The third album for the dream pop group is its first without Claudia Deheza and it tells a story about the ghosts that surround a girl named Lafaye.
The latest release for the Northern Irish singer is his first album with all original songs since 1999's Back on Top.
The fifth full-length studio release for the rock band-turned-solo-act featuring Brendon Urie was produced by Jake Sinclair.
The Las Vegas band returns with its its third studio album produced by Stuart Price.
This is the first full-length release in nearly 40 years for the British avant-garde artist.
The fourth full-length release for the Japanese psychedelic rock band was recorded in Lisbon and was produced by Bruno Pernadas.
The full-length debut release for the Brooklyn-based garage rock band led by Mike Brandon and LA Solano was produced by Wayne Gordon.

recordname: To Where the Wild Things Are
description: This is the second full-length release for the Swedish psychedelic dream-pop duo of Marleen Nilsson and Anders Hansson.
This is the second full-length album of folk and blues music from Katherine Blamire and Jessica Davies.
Self-produced (with some help from Johannes Berglund) by the band, the fourth release for the Swedish indie pop five piece was recorded over a year and half.
The fifth release for the R&B singer features co-written with such artists as Babyface, Gary Clark Jr., Dr. Dre, John Legend, Bruno Mars, Frank Ocean, and Emeli Sandé.
This is the second release in 2012 for the Canadian electronic artist, Matt Halversen.
The third album for the Chicago indie rock band is the first with Sonic Youth drummer Steve Shelly.
Jonquil's third album sees the band downsized to a quartet with three members leaving to form the band Trophy Wife.
The Brighton-based trio, led by producer and former DJ Fin "Fink" Greenall, release a fourth album of folk-y electro-pop.

recordname: The Hymn of a Broken Man
description: This is the debut album for the band, which features Adam Dutkiewicz and Jesse Leach of Killswitch Engage.
The sophomore album from the R&B artist features guest appearances by Big Boi, the Game, Lil Wayne, and Kanye West.
The second full-length release for the trio of sisters was co-produced with Ariel Rechtshaid and features contributions from Rostam Batmanglij and Dev Hynes.
Rick Rubin produces the band's major label debut album.
The ninth full-length studio release for the indie rock band was produced by Rich Costey.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn punk band was produced by Dave Sitek.
The third full-length release for the singer-songwriter was co-produced with her husband, Jesse Newport.
This ten-song effort is a sequel to the singer's 1975 album 'Captain Fantastic And The Brown Dirt Cowboy.'
This is the purple one's second straight set of mainstream music, following 2004's 'Musicology,' which itself followed a string of more esoteric releases.
The fifth full-length studio release for the Southern California rapper features guest appearances from 21 Savage, 6LACK, Kid Cudi, Lil Baby, Travis Scott, Ty Dolla $ign, and YG.
The debut full-length release for the alt-rock band formed in England by Australian Sasha Carlson was produced by band member Toto Vivian.
This is the fourth release for the instrumental rock band led by Nathan Burazer.
The Strokes have abandoned longtime producer Gordon Raphael (well, for all but three tracks) in favor of David Kahne (Sugar Ray) for their third album.
The 18th full-length studio release for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame rock band was produced by Julian Raymond.
The debut full-length release for the side project of The Strokes' guitarist Nick Valensi was produced by Queens Of The Stone Age's Josh Homme.
The British band released You Cross My Path as a free download by way of the radio station XFM's Web site.
The veteran duo of Emily Saliers and Amy Ray continue with their well-established sound on this ninth studio album.

Since leaving the Bad Seeds (Nick Cave's backing band) in the late 1980s, Barry Adamson has embarked on a prolific career providing soundtrack music to films both real ('Gas Food Lodging,' 'The Beach') and imagined (numerous cinematic-sounding solo albums, including 'Moss Side Story'). This latest release falls into the latter category, and incorporates pop, rock, jazz, funk, and countless other styles in its ten tracks.
The third studio album for the heralded British band features 13 new self-produced tracks.
Robert Smith declared 'Bloodflowers' to be the final release from The Cure. It wasn't, of course, but it does in theory complete a trilogy that began with 'Pornography' and 'Disintegration.'
The English indie rock band's third album was produced by Jacknife Lee and Paul Epworth.

Toby Pazner was inspired by dreams he had during the a trip to Greece and recruited members from such musicians as The Arcs, Charles Bradley, Budos Band, The Dap-Kings, El Michels Affair, Lee Fields, and Menahan Street Band for this instrumental soul album.
The eight-track album for the singer-songwriter features the nine and half minute long "The Drunken Boat."
The fourth album for the Las Vegas-based artist only runs 25 minutes long.
The debut full-length release for the side project of Tunng's Mike Lindsay and Sam Genders features contributions from mum's Sigurlaug Gísladóttir and Amiina.
The fourth full-length release from the New York indie pop band was produced by Rostam Batmanglij.
Kimbra guests on the single "Somebody That I Used To Know" from the first album in five years from the Belgian-Australian Wally De Backer as Gotye.

The third full-length studio release for the rap trio features guest appearances from 2 Chainz, 21 Savage, Big Sean, Cardi B, Drake, Gucci Mane, Nicki Minaj, Post Malone, Travis Scott, and Ty Dolla Sign.
The punk-pop band returns with its sixth studio album and its first release since it split up in 2005.
Black Moth Super Rainbow's Tom Fec releases a second solo album as Tobacco, which features Beck as a guest vocalist on two tracks.

Songwriter Ryan Bingham has grown tremendously on this third full-length. Barely 30 years old, his previous work showed promise but carried the excess expected of a novice. Bingham won both a Golden Globe and an Oscar for "The Weary Kind," the theme song from the film Crazy Heart. The song was produced by T-Bone Burnett, creating a partnership extended on Junky Star. Bingham and his Dead Horses--drummer Matthew Smith, bassist Elijah Ford, and guitarist Corby Schaub, prove the song was no fluke. The sound is pure Americana; these 12 lyrically sophisticated yet direct songs, reflect a host of tense, lost, desperate, individuals dreaming the same dark dream, one that suggests that we are all growing tenser with the times. Bingham has trimmed his songwriting to the bone, while learing to use metaphor and metonomy like a veteran. A former rodeo rider, he wears his influences proudly: Guthrie, Dylan, Van Zandt, Ely, Earle, Clark, and Hubbard. He begins with a sandblasted vision of America in "the Poet." Amid acoustic guitars, a lonesome harmonica ,restrained electric and bass drum, Bingham's whiskey-smoked vocal offers a lyric theme the entire album turns on: "As I keep walking, people keep talking/About things they've never seen or done/Homeless sleep in the park, lovers kiss in the dark/Me, I keep moving on through time." Time is suspended as Bingham's protagonists tell stories from the road (some of them bone-chilling), from America's past and present, physically and psychologically. Rootlessness as peace of mind is portrayed via country rock in "The Wandering," but the feeling in "Strange Feeling In The Air," the title track, a deeply moving acoustic murder ballad (they are strewn throughout the album), and the angry uptempo "Depression," reflect a contradiction: constant movement is the key to survival, not necessarily peace. "Hallelujah" is another murder ballad with a disturbing twist. "Lay My Head On The Rail," is pure folk poetry illustrated by a lone acoustic guitar. The blues in "Hard Worn Trail," are rooted in poverty worry, strained, broken relationships resulting in the search for comfort. It doesn't come anywehre on Junky Star. "All Choked Up Again," set to Waylon Jennings' brand of outlaw country closes it out by mining the existential darkness deeper. Bingham is unflinching, but his songs hold out for a glimmer of something else. The only real consolation Junky Star offers is that no one need feel alone in her or his desperation-this is a true accomplishment. Bingham has delivered a set of songs that mirrors our uncertain times in a musical language that doesn't unduly distort or romanticise them. ~ Thom Jurek
The Canadian indie pop outfit return with a melodic and mood-driven new album, their fifth release of eclectic, dreamy rock.
This is the debut full-length release for the London electronic pop trio of Lotti Benardout, Arthur Delaney, and Dom Goldsmith.
The debut full-length release for the Swedish pop artist was produced by Magnus Lidehäll.
The 13th studio release for the rapper was produced by Pharrell features guest appearances from Kendrick Lamar, Rick Ross, Gwen Stefani, T.I., Charlie Wilson, and Stevie Wonder.
The fourth album for the indie folk band led by Justin Ringle was produced by Skyler Norwood.
The now San Francisco-based garage pop band releases its second album on its new label, Woodist Records.
The sixth full-length studio release for the British hard rock band was produced by Dan Hawkins.

The third full-length studio release for the Odd Future rapper features collaborations with Kanye West, Lil Wayne, Schoolboy Q, Pharrell Williams, Toro Y Moi, Charlie Wilson, and Cole Alexander of The Black Lips.
This is the full-length debut for the Scottish indie pop trio of Eilidh Rodgers, Ruary MacLean, and Rachel Aggs.
Originally included as an appendage to the Japanese edition of Dedication, Nothing features a guest appearance by Panda Bear.

recordname: The Stars Are Indifferent to Astronomy
description: This is the seventh studio release for the New York alternative rock band led by Matthew Caws.
Explosions in the Sky's collaborated with David Wingo on the soundtrack to the David Gordon Green's remake of the Icelandic film, Either Way.

recordname: Going Way Out With Heavy Trash
description: The follow-up to their self-titled album released in 2005.
The electro-rock group from Quebec, with the help of producers Radwan Moumneh and Hadji Bakara, releases its fourth album.

The double album from the hip-hop DJ/producer features instrumentals in the first half and hip-hop collaborations that include such artists as De La Soul, Dave East, Ghostface Killah, Inspectah Deck, Nas, Pharoahe Monch, Pusha T, Raekwon, Run The Jewels, and Wiki in the second half.
The latest full-length solo release for the Bloc Party frontman was self-produced.

recordname: The Past, The Present, The Future

description: This is the debut full-length release for the Russian-born New York-based electronic artist and producer.
The third album for the rock band led by Ben Bridwell is its first on Columbia and for new members Tyler Ramsey and Bill Reynolds who joined after the release of 2007's Cease to Begin.
The second album on Matador Records for the band based in New Mexico.
The second full-length solo release for the ex-Smith Westerns frontman was recorded with Taylor Locke in Los Angeles.

recordname: Girl at the End of the World
description: The 14th full-length studio release for the British rock band was produced by Max Dingel.
The third full-length studio release for the British pop singer features guest appearances by Priscilla Renea and Pharrell Williams.
Robert Pollard follows his Guided By Voices' album with his latest solo album produced by Todd Tobias.
The second full-length release for the Massachusetts rock band led by Lemmy Gurtowsky features the addition of Zack Brower.
The Midwestern country-folk singer's full-length debut mixes twangy music from her hometown heartland with rock and pop into a catchy combination.
Originally titled Views From The 6, the fourth full-length studio release for the Canadian rapper features guest appearances from Kyla, Pimp C, Popcaan, and Wizkid.

Mixed by Chris Coady, the third full-length release for the Aaron Maine's project features contributions from such artists as Jason Arce, Bea1991, Bryndon Cook, Alexander Giannascoli, Dev Hynes, Maya Laner, Kaya Wilkins, and Cameron Wisch, as well as his own father.
This is the eighth full-length release for the solo electric guitar project of Sarah Lipstate.
This the debut full-length electro-pop release for Daniel Woolhouse.

On this sixth album, the Athens, GA band's lineup has been expanded to include guitarist Eric Harris (Olivia Tremor Control) and bassist Craig McQuiston (The Glands). Vic Chesnutt guests on the title track.
The classic rock-influenced New York City group led by singer/songwriter Bill Whitten returns with its third album, produced by Mercury Rev's Dave Fridmann.
This is the debut LP from the Texas band, which features three former members of At The Drive-In (including guitarist Jim Ward).

The third LP for Kansas City's Get Up Kids follows after endless touring with the likes of Weezer and Green Day, and sees the emo band moving in a new direction, thanks in part to producer Scott Litt (R.E.M.).
The second album for the duo from New Orleans sees their music move toward a more pop sound while retaining their ambient style.
The debut album for the rap group composed of Joe Budden, Crooked I, Joell Ortiz, and Royce da 5'9.
This is the debut album for the Denton, Texas, metal band.
Tobin Prinz and Suzi Horn's follow-up to their self-titled debut continues their sparse indie rock sound.
The latest release for the band led by Sonny Smith is an album of songs influenced by country music and Smith's break up with his girlfriend of ten years.
The second full-length release for the British indie electronic band was recorded at an old Soviet radio studio in East Berlin.
The fifth studio album for the electronic duo features such guest singers as Kelis, Santigold, Sam Sparro, Yo! Majesty!, and Yoko Ono.

The second release for the British electro-pop singer Victoria Hesketh as Little Boots was produced by Tim Goldsworthy with contributions from Andy Butler of Hercules and Love Affair and James Ford of Simian Mobile Disco.
The third album from the Nashville, Tennessee rock quartet led by Jonas Stein was produced by Jim Eno of Spoon.
The southern Californian indie rock quartet releases its follow-up to its self-titled debut.
The debut album for the indie-rock duo from San Diego who were previously members of The Plot to Blow Up the Eiffel Tower.
The sixth full-length release for the country/pop artist features a guest appearance from Ludacris and was co-produced with David Garcia.
The sixth full-length release for the British folk-punk artist was produced by Butch Walker.
The third album for the New York indie-rock band was produced by Chris Zane.
Following two EPs on the Tri Angle label, San Francisco-based electronic producer Chris Dexter releases his debut full-length album on his own label.
Del returns from recording his albums with the Hieroglyphics and being featured on the Gorillaz's "Clint Eastwood" to release his fifth solo album.
Professor Ladd's second 2005 release is a punk concept album about religious leader George Baker.

Released in conjunction with the band's 2010 farewell tour, this double-disc acoustic album features new recordings of the Black Crowes' classic hits, as well as revised versions of rarities and deep cuts.
The third full-length solo release for the Vampire Weekend bassist was recorded in London and Los Angeles.
Strictly Kev releases the first full-length DJ Food release in more than 10 years.
The eighth studio album sees the '80s star returns with new dance music.

Noel Gallagher of Oasis returns with his debut solo album, which also includes Mike Rowe, former keyboardist for Oasis; Jeremy Stacy of The Lemon Trees; Lenny Castro; and the Crouch End Festival Chorus.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles-based duo of Chris Lynch and Adam Rasmussen was produced by Jacob Portrait.
This is the latest album of electronic pop for the New Zealand-born Annabel Alpers.
The second release for the British pop singer was produced by Jim Eliot.
The Australian indie electronic band's sixth full-length studio release was mixed by Christoffer Berg.

recordname: Street of the Love of Days
description: This is the debut album for the collaboration between Clientele frontman Alasdair MacLean and Lupe Nunez-Fernandez of Pipas.
The second full-length release was produced by Chris Walla.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles garage rock/psychedelic pop band was produced by Kyle Mullarky.
The second full-length release for the Australian indie singer-songwriter features a guest appearance by Angel Olsen and was produced with Foxygen's Jonathan Rado.
The first solo release in six years for the singer-songwriter was produced by R. Walt Vincent.
The second full-length release for the Portland, Oregon-based duo of Sarah Vesprille and Daniel Hindman duo was produced by John Congleton.
Recorded in Seattle but remixed in Iceland by Jón Birgisson of Sigur Rós, A Chorus of Storytellers is the fifth album led by multi-instrumentalist Jimmy LaValle of the Album Leaf.
The Arizona indie rock band's second album was produced by Chris Chu of the Morning Benders.
The first release in five years for the artist formerly known as Cat Stevens was produced by Rick Rubin.
The alternative rock duo's third studio album was recorded at its Los Angeles home.
The debut full-length release for Thomas Arsenault as Mas Ysa features a guest appearance from Hundred Waters Nicole Miglis.
The debut album for the indie-rock band that features ex-members of the Blood Brothers and Pretty Girls Make Graves.
The debut release from the dance supergroup formed by Fatima Al Qadiri, J-Cush, Asma Maroof and Daniel Pineda of Nguzunguzu features guest appearances from Kelela, Maluca, Shawnna, and Tink.
The second full-length release for the Swedish duo of Caroline Hjelt and Aino Jawo features guest appearance from Charli XCX as well as production from Stargate.
The second studio album for comedy writer and Community actor Donald Glover was coproduced with Ludwig Goransson.

This is the debut disc for the duo of Beachwood Sparks/Tyde member Brent Rademaker and vocalist Michelle Loiselle, featuring contributions from Mia Doi Todd and members of The Warlocks, Rooney and The Brian Jonestown Massacre.
The sixth full-length studio release for the experimental Icelandic band sees the return of founding member Gyða Valtýsdóttir.

Originally released on vinyl for Third Man Records on Record Store Day, the 12-track lo-fi covers album from the Canadian singer-songwriter features songs from such artists as Bob Dylan, The Everly Brothers, Bert Jansch, Willie Nelson, Phil Ochs, and Bruce Springsteen.
The second full-length release from the British electronic trio was produced in Leeds by producer Richard Formby.
The third album for the indie rock band was produced by John Congleton.
The South African trio's debut full-length album was originally self-released on the Internet last year. The CD release with Interscope includes several new tracks.
This is the fourth LP for the minimalist blues-rock duo of Patrick Carney (drums) and Dan Auedback (vocals/guitar).
The latest release from the singer-songwriter features new versions of 13 tracks from her back catalogue.
This is the debut full-length collaboration between Chaz Bundick and The Mattson 2.
Emil Svanangen's fifth album under the Loney, Dear name was inspired by chamber orchestras.

recordname: Come Back To The Five & Dime, Bobby Dee Bobby Dee
description: Benjy Ferree's concept album is about the life of Peter Pan actor, Bobby Driscoll, who died broke and homeless at 31.
Self-produced album number five for Neil Halstead & co. is a more upbeat affair than the norm, with Victor Van Vugt (PJ Harvey) handling the mixing.
The second full-length solo release for the Vampire Weekend bassist Chris Baio was co-produced with John Foyle.
Produced by Matthew Sweet, this is the second album since the pop group re-formed in 2000 and its first without Michael Steel, who left in 2005.
Pharrell Williams, Kanye West and Jamie Foxx guest on the MC's follow-up to 'Kamikaze.' Production comes from the likes of Timbaland, Scott Storch and the Neptunes.
The latest full-length studio release for the British singer-songwriter features five piano ballads.
The debut release for the collaboration between Mayer Hawthorne and Jake One was inspired by disco, boogie, and electric funk.
The debut release for the London-based duo includes sound samples from Public information film archives.
The sophomore release from this French electro-pop group takes elements of dancehall and vintage synth sounds to create an eclectic mix of music.

recordname: I Started Out With Nothin And I Still Got Most Of It Left
description: The California-born musician's first album on the Warner Bros. label features Grinderman, Ruby Turner, and KT Tunstall as guests.

This is the second full-length release for the experimental instrumental electronic duo of Matt Carlson of Parenthetical Girls and Jonathan Sielaff, who also was in the Parenthetical Girls as well as the band AU.
The third studio album for the Los Angeles-based alt-rock band was produced by Jacknife Lee.
The eighth full-length release for the band led by Colin Meloy was produced by John Congleton
The eighth full-length release for the Belgian electronic duo features up to three drummers and was recorded in two days.
Neil Hamburger guests on the San Francisco math-rock trio's unsurprisingly titled sixth release, which sees Phil Manley (Oneida, Trans Am) replacing former guitarist Josh Smith.
The debut full-length release from Danish singer-songwriter Søren Løkke Juul was recorded in a countryside studio outside Copenhagen.
The third solo release for the Strokes guitarist was produced by Gus Oberg.
The third album is its first full-length on the Dead Oceans label and was self-produced.
'Memory' marks the former Beatle's first release for Starbucks' Hear Music label. David Kahne produced the 13-song set.
The fifth solo album for Grammy-winning singer was produced and co-written by Danger Mouse.

recordname: It Won't Always Be like This
description: The debut full-length release for the Irish indie rock band led by Elijah Hewson (the eldest son of U2's Bono) was produced by Anthony Genn.
The third full-length release for the Los Angeles rock band was produced by Mark Rains.
The second full-length release for the band leed by James Hoare and Max Oscarnol was recorded on an eight track.
New members DJ rEk and Mike Swarmbots join co-founder MC Dälek for the experimental hip-hop trio's first album since 2010.
The tenth full-length release for the post-rock trio from Maryland was self-produced and recorded in San Francisco.
The latest release from the British actor/musician was inspired by his inability to sleep and was recorded at night in his flat.

Some of Bob Dylan's songs from the 80s are covered by such artists as Blitzen Trapper, Bonnie Prince Billy, Carl Broemel Of My Morning Jacket, Built To Spill, Deer Tick, Craig Finn Of The Hold Steady, Aaron Freeman of Ween, Glen Hansard, Dawn Landes, Langhorne Slim, Lucius, and Slash.
The former Cursive singer is backed by Sara Bertuldo, Nate Kinsella, Patrick Newbery, Dylan Ryan, and Laura Stevenson on his second solo studio release.

The fourth full-length studio release for the rapper includes guest appearances from 2 Chainz, Birdman, DJ Khaled, French Montana, Future, Anthony Hamilton, Lil Wayne, Meek Mill, Rick Ross, T.I., Wiz Khalifa, and Betty Wright.
The debut full-length release for the Portland, Oregon, duo of Rocky Tinder and Eric Phipps was produced by Unknown Mortal Orchestra's Jacob Portrait.

After a number of well-received mixtapes, the Philadelphia rapper releases his debut full-length studio album featuring guest appearances by Mary J. Blige, Drake, Kirko Bangz, John Legend, Louie V, Nas, Rick Ross, Trey Songz, and Wale.
Soul singer Aaron Livingston and hip-hop producer RJD2 team up to release their debut album together as Icebird.
This is the debut full-length album for the Philadelphia psychedelic pop band.
The third album for the New York rapper features production by El-P, Aesop Rock, and F. Sean Martin.
The debut album for the Glasgow-based indie-rock band was produced by Machine.
The seventh album for the pop artist is her first country album.
The 10th album for Ben Chasny's experimental rock band.
'Xterminator' is the second album for Jennifer Herrema's post-Royal Trux project.
This is the debut album for the country-pop duo of Michelle Branch and Jessica Harp.
O'Connor's first studio album since "retiring" from the music business consists of covers of a dozen reggae classics, including songs by Burning Spear, Peter Tosh and Lee "Scratch" Perry.
This Welsh-language disc marks the solo debut for the Super Furry Animals frontman.

recordname: Join The Dots: B-Sides And Rarities, 1978-2001
description: This 70-track, 4-disc collection is just what the title says: every Cure B-side and compilation track, in chronological order, from 1978-2001, each newly remastered and accompanied by extensive liner notes by Robert Smith.

Solex is Amsterdam-based songwriter Elisabeth Esselink, and this is her third album for Matador. Like her previous albums, 'Low Kick' is filled with dozens of eclectic samples pulled from albums found at Esselink's record shop.
KRS-One returns to the solo recording scene with his first new album since 1997's 'I Got Next.'
The alt-country singer-songwriter covers every song on Taylor Swift's 2014 pop album.
The latest album from the Texas-based artist includes guest appearances by Gael Garc?a Bernal, Nick Valensi of The Strokes, and Rodrigo Amarante of Los Hermanos.
The debut full-length album for the Brooklyn electro-pop band led by Elizabeth Harper.
This is the debut full-length release for the Brooklyn-based indie pop band led by Jess Wolfe and Holly Laessig.
This is the debut release for the collaboration between Neil Halstead of Slowdive and Mojave 3, Nick Holton of Holton's Opulent Oog, and Mark Van Hoen of Seefeel.
The Seattle instrumental quartet is back with a second Sub Pop release.
The second full-length solo release for The Gaslight Anthem frontman was produced by Ted Hutt.
This is the third LP for the band featuring members of the Make-Up and Scene Creamers.
This is the second collaboration with ex-Screaming Trees singer Mark Lanegan.

recordname: Don't You Think You've Had Enough?
description: The third full-length release for the sister duo of sisters Jennifer and Jessie Clavin was produced by Shane Stoneback.
The latest release for the Belfast-born singer-songwriter features five originals and 10 covers with contributions from Jeff Beck, Georgie Fame, Chris Farlowe, Paul Jones, and Jason Rebello.
The legendary country singer's 21st studio album, featuring many of her original songs.
The debut album for the six-piece indie rock band from Oklahoma City.
Simian Mobile Disoc's James Ford produces The Crocodile's follow-up to its 2009 debut album, Summer of Hate.
The second album for the Seattle-based four-piece band was produced with Erik Blood.
The follow-up to their 2009 debut full-length sees a new lineup, with Mika Miko's Jenna Thornhill and Seth Densham joining, while Darker My Love's Tim Presley also appears on this release.
Ted Hutt produced the fourth release for the Americana band that welcomes back Critter Fuqua and features final appearances of Willie Watson, who parted with the band in January 2012.
The fourth full-length studio release form the British electronic duo was written over three days and recorded at a show near the Joshua Tree National Park.
The experimental electronica duo of Rob Brown and Sean Booth return with eight new tracks.
The debut full-length release for the Canadian duo of Majid Al Maskati and producer Jordan Ullman features a guest appearance by Drake.
The second full-length release for Henry Laufer as Shlohmo features a guest appearance from D33J.
The Berlin-based duo's latest release is 18 tracks of experimental electronic music from such artists as Addison Groove, Clark, Lazer Sword, Martyn, Monolake, Phon.o, and Prefuse 73.
Political themes continue to influence the latest album from the punk rock band from Pennsylvania.
The Canadian reggae/ska band returns with a new drummer by the name of Sekou Lumumba and a new producer, King Britt, for its fourth album.
Dave Eringa produced the politically-charged eighth studio album for the Welsh rockers.
The debut full-length release for the British rock trio of Kristian Bell, Daniel Rumsey, and Gianni Honey was produced by Bell and Bill Ryder-Jones.
The fourth full-length studio release for the British rock band features guest appearances from Phoebe Bridgers, Cutty Ranks, FKA Twigs, Tim Healy, and Greta Thunberg.
This is the debut solo dance side project release for Toro y Moi's Chaz Bundick.
The Australian singer-songwriter trio of Sarah Blasko, Holly Throsby, and Sally Seltmann releases its first album together.
The third solo recording for the drummer for Wilco and Loose Fur is an all-percussion affair, featuring eight original compositions.
The Miami-based band releases an album of garage punk songs.
The Australian duo of Lisa Gerrard and Brendan Perry return with their first album since 1996's Spiritchaser.
The first English-language release since 2009's She Wolf for the Colombian singer features guest appearances from Magic!, Rihanna, and Blake Shelton.
Mike Mogis produced this second set from the Swedish act.

No, Jon Spencer hasn't left the blues trio, but they have officially shortened their name for their seventh release (their first for Sanctuary after a long stay at Matador). With all the money they saved by cutting out those extra two words, they were able to afford an all-star team of producers, including David Holmes, Alan Moulder, DJ Shadow, Dan The Automator and Steve Jordan.

The electronica duo of Andrew Weatherall and Keith Tenniswood return with 12 new tracks, featuring both vocals (from Weatherall) and live instrumentation (from Tenniswood) and departing significantly from the techno of past albums.
The third full-length from the Minneapolis band.
Kevin Barnes moved away from live band recording for the indie rock band's 15th full-length stdio release.
This is the third EP for the New York electronic rock duo of Sarah Barthel and Josh Carter.

The Detroit garage/hard rock band's remaining members of Bobby Hackney, Dannis Hackney, and Bobbie Duncan recorded songs written by the late David Hackney as well as new songs for its first new recordings since 1976.

recordauthor: Thee Silver Mt. Zion Memorial Orchestra & Tra-La-La Band
description: The fifth full-length album by the Canadian group features four songs and 12 instrumental introductions.
The third full-length release for the indie pop duo was produced by Wally Gagel.
The debut full-length release for the London-based post-punk quartet that includes Charlie Drinkwater, Alex Sprogis, Nic Smith, and Ed Kelland was self-produced.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Sacramento experimental hip-hop trio features contributions from Andrew Adamson and Tool's Justin Chancellor.
The latest full-length studio release for the country singer features guest appearances from Kacey Musgraves and Chris Stapleton.

The debut collaborative release from Stephanie Dosen and Cocteau Twins' Simon Raymonde was supported by Philip Selway and Ed O'Brien of Radiohead, Eric Pulido and McKenzie Smith of Midlake, Lanterns on the Lake's Paul Gregory, and Jonathan Wilson.
The second album for the Leeds trio was recorded in Seattle, Washington, with producer John Goodmanson.
This is the debut full-length release for solo electro-pop project of Caila Thompson-Hannant (formerly of Shapes & Sizes).
This is the second album for the Icelandic group which started as a solo project for Sindri Mar Sigfusson.

recordname: Man on the Moon, Vol. 2: The Legend of Mr. Rager
description: The rapper from Cleveland returns with the sequel to his debut album, featuring guest rappers Snoop Dogg and Cage.
The experimental San Francisco trio's third record marks their debut for Anticon.
The New York rapper's fifth album attempts to return to the sound of his similar-titled 1994 hit debut, 'Illmatic.' Here, DJ Premier, Large Professor, and Swizz Beatz provide the beats.
The fourth full-length studio release for California artist Banks features a guest appearance from Samoht.
The first full-length studio release in seven years for the Danish group is an Danish-language only album featuring the Belgian baroque collective, B.O.X. (Baroque Orchestration X).
The second full-length studio release for the Canadian R&B artist features a guest appearance from Drake.

Alice Cooper and Johnny Depp decided three years ago to form their own Hollywood Vampires and recruited Joe Perry and producer Bob Ezrin to record a tribute album to the original members with the profits going to MusiCares. Guest appearances include Perry Farrell, Dave Grohl, Brian Johnson, Robbie Krieger, the late Christopher Lee, Sir Paul McCartney, Slash, Zak Starkey, Joe Walsh, and Kip Winger.
The British rock quartet's third full-length album was produced by Pete Miles and is its first without Dan Brown, who left performing to manage the band.
Avey Tare, Geologist, and Panda Bear created shorter songs for the trio's 11th full-length release that features contributions from Colin Stetson and John Cale.
This is the debut album for the Swedish duo of Maria Linden and Fredrik Balck.
The second full-length album for the Israeli rock band was produced by Steve Albini.
The sophomore album for the British quintet was produced by Chris Goss.
The DJ/producer takes his jazzy, cinematic drum'n'bass beats to the videogame world, scoring the latest sequel in the Tom Clancy Splinter Cell franchise.
The Los Angeles indie rock band release their debut album.
Del the Funky Homosapien's latest album features his collaboration with the with New Jersey producers, Parallel Thought.
Recorded in a 19th-century church, the fifth album for the two sisters is the first without Michael Collins who took a hiatus from the band.
The latest release for the sludge band features both Steven McDonald and Jeff Pinkus of the Butthole Surfers on bass.

recordname: Too Young to Be in Love
description: Singer/hairdresser/bon vivant, Hunx, has made a name for himself as an out-and-proud, teen-from-Mars crooner from the band Gravy Train!!!! and now resurrects the upbeat post-rock sounds of the fifties and sixties with the first full-length Hunx & His Punx record.
The Massachusetts rock quintet rereleases its debut album on the Astralwerks label.
The Canadian singer releases her sophomore album produced by Dave Draves.
The London-based rock trio make their full-length debut with this disc, produced by Edwyn Collins.
The 'Basics' in the title of this double-disc set are the jazzy blues and soul sounds of the 1920s, 30s and 40s, which Aguilera tackles with the help of Linda Perry and DJ Premier.

Beck and Philip Glass worked together on this collection of remixes of the composers songs by such artists as Tyondai Braxton, Peter Broderick, Cornelius, Dan Deacon, Johan Johannsson, Memory Tapes, Pantha du Prince, and Amon Tobin.
The second album for the Washington, DC, rapper features guest appearances by Big Sean, Kid Cudi, Jeremih, Lloyd, Miguel, Meek Mill, and Rick Ross.
Ssss is the debut electronic release from Depeche Mode's Vince Clarke and Martin Gore. They last worked together on 1981's Speak & Spell, after which Clarke left to form Yazoo (Yaz in the US).
The increasingly prolific brother-sister duo of Matthew and Eleanor Friedberger (this time, sans grandmother) return with their fourth album.
The second full-length release for the Florida indie rock quartet was produced by Gil Norton.
Train disasters from late 19th and early 20th centuries are the focus of this concept album from the San Francisco-based art collective.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Canadian indie rock quartet was recorded in three weeks by Jeff McMurrich.
The fifth full-length release for the country singer features a duet with Little Big Town's Karen Fairchild.
The 15th studio release for the Los Angeles metal band features new guitarist Kiko Loureiro and Lamb Of God's Chris Adler on drums.
This 26-track set compiles works composed by the Magnetic Fields leader for three separate Chen Shi-Zheng operas.
James Ford and Jas Shaw's third studio album as Simian Mobile Disco is a mix of house and techno electronic music.
The second full-length release for the British grime artist features a guest appearance from Rolynne.
The Washington D.C band returns as a three piece with its latest album.
The second full-length release for Tom Krell was produced by Rodaidh McDonald.
The first release in seven years for the New Zealand artist Nick Harte was influenced by the 2011 Christchurch earthquake .
The hard-rock band's first album in eight years was produced by Brendan O'Brien.
The first album on his new label for the folk singer was co-produced with Paul Butler.
The addition of Zac Brown and Rory OConnor turns Scott Hansen's solo project into an ambient trio for its third full-length release.
The first full-length release since 2016's Walls for the Southern rock band was produced by Markus Dravs.
The third album for the British indie rock band was recorded over two sessions with producers Tim Goldsworthy, Bruno Ellingham, and Jag Jago.

The collaboration between Ghostface Killah and Sheek Louch features guest appearances by Cappadonna, Erykah Badu, as well as members of Wu-Tang (GZA, Inspectah Deck, Masta Killa, Method Man, Raekwon) and The Lox/D-Block (Styles P and Jadakiss).
The Leeds, England neo-soul singer makes her debut with this self-titled album, on which she also handles the instrumentation and songwriting duties.
After 15 years and six albums, the brothers Hartnoll are calling it quits with this final release. Lisa Gerrard (Dead Can Dance) guests on one track, with The Sparks collaborating on another.
The three Hanson brothers (now ranging in age from 19 to 24) return with their third album, a full seven years after first hitting the pop charts.

A musician since his early childhood, 20-year-old Texan Ben Kweller experienced some minor success with the band Radish in the late 1990s before embarking on a solo career highlighted by 'Sha Sha,' his debut full-length for Dave Matthews' label Ato.
This is the follow-up to 1999's 'Enema Of The State.' If you like them, then don't worry--they haven't grown up. If you don't like them, well... they haven't grown up.
The live versions of songs from 2007's Cross; 2011's Audio, Video, Disco; and 2016's Woman were recorded in the studio for this 15-track release.
Morgan Z's debut release is an instrumental album of music inspired by electronic film scores of the past.
The fourth full-length release for the Los Angeles-based Canadian singer-songwriter was co-mixed with Joe Santarpia.
The debut full-length release for the Canadian indie pop quartet founded by Sarah Cogan and Dylan Frankland was co-produced Frankland and Josh Korody of Beliefs.

The singer-songwriter and guitarist's self-titled album follows his collaborative effort with actress Scarlett Johansson and features famed Pixies frontman Frank Black as a producer of his straightforward pop rock.
The singer-songwriter turns to the blues for his 16th studio release that was written in five weeks while he toured Europe by himself.
The fourth album from the Denver indie-pop band led by Tammy Ealom is a sugary 12-song set.
The debut album for this indie electronica band from London, England.
Chicago's pop punk band returns with a collection of unplugged versions of favorite tracks.
The six-track album introduces Emmanuel Nicolaidis, who joins the Baltimore, Maryland-based trio as its new drummer.

This unusual set from the Pixies frontman includes a disc of demo solo recordings dating from 1987, and a second disc of new studio recordings of an assortment of Pixies songs by Black with collaborators such as Pere Ubu and Two Pale Boys.
This is the debut full-length release for the London-based producer/videographer who has who has collaborated with likes of Björk, Arca and FKA twigs.
This is the fifth studio release for the New York-based sister duo of Allison and Catherine Pierce.
This is the third and final part of the psychedelic concept trilogy from the British artist who previously was a member of The Auteurs, Baader Meinhof, Black Box Recorder, and The Servants.

recordname: Some Things Never Stay the Same
description: The second release of 1970s rock-inspired music from the collaboration between Heidecker & Wood includes guest appearances from Mike Bloom, Jason Boesel, Mike Green, Eric Johnson of The Shins, Aimee Mann, and Rilo Kileys Pierre de Reeder.
The debut album for the electronic duo of Tim Felton and Billy Bainbridge.

recordname: From the Corner to the Block
description: The sixth CD from the New Orleans funk/jazz outfit includes guests Lyrics Born, The Coup's Boots Riley, Digable Planets' Ladybug Mecca, Juvenile, Jurassic 5's Chali 2na, Mr. Lif, and Gift of Gab from Blackalicious.
A best-of collection from the band led by singer Shirley Manson.
This is the British singer-songwriter's first album in three years, and it finds him working with an outside producer (Marius De Vries) for the first time.
The debut solo full-length release for the former One Direction singer features production from Levi Lennox and Malay.
The 12 live tracks were recorded from the alternative rock band's two reunion concerts in California and New York in 2015.

More than 35 years after the Scottish punk band released its debut album Can't Stand the Rezillos in 1978 (and then split up four months later), the sophomore release features three of the original members, who reformed in 2001.

Executive produced by Pharrell Williams, the ninth studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from such artists as Iggy Azalea, Chris Brown, Skylar Grey, Jeezy, Victoria Monet, Pharrell, The-Dream, Trae tha Truth, Usher, Watch The Duck, and Young Thug.
The debut full-length studio release for the San Francisco Bay Area rapper features guest appearances from Jay Ant, August Alsina, Eric Bellinger, Iamsu!, Kool John, and Shady Bo.
This is the debut for the garage rock duo from Mississippi and was produced by Ross Robinson.
The ex-Jayhawks team up again as a duo on their first album together in over ten years.

Folds' second solo outing actually finds him working once again in trio format, now joined by drummer Lindsay Jamieson (Departure Lounge) and bassist Jared Reynolds (who, like Folds, contributed to the recent William Shatner album).

recordname: It's What I'm Thinking, Pt. 1: Photographing Snowflakes
description: Damon Gough's latest release is the first of a planned trilogy of albums.
