The latest experimental ambient release from the producer features sounds formed from human voices, piano, bass, drums, steel and electric guitars.
The fourth full-length release for the Aaron Maine project was co-produced by Jake Portrait and features contributions from Dev Hynes, Peter Maine, Mitski, and Zsela.
Pete Seeger guests on DiFrancho's cover of his song Which Side Are You On? on her 16th studio album.
This debut full-length for the British five-piece offers ten tracks of shoegaze- and folk-influenced indie rock. (We also detect a little Snow Patrol and Broken Social Scene in there.)
This is the debut full-length release from the project formed by TV on the Radio frontman Tunde Adebimpe, Adam Drucker (Doseone), and Mike Patton.
The band's first album in more than 14 years was produced with Nick Raskulinecz and features new lead singer William DuVall (original singer Layne Staley died in 2002).
This debut LP from the guitar/drums duo of Mike Conte and Adam Bennati is defintely harder and heavier than your typical Matador release.
The dancehall artist returns with a more genre-consistent (and yes, back to basics) album, with a lone Timbaland-produced crossover track, "All Girls Party."
The London-based duo of Tom Findlay and Andy Cato return with their fourth LP, named after one of their club nights.
RZA and company return to their hardcore roots for this, Wu-Tang's fourth album together.
The Liverpool quartet known for wearing surgical masks releases its fifth studio album.
The latest solo release for the San Francisco singer-songwriter features a guest appearance on drums from Steve Shelley and was primarily recorded in two San Francisco hotels.

recordname: Excerpts From The Diary Of Todd Zilla [EP]
description: This seven-track mini-album is intended to hold fans over until the Modesto, California band return with their next LP in early 2006.
The first new studio release in 12 years for the British post-punk band features contributions from Gabe Gurnsey, Mike Joyce, Eric Random, and Sink Ya Teeth (Maria Uzor and Gemma Cullingford).
Produced by Will Yip, the fifth full-length release for the Pennsylvania rock band shrunken down from a five-piece into a duo that consists of Ben Walsh and Brianna Collins.
The fifth album for the Swedish garage rock band was self-produced.
The debut solo release for the guitarist for Mercy Arms was produced by Kim Moyes.
The self-titled album is the third for the San Francisco duo.
Credited to Ryan Adams & The Cardinals, double album 'Cold Roses' is the first of three planned 2005 releases for the prolific singer-songwriter. Tom Schick produced.
The singer-songwriter co-produced her eighth album with veteran Hal Willner. The Jayhawks' Gary Louris is among the musicians lending a hand.
Ben Harper's latest album is the first album to be credited with the Relentless7.

On their second album, School of Seven Bells cast themselves as an update of a specific kind of misfit band. Alpinisms reconstituted late-â80/early-â90s shoegaze. Disconnect from Desire, however, updates the sound of a kind of band that would have opened for Peter Gabriel and Eurythmics, or headlined over Revolver, rather than tour with the likes of Lush, Ride, and Pale Saints. Here, a focused songcraft and central placement of the Deheza twinsâ alluring vocals -- which tend to be lower and more earthly than they were on the debut -- disallow School of Seven Bells from being squarely shoegaze. At the same time, the band is too left of center, too odd, to be considered anywhere near the mainstream. Their cleaner, less wispy, more muscular sound, combined with more traditional songwriting, is not that radical a change. Itâs closer to a slight shift that registers after a couple spins, once it becomes apparent that deeply emotive and relatively sparse songs like âI L U,â âJoviann,â and âThe Waitâ would have made excellent tracks buried throughout Sireâs Just Say series. They have shoegaze lyric-generator staples like wind, waves, ocean, storms, and even talk of âslipping away.â And yet, the words are not merely functional, written solely for the sake of complementing the sound as an additional instrument. Theyâre either poetically vague or vaguely poetic -- stuff like âLet me will the dial to turn and gild the air with silver pearls of rainâ and âWhenâs the wait a cradle in which youâre lulled from time to time, soundly spun into an insensate lie.â The thicker, more driving songs resemble a polished, warm Curve, whipping up squalls of noise over robust played-and-programmed rhythms that soar more often than batter. No matter the amount of layering, not a single element is obscured. This vivid directness suits them very well. ~ Andy Kellman
The third full-length release for Alexis Georgopoulos is more pop than his previous two synth-based albums.

The debut studio release for the Swedish EDM DJ/producer Tim Bergling as Avicii includes guest appearances from such artists as Aloe Blacc, Mike Einziger of Incubus, Adam Lambert, Audra Mae, Nile Rodgers, and Dan Tyminski of Union Station.
The second release for the British indie pop band was produced by Bernard Butler.
The 25-track (with nine tracks under a minute long) release for the alternative rock band from Brooklyn was produced by Pat Dillett.
The debut album for the British indie rock band was produced by Franz Ferdinand's Alex Kapranos.
The follow-up album to its Mercury Prize-nominated debut was produced by Owen Morris.
This self-titled disc finds Adam Pierce joined by guests Kristin Anna Valtysdottir (Mum) and Laetitia Sadier (Stereolab).
This is the second album for the Swedish garage rockers.
Michael Andrews (composer of the score for 'Donnie Darko') produced this debut disc for the Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter, who is the daughter of Little Feat's Lowell George.
The debut full-length release from Canadian duo of Alexander Cowan and Raphaelle Standell-Preston was written separately and recorded over two years.
This is the debut album for the rock group led by John Petkovic, which includes Dinosaur Jr.'s J. Mascis, Cobra Verde's Tim Parnin, and Witch's Dave Sweetapple as members.
The fourth full-length release for the Canadian indie rock trio band features guest appearances from Emma Baxter, Caroline Desilets, Katie Moore, and Adéle Trottier-Rivard.
Amon Tobin and Joe "Doubleclick" Chapman join together to release their debut album together featuring Sway, Ms. Jade, and Ce'Cile as guests.
The fifth album for the pop artist features tracks produced by Max Martin and Butch Walker.
The third full-length album for the rock band from San Diego was produced by Chris Coady and recorded in a converted church in Woodstock, New York.

recordname: Tha Funk Capital Of The World
description: The legendary Rock and Roll Hall of Fame member, funk bassist, singer, and songwriter returns with his first new album in five years.
Marc Nugyen Tan returns with a second album of 80s-influenced electronica.

recordname: A Walk With Love and Death
description: The second disc from the double album from the rock band includes the soundtrack to the Jesse Neiminen short film of the same name.
The second full-length release for the Danish electro pop artist features guest appearances from Charli XCX, Diplo, Empress Of, Two Feet, and What So Not.
The third full-length release from Japanese kawaii metal band is its first without Yuimetal, who left the band in October 2018 to pursue a solo career.
The Portland, Oregon indie band led by Justin Ringle releases its third album.
The second full-length release for the Scottish indie rock trio was self-produced.
The solo debut release for Chairlift's Caroline Polachek was recorded on her laptop in various locations while on tour.
This is the debut full-length release for the indie pop rock band from Atlanta, Georgia.
Be Your Own Pet's Jemina Pearl releases her debut solo album.

Grand in scope, 'Lost Riots' is the debut disc for the UK band who are often described as falling somewhere between Coldplay and Godspeed You Black Emperor (wherever that might be). The band's guitarist, Jimmi Lawrence, took his own life shortly after the album was recorded.
The third full-length studio release for the French electronic duo features guest appeances from Johnny Blake, Morgan Phalen of Diamond Nights, Romuald, and M. Yaman.
The 15th full-length studio release for the psychedelic rock band led by Mark Coyne was produced with Dave Fridmann.
The debut album for the Brooklyn indie rock quintet was co-produced by Matt Boynton.
Nine Inch Nails releases a mostly instrumental album, with some tracks falling under the Creative Commons License instead of being copyrighted.
The second album for the band led by Martin Cohen was recorded at his house.
The Smiths' guitarist wrote and produced his debut solo release.
The second full-length release for the Texas dream pop was recorded at night in Mallorca.
The fourth full-length release for the Canadian indie rock quartet was produced by Doug Boehm and the band's lead singer, David Monks.
The first release in 17 years for the Swedish punk band features production from Michael Ilbert, Nick Launay, and Shellback.
Produced by lead singer Jack Steadman, the fourth release for the indie band was written while traveling in Asia and Europe.
The eighth full-length release for the rock band led by Tim Kasher sees the return of drummer Clint Schnase and was co-produced by Mike Mogis.
The second album for the British singer-songwriter was produced by ex-Suede guitarist Bernard Butler.
The latest, two-disc album from one of Damon Albarn's bands contains remixes and demos.

recordname: Good Apollo, I'm Burning Star IV, Volume Two: No World For Tomorrow
description: The album features Taylor Hawkins on drums after Josh Eppard left the band.

Ethan Johns produced the singer-songwriter's third and final release of 2005, which unlike its predecessors is a stripped-down solo affair consisting of nine lengthy story-songs each representing a year of Adams' life during his twenties.

Slapped with the label "the female Beastie Boys" after their 2003 debut, the New York all-girl rap outfit make their major-label debut with 'All City,' which includes collaborations with Har Mar Superstar, ?uestlove and DJ Muggs.
The latest LP from Steven Tyler & co. includes just one original ("The Grind") with the remainder of the tracks occupied by covers of blues standards.

The veteran singer-songwriter was forced by Island to re-record the songs for this eighth album three times, before the label finally approved a release. This final version was recorded with producer John Shanks (Alanis Morissette) and marks the first of her albums to include songs not written by Etheridge.

Only the band's fourth studio recording in their 10+ year existence, 'Hard Candy' offers up 13 new tracks, including the single "American Girls" and "Butterfly Reverse," which was cowritten by Ryan Adams. Steve Lillywhite produces.
The fourth album from the Milwaukee emo band is their first with veteran producer Stephen Street, who gives the album a more expansive sound.
This is the first new album in three years for the folk-rock duo of Emily Saliers and Amy Ray.
The follow-up to 'Return of Saturn' finds Gwen Stefani & co. working with a variety of producers (Sly and Robbie, Ric Ocasek, William Orbit) in a variety of styles.
Lenny Kravitz's sixth album features a mix of retro rock and mid-tempo ballads.
The Los Angeles indie band returns with its second album for Vapor Records, following 1997's 'Acetone.'
The second LP from former Stone Roses frontman Ian Brown.
The hardcore, often political rockers return with their 14th studio album.
The Canadian post-hardcore band releases its fifth studio album.

The New Zealand pop star's third studio album finds her working again with producer Jack Antonoff. For environmental reasons, she has opted against a physical CD release in favor of a digital download.
Damon Albarn produced and wrote the music for the adaptation of a 16th Chinese book into a stage opera.
The hip-hop producer's latest album includes guests such as Redman and Raekwon.

recordname: Fast Cars, Danger, Fire And Knives [EP]
description: This seven-song EP includes production work from Rob Sonic and Blockhead. El-P also appears.
The second full-length release British punk band features guest appearances from Aimee Interrupter and Rancid's Tim Armstrong (who also produced the album).

Hawaiian native and unofficial kingpin of beachside pop rock, Jack Johnson's newest delivery of breezily spun folk songs capture the mellow mood of Johnson's previous albums, complete with a sunny surf vibe.

recordauthor: The Pains of Being Pure at Heart
description: The third full-length release for the Brooklyn indie pop band led by Kip Berman was produced by Andy Savours.

recordname: In the Belly of the Brazen Bull
description: Dave Fridmann and Steve Albini helped produce the fifth studio album for the British indie rock band that returns as a trio after Johnny Marr left to pursue his own solo work.
The latest release for the sludge metal band led by Buzz Osborne features the return of original drummer Mike Dillard, with Dale Crover taking over bass duties.

The 17th studio release for the rock singer features both originals as well as four covers of songs including Steve Earles The Devils Right Hand," and Kasey Chambers and Shane Nicholsons Adam & Eve.
Anyone disappointed by the last Daft Punk album might enjoy this funky, largely instrumental second album for the New York duo.
The sophomore solo album for the Mojave 3 and Slowdive member.
Harper's first album in three years is split into a disc of uptempo rockers and a second disc of acoustic ballads.
The debut full-length solo release for the Melvins' Buzz Osborne is an acoustic 17-track album.

recordname: Rufus Does Judy At Carnegie Hall
description: The live album of Rufus Wainwright's recreation of Judy Garland's 1961 concert at Carnegie Hall.
John McEntire produced this third album for the Chicago indie rockers led by Jim Elkington.
The eighth full-length studio release for the Scottish rock band was recorded in Los Angeles and Scotland with producer Dave Eringa.
The debut full-length release for the London-based duo of Andy Clutterbuck and James Hatch features a guest appearance from Izzy Bizu.
The second full-length solo release for the Bon Iver drummer includes a guest appearance from Justin Vernon.
The Swedish producer, who has worked with Lykke Li and Robyn, releases his debut album.
The debut from the Detroit rapper features executive producers Kanye West and No I.D.
The seventh full-length studio release for the San Diego rock band led by Nathan Williams was produced by Dave Sitek.
Petra Haden returns with a follow-up to her 2005 a capella album of The Who Sell Out with an album of a capella movie themes.

The singer-songwriter-pianist's ninth studio album is political, confrontational, and lengthy (at over 20 tracks)--and also falls under the dreaded "concept album" category, as its songs come from the viewpoints of five different characters.
The 17th full-length studio release for the synthpop duo was said to be inspired by the current political climate in the UK and US.
The first album for the rock band featuring Black Francis and his wife Violet Clark.
The second full-length studio release for the California singer-songwriter was produced by Garret "Jacknife" Lee.
This is the second solo outing for the former Archers Of Loaf and Crooked Fingers frontman.

The latest release for the singer-songwriter credited under the names Yusuf/Cat Stevens features re-recordings of the songs from his 1970 album Tea For The Tillerman with new interpretations and arrangements.
The fourth full-length release for indie rock artist Tim Showalter was produced by Nicolas Vernhes.
The second full-length release for the California hip-hop producer features influences from R&B, drum 'n' bass, and ambient music.
The second full-length release for the British duo of Sam Ricketts and Tom Clarke was produced by Andy Savours.
The second full-length release for the Mike Paradinas project features vocals from Vezelay (Matthieu Le Berre).
This is the first release in eight years for French electronic artist, Jackson Fourgeaud.
The British indie rock band led by Guy Chadwick releases its second album since returning in 2005.
The fourth album for the Canadian pop-rock band was written while singer Nicholas Thorburn was recovering from a breakup in Los Angeles.
The psychedelic pop duo releases its sophomore album.
The New York-based electro pop group made up of two friends, Alex Frankel and Nick Millhiser, release their debut album of dancefloor, disco jams.
The second album for the British group was produced by Mark Ronson.
The British singer sticks to the successful formula established on her 1999 debut "No Angel" for this sophomore effort.
This is the sophomore release for the Boston-based alt-rockers.
Another eclectic offering from Shirley Manson and Garbage, their third album and first since 1998.
The long-awaited follow-up to the band's 1995 eponymous debut features a guest contribution from The Fall's Mark E. Smith and a cover of Trio's 'Da Da Da.'

recordname: Mysterious Phonk: The Chronicles of Spaceghostpurrp
description: The debut full-length studio album for the Miami-based producer/rapper who also worked with A$AP Rocky and Wiz Khalifa, contains new material and re-recorded tracks from his mixtapes.
The fourth studio album for the ex-Radish member is said to have some country elements.
This is the second release for the London-based sister duo of Colette and Hannah Thurlow.
The second studio album for the British rock trio was produced by Ian Davenport.
The fifth full-length release for the London-based band led by Finn Andrews was co-produced by El-P and Adam "Atom" Greenspan.
The eighth full-length release for the New York City-based dance-punk band features a guest appearance from Meah Pace.
The fourth album for the group from New York features such guests as Estelle, Busta Rhymes, The-Dream, and Lil Wayne.
The sixth album for the jazz artist was produced by Craig Street and features Meshell Ndegeocello, Marc Ribot, and Allen Toussaint.
The debut album for the group from Phildelphia and New York is rereleased by Matador after being self-released in August.

Covers are nothing new for the Roxy Music frontman, but 'Dylanesque' marks the first time Ferry has dedicated an entire album to the work of a single artist. (That would be Bob Dylan, in case you didn't notice the title.)
The fourth full-length release for George Lewis Jr. as Twin Shadow features guest appearances from Haim and Rainsford.
The latest release from the Brooklyn-based sister duo is said to be inspired by a vision of a future where art and extreme sports come together.

The second collaboration with Edie Brickell for the actor/musician was produced by Peter Asher and features contributions from such artists as Cobra Starship's Victoria Asher, Béla Fleck, Mike Einziger of Incubus, Leland Sklar, the Steep Canyon Rangers, and Geoff Zanelli.
The third full-length release for the British rock trio was produced by Steve Albini.
The fourth full-length release for the London-based Australian indie rock band was produced by Catherine J. Marks and Alan Moulder.

Better known for his work as half of the folk-rock duo with his sister Julia, Angus Stone releases his first solo album under his real name (his 2009 solo album was released under the name, Lady of the Sunshine).
Brendan Lynch produced the British indie rock band's sophomore album.
The Brooklyn, New York-via-Memphis rock group releases its full-length debut produced by Chris Coady.
The 10th solo album for the Red Hot Chili Peppers guitarist features Flea and Johnny Marr as guest artists.
Angela McCluskey and Deborah Anderson lend their voices to the French chill-out trio's sophomore record.
The first release in six years for the ex-Battles member was based on his 2013 multimedia installation at the New York's Guggenheim Museum.
The fourth studio release for the indie rock band was produced by Glyn Johns.
The debut album for the New Hampshire rock band was produced by Rob Schnapf.

recordauthor: ...And You Will Know Us by the Trail of Dead
description: King Crimson's Pat Mastelotto and The Dresden Dolls' Amanda Palmer guest on the Texas band's follow-up to 'Worlds Apart.'
This is the 31st studio release for the British pot-punk band led by Mark E. Smith.

Co-[produced with Mike Einzeger of Incubus, the solo debut for Evan Ingersoll as Chuck Inglish features guest appearances from such artists as Action Bronson, Ab-Soul, Chance The Rapper, Chromeo, Mac Miller, and Polyester The Saint.
The Oscar-winning actress and Grammy-winning singer Jennifer Hudson returns with her sophomore studio album.
The English indie-rock band releases its debut full-length album on 4AD.
The third full-length solo release for the Irish singer-songwriter was recorded in France and produced by Frames guitarist David Odlum.

The latest solo recording from former Hüsker Dü and Sugar leader Mould echoes back to those bands as well as the various stages of his solo career. His backing band includes Sugar's David Barbe and Fugazi's Brendan Canty.

recordname: Dying To Say This To You
description: This is the second album for the Swedish five-piece.
The fifth full-length studio release from the British alternative rock band is its first in seven years and was produced with David Kosten.
The third full-length release for the British rock duo of Eoin and Rory Loveless was produced by Ross Orton.
The third full-length release for the Welsh folk rock band includes a disc featuring non-Welsh language interpretations of its songs by such artists as Peter Gabriel, Rhys Ifans, and Maxine Peake.
The debut full-length release for the Oakland-based experimental psychedelic pop band produced by Eli Crews is reissued with two additional tracks.
The second full-length release for Dustin Payseur as Beach Fossils was produced by Ben Greenberg.

Famous for her soaring vocals, Sia's new release brings brilliance to the modern pop track, with catchy grooves, soulful song arrangements, and a few synth-heavy dance beats that are playful and party friendly.
The fourth full-length studio release for the Swedish rapper features a guest appearance from Ariel Pink.
The third full-length release for the Pennsylvania singer-songwriter was produced with Randall Dunn.
This is the second full-length release for the Detroit indie rock band.
Merle Haggard guests on the country star's follow-up to 'Shock'n Y'all.'

What happens when you team Death Cab For Cutie's Ben Gibbard with a cutting-edge electronica artist? Sure, you have the Postal Service, but you also have this new full-length from Arne Van Petegem's Styrofoam, which features multiple contributions not only from Gibbard, but also from Valerie Trebeljahr (Lali Puna), Andrew Kenny (American Analog Set), Markus Acher (The Notwist) and rapper Alias.
The debut album for the supergroup consisting of Man Man's Ryan Kattner, Islands' Nicholas Thorburn, and the Shins' Joe Plummer is influenced by doo-wop music.
The first English-language release in six years for the Canadian pop singer features contributions from David Guetta, Greg Kurstin, LP, Sia, Sam Smith, and Björn Yttling.
The singer-songwriter's fourth full-length studio release was produced by Mark Endert, John O'Mahony, and Kurt Uenala.
One-half of the indie duo Pomplamoose, Nataly Dawn releases her debut autobiographical solo release that was produced by her Pomplamoose partner Jack Conte and funded by Kickstarter donations.

recordname: You Can't Teach An Old Dog New Tricks
description: This is the first album from the Blues singer from California on Third Man Records, Jack White's label.

The stripped-down 'The Will To Death' is not just the second solo disc in 2004 for the Red Hot Chili Peppers guitarist, but marks the first of a whopping six planned albums for Record Collection this year.

A quick follow-up by Spiritualized standards, 'Amazing Grace' finds Jason Pierce with a new record label (his own Spaceman Records imprint) and a more immediate, less orchestral sound than on 2001's 'Let It Come Down.'

Bowie's first studio album in three years (and first for his new label ISO Records, distributed by Columbia) finds the older white duke working with producer Tony Visconti for the first time since 1980's 'Scary Monsters.' Pete Townsend and Dave Grohl guest on guitar on a track apiece.

This is the third album from the New York-based trio, led by French singer Dominique Durand and it finds the group adding a bit of trip-hop into the mix. The album includes a cover of the Blow Monekys' "Digging Your Scene."
The fifth full-length studio release for the San Francisco indie rock duo of Adam Stephens and Tyson Vogel was produced by Karl Derfler.
The fifth full-length release for the Seattle rock band was produced by Jason Lytle and features guest appearances from Sera Cahoone, Jenn Champion, and Dinosaur Jr.'s J. Mascis.
Seth Bogart returns as Hunx but without his backing band for his solo album produced by Ivan Julian.
The debut solo release for the former One Direction band member was produced with Jeff Bhasker.

recordauthor: MV & EE With The Golden Road
description: This is the first release on DiCristina Stair for Matt "MV" Valentine and Erika "EE" Elder.
The fourth full-length studio release for the rock supergroup is its first album of new material in 14 years.
The fourth full-length studio release for the French electronic producer features guest appearances from Mark Kerr, Miss Kittin, and David Shaw And The Beat.
This is the third release from the Swedish electro-pop duo of Johan Agebjörn and Sally Shapiro.
The second album for the New York-based musical group was produced with Patrick Pulsinger.
The first album of a planned trilogy from the Oregon-born singer/songwriter.
Scott Weiland and company return with their second album.
After making an explosive debut appearing on other artist's songs, rapper Nicki Minaj finally releases her debut of electro-infused, bold, and hook-heavy hip-hop.
This is the third album for the indie folk-rock trio from Philadelphia.
German producer Ulrich Schnauss worked with fellow Engineers' bassist Mark Peters on this minimalist electronic album.

The seventh full-length release for the British indie rock band began as four songs recorded with producer Steve Albini in 2011 and now includes six songs they created over three days five years later.
This is the debut album for the neo-grunge outfit based in Manchester, England.

The fourth full-length studio album for the rapper from Rhode Island features songs co-written with such artists as Tim Fite, Death Cab For Cuties Chris Walla, Califones Tim Rutili, Grandaddys Jason Lytle, and Sparklehorses Mark Linkous.
This is the third full-length album for the Brooklyn-based Kentucky-born singer-songwriter.
The debut full-length release for the collaboration between singer-songwriter Joseph Arthur and R.E.M. guitarist Peter Buck was written while in Mexico.
The debut full-length release for the New Jersey rapper who first gained fame with his "Trap Queen" single features guest appearances from M80, Monty, and Remy Boyz.
The debut full-length album for the Brooklyn quintet.

The latest full-length release for the Compton rapper features guest appearances from 21 Savage, Fivio Foreign, Jamie Foxx, Future, Gunna, Alex Isley, Kodak Black, Lil Baby, Takeoff, and Ty Dolla $ign,
The fourth full-length release for the Baltimore noise rock band features some songs from Lifer's recording sessions.
Each of the four tracks on the sixth release for the Australian psychedelic pop band are exactly 10:10 minutes long.
The second full-length studio release for the Danish quartet features a guest appearance from Killer Mike.
This Wu-Tang Clan member's latest album features John Legend, Fabolous, Raheem DeVaughn, Lloyd, and Estelle as guest singers.
This is the first of two releases from an improvised collaboration between pop and jazz drummer Reid and folktronica artist Hebden (Four Tet, Fridge).
The second album for the husband-and-wife duo was produced by The Black Keys' Patrick Carney.
The Dublin-based quartet debuts with a record filled with echoes of California circa the 1960s and 70s (think Brian Wilson) rather than Ireland.
The electronic trio consisting of dubstep regulars Skream, Benga, and Artwork releases its first album together.
The fifth full-length release for the Atlanta punk trio was produced by Nic Jodoin.
Produced with Mike Stevens, the covers album from the former Eurythmics singer includes such classics as "Summertime," Georgia on My Mind and "I Put a Spell on You."
The fifth album for the Seattle, Washington-based band was produced by Mark Nevers, Alex McManus, and Eric Bachmann.
'Days' is the first album in over a dozen years for the reunited London-based alt-rockers, and is their first to include both original guitarists (Guy Chadwick and Terry Bickers) since 1989.
The 12th full-length release for the singer-songwriter was influenced by 1980s pop/rock and was self-produced.
The third album for the Colorado-based artist Kamtin Mohager is heavily influenced by 1980's dance music.
This is the debut solo album for the lead singer of Cursive and The Good Life.
The Brooklyn-based band formed in Colorado releases its debut album.
The debut full-length release of Canadian singer-songwriter Linnea Siggelkow was produced by Jake Aron.
The German duo releases its third album, produced by Arno Meriziger and Walter Krammermeier.
The electro-funk duo returns with its third album of new wave-inspired songs and crooning synthesizer-heavy jams.
This is a collection of B-sides and rare songs from 1995 to 2007.
The fourth album (and second released domestically) for the classic rock-influenced Swedish sextet is the first in a planned series.

recordname: One Way Ticket To Hell... And Back
description: The British band's second album was produced by Roy Thomas Baker (Queen).

N.E.R.D., the rock-oriented trio of Pharrell Williams and Chad Hugo (who also make up the in-demand hip-hop production team The Neptunes) and Shay, return with a highly-anticipated second album. Unlike their previous effort, 'Fly' finds Chad & Pharrell handling the instrumentation themselves.
This is the debut solo release from the former Belle and Sebastian / Gentle Waves vocalist and cellist.
'North' is a song cycle of piano-based ballads dealing with the ups and downs romance--both the ending of one releationship and the subsequent beginning of a new love.
Backed by the London Symphony Orchestra, Joni Mitchell revisits songs from throughout her 35-year career on this two-disc set.
The follow-up to 2000's 'Growing Up Clean in America' EP is a full-length album with 15 new tracks.
Gang Gang Dance's Brian DeGraw releases his debut solo release featuring guest vocalists Douglas Armour, Gang Gang Dance's Lizzi Bougatsos, CSS' Lovefoxxx, and Hot Chip's Alexis Taylor.

recordname: Way to Blue: The Songs of Nick Drake
description: The live covers of Nick Drake's songs performed by such artists as Vashti Bunyan, Green Gartside of Scritti Politti, Lisa Hannigan, Robyn Hitchcock, and Teddy Thompson were collected by producer Joe Boyd.
This is the second full-length release for the Alexander Brettin psychedelic pop project.
On their second album, the three-piece from London--including former Verve guitarist Erland Cooper--continue to create musical poetry with atmospheric soundscapes.
The fourth album for the metal band was produced with Dave Fortman.
This is the fourth studio release for New York-based electronic producer Drew Lustman as FaltyDL.
Scott Herren's quick follow-up to 'Surrounded By Silence' includes two collaborations (with Four Tet and TV On The Radio's Tunde Adebimpe) originally intended for that disc.
Fifteen years after he left the British metal act, singer Rob Halford returns for this unlikely reunion album.
Anohni, Greentea Peng, Kelsey Lu, Robyn, Sia, Seinabo Sey, Sudan Archives, Tyson, and Jamila Woods are some of the artists who create their own versions of Neneh Cherry's songs.
The collaboration between Dean Wareham and Cheval Sombre features covers of Western-themed songs recorded with producer Jason Quever.
The second release for the Canadian singer is described as the second half of his debut album--the first half being the November 2009 release "My World."
This is the first release in five years for the Washington D.C. punk/reggae rock band.

recordname: Days of the Bagnold Summer OST
description: The soundtrack for Simon Bird's coming-of-age comedy from the Scottish indie rock band includes 11 new songs as well as two previously released tracks.
This is the debut album for the alternative rock band who met in high school and now are based in Athens, Georgia.
The debut album for the Canadian trio who were members of the band P:ano.
The debut full-length release for the collaboration between LA Priest/Late Of The Pier's Sam Eastgate and Connan Mockasin was written and recorded over a period of five years.
The Aussie trio fuses punk rock with electronic and hip hop sampling on their second release, featuring collaborations with Diplo and Spankrock.
Ratatat's LP4 includes some tracks from the recording sessions from the duo's 2008 release LP3.
The fifth full-length release for the Brooklyn noise rock band led by Oliver Ackerman is its first with drummer Lia Simone Braswell.
The debut full-length release for the Los Angles post-punk trio of Sean Solomon, Pascal Stevenson, and Andrew MacKelvie was recorded by Alex Newport.
The third full-length release for the singer-songwriter features contributions from such artists as Casey Foubert, Gordi, and Rob Moose of yMusic.
The 11th full-length release from the Senegalese singer-songwriter was produced by Johan Hugo.
The debut full-length solo release for the Miami rapper features guest appearances from Curren$y, Masspike Miles, Rick Ross, PJK, Triple C's, and YG.
The fifth full-length studio release for the Phoenix-based folk-punk band was produced with John Congleton.
This is the fourth album for the British jazz-rock band.
The debut album for the New York group started by Daniel Collas and Sean Marquand.
The sophomore album for the duo features such guests as Swan and Talib Kweli.
Dan the Automator co-produced this sophomore set for the English rockers led by Barrie Cadogan.
The typically quirky Manchester, England trio led by John Bramwell returns with an atypical third album.
The UK synth-pop veterans release their fifth full-length album.
The singer-songwriter based in Los Angeles and Paris, France, releases his latest full-length album.
The fourth full-length studio release for rapper Post Malone features guest appearances from Doja Cat, Fleet Foxes, Gunna, Roddy Ricch, The Kid Laroi, and The Weeknd.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn-based trio was produced by Aaron Dessner of The National.
The band from the Everett, Washington area releases its third album with new label, Tomlab.
The debut full-length release for the artist best known for his producing work on FKA Twigs' M3LL155X and Beyoncé's self-titled albums, features a guest appearance from Angel Deradoorian.

Each song on the eighth full-length release for the rock band led by Dave Grohl was recorded in a different city: Chicago, Austin, Nashville, Los Angeles, Seattle, New Orleans, Washington, D.C., and New York, which is documented in the HBO TV series of the same name.
The System of a Down singer's solo debut album features fellow bandmate John Dolmayan on drums, along with players from Primus and opera singer Ani Maldjian.
The fourth solo release for Rhye's Mike Milosh was co-produced with his wife, actress Alexa Nikolas.
Pete Doherty tries to get out of the tabloids and into critic's hearts with his latest album.
This is the fourth solo album for the former Waxwing member.
The third album for the New York quintet was produced with Alex Newport.

The eighth full-length studio release for the French electronic project of Anthony Gonzalez is a sequel to 2007's Digital Shades Vol. 1 and was inspired by 1980s sci-fi and fantasy movies as well as video game soundtracks.
The second release for Chicago-based production duo of Mike Perry and Austin Kjeultes features guest appearances from Poliça's Channy Leaneagh, Mahaut Mondino, Haleek Maul, and Shy Girls.
This the Brazilian producer's third full-length release of techno electronic music.
The 90s power-pop band releases a new album.
The fifth full-length release for the indie rock duo was produced by guitarist Jamie Hince and John O'Mahoney.
Doug Boehm returns as producer for this ten-track set.
The latest release for the rock band led by Will Sheff, who produced the album with Shawn Everett, was recorded with Benjamin Lazar Davis, Will Graefe, Sarah Pedinotti, and Cully Symington.

This is the debut full-length release for the punk band formed by Pharmakon's Margaret Chardiet, Anasazi's Keegan Dakkar, Walker Behl and Eugene Terry of Crazy Spirit and Hank Wood & the Hammerheads's Logan Montana.
This is the second full-length studio release for the New York neo-disco/funk band founded by producers Eugene Cho and Dan Balis.
This is the second release from the collaboration between Matthew Cooper and Mark T. Smith.
The second album for the British trio sees the band expanding its indie dance sound.
The third album for the Portland, Oregon, indie rock band was partially recorded in an isolated cabin on the Oregon coast before being mixed by Scott Colburn and Julian Martlew.
The multi-award-winning country singer-songwriter releases his latest album, which includes a duet with Lee Ann Womack on the cover of Vern Gosdin's "Til The End."
Signed to a major-label deal after just one single, New York punk foursome The Star Spangles make their full-length debut with Bazooka!!!
The Seattle-based experimental space-rock outfit returns with their sophomore LP, following their 2001 debut 'Be Gentle With the Warm Turtle.'
Filter's third LP finds the band moving in a less industrial/electronic direction.
'C'mon' is the third full-length release for the experimental Chicago-based instrumental quartet.
Brooklyn-based rapper returns with his fourth album of raw emotion and dark, heavy beats.
The first release in five years for the Los Angeles psychedelic rock band led by Bobby Hecksher includes a new lineup with J.C. Rees, Earl V. Miller, Chris Di Pino, and George Serrano.
The second full-length studio release for the British rapper features guest appearances from such artists as 2 Chainz, Big Sean, Dizzee Rascal, Labrinth, Laura Mvula, and Emeli Sandé.
The debut release for the New Zealand singer is a 1950s-inspired rock album with some hip-hop and dance music influences.
The third album for the Canadian folk singer was produced by Colin Stewart.
The second full-length release for the British rock quintet was produced with Charles Reeve and Joshua Third of The Horrors.
The indie pop band from Montreal releases its first album on the Dead Oceans label.
Produced by Markus Dravs, the debut album for the folk rock quartet went platinum in the UK.
The 10th full-length studio release for the Philadelphia indie band was produced by Gus Seyffert.

The third full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was inspired by her tour of Latin America and features contributions from Chris Boot, Ben Daniels, Matthew and The Atlas' Emma Gatrill, Marcus Hamblett of Bear's Den, The Staves, and Daughter's Elena Tonra.
Louis Jones' debut release of pop rock was produced by Richard Formby.
The latest album for the singer-songwriter is 12 tracks (14 on the deluxe edition or 15 with the iTunes bonus track) of traditional and original holiday songs.
The latest album for Canada's Hot Hot Heat is its first since leaving Warner Music and since bassist Dustin Hawthorne's departure from the band.
Gym Class Heroes' Travie McCoy releases his debut solo album featuring guest appearances by Cee Lo Green, Bruno Mars, Tim Williams, Colin Munroe, T-Pain and Young Cash.

The dark, proggy, hugely-popular alt-metal outfit fronted by Maynard James Keenan returns with that rarest of things: a new Tool album. It's the band's first release in five years and just their fourth full-length in their 16-year history.
The fourth full-length release for the Texas-based psychedelic rock band was produced by John Congleton.
The Canadian rock band releases its second album produced by David Schiffman.
The singer's first album in eight years includes instrumental help from Jon Brion and Matt Chamberlain, as well as guitarist Harper (son of Paul) Simon.
This is the second collaboration between Moonface (aka Spencer Krug) and the Finnish band Siinai.
This is the debut full-length release for the London-based electro-pop trio of Olly Alexander, Mikey Goldsworthy, and Emre Turkmen.
The first full-length solo release in over six years for the singer-songwriter was co-produced with James Barone and Patrick Meese.
The second album from the Canadian group was inspired by end of the romantic relationship between band members Daniel Lee and April Aliermo.
The jazz trio introduces vocals by Wendy Lewis on its latest album of cover songs.
Mos Def and Jean Grae guest on Kweli's third solo outing.
The third full-length release for the Danish artist MØ features production from Ariel Rechtshaid, Jam City, SG Lewis, Lotus IV, Sly, Stint, Ronni Vindahl, Linus Wiklund and Yangze.
Featuring influences from country, hip-hop and R&B, the two-disc release for the British band led by Mike Scott was recorded in Dublin and Tokyo.
The sophomore album for the Brooklyn, New York band now includes Ryan Sawyer as its full-time drummer.
The former A Camp and Cardigans singer releases her first solo release under her real name.
The pop singer reworked some of her biggest hits with an orchestra at London's Abbey Road Studios.
There is no irony in the title of Eddie Vedder's first solo album: These are indeed songs performed on a ukulele.

recordname: You Can't Take It With You
description: This is the second album for the Long Island indie rock band.
The tenth full-length studio release for the British rock band was produced by Bob Rock.
The debut full-length release for the British-based trio of Luís Santos, Guro Gikling, and Rich O'Flynn was produced by Dan Carey.
This is the debut album for the Portland, Oregon rock band.
The sophomore album for the Austin, Texas band was produced by Erik Wofford.
The Melvins' King Buzzo and Dale Crover team up with Mr. Bungle bassist Trevor Dunn as Melvins Lite for this release.
The debut studio album for the Decatur, Georgia-born rapper features guest appearances from Drake, R. Kelly, Juicy J, T.I., Trae, and Snoop Dogg.
The second album for the rock quartet was produced with Phil Ek.
The third full-length release for the Philadelphia alternative rock band led by Sean Miller was produced by Peter Mavrogeorgis.
The fifth full-length release for Jonathan Rado and Sam France was self-produced and mixed by Shawn Everett.
The debut full-length release for the Welsh singer-songwriter Catherine Ann Davies was co-produced with Paul Draper.
The latest solo release for the veteran pop singer was produced by Steven Van Zandt and features original songs written by Elvis Costello, Bruce Springsteen, and Van Zandt.
The debut album for the North Carolina singer who wrote songs for several television shows, including "Beverly Hills, 90210" and "How I Met Your Mother."
The second release under the Deutsche Grammophon label from Tori Amos contains 14 [15 on the deluxe editions] of her songs reworked with the Metropole Orchestra conducted by Jules Buckley.
The 38th full-length studio release for the Belfast-born singer-songwriter features jazz and vocal standards as well as three new songs.
The first release of original songs from the country singer since 2001's Scarecrow was produced by Mark Miller.
Primarily known as the lead singer/guitarist of Hootie & the Blowfish, Darius Rucker continues his crossover to pop-country with his second release since his Capitol Nashville debut.
The debut collaboration between Neil Finn and his son Liam features contributions from Neil's wife (and Liam's mother) Sharon, Liam's brother Elroy, Connan Mockasin, and Mick Fleetwood.
The fifth full-length studio release for the Sacramento harcore punk band features guest appearances from King Rule and Wiki.

The third album from the London-based duo of Richard Fearless and Tim Holmes, much like its predecessor (1999's 'Contino Sessions'), mixes electronica and rock with a variety of celebrity guests handling vocals. This time out, the voices come from Hope Sandoval, Paul Weller, Dot Allison and Liam Gallagher.
Stephin Merritt (Magnetic Fields, Future Bible Heroes, Gothic Archies, The 6ths) provides the low-key score to the James Bolton indie film, consisting of 10 instrumental and 6 vocal tracks.

The New Orleans rapper returns with his first album since the success of his 2000 single "Shake Ya Ass." The Neptunes return to produce two tracks, with Timbaland, Rockwilder, and others filling out the production duties.
This is the first new album for the UK act since 1992's 'Connected.'
Produced by Ted Hutt, the 10th full-length studio release for the folk punk band features guest appearances from Stefan Janoski and Tom Verlaine.
The second full-length release for the Australian electro-pop duo continues the post-apocalyptic saga begun in 2008's Walking On A Dream.
The fourth full-length solo studio release for the Soundgarden frontman was produced by Brendan O'Brien.

The second full-length studio release for the Diplo project features guest appearances from such artists as Amber of Dirty Projectors, Ezra Koenig of Vampire Weekend, Wyclef Jean, Bruno Mars, Santigold, Shaggy, Tyga, and Yasmin.
Chris Carrabba returns to acoustic rock on the band's fifth album.
The third full-length release for the synth-pop artist was self-produced with some assistance from Dan Carey.

recordname: Wham! Bang! Pow! Let's Rock Out!
description: The first new full-length release for the art pop band in seven years was produced by Jim Moray.
The sixth full-length studio release for the Welsh post-hardcore band is its first with new drummer, Pat Lundy.
Yellow Ostrich began as a solo project for Alex Schaaf, but for his third album, the band has expanded to become a trio.
The sixth release for the Scottish rock trio was produced by Garth "GGGarth" Richardson.
The Canadian artist's sixth full length album.
The fourth full-length release for Alabama soul group St. Paul & the Broken Bones was recorded in Birmingham and was produced by Matt Ross-Spang.
The Dinosaur Jr and Sebadoh band member returns to release his latest solo album produced by Andrew Murdock.
The debut full-length studio release for the Southern California indie pop artist was self-produced.
Electronic producer Scott Heren's seventh album focuses on female vocals and infuses dreamlike psychedelia into the electronic symphony.
The Canadian singer-songwriter from the folk trio Be Good Tanyas includes soul music influences on her first solo album.
This is the debut album for the New York City indie quintet.
The Los Angeles-based electronic duo of Patricia Hall and Ian Hicks self-produced and recorded their second full-length release.

recordauthor: Working for a Nuclear Free City
description: The third full-length album for the Manchester, England, rock band is another two-disc release, featuring 17 songs on one disc and the 33-minute title track on the second.
The Sri Lankan-born, UK-based rapper releases her third album of eclectic, bold beats featuring production by Blaqstarr, Switch, and Diplo.
The second full-length release for Foxygen drummer Shaun Fleming as Diane Coffee was inspired by his move to Bloomington, Indiana.
The English singer was named the Brit Awards' Critics' Choice even before her debut album was released.

The first full-length studio release in six years from the San Francisco-based alternative rock band led by Les Claypool and its first with original drummer Tim Alexander since 1995's Tales From The Punchbowl.
The second full-length solo release for the Animal Collective co-founder was recorded by Josh Dibb (Deakin) with contributions from Angel Deradoorian, Eyvind Kang and Jessika Kenney,
This is the debut full-length release for the Norwegian pop group that can include up to twelve band members.
The eighth full-length release from the Portland, Oregon quintet was inspired by classic and southern rock.
Douglas McCombs of Tortoise returns to his side project with a new band that includes Pete Croke, Chris Hansen, and James Elkington for his fourth release.
The fifth full-length release for the electronic French artist is a largely instrumental album that includes contributions from Cassius producer Phillipe Dzar and drummer Tony Allen.
This is the debut album for Julie Ann Baenziger, who wrote, sang, and played all the instruments on the release.
This is the first full-length release for the Minnesota rock band led by Jordan Gatesmith.
The third studio album for the British band was produced by Dan the Automator.

The latest album for the British electronic duo features guest appearances by Mark Lanegan, Gavin Clark, Elle J, South's Joel Cadbury, Celebration's Katrina Ford, Autolux, Sleepy Sun, The Black Angels, and Big In Japan.
The latest studio album for Alison Goldfrapp and producer Will Gregory finds the duo moving away from the more ambient sound of 2008's "Seventh Tree."
This is the first release on Fat Possum Records for the San Diego-based indie-rock artist.
The second full-length release for the indie rock supergroup that includes Kurt Bloch, Peter Buck, Scott McCaughey, Linda Pitmon, and Corin Tucker was co-produced by Bill Rieflin.
The second collection of covers by the Boston alternative rock band led by Evan Dando was produced by Matthew Cullen.
The debut full-length release for the British pop singer-songwriter features a guest appearance from Hailee Steinfeld.

The second full-length studio release for the New York City-based rapper features guest appearances from Alkaline, Marc E. Bassy, Chinx, Fe, Future, Kid Daytona, Max B, Ziico Niico, Quavo, Travis Scott, Rae Sremmurd, Swae Lee, T.I., The Weeknd, Pharrell Williams, and Young Thug.
The fourth full-length solo release for the British singer-songwriter features a cover of xx's Angelsand was produced with Simon Byrt.
The second full-length release for the British metal band was produced by James Sclavunos.
The fourth release from the Seattle indie folk rock band was produced by Phil Ek.
Conrad Lambert worked with producer Matthew Herbert on his fourth full-length release.
The British boy band releases its second full-length release featuring production and songs written by such artists as Ed Sheeran, Carl Falk, Rami Yacoub, Savan Kotecha, Max Martin, and Dr. Luke.
The fifth release for the R&B singer features guest appearances by Tim McGraw and Wiz Khalifa.

This studio compilation album features artists from the G.O.O.D. Music label and guest appearances from others including: Kanye West, Jay Z, Ghostface Killah, Raekwon, Push T, R. Kelly, Common, Kid Cudi, 2 Chainz, Big Sean, DJ Khaled, Ma$e, and Teyana Taylor.
The British duo of Dean Blunt and Inga Copeland releases its fourth album together.
The electronic UK producer duo of Joe Ray and Dan Stephens, with guest vocalist Alana Watson, releases its debut full-length album.
Human sexuality and reproduction are the central themes of the concept album from the Oklahoma rock band led by Ryan Hendrix.
The debut album for the British indie quintet was produced by Paul Epworth.
Jimmy Eat World's seventh album was produced by Mark Trombino, who also produced 1999's Clarity and 2001's Bleed American.
The latest album for Jason Beck and produced with Boys Noize shares the same name as the film starring his alter ego Chilly Gonzales, Feist, Peaches, and Tiga.
Fin Greenall releases his third album under the alias Fink.
This is the third solo album for the British singer-songwriter.
This is the latest album for the indie rock trio from Portland, Oregon.
The second album for the experimental rock trio was recorded near Yosemite.
The latest album for the New Zealand-born country singer was produced with Dann Huff.
'Songs' (one of two April 2006 releases) is the former Television frontman's first vocal release in sixteen years. Television's Fred Smith guests.
The guitarist pays homage to legendary bluesman Robert Johnson with these 14 covers.

Originally intended as a loose, spontaneous recording called 'Get Back,' 'Let It Be' was eventually released (after the band's breakup) after being shelved and then reproduced/enhanced by Phil Spector, leaving many fans (and an angry Paul McCartney) wondering, "what if?" This new release answers that question to a certain extent, with an altered track listing (which adds "Don't Let Me Down") containing some de-Spectorized versions as well as some originals that have been remixed and remastered.
The former Eurythmics' singer's third solo album is her first collection of original songs since 1992's 'Diva.'
The Indiana rocker returns with his very first covers album, with versions of 12 roots/blues tunes.
M. Ward and the Kronos Quartet are among the guests on the singer's third album.

A better album title would have been 'Nancy Sinatra & Friends,' as the 64-year-old singer collaborates with fans such as Morrissey, Pulp's Jarvis Cocker and Richard Hawley, Sonic Youth's Jim O'Rourke and Thurston Moore, Jon Spencer, Pete Yorn and U2.
The Brooklyn rock band's full-length debut was written and recorded in Delaware.
The sixth studio album for the New York rapper features Byrd Lady, Skitzo, 40 Cal., C.O., and Sky Lyn as guests.

recordname: Let's Face the Music and Dance
description: The latest release from the country singer with his backing band, the Family, includes covers of classic country and standard songs.
Ramona Gonzalez first release in four years as Nite Jewel was self produced and on her own label.
This is the fourth studio album for the French music producer.
Band member Adam Schlesinger produced FOW's long-awaited fourth studio album, which follows four years after their breakthrough hit 'Welcome Interstate Managers.'
This is the third full-length release for the electronic producer Hannes Norrvide.
The debut release for the North Carolina singer includes influences from kraut, pop, psych and punk music.
The latest compilation features rare and unreleased remixes produced by Mathematics.

Adam Landry and Justin Collins produced the debut album from the indie "supergroup" that includes John McCauley and Robbie Crowell of Deer Tick, Steve Berlin of Los Lobos, Hardy Morris of Dead Confederate, Ian Saint Pe of the Black Lips, and Bryan Dufresne of Six Finger Satellite.

Elements of folk-rock, psychedelic rock, Persian, Indian, and Eastern European music are found on the debut full-length release from the Seattle rock septet led by Chris Cheveyo and produced by Randall Dunn.
The second full-length release for the indie band led by Louis Jones was produced by Girls bassist, JR White.
The fifth full-length release for the indie punk band led by Patrick Stickles features a cover of Bob Dylan's "(I'm) Like a Rolling Stone" and was produced by Kevin S. McMahon.
The third album for the Swedish indie rock quintet was produced by Phil Ek.

Ever since the dawn of the electric guitar, white boys have sung the blues, some with considerably more success than others. Eli âPaperboyâ Reed is part of that long tradition, but he stands apart from the pack as much as he belongs to it, due in large part to his age. Raised on CD reissues of classic blues and soul -- he was not even 10 when the first Complete Stax/Volt Singles box came out -- Reed has absorbed the sound and sensibility of classic â60s soul but sings without any white-boy blues affectations, totally comfortable in his own skin because nobody else his age, of any race, was attempting to make this kind of music. This can cause a kind of a disconnect -- Reed sounds so white when he sings, itâs disarming -- but he pours on the passion and has fully absorbed the tight turns of Stax and loves the sound as much as the structure, so much so that Come and Get It -- his third LP and first for a major label -- feels a bit like an unearthed relic, built on songs and sounds that could pass for unheard gems if it wasnât for Reedâs unapologetically white voice, free of affectations and ticks. Some of that may be due to producer Mike Elizondoâs work -- he manages to make this sound like a throwback without being stiff, and without having a hint of Mark Ronsonâs hipster retroism for Amy Winehouse -- but heâs just articulating Reedâs gifts, letting the songs stand front and center. And thatâs whatâs remarkable about Come and Get It: this is not a modern-day blues album, itâs a classic soul album, with almost all the tracks clocking in at 3:30 or less, leaving very little room for showboating solos. All concentration is on the tunes themselves, with the band kicking them toward kineticism, Reed channeling all his energy into making the songs sing, and they wind up sticking, sounding a bit like forgotten classics upon first listen, then winding up as familiar favorites upon the second. If there is any fault here, itâs that Reedâs voice remains perennially boyish, sometimes preventing this from achieving a level of gravity, but thereâs no attempt to hide this: itâs an honest reflection of who Reed is, a young kid from Boston in love with the Southern sounds of the â60s and intent on carrying them on, even if he invites ridicule or scorn. He believes it, man, and based on Come and Get It, itâs hard not to believe it too. ~ Stephen Thomas Erlewine
The sixth full-length studio release album for the R&B singer features guest appearances from Justin Bieber, Juicy J, Mila J, Nicki Minaj, and Ty Dolla $ign.
The debut release from the British sisters Hannah and Colette Thurlow was produced by Rob Ellis.
The Texas trio's debut album is dreamy mix of shoegaze, noise pop, and heavily-textured rock, drawing comparisons to My Bloody Valentine and The Jesus and Mary Chain.
The sophomore album for the Swedish band was produced by Emanuel Lundgren and Fabian "Phatfabe" Torsson.
This companion to the original 'Suitcase' continues where that box set left off, packing 100 more GBV rareties and outtakes from the now-disbanded group onto four discs.
This is the debut full-length release for the Ben Schneider folk rock project.

The third studio release for the Diplo's dancehall trio features collaborations and guest appearances from from 2 Chainz, Chronixx, DJ Snake, Ellie Goulding, Elliphant, Mad Cobra, MØ, Nyla, Pusha T, Tarrus Riley, Jovi Rockwell, Travi$ Scott, and Wild Belle.
A concept album set in an alternate version of the U.S. where the states are actually countries, 'New Roman Times' marks the first studio album in 15 years for the newly-reunited California band.
The Chicago post-rock instrumentalists add vocals (courtesy of Kelly Hogan) into the mix for the first time on this, their fifth LP.
The mellow UK electronic outfit (who have been compared to artists such as Morcheeba and Air) follows up 2001 debut 'Simple Things' with this 11-track effort.

Folkie Dar Williams returns with her sixth album, which is perhaps her most diverse and fullest-sounding yet, enhanced by the presence of a host of contributors including Alison Krauss, John Medeski, Bela Fleck, and John Popper.

Brokeback is a side project for Eleventh Dream Day/Tortoise bassist Douglas McCombs (joined semi-permanently by second bassist Noel Kupersmith), supplemented here on this third album by Laetitia Sadier and the late Mary Hansen from Stereolab.
Jack Dangers returns with his first Meat Beat Manifesto album since 1998's 'Actual Sounds and Voices.' The Orb's Dr. Alex Paterson and turntablist Z-Trip guest.
The 17-year-old Canadian singer-songwriter-skater nails the adult alternative Michelle Branch/Jewel/Alanis Morissette sound on this debut album, featuring her breakout hit single "Complicated."

Believe it or not, this is indeed a brand-new album from L.A.'s Go-Go's -- their first in 17 years, to be exact. The original lineup (including Belinda Carlisle and Jane Wiedlin) is intact for this 13-track outing, produced by Paul Kolderie and Sean Slade (Hole, Radiohead). Green Day's Billie Joe Armstrong is featured on the first single, "Unforgiven."

Perhaps the former Talking Head's best solo work since 1994's 'David Byrne,' 'Look Into The Eyeball' features 12 tracks and, as expected, numerous musical styles. NRU from Cafe Tacuba guests on the Spanish-language track "Desconocido Soy."
The Chicago band's third album marks their Matador debut. John Agnello (Dinosaur Jr.) produces.
The ninth studio release from the singer-songwriter was produced by Jamie Candiloro.
The Swedish trio releases its fifth album.
The first release in nearly a decade for the pop group formed in London features production from Fred Ball, James Draper, The Invisible Men, K-Gee, James Draper, and The Rural.
The second and last release for the Seattle-based psych-rock band was produced by Randall Dunn.
The fifth studio release for the indie rock duo Keith Murray and Chris Cain was produced by Chris Coady.
The second full-length release for the Brooklyn-based indie quartet was produced by band member Fraser McCulloch.
The solo debut album for Former Arab Strap guitarist Malcolm Middleton was produced by Paul Savage and features drumming from fellow Arab Strap partner, Aidan Moffat.
The latest album for the Grammy-winning South African a cappella group looks back on the songs group leader Joseph Shabalala sang as a child.
The former member of Roxy Music brings his ambient melodies back with a new album, featuring spoken word from Rick Holland.
The second release for the British quartet is a mini-album about gender and features three instrumental tracks.

Grace Potter's second solo release (her first since forming The Nocturnals) was produced by Eric Valentine and features contributions from her bandmates as well as Rayland Baxter, Wayne Coyne of The Flaming Lips, Audra Mae, Nick Oliveri of Queens Of The Stone Age, and Noelle Skaggs of Fitz & The Tantrums.
This is the solo debut release for the former Mmoss guitarist following the end of the psych rock band with Rachel Neveu.
This is the latest release from the Los Angeles-based electronic producer.
The first release in nine years for Neil Young and his band Crazy Horse is an album of classic American folk songs.
The latest album for the actor/hip-hop artist features guest appearances from Eve, Flo Rida, Lil' Kim, Ne-Yo, Trey Songz, and Trina.
The debut album for the model-turned-singer-songwriter was produced by her husband, Jack White.
The follow-up to the band's Mercury Prize-winning 2007 debut album Myths Of The Near Future was produced by Ross Robinson.
The second full-length release for Julian Casablancas and the band was produced by Shawn Everett and its first as The Voidz (dropping "Julian Casablancas+").
The 12 unreleased recordings by rock legend Jimi Hendrix include new versions of songs that were under consideration to be included on a follow-up to 1968's "Electric Ladyland."
The sixth album for the rapper features such diverse guests as Ving Rhames, Rick Ross, Chris Rock, Spike Lee, T.I., T-Pain, Jay-Z, Nas, Chris Brown, and Jamie Foxx.

The final release for the Texan blues guitarist who passed away in July 2014 features guest appearances from Joe Bonnamassa, Eric Clapton, Dr. John, Ben Harper, Billy Gibbons, Paul Nelson, Joe Perry, Brian Setzer, and Leslie West.

The soundtrack features several cover songs and songs written by Beck for the movie based on the comic book about a young Canadian bass player named Scott Pilgrim who meets the perfect girl but soon discovers he must fight her seven exes.
The Canadian indie rock band releases its first full-length album after two well-received EPs.
Former Beach Fossils bassist John Pena releases his debut full-length album under the name Heavenly Beat.

Snow Patrol's Gary Lightbody gathers together fellow band member Iain Archer, R.E.M.'s Peter Buck, Scott McCaughey, Belle & Sebastian's Richard Colburn, Garret "Jacknife" Lee, and Troy Stewart to record a country-inspired album.
Steve Fisk produced this sophomore set for the--dare we say it--cinematic Los Angeles-based band, now a four-piece after the departure of co-founder Jason Hammons and the addition of two new members.
The third full-length solo release for the pop singer features guest appearances from Big Sean, Tove Lo and Ty Dolla $ign.
The debut solo release for the Doves frontman was produced with Dan Austin.
The Texan folk singer--one of the founding members of The Be Good Tanyas--returns with her fourth studio album, which combines traditional folk with country and rock.
The Ohio's trio's latest album was recorded on VHS tape.
The second full-length release for the Austin trio was written while singer/guitarist Nate Grace was recovering from a serious leg injury.
The 10th studio release for the indie rock band is an album of re-recordings of older rare tracks.
The first album in over 20 years for the British rock band is also their last.
Produced by Thomas Bartlett, Glen Hansard returns after his success with Frames, the Swell Season, and the Once soundtrack/musical score, with his first solo album.
Alec Ounsworth, the sole member of the indie rock band remaining, worked with Nick Krill on the CYHSY's fifth full-length release.
The people (Akiva Schaffer, Jorma Taccone, and Andy Samberg) behind the "Dick In A Box" song/video on Saturday Night Live releases their debut album.

Yes, it 'has been' a long time since the last William Shatner album (and with good reason), but the veteran recording artist returns for this collaboration with Ben Folds. Other guests include Joe Jackson, Aimee Mann and Adrian Belew, but sadly, no Leonard Nimoy.

The soul singer's latest release marks her 25th year as a recording artist (she made her debut in 1979 as a member of the first female rap group ever, Sequence). Guests here include Missy Elliott, Floetry and Snoop Dogg.

Bobby Gillespie and co. follow 2000's widely acclaimed 'XTRMNTR' with a similar blend of Stooges-style rock and electronica, thanks to the production work of semi-official Primal Scream member Kevin Shields (formerly of My Bloody Valentine) and Andy Weatherall. Tracks include first single "Miss Lucifer," "City," a remake of a Gillespie-sung track on David Holmes' most recent album, and "Some Velvet Morning," sung as a duet with supermodel Kate Moss.

Aw... little Justin's all grows up. First Mickey Mouse Club, then 'NSync, and now this, his solo debut. Can he be a success on his own? Well, having Timbaland and The Neptunes along as his producers certainly won't hurt.

2001 gave us The White Stripes and The Strokes; 2002 gives us The Hives and The Vines. This Australian four-piece outfit is the latest rock band to be hyped to stratospheric proportions (and an instant major-label contract) by the UK rock press, who compared the Vines to Nirvana (the band, not the concept). But although the Aussies did indeed get their start as a Nirvana cover band, there is a bit more to their debut album 'Highly Evolved' than Grunge, Part 2.

This high-energy dance album from the Australian veteran includes the UK hit single "Can't Get You out of My Head." It is her first American release since 1988, although she has retained her popularity in Europe and her native Australia since the 1980's, updating her sound along the way.

The Magnetic Fields' Stephin Merritt returns with a second disc under The 6ths nameplate (following 1995's Wasps' Nests). Like its predecessor, this album features original Merritt compositions sung by guest vocalists, including Gary Numan, Sarah Cracknell, Marc Almond, Bob Mould, and Sally Timms.
After ending a 22-year hiatus in 2010, the legendary rock band returns on this reunion album, featuring their familiar mix of psychedelic pop and new wave.
The debut album for the rock band led by Michael Benjamin Lerner was produced by Death Cab For Cutie's Chris Walla.

recordname: Fold Your Hands Child, You Walk Like A Peasant

description: The first full-length solo release on Deutsche Grammophon for British composer/pianist Roger Eno features the German string ensemble Scoring Berlin.
The sudden death of a close friend was an influence on the follow-up to the Canadian band's 2011 Polaris Music Prize long-listed debut release, Too Beautiful to Work.
This is the debut for the Toronto six-piece led by Adrian Jewett.
Big Sean, Drake, Ludacris, and Nicki Minaj guest on the third full-length album from the Canadian pop singer.
The debut album for the singer-songwriter was produced with Greg Kurstin and Joe Goddard.
The fourth release for Jimmy Tamborello as Dntel includes guest vocals from Will Wiesenfeld (also known as Baths) and Nite Jewel.
Glen Ballard produces the ex-Eurythmics singer's fourth album.

recordname: Time as We Know It: The Songs of Jerry Jeff Walker
description: The latest album from Todd Snider is a tribute album to Jerry Jeff Walker.
After a successful solo turn, lead singer Fyfe Dangerfield returns to his indie rock band to release its third full-length release.
The latest release for the Athens, Georgia-based post-rock quartet was self-produced by the band and recorded by Mike Albanese.

The third set of covers from Matthew Sweet and Susanna Hoffs is a collection of songs from the 1980s including covers of R.E.M.s Sitting Still, The Smiths' How Soon is Now, and Kirsty MacColls They Dont Know.

recordauthor: ...And You Will Know Us by the Trail of Dead
description: The sixth full-length album for the rock band from Texas is its first on the Richter Scale/Justice label.
Los Angeles rapper Regan Farquhar returns with an album produced by Boom Bip and DJ Nobody.
As its first independently released album, Weezer still remains true to form with a collection of Pinkerton-esque pop rock.
This third LP is the first release since 2004 for the Texas-based choral/symphonic rock group fronted by Tim DeLaughter.
The Wales-born Greek singer-songwriter releases her debut full-length album.
The fourth full-length release from the Atlanta rapper features a guest appearance by The Weeknd and was a surprise release after announcing it two days prior.
The second full-length solo release for The Smashing Pumpkins lead singer under his full name was recorded in Chicago and Nashville.

The 15th full-length release for the British singer-songwriter was produced by Paul Samwell-Smith and features guitarist Alun Davie, who both worked on some of the artist's 1970s albums released under the Cat Stevens name.
The fifth studio album for the R&B singer features guest appearances from Diddy, Lil Wayne, Meek Mill, Rick Ross, T.I., and Young Jeezy.
"Drastic Fantastic" is KT's studio follow-up to her successful debut CD.
The 13th full-length studio release for the pop artist features guest appearances from Chance The Rapper, Nicki Minaj, Nas, and Mike Tyson.

recordname: The Blue Ridge Rangers Rides Again
description: The ex-Creedence Clearwater Revival guitarist releases his latest solo album, a sequel of sorts to his first solo album (he doesn't play all the instruments himself as he did in his debut.)
The debut full-length release for the indie duo of Ryan Needham and Liza Violet was produced by MJ of Hookworms.

recordname: Peanut Butter And Jelly Live At The Ginger Minge
description: This is the third studio album (don't believe the title) for the San Francisco punkers.
The covers album from the Green Day frontman features songs he released during the COVID-19 lockdown on YouTube.

The latest release from the sludge-metal pioneers features six different bassists: current drummer Dale Crover, Mr. Bungle's Trevor Dunn, Redd Kross' Steven McDonald, ex-Nirvana Krist Novoselic, Butthole Surfers' Jeff Pinkus, and Big Business' Jared Warren.
The second full-length solo release was self-produced by the former Oasis singer/guitarist and features a guest appearance from Johnny Marr.
The ninth full-length release [and its third for Kompakt] for the Icelandic electronic quartet includes influences from synth pop, trance and UK garage music.

recordname: Still Within the Sound of My Voice
description: Produced by Fred Molin, the latest release from the singer-songwriter features guest appearances from such artists as Joe Cocker, David Crosby, Art Garfunkel, Amy Grant, Kris Kristofferson, Lyle Lovett, Graham Nash, Carly Simon, Keith Urban and Brian Wilson.
The New York band returns after five years to release its fifth album.
The sixth solo studio release for the rapper features guest appearances from such artists as Big Sean, French Montana, Jay-Z, Lil Wayne, Meek Mill, Scarface, The Weeknd, and Kanye West.
This is the fifth LP in 15 years for the veteran hip-hop unit of Grand Puba, Lord Jamar and Sadat X.
This is the veteran Australian band's 17th album.

'Imperial' marks the first-ever solo release for the Cocteau Twins' guitarist (who also runs record label Bella Union, works as a record producer, and is one-half of the band Violet Indiana). This ten-track instrumental disc sounds a lot like his work with that earlier band.

This is the first album in nine years for the reunited Los Angeles alternative act, featuring three original members Johnette Napolitano, Jim Mankey and Harry Rushakoff. The 12 new tracks here include "Roxy," a tribute to Roxy Music.

The French indie-electronica band made waves with their 1998 debut 'Moon Safari,' but since then their only release has been the motion picture score to Sofia Coppola's "The Virgin Suicides." The wait for their true sophomore album is over with the release of '10,000 Hz Legend,' which includes guest vocal contributions from Beck and Buffalo Daughter.
The first new studio release of new songs from the Chicago R&B/funk artist since 2007 was co-produced by Sarah Ruba and David "Switch" Taylor.
The Icelandic band's 1997 debut album received its first international release in 2004.
The third full-length release for the Chicago-area garage rock band was produced by Jim Abbiss.
The Nebraskan singer-songwriter recorded this seventh album in his new home of Spain.
The debut release for Tricky's side project features guest appearances from Francesca Belmonte, Ivy, DJ Milo, Oh Land, and Xdare.
The first volume of an archival series titled Willie's Stash features the collaboration of the country singer with his older sister Bobbie with some of Willie's catalog and cover songs.
A member of the band Jealous Girlfriends, the singer returns with a debut full-length solo album produced by TV On The Radio's Dave Sitek.
The fourth full-length release for the Spanish electronic pop band includes a guest appearance of Chairlift's Caroline Polachek.
'National Anthem' is the second album for the Canadian band led by Andrew Whiteman, also a guitarist in Broken Social Scene.
The ninth full-length release for the North Carolina band was produced by Rick Rubin.
The latest release from Robert Pollard's prolific indie rock band sees the return of drummer Kevin March.
This is the second full-length release for Los Angeles-based producer Mtendere Mandowa.
The third release from the Portland, Oregon-based garage pop band is its first on the Woodsist label.

recordname: When Life Gives You Lemons, You Paint That Shit Gold
description: The latest album for the hip-hop duo from Minneapolis also includes a book written by Slug with the deluxe edition release.
The country singer follows her disappointing sophomore set with this third album, which includes multiple co-writes with John Rich (of Big & Rich).
This is the fourth solo release for the former member of the Moldy Peaches.
The third full-length release for the Swedish indie pop band features a guest appearance from Charli XCX.
This is the second full-length album for Jesy Fortino, the singer-songwriter based in Seattle, Washington.

Produced by Justin Vernon, the latest release for the gospel group features guest appearances from Sam Amidon, Phil Cook of Megafaun, Merrill Garbus of tUnE-yArDs, Patty Griffin, and Shara Worden of My Brightest Diamond.
The second solo release for Broken Social Scene's co-founder Brendan Canning was produced by Sarah Haywood and Steve Singh.
The debut solo album for the Irish singer, who has provided vocals on several of Damien Rice's albums.
Travis Stewart concludes his Vapor City concept with this latest full-length release.
The latest release for Sonic Youth's Lee Ranaldo includes the Dust, his new band that includes fellow Sonic Youth alum Steve Shelley, Alan Licht, and Tim Lüntze.
The second release for the Detroit rock band is its first with a smaller lineup--the five-piece band is now only three.
Andy Magoffin produced the fifth album for the Canadian indie folk band led by Tony Dekker.
The fifth full-length studio release for the alternative rock band led by Julian Casablancas.
The duo's second album is far more vocal-oriented, and darker, than their debut.

The 14th full-length studio release for the Long Beach rapper features guest appearances from E-40, Jazze Pha, Jeremih, October London, Suga Free, Swizz Beatz, Too $hort, Trick Trick, and Wiz Khalifa.
This is the debut full-length release for the electronic project of the New York electronic producer Mike Simonetti, Elizabeth Wight and Jana Hunter.
The full-length debut release from the French indie pop band was produced by Dan Levy.
The third album for the Los Angeles metal band was produced by Jeremy Mckinnon of A Day To Remember.
The third album for the rock band from England was produced by Garth "GGGarth" Richardson.
The 15th album was written entirely by the country singer from Georgia.
This is the debut full-length release for the British rock band founded by Ben Romans-Hopcraft and Leo Dobsen.
The Canadian singer-songwriter and Promise Of The Real return for a third full-length collaboration following 2015's The Monsanto Years and the 2016 live album, Earth.
The Occupy movement inspired band leader Al Jourgensen to resurrect the band after it had ended in 2008.
The official release of songs previously only sold on their tour.
Rob Schnapf and Jon Brion produced the for the Los Angeles band (and by "band" we really just mean Evan Slamka).
This lengthily-titled album marks a reunion for the band with producer David Kahne. Included here is a cover of Joe Jackson's "Is She Really Going Out With Him?"
Eve's third album finds the popular Philly rapper working with producers Dr. Dre, Irv Gotti and Swizz Beatz. Alicia Keys guests on one track.
Produced by Ross Robinson, 'Iowa' is the metal band's third album.
This is the third full-length for the British threesome. It debuted at #1 on the UK music charts.
The debut solo release for the former frontman for the indie band Girls traces the long-distance relationship he had with a woman named Lysandre.
The rock band releases a soundtrack to the 1934 movie "Man of Aran."
The second of Green Day's 2012 trilogy produced by Rob Cavallo is said to have garage rock influences.
The funk rock singer and multi-instrumentalist releases his ninth studio album.
This is the second full-length album for the hip-hop producer.
Having been compared to everyone from Norah Jones to Billy Joel, this singer-songwriter returns with her sophomore release that further exemplifies her musical talent and bold lyricism.

recordname: Time Is Over One Day Old
